I recommend buying this tamper RSVP Terry's Dual Sided Espresso Tamper and this metal frothing pitcher Update International (EP-12) 12 Oz Stainless Steel Frothing Pitcher. You'll get very skilled at making just the right combination of espresso to milk.

One note of caution! DO NOT tamp the espresso grounds too tightly! I did that and the machine nearly broke due to the inability for the water to get through the too tightly compressed grounds.

review_content: I have owned this Mr. Coffee espresso maker for about a month and, so far, it's working out wonderfully. It is obviously not the most expensive espresso maker one can buy, but, for the price, it's a great value. You cannot steam milk and brew espresso at the same time, as long as you work relatively quickly to assemble your drink, it's not a problem. It does not come with a tamper, but the scoop has a flat bottom that works fine for this purpose, no need to buy a tamper. I would recommend getting a stainless steel frothing pitcher, I tried with a number of pitchers I already owned, and none of them worked as well as the stainless steel version. Although I was never a Starbucks addict, if you are, this machine will pay for itself very quickly. After a couple of practice trials, I made lattes and espressos that taste better than what I can get at Starbucks. It does not take up very much counter space, which is a premium at our house. As long as this lasts a couple years, I don't think you'll regret buying this little guy.

review_content: So we had this great little Krups espresso maker that lasted for years with daily use, losing pieces and parts (i.e. the cover to the carafe), but still producing a great espresso for a little $5 find at a yard sale. When I couldn't find that particular machine any where, I thought I would try something similar with good ratings: Mr. Coffee's version. Right away we noticed that the espresso is not just weaker, but not as hot. It blows out espresso very quickly, and you have to really pay attention to be able to steam any milk. The wand is very inconveniently positioned, too, with a crappy plastic cover that is really kind of useless. Just really an all around weak espresso maker in every sense. I am by no means an expert, but we both miss our little Krups, and I realize now that it's time for a big girl's espresso maker. Live and learn! And get what you pay for...

review_content:
If you're looking for a good tasting espresso drink anywhere near cafe quality, this is NOT the machine for you. I had high hopes for this coffee machine since it was cheap. I would have been very happy with it if it only made good coffee. The controls are fine.
The frothing is OK. However, the "espresso" it produced was weak and bad tasting. This page advertises a 15-bar pump, but like another reviewer mentioned, there is no reference in the manual about a 15-bar pump. It's misleading as if it would produce a shot that is as good as other machines with 15-bar pumps. Also, the pictures of a full class of dark coffee is misleading. There is no way it could produce a cup that strong. You can tell when the coffee comes out that it's either 1) not applying enough pressure, 2) not applying enough pressure long enough, and/or 3) not wetting the puck like I've read it should do. You see a short squirt of dark coffee followed by a long stream of light brown coming out. We tried different grind sizes. We tried different beans. It always came out weak tasting like diner coffee. We returned our machine and plan on footing the bill for a better one. Check out the tech gear lab reviews and they make similar comments about the taste.
title: Get What You Pay For
bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Espresso/Cappuccino Maker

review_content: I received this as a gift and was extremely excited! But right from the beginning I was having trouble.  I figured it was a bit more intuitive and did not bother reading the manual. Definitely do so and do not skip the priming section. There was one thing that had me super frustrated and it was that there is a orange little water stopper in the bottom of the water reservoir that is not mentioned in the instruction manual. You have to remove it! Otherwise the water will not go through. The only reason I found this out was because I called a representative. As soon as I took that off everything was working perfectly. I wish they would've mentioned that in the instructions because it would've saved me a lot of time as I am sure other people have had the same frustrations. This coffee maker is amazing I was able to do an espresso cappuccino coffee latte and froth milk as much or as little as I wanted. I am very happy for having received this item and definitely think it's worth the money, my friend has one of those fancier thousand dollar coffee machines and it's the exact same thing. I'm sure that the quality of the material may be a little bit nicer but it gets the job done and the coffee taste the same.

review_content: The steamer doubles the volume of my milk by the time it's 100 degrees. The milk starts to bubble over the pitcher before it's even hot. There is no way to control the level of steam and prevent this from happening, so I usually just microwave my milk. One trick could be to microwave my milk and then add froth on top. Meh.... but the espresso part is good! I might invest in a heavier tamper.
title: Good espresso. Steamer is iffy.
bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Automatic Dual Shot

review_content:
I was surprised that this cheap little machine had higher ratings than so many more expensive models, so it seemed like a no-brainer. It arrived last week and so far, I'm very impressed. It makes good espresso and I'm especially impressed by how well it froths the milk. Steaming milk tends to be a noisy process, but this machine is the quietest I've used. It's also fast- I've typically started the milk in the microwave to speed up the process, but with this machine, it goes from fridge to frothy in only a couple minutes. The foam is also robust enough that the caramel sits on top before it settles down, which is more difficult to accomplish with the skim milk I use. The only drawback I've found is that the espresso is a little slow to start brewing, but that could be a result of the filtered water I use right out of the fridge. Overall, it seems to be a very good little machine and you can't beat the small footprint on the counter- a definite plus if you have limited counterspace like me.

An additional note- I haven't used plastic snap-on frothing tip yet, as I just haven't seen the need. Just make sure you clean off the steam arm carefully after each use, as in the past, I've found that any residue that develops quickly becomes impossible to remove. A wet paper towel used right after you finish does the trick.
title: Great little machine!
bought_model: Color: CappuccinoStyle Name: 4-Cup Steam

review_content:
I've had an old Starbucks Barista for 10 years. Hardly use it because the priming is a pain in the bum. Frothing the milk is even worse.
I wanted a new one that I would actually use, but felt guilty all of these years about buying another one...so expensive. I stumbled upon
this one surfing Amazon (now wish I'd of taken the BBandBeyond 20% coupon route...but oh well...I didn't know and could have saved
a few bucks...ANYWAY...this machine rocks. You have to prime it the first use...and clean AFTER use...but that is so easy to do because
hey, you have already had your coffee fix and have TONS of energy. LOL

Great machine, and I am bummed I waited so long for something I thought I couldn't afford. I had a Starbucks yesterday...and my cup
today was every bit as good with simple Costco Espresso Roast. What a steal.

One happy mama of two toddlers...YES!
title: Mr. Coffee, I don't care if people think you're cheap...I love you!
bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Espresso/Cappuccino Maker

review_content:
I was fighting some things on this but found a great video on Youtube. I think it has a cheaper model than this with the same type of dials and frothing wand. Just type "Make cheap Mocha with a $30 Espresso Machine ECM250".

I read through the instructions and gave her a try for the first time jamming the steam wand down into a coffee mug of milk. Wow, haha - like some buyer mentioned in here about getting nothing but boiling milk was a true enough statement and burned myself along the way, my hands and fingers were splattered with boiling milk all over the place! Keep in mind, I've NEVER done this or even seen someone do it. Oh, and taking off the top without depressurizing it when I shouldn't was another learning curve, it burned my fingers AGAIN. Anyways, I couldn't get the micro-foam until I did some research and watched several videos on You Tube about how to do it. So, I tossed and turned about this my first night of ownership and woke with determination! Oh... did I earn some kisses from my bride when she was licking the spoon from a cup of Micro-Foam, and yes, from 2% milk, not whole milk as was mentioned in many of the videos to use.

Micro-Foam:
I had ordered the 20oz Stainless Steel Frothing cup with a Temperature Gauge and proceeded to make it happen! Like me, if you don't know how to do this, you need a temp gauge. But, using a cold cup with cold milk about 10oz, half the container inserting the steaming wand all the way down and let it set, gently moving the cup up and down. When bubbles start, just put the wand in as deep as it will go. The steam wand IS short and close to the sides of the machine, but making do and using all my senses began to notice when the milk hits about 90 degrees a sweet spot begins form (funny sounding noise) that can be massaged until the temp hits 155 degrees tops. IMMEDIATELY take the brown wand extension off and drop it into some water, wipe the wand with a wet towel. Tap the mug on the counter if any large bubbles are present and whirl the frothing cup.

Espresso:
I need some better grounds than pre-ground stuff. "Pending"
title: ECM160 - 4 Cup - Nice Nice & Nice
bought_model: Color: CappuccinoStyle Name: 4-Cup Steam

review_content: Used it once and the knob to turn on the machine melted off from the inside. The melted "plastic" was like cool got glue that was still liquid but you could touch it. I do not recommend it.
title: Melted knobs
bought_model: Color: CappuccinoStyle Name: 4-Cup Steam

review_content:
My husband loves this machine so much. We have been using bialetti moka. When we saw this machine, we were like.. "well, let's try this out." Although my hubby loves this so much, I prefer my old moka kettle for following reasons...
1. I don't know if I am using it in a wrong way (probably not), but it is not espresso. What you get is just regular dark coffee. It is not as dark as espresso is supposed to be. So if you make latte or americano, it will be very light.
2. Too much hassle to clean. Every time you brew and steam, you have to unplug the power to release the pressure, put more water to clean any left residue/debri.

Well, other than these reasons it is fairly easy to use and super cheap for an "espresso" machine. And takes a short time to get your coffee. You get what you pay for.

I will be using my moka until I get a real espresso machine for christmas.
title: we were like.. "well
bought_model: Color: CappuccinoStyle Name: 4-Cup Steam

review_content: I love this machine. A recipe book comes with it and I've been making all sorts of coffee drinks. Having a caramel latte at home at your convince is pure Bliss. I haven't had any problems with the milk dispenser, but I run the clean cycle after every or every other use.
title: Love this machine
bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Espresso/Cappuccino Maker

review_content:
I bought this Espresso Maker for my fianc√© who is a huge Espresso fan. My dad recommended it as he has the same one! It is great! Works perfectly every time, easy to clean, just a great addition to our kitchen (and parties). I definitely recommend it!

UPDATE 2/4/15:

We've been using the machine with NO issues at all for four months. Happy with every brew!

Today, after removing the brew basket / filter holder from the machine to dump the used grounds, there was a piece of plastic screw head stuck in the grounds. Basically, we discovered they use a plastic screw to secure the strainer through which the water seeps into the grounds before dripping into your cup. Our screw head had snapped off, leaving the remainder of the screw stuck up in the machine. I immediately called the warranty number listed in the manual for assistance. I thought they might be able to send us a new plastic screw and we'd be good to go. Turns out, it's not an issue they feel is "replaceable part-worthy," so they are sending us a brand new machine. So far, I'm pleased with the support we received and the ease of reporting the issue and getting it resolved. I was on the phone for maybe 5 minutes - total. She said nothing about them sending me a different model as other reviewers have mentioned. I'll update again once we receive the new machine, but I have high hopes for now!

I would still recommend this product today!
title: GREAT Espresso Maker
bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Automatic Dual Shot

review_content:
People who say their expresso coffee makers blew up on them,
must be idiots. It boils the water to produce steam and once
the steam is gone, so is the water. The steam either comes out
to steam coffer or to steam milk. There is no way, this could
blow up, even if it was plugged up, there wouldn't be enough
pressure to blow it up, no water left, no pressure.

THIS IS A GOOD EXPRESSO COFFEE MAKER and
should cost allot more. Enjoy, And don't worry about it
blowing up, can't be done.

UPDATE: You don't want to OVERPACK your coffee to hard, it will
create to much back pressure and steam will come out everywhere.

You do want to seat and seal the coffee pot handle, all the way to
the right, not just the middle or it will build up pressure and leak.

Turn it pass center and a little to the right, for a good seal.

Don't forget to turn it off and you might release the pressure, by
turning it to 'steam' for a 'few seconds' and then off.
title: For less than $40, this is a great expresso coffee maker!
bought_model: Color: CappuccinoStyle Name: 4-Cup Steam

review_content:
I've been using the Krups espresso machine for the last 5 years. It's been a great machine and definitely fulfilled my needs with coffee. However, one thing I wanted with a new espresso machine, was a milk steamer that worked and wouldn't break easily which is what would happen with my Krups machine. I've learned to microwave my milk or buy a separate milk frother which has worked fine. The reason I upgraded to the Mr. Coffee, was because a) I wanted a built in milk steamer and b), because I'm lazy, I wanted an apparatus that I didn't have to keep adding water to. That's definitely something that I like about this machine: you fill the water canister in the back and you don't have to refill it until after a few uses, which is great. Two things I don't like about this machine:
1) You can't just turn it on and forget about it and then come back to it a few minutes later and it has the right amount of espresso that you need. You have to babysit it and then turn off the machine when you think you've brewed enough. So, what's happening is that the espresso is actually a little too watery because I didn't turn it off at the right time. That's annoying.
2) Though the milk steamer works, it doesn't froth the way I always hope an attached frother would. I used to work in a restaurant and we made cappuccinos from time to time, and the steamer was just awesome. Sure, my expectations are too high with frothing milk as I'm sure the machine the restaurant had was maybe a thousand dollars or close to. Regardless, this is something I've come to terms with: I will never get a machine for less than $100 that will froth my milk the way I want it.
title: It's been a great machine and definitely fulfilled my needs with coffee
bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Automatic Dual Shot

review_content:
The machine isn't powerful enough to get a good cup of espresso out of it and it doesn't froth the milk it only slightly heats it up.

review_content:
Ah, the Mr. Coffee Cafe Barista Espresso Maker is a lovely modern kitchen device. The instructions are very clear on how to prime the machine and how to make espresso, cappuccinos or lattes. So, why couldn't I get it to work right???

I primed it twice, I kept pushing in the milk carafe, made sure milk was cold, let it cool off, tried again...After (4) tries I was about to give up. Luckily, my son found a little tube that had gone down the drain. It was a missing tube that helped with steaming the milk. The one thing I couldn't get to work! Apparently when I washed all the parts before priming the machine-unbeknownst to me, this little tube fell off.

So, yes, the machine works beautifully. It's quick & easy. (if you don't lose any parts!) It is noisy, but that's to be expected with the steam. It doesn't take up too much room on the counter either. Although this is a nice machine...I prefer the Mr. Coffee Latte Maker which lets me make decaf tea lattes in a snap. It's quieter too.

Overall, very nice machine if you like a strong espresso drinks.

review_content: I purchased this Mr Coffee Espresso maker so many years ago (at least 5) that I can't remember exactly how many.  At a price of $60+ back then, I did not expect a lot.  I figured if it made decent coffee and lasted a year, I would have gotten my money's worth.  5 plus years later, the little machine is still going strong.  I give it 5 stars for quality and durability vis a vis a very low price for an espresso machine.  I have had much more expensive machines that have had the pump go out within a couple of years.  This machine makes good coffee with a nice foam on top.  The frother is not a strong point of the machine.  I found it did not steam sufficiently and after a few seconds would start putting out a jet of hot water rather than steam. The design of the steaming arm also makes it difficult to clean.  If I had an option of 4.5 stars I might ding it half a star for that.  However, since I am primarily an espresso and Americano drinker, I do not use the steaming arm much.  When I want a latte, I heat the milk separately in a pan like a grew up doing.  The coffee the machine makes is hot and very good with a nice foam on top.  I always pour a double or triple shot and it takes approximately 30 seconds for the machine to warm up and another 30 seconds to pour my very large shot.  I have never had a leakage problem as reported by others.  One item that might contribute to the machine's longevity is that we have a reverse osmosis filter on our tap and I only use that water to fill the tank.  Therefore, I've had very little problem with any mineral build up and I've had to clean the machine much less often than I would have to if using regular tap water.  If you are looking for a truly affordable, dependable, basic espresso maker, this is a great choice.
title: Great quality and durability for the price.
bought_model: Color: CappuccinoStyle Name: 4-Cup Steam

review_content:
Bottom line:

I bought this item in 2007. It finally gave up the ghost in August, 2015. For the price, I'd say that's a pretty good return on my investment.

I used to spend around $60 a month for lattes at Starbucks. Then the light went off. I bought this unit because I couldn't afford anything more expensive. Except for the rattle (which I fixed with some electrical tape), it paid for itself in a month. And I get to use any flavor I can find, not just the Starbucks flavors.

Here's some advise for those giving it one or two stars: I clean mine about every six months with vinegar... just run a 16oz bottle through it multiple times. And I only use distilled water so the minerals don't build up in the system. I clean it after every use: blow the milk out of the steamer nozzle, then wipe it off (the metal tube), run a small amount of water through the brewing port to get the espresso gack out, and clean the espresso cup gasket EVERY TIME I USE IT. This keeps the rubber seal from breaking down.

My machine has finally decided to call it quits. Since I got 8 years of service out of this baby, I'm going to buy another. Now I can afford the $300 machines, but why go with an unknown when I can stick with something that will give me another 8 years?
title: I'd say that's a pretty good return on my investment
bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Automatic Dual Shot

review_content:
Ok, I'm not a coffee drinker--never had a cup in my life. But when my healthy 13 year-old daughter craves for a white chocolate mocha latte and keeps getting rung up Starbucks for $4.25 a pop, I decided it was time to explore options. I bought this, Starbucks ground espresso, Starbucks vanilla syrup and went to work. Set up was very easy, even for this non-coffee drinking Keurig operator. MOST IMPORTANTLY, I prepared my daughter's favorite iced white chocolate mocha latte and put it into her Starbucks tumbler she uses at the retail stores and brought up to her in the morning, with a "got you some Starbucks" as I handed her the coffee. She couldn't tell I made it. Brought her down later to see the machine that was bought for her and showed her how I made--happy, happy, happy! Ten cups into this, the ECMP 1000 has been great. We bought a 12 oz pkg of SBUX coffee and a 12 oz. bottle of the syrup. It looks like we will get at least 30 cups of coffee from each. The coffee was $7.00, milk for 30 cups another $7 and the syrup was $6.00--I know I overpaid on the syrup. However, the point is 30 X $4.00 at retail is $120, less the $19 cost of ingredients get me a savings of around $100, or $3 per day. With one latte coffee drinker, the breakeven versus Starbucks retail is around 40 days; 2 drinkers in your house brings the break even down to 20 days.Besides the economic slam-dunk, here are somes pros and cons.
Pros:
Simple to use, push buttons for large and small varieties of espresso, cappuccino and latte.
Easy to put together
No paper filters
Comes with everything you need to brew
Milk reservoir unplugs and can be refrigerated.

Cons (very picky list here):
Would like a separate one-button milk-only froth button (can be done with this unit, but I want a separate button-LOL)
The filter handle, once the espresso is in the filter and is being tightened into the holder is VERY tight--feels like I could break the handle. Even with level espresso in filter. Advice: use 90-95%% of filter capacity to reduce tightness to lock in filter.
Getting the right cup to fit in the drip zone is a little tricky because my 16 oz coffee mug barely fit and after a single shot latte, the froth is just over the edge of my mug I use to collect the latte before pouring it on the ice in a tumbler. I got lucky my 16 oz. fit.
title: Awesome!! Highly Recommended!! Payback For 1-A-Day Starbucks Latte Ritual Is Around 40 Days!!
bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Espresso/Cappuccino Maker

review_content: This espresso maker is great for the price. I have had this machine for almost two years now and it is still working great. There are a few tips I would like to share. A burr grinder is a must. The best setting on my Capresso grinder is the very first "extra fine" setting just in between "fine" and "extra fine." Next, pack the coffee in the filter fairly well. This takes some practice, too packed makes the coffee not come out. I would throw out the small filter and use only the large. When I make a 16 oz or 20 oz coffee, I use two large filter fulls. For the frothing, I like to warm my milk in the microwave for one minute before I use the frother. Let the frother spit out a bit of steam for a second. The frothing takes a while. I set it there and go brush my teeth and come back and it is about done. I did take the rubber piece off to try to keep it a bit more sanitary. Sometimes milk will dry in the hole and you just unscrew it and poke it with a tooth pick. Some people have noted the rubber seal on the water tank going bad and leaking water. I have only taken my water container off a hand full of times and I have not had any problem. I pour water into it with a cup. It takes a minute to make my coffee; however, I think my coffee tastes better than a coffee shops. I can also get unique syrups like toasted marshmallow.
title: Great for the price
bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Automatic Dual Shot

review_content: I've worked as a barista for a few different places for a total of about 6 years give or take and have experience with latte art and manual machines. this little machine isn't quite the same as a real espresso machine, but it does work great! I can even make latte art (I removed the plastic cover to make it easier to steam milk; but be careful not to burn yourself). It does have a tendency to act up if you do not release all the pressure after EACH drink, or if you make multiple drinks in a row I've also noticed it has a tendency to overheat and act up. Just make sure to try to do only one drink at a time, and release all pressure/water after each drink and you should be fine. also make sure to unscrew the filter and clean out gunky build up to maintain espresso flavor thats not bitter!

review_content:
It may not show up as a verified purchase as I received it as a Christmas present and my wife used her sister's account instead of our family Amazon account so I wouldn't know. Most reviews are typically done after receiving the product and using it for a short time. We've owned this one and used it at least once a day for the past 16 months and during that time have not plugged in our Keurig.
I like it. It heats up pretty quickly and with the right ingredients and proper grind of coffee you can make a latte, cappuccino or whatever else you'd like that will taste like what you can get at Caribou, Starbucks or other spendy/trendy coffee locations. The kids like it since they can heat up milk only for their hot chocolates. It has multiple settings so you can get a two pre-programmed amounts for espresso, cappuccino or latte or you can use the "manual" setting and get more or less if you'd like. The coffee comes out pretty hot, however, I wish the milk came out hotter.
We use only filtered water in the tank and use some cleaner once in a while. There was a period of time that it seemed to not work well as if the pump was going out but after observing it for a while these events only happened during the heating of milk. I took the entire milk container apart and cleaned it thoroughly - all internal tubes and valve. Determined that since we store the container in the fridge with remaining milk over a period of time milk scum was building up. Bottom line: keep it clean.
To date it is still going strong. I like that it has an internal timer and will shut off if not used for some time. Press a button on front and it turns back on and wait a little bit for it to heat back up. Beats spending $5-6 at the local coffee shop which I would visit maybe once a week.
title: Pays for itself after a few uses.

review_content: I am not one to leave reviews, but it occurred to me today that I've used this machine for over 5 years last month. I can't say enough positive things about this machine. It makes killer espresso shots! I don't use the cappuccino portion of it (the milk part), because I prefer iced beverages - but its a quality machine that makes amazing espresso! I clean it once a month and run diluted vinegar through it. I've had several friends buy this machine just from my raving reviews. Buy this espresso maker! You won't regret it!
title: I've used this machine daily for over 5 years!
bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Espresso/Cappuccino Maker

review_content:
I got this for Christmas and after using it several times a day since then, I can tell you that this is a wonderful espresso maker and there's nothing in the $100-$1000 machines I'd find worth the extra money.

Pros:
- Steam is the only way to make proper coffee or espresso. Other methods don't produce the smooth, rich taste of a real espresso. In fact, it wasn't until the 1940s that added pressure and lower temperatures were used in espresso machines; this was not done to make a better espresso, but to make it cheaper and have a larger amount of foam on top (the crema). The hot water doesn't extract the oils in the same way as steam, so if you're using hot water, you're not making a true espresso. And for those who've written reviews saying this kind of espresso machine can't make a decent crema, check out the pictures I've posted (using Lavazza Super Crema).
- Milk frother runs from the same reservoir you're making the espresso with; only one heating element, no second reservoir to fill and check, and no delay between finishing the espresso and starting the frothing.
- Everything you need is in the box. The coffee scoop has a flattened bottom for use as a tamper (not the best, see below) but it will do for a while; the other end of the coffee scoop is the wrench you'll need to removing the frothing arm for cleaning.
- Actually faster than my single-cup drip machine. If I want a 12-oz coffee with a double shot of espresso, the espresso machine, even having to make steam, finishes before the coffee maker gets done. Considering that both are starting from room-temperature water, I think this is wonderfully fast.
- The Mr. Coffee customer service is top notch. I had a problem with the decanter lid and they took care of it quickly and courteously.
- If you fill the basket to the first notch but use 4 cups (8 oz) of water, you'll get a really nice cup of what I'd call American coffee. It will still have the richness of good espresso because the steam will get all the different oils out of the grounds, but it will be less strong with no crema or aftertaste.

Cons:
- Pretty long cool-down time. The best thing to do here, if you have the time, is to wait about five minutes after you've made the espresso, turn the selector to froth and let the pressure escape for a couple seconds, then remove the reservoir top; this will let the reservoir cool down faster.
- Going anywhere over 3 shots (6 oz) will destroy the crema; there's just too much steam coming out too close to the top of the liquid for any foam to survive.
- This is related to the first two, actually putting the two together. It's hard to use this if you want to prepare espresso for a lot of people, say at a party or holiday dinner. If this really is a big concern, at this price, buy two. I'm serious...for less than the price of the fancy machines that don't do anything more than this one you can buy a couple of these to keep the drinks flowing.

Suggestions:
- Buy a good tamper, it will make a lot of difference. I use Red 49mm Espresso Tamper Stainless Steel Coffee and am very happy with the results.
- Remember to always release the pressure through the frothing arm before removing the reservoir lid. This applies even if you've steamed milk because there always seems to be a pressure difference after the machine cools down.

I just want to clear one thing up that I'm sure is just a typo on the Amazon page but some people might be unsure of. This will not make 20 ounces of coffee per use. Where the page says, "Steam espresso machine brews 1 to 4 cups (20 ounces)" it almost certainly means to say, "Steam espresso machine brews 1 to 4 cups (2.0 ounces per cup)."

Recommendation:
Buy this espresso maker.
title: Don't spend a penny more, this is a wonderful espresso maker.
bought_model: Color: CappuccinoStyle Name: 4-Cup Steam

review_content: I did not buy on Amazon, a friend gave it to me.  I have used this type of steam espresso machine for 20 years.  It works just like every other espresso machine I have used. review_content: I made the transition from a steam espresso maker to a pump driven machine, it was the right choice. title: Mr. Coffee Espresso maker

review_content:
I bought this item last year, and it came with the water tank cap broken. I didn't mind as it wasn't a functional fault, so I carried on.
The milk frother is difficult to clean up so I almost never used it. However, I tried to use it to make some lattes for a friend and the frother is completely broken. I thought may be it's a temporary fault and tried to run the cleaner frequently for the past month with no avail.
So in short, it came physically broken and just over a year, the milk frother is completely non-operational. My previous, much cheaper machine survived for far longer.
title: Very low quality material!
bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Espresso/Cappuccino Maker

review_content:
It is less expensive, but does not function as well as, some of the "fancier" Euro brands that appear to have gone up in price a lot since I last bought one. It brews okay, but is hard to get good milk frothing from this unit. I use a different attachment than comes with it, but the tube is short and does not reach very far into a taller cup without the attachment that comes with it.

The steamer lid is slippery and shaped in a way that makes it hard to lift, a silly poor design. The steamer basket attachment is plastic, not metal, so I don't know if it will last very long. Within a couple of weeks the carafe had a chip/hole in it after coming out of the dishwasher. Not sure if that was our doing, but I have used other carafes for years without issues.
title: Does the job, sort of
bought_model: Color: CappuccinoStyle Name: 4-Cup Steam

review_content:
Makes a wonderful cup of espresso. Makes a wonderful carafe of frothy milk....when you get the rubbber frothing wand attachment on ‚Äújust right‚Äù. If it‚Äôs not on ‚Äújust right‚Äù, the steam escapes out the top of the rubber piece and the milk doesn‚Äôt get frothy, or it over froths and makes a frothed over mess. The frother is timed, so turns itself off at the perfect temp for me (usually between 180-190) I like my lattes extra hot. This would be perfect for me if the frothing wand was long enough for me to leave the carafe on the tray while I do other things.

After 3 machines before this one, I give it 3 stars overall because of the quality of the espresso, especially for the affordable price of the machine. But because I use this machine every morning, the annoying frothing wand can‚Äôt be ignored.
title: Almost Perfect But Not
bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Automatic Dual Shot

review_content:
Update after over 2 years:
Still love this machine! It gets a lot of work and absolutely no issues. I‚Äôm pretty consistent with descaling but that‚Äôs the only maintenance. This thing keeps churning out delicious espresso for me and cappuccinos and lattes for family. One note: make sure you‚Äôre using good (dark roast) beans and grind them for espresso. And enjoy!
‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äîoriginal‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî-
So glad I bought this! I was reminded how much I love true espresso when traveling in Europe earlier this year after living there for several years in the distant past. I wanted to make it at home and glad I took a chance on this machine. It works great! And it gets a good workout between my daughter and me, probably averages 4 cups per day over the last 5 months, plus a couple times per week I make lattes for my wife. I also bought a very nice little set of demitasse (also from Amazon) and already had a Mr Coffee burr mill that lets me switch back and forth from espresso to french press. I also run some descaling agent through the system around every 6 weeks just to prevent any problems. The two "spouts" don't necessarily pour out at the same rate, which is only a factor when filling 2 coups at once, so I have to pause the press and switch the cups--which isn't a big deal at all. And usually only make one (demitasse) cup at a time, so this is seldom a factor. Overall, a very nice system at a great price!
title: The real deal!

review_content: I was surprised to find an espresso machine at this price that performed this well. I'm not sure about the longevity of the product, as I have only had it a short time, but given the price and the perceived build quality I would be happy if I only got a few years out of it. The initial run (following the instructions) was a little more difficult than I expected. Seemed to take a bit of fiddling to get the steam pump primed, but now that it is up and running I really love that feature. The drip tray fills up quickly, but I believe a bit of that is due to the steam setting's post-steam cleaning as opposed to leaks or messy drips. It's a tight fit for my short Yeti mug, but works using the double size filter if filling the mug about 1/2 full - tilting the mug to pull it from under the dispenser.

review_content:
Works great, but first of all, Amazon didn‚Äôt bother putting it in a box, so they just left the espresso machine on my front porch and anyone could have seen what it was and taken it. Not that there are a ton of coffee pot thieves, but it‚Äôs not a cheap product, so not super happy that I had a $168 espresso machine out there for anyone to see and take. Second problem, when I got the product, it looked okay, however, there was some water in the water reservoir, so I‚Äôm just wondering if I paid full price for a used product. However, on the how the product works, it works great! I‚Äôd give it a 4 out of 5 stars on the coffee pot itself. Tastes great, get really great froth with the milk frother. My only issue is it‚Äôs definitely not quick, it‚Äôs a bit noisy, and kinda hard to clean the milk frother. Although, that may be just a rtfm problem (read the freaking manual). So I‚Äôd say, if you‚Äôre looking for something super quick and quiet, probably choose something else, but if you don‚Äôt mind waiting for a really great tasting cup of espresso coffee, better than Starbucks even, I‚Äôd say get this one!
title: 4 star product 2 star Amazon
bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Espresso/Cappuccino Maker

review_content: We've found this espresso machine to make fairly decent espresso and cappuccino. Our particular unit is a bit noisy - the pump makes a sound that resembles a fog horn. It's not awful, but can be annoying if there are bedrooms located near the kitchen and people are still sleeping while the coffee is being prepared by early risers. For those who are seafarers and are using this on board a sailing vessel, however, this sound can be very useful during times of fog and heavy mist. Design-wise it would be nice to have all of the controls on the front of the unit. Having the power switch and brew/steam control on the right side requires a bit more room on that side of the machine to access these. Again, this is not awful, but for those with very limited counter space - such as a galley on the aforementioned sailing vessel - this can be an issue. The reservoir has ample capacity for a machine this size. It can be helpful to have a light source near the unit for easier viewing of the water level in the reservoir without having to remove it. While there have been a few detractors with this machine for our family, it has been a good espresso and cappuccino maker overall, especially within this price range.
title: Good espresso, especially for seafarers.
bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Automatic Dual Shot

review_content: Having no experience making expresso or cappuccino, I have nothing to compare this unit to.  On that basis, I would rate this maker a three star.  One, it doesn't create creama.  Two, no pitcher and three, no tamper.  I received this as a gift from my Wish List.  I chose this maker for the price, manufacturer and majority of the ratings.  I am not displeased and was aware of the missing pitcher and tamper, henceforth the inclusion of them on my Wish List.  I had trouble getting the steamer to work.  I believe it was because the tube was clogged with built up milk residue, since I did get steam the first two times.  That would put excessive force on the screw cap on the top.  Also, if the grounds aren't screwed in tightly and the coffee is tamped down too firmly, it could blow off breaking the coffee pot.  I believe this has been the cause of the "explosions".  Either way, I will surely be carefull.  This may be inheirent with any expresso maker.  I still haven't been able to make a decent latte, though cappuccinos have been easy.  Practice is the key, I'm sure.  The individual who stated his cleaning and pre-steam method was wise.  I will follow his method for sure.  $40 is a fair price for this maker and I would recommend it for the beginner or those not too critical of their result.
title: Mr. Coffee Express Maker
bought_model: Color: CappuccinoStyle Name: 4-Cup Steam

review_content:
IN DEPTH REVIEW:

We have owned the earlier version of this same model for almost two years. I am going to list the pros and cons for you so as you can make a a choice of whether or not this is the machine for you.

The Pros:

It functions well and have not had a problem with the pump or steamer not working. Occasionally, you might need to unclog the steam wand with a toothpick. But this happens with any machine where the steam port is very small. I have had to descale the machine once so far. I used 100% white vinegar and filled it to the top and left it overnight. Ran it through 3-4 times with water and Presto!

It is a very economically priced machine. The prior model which I have (looks almost identical, except this one has a slightly more polished look) was slightly less expensive. Around $29.99.

The steam wand produces good quality steamed/frothed milk. However, this is somewhat on the users end as this is mainly achieved through proper technique. But it does do the job.

Cons: For true espresso and cappuccino fans out there such as myself, it is important to note that this machine does not make a true espresso. It makes strong coffee and works well for those that are not after a true espresso which has a golden cream layer on the top referred to as crema. This only results from using the proper machine and grinding the coffee precisely to make espressos. But the machine does turn out quality coffee drinks for the average coffee lover.

As with most inexpensive models, you can only run one function at a time. You can brew the espresso or steam milk. This is the case with most in home machines so I was not disappointed. This was expected, but I would love to be able to operate both functions at once. Also, with inexpensive models, it is almost entirely made of plastic with no chrome accents. For the price, it is a great machine non the less.

For the cost of this machine, it is a great machine. One thing I love about it is that it works! I have read reviews on more expensive machines but still in a moderate price range (under $100.00) with pumps going bad in under a year. Mine is a few years old and has shown no signs of mechanical failure. Does it make a true espresso? No...but it does a great job and let's be honest. A machine in this price range is not targeted to espresso aficionados. It's target market is for coffee lovers of all types who are budget minded. This would be great for in home use, a small office or a college student.
title: AN INDEPTH REVIEW.
bought_model: Color: CappuccinoStyle Name: 4-Cup Steam

review_content: I've lost count of how many years I've had my machine (probably >5).  It just broke this morning.  Wiring failure I'm sure.  My parents couldn't be bothered with the one I got them, so I have a backup (thank God).  You can't beat the price, and gives impressive pulls, crema, and foam from such an affordable machine.  I will agree with everyone else here though, the grind is super important (but it would be with a machine 5 times the price too) and take off the rubber thingy from the steam arm.  Works awesome.  Won't produce ultra fancy shots and foam like professional coffeeshops, but if you practice your technique and read a little on the internet about how to make espresso and foam, it'll beat out any overpriced drink you can buy at Schwarbucks.
title: Excellent machine...sad mine just broke but I have a replacement.
bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Automatic Dual Shot

review_content: Giving it 4 as it's nothing super fancy, but it does the job every morning. I've really enjoyed this, as it's easy to use, gets my coffee made in about 5 minutes (I brew it under espresso strength so it's more like drip coffee and I can have a full mug), and the few times I've used the frother it's worked nicely. I will caution that you make sure you put everything on tight and well-aligned. I've had two problems with it and both are user error - once I screwed the water resevoir cap on at the wrong angle, so things weren't sealed, and steam escaped through the top; the second time I didn't get the grounds holder in correctly and it caused a lot of steam and coffee grounds to go everywhere. Again, these were both my fault, and they only happened once. Since then, I've just done an extra check before starting and have had zero problems in the 3 months since.
title: Giving it 4 as it's nothing super fancy, but it does the job every morning
bought_model: Color: CappuccinoStyle Name: 4-Cup Steam

review_content: This machine works ok. I've had it 3 or 4 years. No crema as stated in other reviews. I've done the descaling with vinegar...not helpful. Bought a product specifically for coffee/espresso makers, works better. The frothing wand on my machine is different than pictured, maybe because it's an older model? The instructions call for cleaning the frothing wand in a manner that I cannot physically do based on the difference  in my frothing wand. The frothing wand is hard to keep clean, but I try my best. Sometimes it won't froth the milk, not sure why. The scoop/tamper is not really a good tamper. I need to buy another one that will work better. I get decent espresso with it, although if I want to brew 4 espresso shots and then froth milk I don't think there's enough water left, so I'd have to let the machine cool down before being able to put in more water, then brew more espresso (or at least run water through the brew cycle I guess) to heat up the machine to froth milk. Maybe a manual frother like shown in the Rok video would help. Having trouble finding a cheap frothing cup to go with this cheap machine...would hate to have to buy a frothing cup that cost more than the machine! Using a measuring cup with mixed results but that's my fault I guess. I wish I knew what the deal was with the frothing wand sometimes not working though.
title: Passable machine
bought_model: Color: CappuccinoStyle Name: 4-Cup Steam

review_content: I had it for a year, and I was happy about it. A year, and 2 months later it started leaking. I emailed the company after looking at the troubleshooting on the website for them to tell me the exact same thing which was to empty the reservoir. Very helpful... The problem is not coming from the reservoir that I am not emptying since the water is coming from under the machine which might not even be safe. I saw several people complaining about that by the way, but I got it as a gift, so I did not choose. One thing for sure is that next machine I buy won't be from Mr.Coffee and its great costumer service.
title: Leaking
bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Automatic Dual Shot

review_content:
ok. this is the same price in most stores.

i bought this at walmart for the exact same price with out having to wait for the shipping blah blah blah. this item is great, It is probably the cheapest espresso maker around, very reliable and easy to use.

you will need some extras with this for optimal espresso making.. you will want some good ground espresso, a foam pitcher, a tamper, and some creamer/milk/syrups. I only have the maker and some cheap store brand espresso and im fine for now. I use the spoon scooper that came with it for "tamping", which im sure isnt ideal, but its ok for me.. I use whatever cup im going to drink out of for steaming the milk, and im using 3parts milk to 1 part flavored creamer until i get some fun syrups.

so yeah, I would definately get the frothing cup with your purchase, and if you like fancy drinks you can find all different kinds of coffee syrups here on amazon in both sugar free and regular versions.

easy, cheap, hot espresso. its as simple as that.
hope this helps.
title: cheap, easy, fast, hot caffiene
bought_model: Color: CappuccinoStyle Name: 4-Cup Steam

review_content:
Mr Coffee espresso maker review
About 22 years ago I used to own a Krups espresso maker. It was temperamental and expensive, but it made a great cup of coffee. Many moves and years later, I've lost my old espresso maker along the way. After reading the reviews about this espresso maker, I decided to give it a shot. I've now had it for about 2 months and I *LOVE* this little guy! I would highly recommend this product to anyone!
Price - Cheap! I don't mean quality, I mean you get a very nice machine for a very low price. I paid over $80 for my Krups 22 years ago. This espresso machine is less than half that price and works a lot better.
Ease of use - relatively easy. Look, you're dealing with a small machine with a lot of pressure. You do have to exercise some caution, like relieving the pressure before you try to open the reservoir. There are a few points on 'ease of use' that I would also like to point out:
-Reservoir lid can be slippery. There is no grippage, no knobbbyness, nothing to grab onto. Plus it's angled upwards, in a cone shape. What the heck guys? The reservoir is under pressure during use. Why would you create the lid to be slippery and make it cone shaped? It can be difficult to handle if your hands are wet. Just be careful when you're relieving the pressure and you should be good.
-The slot where the coffee filter assembly is awkward. I don't know what you call the thing, but trying to insert your coffee filter assembly into the machine can be tricky. It's in the middle of the machine and it has to be lined up just right. Couldn't someone have made this a little (a LOT) easier to line up?
-Frothing aid is useless! That rubber black thing on the end of the frother? What's up with that? Chuck it. My old krups had something similar on it. I had a hard time frothing milk until I chucked it. So straight out of the box, I didn't even bother with it, just removed it and chucked it!
Having said my few points of contention with this machine, overall it is a very easy to use machine, well made, brews FAST, and makes a very tasty cup of espresso or latte. Unlike my old krups, you can make multiple carafes by relieving the pressure and refilling the reservoir between brews. And it's quiet! Maybe too quiet. I kind of miss all the weird whistling, bubbling, and clouds of steam my old krups put out. I was always on the edge of my seat wondering if today I'd get a good cup of coffee or get blown to smithereens.
Oh, one last thing- Don't be fooled by the name. I was cautious about buying the brand. It's a bit of joke, right? The same company that grandpa used to make his cruddy coffee is now making espresso makers... I mean, what do they know about *GOOD* espresso? Apparently, quiet a bit! BUY the MR COFFEE ESPRESSO MACHINE!

*** update: I've now had this espresso machine for 9 months. I have yet to scale it, and it STILL makes great espresso. SUPERB MACHINE! ***
title: Well worth buying!
bought_model: Color: CappuccinoStyle Name: 4-Cup Steam

review_content:
Would like to give this P.O.S. zero star rating. Don't buy this product unless you want to burn your house down with an electrical fire, then this product is the best fit for your home! Especially if you keep it next to other electrical appliances like a toaster. Alternatively, you can electricute yourself or a loved one when making that perfect cup of Latte.

The issue with this product is, it leaks water from the reservoir that it was shipped with. I've tried multiple ways to see if the leak can be stoped by filling water below the maximum level, but to no luck.

The finish and quality of the product is so bad, I don't know how Mr.Coffee got the gall to sell it for 200$ (White). The product is less than a month old, purchased it as a Christmas gift for our family. Now that the holidays are over, I'm going to try to get this crap replaced, either from Amazon or Mr.Coffee and if they refuse, I'll contact my Lawyer. Here are some pictures and videos for proof.
title: Would like to give this P
bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Espresso/Cappuccino Maker

review_content:
So, here's the story. I love cafe mocha. I work at home. I spend $4.10 every couple of days at the local coffee shop for a "venti". Plus a bit of gas to get there. It's not a big deal, it gets me out of my chair.

One night, I see this in Wal Mart one night with my wife. $37 or thereabouts. She buys it (and a tin of coffee, some whipped cream, some hershey's chocolate syrup, and a gallon of milk). All told, maybe $55. The tin of coffee looks like it will be good for 100 cups or so, really, the ingredients for a "venti" probably are in the range of 50 to 75 cents, at the very highest. So, the math looks favorable, I just need to brew a dozen or so cafe mochas and this thing pays for myself. I'm thinking, even if it is low quality, it's worth the risk for the reward.

This device is far from cheap, and does the job wonderfully. I make great cafe mochas with this thing, all by myself, no need to leave the house now. It brews fast, the steamer works great.

I'll still go to a coffee shop, as I'm not that much of a penny pincher. But I'm really glad I can stay at home and make my own now, and frankly, they could charge $100 for this maker and I would not hesitate to recommend it. Bravo Mr Coffee, I'll be your fan on Facebook forever for making this device and selling it for such a fair price.
title: Deal of the Century++
bought_model: Color: CappuccinoStyle Name: 4-Cup Steam

review_content:
This is my 3rd espresso machine and while not my favorite, it is an amazing value. It works better than DeLonghi EC155 which cost twice as much and it is fairly idiot proof once you know how to use it. I had visitors who'd never made espresso before making my morning latte for me. Normally I get stuck with coffee duty every morning. Sweet.

It actually seems to make better espresso with a coarser grind which is fine since you have the choice, if grinding at the store, to make regular coffee or espresso with the same coffee.

My only complaint are the buttons and knobs. The front buttons set the pressure (different for steam vs espresso) and the knob on the right is a valve that directs the pressurized steam to either making espresso or the milk foamer. The buttons love to blink green in different patterns and no one who approaches this machine initially has any clue what this means. Since I rent my home out on AirBnB I made a Youtube video on how to use this thing so I wouldn't have to teach people how to use it all the time.

Some reviews mention the longevity is poor, but if I have to replace it every year, it still saves money. My EC155 went downhill after 18 months anyway.
title: Not my favorite but an amazing value
bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Automatic Dual Shot

review_content:
Had this for almost a year and love it more now then when we bought it (between my wife and I we make about 4 drinks a day, usually double lattes and the machine is showing no signs of visible wear). It's very easy to use and clean (has cleaning features that make it simple). I like that I can control the amounts that are made during the brew and froth, as I like a double shot of espresso with only a single Latte's portion of steamed milk. There is a huge range between the steam and froth of the milk so you can fine tune exactly what you like to suit your individual taste. If you have decent beans you will have a great brew with beautiful crema every time.

Only advice I can give you (if you are just starting out with good coffee) is go with a good Burr Grinder at the same time you get this. Consider it an investment on the beans you will be buying. If you cheap out and get a spice grinder sort of thing you will have no consistency with your grind and you will never be able to get the great cup you want. This Mr. Coffee with a Burr Grinder are a must have for people who want great coffee with minimal effort! Best espresso machine I've ever had, and is easily worth double what you pay! I'm actually drinking a Cafe Latte that I made

UPDATE 4/11/2017
So after making approximately 2,000 drinks our compressor is starting to go out. It still works but less effectively. We've enjoyed this product so much we are purchasing a new one with no reservation.
title: Tried and Tested, and I'm picky...
bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Espresso/Cappuccino Maker

review_content: Eight months later...a BIG DISAPPOINTMENT!!! On May 4, 2016, I purchased this machine because it was a best seller, inexpensive and the most important factor - I LOVE COFFEE! Did I not pay close attention to it's gurgling and sputtering halt during the initial performance? No! Did I not note the very suggestive warranty purchase during check out? No! Did I assume being single and used only during the weekends, that it would last me 4-5 years? Yes! This wonderful, useless contraption hasn't even stood-fast for 8 months!!! It's early Saturday morning, and the deception won't even brew...sigh. Oh, well..hats off to the littel engine that could - take this straight to the dump! Like Grandma often said: UGET EXACTLY WHAT YOU PAID FOR, FOLKS!
title: A beginnners dream...turned nightmare!
bought_model: Color: CappuccinoStyle Name: 4-Cup Steam

review_content: I've had this for about a month now and I am loving my morning lattes.  I am learning that the right Espresso beans go a long way.  I initially bought a fancy crema espresso and it wasn't quite like the lattes I was having at my local coffee shop.  Then I switched to their beans and wow.....now I have a daily latte for 1/5 of the price (maybe more).  This machine was intimidating until I watched a number of Youtube videos and really got to know how the machine worked and had to be done with it to keep it running.  I bought new glasses, syrups, milks, and beans to get this ready.  I prepped the machine and it has been so easy to use.  I prefer to brew the Espresso first and put that in with my syrup.  One double and one single is easy.  I then use a container to get the frothed milk going and then use a spoon to keep the foam and add this to my Espresso.  Bingo bango, I gotta latte!  It's the perfect machine for me to learn from and if it lasts long enough, I'll buy another down the road.  I purchased replacement parts directly from Mr. Coffee to make sure that a lost silicone tube does not keep me from my morning joy.
title: How did I ever live without this machine?!
bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Espresso/Cappuccino Maker

review_content:
NO SUPPORT, not even trying
e.g. trying to buy a second double shot filter assembly
No parts list to mail order, no official on line part found
Cust.Serv offers only the metal part for 2.99usd (same as single shot found on line) ?!?!? swears it is the dbl
but has NO IDEA what the inner rubber gasket/washer is nor bottom exterior screw on plastic part is to look up & order ?!?!?!
Supervisor chooses not to come to phone unti lquitting time, when they hang up on me
Here's a quote reply to another disgruntled reviewer
"We do have the double shot filters
available and would be more than happy to assist you in obtaining those parts. Please call us at
(800) 672-6333" =
clearly full of BS

The other getting used to is the great quantity of milk or 1/2-1/2 it sucks up into both lattes & cappuccinos ... I will try to water this down, but way too generous!

All in all, press a button and it's done using full jugs of water & milk, no more frosting from a Mr. Coffee stem as before, chained to it.

Still experimenting with formulas to get it back to the good ol' Mr. Coffee Latte days with cheaper machine and tall French latte mug.

title: Great idea, easy, fast, simple but ....
bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Espresso/Cappuccino Maker

review_content:
Just purchased this as a XMAS gift for myself and I must say I was disappointed on first use. I am in no way a "barista" so i didnt know how tight to pack the grounds or even how high they should be filled up. Every time it came out watered down and slowly got richer. Wasnt happy at all.

Second use now and I'm glad I bought a heavy metal tamper to go with this machine. I packed these grounds so tight that of the 3 drinks I made today they were all perfect.

I will agree with everybody else and say do not use grounds on the first push of the button in the morning. Toss the first one in the sink to allow the machine to get the water hot enough.

The milk section is nice however it should have lines so you know how much to add into the reservoir instead of wasting it or having to pour it back into the jug.
title: Great machine when you buy a heavy metal tamper.
bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Espresso/Cappuccino Maker

review_content: I‚Äôve been reading reviews and trying to find an espresso machine that wouldn‚Äôt disappoint me or be intimidating to use. I finally decided this was the one and received  it Nov 9th. I‚Äôve used it at least 2-3 times a day by myself and several more times for guests. So far I am very impressed with the quality of espresso drinks it makes. It took me a just few tries to get it perfect the first time. One important thing I do first is heat my milk for about 45 seconds in the microwave before I put it in the machine. This not only heats the milk but also my coffee cup.( I like hot coffee) I wasn‚Äôt getting a hot latte before this step. I had been considering the coffee Ninja and also more expensive high quality espresso machines but this one is  perfect for the home coffee bar and keeps me from buying one when I‚Äôm out knowing I can make a custom coffee drink right at home. So far all the parts are working fine and I haven‚Äôt had to ‚Äúclean‚Äù the machine yet but it looks like it will be fairly easy with this machine having a ‚Äúclean‚Äù button.
title: Yes, Buy Mr Coffee Cafe Barista!
bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Espresso/Cappuccino Maker

review_content: Wow. I purchased this for about $175 on sale a couple of weeks ago and man is it amazing!  You can fill the removable chamber with water and it lasts for several days. The other front removable chamber if for your milk or half n' half and it froths perfectly every time.  My wife brews two cups a day for her and my son does another cup for him. The construction is solid, fittings are very tight and it takes about a minute to warm up and start frothing the milk first. It is designed to put your cup directly under the coffee and place the spout for the milk in your cup. The design is so well thought out the coffee makes itself after you add the milk and select your choice of brew either cappucino, espresso or latte. If you use oversized cups like we do, then you have to use the large setting and sometimes after it's done run another small cup to fill it completely, but that's no problem as the pressure extracts every last bit of flavor from your coffee grounds. There's no need to refill the cup with more grounds even when making two cups!  It's squarish design fits neatly on the counter top and the milk chamber cleans easily just by rinsing out and putting it back. After shopping extensively for over a month I am completely satisfied with this purchase and am convinced there is nothing on the market for under $200 that will do the job like this machine!  BUY IT!
title: Look No Further! This is THE ONE!!!
bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Espresso/Cappuccino Maker

review_content:
When you read the description of this machine, you just want it to work because it is just about everything your coffee dreams are made of.

I tried to temper my hopes and anticipation, but when the machine arrived and the coffee and milk froth came out of this machine it was just too good to be true. A great tasting coffee with nice froth all in one machine. Just perfect!! I imagined a bright future for our family and this machine.

Were it not that after one week, the water reservoir started leaking from the bottom plug. I tried with a little tape, but it just leaked more and more. So after a week of great coffee and a second week of great coffee and small water disasters I sent it back for another one.
I assumed this was a monday-morning product and the next one would be better. And the next machine was better!! That is, for three weeks. Then it slowly started to leak just like the first machine. DARN! My coffee dreams of a future together with froth were shattered.

I will be sending this one back as well. I considered to buy some silicone and completely glue the water reservoir to the machine. But I expect that the leaking is exemplary for the built quality of the rest of the machine. So back it goes, and on with the search for the perfect coffee machine...
title: Great coffee, but twice a water reservoir leaking from its plug. Great concept, though poorly constructed.
bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Espresso/Cappuccino Maker

review_content:
Really love this coffee maker. I've had it a 1-¬Ω years and use it almost daily. Easy clean up and easy to use. The coffee tastes really good too and love the ability to have more or less foam. You can make espresso, cappuccino or latte. I'd recommend this coffee maker if you want a latte with a push of one button.

UPDATE: It quit frothing milk a couple weeks ago already, just over a year. I bought a new milk dispenser/frother from the company website; it still won't froth milk. Don't waste your money. I called the company, but they said it needed new filters too. However, it isn't something I can repair/replace myself. Since I've had it over a year, too bad. Our disposable society; things can't be repaired; or repaired for less than buying a new one. I clean it after each use and routinely clean it with white vinegar. But, now it's done.

review_content: Great product
title: Five Stars
bought_model: Color: CappuccinoStyle Name: 4-Cup Steam

review_content:
I read reviews before ordering this machine and saw several people saying it crapped out on them after several months of use. I figured the machine to be a pretty decent bargain even so; at the low price, getting a few months of use out of it is pretty solid! Also, as a former barista, I figured people probably just abused the machine and that's why they ceased to function.

OH, HOW SNOOTY AND NAIVE I WAS.

The FIRST time I tried to use the machine, it kept flashing both the red and green lights, which--as several other reviewers can tell you--meant I was unable to use any function of the machine. I reread the manual, made sure every piece was in the proper place, unplugged it and turned it on/off a few times. Finally the red light remained solid (to indicate it was powered on) and the green light went from blinking to solid after the machine warmed up. And I was able to make a single cappuccino! I'll remember fondly that single brush with victory. How fleeting it was...

Then I tried to use it again later in the day, and the steam wand stopped in the middle of steaming a few ounces of milk. The red and green lights began blinking again. This time, no amount of unplugging or turning off/on would work.

Back in the box it goes, to be returned to Amazon. I'm very disappointed. I knew I was in for a cheap machine that would die fairly soon--but I thought I could get more than a single use out of it!

Also, if you decide to purchase this (for god knows what reason) and are going to steam milk with the steaming wand--make sure your pitcher is tiny. No more than 12oz, for sure. I purchased a 16oz pitcher because I wanted a roomy pitcher since I like to create a lot of foam. But the wand is only three inches long or so, and very underpowered. It couldn't reach the bottom of the pitcher, and struggled to steam even 5oz of milk.
title: Blinking lights of doom--during first use!
bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Automatic Dual Shot

review_content: Lasted less than a year before it started clogging up, and slowing down, in spite of daily cleaning.
title: Three Stars
bought_model: Color: CappuccinoStyle Name: 4-Cup Steam

review_content: Delicious perfection. Easy to use and clean. Best purchase this year, by far. And with my own spices and additions, I can make every flavored beverage under the sun. Bravo Mr. Coffee!!
title: Easy to use and clean
bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Espresso/Cappuccino Maker

If it breaks I already got my money out of it compared to other expresso makers for hundreds of dollars! You don't need a Tamper as many reviews state! Read instruction! review_content:
I'm returning this for 3 main reasons. The cord is too short. In fact, the short cord is one of the first "features" mentioned in the instruction manual and it is highlighted a safety benefit. They recommend buying an additional extension cord if it's too short. I need about 3 extra inches, and an actual extension cord would be a larger safety issue and it would look horrible.

In addition to the stupidity of the short cord, it doesn't foam milk well at all. Yes, I've read the instructions. I can't get a good froth on my soy milk. Sure it's hot, but it's not a latte.

Finally, it is hard to clean. The steamer pipe has a ring at the top which clearly gets milk all over it. It's hard to clean off and over time I'm sure it will become gunky unless I get out toothpick or special cleaning brush.

I do not recommend this product.

review_content:
I'm saving so much money with this espresso/latte maker and the drinks taste (almost) as good. This machine can pull excellent espresso shots; as good as a much more expensive machine. The milk frother -- not so much. But, I can make a double cafe mocha for less than a dollar! And when I want to get "fancy", I can do the drink manually by first pouring the frothed milk into a pitcher, then pull the espresso shots into my mug. Then, tamp/stir the milk and pour it into the espresso. Can't do latte art, but the drink tastes great!

Suggestions after several months of use:
1. Let the machine heat up with the (empty) portafilter in place and the mug on top for 15 minutes if you have time. Get everything nice and hot. Just note that the portafilter will get VERY hot. Nothing worse than a lukewarm latte.
2. Keep the milk ice cold until you're ready to froth it. This will keep the hard sticky foam to a minimum.
3. Use freshly-ground beans if you have a grinder. I'm using pre-ground because I don't have a grinder and the coffee has lost its oil after a few weeks and no longer makes a nice thick crema.
4. For the best results (if you have time), pull the espresso and the milk separately as I mention above. This gives you control over the milk content and allows you to "work" the milk a little to remove the big bubbles before adding it to the drink.
5. Keep the whole machine as clean as possible including the milk container, hoses, spouts, filters and trays. Milk and coffee build up if you don't.
6. Go ahead and buy a real tamper. They're less than $20 and are much better than the plastic thing that comes with the machine.
title: Coffeehouse-quality lattes for less than $1!
bought_model: Color: RedStyle Name: Espresso/Cappuccino Maker

review_content:
This product began breaking with in 40 days of very minimal use of 1 to 2 drinks maybe 3 to 4 days a week. The plastic tube on the steamer nozzle began cracking and fell apart - threw it away for safety reasons. The black plastic plate cover on the top where it says "Mr. Coffee" has separated on the right front and does NOT PRESS DOWN IN PLACE. Steam does escape. The plastic on the coffee pot handle cracked and broke near the glass.
Over all this product is of very poor quality and I would say a safety problem due to the small parts that may flake off or break and end up in your drink.
title: Over all this product is of very poor quality and I would say a safety problem due ...
bought_model: Color: CappuccinoStyle Name: 4-Cup Steam

review_content: This product works great for the price. For the first couple of uses, it made my coffee taste like plastic but after testing it with and without the plastic cap to the steamer, I figured out it was the plastic covering. Once the plastic cover over the steamer is removed coffee tastes great. So far, after many-many uses, the steamer remains clear and doesn't leave a bad taste. Barista trick: run the steam through the steamer without any milk to get a thorough clean, then take a hot towel/rag and remove any dried milk. In addition, I thought the steamer moved but it is in a fixed position. No big deal but definitely that would be nice for future models. It also took a few tries to get a good temperature for milk. I highly suggest a metal milk cup for steaming this way you can feel when the milk is hot, no thermometer needed. Takes about 1-2 mins to reach a comfortable/hot temperature. I have used almond milk, rice milk, and 2% milk with great results. Overall, espresso tastes good and froths perfectly. Only complaints (and reason for 4/5 stars) would be the plastic covering on the steamer and it being in a fixed position.
title: Great for price - plastic gives nasty taste (but is fixable)
bought_model: Color: CappuccinoStyle Name: 4-Cup Steam

review_content:
I wanted a simple cappuccino and once in a while latte. The thought of having steamed milk froth was my main objective. This machine does it all. I shuddered at the thought of getting into the world of 'pulling the perfect shot of espresso' and have shied away from buying any machine for years. The Mr. Coffee Cafe Barista is the solution for me. Simple and delicious.
As I sit here sipping my cappuccino after a week of use I'm very happy with my purchase. Here's why.
1. The operation is simple and the front of the machine has icons that I would hope anyone can follow. I can.
2. It makes a very good cuppa whatever you want. Maybe not for the gourmet, but it does it for me.
3. The price is great.
There were some problems with what filter came with the machine. Instead of the promised two there was only one and Mr. Coffee is going through some kind of a transition with whether they will include the double shot filter. I called and they sent what I needed but only after asking for a supervisor.
I make chai tea latte's often and this is a great machine for that. I simply grind my loose tea finer and put it in the filter and treat it like latte from there! Rooibos, Assam and chai spices all make a great drink.
Finally, the machine has cleaning modes for both the milk container and the espresso filter. I recommend reading the manual as it's super easy to follow and the questions and answers are needlessly complicated here.
title: Great value, great cuppa
bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Espresso/Cappuccino Maker

review_content:
I have used this espresso maker for over 9 months and I wish I could give a positive review. The machine was great at the beginning. After 7 months of use, the machine started to make louder noises and the amount of coffee coming out started to decrease. This was troubling since I would consistently take care of the machine through the recommended cleaning procedures. Just recently, the machine totally stopped working. I can hear the pumps working but nothing is coming out. This seems to be a common issue. Customer service is a very big joke. They go out of their way to try to not help you. I am still within the warranty period but customer service is unwilling to help at all. This will be my last purchase of a Mr. Coffee product.

While most of the 5 star reviews are from initial impressions, I would put more weight on the reviews that are made after a few months have past from the date of purchase.
title: Started off well ...
bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Espresso/Cappuccino Maker

review_content: This coffee machine could be wonderful! I love how easy it is to use. I love the temperature of the coffee. I love the option to manually or automatically brew. I love the auto clean function. However, it doesn‚Äôt brew consistent cups! I have not had this machine for more than two months and only use distilled water. The first week, my cups were perfect. After the first week, the lattes are not consistently sized. Sometimes a lot of milk comes out and cry little espresso. Sometimes the opposite occurs. Sometimes the proportions seem correct, but both are smaller or larger amounts than usual. Sometimes my cup is half full and sometimes it overflows! It‚Äôs a hassle to have to manually brew the espresso and milk, especially since I bought this machine for the convenience of being able to push a button and walk away, come back and my coffee is done. I‚Äôm very disappointed about this. It wouldn‚Äôt be as bad if the proportions of milk to espresso were always consistent, just the amount in total was different. However, sometimes I have a cup of basically all milk with just a hint of espresso, and this is extremely disappointing as well as a waste of grounds if I didn‚Äôt notice that the grounds were barely used before throwing th away.
title: Could be amazing, instead is inconsistent

Anyway, I found this on Amazon for about $35. I figured it should last at least 2 years. I read the reviews about the plastic taste in the coffee.
