review_content:
Photos: I still suck at latte art, but it is definitely possible with this machine.

UPDATE: I've had to lower my star rating because after just a month IT HAS STOPPED WORKING! :( The past couple of times I've used it, it hasn't been pulling shots normally, just drip, drip, drip. I thought I was tamping too hard. Today I went to pull a shot and nothing came out. I took the brew basket out and there was a lot of pressure buildup, water/coffee ground splatter. Now all of the lights are blinking and won't go off. I unplugged the unit and waited and it is still doing it. I am soooooo upset at this. I really liked this machine, and it took only a little over a month for it to break. I'm pretty sure it's too late to return it! NOOOO!!

Previous post:
I have been practicing latte art with it for about a month now (still have yet to master). They make it look so easy. I took off the black frothing attachment because it just gets in the way and the froth can't be done as well.
Only thing I wish is that after brewing my espresso shot I didn't have to turn the unit off and back on in order to go from brewing to steaming buttons. I wish you could easily switch from one to the other. The steam wand also takes around 10 seconds to prime up, so my shot starts to get a little cold. I brew my shot, then immediately turn it off, back on, and press the steam button to charge it so it's ready.

BUT...for the price, it is great. It's my first espresso machine and am happy with the purchase. Just takes a little bit of getting used to how to make your coffee right with it if you're looking to do latte's or cappuccinos, but I won't be as sad if this ever breaks because of the affordable price.
title: Works great! No leaks. A tip for cleaning Update: Broke on me after a month :(
bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Automatic Dual Shot

review_content:
I bought this as an experiment to see whether we could cut down on our trips to the boutique coffee shops. It has more than met my expectations. Espresso machines are tricky to use, and it does take some time and effort to come up with a single or double shot beverage, but once you get the hang of it, it's kind of fun and you get to enjoy the results of your efforts.

This is a manual machine, so you control the flow. It's designed to make a 2oz double shot from 14g of coffee, but you have to stop the flow when you've accumulated 2oz. The machine continues to pump water through the grounds as long as the knob is turned to brew. I still need to find a quick and easy way to know when I've reached the 2oz mark, so get some espresso cups or a small measuring container to get this right.

Likewise for the milk. Frothing and heating is totally under your control with the steam knob. I have an instant read pen thermometer that lets me know when the milk has reached the right temperature, which I highly recommend.

When you're done, there's a lot of cleanup, but do that after you've enjoyed your beverage. You need to keep the machine clean to keep it in working order. I've read some reviews that complain about leaks and wonder if they don't understand how the brew process ends. Once you've completed your brew, the machine needs to dump the pressure from the brewing process. It accomplishes this by venting steam into the bottom drip tray. This puts quite a bit of water into the tray at the end, so you have to dump and dry this after each use. If you don't, it will eventually overflow through no fault of its own.

In the end, you'll have to decide whether it's easier for you to head to the drive-through for your caffeine fix, but if you want to make decent espresso and cappuccino at home after that special dinner, this is a great reasonably priced way to do it and to impress your guests with your barista expertise.

review_content:
Changed my 4 star to 5 stars. After a month of using, continues to make a great cappuccino and macchiato. Frothy coffee goodness, excuse me if I say so, every bit as good as Peets or Starbucks, or to those real hard core coffee snobs out there that actually think "their" favorite boutique coffee store makes the "real" coffee, it's as good as those too. (Hey, I've been around the world drinking coffee.)

Other one and two star reviews here complain about cleaning or other minor details that I find no problem. I mean, have they ever really tried to make milk froth with one of the manual steam wands? It's messy and takes too long and clean-up is a bear. This system is easy, but you do have to run the automatic cleaner once and a while and provide minimal maintenance. There would be one improvement I would suggest...if they made a 3 or 4 shot filter basket. The Mr coffee only comes with a 1 and 2 shot filter basket. I can get around it but it would be a nice to have a little larger size.

Update: Had the unit for a year and still making a great cappuccino. I did buy a replacement milk reservoir because I dropped mine and the mechanism broke.

Update: 12-31-2014 Still making a great macchiato, going on almost 2 years. And yes, it still rivals a Peets or Starbucks. Pretty good design and product in these days of planned obsolescence. Sometimes the milk reservoir disengages when stream comes through it. This is probably due to wear on the unit interface, seals getting stretched, worn and such. Its a minor inconvenience.

review_content:
This is a great machine. I have had it for a year now and use it quite frequently and it works very well. For those who claim they had a dud out of the box, they didn't prime it properly. I confess I had a little trouble at first too but I called the phone number included in the instructions, got a helpful LIVE person on the phone who talked me through the process, and I have not looked back.

Pros: makes a super reliable, brainless shot of espresso with lots of crema. Cheap. Shot impressed even my dad (not easy to do as he has a $1500 machine). Did I mention, cheap? Makes a nice latte or cappuccino too but I rarely make those.

Cons: Occasionally get some bubbling from the milk frother connector, even when it's not attached. No big deal. A little messy to clean up but as long as you hold a spoon under the portafilter when carrying it to the trash, it's manageable. May not last forever but at a year, going strong and you could buy several of these for the cost of one high end machine so I look at it as a disposable item.

UPDATE: Two years in with this machine and it's still going strong and I still love it. I mostly use it to make espresso and it makes a consistent cup every time. It's becoming a better bargain by the day.

title: So far we both love it. Use it a half dozen times every ...
bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Espresso/Cappuccino Maker

review_content: I really like this espresso/latte/cappuccino maker!!  I like to make latte's with my own coffee choices as they're usually organic, so there's no question it was this machine over a Keurig.  It makes delicious espresso and is good at heating (not too hot to drink immediately) and frothing the milk for cappuccinos!  It also allows you to add more frothed milk if you use a larger mug or if you just want frothed milk for hot cocoa.  Only draw back that I noticed was the water reservoir leaks if you move the machine.  I've learned how to move it with out any leaking so I'm ok with it.  However, if you have a place to put it without moving it, that would probably work best.  Still would highly recommend this espresso maker! ;)
title: I really like this espresso/latte/cappuccino maker
bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Espresso/Cappuccino Maker

review_content: Know its limitations before you buy. You'll only be able to make one batch of espresso (about two shots by my count) because you'll have to let it cool down for at least an hour before using it again. The espresso itself was okay, a little bit watery by my taste.
title: You'll only be able to make one batch of espresso (about two shots by my count) because you'll have to let it cool down for at l
bought_model: Color: CappuccinoStyle Name: 4-Cup Steam

review_content: This product was the buy of the year. It is very fast and quiet when operating. I love it. I couldn't believe the price.
title: I love it. I couldn't believe the price
bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Espresso/Cappuccino Maker

review_content:
Great advantage (for me) over other same-/higher-end coffee makers: You just put there milk or half&half and turn it on. No need to make the foam manually by holding it in the milk like almost all other products do.
Small disadvantage: The foam maker has 5 pieces, which you have to clean carefully ... but IMO it is worth the advantage.

Compared to a coffee maker which uses capsules (even for milk) ... I prefer this one, because I can choose milk/half&half brand and I can control the amount of it used.

Note: There's no coffee grinder which is perfectly fine for me as we buy ground coffee from store.
title: Foam without handholding!
bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Espresso/Cappuccino Maker

review_content: Granted this is not the same quality of machine that Starbuck's uses however for the price and the ease of use, I am extremely happy with it.  I haven't used the frothing feature yet but brewing espresso is no more difficult than brewing a regular cup of coffee.  I believe pricier models have the ability to have the clock set and preprogrammed brew times but 4 cups of espresso brew in less than 5 minutes with this.
title: Simple and easy to use
bought_model: Color: CappuccinoStyle Name: 4-Cup Steam

review_content: It's loud and takes a while for it to be ready to make coffee. and the creamer makes a mess. And the portions are small.

bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Espresso/Cappuccino Maker

review_content: Love the machine.  I thought at one point the steam was broken but realized it just came unscrewed. I have had no issue with the machine works great no leaking and puts out a great froth.
title: Love the machine
bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Automatic Dual Shot

review_content: I am very happy with my espresso coffee maker and it is a very good product for the reasonable price. I only detected two  drawbacks:  It is noisy and vibrates when pouring the coffee.  The side switch to pour the coffee or steam the milk is manual and you must stand there and wait.  However, these were not showstoppers for me-- I can have a nice cup of espresso or a latte at reasonable cost.
title: I am very happy with my espresso coffee maker and it is a ...
bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Automatic Dual Shot

review_content:
I've always been a huge espresso fanatic and would usually start out my days with a double shot of espresso. My obsession started when I worked as a barista at an Italian restaurant. I wanted to produce the same quality espresso at home so being on a budget, I purchased the EMCP10 in 2005. The machine was great and would produce a great cup of espresso every time with just the right amount of crema. The pump died out last week and I went to Target to purchase the ECMP50.

I took my new machine home ready to feed my caffeine addiction (at this point I've been deprived of espresso for about a week). I set the machine up and filled the water tank to the "max" mark. So far, so good. I turned the machine on to let it warm up so that I could run some water through it and get it nice and clean. I step out of the room for no more than 2 minutes and when I return my counter is flooded with water. I look at my machine and the water tank is empty!! "Ok.." I think to myself. "Maybe I put the tank on the wrong way?". I fiddle around for another 20 minutes and realize that water is leaking out of the bottom of the machine (where the power cord feeds into the machine) and might cause a serious problem down the road (Morning Headline: Man found electricuted hunched over his coffee maker). Still wearing my jacket I throw the machine back into the box and head back to Target. The customer service lady said that was the third machine that was returned for the same problem this month (I noticed alot of the negative complaints were also individuals who had the leaking problem AND purchased the machine from Target. Perhaps a bad batch?). I give it another shot, crossing my fingers and hoping that the machine I got was just a bad apple and I do an exchange as opposed to a refund.

I get home and open up the box. Right away I could tell this wasn't the original packaging. There were also watermarks in the water tank as well as a few espresso grinds here and there. Now i'm thinking that this machine was probably one of the returns that Target recieved or it was a refurbished model. Either way, I decide to give this bad boy another spin. I do the same setup, fill up the tank, clean the machine and I'm ready to brew my first cup. I used illy coffee (a bit pricey but worth it), used my trusty tamper and set the machine up to brew. I cross my fingers and low and behold, rich crema! I time the pull and it took about 20 seconds... perfect. This $70 machine ($69.99 on sale at Target) produced a cup of espresso comparable to something you would get from a $3,000 machine (without all the bells and whistles of course).

The machine itself looks sleak and elegant. Controls are easy to use. When your actually handling the machine it seems a bit cheap because of all the plastic components. Overall, if you get a machine that doesn't leak you'll be happy with the results!
title: True Review for Mr. Coffee ECMP50: Great Machine, But...
bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Automatic Dual Shot

review_content: I have had this model for about 2-3 years and it has outperformed my expectations. I only had a couple issues but those were due to my own mistakes such as not securely attaching the handle securely enough - which made a mess of course - the mistake has not been repeated : ). I used the plastic tamper which is more than adequate but I did buy a heavy metal tamper which i enjoy using more even though the fit is not as precise as the plastic one supplied. I guess I enjoy the weight of the metal and I use it to tap the side of the basket to settle the coffee grounds in. Getting back to this espresso & cappucino machine - buy it, you will not be sorry, I think it is worth more than the price asked. It is so easy to use and is well designed. I really wonder if this was designed by Mr. Coffee or was this OEM'ed by one of the big European coffee machine makers - I would not be surprised if the latter is the case.
title: Great Machine
bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Automatic Dual Shot

review_content: It's 4-stars for the price point not the quality of the machine. It's also NOT ESPRESSO machine but steam COFFEE machine. I have to say it's a fantastic coffee maker. It made very good and strong coffee. However, it's NOT a real espresso machine. You don't get crema out of it. You might get some foam, but that is all. Over all, it's a good investment if you like strong coffee.
title: It makes strong coffee, but not espresso
bought_model: Color: CappuccinoStyle Name: 4-Cup Steam

review_content: Broke after about 5 months of once/daily use. Milk would no longer pull from the milk container. Tried cleaning multiple times with no luck. Made an OK cup of espresso but a pretty good latte. If you are looking for a true espresso machine that makes crema and is reliable, keep looking.
title: Great while it lasted.
bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Espresso/Cappuccino Maker

review_content: Way too many parts to deal with. Must run clean cycle and the amount of coffee/latte is so minimal. Doesn't seem like quality made.
title: Doesn't seem like quality made
bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Espresso/Cappuccino Maker

review_content:
I was leary about a MrCoffe product that could produce acceptable espresso drinks. First it was so cheap and the brand has a low end reputation. Being strapped for cash pretty much excluded anything over $100 bucks so after much research I decided to try the Mr Coffee ECMP50, knowing that I could return it if it under delivered. After the first cup through the machine, I was totally blown away by the performance of the machine and would recommend this to anyone who wants a machine capable of making first rate espresso.

Now the details: I purchased my first pump espresso machine in the late 80's, a Krups machine styled a lot like the Mr Coffee and many others these days. The first one worked hard everyday for several years and was replaced with another which did fine service for many more. Kind of got the caffeine shakes and decided to lay off coffee for quite a few years. Came back to java this year and picked this one up.

First thing I did was rip the rubber thing off the steamer. Many years ago they started adding these things to make it easier for some to make decent foam and steam. If you master the steaming technique you don't need this thing and it made it harder for me. You have to learn when and how and where to place tip into the milk. It takes awhile to get it right everytime but once you get it, it is like riding a bike. Like I said my very first cup from this machine was perfect as well as the steamed frothy milk.

Somewhere I read the machine has 15 bars and it has plenty of power. You find this out when you have the grind maybe a bit too fine or you tamped a bit too much. A strong machine will push through to the end but may slow down but it will get the job done. This one does that just fine.

Bars also deliver the steam pressure and this one has plenty. It actually has such force you had better have the tip fully immersed in the liquid before flipping the switch as you will not be able to do it once any steam emerges due to immediate strong force. One thing which would be nicer is a rotary variable valve for delivering the steam incrementally. If you are moving fast, you can get the steamer moving toward the steam tip while starting to turn the value on and manually give it the full power once you got the tip in the liquid. This machine you have to get the tip in, then flip the steamer on. This is clearly a finer point in the use of the machine not the final result.

The machine gets ready in an amazingly short timeframe. I have not timed it but it must be no more than about 20-30 seconds and it is ready to go. By the time you grab the coffee and load it up, the machine is waiting for you to get that cup under there and go. Steaming takes a bit longer but it is still quite acceptable. What I do is as soon as the coffee is done, hit the steam button then go fetch the milk and put in the steamer cup. Stick the tip in and the machine will be ready to steam.

The machine is made cheaply, no getting around that. Lots of plastic and thin brushed metal. It certainly feels cheapish so if you want something with authority and status on the kitchen counter, look elsewhere. The machine makes a fair bit of noise, rattles while warming up and shakes enough to jiggle and move the cups from under the stream if not totally level. This can send some elsewhere but it is consistent with its exterior appearance. I may place a mouse pad underneath it and I suspect that will dampen the vibration and sound as well as level it up. Maybe putting a few sticky rubber feet will solve it too. Again, this has no effect on the quality of the espresso.

Filling the reservoir could not be simpler. Just lift the back and up it pops to get refilled. Our machine is located near the sink which has a pull out flex hose so we just pull it over the top of the machine and fill it up without removing it. Also the volume is good and you get many pulls before refilling.

Cleanup is really simple. Just a slight tilt of the tray and it slides out for easy dumping. Make sure to empty it sooner rather than later since once it is full, that slight tilt will splash water. Also, make sure to take a rag now and then and gently clean around the O-ring and mesh where the water comes out.

The only really serviceable part on this one like my old Krups is a rubber O-ring that seals the coffee holder. It will wear out at some point but no big deal to replace.

The only thing which remains a mystery is the internals and how well they will hold up over time. There really isn't too much too these things other than a thermo plate to heat the water, a thermostat, and a few values to control the flow of water and steam. But who knows. I just plan top keep the receipt and if it fails to perform prematurely, go get another under warranty.

All in all, this is an amazing machine and a super cheap price if your primary goal is to produce a first class cap or espresso. Honestly, if you have all your technique mastered and use good beans, you can produce on par with the best. It will rattle and look cheap and who know how long it will last but for the cost of buying 20 cups down the street it is a no brainer.
title: Super value - Super performance
bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Automatic Dual Shot

review_content:
After sifting through other reviews on Amazon, it turns out I'm not the only one who's encountered this problem.

I received one of these as a gift last year, and after a few months of use, it exploded, sending flying tempered glass and boiling-hot water all over my kitchen. Anyone standing next to this thing would have been hurt.

I sent it off for a replacement and that one worked just fine, for a few months. Then this morning, it too decided to explode, despite going to near-paranoia precautions to prevent this from repeating.

I'm not expert in machinery, but it seems as though the handle likes to slip no matter how tight you screw it in, and coupled with the pressure this thing builds up, sends the entire contraption straight down into the carafe with enough force to send shards of glass as far as 10 feet (I have pictures!).

Just just be warned: while it's a decent espresso maker for a decent price, it's tendency to self-destruct can be a danger to children, pets, loved ones and your mental well-being.

STAY AWAY!
title: Warning - These are known to explode
bought_model: Color: CappuccinoStyle Name: 4-Cup Steam

review_content: Got this for my mom as a Christmas gift and she loves it. I may just buy one for myself. Makes a great tasting cappuccino and latte. Not a fan of espresso myself. Folgers coffee grounds work just fine in it. Will try it with fresh ground espresso beans.
title: Works great
bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Espresso/Cappuccino Maker

review_content:
So I've had this machine for over a year and I still love it. When I first bought it I did a lot of research and felt that the cons for this machine were not too bad. Like many of the other reviews I discovered that the reservoir would occasionally leak, especially after filling it up. After a while and the machine continuing to leak I finally figured out why!!! In the resvoir, where the lid attaches there are 2 thin slots (its the area that allows the lid to slide up). When I was pouring the water in (I don't remove the reservoir when i fill it), I wasn't really paying attention to how I was pouring it, and realized that if you pour water over the slots, then it is not going inside the reservoir, making it appear that it is leaking. I understand that some of you may have actual leaks, but if your machine only leaks when you add water, then this is probably your problem as well. Just make sure you pour it in carefully or remove the reservoir altogether to fill it. I don't expect this to solve all the leakage problems, but if it helps a couple of you then I've done my work.

In general, this is a great machine, especially for the money. I have had it for over a year and make two lattes for myself a day (plus i make a lot for others) so I would say i have used it almost 1,000 times. Like others have said read the directions carefully, and you'll get used to the machine quickly. The most important part is to use the red switch to turn the machine off. I once used one of the buttons or the dial to turn it off and broke it. The good news is that Mr. Coffees repair service was great. The biggest pain was that I had to drive about 30 minutes to bring it to a specific place for them to send it out, but I didn't have to pay anything, not even shipping, and I had a brand new unit sent to me in about a week!

Great product, and I would buy another in a second.
title: I FOUND OUT WHY MINE LEAKS!!!
bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Automatic Dual Shot

review_content: Its a good starter espresso maker for someone who doesn't want to spend a whole lot of money on a espresso and latte machine, it does do the 15 bars of pressure needed for extraction, so if you looking for shots you got your machine, only a few design issues I have issues with the button being on the right side is annoying should be in front for easy turning off, the steamer doesn't immediately steam the milk and you have to play with the knob a bit to get it going, and the shot doesn't automatically stop and you basically have to eye it and know how much you want before it become way too diluted, mind you even pro machines don't have auto cut off but for a starter machine it should. The machine works for the price and some design issues are annoying but it works for what you want it for.
title: Its a good starter but not good for a pro
bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Automatic Dual Shot

My problem now is after 4-5 months the milk frother refuses to work. I bought the 3 year warranty and they just told me to call the manufacturer even though it is past the time allowment. Now I have all this coffee syrups/espresso/pitcher/etc. and a machine that doesn't work anymore. I used to be a barista and clean it after every use, very disappointed now.
title: Wish it could heat longer but good for the price
bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Automatic Dual Shot

review_content: We used this for a month now and have yet to get the "perfect" latte.  One shot seems to weak, two shots seems too bitter. The milk container concerns me too. It looks gross after milk has sat in it in the fridge for a day or two. I find myself constantly cleaning it, and yet it never feels like it's clean. Milk keeps getting in places it shouldn't be. I prefer a separate milk frother.  With that being said, it does what it's advertised to do, just not to my satisfaction.  We had a Nespresso machine but switched because the coffee was so expensive, but it makes perfect coffee! We will be going back to that. Too bad it's past the return date.
title: Just ok.
bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Espresso/Cappuccino Maker

review_content: I've had mine 2 months, and I  love mine...I'm a coffee shop addict. .. I also bought a tamper, a stainless steel frothing pitcher, and long stainless steel spoons... really glad I did. I also ordered Torani sauces/syrups....Stainless steel frothing pitcher works really well with this,  and then I can pour easily into my tall travel mug and stir with long spoons... I've created my own coffee bar at home. ...use this daily! ! Someone said it doesn't froth as hot as they like.  I also like my coffee very hot,  so I have used a few tricks that have worked for me: run very hot tap water in pitcher/mugs to heat up prior to using. I also sometimes after frothing pour latte in XL ceramic mug and heat on high for 30 seconds in microwave.  Watch carefully while in microwave since milk will froth more in microwave, and you don't want it to spill over outside the mug... but 30 seconds on high works really well for me.
title: Very happy with this purchase... from coffee shop addict
bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Espresso/Cappuccino Maker

review_content: Ive used this machine maybe a dozen times in the past 6 wks. You get what you pay for, I guess. Maybe I should've waited and gotten a more midline product. The espresso seems to always be overly bitter. It just tastes a bit off. But I always do a cappucino, so I was hoping the frother would be cooperative and balance out the flavor. However, the frother seems to be malfunctioning. Its properly cleaned each time. But the lights are all blinking and it shut off yesterday during use. Ugh! Waiting on amazon to open so I can open a ticket. Crossing my fingers. I should've used it more during the 1st 30 days.
title: Use yours often during your 1st 30 days,  to verify its up to par.

review_content: I have made about 30 espresso, latte and cappuccino with this machine and I find the process an enjoyable morning ritual. With a little experimentation, I'm already making espressos that are customized to my own taste (better than Starbucks or Peets.)  I'm glad that I opted out of getting one of those fancy fully automated espresso machines: I avoided the hassle of breakage (which seems to be quite frequent), saved a lot of money, and gained the experience of continually improving my espresso making.  This machine is well-made and should last for a good while.
title: Excellent espresso and pretty good latte
bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Espresso/Cappuccino Maker

review_content: I used to make espresso with a machine that used pods and add hot milk like a jerk. This machine makes a drink that is far superior at a much lower cost. I did some simple math; this machine will pay for itself in 4-6 months, if you currently drink one or two pod beverages a day. Much cheaper than Coffee Bean or Starbucks, tastes the same and you don't have to leave your house. Hope the machine doesn't die or malfunction like every other small appliance made after World War II. One minor complaint: cups large enough to hold double shot drinks, don't seem to fit in the unit. My 15 ounce mugs fit, but occasionally overflow with foam. Taller mugs don't fit.
title: Trust it
bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Espresso/Cappuccino Maker

review_content: Great machine, makes a quality product.  But the first latte you make in a day will have easily twice the milk froth as ones that follow. This quirk has turned up in reviews for over 3 years.  Interestingly when I called tech support not only had they never heard of this quirk, and I had to explain to the guy that milk came in whole, 2%, 1%, and skim varieties.  I love the machine, but just be ready for this one oddity.
title: Quick, flexible, good coffee products
bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Espresso/Cappuccino Maker

review_content: The steamer on this machine is incredible.  Hands down the best steamer I have used.  However, the espresso side leaves something to be desired.  This makes great coffee if you are using it as a percolator, but for mochas, it doesn't do it.  The coffee ends up WAY too bitter because the temp for the coffee isn't right.  It's a pretty durable machine though.
title: Hands down the best steamer I have used
bought_model: Color: CappuccinoStyle Name: 4-Cup Steam

review_content:
It's been a year since I purchased this little machine. It was for sale at a cheaper price then, but I still think it's worth the price for which it's being offered now. I've had several espresso/cappuccino machines, most 4xs the price, and this has held up better than most.
I write this review because one thing is really important....regular cleaning and maintenance are very important. I have discovered that if I put 1/3 vinegar with 2/3 water in the machine and run it like that weekly, I can keep using this without any issues. I also run that water through the steamer to make sure things run smoothly with that as well.
The other thing that I have found works better is to simply remove the plastic cap on the steam wand. It produced bubbles and no froth. Without it I've been able to get a really nice froth.

review_content: This was my 2nd ever espresso machine.  I had the real cheapy,$40 you had to fill with water each use, scrappy frother.  I purchased this machine July 2012.  It still works as perfect as the first use.  I am purchasing another one as a gift for my roommates daughter for her new apt as a house warming gift so she won't run off with mine, as she now uses mine daily. It's ok, makes a decent cup of coffee but takes FOREVER to heat.
Also nervous about deep cleaning it, we went on vacation and I forgot to dump the water reservoir, had green yuck after a week...now my coffee tastes funny even after descaling the unit, so I'm thinking the tubing is the issue :/

title: Meh
bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Espresso/Cappuccino Maker

review_content:
UPDATE 02/10/2017
Well, about 2 weeks after my original review the machine started to leak slightly. Initially I thought it was from the drain tube going into the tray after steaming, it was not. It started out as about 1/4 cup of water, and has progressively gotten worse. This morning I went to make my morning coffee and the machine went crazy. It now does not make coffee at all, instead it makes the noise like the pump is running and dumps the entire tank full of water all over the counter. Sorry folks, but for daily or multiple cups a day, this machine simply can't hold up it seems. I'll be spending an extra few dollars and getting the De'Longhi 155 today. Really wish it was a different story, but this thing is no good.

I want to start this review by saying that I am a hardcore coffee snob, but I also do not see the need to spend hundreds to make a good espresso. As such, I took a shot at this machine, and I must say that I am really really impressed.

The quality of the build on this machine is pretty impressive, the accessories that come with it are usable, and the fill tank is an absolute dream. Since buying this machine I have made easily over 100 shots from it, and I haven't had a single problem. If you grind right this machine will produce an excellent espresso with a nice thick crema. My wife does lattes with this machine every morning and loves it. It does have a lower end steam wand, but it works perfectly to make micro and macro foam depending on the drink. I also really like the basket on the top, and the drip tray is perfect. Priming on this machine takes nearly no time compared to others I have owned as well.

The only complaints I have about this machine are the vibration and steam feature. However, it seems the more I use the machine, the more the vibration has decreased. It's no longer so bad it rattles my cup off the drip tray, so that is a plus. For the steam, it just seems there's not a lot of customization on the flow etc. You switch the knob to steam and it is steaming, if you try to turn the knob back a bit it will stop steaming and go into the cleaning cycle. A minor irritation, but an irritation nonetheless.

Overall I am happy to give this machine 5 out of 5 stars based on the price and the quality you get for that price. Yes, you can buy a much better machine, but it will cost you a lot of money. For a basic but superb quality espresso, I have no problem recommending this machine to anyone in the market.
title: Didn't even last a year... Updated review from 5 stars to 1.
bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Automatic Dual Shot

review_content: This expresso does an okay job of making espresso, however I can't get rid of that strong plastic smell. I ran two of vinegar through this machine and soak the plastic top in it as well. Despite all that, you can't get rid of the plastic steam. The steamer is pretty neat, but it's very hard to clean the milk residue on it.

review_content: Love the idea but is very inconsistent.  When making a latte I get half a cup of froth. If I make another cup right after I get less coffee and more froth. The bigger cup setting is misleading. It's a regular coffee mug size. IT sits collecting dust now.  I used it for 3 months but I finally gave up.

review_content:
This little machine has impressed me! When we first got it, I will say that I was a little disappointed, but I played around with it, and I've worked out some of the quirks, and it's actually quite a great little machine. First tip: Fill the carafe to the top of the metal line to get the amount of steam you need to froth your milk. Second: Invest in a good tamper. The measuring cup isn't great. Third: Take the guard off of the steaming arm.

This machine actually produces an impressive amount of crema despite the fact that it's not a pump machine. It beats Starbucks in our book! I'd recommend it to anyone.
title: Great little machine!

review_content:
I got this as a gift for my latte-loving girlfriend's birthday. I had super high hopes for it as I read A LOT of the reviews, good, bad, and mediocre. It has a great rating, which IMO is a huge selling point for any product. Unfortunately, it's just OKAY...

The main reason it's a 3, not 4 star rating is that the WATER RESERVOIR LEAKS!!! If filled to the the max level, which is what should be intended, the bottom "seal" appears to be overwhelmed by the weight of the water and it starts to slowly leak everywhere... I discovered this the hard way after filling it, reading more of the instructions, and then feeling a wetness on my sock. I hate wet socks. After huffing and puffing for about a half hour I learned that filling the reservoir about halfway to max solves the problem. I just wish the tank worked like it's supposed to.

My other qualm with the espresso maker is that I think the amount of each serving, single and double, is less than it should be. She and I mostly make "double" style drinks, cuz we luvz our coffeez, and I just wish the amount per serving were a little closer to what you'd get in a coffee shop. Not a big thing, but a half-star deduction nonetheless.

My GF thinks the lattes taste great. I do mostly straight espressos or cappuccinos and they, again and sadly, are just OKAY. Another half-star mark.

So with all that comes a solid three star rating.
title: High hopes - just OKAY
bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Espresso/Cappuccino Maker

review_content:
This was my first espresso machine. I wanted something cheap in case I turned out to be terrible at making it and the reviews convinced me it was worth a shot. I'm so happy I bought this; after getting a tamper, a frothing pitcher, a grinder, and some syrups, I was in business and now I have fresh lattes whenever I want, for a fraction of the price I was paying at the store. It really only takes me about 5-7 minutes to grind the beans (by hand!), brew the espresso, steam the milk, and assemble my drink, so it's a time saver, too. I was nervous from some of the other reviews, but it's been working very well for me. I disassemble and clean it after every use, which only takes a minute.

It took me a while to learn how to steam the milk properly. I tried it with and without the plastic "frothing aid," or whatever it's called in the description, and I definitely get better results without it. The frothing wand is very short, which means you need to choose your frothing pitcher carefully; I have a 12 oz one that I usually fill with 5-6 oz of milk and it works well. I can submerge the wand, the milk has room to move, and I have enough room to get the amount of foam I like at the end.

Great beginner's model!
title: Has a learning curve, but worth it

review_content:
I love this thing... As long as you take care to clean it after each use and give it a good detailing every so often, it will work like a charm!

Here is my routine - I hope it helps someone out!

1. Fold a paper towel and put it on the counter. Take the small espresso basket out of the holder and put it on the paper towel. Fill with desired amount of espresso, and tamp - not too hard! (ps., do you have a Misto olive oil sprayer? Turn it upside down and use that to tamp. Your welcome. :p) Make sure the edges are clean and place in the holder. Use paper towel to wipe tamp-er. Lock the holder into the espresso machine.

2. Using glass carafe, fill espresso machine with desired amount of water. (I generally make a latte, so I fill it with enough to make the espresso and steam too!) Put the lid on the carafe and slide into place. Do not screw the top on yet!!

3. Plug in the espresso machine *with the screw-top off* and turn to 'brew'. If you're steaming milk, take out the milk and pour into steaming cup. Set on the counter.

4. Once the water starts to make noise and is about to be or already boiling, quickly screw the top into place. This method ensures that no yucky warm water filters through the espresso and weakens it/changes the flavor. Since this little guy just works off of steam pressure, screwing the cap on when the steam really starts is the best way to avoid this. Be a bit careful, by the way.

5. While the espresso is brewing, I like to put my sugar in the mug beforehand. Remember that paper towel? Wet it. Once the espresso starts to change color or the machine makes a slightly different noise, get your milk ready, stick the nozzle in, and steam. I won't go into the method... You'll figure out what works for you! Once you're done steaming, use the wet paper towel to immediately wipe down the steam nozzle.

6. Pour your espresso into the mug, followed by your milk/foam. Fill the milk steaming cup with water and re-insert the nozzle. I rest the cup on top of another upside down mug so that I don't have to hold it. Now unplug the machine, turn the nozzle to steam, and let the rest of the steam out into the water. This will release the pressure as well as cleaning the nozzle!

Enjoy!

My only complaint about this machine is the position of the steaming nozzle. It is way to close to the body and not at all adjustable. Otherwise, it's a pretty good solution!
title: Great little espresso maker!
bought_model: Color: CappuccinoStyle Name: 4-Cup Steam

review_content:
This machine works pretty good. Unless you're a real stickler you're not gonna hate what comes out of this. Is it 100% authentic coffeehouse espresso? No. But it gets pretty close especially once you get the technique down. It is definitely better than when Starbucks has an off day, you know sometimes the barista is rushed or new and in training.

You definitely need to get a real tamper to evenly tamp the grounds, the flattened spoon it comes with is a joke. Also a nice accessory would be a stainless milk frothing cup but isn't entirely necessary. To get the most extraction you gotta experiment with how fine you grind it, you want it to be close to real espresso grind but not quite, then tamp down moderately, I use the same 30 lbs tamp force as recommended and try to adjust the grind, I don't use anything fancy, just a regular cheapo automatic blade grinder and just grind til I don't hear coffee chunks in the grinder about 45 seconds to 1 minute. Doing this you'll only ever be able to fill the filter cup to the "2" cup marking, 4 won't flow, but this technique extracts the highest quality strongest espresso without burning it.

Now for the extraction process to work properly you should definitely fully heat the machine, especially if you're going to use an "espresso" grind like I previously mentioned. This is where I did a little experimentation. Just setting it to brew will heat the water but not build enough pressure and soak the coffee too long before pressurizing to get water through the finely ground and tamped puck so you get weak yet burned espresso.

So instead if you slowly turn the knob to steam but not all the way you'll notice the machine turns on but the steam valve won't let steam out. This is great because you can let it build up a head of steam to really push the water through the puck. So I let it heat til it actually shuts itself off, listen carefully, you'll hear a little tick and then notice the boiling in the machine stopping. This means it's fully pressurized. Then what you do is then slowly turn it to brew til you just hear it drip through, let it slowly soak into the grounds til the first drip comes out then go full blast to the brew setting. This should get you to the proper quick brewing that espresso should have so you don't extract much bitterness and you don't burn it.

The milk steamer is a little weak but I actually fixed this with a little modding. Now people think it needs more steam, that's wrong. It needed more AIR. The real trick to foaming milk without overheating it is to incorporate air. Try it, remove the black plastic tube and try steaming the milk. It'll get hot but hardly foam at all. So how to incorporate more air? Simple look carefully at it, there's a couple holes near the top and a couple near the bottom I took a small drill bit the same size as the holes and drilled two more where they are so instead of two directly across from each other there are four 90 degrees apart. This incorporates far more air and I can froth milk completely even before it gets completely warm and the extra holes at the top also prevent the large foam bubbles from overflowing as it'll suck them back in for more foaming. Perfect, the milk is frothy warm and actually sorta smells of butter. If I want to whip up even more foam I can afterwards use my Aerolatte frother but I don't really need to after drilling those holes.

Following these techniques made the coffee and cappuccinos from acceptable to actually quite good. I usually make mochas with Coffee Bean & Tea Leaf Cocoa powder, absolutely amazing, and everyone I make them for actually said what I make is better than the coffee shop stuff.
title: Great machine, a few quirks, could use a few tweaks
bought_model: Color: CappuccinoStyle Name: 4-Cup Steam

review_content:
Why spend hundreds of dollars on one of the really fancy machines, when you can spend $80 on this one and get perfect espressos and lattes every time? I really love this espresso maker and have recommended it to all my friends.

I've read some of the reviews on this site that state these machines can leak. I had that problem once and lifted up the rear reservoir of water, then seated it again. I think the valve could be where it's leaking - it hasn't been an issue since then.

The frother is fantastic. The only thing I don't like about it is the difficulty in cleaning the rubber tube. My solution is to rinse the tube after every use, then drop it into a glass of soapy water next to the sink.

I removed the bottom tray completely so I can put a larger-sized coffee cup under it - that way I have a bigger cup for more hot soy milk in my coffee, which I prefer. After making each espresso, the machine will shoot out a small stream of hot water on the bottom for cleaning, which is normally caught by the tray. Because the tray's no longer there, I lay down a kitchen towel to catch the hot water, then I use the wet corner of the towel to clean the frother spout after I've removed the rubber tube. Sounds complicated but it works quite well.

There is a learning curve when you first buy the machine, but I've become quite good at it. My African grey parrot is my buddy every morning and watches everything I do while my latte is put together - it's become a cute daily ritual for us.

I highly recommend this machine for everyone, including neophytes to the espresso world.
title: Who would have thought Mr. Coffee would come out with something this good?
bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Automatic Dual Shot

review_content:
I see that a few of the initial reviewers did a great job of covering all the features, so I'll hit the highlights and also compare it to my previous espresso maker, a DeLonghi, another popular choice at about the same price.

First - for those that don't want to read too far - for my family, the highlight of this product is the milk reservoir. Our favorite drink is a nice, steamed, frothy cappuccino but with the DeLonghi (and most others) it was just too much of a hassle and I'd just use microwaved milk. Those units just provided the steam and often it would shoot hot water into your milk and it was a pain to have to clean the nozzle afterwards. With this unit, the milk goes into its own compartment - the machine steams it, dumps the appropriate amount into your cup and then adds the espresso. Afterwards, there's a "clean" setting that quickly sends some sterilizing steam through the milk path. When you're done, pop out the milk reservoir and stick it in the fridge until next time. So - still some work, but I'm much more likely to use this than I was with the DeLonghi - plus, this machine makes excellent milk froth, whereas the other one was hit or miss.

The DeLonghi is styled in silver plastic and stainless steel whereas the Mr. Coffee is black plastic and stainless steel (or simulated ss - not sure). I actually like the look of the Mr. Coffee better, but the DeLonghi seems a bit more heavily constructed and in line with coffee house styling. This one just "looks" like a fancy Mr. Coffee. If you were shown the two side-by-side with the labels removed you would have no trouble guessing which was which.

My only real complaint is that you have to swing the froth spigot out so that it is situated above your cup. If you forget to do this - as we did on the first day - the unit will gleefully squirt hot milk all over the counter. I wish it had a sensor to prevent you from starting the dispensing while the spigot was still in the down position.

Other than that, it works great, and tastes great. The DeLonghi is being demoted to the cabin and Mr. Coffee is taking center stage.

Can't comment on longevity - have only used it for a few days - but I'll be sure to update this review if this slightly lightweight unit fails to deliver in the long run, but so far, great!

4.5 stars.

This appliance maker would do well to re-engineer the oddly shaped, texture-less water reservoir cap and control knob. I also agree with others about the too-short electrical cord (yes, it's completely unwrapped).

title: It's not like the fancy ones that cost hundreds of dollars but ...
bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Automatic Dual Shot

review_content:
To start, this product does not even make real espresso, just dark coffee... but we figured that out and were fine with it, as we were just in it for the caffeine fix and taste. But our machine cannot make over two shots at once... I read the troubleshooting manual and tried different fineness of grinds and adjusted my tamping, but it still has a hard time brewing over 2 shots. Speaking of the tamping, it would have been nice.. err.. necessary for it to come with a tamp, and a frothing pitcher at that. I have not had success frothing the milk ONCE and have tried all different sorts of ways, including a frothing pitcher, cold fresh milk, cleaning, adjusting, etc. So if you can't froth the milk... it's really not a cappuccino maker.
Basically, all I can do is brew two shots of strong coffee at once. Not bad for that. So I'll just wait for it to die on me, since everyone says that's what it does in 6-12 months anyways and then get a "real" espresso machine that works.
I've read really good things about the De'Longhi EC155 and you can get it from Amazon for only $80. I'm excited to try that out. I'd fork over the extra $40 dollars for that if I had known what junk this was gonna be.

My only complaint is the auto dispense options are a little inconsistent, especially since the milk frother puts out more/less based on how full it is, and I kind of wish Mr. Coffee would just make cups designed for the various settings so I could simply buy a set made for the darn thing, but that's really a minor complaint.

title: A miracle of morning engineering.

review_content:
This cappuccino maker is ok and will do what it was designed to do, BUT at the lowest quality possible. And you can forget about making decent froth. The frothing arm will beryl steams the milk and also is oriented in different direction on the right side of the unit so it is more difficult to froth the milk. What you see on the images is photoshopped frothing arm placed there for the purpose of showing buyer that appliance has one, in reality you will not see the arm from that direction. Control knob can be shaped differently so that you can have a good grip on it.

All in all it's ok but I would suggest spending at least $100.00 to get quality and performance to really enjoy coffee.
title: You get what you pay for.
bought_model: Color: CappuccinoStyle Name: 4-Cup Steam

review_content: Just made my first beverage!!  I always loved the Starbucks white mocha however looking at the cost of all my coffee as I knew there had to be a way to do this at home. After doing research I looked for my own espresso machine/steamer. All of them were over $100 and I found this one for $40. Since it was so much cheaper I read a lot of the reviews before purchasing. I just made my first drink and it tastes so yummy!  Make sure you read the directions or watch an online tutorial to use the machine otherwise you will be lost and may end of breaking the machine. Also be sur to clean everything first including just running water through the machine without any coffee (the instructions explain this too). I watched a tutorial on YouTube on how to make the drink and use the machine so that was really helpful. The only thing I would recommend based on reading the reviews as well is to buy at least a 12 ounce frothing pitcher. I bought a 10 ounce and it seems a bit small. Also some reviews say to buy a tamper however you would be fine just using the spoon that  this machine comes with. Ive never been a barista or anything so this machine is perfect for me. For my flavorings I got Ghiradelli sauces for $20 for a pack of 3 on amazon (chocolate, white chocolate, and carmel). I would suggest this come with a frothing pitcher, thats my only negative. I did my research so I knew what to expect but if I didnt know that I would have been a bit frusterated. All in all, so far so good!! Now, back to my mocha :)
title: I always loved the Starbucks white mocha however looking at the cost ...
bought_model: Color: CappuccinoStyle Name: 4-Cup Steam

review_content:
I had the DeLonghi EC155 previously, but it didn't produce the kind of espresso I was expecting. The grind was correct but the pump struggled to make the espresso; it would fall in small drips.

The Mr Coffee ECMP50 is awesome in comparison. Using the same grind, it was able to produce a nice dark espresso. I noticed that the pump has a 1200 watt output, compared to the 1000W EC155.

However, Mr Coffee has added a very cheap frother attachment, which goes more with a $30 steam machine, than the $90 pump machine. The frother attachment does not produce the kind of milk I expect - it is too bubbly, while a good frother would also thicken the milk and give it a more dense texture. The EC155 was superlative in this aspect. Anyway, my main objective is to get a good shot, and Mr Coffee ECMP50 does it better than the DeLonghi EC155. I didn't give it 5 stars due to the frother.

I do notice quite a few reviewers saying that it breaks down after a few months of use, and that is also a lingering concern. Plan to take a warranty. Have any other users done this? Any suggestions?
title: Great espresso but poor frother
bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Automatic Dual Shot

review_content: Makes good espresso, but does NOT produce enough milk. The manual says that a double latte is 15 ounces, and I get about 6. The single is even smaller--about two swallows' worth. Very disappointing. I'm not the only one with this problem if you go through the other reviews/questions, so it's not just a flaw in my machine.
title: Manual is wrong--hardly produces any heated milk
bought_model: Color: RedStyle Name: Espresso/Cappuccino Maker

review_content:
I have had 4 Mr. Coffee machines over the past 5+ years. The first one was a great machine for the am quick coffee and lasted until the decanter was broken by my dropping it. The second machine was a Espresso maker, a cheap model, and over about 2 years. The third one, a replacement for the cheap Espresso maker and again Mr. Coffee's cheap machine, lasted just over 1 year prior to going south. The fourth one, which was this machine, is not a good of a machine as the cheaper model and only lasted about 3 month prior to the wand tip coming off when ever the steam function is used, making the machine useless. In addition, the steam function will only work sometimes without a bunch of resetting the unit to the steam function. Even though I had the machine only a short time, I was unable to exchange it. The clerk noted that they had a 'few in the back' and were really sticking to the "in box' exchange policy.

As I have noticed a trend in the quality of Mr. Coffee machines going down, Mr. Coffee will not get any more of my money. I for sure was willing to put out about $80.00 bucks every 18 months or so for a machine, but this machine does not perform and for sure Mr. Coffee is having production and design issues which are not being noted in the general public. Their marketing group has done a wonderful job of selling really poor products.
title: Make a different choice for your am coffee
bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Automatic Dual Shot

review_content:
This is one big espresso maker. It takes up a lot of space on the counter. Also, it has a lot of parts that need to be washed each time you use it, which makes the morning routine more of a chore.

It does make a decent cup of coffee. You can choose between two cups to hold the coffee in. A small one for a single shot and a larger one for a double shot. There are buttons to select a single or double shot of espresso, cappuccino or latte. You can also mix it up and make it anywhere in between.

The espresso button gives you espresso with a nice cremora. The cappuccino dispenses milk into the glass first, then the espresso. The milk is sort of warm, but not hot. It also doesn't really foam. More like bubbles. The latte dispenses warm milk into the cup then the espresso. After trying each type, I decided on dispensing warm milk via the latte setting, stopping that, dispensing espresso, then dispensing the faux foam via the cappuccino button.

Why don't I like this? Because the hot, foam is very important to both lattes and cappuccinos. A latte is supposed to have 1/3 coffee, 1/3 hot milk, and 1/3 hot foam. This machine does not give you that. Also, the milk/foam should go in last, not first. And, as I said before, it takes up a lot of space. If this was a great appliance, I'd make room. But not for mediocre cappuccinos.
title: OK coffee, poor foam

It's easy to use and the milk container can be stored in the fridge and put in the dishwasher to clean it. I suspect there are better machines out there but I couldn't justify spending $1,000 dollars on one. Maybe I'll treat myself to an expensive one someday - for now, I'm very happy I have this one.

review_content: Don't listen to the coffee snobs who say you need to spend hundreds (or more) for a good cappuccino machine!  I didn't get a machine for a long time because I figured they would be too complicated to use, time-consuming to clean, and the inexpensive ones would make lousy cappuccino.  But Starbucks gets expensive, so when I saw this one on sale for $59.99 I figured all it needed to do was make 20 decent drinks to pay for itself.  It has done that in a couple of weeks!  Following the instructions, it's very easy to use, cleaning is also quick and easy, and the cappuccinos and lattees come out great.  It's a huge plus that you can use regular coffee mugs, so who cares that it doesn't come with little espresso cups?  The ONLY negative is that it really should have come with a milk frothing pitcher, but I picked up an 8-oz. one at the supermarket for $1.99 and it works fine.  If you are on the fence about whether or not to take the plunge on an inexpensive espresso/cappuccino maker, buy this one.

review_content:
I'm always a little hesitant to review an appliance. I'd hate to steer someone in the wrong direction, particularly on a high ticket item like a refrigerator or TV. I mean, really, you never know, maybe I got the only good one, or maybe my needs aren't the same as yours. That said, Holy $&%#, this thing is amazing, PARTICULARLY for the money. It was less than half the price of my Starbucks Barista I bought 10 years ago. I can't compare it to a 3 thousand dollar restaurant style machine, because I don't have one of those. I CAN compare it to the Barista AND my local Starbucks.

For $200, this is an excellent value. Even the packaging was a work of art and ingeniously set up for both reliable safe shipping, and ease of unpacking. Sounds silly, I know, but when you open it up, you'll see exactly what I mean. That's always a good start. If they take this much care with the packaging, I have to assume the build quality comparable.

The Quick start directions are all you will need. It's FAR easier to use than any of the fancier and far more expensive machines I was considering purchasing. As a matter of fact, it's so easy to use, I think I can safely call it idiot proof.

I drink my coffee black, so my first drink was naturally a double espresso. As close to perfect as I've ever made at home. I suggest you purchase some REALLY good quality coffee to take full advantage of just how well this thing works. We purchase whole bean dark roast Costa Rican coffee exclusively and grind it as needed. The espresso had a beautiful rich crema and was delicious. My first foray into a latte for my wife was met with great enthusiasm. She LOVED it and when I showed her how easy it was, she was excited that she could make it herself. Evan as a trained chef, she never really got steaming the milk for a latte or cappuccino down to an art.

It disassembles and cleans very easily. Fill the milk reservoir with your choice, milk, soy, almond milk, half and half, whatever you'd like. Remove the reservoir and just put the unused beverage in the refrigerator when finished.

I can't attest to the reliability or longevity of this machine, I've only had it a week, but frankly I don't care. I'll easily save the cost of this machine several times over if it lasts a year by staying out of Starbucks.
title: An awesome cup o' Joe
bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Espresso/Cappuccino Maker

I soaked it in vinegar and baking soda then I ran that through the machine.  I ran filtered water through it countless times.  All was to no avail.  The coffee comes out with some of that awful stink and the machine itself stinks up the corner of my kitchen where it sits on the counter.  I can't believe this isn't bad for a person's health...  Surprised it hasn't been recalled.  I wish I had paid attention to the couple of reviews that mentioned the smell but I let the price and the good reviews sway me.  Hard to believe anyone could tolerate this stink.  I am throwing it away and buying one with a stainless steel boiler.  DO NOT BUY IT!

review_content:
This makes very good cappuccino etc, but it is cumbersome.

1. Setup - the first time I had to prime it about 10 times before it actually started running water through. I almost gave up since directions indicate it probably only needs to be done once or twice. Thought it was broken

2. It is somewhat hard to line up the device that holds the coffee grounds with the machine.. and then it feels like you are pushing too hard when you lock it in place. It just isn't elegant. My wife has lots of trouble and has spilled the grounds several times.

3. The controls are not too hard to remember as far as making the coffee. But you have to clean it each time and I find it impossible to remember that you touch the button twice to get a double shot, but have to hold the latte button three seconds and not let go until it starts to clean.. and if you didn't move the other knob to clean, you get milk froth. I always forget one or the other. And forget my wife or kids remembering.

4. You have to clean. So every time I make cappuccino or latte, I have to remember afterwards to come back to the coffee machine to run a clean cycle... or I have to do it before I enjoy the coffee. If I don't do it right then, it is hanging over me... If I do do it right then, the several minute process just eats into the coffee drinking experience. When I put it off, I end up forgetting and someone else is exposed to the old milk. Oh, and don't forget to throw out the grounds.. expected.. but also time consuming. And don't forget to put the milk container in the fridge without knocking off the top!

The one thing that makes this worth it is the froth. It is excellent froth. With my regular machine, I often use one of those electric stirrers to whip froth... which never says frothed... This froth lasts and is hot.

Bottom line, for a semi automatic process, it is very cumbersome. I like the coffee and I am not sending it back.. but I will use my regular coffee maker (a Hamilton Beach Flex Brew) for everyday coffee... and save this for treats on the weekend.
title: Makes good coffee/cappuccino/Latte, but the process is very cumbersome
bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Espresso/Cappuccino Maker

review_content:
Wow! We are very particular about our coffee ‚Äî we live in the Puget Sound and even if we have only one cup a day, it needs to be of consistent quality and delicious. So I just got this unit yesterday and completed the setup / primed the unit and gauged using the Latte cycle plus added additional foam and voila! We are both pegged on Peet‚Äôs golden lattes right now, so I added a turmeric mix plus a half teaspoon of honey and 1/4 tsp of ginger, and the drink is already an 8 out of 10 plus a 10 for hotness. This drink was the perfect temp and just a bit hotter than how Peet‚Äôs makes theirs. I hope the machine holds up and to help you all, I will continue to post updates thru the next several weeks. Very easy to use and cleanup is a snap btw. Can‚Äôt wait for my hubby to try. He was convinced we needed to spend 1500+ dollars to get a good espresso machine. Coincidentally we also have their grinder ‚Äîgoing on two years of use and still working fine.

Update 5/5/18: very happy to say that we‚Äôve now had our caf√© barista for a few months and it is working great. We finally got the hang of how to make the perfect golden latte just like Peet‚Äôs makes, and we are incredibly happy with the quality of the drinks and the money we are saving not going to a stand or to Peet‚Äôs anymore. The value for the cost is highly recommended. Who would have thought that for less than 200 dollars, we would have found a great little espresso maker.

Update 9/1/18 -- sorry to report that the milk frothing capability stopped working last month. We have to g through parent company Jarden who mfrs and warrants this product for the first year, and it[s been a sh@T show through and through. Submitted our claim 3 weeks ago, and we keep getting passed to another dept who requests info we already provided on the original claim, told the same troubleshooting steps and we still don't have a resolution. For what we have spent going to a coffee stand due to this delay, we could have bought another espresso machine. For this reason, I can no longer give this 5 stars. Buyer beware of Jarden!!

review_content:
I'm new to the world of coffee, but already found I prefer espresso-based drinks over those brewed in a drip-style or pod-type machine. What to do, then, if you want to take baby steps towards brewing at home? For me, this machine was a no brainer. At the time, it was only about $150 (although that price has apparently fluctuated since), making it a relatively inexpensive way to try different drinks at home.

Simply put, I adore this machine. My wife, a more established coffee drinker, also loves what this machine is capable of. With fresh milk and high-quality/ fresh coffee grounds, it's hard to taste much difference between what we're able to brew at home and what we can order from a quality coffee shop.

My only couple complaints I have with this machine are:

1. There are settings to auto-brew cappuccinos and lattes based off a double shot of espresso, but they also increase the total volume of the drink considerably - to the point where only a few of our coffee mugs can handle the volume. I instead auto-brew a double shot of espresso, then manually produce the steamed/ foamed milk into a pitcher (you can do so by manually holding the cappuccino button for 3+ seconds), and then pour into the drink.
2. I find the warm-up time to be slightly on the long side. I've countered this by plugging the machine into a Wi-Fi connected outlet, which I can activate by Google Assistant in one side of the house, giving it a couple of minutes to come to temperature before I enter the kitchen.

There are a few things you should seriously consider adding to your purchase list if you're considering this machine:

1. A high-quality 49-mm tamper. Yes, the plastic scoop that comes with this machine can technically double as a tamper, but after picking up a proper weighted tamper -- even the $10 budget one on Amazon - it's SO much easier to pack the portafilter with coffee in order to get a proper brew.
2. One or two stainless steel frothing pitchers. Especially important if you plan on brewing a drink to fill a tall to-go style tumbler, as it will not likely fit beneath the machine.
3. A proper knock box for coffee grounds that you can keep on your countertop by the machine.

While yes, a much more expensive, more professional-grade machine may be more
title: A great intro to the world of espresso-based drinks
bought_model: Color: RedStyle Name: Espresso/Cappuccino Maker

review_content:
I just purchased the Caf√© Barista and it makes great Espresso and Cappuccino. I can't comment on the quality of the latte because I don't drink latte and so I cannot judge. I developed a taste for expresso and cappuccino on my visits to Italy and more often than not I am disappointed when ordering these drinks at major coffee chains here in the states, hence why I brew my own. For years I have used manual machines and been happy with the results, however, as I get older I am getting lazier so wanted more automation - hence purchasing the Cafa Barista.

Before purchasing this product I did my research (I am retired, but once was a research director at a not-for-profit research institute). The only concern I had was that some reviewers said the volume of the liquid delivered could be low compared to what was listed in the users manual. Upon first using the machine I thought so too. So being the geek I am I decided to conduct some experiments. I ran 10 trials under different conditions and used accurate measuring devices to measure the liquid delivered. Bottom line if you don't want to read the details is this a great little machine but not perfect - but for the price it is an amazing feat of engineering.

What I found is that the unit consistently delivers 1.75 ozs for a single shot expresso, and 3.5 ozs for a double shot expresso. More than the advertised 1.25 and 2.5 ozs -- so no complaint there. Next I measured cappuccino output. The output delivered will vary based on the temperature and fill level of the milk reservoir. A full reservoir at room temperature will consistently deliver a 5.5 oz single cappuccino, and a 9 oz double cappuccino. A little less than advertised. If you let the reservoir get low you will see a reduction in liquid by about 1/4 oz. If you heat the milk before putting it in the reservoir you will lose another 1/4 oz of output. Hot milk is losing volume in the steaming frothing process so this makes complete sense.

Single Latte output ranges from 7-9 ozs depending on fill level of the reservoir and temperature of the milk. For double lattes output ranges from 11-12 ozs. This is significantly below what is advertised.

In my opinion, for the price you pay for this device this performance is excellent. And the bottom line is the taste and for my palate the espresso and cappuccino out of this machine is better than what I can do with my manual machine, and is better than 99% percent of the product sold in cafes here in the states. There is one little family run caf√© here in the states that I visit occasionally, run be a couple of Italian ex-pats, that the Caf√© Barista can't best - but that is the only one.
title: Scientific Review of Cafe Barista's Liquid Volume Output
bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Espresso/Cappuccino Maker

review_content:
Overall this is an OK unit. I have always liked MR. Coffee products. There were, however, a few issues:

1. The steamer arm did not always work. I am not sure if mine was defective or not, but it would steam sometimes, and at other times it would just sit there and make thumping sounds. It sounded as if the pump was trying to start and couldn't. I would try priming the thing again, and no go. Then, after I turned it off for a bit it would start working again.

2. The frothing arm itself is way too short. In order to get the arm into a 10 ounce frothing pitcher you have to hold it up so high that the top of the pitcher is touching the machine (see photos.)

3. When attaching the filter basket there is a little latch that is supposed to help retain the sieve in the basket when dumping the grounds. However, the latch is on the large side, and when trying to turn the filter basket into place, (again, see photo) it hits the bottom edge of the machine, and makes turning it almost impossible. It may cause breakage at some point as well if trying to turn it causes undue force. Plus, the latch does not really help with holding the sieve in.

4. The water reservoir is very nice, easy to access, clean and fill. It holds more than an adequate supply of water.

5. Although a lot of the machine is made from plastic (aren't most of them these days!) one of the more important ones, the top of the drip tray, is made from stainless steel.

6. The unit works great making espresso and other drinks. As with all lower end units you have to watch the flow of liquid as there is no auto turn off. This is not a big issue though, and it is very easy to see the fluid coming out. I have had no issues with the filter baskets and sieves, they all function well.

Overall, with the exception of the very, and too, short frothing arm, this is a good machine.
title: A good performing machine that has a few design flaws. Overall makes good espresso.
bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Automatic Dual Shot

review_content: This is my second time purchasing this unit as our old one recently died (started taking forever to brew likely due to pressure/steam escaping). Still, before its death it lasted over a year of daily use (sometimes multiple times a day), so our $30 got us roughly 400-500 cups of espresso without a problem. Is it going to brew gourmet "Starbucks" quality espresso? No. The machines that do that are $1,000+ and we don't care to spend that much. When deciding whether to buy this unit again or get one in the $100-200 range, I found those ones have the same issues this one does and don't seem to last nearly as long, so why bother spending more? Bottom line: if you want a decent and quick espresso fix and are ok buying a new unit every year or so, this is an economical choice.

review_content:
For the price, this machine makes a fairly decent latte but it does have some quirks. I've been using it once per day for about 4 months and figured out a few tips that help me make this thing feasible.

First, get rid of the plastic cover over the steam arm - the bare metal works better.
I use a 2 Tbsp coffee scoop for one latte and pack the grinds down with the top of a kitchen thermometer (the flat glass cover over the dial).
I measure the water exactly using the carafe, filling it to the 2 C line and then refilling it to the steam line. Too much water, even a spoonful, results in watered down espresso & too little, it won't steam properly.
I use about 6-8 oz of cold whole milk - I've also tried almond & coconut creamer - the higher fat content in whole milk & the creamers steam better. Low fat & fat free milk just won't froth well.
I start the brew and watch it carefully - as soon as it brews enough espresso to reach the steam line on the carafe, I immediately switch it to steam.
I steam the milk to about 150 degrees, testing it with the same kitchen thermometer - this makes it hot enough for me to drink right away, but some may want to heat the milk a little more, just don't go over about 165 or the milk will taste scalded.
To get the best froth, I submerge the steam arm tip just enough to cover it, don't stick it deep into the milk. (I just steam my milk in the ceramic mug I'm going to drink out of, even though this is "backward" because instead of pouring the steamed milk into the espresso, I do the opposite. Since I add sugar and stir it, I'm not that concerned that I'm doing it backward and messing up the milk :).
As soon as the milk reaches 150, I switch it back to brew and let if finish.

A few observations - if I switch to steam too early in the brew process, it screams and makes a ton of noise for the first several seconds. If I wait until the brew finishes and then switch to steam, it keeps brewing and waters down the espresso and won't initiate the steam process.

When I've gone out of town a few times and the machine wasn't used, it took it several days to get back to "normal" - the first few days I used it after returning, it took several MINUTES before the steam would start, following the exact steps I always do. Then after a few days of this, it started working normally again.

If I pack too many grinds into the grind container, it will leak water all over the place. As I said, I carefully measure 2 Tbsp for one latte.

It's better to make lattes one at a time, when I've tried to make 2, I didn't get good results.

I suspect this thing won't last long, but I didn't want to invest a ton of $ into a machine and I don't really have the counter space for a larger one. Even if I have to replace it periodically, it's still way cheaper & more convenient to make my lattes at home!
title: A few tips that made this work for me
bought_model: Color: CappuccinoStyle Name: 4-Cup Steam

review_content: Up front, I'll say this machine makes a great espresso.  For $39, you can't go wrong.  But be aware that the difference between a good espresso and a great espresso is in the bean grinder, not the steamer-machine. I owned the previous model (ECM-150) for five(!) years, making several cups a day, until the rubber seal failed (the seal between the filter basket holder and the machine itself). Replacement seals are not available (go figure) so I bought this more recent model.  The espresso is just as good.  But I give the machine only 3 stars because of the terrible design of the on-off knob (on the left) and the filler cap that seals the water reservoir (on top).  Both are so poorly designed, so difficult to grasp, so completely un-ergonomic, that it occurred to me that perhaps the designers made them that way intentionally.  Why?  Perhaps to slow down the process?  I haven't a clue.  I am a strong man with dexterous hands and good small-motor-skills, yet I find these knobs a challenge.  They'd be impossible for anyone with arthritis, weak hand muscles, etc. Moreover, the top filler cap is set down into a sort of well, so that when the cap is loosened, any residual steam comes straight up to scald the fingers, rather than arcing out to the sides as on the previous model; always use the frother to release excess steam, then let the machine cool down before making a second cup.  With the ECM-150, one could brew almost continuously if need be, but not this model.
title: Good Espresso from a Poor Design
bought_model: Color: CappuccinoStyle Name: 4-Cup Steam
