title: Silicone Steam Gasket its Achilles' heel

Con: must pour steam water often or it will overflow, doesn't come with frothing pitcher, and plastic tamper.

title: I've been using Mr. coffee espresso makers for years.
bought_model: Color: CappuccinoStyle Name: 4-Cup Steam

review_content:
I'm a newb when it comes to brewing espresso, frothing milk, "latte art", etc., but after just a little practice with this machine already I can produce better caramel and mocha lattes than any of the local Starbucks. No doubt this says more about the local Starbucks than it does about me or the machine...

Nevertheless, the machine is easy to use and seems capable of producing pretty good foam for cappuccinos and lattes. I have had no problems with leaks, excepting a couple of incidents that were my fault (see below).

Some tips (based on a few days' use and research on [...] and You Tube):

- Pay attention to the size of the grind and don't over-tamp! Professional machines can push water through super-fine powdery grinds that are tamped by The Hulk, but this machine isn't quite that strong. If the machine doesn't produce a steady pour of espresso after several seconds of pumping, or doesn't fill two shots in 25-30 seconds, either your grind is too fine or it is tamped too hard. In either case, the seal between the portafilter and the machine will blow out, spitting hot water and steam - be careful! This happened twice to me before I figured out that my grind was too fine (no permanent damage to the unit). Mixing in some coarser-grind coffee fixed the problem and next time I buy espresso I know what granularity to look for. On the flip side, if you get two shots in 10 seconds, you need to tamp more and/or get a slightly finer grind.

- The black steam wand cover is a helper for novice milk foamers (like me). It makes it easier to create decent foam by pulling air down between the black rubber tip and the metal wand and into the milk. Once you've about doubled the volume of the milk you're supposed to sink the tip until the top of the rubber piece is just under the foam surface. This pulls the foam back down the wand and infuses the milk with it. It works OK, but after doing some research [...] I've removed the helper tip and am learning to froth the milk "like a pro" (except that so far I suck at it). Note that it's easy to make better lattes than Starbucks while using the helper tip, so it does do a decent job. If you want to experiment with "latte art" (rosettas, hearts, apples, etc. in the foam), which requires very fine foam ("microfoam"), you'll probably want to set the helper tip aside and learn to froth the milk with just the metal tip. [...] has some good videos on how to do this.

- Never leave the portafilter locked into the machine (thanks [...]). The rubber gasket will stay compressed all the time if you do, and eventually it won't create a good seal.

- Blow out some steam after you're done to make sure milk hasn't clogged the steam wand. And remove the rubber tip to clean it and the metal wand thoroughly. The tip of the metal wand is removable for cleaning as well.

- Empty the bottom tray frequently. After the steam cycle the machine will purge excess water into this tray. It is usually about 1/3 full after I've made one latte.

- I have only found one downside to this unit so far: there is no way to quickly turn the steam on-off-on, which would allow you to purge water from the steam wand just prior to steaming the milk. As soon as you turn the steam off after purging, the machine goes into it's internal tank-emptying process and you can't turn the steam back on for several seconds (during which water condenses in the steam wand again). This just means that a small squirt of water is going into the milk right before the steaming starts. (If you turn the steam on to purge the water out and then just leave it on as you bring the milk pitcher up to the wand, you'll end up with huge bubbles in the milk and probably milk splattered all over the place as the steam blows it around.)

I agree with some of the other reviewers - if this machine lasts only a year it will pay for itself many times over! I hope that with proper periodic de-scaling it will last much longer than that.

review_content:
Okay, this is my second version of this machine. When buying this machine, be sure to realize that after a year or more of repeated use, the pump may begin to lose pressure. This is normal. I work in a coffee shop and our professional $15,000 machines need to have the pump replaced every so often, and as this machine is so cheap, it's easier to just buy an entirely new one every time. I keep telling myself this, but I've kept my old espresso maker with the bum pump at the back of my closet anyway, for a rainy day project.

If you know how to do it, this espresso maker can make great lattes and cappuccinos. I've found that it takes about five minutes to get the temperature of the milk up to around 140 (how I like my lattes), so it does take a little bit of time, but it's definately worth it. I have very hard water in my area, so I used bottled water to make my espresso: trust me, you'll be wanting to spend a quarter on enough water to make a dozen lattes rather than drink nasty coffee! I also have a burr grinder that I use in conjunction with this espresso machine, and grinding the coffee fresh before each use gave me a marked improvement in flavor and crema quality.

On a last note, this machine can get pretty nasty if you don't know how to properly clean a pump action espresso machine after use. If you watch closely, after steaming, when you turn off the steam wand and remove the milk pitcher: that little droplet of foamed milk that hangs on the end of the wand will suck back into the machine as the steam is stopped and is instead directed out of the outtake tray. That means that the little blub of milk there just got suctioned into the metal steam wand: and it means you'll want to grab a wet rag, wrap it around the steam wand, and blow empty steam for a few seconds as it's cleared out. After that, the normal cleaning process (taking it all down, wiping it up) will suffice inbetween the "big cleanings" every couple of months. If you do this, your steam wand will work way more effectively and you won't be losing pressure as quickly. It'll also prevent some leakage that I've read in other comments.

Anyway, to wrap this up, I've had this type of espresso machine for about two years now. The one I'm currently using is brand new, and the pump is a little workhorse and I've consistently gotten nothing but great shots from this machine when in like-new condition. There's probably a 1 or 1 1/2 year lifetime on the machines I've used, given daily use (and I'm mean to my machines). I haven't had a single leak in all that time, and I consistently get perfect shots and beautiful fluffy foam. This is probably one of my favorite purchases on Amazon, and as long as Mr. Coffee continues to make this machine I will continue to buy it.

Ooh! And one last note: the box was just delivered as it would have been in a store. It wasn't the brown Amazon box I have become accustomed to getting...it was as if I walked into a supermarket, bought this espresso maker, and then set it down in the highly visible box on my front porch and went to work that day. Thankfully, it wasn't stolen when I got home!

Miss my old Mr. Coffee espresso maker. If I wasn't in Japan I would request a full refund.

review_content:
I'm really dissapointed because when it works, this is a GREAT machine. Very user friendly, quick clean up, and it makes very tasty brews. When it doesn't work, it's completely awful. It's hard to describe the milk, so I've attached photos.

We've gone through two of these machines in the last 14 months. The first machine was purchased for me as a Christmas gift in December 2014. It worked well and I loved brewing my own expresso at home. Then, around the tenth month we noticed that less expresso than usual was coming out the machine. Around the 12th month, it started curdling the milk.

Though we cleaned our machine religiously after each brew and use fresh milk, when the milk went into the cup, it looked spoiled and made the coffee completely undrinkable. Luckily the machine was under warranty, so we were able to send it back and get a second machine in February 2016. Like the first one, it worked great at first. Then, last week, it began curdling the milk again. It's been two months this time.

I called and spoke to Mr. Coffee's customer service about an hour ago and the rep was friendly and helpful, but said she wasn't sure why our machine was doing that. I asked her for suggestions on how to fix it because I didn't want a refund or a new machine, I just want my current one to work properly.

She then put me on hold and spoke to her supervisor who also was not sure. So, they're sending us another machine...our third one in less than two years.

I'll take the new machine, but I'm planning to look for something similar under a different brand. I don't want to keep replacing them.
title: On our third machine in less than 2 years...
bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Espresso/Cappuccino Maker

review_content: It may not be fair to compare this to my Cuisinart espresso machine, but...I ordered this to use on my vacation away from home.  Several quirks became immediately apparent.  The machine itself is light - easily pushed around by normal use, such as inserting the ground beans holder.  The ground coffee holder is plastic except for the inner bowl which is metal.  The milk steamer nozzle is plastic. The bottom where the glass pot sits is very light plastic.  Instructions tell you to fill the water dispenser on the top with 4oz of water and not to overfill.  No way to tell how much is in there after finishing each time.  Instructions also say to empty it of water after each use...how?  Turn it upside down, or steam it out which could take a while.  One of the most irritating things for me was that you have to add water every time, not like my Cuisinart that has the clear water container on the outside that holds enough for 5 espressos!  Note that the machine came with the coffee bean holder and the little glass pot.  Would have been better if a milk-steaming cup was included. Could not find one in Orange County in So. Calif.!  You should order online if you don't have one!  The machine got me by, but sure was glad to get home again!

review_content: My father in laws unit he had me look at it because it was not dripping water or coffee for that mater and I attempted to clean the machine following the cleaning instructions in the owners manual but when I attempted to this the water or coffee wouldn't drip and built up a lot of pressure and I had to be very careful when I turned the handle to the left to remove the coffee filter or what they call the demitasse cup (the cup where you put the coffee in) so I took out the filter and it worked like it was suppose to so I had attempted to use vinegar to clean this cup and retried it still was the same so then I attempted to boil water and vinegar and clean the cup and when reinstalled the filter or cup it was still the same issue so I had figured out it was the cup that was the problem and the machine came with two cups and I attempted to use the other cup and the machine worked perfect so I went to Mr coffee and ordered two double filters or cups this was after I wasted a lot of time figuring out the problem as well as the danger I was in from the pressure buildup which was so dangerous (I recommend putting a towel over the front of the unit and turn the handle slowly to the left even though you do this there is a lot of pressure so be careful and aware) I then read some more reviews and a lot of people had the same issue and also while some of them had coffee cups filling them when the unit built up so much pressure and blew the coffee and glass all over the kitchen and walls and floor. I had written to Mr Coffee on their website before I had it figured the problem out without a response so I figured I would let people know whom had the same problem know whet worked for me to solve the issue and I sure hope nobody gets injured.
title: ** BEWARE WITH MR COFFEE MODEL ECMP50 FROM PRESSURE DANGER IF FILTER IS CLOGGED **
bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Automatic Dual Shot

review_content:
I bought this as a present for my fiance. It looks great and we leave it out on the counter when we're not using it. Neither one of us really drink straight espresso so I can't attest to how good the espresso it but we use to it to make lattes and other various coffee drinks and we love it.

It is easy to operate. It doesn't take long to warm up or to prepare to make espresso or to use the steamer. It's also pretty easy to clean. The steamer comes with a rubber cover that can be wiped off pretty easily. Every now and then I still will take the cover off and clean the nozzle. The two containers it comes with for espresso are two different sizes but we almost always use the bigger one since we make espresso for two usually.

Overall, it's a great espresso maker for people who don't consider themselves to be espresso connoisseurs and is a great option for someone looking to just make lattes and other various coffee drinks. Plus, it's pretty cheap as far as espresso makers go.
title: Great Intro Espresso Maker!
bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Automatic Dual Shot

review_content: I have owned this machine for a year now.  I waited to write a review as my last two (different model) coffee machines failed; one just as the warranty expired, and one at less than a month.  This, however, is still functioning as it did initially. I really enjoy my morning coffee, and most often drink lattes.  When I've had company, they have also expressed delight in the coffees that I prepared.  Some of that company was from Italy, where they have excellent coffee. Someone visiting this weekend said it was the best Latte he had every had. I do buy fresh beans and grind them and I am sure this contributes to the equation. However, I cannot say enough about how I love the fact that this machine does all of the work to froth the milk; I never was satisfied with the wand type frother available on other machines. I'm pleased that this offers both a single shot and a double shot filter and I've used both. The parts are easy to take apart and reassemble, making it easy to clean. I like that I can quickly put the milk container in the fridge if I'm dashing out the door. There is an easy steam cleaning cycle which I generally perform every time i use it (although not those days I'm dashing out the door). Yes, it is plastic but the brushed metal front is attractive and the working inside parts do a great job. It is compact for a machine that makes espressos, cappucinnos, and lattes and smaller than some drip models out there. It is very practical for someone like me who appreciates a good cup of coffee each morning, and the ability to make a variety of coffees, but will not spend exorbitant amounts on a coffee maker. I've found my happy spot in this machine. I was surprised. Way to go Mr. Coffee!
title: My happy spot; this is s'pot to have!
bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Espresso/Cappuccino Maker

review_content:
Okay, so there are a lot of mixed reviews on this product and if you are considering buying the Mr. Coffee ECMP-50, please give it a chance.
First of all I am no expert on this machine. I have just made my first Latte and am very relieved my machine works and the quality is what you make it as far as I'm concerned. Now understand this is my second machine! I just bought the ECMP-50 yesterday and upon setting it up, the machine only "flashed" it's glaring lights at me and nothing more. I was a little disheartened but figured it was a lemon, and thankfully it was!
So today I exchanged my machine for a new one and yes it works just fine but lets' look a little closer. So consider first off this is a low end espresso machine. $80... great price and honestly I don't expect much out of this for this price range. I am just tired of going to Starbucks and spending $3 a pop on an espresso drink. So point #1...

1- If you can get about 30 uses out of this machine... it just paid for itself. So if it breaks after that, who cares. Buy another one! It's not a big deal.

The steamer is probably one of the better features of this machine in my opinion. To really have full control of it though your going to need to ditch the rubber tip and just get comfortable using the machine itself. The rubber end piece while a convenient way to help maintain cleanliness and create sub-par foam, is going to hinder the quality of your drinks... plus you lose that awesome "screaming" sound.

2-To properly steam your milk! GET A THERMOMETER! Yes you need this. Next you need COLD milk. Steam up to about 140-160 degrees depending on your preference and you should be good to go. To get quality foam you need not just cold milk but lift the steam wand to the top of your milk towards the end of your steaming cycle to just steam the surface.

I can't comment on the leaking problem because I have not had this machine long enough but It sounds like a quick return to where you purchased it or sending it to Mr. Coffee should take care of this and all other structural/wear and tear defects. (hopefully)

So. Given my experience working at Starbucks for a few years I can tell you that after using this machine. Price does not matter. Starbucks espresso machines run from $5000+ easily and they break down a lot more than you think (also get used a lot more!) But think of this like a car. It's a machine, it's going to require maintenance and cleaning. Take care of it. Use clean filtered water to prevent build up. Run recommended cleaning solutions through your machine periodically to break down deposits. This is plastic, do not be aggressive or forceful with your machine. Treat it like a lady :)

What I don't like?
-So far it's just a minor inconvenience but turning the dial for the steamer setting with a required purge at the end is a little annoying. I'd rather be able to have a little more control over my steaming and be able to purge the wand myself afterwards. BUT the swivel on the wand is great, and I'm satisfied with the length and quality of it. My milk was the right temp (with thermometer) & did not take very long to do... and the foam was better than what I usually get handed at "the bucks".
-I don't like that I cannot brew espresso & steam at the same time.
-I don't like that the espresso will continue to brew until you turn the dial and make it stop. If your not paying attention you'll overflow your shot glass and lose your crema :( very sad. Speaking of shot glasses? Get espresso shot glasses, they will indicate where you should stop the brewing process making sure you have the best quality espresso possible.

I know this is a bit long and I have a hard time reading long reviews but I hope this gives a little insight. This machine is worth the money and will be just as durable and reliable as machines that run in this price range up to $1,000. It's frustrating getting a lemon but it happens. Don't be discouraged.
Starbucks makes a great little home brew kit with 2 shot glasses, measuring scoop, clamps, steam pot, and thermometer for about $20 as well which is a great companion for this machine.

Oh one last thing. You can buy this at Target. So very convenient to not deal with all the mail-order delays if you have an issue.
Best of luck, and happy brewing!

Mr. Coffee ECMP50 Espresso/ Cappuccino Maker

review_content: I really like the product.  It brews lattes that taste very similar to SB.  It is a process (from warm up to completion about 6 minutes) to make but much faster that running to the coffee shop and cheaper.  My only complaint, it is pretty noisy.  I normally make my latte from a now discontinued Mr. Coffee Cafe Latte that is almost silent, which is important to me since I leave for work while my family is still asleep. title: Tastes similar to SB...IMO.
bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Espresso/Cappuccino Maker

review_content:
I have to say that I'm pleasantly surprised by the Mr. Coffee Cafe Barista's features and functionality for the price.

The Cafe Barista is rather lightweight and has a standard sized footprint. I'm coming from a sub $100 cheap 4-cup coffee maker/espresso combo machine and the durability and feel of this Mr. Coffee obviously blows that away. However, I'm still impressed with how well it stacks up against the $400 and up espresso machines I see at the store. Making an espresso, cappuccino, or latte is a straightforward process of loading your favorite espresso grounds into the included single or double shot filter, loading milk if necessary, and pushing the pre-set single or double buttons on the front of the machine. The Mr. Coffee brews quick and can produce a consistently great froth with 1% milk (I didn't try any other types). The milk frother's arm is adjustable and there is a cool mini-tray that you can pull out to position smaller glasses closer to the dispenser to minimize splashes. The latter is an extremely simple, yet clever feature that I love.

I have a couple cons, but they're minor. For starters, filling the water reservoir in a shallow sink isn't always the easiest task. The reservoir is tall, but slim. For my shallow sink I would have loved to see a a slightly wider, but shorter reservoir. Also, the dispenser tends to drip/leak a little after you're done brewing. Everytime I think my beverage is totally done, I wait another minute and watch a couple extra drips fall, but there always seems to be a few more that fall out after I grab my mug. Still, the overall clean-up isn't bad and these complaints and somewhat personalized and/or trivial. Given the price of this unit compared to the competition, I believe it's still worth 5-stars. Well done, Mr. Coffee...quality at-home espresso/cappucino/lattes at a price that's good for the masses.
title: A nice at home brew
bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Espresso/Cappuccino Maker

review_content:
A great little coffee machine
Id get this http://amzn.to/1mFX6Qp to go with the machine. Makes like a lot easier.

Pros:
Great tasting Espresso drinks - The flavor, the balance, the froth; it just all fits together
Customize your drinks - Easily add more water in your espresso or foam in your latte.
Easy to clean - With the touch of a button and some water and soap your job is done.
Straightforward buttons - No need for a manual to create your first espresso.
Affordable - For all the features that are included this is an awesome price and hard to beat!
Cons:
No integrated grinder - You either use ground coffee or need an extra grinder for whole beans.
Tall water reservoir - Refilling the water tank could be bothersome for less deep sinks.
Maybe too noisy - It can be too loud especially in very quiet places.

One of the specifications of this Espresso Maker is its 15 bar pump. While the optimum pressure for espresso is around 8 to 10 bars, it seems that this machine handles it quite well since most reviewers love the taste of the espresso.

All selected drinks are prepared within a minute. Therefore, it is not difficult at all for me to accept the not so perfect looking bonnet of milk.

There are probably other machines that are as great as this one.

But the amazingly simple way to use and the easy way to clean
So thumbs up and bow down to Mr. Coffee for creating this user-friendly Espresso Maker for your home and kitchen!
title: Nice little coffee machine that won't dissapoint
bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Espresso/Cappuccino Maker

review_content:
My first one the water tank leaked and the small cup shelf was stuck inside the holder. I had bought it used on Amazon, so I was protected & got a refund & shipping paid back. I then used my credit refund to purchase a new one, higher price, but not by much.
I love this unit, but the cons are the milk dispenser, you have to clean very thoroughly because the milk gets stuck down in the screws, so I use a toothbrush to scrub the milk out. Also the little metal piece that goes into the cup the milk dries on it and hardens, even when you use the clean after use feature. So again, you need something that can get into the small metal opening and clean inside the tube. Then the thing that really is annoying is that the first cup of cappuchino you make is the most frothy and fills the cup when you use the larger fill, but you repeat that very same procedure on the next cup and it only fills half. Its inconsistent. I contacted Mr.Coffee about these complaints and they are sending me another unit for free, to see if it was just the unit. But I do love this machine, saves me from paying an arm & leg at other places, and being I am in Seattle, it is costing me a arm & leg everywhere else.
title: I love this unit
bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Espresso/Cappuccino Maker

review_content:
Writing this review since I was dismayed when first using it that the espresso made was sour and cappuccino had a quite noticeable and unpleasant chemical taste. This, despite following the mandatory 'priming' instructions closely.

I feared the plastic reservoirs were leaching into both espresso and milk.

The good news is that we seem to have largely beat that problem.

Step one was running several dozen double caps and double espressos of pure water through.

Step two was the real improvement though which was to after soap cleaning the reservoirs and rinsing them thoroughly, running through a half dozen times with a mild white vinegar solution.

The combination of rinse runs, extra cleaning, and especially the vinegar solution seem to have largely eliminated the 'off' tastes.

They are still present but reduced and diminishing. I anticipate that with continued aggressive rinse/cleaning we'll get rid of them.

That said, I would happily pay $50 more for a 'pro' motel with stainless steel through the entire water/milk path. That would not only make the whole thing much more robust but eliminate this issue.

So Mr. Coffee: please offer a steel-only Pro version!
title: How to eliminate new machine chemical taste!
bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Espresso/Cappuccino Maker

review_content:
Espresso is an art and there are many steps in making the perfect shot. Getting this machine is the first step. It will allow you to produce nice crema. It also allows you to froth milk, but it will take longer than a more expensive machine. The machine is well-made and the parts are easy to take off and clean. The best part of this machine is that there is enough room for you to put a large coffee mug under the filter. This means if you are making a latte you don't need extra cups to pour the shot into.

There are a couple other things you will need to make good espresso in addition to this machine. Here is a list of what I use, but other brands can do the job as well:

Conical Burr Grinder:
The average grinder will "burn" coffee as it grinds it and cannot make a very even grind. If you want espresso like the coffee shops you need a conical burr grinder. I cannot say enough good things about this Capresso 560:
http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B001QTVXCS/ref=oh_details_o08_s00_i00?ie=UTF8&psc=1

Tamper:
Good espresso needs about 30lbs of pressure on the coffee in the portafilter to produce crema. This one works for me, but the one amazon recommends may give better fitment:
http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B000BU7TSA/ref=oh_details_o09_s00_i01?ie=UTF8&psc=1

Stainless Frothing Pitcher:
I used a ceramic one early and it takes far too long. This stainless heats milk more quickly and the 20oz makes enough milk for 2 lattes:
http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B000FNK3Z4/ref=oh_details_o08_s00_i01?ie=UTF8&psc=1

Those 3 things should enable the average joe to make good espresso and lattes. Remember the quality and type of coffee is also important. I have had this machine over 2 years and it still runs like a champ. I am religious about cleaning it after every use because coffee grinds will clog and discolor if left untouched.

There are much better machines out there, but you will have to pay a great deal more for them. This Mr. Coffee espresso maker is a great intro to espresso making and perfect for the average consumer.
title: Great Value and Intro Into The Art of Espresso

review_content: As a dedicated iced latte maker this thing works well and is a good value.  I can't speak to the frother...have never tried it.  You have to understand that this is a 'steam' espresso machine, not a bar pressure espresso machine...there is a difference.  I use Starbucks espresso roast and grind it gain in a bullet grinder so it is more like espresso grind.  I then fill the basket to two thirds full and gently pack.  I then use 2 ounces of filtered water.  The unit brews in a matter of minutes time which I am grabbing ice, splenda and milk.  Fill up a 24 oz cup two thirds with ice and splenda, add the brew, stir, add the milk...bam!!!  And my using this as a dedicated was not immediate...I originally was making hot lattes using a electric frother and was only moderately impressed.  But you can make two iced lattes with this in about 6 minutes...two different brew efforts...which is about the same amount of time you wait in line at starbucks!  lol.
title: Awesome iced lattes!

review_content: This product has a major design flaw. It has three settings; Off, Brew, and Steam. There is no option to heat up the water before brewing or steaming. This means you turn the dial to Brew first, then as the water heats up the water is slowly forced through the grounds with little pressure until 1-2 minutes it achieves appropriately high pressure. Making an espresso shot should not take 2-3 minutes, that is just coffee, and making espresso that slowly creates a very bitter metallic flavor. I've had cheap (sub $60) espresso machines before that performed much better. This machine will collect dust in your kitchen because you will simply say "eh, let's make coffee instead because this isn't very good"

review_content:
This machine is cheap, but does a decent job of making a cappuccino. What do I mean by cheap? Well, the first machine I got started falling apart the moment I tried to use it; multiple screws from under where the filter holder goes started falling out along with hot water. I was very disappointed, but sent it back to Amazon and I got a new one two days later. The new one worked like a charm.

A couple things you will need to accompany the machine (all available from Amazon as of April 25 2013): stainless steel frothing pitcher (I got Update International's EP-12 12-ounce pitcher), an espresso tamper (I got the Amco's 47mm Coffee Tamper), and of course finely ground dark-roast espresso coffee (at first I was worried that Illy would be too fine, but it worked just fine). If you've got a burr grinder that's great, but I went cheap.

One last minute, but still (in my opinion) negative detail is the location of the frothing arm. All the (photo-shopped) photos of the ECM160 show it near the front, but it is actually located near the rear of the machine. This isn't too bad, but it would better if it was toward the front of the machine as shown in the photos.

This was my first espresso machine.

Update: After less than two months of use (making about one cap daily), the frothing arm disintegrated. That's right: a metallic component fell apart during use. Fortunately I was able to return it for a full refund and replaced it with a KRUPS XP601050. I've been using this machine continuously since then and have yet to regret the purchase. The difference in the quality of the espresso is phenomenal. Even the foaming is better. The ECM160 is a toy in comparison; do not waste your time or money on it. I'm now fairly convinced that an espresso machine should cost at least $100.
title: Great for the price! *Sarcasm*
bought_model: Color: CappuccinoStyle Name: 4-Cup Steam

review_content:
I love this machine. The lattes taste wonderful, the machine is easy to use, and it was an affordable option.

The only cons on the machine are

-I wish there was an indicator to let you know when the water receptacle was low. Many a time have I noticed the machine acting wonky, only to realize it was just low on water!

- occasionally the milk dispenser has a hard time dispensing and will only end up dispensing about half the amount of milk as usual. I haven‚Äôt been able to find a reason for this and it seems to right itself over time ü§î

Overall I would definitely recommend this espresso machine. You cannot beat the price and it is so fun and easy.
title: Use it every morning!
bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Espresso/Cappuccino Maker

review_content: l'm lazy and I've never used an espresso machine. I was tired of my so-so regular coffee machine coffee and wanted an entry level machine that makes tasty cappuccinos and lattes with the least amount of work. I got this machine as a bundle with a (Mr. Coffee burr) grinder and I'm glad I did. The grinder takes the guess work out of how much coffee I need to put into the portafilter since it has settings for the number of shots one is planning to make. I read that I was supposed to use 30 pounds of force tamping the coffee into the portafilter so I tested my strength by pushing the tamper down on my bathroom scale until I hit 30 pounds. Easy peasy. Almond milk into the milk compartment and half a minute later I have a cup of almond milk cappuccino that is at least as good as what I could get at an average coffee shop. I used Costco's organic rain forest blend coffee and it was neither too weak nor too strong. To clean I just filled the milk compartment with water and pushed the cleaning button and then rinsed the compartment and portafilter. I wish it had fewer plastic parts, but at this price point and the fabulous cappuccino it makes I can't complain. Also, the space under the portafilter is a little cramped and none of my tall travel mugs fit under it, so I use a glass jug that doesn't make a mess when I re-pour the coffee into the travel mug.
title: Almond Milk Cappuccino!
bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Espresso/Cappuccino Maker

review_content:
Great bargain. I'm very happy! This is a powerful espresso maker. I've always had basic Krups espresso makers with the nob that let you steam while you were brewing coffee.They are OK. I don't own a coffee tamper because the Krups machine wasn't powerful enough to push through packed coffee. If you get this machine get a coffee tamper and use it.

When I make caf√© lattes for my husband and I -- I fill the carafe with cold water just a little above the silver band. That way I have enough water for the espresso and milk steaming. I'll let the espresso brew a little so there is maybe 1/2 inch or so of espresso in the carafe then I switch it to steam and take the milk to about 137 degrees, then I switch back to the brew side and finish. We each have a regular size mug of caf√© latte. The frother works very well but we don't like a lot of foam so I won't use it much.

The Mr. Coffee brew basket holes are just a titch bigger than the holes in my Krups brew basket. (probably like a micron or so, I'm not an engineer.) I wondered if grounds would come through but there is no problem. I use the first espresso grind on the commercial coffee grinder and all is well.

You can spend a lot of money on exotic pump machines and there is nothing wrong with that. But this Mr. Coffee is great and serves the purpose. Once you taste a good caf√© latte or cappuccino you are hooked : )
title: Awesome little machine
bought_model: Color: CappuccinoStyle Name: 4-Cup Steam

review_content: I will be totally honest in telling why I bought this.  As of January 1st, 2017, here in the State of Washington the minimum wage took a significant leap.  This in turn drove up the price of served specialty coffee as every little coffee kiosk in the State had to raise prices to meet the new minimum wage requirements.  I said 'phooey' to this and totally quit purchasing prepared coffee drinks!  Instead of buying myself a coffee on the way to work every morning I now make my own with this wonderful machine.  The best part is the machine has paid for itself in less than one month.  Now that I have the hang of its operation I can knock out my favorite coffee drinks and clean up in the same time I use to spend waiting in line at the coffee kiosks.  My wife swears the coffee we are getting in our own kitchen tastes better than anything we can buy from anyplace (you know who you are).  Although this machine does most of the work it still gives me a sense of satisfaction every morning when I drive past a coffee kiosk without stopping because I already have my very own Espresso/Cappuccino, etc..
title: Paid for itself in less than one month!
bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Espresso/Cappuccino Maker

review_content:
I have had this machine for one month and so far I love it! For the price, it can't be beat. I looked around for a while to try to find something that would compare but couldn't. I love how it has a self cleaning feature for the milk spout. I don't mind the tamper either, for some reason other reviewers complain about it. Works fine for me.

Other reviewers also say that their unit leaks at the water basin. I left mine with water over night once and I had no problem. Water usually stays in the basin for about and hour at a time and still no leaks. When I brew I just put in one cup of water, brew a double shot, use the self clean function and then pour out the rest that is left in the basin after I am done drinking my cup. Worry free.

Here is a tip from my experimenting with two types of coffee. I tried the in blu lavazza espresso coffee ($10+ on amazon) and cafe bustello ($3 at my grocery store). For me the cafe bustello was very strong and bitter even in a cappuccino. However, if you use a single shot tamper, and brew a double shot cappuccino or latte, it takes the edge off and tastes great!
title: Love it!
bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Espresso/Cappuccino Maker

review_content: Didnt expect much since this was a steam system (vs the more effective pump), but the build quality and overall design was lacking too. Very lightweight unit, getting the portafilter in position basically forces you to hold the entire espresso maker in place. The portafilter design seemed cheap and prone to breaking easily. The system took a long time to warm up, and produced mediocre espresso even at full temp. I purchased a Capresso pump system for $30 more on sale, which has a proper 15 bar pump system, and have been much happier. Definitely spend a few extra dollars for a pump pressure system, it is the only way to get a proper espresso shot!

review_content: Fantastic product for the price, if you aren't unlucky.  So far, I have used three of these machines, and the quality of espresso they put out is actually very good.  However, it seems that quality control might be an issue for these machines (as the price would suggest), and sometimes that might lead to failure; I have had one completely break (broken seal or something), that ended in a cloud of steam and grounds all over a counter.  Bad quality control also means that most of the time the machine will be fine for years;  I've been using the same one in my house for around three years now I think.  Overall, I would definitely recommend this machine if you're on a budget.

review_content: This is an amazing little machine. I‚Äôve used it every day since it was delivered. It is easy to use and I enjoy the variety of drinks that I can make. The built in frothier and milk frother/reservoir was a dealbreaker for me. It makes things very convenient. I was pleasantly surprised at the compact size of this machine. I was expecting it to be larger, but it‚Äôs smaller size takes up less room then you‚Äôd think. I‚Äôve been comparison shopping for this model for several months, and I couldn‚Äôt find one company that could beat Amazon‚Äôs price. It‚Äôs a great machine at a fantastic price. Well worth the cost. Even if you are a novice, you will find this machine so easy to operate, you‚Äôll be a pro in no time.

review_content: Replaced a discontinued very inexpensive Mr. Coffee model after it finally gave out after years of expressos. This model has the automatic milk frother. We love it! The only problem we have is that the self cleaning by push button frothing system no longer works. No big deal as we rinse it under the sink and put it back in the fridge full of milk. Hot mix for my College and high school daughters, push a small latte and let it finish, then push a small cappuccino, push the button again after the milk only. Add a touch of natural bliss, stir, and you have a not too strong drink much cheaper then you get at the coffee shops. Spend your money on a good grinder and you will like the results!
title: Mr. Coffee, you make our family very happy for a 1/10 of what the top end machines cost!
bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Espresso/Cappuccino Maker

review_content:
This is perhaps the fifth Mr. Coffee espresso maker I have bought in my life. They are not expensive and need to be replaced about once every couple of years if you use it every day - but they are way cheaper than buying cappuccino everyday, even if you buy the machine once a year! That is how I look at it.

They produce great foam (I automatically remove the plastic cover that comes on the foaming apparatus and do not use it; I just don't need it and I feel like it foams it before it heats it - probably because I steam the milk right in my coffee cup, which is small compared to a foaming carafe). And they produce a decent espresso. It is not thick espresso, but it is adequate. I know espresso is supposed to pour at a certain thickness per second - but I am not that technical or picky.

I have bought a model every couple of years since I was a freshman in college in 2001 - I recommend it to someone who likes cappuccino, doesn't want to pay three dollars a day for coffee, and who is not an aficionado.

How do I know when it is time to replace my machine? Either the foamer or the espresso making part just quits working, it sputters and takes forever to produce coffee, even after I give it a vinegar rinse. Then it is cheaper to replace than to fix.

Tip: using distilled water from the grocery store prolongs the life of this product significantly.

Another tip: if your water is hard, like well water from Michigan or Florida, DO NOT PUT IT IN THIS MACHINE. Hard water clogs this thing fast. I think this would be true of any espresso maker, however.
title: Still worth the money, even though you have to replace every couple of years.

Please read THOROUGHLY!!! With respect to the others who have left less than 4 stars, BOO HOO! ITS 39.00! THIS THING ROCKS FOR 39.00 bucks. I must tell you, I thought, Mr. Coffee, it must be a piece of s_hit, but I bought it anyway cause it seemed simple and I liked the weight and feel of the potential piece of crap. A great man once said "Contempt prior to investigation is a bar against all information."

Buy this even if you don't need it daily. I spend over 200.00 a MONTH at Starbucks, I used their Expresso Dark Roast in this thing and it was AWESOME! I hate Mr. Coffee, but the sub in China that makes this for them hit the f'n nail on the head. You watch, they will double the price after reading this review.

By the by, I NEVER write reviews, let alone a positive one for a over-hyped marketing company like Mr. Coffee. I am writing this for you, that is going to stand in Target, Penny's, Macys, or alike that is going to buy the complicated, more expensive 100.00 to 300.00 machine when we dont possibly have that many friends interested in the size of our unit or the frequency of its use. A little poetic licence here, but buy one and tell me I was wrong, I doubt you will...

Best,

Dave

review_content:
It's only my 3rd day enjoying the espresso maker and so far so good! I'm no espresso expert what so ever, but this unit fits my needs. 2 things I wish were different though, I wish the milk would froth hotter. With my old espresso maker I frothed manually making the milk as hot as I wanted, but this is not an option on this unit since it's done automatically. Still it's great to have frothed milk with a push of a button.

. Also wish there would be a button for frothing alone. I feel that I will end up damaging the cappuccino button( that's the option that makes the most froth) or the whole frothing system since I have to press it like 4 times to get the perfect amount of frothed milk for my white mocha... Other than that the Espresso maker is just great! It's small enough to fit the limited counter space I have, cleaning is a breeze, and I get a perfect espresso shot with just the right crema for my morning mocha!

If wondering, for my espresso I use "lavazza inblu"(I've tried so many including "illy", "Starbucks" and even the budget friendly Bustelo, but for my taste nothing better than "inblu".)

For the white chocolate syrup I use "Torani White Chocolate Sauce"(the taste is similar to the brand that Starbucks use to sell. Sadly it's not available but at least I found a good substitute.)

review_content:
After battling with a DeLonghi espresso maker that never worked from the beginning I decided to go with this more automated espresso and milk steaming machine. All I can say is that it is amazing. It takes a few times to get used to the setting that will get you exactly what you want but it will happen. It's a matter of playing with the Foam/Froth knob. That is the main way you can get the machine to make you steamed milk verses froth. I tend to favor more steamed milk than froth. The crema on the espresso is far superior to that of the manual Delonghi machine I had.

My wife enjoys the automatic features. Just select the size latte or cappuccino and away it goes. One warning, the large latte, well, it's large. A standard coffee cup will be too small for this. The large cappuccino also barely fits in a standard mug. Due mostly to the foam. We've had a few messes when the milk went over the top of the cup.

I enjoy the manual feature. You can brew a shot or double shot of espresso and then manually add the steamed milk and foam as you like it. I like a little less steamed milk than the machine provides for its automatic cappuccino and latte settings.
If you are someone who doesn't want to mess around with a crazy espresso machine and just wants an easy way to make a decent latte or cappuccino or even just add a drop of steamed milk to an espresso shot then this is the machine for you.

title: Mr coffee Batista is the best way to go
bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Espresso/Cappuccino Maker

review_content:
We purchased this machine a little over six months ago, and it has performed well. We use our machine two to four times per day, use filtered water only, and cleaning as recommended, which is after each round of use and quickly becomes part of the ritual. A few times we did deferred maintenance and could tell; Mr. Coffee likes to be clean. Deliming has not been a problem. So if you don't like to clean or simply don't have time this may not be the espresso machine for you.

We have currently settled on LaVazza as our coffee of choice, and it produces very good espresso and cappuccino with the Barista.

Recently, the brew head has developed a drip during preheating, but this hasn't affected the quality of our drinks. Hopefully it's not a sign of another problem to come. The instructions suggested that you can store milk in the removable milk reservoir, but we advise against it because the milk tends to sour rather quickly in the container. We just pour any remaining milk back into the carton. Others have commented that dried milk collects on the end of the metal froth tube, and while this is true, the metal tube is actually a sleeve over a plastic tube, and is removable and easily cleaned.

This little espresso maker has caused us to put our coffeemaker into storage. We're hoping it is more dependable then others have noted around the warranty expiration time‚Äî one year‚Äî but so far this product delivers hot tasty beverages every morning and most afternoons, and we‚Äôre glad to have it in our kitchen.
title: Mr. Coffee Cafe Barista Espresso Maker Makes My Day.
bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Espresso/Cappuccino Maker

review_content:
This is my third home espresso machine, and I'm totally LOVING this one!

Each of my previous machines lasted about 10 years each, so I'm a veteran home latte brewer! My last machine was a Mr. Coffee as well, and I was really fond of the sleek design of it, so I was initially not very thrilled about this boxy look. I considered this model for several months, only seeing it online and thinking it looked like it would take up more space than I wanted. I finally saw one in a store then immediately came home and ordered one from Amazon.

It has taken some getting used to, mostly because of differences between it and my last machine, but after several weeks of daily use I now love it! What I love most is that it is REALLY FAST!!! I guess that's the drawback of a machine that lasts 10 years... you miss out on the latest technological improvements! This machine heats up incredibly fast, so 4 shots of coffee is done in less than 5 minutes, and steaming the milk takes about 30 seconds for two batches! ... I'll time it soon and update with exact times. :)

The steaming wand is very short and far back, and I thought this might be an issue for me as just a personal preference thing, but it's not, at all. In fact, my previous machine had a very long wand that swept forward toward the front, and I would sometimes burn myself a little bumping into it. There is very little chance of that happening with this model.

The boxy shape of the top part of the machine is made that way to be functional so you can put the carafe or portafilter parts there to dry or store while not in use, which I actually finally started doing, so now I appreciate the boxy design. The handles on the portafilter and carafe are longer than I'd like, and it makes me more nervous about knocking the glass carafe on the floor and breaking it. But I'm getting used to them after using it daily for several weeks now, and I suppose it's better for someone with very large hands.

My only lingering complaint is that the lid of the glass carafe barely snaps in, so at the slightest tap against the Portafilters spout, it dislodges. This can make pouring the coffee a little messy if you don't realize it and re-seat the lid first.

All around this is an amazing home espresso machine, especially for the price, and I would highly recommend it to anyone wishing to make espresso, cappuccino's or lattes at home. It would also make a wonderful gift!
title: Fastest home espresso machine I've ever used!  Love it!
bought_model: Color: CappuccinoStyle Name: 4-Cup Steam

review_content: Espresso-philia grows out of control very quickly. The process holds both artists and engineers at the intersection of creativity and logic. For those of us that just want a decent espresso in the morning, without much trouble or expense, or reporting to the local dosing center (coffee house), this machine is a great compromise, and at the price will pay for itself in a less than a month's worth of coffee house visits. Also quite nice for a morning wake-up, before leaving.  This machine even does pre-infusion... Combined with a conical burr grinder, the ECMP50 makes the morning coffee ritual starts to look very promising indeed.
title: Great at-home solution for the price.
bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Automatic Dual Shot

review_content: It fits easily on my counter & the coffee is fine. What I like the least: the frother. Will I ever, ever find one that really works? I get lots of bubbles but, so far, am pretty disappointed with the lack the "cream." The design is also flawed. The brew/froth knob is on the left while the froth arm is on the right. That means I have to pull the whole unit away from the wall prior to brewing. It would be much better if that knob was on the front of the unit. Also, I noted a lack of good instructions on that frothing arm, esp regarding cleaning. You have to pull down on the black attachment and then unscrew the tip for cleaning. My local coffee shop is safe from demise.
title: Ok for espresso; not so much for cappuccino.
bought_model: Color: CappuccinoStyle Name: 4-Cup Steam

review_content:
Pros-

1. Makes great coffee
2. Price.
3. Maintenance free.
4. Very compact. Good for small kitchens.

Cons-

1. Difficult to open the lid that stores the water.

I bought this coffeemaker after my old Mr.Coffee started to get clogged after 5 years of daily usage. So far I had this coffeemaker for a month and I am very pleased. I use it daily at least two times a day to make espresso (duh) and love it. The machine only takes about 5 minutes to finish brewing and it makes plenty of steam after it is done. It serves about 5 cups of coffee. There is no cleaning afterwards. No filter that you have to replace or anything. The machine is maintenance free.

I bought this coffeemaker directly from Amazon for $39.99 and I find the price to be very reasonable. If it turns out to be as durable as my old Mr.Coffee it is going to be a steal. I have seen machines that cost double and triple and are not much better. At least not enough to justify the price (in my opinion). The machine comes with its own measuring cup and the little spoon that is used to put the coffee on the pouring spout.

If you have a small kitchen you are going to like the fact that the machine itself is very compact and portable. It has a width of about 10 inches and a height of 12 inches. It is also very light. Moving it around would not be a problem. On the bottom of the coffeemaker you have a place to store the cable in case you want to put away the machine or use it on the road.

The only thing I do not like is the lid used to open the water container at the top. The lid has an oval shape that does not provide a lot of friction when you are trying to open it. It makes it harder than it needs to be to open the container. My previous machine had a square design that made it easier to grip. The new oval shape is aesthetically pleasing but less functional.

Overall, I like the coffeemaker and certainly recommend it. It makes great coffee and it offers a good value for you money. I have had good experience with Mr.Coffee machines in the past and I hope this one lasts as long as the other ones. I will update this review in the future if I encounter any problem.
title: Makes great coffee at a great price.
bought_model: Color: CappuccinoStyle Name: 4-Cup Steam

review_content:
I've been using this for about two months now. I love it. It comes with everything I need and is easy to use. This is just a regular 15 bar espresso maker with the added automatic frother. Is the automatic frother better than a simple frothing wand? As someone who has had both, its hard to say. The automatic frother is easier to use, and is much easier to keep clean especially if you have a dishwasher. Steam wands can get really gunked up and are hard to clean. Still, sometimes I miss having a steam wand because it gives me more control over the brewing process and I feel like it makes a thicker, richer latte.

Overall, this is a great machine, and well worth the upgrade from Mr. Coffee's $40 base model
title: Worth the upgrade from the $40 Mr. Coffee Espresso Maker
bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Espresso/Cappuccino Maker

review_content:
I looked at many espresso machines before settling on this one and I am confident I made the right decision. I was a barista for many years and did not like the idea of not steaming mine own milk. However, I work in an ER and needed something that was quicker that hopefully didn't sacrifice quality. I most definitely found that. I am shocked at how well the milk comes out. The setting can be adjusted from latte to cappuccino and can also be switched midway through using it. So, for example, if you have a small amount of milk you can initially put it on latte and then as the milk gets lower you can switch to cappuccino to get a frothier head thus maximizing your milk. The espresso portion is also great and easy to operate. I have been brewing double espresso‚Äôs with the single cup which allows for me to have slightly stronger drinks with the same amount of espresso I would use for a single and there is no quality of flavor sacrificed.

There are a few things I don‚Äôt like. First, the milk container which plugs into the side can disconnect halfway through making a drink which halts the entire process. I have found I need to hold the milk container in while I make my drink which kind of defeats the purpose of it being more convenient. This doesn‚Äôt happen every time and I admittedly haven‚Äôt tried to rig it up or change its position on the table. Second, there is an option to brew a single or double espresso but no option to solely steam milk. You can set it on latte and then turn the machine off once the milk is steamed since the espresso enters the cup last ‚Äì but I would like to be able to do each on their own.

The things I really like, as I mentioned first and foremost is the quality of the beverages. They are seriously as good as I have had on any $500 machine. It is also extremely easy to clean. I mean ‚Äì like really easy. It has a self-cleaning setting but all it really needs is a rinse. It also does not take up much counter space and it looks great. I can‚Äôt comment on the scoop/tamper combo because it did not come in the box, however I contacted Mr. Coffee directly and they are sending me one free of charge even though I placed my order on amazon ‚Äì which I am very pleased with.

Overall, if you are on the fence about this machine, I don‚Äôt believe there is anything better or more convenient ‚Äì especially at this price point. I am pretty snobby about my espresso and right out of the box I was not disappointed with this item. The things I don‚Äôt like about it are far weighed out by what I do and ultimately that is the benchmark of a good product.
title: Shockingly high quality from such an easy, convenient machine
bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Espresso/Cappuccino Maker

review_content: The machine makes espresso just fine, and I haven't really  had any issues with that, and I use it at least 5-6x per week. It's very user friendly. However, the frother/steamer, unfortunately, stopped working well pretty quickly (within the first 2 to 3 months, and I've only had it for just under 6 months). I followed instructions, cleaned it regularly (it's actually pretty hard to get the piece off to clean the steamer), and read the manual to do any troubleshooting, but it was way more trouble than necessary. To make up for it, I just use the espresso machine for espresso, and then use a frothing wand to make lattes.
title: Espresso machine good, steamer not.
bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Automatic Dual Shot

review_content: Best coffee machine ever. Easy to use plus make tasty coffee in mins! Expresso shots less than 30sec! No more microwave to heat up Milk! One word, perfect!
title: Awesome Coffee maker!
bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Espresso/Cappuccino Maker

review_content:
If you are expecting to get the highest quality coffee experience, then keep looking. However, this machine is perfect if you accept it for what it is, a cheaper espresso machine that is made for easy use. It is super easy to get started and everything is easy to clean. It creates good enough coffee for home use that is about on par with Starbucks, Dunkin Donuts, and the like. However, it does not compare to the mom and pop coffee shops, but that should be expected at this price range. I really have been impressed with this machine. It does use the weird pressurized portafilter or whatever which is a con for some. However, this helps you with the brewing process as it doesn't matter as much if your grind or pack are off. I have not had an issue with the handle being hard to insert and twist all the way in the machine either.

One thing to note, the holes in the portafilter basket deal do not go all the way through by design. Some people have been mentioning in their review they keep getting faulty parts but that is just the way they are manufactured. It is very different coming from ones that have the holes all the way through, but rest assured it works just fine.

Others have complained about the difficulty of removing the water tank to refill it as it degrades the seal over time. The solution to this is simple, don't remove the water tank. The top lifts up and over and is still attached. It makes it very easy to just fill it up via filling up a cup and dumping it in. It actually is super convenient as I top it off every time I go to use it.

Also, I did purchase an extended 3 year warranty (really just two years since the manufacturer covers the 1st year) for an additional $5 since quite a few mentioned that they had issues after a year.

Another common complaint is that the machine vibrates and moves the cups around when it brews. This is due to the finish on the cover for the drain compartment. However, you have to stand at the machine anyways while it is brewing to shut off the flow once you have the desired amount in the cup. You might as well hold it while it fills. However, you can also just set the cup inside a rubber band or something tacky to keep it in place. It is frustrating that this is an issue, but really its an easy fix.

One last note, the machine drains into the removable drip catcher after every time you use the steam function. It just about fills to the top with moderate use so be sure to empty it each time. Otherwise you will end up with it overflowing onto your counter. This is what I believe the other reviewers are complaining about. Also make sure it is aligned correctly when you put it back as the back left goes into the machine and is the point of contact for the water to drain out. If it is not aligned correctly it can leak as well.

Overall, this is a great machine. It is cheap, easy to use, and creates decent enough results to satisfy my craving for a latte without having to go to a coffee shop. It also saves money in the long run. The pros by far outweigh the cons in my opinion and I'm sure you will love it too as long as you go into it with realistic expectations.

I have added photos of the drip catcher with the cover on and off, where the drip catcher aligns in the machine, the water reservoir open, and the filters tops and bottoms.
title: Great Espresso Maker For The Price!
bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Automatic Dual Shot

review_content:
UPDATE 10/6/16 - Tried the DeLonghi - sent it back. Bought ANOTHER of these!!! It's now almost 2 years exactly. Working fine - though we did go several months only using the Bialetti. Raising my review from 1 star to 3 stars.

UPDATE 9/2/14 - The new machine just died. So do the math - bought original in March of '13. Replaced 9 months later with new one (warranty) in December of '13. New one dies --- 9 months later. It was a daily user - 3 cups for me and one or 2 for my wife. SO...I'm looking at the $99 DeLonghi. With this experience, I'm a little gun shy of shelling out $4-500 for a fancy one.

UPDATE 11/18/13 - They sent us a new machine within two weeks of shipping it back for repair. My guess is this is designed to be a throw away machine - though I suspect that the manufacturer would prefer it be AFTER the warranty expires. If you can get two good years of service out of this, then it is probably on par with a $750 machine that lasts 10 years (with regard to cost-to-own). While we were waiting for our machine to return, I pulled out the 1 cup Bialetti Moka my daughter had given us. The Moka actually makes a very good cup of Italian style coffee that we got many places in Italy. (but, to you purists, not it's not espresso.) The coffee from the Moka is stronger and thicker than espresso, but it does not have the crema of the espresso. At least, not the way I make it. The other beauty of the Moka is no moving parts. We've decided, to take some of the daily load off the Mr. Coffee (to hopefully make it last longer) we will alternate between Italian coffee and espresso.

UPDATE 10/24/13 - Stopped working yesterday. Turn it on and the only thing that happens is the red and green lights blink at you. Will update again after warranty repair.

Within the last week the machine has become extremely slow to fill the espresso cup. I don't get any crema on top of the espresso. I've run a quart of vinegar through it in case there was mineral buildup. We have a water softener so mineral buildup should not be a problem anyway. I also have a 3-stage reverse osmosis filter under the sink - I use that water to fill the reservoir. I was in love with this machine for almost 3 months. Now I'm in hate with it. Will try to work with Sunbeam repair to get it fixed or replaced. More news later.

UPDATE: After 2 overnight soaks with vinegar, and making about 20 cups of vinegar espresso it's working again. Keep the vinegar handy even if you have a reverse osmosis filter.
title: UPDATE #4 - Replacement machine died - this machine is good for 9 months of daily use
bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Automatic Dual Shot

review_content:
Author's note: I had a Mr coffee expresso machine from 2014 or so that did the bare minimum for 40$ loved, loved, loved that machine.

Liked?
Not much. Honestly? I like that I can see how much water is in the tank and it makes my expresso taste better than the ninja coffee bar by at least tenfold, but still comparing to my previous machine: watered down with crema.

Dislike?
The old mr coffee came with a glass carafe for the expresso. This one does not.

This machine is obnoxiouy loud in comparison when pulling a shot... Or sadly enough you cut off the steamer.

The pucks are soup. I use fine ground expresso and this machine can't handle it. I theorize this it because it literally has one hole to escape the basket. Instead of the previous model that had perhaps fifty small holes and left me with dry pucks. Disappointing to say the least, when you try to use this machine often. I'm a diagnosed narcoleptic, I drink A LOT of coffee.

Everything must preheat and think. Comes on? Must wait for light. Espresso pull? Must preheat better wait. Done pulling and need steam? Must preheat. Loud noise when cutting off steam and forbid if you need more froth because you'll have to wait to preheat AGAIN!

super disappointed. I've refused to throw out my old expresso machine even though the wand won't work because I knew how much of a struggle I'd have finding another one.
title: Loud as can be; sludge pucks: disappointing
bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Automatic Dual Shot

review_content: i bought this 9 months ago and we use it daily- it's a pretty good coffeemaker so far and haven't had any problems with it. The milk frother is especially good and works better than expected. The coffee quality doesn't taste quite the same as it does out of the high end models but it's adequate. The crema layer can be fairly good but is better in the high end units. You can operate this without having barista training so it's perfect for a newbie like myself. When/if this one ever quits then i will upgrade but have been happy with it so far.

review_content: I will admit I am a European coffee snob so I was reluctant to purchase a Mr. Coffee anything but the product had all of the specs and functions I was looking for so I pulled the trigger.  Boy am I glad I did.  It is a very high quality machine and I have now used all the functions and am totally satisfied enough to write a review.  I received the package the day after I ordered it and went through the entire manual before using it.  I would suggest that you follow the steps in the manual to properly clean, prime and use the machine.  It is not something you should just "wing it" and if you do you may not be satisfied with the outcome.  I wanted to get away from the expresso pod machine I was using and since it had an EU plug I figured I would buy something totally American - I am impressed and recommend this machine for anyone that loves a good cup of espresso or a smooth latte or a frothy cappuccino at home.

review_content: I am the espresso version of the art gallery patron who knows nothing about art aside from what I like. After trying espresso in Rome and a few local places I decided to try making coffee drinks at home, and chose this machine based on the reviews. I spent the first weekend alternating between the espresso and cappuccino settings  and enjoying every cup from the first (and I was so caffeinated it was a very productive weekend!). The machine is quick and easy to prep; I've been making two double-shot cappuccinos before work every weekday morning. The milk steamer / frother is easy to set up and can be placed in the refrigerator between uses, and the water reservoir is of a generous size and sealed so you can use it for several days running. Cleaning cycles are easy and quick. I've never paid more than $15 for a coffee maker but I like this one so much I'm seriously considering buying a second for my office. I'm looking forward to messing about with mochas and frothy milk cocoas for winter!

title: Works great
bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Automatic Dual Shot

review_content:
Nice idea, poor product. With Krups Duomo being impossible to find, and DeLonghi making such poor espresso machines lately, we felt we had no choice but to go with this Mr. Coffee machine.
Let me start by saying that whoever praises espresso produced by this particular model, obviously never experienced real, European espresso! We are Europeans, living in the states for the past 20 years, and espresso is a big part of our lives. With this model being pump driven, i expected superb espresso, when compared to the steam one produced by Krups and similar espresso makers, but sadly that didn't happen, and now that i used it for few times, i see why.
This is not an espresso maker. This is just another Keurig knock off that we had long time ago and trashed. Same principle, same crap product that comes on the other end. You press the button 1, then stare at the button 2 until it stops blinking, then turn the button 3 to pour so called espresso in a pitcher or a cup. Eh?
Problem 1:
Water sits in a tank, and while the machine is heating up, water still sits in a tank. When you turn on the knob to make the actual coffee, it is only then that water leaves the tank, which tells me that water actually just flows over a hot element, and it does this very fast. In turn, what you're left with is almost cold shot of meh coffee. We tried to remedy this by heating up the cups or a pitcher, to no avail, still not nowhere near hot enough to be called coffee.
Problem 2:
Portafilter. One shot portafilter is way too shallow to produce a good strong shot of espresso,and you just can't thump enough coffee in there, no matter how hard you try. Two shot portafilter has a same problem, way to shallow. Once you produce two cups worth of espresso, it's so weak that is absolutely undrinkable and disgusting. Maybe we could use double shot to produce one cup, and duplicate the process for the second cup, but then you have to go thru the entire "heat up, turn button 1, and 2...etc" procedure again. Annoying, and who has the time?

All in all, for a good shot of espresso i will stick with steam espresso makers, as pump driven ones simply don't work. I managed to find old version of a little Mr. Coffee espresso maker on ebay, and went with that. Had it in the past and it produced very good, strong, and hot shot of espresso for a very long time. please note that newer version of this espresso maker is very poorly made.

Disappointed with the entire experience, and now have to bother with return.
