bought_model: Color: CappuccinoStyle Name: 4-Cup Steam

review_content: I debates over whether or not this was worth the extra money over other basic espresso machines with manual steam. I'm so glad I went with the cafe barista, I love this thing! It's so easy to use. Makes perfect lattes and good espresso shots. It's very fast too. I love coffee but this is my first espresso machine.  I drink drip coffee most days but this is great for weekends and days off.  Fyi Mr. Coffee makes a ese pod adapter for this machine.  They really should include it.  It only cost $2.95 from their website and shipped for free so they're basically giving it to you. I found the pods to taste fine for lattes and are far less messy than ground coffee.
title: Great machine
bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Espresso/Cappuccino Maker

review_content:
The coffee tastes great, provided you're starting with good beans, clean water, and letting it heat up properly. the auto milk thing is kind of nice because it measures out the milk for you. Overall, i taught my wife to use it very quickly and she didn't try to kill me for taking away her nespresso! Winning.

There are a few issues, but there's also one very very massive design flaw!
Issue#1: Sour Milk! If you ever forget to clean out the milk container with the clean cycle, you will eventually get sour milk in there. You have to use the clean cycle ever time, and you have to pipe vinegar through it periodically. Also, the repeat of pulling milk in and out of the fridge, and next to steaming water/coffee, means that the milk in the container spoils after about 2 days. You have to wash it out every 3 days! Don't just keep topping off...

Issue#2: The drip trays can get nasty very quickly if any milk makes it's way out of the cup, which is very easy to do when the machine decides to randomly make giant milk bubbles instead of froth. It gets gross quickly, so you have to clean the drip trays at least every week.

Issue#3: The manual and reality contradict each other. The manual doesn't give specs on how much coffee/milk each setting makes, but the quick guide does. It's wrong. The machine makes 9 ounces of coffee and 3 ounces of just foam on the large latte setting, not 15 ounces like the book says. It's trying to tell you a 15 ounce cup so nothing spills over, so just expect to get 9 ounces of drinkable latte for each large doubleshot setting. You can use the extra froth button to get more, though. Not a deal breaker, but pretty annoying. No, the real issue, is that it's never consistent in the amount you get for each setting. Or the fact that the foam is actually very loose, while good foam is supposed to be tighter and denser, this machine's foam is so loose that stirring quickly kills half of it.

Issue#4: Critical Design Flaw! The porta filter basket has a plastic insert which leads the coffee from the porta filter exit, to the basket exit. It also exits the filter and has two protruding plastic ends. This whole plastic is held in place with a small screw on the bottom of the basket, from the outside. This means any time you put pressure on the coffee in the filter (like when you push with 30# of force to tamp espresso every time you make espresso), you're putting 30 pounds of force onto the plastic the screw is holding onto and the protruding plastic bits are fighting you. I've had this machine for two months, and the screw stripped itself out, the plastic is no loose, the filter won't stay tight, which all means the machine is useless at making coffee. Customer support told me it would be 2 to 3 weeks until they have a replacement part in, for which i'll have to call them (they won't call me) to order that replacement part. I'm not holding my breath. Who knew the demise of this machine was one little screw that would strip and fall out? Oh wait, I should have paid more attention to the reviews, because it happened to others...I'm putting a wooden block narrower than the two plastic prongs to have metal facing the force of tamping down. It's wobble and i will likely injure myself at some point, but my only other option is to pony up for a Breville...
title: Critical Design Flaw!
bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Espresso/Cappuccino Maker

review_content:
Let me just say that this machine is awesome and easy! I‚Äôve always been too intimidated to buy an espresso machine because whenever I saw my friends use theirs it took foerever and there were thermometers in the milk and it just seemed to be to hard and a pain.

Well this machine is cool and easy to use. You tun on the unit when you start because it takes a minute to heat up before you can brew. Behind the unit, the full width and height has a water container that you slide easily up and off to refill the water. It holds a lot of water, so you don‚Äôt have to refill it very often.

So you grind your coffee beans on smooth grind then use the scoop to fill the little brewing thing and flatten the coffee then you add maybe an inch of milk to the milk container and slide it in. I use a regular mug, hit the double cappuccino button. It steams the milk into the cup, then brews, dripping the coffee into the cup.

The thing to remember on this is to right away put the remaining milk in the fridge or rinse the container immediately after making your coffee. It‚Äôs really easy to pull the milk container components apart, rinse them and set to dry. If you do that, your cool. If you forget to rinse out the milk and leave it accidentally for a few hours or a day then you need to put soap and hot water into the container with the components in there to soak a bit before you can rinse the dried milk out of the rubber straw. It‚Äôs still easy, but just a pain. Much easier to rinse immediately in seconds and set aside to dry for later use.
title: Awesome easy to use and clean espresso, cappuccino, latte machine. Easy, easy, easy.
bought_model: Color: RedStyle Name: Espresso/Cappuccino Maker

review_content:
Would have been a 5 star machine if it wasn‚Äôt this design flaw. When you execute the clean feature as you normally would after each use, you would notice dirty water being leaked back into the milk carafe contaminating any remaining milk in the carafe. Otherwise this machine makes a great cup of cappuccino.

Update: really wanted this machine to work and tried a brand new replacement. However, same results. See video. It's a real pity they couldn't get this fundamental thing fixed.
title: Design flaw with milk carafe.  Clean feature contaminates milk with dirty water
bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Espresso/Cappuccino Maker

review_content:
This machine makes some of the best coffee I've ever had. It's very quick and reliable. Like "real" espresso machines, it will require some work to narrow in on the best grind for your coffee, and you can't tweak any other settings so you really need to get this right.

My wife and I make two pots every weekday and have for about two years. I'd say we've run over a thousand pots of coffee through this machine. We clean it probably twice a year, and a standard vinegar soak has produced perfectly good results.

I will say we do not use the milk frother. My wife doesn't care for it, and I'm fine without it, so we've only ever run steam through it by accident. That might account for part of its longevity. I'm hoping it will continue to last another two-and-a-half years, but even if it doesn't we have gotten MORE than our money's worth out of it.
title: Fantastic, If Inflexible
bought_model: Color: CappuccinoStyle Name: 4-Cup Steam

review_content:
I work at a certain coffee shop (It's popular) and I needed an espresso machine for at home while I am on paternity leave. I usually skip coffee on my days off, but not anymore! This little machine has been amazing and it pulls shots very consistently. I can only imagine that all the negative reviews are from users who don't know the importance of keeping an espresso machine clean. C'mon people, don't expect it to work if you can't take care of it. When I get off work, the last thing I want to do is make "one more drink". This machine takes all the work out of it.

I would buy it again for myself
I would give it as a gift
Thank you Mr. Coffee

This was used and the packaging was messed up, but that isn't Mr. Coffee's fault.
title: Barista Seeking Espresso Machine
bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Espresso/Cappuccino Maker

review_content: I purchased this machine because we don‚Äôt want to drive into town for an overpriced expresso or cappuccino. It took an afternoon to assemble, but at least I was successful. I ran water through it five times before I used it and washed everything very well. The first time I used it I really, really had to pay attention to the instructions. When I finally got something out of it I was happy, but wasn‚Äôt sure how to repeat what I had done the next day. This happened for several days as it just seemed very complicated. Now, two weeks later, I think I have the hang of it but I have thought that several times. I have learned, at least, to turn on and let it heat up for 10 minuets. My advice, if you are not DOGGEDLY PERSISTENT, don‚Äôt purchase this machine! However, if you are, you will get decent expresso and cappuccino if you stick with it.
title: Pretty good but takes ALOT of initial patience.
bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Automatic Dual Shot

review_content:
I wanted to wait a while before I reviewed because of some of the complaints others have had. Read instructions about setup and use and you will never have a problem. I initially bought this because I've had experiences with milk frothers exploding milk and steam everywhere making a mess. Its so easy to use this lil guy and I do every morning and sometimes throughout the day.

Only one minor complaint! I takes significantly longer to be ready to auto froth. If i just want expresso/coffee black, it takes about 1 minute to warm up. If I want milk to froth, I have to wait another 2 or 3 minutes to be able to start once the lights stop blinking and go solid. Once the lights go solid, it takes 20 or 30 seconds tops to make it.
title: One small complaint but It doesn't matter, I love it
bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Espresso/Cappuccino Maker

review_content: One and most important , you can't use all espresso coffee with it , the same issue was with early Mr.Coffee makers , the pressure is too low , they added the net in the filter to it to make the coffee crema other way you will not get it with this pressure and the water does not pass well and quick . I had to use regular ground coffee to make it .. or use less coffee with double filter . The only super thing here is the milk frother , but I am not sure if I want to keep it , coffee taste is not what it should as the water keep going too long burning its taste . I will try to grind the coffee less fine and see how it works .For the regular price it is not worth purchase as there are better espresso maker for the value today , but I will give it a chance once again and if not happy with this will be my last Mr.Coffee purchase ever . 4 starts for milk frother, 2 stars for espresso since it can;t handle fine espresso coffee .
title: expected more :(
bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Espresso/Cappuccino Maker

review_content:
I've owned this machine for nearly a year now and overall I really do like it.

Pros:
-- It's simple/easy to use. (That's a big pro to me). I'm not a barista. I have 2 young kids and needed something quick and easy.
-- It's compact. It doesn't take up much counter space.
-- The water reservoir holds quite a lot and is easy to remove/refill.
-- Easy to clean. Milk container and lid are dishwasher safe (though it does not specifically say if the silicone "straw" attachment is, so I've washed that by hand.

Cons:
-- It's quite loud, but I'm not sure there is such a thing as a quiet espresso machine.
-- The space that holds your mug is too small. In order to make a small sized latte, you need a decent sized mug to avoid overflowing. If I wanted a large latte, the space provided is not big enough to be able to use a mug large enough that it wouldn't overflow. A large mug may fit under the brew head/porta filter just fine, but the milk dispensing tube will not fit/be able to aim into your mug properly.
-- The silicone "straw" that attaches inside the milk reservoir is incredibly easy to LOSE. It's small, clear, and can easily go down a kitchen drain. Just a heads up. I've gotten lucky with it so far. I wish it had come with 2 or 3 of them as I'm sure I'm not the only one who has had issues with that.
-- At some point a couple months ago, I started experiencing what others had posted about the milk not frothing properly. It has been touch and go ever since. I cleaned the entire machine, thoroughly washed the milk reservoir and it's parts, etc. and it seemed to froth properly for a while but some days it has a mind of its own and comes out watery again and I'm not sure what is making that happen. That has been the only true disappointing thing as I can't figure out how to fix it. The milk just spits out watery and then the latte isn't thick and creamy like it should be. I've cleaned the milk reservoir by using the "clean" feature on the machine, I've taken it out and washed it thoroughly, I've scrubbed around all pieces on the machine that may affect it, etc. and some days it froths and some days it doesn't. I have thoroughly enjoyed this machine up until this point... it doesn't get much more simple than this with an espresso machine, but I wish there were clear instructions on what to do if this happens as it seems to be a common issue.
title: User friendly, but having some issues after 9+ months use.
bought_model: Color: WhiteStyle Name: Espresso/Cappuccino Maker

review_content:
I've been using the more expensive Mr. Coffee model ECMP55 for about a year now and love it. All the controls are on the front of the machine and are easy to use. This led me to purchase the less expensive model ECMP50 on-line, which I had delivered to my son and daughter in-laws house so that when I visit I would be able to enjoy a mocha.
At first glance the ECMP50 looks similar in appearance to mine, but the safety features on this machine require you to wait for it to depressurize after frothing your milk and before you can continue. So if you froth your milk in the cup as I do, it can take some time to make more than one. I'd suggest using a frothing pitcher but be mindful of the wand as it is situated rather low. I also noticed it is picky about the grind of your coffee and how you tamp it. If not just right it can stop water flow through the basket requiring you to remove it and start over. I found it extremely difficult to get the basket off the when this happened to me. This particular model can make a decent latte if your patient, but I can't recommend it.

Also at times it would be a total fail. This machine doesn't attain the heights of magnificence foam wise, but if you set the milk closer to Latte rather than Cappuccino you get a pretty nice foam, especially if you hit the button a second time. If you set it to Cappuccino (I use skim milk) you end up with something very frothy rather than creamy. With this machine I can make multiple cappuccinos in the morning before I feel fully awake and it is no effort at all. I now have one for my home and one for my office.

review_content:
I bought this product during Thanksgiving with high hopes based on the 1000+ reviews it has, but since then I have returned it twice for new units (still with high hopes) and now I am going to refund it. This means I've had a total of 3 of these units sent to me and I'm not satisfied with all of them.

Main issue: Water reservoir not clean, made out of material which is not stable.

I've de-limed the unit , soaked the water reservoir in water overnight (twice) but every time I brew just hot water (no coffee), the water that comes out to the carafe contains silver-white particles (see picture attached, this is after the 12th time I passed water through the unit to rinse out the interior). Looking at the water reservoir, the inside of it looks crudely made and when I used my finger to touch the inner thread where you would screw the top on, silver particles fall off. This is where the water is stored and I have absolutely NO CONFIDENCE in how clean the coffee will be. See the pictures I have attached, the one with plastic around it was the 2nd unit I received which contains white-green gunk. I understand that we have to clean these units but this is too much.

I've called both Amazon support and Mr. Coffee support lines and they've all been helpful but if it's a material defect there's nothing they can do.
title: This means I've had a total of 3 of these units sent to me and I'm not satisfied with all of them
bought_model: Color: CappuccinoStyle Name: 4-Cup Steam

review_content:
I recently bought this to replace the cheaper steam version. It excelled when compared to the less expensive steam version in all but 2 categories...nasty soggy grounds, and getting only 2 cups at one time.

I just get highly annoyed trying in vain to dump the grounds in the ash can. It wound up being an obstacle to making a pot. You have to press the mess in the sink to extract the excess water, thereby making a mess of the sink - with the end result of depositing grounds in the trap and clogging. This has happened more than once - and I do not do plumbing. So this just killed the entire value proposition and I wound up dumping this product and going back to the tried and true Mr Coffee steam version where the grounds just pop out in one easy-to-dispose dry lump. The reason for the sogginess - is that the pump has insufficient pressure.

So if you are like me...this was not a good purchase.

P.S. I wound up using the old glass 4 cup container from the steam version and modifying it so that I could get more than a twinky's version of espresso in two cups.

review_content:
I want to start off and say the main reason I purchased this unit was for the steam wand. I needed a Diamond Steamer and I didn't want to pay $100 for a Jewel Jet or similar jewelery steamer. I did some research online and on diamond forums and found that the espresso machine steamers produced steam that was capable of cleaning jewelry. For the $37.00 price tag of this machine I decided it was worth a shot. I filled up the machine and did a test run to see how good the steam was and all I have to say is it is more than sufficient to clean jewelry and I give it a huge thumbs up in terms of value versus the stand alone steamer.

Now onto the espresso making part of this machine. It is very simple in terms of its operation. I used to be a former barista and it makes decent enough espresso to be used for lattes, cappuccinos, and americanos because the milk and flavoring mask most bad pulls. Now the flavor of the espresso really is a function of the grounds you choose and the grinder that you have available to you. You will have to experiment with the grind coarseness to match this machine exactly. I just received my unit but I will be experimenting to see what the ECM160 likes in terms of how fine or coarse my grounds need to be. I have read other comments about the ECM160 and blowing up and other places online have addressed this issue and it seems that some users are either tamping much too hard, using too fine of a ground, or not locking in portafilter far enough. Also users need to look under the unit for the rest of the cord. It is just coiled underneath for shipping purposes.

I do wish the wand was longer and could be moved, but I still find it is useful. The plastic steaming attachment really needs to be removed as it is of no help at all. I was actually impressed with this little units ability to froth milk. I created very very thick foam with this unit on the first try using a coffee mug and 2% milk. If you want the really dry foam the trick is to work the tip just underneath the surface of the milk.

The carafe that comes with this unit is fine and if it does break like others have mentioned you always have the option of getting actual espressso shot glasses and using those as a true measurement for each shot.

Now I do wish they would have provided a better tamp and milk carafe but at this price they would probably be junk anyways. My biggest concern is with the portafilter. I have to double check the dimensions but I don't think it is a standard size. It seems a little flimsy and I would like to replace it with a double spout unit if possible. I still have more research to do on this part.

My last recommendation is for everyone knocking the quality of this unit, spend some money on a very good burr grinder such as the Baratza Maestro Grinder. A good burr grinder along with good beans will do a world of difference for your espresso.

All in all I would recommend this unit to people as a cheap espresso solution. It's cheap enough for people to try. It's also a good backup and travel unit. The added bonus is the jewelry cleaner.
title: Dual Purpose and Bang For Your Buck

review_content: I was wary of buying this machine, but I've got to say that I'm extremely pleased with this purchase. I use it to brew standalone espresso and cappuccino. The frother is adequate, though I've had no luck frothing soy milk or almond milk. Since I'm lactose intolerant, I've tried a few brands of lactose free milk. I've found that Lactaid brand milk with 1% milk fat works best in my machine. Fat free, 2% and whole lactose-free don't froth as well as the 1%. Also, the brand of milk seems to effect the frothability. The upshot is that you may have to experiment a bit with both the milk and frother adjustments, but with a little effort you can find a combination that yields a very satisfying brew. It's good enough that I've discontinued my morning cafe stop on the way to work, so this machine will more than pay for itself in a few months.

Nice design but poor quality. This espresso maker will not contain the hot water when brewing 4 cups. The hot water shoots out around the filter holder. The rubber seal above the filter appears to be defective.
UPDATE: After some experimentation, I have found that I can safely brew 4 full cups by tamping the grounds lightly and by unplugging the power cord if the machine begins to hiss loudly. This should eliminate the excess steam pressure in the machine. My machine works better as it gets older.

bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Automatic Dual Shot

review_content:
Great price during the post-Thanksgiving period and makes great coffee with ease. The milk dispenser can vary quite a bit depending on 'cleaning' and can foam over even a large cup with set to double latte or cappacino. The foot print was actually smaller than my regular electric coffee pot. Fast excellent individualized serving.
Was somewhat disappointed by the second week of use as the silicone tube that incorporates the milk can be easily lost during the frequent cleanings that it is needed ("after every use")....but eventually found replacements directly from the Mr. Coffee website for a fair price. Still very happy with quality of coffee and the fact that milk frothing is automatic with no need to pre-heat...just be sure spout is in the cup and better to use higher walled cups to avoid splatter...unfortunately you will find double latte cups do NOT fit under the spouts so order smaller latte cups.
title: Very good coffee conveniently and priced right.
bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Espresso/Cappuccino Maker

review_content: This small compact machine makes great espresso & cappuccino for $30.00.  It reminds me of the Krups machine I had years ago.  It's similarities made it easy to use.  I was enjoying my 1st cappuccino within minutes.  The only negative was the plastic sleeve to froth the cream which can be easily removed to make it work properly.  My first attempt was with the plastic sleeve on and the cream splattered every where.  I removed the plastic sleeve on my 2nd cup and I had no issues frothing the cream, no splatter at all.  For those of you needing help making great cappuccino here are my recommendations.  You do not need to use espresso grounds.  I actually find that the espresso grinds are too fine and when lightly tamped down using a small spice container the steam has a hard time making it's way through the grinds and steam escapes through very small gaps thus reducing the steam for frothing.  I use Militta classic blend coffee lightly tamped down with a small spice container.  As far as frothing the cream or milk I highly recommend adding an extra ounce and a half of water so there is enough water to steam your cream or milk.  I have lived in Italy for 3 years when I was young and the cappuccino I make using this machine and Militta coffee taste just like I remember.
title: Fantastic for the Price
bought_model: Color: CappuccinoStyle Name: 4-Cup Steam

review_content:
The machine is, for the most part, capable of doing the job well. What absolutely drives me crazy is that it is very inconsistent about the size of coffee. The first one comes out correctly, and the second one is always half the size. It ends up with me using the manual button to get the rest of froth.

Only way I know to fix this is to make the first one on the latte setting and the second one on the capuccino setting. And even then, it's still a very different cup.
title: Inconsistent coffee sizes
bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Espresso/Cappuccino Maker

review_content:
This is a great machine! When I worked, we had a $6000.00 machine and I can't say it was better! The only thing it did was grind/fill/dump old coffee grounds. I can't say that is worth $5925.00! Seriously, this machine make a perfect Espresso and Cappuccino. We use the dark whole beans at Sam's club and grind a small counter-top storage container at a time with our magic bullet. Highly recommend this over a coffee bean grinder. It isn't as messy, easy to use, washable and you can see when the beans are ready. You have to play around with the fineness of the grounds, ours are almost power like. We also removed the rubber piece from the steam wand. Again, you have to learn how to froth your milk. It only takes about 1 to 1.5" at the bottom of your stainless frothing cup. You have to swirl, lift and dip - I find the best froth comes when you put the tip just before removing it from the milk. It takes a little while to get to this point, just keep moving it. Otherwise, you will burn the milk. Patients and practice! When we first started, it seemed like it took forever to make just 1 cup. Now, it is quick and easy. I make my cup while heating my daughters pancakes in the toaster. It is that quick and easy!

The only downfall is the height where you place your cup. We like using the double cup and making a large coffee mug. You have to tilt the cup to get it underneath - same to remove it. Since you have to leave space for your froth, it doesn't spill... it would just be easier if we didn't have to do this. @ Mr. Coffee: raising it just a 1/2" would solve this problem!
title: We are addicted!
bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Automatic Dual Shot

review_content: This is a great machine for the price. I use it every day. I have one piece of advice and one complaint. Advice first: READ THE INSTRUCTIONS BEFORE USE. I didn't read them all the way through and ended up with very hot water all over my hands. Read the entire instruction manual before you brew. You'll thank me later. Now, complaint: The plastic taste is overwhelming. I think it's because it's new but nothing tastes worse than burnt plastic in a cup of good espresso. I've been washing it through with water cycles and even trying to leave the pressure cap off to let it air out, but the taste/smell has only gone away slightly and I've had it for almost a week and a half. I'm going to try to rinse it out with vinegar, I read that can help. It's helped with my Keurig before. Anyway, great product for the price, but I hope they come up with a way to eliminate that taste!
title: Great for the price but tastes like plastic.
bought_model: Color: CappuccinoStyle Name: 4-Cup Steam

review_content: First, this product works as advertised.  The coffee tastes as good as the cafe offerings.  It's quite fast too and easy to clean.  We buy Starbucks espresso grind.  There is a gotcha, though.  Nothing serious.  The froth dispenser folds away nicely when not used which is where it has been a few times as I made cappuccino and walked away.  It leaves a heck of a mess with chocolate milk all over the counter (I love mochaccino).  I'm sure I'll learn not to do that but we are not always at our best when we need coffee the most.  Other than that I love the look and even the sound of this machine.  My wife drinks mostly espresso and using a double and then a single with the same grind makes is the way she likes it:  not too strong.  I may soon apply at Ozo's.

review_content:
I've had this for almost 5 months now and I love it. I use it everyday. I have saved so much money on Starbucks by making my own. I'm sure I've paid for it by now with the money saved. I've tried other inexpensive machines in the past but could just never get it right. This makes it easy! You can push a button and let it do the work for you, customize brewing and froth times/quantities or a combination of the two.

My only "issues" are that:
1. Taller travel mugs don't fit , so I just make it in a Pyrex measuring cup and pour it in after.
2. Even at the lowest setting it makes A LOT of froth/foam. I scoop off most of it. That said, it doesn't warrant reducing it to 4 stars.

It takes one or two times to figure out when to turn the knob to stop dripping the coffee (else it becomes watered down) but after you realize that, you're all set.

My one complaint is that it didn't come with the tamper, which was fine because I purchased a metal one when I ordered this machine due to the reviews about the cruddy one that's included in the box.

Overall, I highly recommend this espresso machine if you're looking for something simple and inexpensive to feed your caffeine habit. I like it so much that I'm buying the same model for my best friend for christmas.

review_content: I would suggest this if you need a cheap machine to use espresso as a base for latte‚Äôs, cappuccino‚Äôs, etc. as 5e frother bar comes in handy for that. As far as making quality espresso, you might as well just use a moka pot. Much cheaper and you‚Äôll get the same quality espresso. The simple fact is 1.5-2 bars of pressure is just not enough to make a decent pull of espresso. I bought this figuring what the heck for the price.. but have come to learn I simply demand a higher quality espresso. His has come in handy on mornings I‚Äôm out of my homemade cold brew.. but I sort of suffer through my triple, knowing it could taste A LOT better. Also, the band on the glass pot broke after about a year. So now I have to use a pot holder to pour the espresso after it is made, other wise the glass pot is too hot.. Simple answer, great for someone who likes to show off they can make a latte or cappuccino once or twice a year when entertaining. For espresso lovers/aficionados, save your money and go with a higher quality product.

Very easy to use and clean. Make sure you prep it properly according to the instructions the first time you use it. I like that the milk froth goes in by itself through the dispenser and you don‚Äôt have to worry about frothing and hand-pouring.

bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Espresso/Cappuccino Maker

review_content: I've never reviewed anything online, but felt compelled to review this product. I purchased it as an 'interim' fix until I could afford to get my isomac tea fixed (which turns out was not even worth fixing) based on reviews read on Amazon. We've had it about 3 months. I have been pleasantly surprised by the both the acceptability of flavor of shots and by the ability to foam. While I would not use this machine if the majority of your coffee are espressos, if you do mostly milk based or frozen drinks as I do, I've found it works fine. Nobody but me can tell the difference between drinks made from this machine or the isomac (or Rancilio previous to that). Are the shots as good as from those machines? No; when you had good shots from those machines, they were fantastic; but unfortunately over 6 years of using those machines I found there are so many variables that I often ended up with not very good tasting shots. Shots from Mr. Coffee are not quite as good, but more consistent, so I'll take it.  This machine does not foam as nice either, but the foam is better than I had anticipated once I practiced -I would call it a light 'almost' micro foam. I would take a latte made form this machine over Starbucks anyday. And now the good news. The Rancilio I had was $600, the Isomace Tea over $1400, and they were repaired before they went bad. Total cost of ownership over 6 years - about $3,000. I was using pre-softened RO water, but found out after that the people who sold me the machines didn't give me full information on RO units not filtering out calcium or lime, so certainly the damage to the machines was partly my fault; none-the-less, even if I had added in all the additional water softening equipment, upkeep, etc. over those years, it would have easily added another $1000. Would I love to have an upscale fancy machine again? Yes, I loved having them, but I just can't justify the cost anymore-not when I can replace the Mr. Coffee for less than it cost me just to ship my previous espresso machines to get fixed! They take up less counter space, can be taken to a friend's house for parties, and with our hard water in Las Vegas will no doubt scale up in probably less than a year, or the pump will blow out; then I'll spend another $70 at Dealyard and be good for another year-which I am more than happy to live with.

review_content:
UPDATE TO REVIEW: I decided to keep the second Cafe Barista despite the initial leaks. I have found that if I am extremely careful in placing the reservoir onto the base unit without pressing down on the spring-loaded valve before is fully seated it will not leak. So far at least it has not leaked since the initial use. Overall it is a very useful espresso maker. Simple, elegant, and makes a good product. Overall I like it but had to mark it three stars because I do think the design of the water reservoir is problemmatic. My initial experiences with leaking in addition to other reviews here indicates this is a common problem.

ORIGINAL REVIEW I have very mixed feelings about the Mr. Coffee Caf√© Barista. I wanted very much to be completely satisfied with it because I do believe it is a great entry-level espresso machine with unique features. Unfortunately, I had to return the initial one I purchased which I exchanged for the exact same model. My experience with the second one was not much better. In both cases, the unit leaked significantly from the base of the water reservoir. I thought for certain the first one was an aberration (although other reviews on this site indicate it is a common problem) and felt confident the replacement would work without problem. The replacement also leaked although not quite as substantially.

I really liked the espresso and lattes the Caf√© Barista produced. In shopping for a comparable model I am shocked at how few incorporate the milk steamer into the unit and offer the ease of use in preparing espressos, lattes, and cappuccinos. The drinks we were able to make -- while desperately mopping up water flowing out the back of the unit -- were quite good. Not perfect but good enough for what I am looking for. The leaking water, though, is untenable and I am inclined to return this second model. I know I could possibly fix the leak with some silicone around the water inlet nozzle or other alterations. But I am not inclined to do this for a machine at this price -- for $200 it should work out of the box. It is really quite disappointing that the water reservoir is designed so poorly that the leaking happens so easily. It is clear that the rubber gasket does not seal sufficiently and water leaks around the nozzle and then trickles out of the surprisingly insufficient drip tray. The problem could easily have been fixed in design by simply eliminating the removable feature of the water reservoir and leaving it permanently attached to the base. Or, by simply designing a better sealing gasket and/or providing rubber flanging around the base of the water reservoir.

Overall, these are the pros and cons of the Mr. Coffee Caf√© Barista:

PROS:
- Great tasting lattes, cappuccinos, and espressos
- The attached milk steamer is a neat and rare feature on these home espresso machines
- Nice look and does not take up too much counter space
- Good price for its potential

CONS:
- The significant water leaking is an overriding problem
- Does not make drinks very hot -- I am fine with this as I prefer drinks lukewarm but others may want hotter drinks and I was unable to figure out how to get it to make hotter drinks
- Inconsistent size of the beverage. This would not be a big problem for me but others may want more consistency. The drinks seem to vary by 1-2 oz. in size with each attempt. My understanding is that this may have something to do with the setting of the frother and also how closely packed the espresso grounds are. If I had more time and were not running out of towels in my kitchen I might have experimented further.
title: Simple and Elegant Espresso Maker But Tends to Leak
bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Espresso/Cappuccino Maker

review_content: Nice machine so far. Foams ok and seems to work well. Some reviews nitpicked what was included, but I did get a tamper/scoop in my package. Cord is a bit short(and yes, I did unwind it all the way). I can barely get it to the edge of a not too deep counter for clearance to use the foamer. Seems to be a decent construction and brews a cup quicker than my last Mr Coffee did. For the price you can't beat it. Some metal in the construction was a plus. I use these units at least two times a day and the Mr Coffee brand has held up as well as others have. Don't forget to release pressure on the lids and coffee bins of these units when you are done brewing. Most early gasket problems come from leaving them attached under pressure. Amazon was competitive on price and the unit arrived within two days. Good, because I was stove top brewing until it did and that doesn't cut it.

review_content:
I will not brag about how many espresso's I drink or how many machines I've reviewed because none of that matters. For the price, this unit can't be beat. With some good coffee (fresh after grinding of course) and the right technique, you will be pleased with this machine. I don't use it everyday and have yet to clean it so I can't comment on that portion. I grind my own beans as this is a better value and provides better quality. I also recently tried following the instructions more closely and it provided great results. As a starter unit, it is is easy to use, compact, quiet and fast. There are machines that do more but probably cost much more as well.

Some things that I learned about this machine:
It will not provide scalding hot espresso's so don't count on it
Using it a couple of times with throwaway coffee will be a good learning experience
pay attention to when the machine is done. When it starts to look too watery for your taste, stop it. You can't just leave it running by itself.
Steaming the milk properly will take some practice.
title: A capable and efficient espresso maker

review_content:
I got this espresso machine for Christmas last year so it's almost been a year since I've been using it. I absolutely love it and can't IMAGINE all the money I've saved from using it! I wanted to share my experience with it, for what it's worth. I had a little trouble with it at first but now it works like a charm! I will say this is more for a single use espresso maker. I made several lattes for friends and it took me awhile. I had to wait until the machine cooled off a bit before I could de-pressurize and make some more. But if that's not your purpose no worries! Otherwise, no problems at all. If you are having any doubts at all about getting this machine, put them aside and get it! You will not regret it. For $39 you will be very pleased with what you get!

For those of you who have the machine:

When I first received my Mr. Coffee Espresso Machine for Christmas, I was with my brother, who is a former barista, and whom was quite impressed with the little machine! He worked it like a charm and made my first latte for me. YUM!! He was even thinking about getting his own machine as he was pleasantly surprised how great it worked. For $39 who can beat that? Once I got home it was a different story. I discovered the cord wrapped around the bottom and chuckled at the people who thought the "cord was too short". =) With the first few lattes I tried to make, some worked and some didn't. Sometimes the steam would run out and I wouldn't have enough to finish frothing my milk. Frustrating! I was only filling up the decanter to 2 cups, which apparently wasn't enough to produce steam to froth the milk. I started filling the decanter to 4 cups (and pouring it into the machine obviously) and it's worked like a charm ever since! Hope that helps if anyone else is having the same problem.

**Definitely make sure you buy a frothing pitcher! I can't imagine frothing the milk in a coffee mug. Wow!

I still haven't bought a tamper, but should probably invest in one! I've just used the flat end of the measuring scoop and it's sufficed. My brother showed me how to tamper it, so it's worked fine for me. I'm not saying that's what you should use.

Save money on all your store bought lattes and DON'T spend a fortune on an expensive espresso machine when you can use this machine! You'll love it!
title: No Disappointments Here!!
bought_model: Color: CappuccinoStyle Name: 4-Cup Steam

review_content: It blew the cup right off smashing the decanter, I get to spend coffee time cleaning. I hate you now, & I realize the cup was packed to much, but it didn‚Äôt seem any different than normal
title: It blew up and so have I
bought_model: Color: BlackStyle Name: Steam + Starter Set

review_content:
Having worked as a barista at two local coffee shops during undergrad and grad school, once I started my "real job," I wanted to have an espresso machine at home so I could continue to enjoy creating my own espresso-based beverages. I registered for this Mr Coffee Espresso Maker as a wedding gift and was excited that someone decided to get it for me!

Within minutes of opening the box and reading through the instructions, I was able to pull a great shot of espresso. The manual was fairly straight forward, and the machine is VERY easy to use -- I think you could quickly figure it out even if you've never used an espresso machine of any sort before.

I'm going to be completely honest: aside from rinsing out the brew basket and drip tray after each use, I have never cleaned out the machine or descaled it, and it has worked PERFECTLY for over THREE years -- and that's with me using regular tap water and pulling a double shot at least once every day (and several times twice a day when my husband wants a coffee drink as well). I really probably should properly clean/descale it for sanitary reasons, but I'm just saying it works well for years with very little maintenance!

As for using for entertaining, yes, it may be a small machine, but I've been able to pull five or six double shots within a very short amount of time and no trouble with the water not being hot enough. Now, that was for iced coffees, meaning I didn't use up heat for the steam wand, so that might be a different story if you wanted hot drinks. But it seems to heat back up rather quickly after each use.

Another feature I really like is the large water reservoir -- I feel like it takes weeks before the water line goes below the "min" level. And the handy scoop/tamper works perfectly. I use the double basket for myself because I like a good 2-3 ounces of espresso in my iced white mochas. For my husband, who likes his drinks a little sweeter and with less of a "coffee flavor," I'll use the single basket. I either buy espresso beans from a local coffee house and have them grind them or purchase them in the grocery store and grind them there (on espresso grind, of course). I may one day invest in a grinder of my own, but for now this is what works for me, and I know the beans are ground to the right size and will work every time.

I can't speak much to the steam wand for steaming milk because I primarily drink iced coffees, so I mainly only use it for the initial warm up when turning on the machine. I did try steaming milk a couple times and found that it took a long time for the milk to get hot enough, and by then most of it was foam, HOWEVER, this was after owning and using the machine for over two years, so it's possible that it was just old and therefore not as powerful. Other reviews say the milk heats up quickly, so I'll take their word for it.

Only recently, after owning and regularly using my Mr Coffee for over three years, have I noticed a little bit of leaking that happens when I initial turn the machine on, while waiting for the OK light to come on. That never happened before, and it still works great, and I'm sure it's just regular wear. Honestly, these small machines probably aren't intended to be used every single day and work perfectly for this long, so I'm overjoyed that it is still working, and I'll happily put up with a small dripping when it's the only sign of wear that I've encountered.

For my birthday this month, my husband said I could pick out a new espresso machine, and being one who likes to try out something new and different, I have settled on the DeLonghi EC155 Espresso Maker. I've only had it for a couple days, and I'm still getting the hang of the slightly different style and warmup, but so far it seems to be just as good as (if not better than) the Mr Coffee. We'll see. I plan to hold off on that review for a few months.

Not that this is the end of dear old Mr Coffee, no siree! I plan to take this trusty guy to my office and share it with a few of my coworkers. Over three years and still going strong!

review_content:
The first one leaked all over the place. Can you say zero quality control? I boxed it up and took it back to Target. Hell, I'm not paying shipping back to Amazon.
The second one has not leaked in six months and will in fact produce a decent cup of coffee. Burr grinding tweakers beware, however. It claims to be a fifteen bar machine, but will not allow an extra fine grind to pass through the filter. Hmmm. As well, it has lately developed the habit of blinking idiotically on startup until you turn it off and try again.
I very much doubt that this machine will last more than a few more months before it finds its way to the landfill, there to remain unbiodegraded for the next ten thousand years and more.
In short, folks, save up your money and get a better mostly metal machine as I should have done.

title: Excellent machine and brews fast.
bought_model: Color: CappuccinoStyle Name: 4-Cup Steam

review_content:
I love my coffee, especially through the cold, dark, winter days. I've been buying from our work cafe for years now, since they serve white coffee, but I resolved this year to save money and brew my own. After reviewing a few of the lower priced units on here (lets admit, I'm only using this for personal use, so I'm not too picky), I decided on the Mr Coffee ECM160 model, and was pleasantly rewarded.

The machine itself appears relatively sturdy and compact, and fits quite nicely on my counter. As other reviewers mentioned, it is necessary in some cases to unwind the cord at the base for additional length. I did not have to, where I have it located. The stainless steel finish is nice, and I like the ridged top - it makes it easy to clean. The carafe and lid are dishwasher safe, as is the basket, although I prefer to hand-wash. But, for convenience sake, this could be noted.

I find that the scoop included works well for standard espresso, but when making white coffee (my preferred method), it's best to err on the side of under-filling, as the white coffee seems to expand more when the steam is pressed through. For four shots, it takes roughly 5 minutes to brew, and I plan on taking the recommendations of others and cleaning/descaling with vinegar on a regular basis to prevent any slowness. I do the same for my Keurig, it's just part of basic maintenance.

The steaming attachment is kinda cheesy with the plastic case, so I just take that off (I find it's easier for me to clean without it). I use it to heat/foam my milk, and as I mentioned in the title, it foams like a beast! I use rice milk, and have had NO problems whatsoever in building an absurd amount of foam. It takes a few minutes and some angling, but it's not a pain by any means, and as a foam lover, totally worth it.

For $40, I love this machine. The plastic bits aren't as fancy as a professional espresso, but I'm in this for utility, not looks. We make 2-3 espressos daily, and on Sundays I pre-brew a quart jar of white coffee so I can add it to my breakfast protein shake with ease. It gives me a great extra kick to the day, and it's great knowing that a week's worth of coffee has already paid for itself.

Awesome espresso machine. It does the job for the price.. Coffee comes out really good but You have to make sure that you use filtered water and fresh ground coffee. Also, don't forget to clean the steamer every time you use it, and make sure that some steam comes out at the end, if not the steamer will get clogged. The part that I didn't like was that you are able to make only 2 cups of espresso at a time (if you are looking for a late or capuccino) main reason is because you need half the water to brew the coffee and half the water to steam the milk. If you are not a pro like me and you are looking for a good espresso machine, this is the one. I''ve had this coffee maker for about a year and it is great. A lot of comments said that it would explode and things like that but, after I've been using it I think theirs exploded because it wasn't closed properly or coffee deposit was not installed correctly. Make sure to read the users manual before using it.

Good luck

review_content:
I read the reviews and decided to give it a go. I have used many expresso machines, pump drive and drip like this one. I have an Ascaso Dream and believe it or not, I like this one better. This is why.

* Someone wrote that the foam was really tight and they were right it is. The foam is really a nice consistency.
* It heats water and drips quickly. What I really like about this machine is the knob has to be turned either to make expresso or steam the milk with the middle being off. There is absolutely no way to leave this machine by accident. I have done that and in retrospect, that is why I keep burning them up.
* Also, after steaming milk, I clean the stainless frother with a sponge. The steam is very hot and I sterile my kitchen sponge every morning with the steam. Works great... Hope this helps.
title: Best little machine I have ever used.
bought_model: Color: CappuccinoStyle Name: 4-Cup Steam

review_content:
This espresso machine is worth every penny. It doesn't make fancy high end coffee, but it isn't a fancy high end machine. What it does is make a pretty good cup of coffee for a pretty small price.

I did have a little trouble getting the pump primed, but that isn't really a problem with the machine itself; it is the nature of a suction pump which is a component of all pump driven espresso machines. I have read of similar issues with just about every pump driven espresso machine on which I read reviews. It was an easy fix, I got a cheep turkey baster (under $2) and cut the end off the taper at the point where it was wide enough to fill the water intake, then, after filling the baster with water, I kept constant pressure while following the priming sequence listed in the directions.

The good news is that you only have to prime it once (unless you put it away for a year, or long enough for the pump to dry out). All things considered, it beats my old steam driven machine hands down.
title: Good price, good coffee.

review_content: I have had mine for over a year and still love it.  I make mostly lattes with it and they are just as good as the coffee shop.  Such a treat to be able to get a latte at home!  If you flavor your drinks make sure you find quality flavoring.  I do caramel and like the Starbucks caramel.  I always buy the lavazza espresso grounds for it.  You can put the milk container right in the fridge but it only lasts a day before it sours...sometimes it's easier to just clean after.  The only thing I dislike.
title: Makes a great latte
bought_model: Color: WhiteStyle Name: Espresso/Cappuccino Maker

review_content:
I love this machine. A ton has been mentioned here already, but I have two that I've had for over 2-3 years now, and they work beautifully. I like to set a timer for 25 seconds from when I engage the pump to when I stop extraction and the espresso turns out beautifully.

I'm attaching a short clip of me pulling a double shot into hot water (also from this machine) for a long black (Americano). Beautiful crema and wonderful flavor when your beans, grind, tamp, and timing all work together. Consistency is key.

I used a Hario manual grinder for a long time, but it takes forever. I recently bought the new OXO automatic conical burr grinder and it makes the whole process infinitely more enjoyable and faster!
title: Budget beast for espresso. Fantastic when paired with a good automatic conical burr grinder too!

I just bought this for my daughter and husband because they also spend a lot of money buying latte from those various coffee shops (I also bought this for her, because, let's face it, I wanted to drink my daily dose of cappuccino (2 vent per day) whenever I stay with them, which is about 30 days per year). title: Does anyone make an espresso machine that lasts?!
bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Espresso/Cappuccino Maker

review_content:
I became interested in having an espresso maker at home after experiencing delicious "cortaditos" at our local Cuban restaurant. We have owned this unit for a month and have made many cortaditos and cappuccinos. There is a learning curve and I am still fine-tuning my grinds, sugar types and milk steaming technique. My coffees are getting better and I am enjoying the process and the caffeine buzz.

I have had no problems with the machine at all. The instructions were not clear enough on a few things, like the role of the lever on the handle of the ground cup holder. Watching a couple of YouTube reviews of the machine cleared things up.

Tips:
*Put some water in your espresso cups and microwave them for 20 seconds to get them warm
*Use the double shot cup. The single cup just doesn't make it.
*Put raw sugar in the espresso cup before pulling the coffee. Stir the sugar in before adding the milk.
*A steel 12 oz frother is a inexpensive addition and makes for better frothing.
*I decided to leave the rubber frother cover on: easier cleaning. Make sure it goes on all the way and does not block the steam exit hole when re-installing.
*To cut the prep (bean grinding) time, we are using Cafe Bustelo decaf and regular espresso ground coffee. It's ground finer than the instructions recommend, but works great. We can find it everywhere, including on Amazon.

Final Thoughts:
If we get a year out of this machine I will be happy. My brother-in-law's fancy (rebuilt) Italian machine cost four times this machine, and might make better coffee, but I am learning more with the hands-on approach required by this unit. I take the credit (or blame) for the end product, which I like.

review_content: Love, love, love this machine.  It makes unbelievable espresso coffees!  I wanted this for Christmas and my husband ordered it for me.  I used to go to the coffee shops almost everyday.  Not so anymore with my Mr. Coffee!  We did a lot of research before we ordered this one.  We looked at expensive espresso makers, not so expensive espresso makers and all the ones in-between.  This one had all the great ratings.  I wanted one that I could use my own espresso and I didn't have to buy the brand "pods".  This one fit the bill.  It is also truly easy to clean!  I didn't want one where I had to take forever to clean out the machine for 20 minutes after each coffee.  I knew what would happen.  It would eventually just sit there because it was too much of a hassle.  The espressos taste unbelievable.  You can make just espresso, Cafe Latte or Cappuccino.  If you are in the market for an espresso machine, don't pass this one by!
title: Love, love
bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Espresso/Cappuccino Maker

review_content:
We love this little thing! We did quite a lot of research on espresso machines and didn't have that big of a budget. Mr. Coffee has been a trusted name for years, so we thought we really couldn't go wrong. We've had it for about three weeks and although we don't use it daily, we use it several times a week. It's very simple to use ~ but if you get stuck, you can look on Youtube for a "how to video". Just make sure to plug in the "ECMP50" as there are various models. The most difficult part,is getting the right ratios to make your latte (or cappuccino). The espresso part is pretty easy.

One of the reasons we decided to go with this machine is the fact that you can put a larger mug/cup under it. Some of the others just fit a little espresso cup. You can use a really large mug if you remove the drip tray (which you do at the end anyway to clean), and just sit the mug down. It gives you about another inch or so clearance. The lights/labeling are all very clear and easy to understand too.

You should really buy this: http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B0001XRNEM/ref=wms_ohs_product?ie=UTF8&psc=1

and this: http://www.amazon.com/Update-International-EP-12-Stainless-Frothing/dp/B000MR6I9I/ref=pd_sim_k_1?ie=UTF8&refRID=0V42FG7K080GGQ2129PV

The tamper and the stainless steel frothing pitcher. None of those things come with the machine. You NEED a tamper. The pitcher, well, you could get away with using any vessel with handle. You also need a good grind of coffee made especially for espresso. We bought this brand and are very happy with it: http://www.amazon.com/Lavazza-Espresso-Ground-Coffee-8-Ounce/dp/B004N71J7O/ref=pd_sim_k_4?ie=UTF8&refRID=0V42FG7K080GGQ2129PV. We have a coffee grinder, but I've read that you really need a GOOD one in order to get the beans ground fine enough.

My only real complaint, and it's just my pet peeve, is that the espresso/milk doesn't really get hot enough. When I get lattes from coffee houses, I generally ask them to make it "super hot". They can, because their machines can control the temperature. Again, this is not a super expensive machine that will do that. Sometimes, we heat water up in the cup we are going to use, in the microwave to get it hot in order to hold the heat of the coffee better. It does the job:)

So far, we are really enjoying this machine and highly recommend it!
title: Awesome little esspresso/cappuccino/latte maker!

review_content: Extremely user friendly. Easy to follow instructions. Makes a GREAT latte!  Spoken from a Starbucks fan, that's saying a lot. My kids sleep on the same floor as the kitchen and so far it hasn't woken them up in the morning.  Would have given it 5 stars, but the largest latte it makes is only 12 oz, despite the manual saying it makes a 15 oz. Customer support offered that my measurements must be different than theirs (I used a glass measuring cup). Oh well. Due to the low cost of this machine and the fact that it makes a delicious 12 oz latte, I am not returning it. In no time at all it will have paid for itself with the money I will save by not heading to a Starbucks almost every morning.

review_content:
So after opening this, I expected to have to clean it, but I didn't expect it to have as much trash and manufacturing byproduct in it as I did.

The first time I steamed milk, it tasted like licking a circuit board (semi-expected) so I figured after running a bunch of steam through it it would go away. However, much to my dismay, I looked in the cup I used to catch the steam and water that was shooting out and there were metal and plastic particles in the water! I was absolutely shocked. So I ran more steam through it (filling it up to it's max with water and letting it all go through the steamer) probably at least 6 times, and each time metal and plastic came out. When I finally stopped getting particles out of the steamer, I tried to steam milk again, and it still tasted like circuit board. I thought it would've been well clean by now, but it wasn't. Then I switched over to the espresso side to see what would happen, and when the water came out I found a white flaky substance in the water. Again, horrified, I decided to clean it, only this time I stepped up my game and used part for part vinegar and water. I let it go through the steamer about 3 times, and the espresso part 3 times (both times using the entire tank for each cleaning). Then, and ONLY then, did I stop seeing mysterious particles in the water and the coffee/milk started tasting like it should. I was shocked it wasn't more clean than it was. Seriously, I probably could have sued them had I documented all of the contaminants I found in the water after cleaning it so much.

That aside, as an espresso machine for a novice barista, it works well. Easy to use, easy to clean, steams milk well, brews espresso well. No bells and whistles, but it fits my needs and makes a good latte once you get the hang of it. Decently priced, so that always helps. But please, please clean it extremely thoroughly before you use it. Hopefully you won't have as much trash and residue in yours as I did mine, but if you get rid of it by cleaning it well it works fine.
title: BEWARE!!!! CLEAN EXTREMELY THOROUGHLY!!!

review_content:
Fantastic product!! Love this machine. The best thing is the dial on the side that allows you to control the steam by shifting from "brew" to "off" to "steam" (for frothing). You will need to separately purchase some must haves... a stainless steel tamper, frothing pitcher and rubber mat for accessories. But they're well worth it.

Tip: THE SECRET TO GREAT FROTH!!!

I have used the ECM-160 for over a year and it's perfect for making amazing froth for cappuccinos (big, super-smooth froth that rises 3/4 inch+ above the rim of your cup like whipped cream) but you have to know the secret. And here it is:
First... use the right milk... 1% works best. More fat, and it tends to "spit" everywhere while frothing.

Second... the milk has to be ICE cold, and kept cold while frothing. "How am I supposed to do that??" you may ask. My trick is to get an ice cube tray for tiny-sized cubes (I found one at the supermarket that makes small, grape-size ice cubes that work perfectly) and make frozen milk-cubes.

Third... put about four to five frozen milk cubes in your stainless steel frothing pitcher, then add more cold milk until its about 1/3 full.

Fourth... take one of those small, palm-sized "blue-ice" freezer paks out of your freezer and palm it against the bottom of the pitcher as you froth the milk. This further helps to keep the milk from overheating and breaking down. Make sure to keep the tip of the frothing tube nozzle just below the surface for best frothing effect.

Fifth, froth until the stainless steel pitcher is about as hot as the hood of a car that's been driving around for a while.

Using this technique, I've been able to get the entire frothing pitcher to overflow with fine, beautifully smooth froth on a consistent basis. But it still takes some finesse in the technique. It's a bit of an art.

To really kick-it up, add some flavored International Coffee creamer to the milk before frothing. You have to try out different flavors because each one changes the frothiness to a greater or lesser degree.

Enjoy!
title: FantasticEspresso/ Cappuccino maker - The SECRET to Great Froth too!
bought_model: Color: CappuccinoStyle Name: 4-Cup Steam

review_content:
This machine is very user friendly as the directions are well written and easy to follow. I recommend it for anyone who is not familiar with making espresso/steaming milk. If you are a barista and just wanted something for your house it will never compare to the commercial grade machines but works well for home use.

BUT, I have only used this machine for about 3 months and it has begun to leak. There is some sort of leak coming out of the bottom of the machine that leaves a puddle under the machine. At first I thought it was because I forget to empty the water resevoir one time with left my entire counter covered in water...but, even after dumping out the water after use I still get a puddle of water under the machine. I was going to call the company b/c it has a one year warranty but the receipt was thrown away and you need the receipt.

So, I do recommend the machine but keep your receipt in case you need to utilize the warranty within the first year. If it breaks after one year it is still a good deal b/c the price is so low.

review_content:
My husband and I are not coffee drinkers per se. Neither of us can tell the difference between gourmet and cheap coffee, nor between espresso and regular coffee except for the espresso having a higher caffeine content. For us, coffee is a flavoring for other things: In the present instance, frothy milk drinks. We are, however, quite particular about the milk. It must be very thick, frothy, and hot. It may be flavored with coffee only, or with coffee and chocolate, or with coffee, chocolate, and an addition such as rum, Grand Marnier, almond extract, walnut extract, cinnamon sprinkled on top, etc. Not to mention artificial sweetener. The drink also must be low fat, low calorie, and low priced, all things coffee shops notably fail to deliver.

Thus we are devotees of DIY caffe mochas, lattes, etc. And when we received this machine, we rushed to experiment with the milk frother. The Mr. Coffee machine has a separate milk tank (which can hold milk in the refrigerator before use, be sterilized with hot water immediately after use, and be removed for washing later). The steamed milk comes out deliciously textured and piping hot. This is far preferable to another espresso machine we have, which requires heating the milk in a pot on the stove, pouring it into a mug of a size that fits under the nozzle, and holding the mug there till the milk froths slightly, hopefully without cooling off too much.

Overall, the Mr. Coffee machine is easy to use and easy to clean. It has a reasonable footprint on the countertop and an adequate length of cord. It comes with clearly written instructions and a few recipes. We are very happy with it, even though we are going to leave the super-gourmet-coffee-bean drinks to people who care more about them!
title: Produces fantastic mochas and lattes
bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Espresso/Cappuccino Maker

review_content: When I saw this on a lightning deal for 50% off, I had to buy it. I've had this for 3 weeks and have made yummy cuppucinos and lattes from it nearly every day. Reason for four stars and not five - I wish the coffee would come out more hot. Other than that, it's perfect.

Got this little item for my wife for Xmas. She looooves the espresso. My first inclination was to find a machine with an Italian pedigree, since I was dubious that Mr. Coffee could provide that great of a espresso maker. After reading the reviews I decided to go for it!

We have been pleasantly surprised by the performance of this machine. Now, every morning my wife and I line up at the kitchen counter with coffee cups like the caffeine addicts we are and brew ourselves some hooch. We're saving ourselves a lot of $ on coffeehouse coffee and getting some really nice brew too. It's like having our own java cow.

Although it took us a little bit to figure out how to operate it, it got a lot easier after that first cup of coffee (which we had to fix that on our old drip coffee maker in order to think clearly). Eventually we realized that it's an easy, 3-step process to make a cup. The pressure is great, there's no waiting for steam pressure to build up and the water reservoir rarely runs dry.

review_content:
For about $10 more, you can get a reasonable pump maker, and here is why you should:

Steam powered units make an entirely different beverage that those that pump heated water through under a certain pressure that is constant. With a pump, fewer undesirables, such as waxy acids are extracted. What you get with a "steam toy" is much more like what you get with a mocha pot.

If you are going to make lattes, it may not matter as much, as the milk hides or neutralizes the yuccky acidity. But for real flavorful espresso, get a modest pump machine.

If you already have a steam unit, you can get a slight improvement by shutting it off about halfway into the shot (you have to experiement). This prevents the final superheated burst of steam from releasing even more waxy acids. It also works with mocha pots.
title: Pump Machines Can Be Found For About The Same Price And Are Better.
bought_model: Color: CappuccinoStyle Name: 4-Cup Steam

review_content:
Update 5/29/16:
It still works good after several years. Perhaps this is because I only use distilled water (no scale buildup).

Original review:
I agree with all the other positive reviews here and don't have much to add. However, the Mr. Coffee Barista manual is vague as to the volumes of cappuccino and latte to be expected. It does not give the actual amount of coffee, but rather the size cup to use (single espresso = 1.25oz, double espresso = 2.5oz, single latte = 12oz, double latte = 15oz). I have found that the volume will be much greater if the milk level in the reservoir is at max. BE CAREFUL, a double latte or double cappuccino with foam can EASILY OVERFLOW THE 15 OZ CUP!

Actual Amounts (not cup size):
I measured actual amounts of coffee and milk with a digital scale (amounts do vary somewhat each time). NOTE: the level of milk in the reservoir will change the amounts. These are by weight, and the total includes condensed steam but (of course) doesn't include foam volume. I used distilled water, cold full fat milk and espresso ground coffee (I prefer Lavazza Crema e Gusto). The porta-filter and filters were washed and dried between measurements, and the milk reservoir settings were set to "Latte" or "Cappuccino" as recommended by Mr Coffee.

Single espresso (7g coffee) = 28.5g (1.0oz)
Double espresso (only 7g coffee) = 57.0g (2.0oz)
Double espresso (14g coffee) = 54g (1.9oz)
Custom espresso for cafe Americano (hold espresso button) = up to about 5 oz

Single cappuccino (milk reservoir full) = 130g (4.6oz) containing 79g (2.8oz) milk
Single cappuccino (milk at half full) = 117g (4.1oz) containing 68g (2.4oz) milk
Double cappuccino (milk at half full) = 187g (6.6oz) containing 113g (4.0oz) milk

Single latte (milk reservoir full) = 197g (6.9oz) containing 143g (5.0oz) milk
Single latte (milk at half full) = 173g (6.1oz) containing 128g (4.5oz) milk
Double latte (milk reservoir full) = 281g (10.0oz) containing 194g (6.8oz) milk
Double latte (milk at half full) = 252g (8.9oz) containing 167g (5.9oz) milk
title: Actual Measured Coffee Volumes
bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Espresso/Cappuccino Maker

review_content:
I've had this unit for greater than 6 years using it daily for morning double shot 'cap'. Read instructions and several websites and many reviews to avoid brewing or maintenance errors. Using vinegar every 2-3 months for descaling. Twice have disassembled and cleaned/inspected the removable parts. Cant say that ive used a needle to clear holes in the portafilter or main filter.

Filling with the finest grind created daily with economical burr grinder and never tamping only leveling with palm of my hand has served me to extract full flavored espresso with adequate crema. (Imported/expensive whole bean torrefacto from Spain gets the credit for the best flavor since residence in Madrid).

Recurrent leakage initially was due to removal of water reservoir for filling filtered water at frig . Once I resorted to filling by large cup in place this small leak minimized. Now years into use the counter top will flood if the descaling is not done more frequently. I must always empty the tray after every use. The volume of coffee is smaller and the flow rate is less regardless of the descaling. Six yrs is very good service and replacing this unit with an identical one is my plan. Better maintenance frequency perhaps with a formal descaling product may be an upgrade. More education via utube for cleaning is another target.

This is very good, albeit not excellent espresso, producing unit at VERY reasonable price. Available at Target or Walmart? Yes a bit noisy and coffee is not as hot as preferred nor is the steam created as hot as needed for the best foam. Still this machine has not been a major problem and relatively easy to maintain. Preheating the mug would help significantly if I took the time and effort to do so.

Prior years have used with fair to good satisfaction, the stove top 2 piece unit originally from Spain or Italy made of aluminum, now stainless which lack a foaming option but allowed for hot milk to be incorporated. Simple and reliable served me well for over 20 years. (imported coffee made it worthwhile)

Several times I have researched machines at double or triple the price. None appear to have the low price to upkeep ratio this one offers. "Lemons" may be received regardless of product chosen. At a higher or much higher price with considerably more options and maintenance steps I hesitate to take the plunge. If I knew the machine would last 6 or more years,.....it might be a new level in home brewed espresso appreciation. To start my day with Headaches and frustration stemming from a failed adventure in coffee making is very undesireable. Then again, I could just return it and go back to Mr Coffee. Time will tell. In the meantime. replace this unit every 6 years is not unacceptable at all.
title: Very good, not great but nothing else at this price or even double is likely to last 6 years!

title: Very poor quality
bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Automatic Dual Shot

review_content:
Previous to this I had purchased a small little 4-cup Mr.Coffee Espresso/Cappuccino machine. I was very happy with it but after a year it seemed to spit out fairly bland espresso. I decided to hit a few stores and snatched this model up for $59 on sale at Target.

First and foremost if you have any odd questions about the machine, this FAQ is a nice place to start =)
[...]

Unlike my previous Mr. Coffee, this machine uses pressure as oppose to steam. I notice a big difference in the flavor and the perfect crema this machine produces. Where the previous machine lacked in those areas. Sadly the only downfall to this model is it only does 2 shots at a time, where I liked having the option of doing four to serve more people. But, oh well.

The unit is pretty well built and includes everything but a decanter, any cups or demitasse cups should do. I also recommend removing the rubbery piece from the frothing tip and just using the metal itself. It's a pain to clean but easier to use and less likely to get bacteria.

One of the major things I read about is these machines leaking, I found via the FAQ above that the drip tray collect all excess water from the machine once it is ran. Thus the drip tray needs to be emptied after each use. Some people were letting the tray build up until it overflowed I guess. The machine can be a little noisy with it's clunking patterns but is to be expected from any pressure based machines I have seen. (You'll get used to it.)

The espresso comes out nice and creamy, the frothing wand does a great job, and I really enjoy that this machine has a reservoir and doesn't need to be refilled for every batch made. On a side note, since there is a reservoir you need to stop the machine at the right moment or else you will keep spewing out espresso and A) Make a mess, and B) have watered down drivel. After a few tries you will get the hang of how much espresso you need spit out for one shot or two, try to stick to using the same decanter or demitasse cups.

The machine's buttons are used in steps, first the power, then wait for the green check mark light to go solid, then choose either the foam icon or the coffee cup. Then turn the side dial to choose which one. If you do it out of order or don't wait for the green check mark to light up first then it just all starts to blink. Kind of like an error code. Your best bet is to take it slow, it's a touch convoluted but worth it in the end for the kind of espresso/cappuccino this machine puts out.

Overall I highly recommend this machine for any coffee fans.

Ease of Use: B (A little convoluted but you will get the hang of it)
Aesthetics: A (Not a bad looking entry level machine at all)
Espresso: A+ (Excellent coffee, excellent crema (foam on top of espresso) as long as you know when to stop it.)
Foam: A+ (Will take practice but it makes a nice foam once you skim it on the top of the milk, I use lactaid or fat free half and half btw)
Maintenance: B+ (The drip tray needs to be emptied, and you need to clean the frothing wand after each use as well.)
Price: A ($59 was a good price for me)
Footprint:A (looks smaller in person as oppose to the box, which is great. I lack counter space!)

Overall: A
title: A step up from my previous machine(s)

title: this is an amazing value. Its a pump espresso machine and doesnt ...
