review_content: I bought this to replace one I owned for four years. The old one worked perfect until the heating element quit. I thought this was ok as I made coffee more than once a day for the four years and no problems. This new Coffee make looks like the old one but it is not the same. It is not as sturdy as the old one. Now for the really bad part. My wife was making a cup of coffee one morning and she left the room for a minute when all of a sudden the cup that holds the grounds explodes off the maker splashing HOT coffee and grounds all over the kitchen. We just assumed she did not get the grounds cup secured and we were careful from then on. Now just the other day I was making a cup of coffee being careful to get the grounds cup tight. I was in the kitchen when the coffee maker started spewing steam from around the grounds cup and I ran out of the kitchen just as the grounds cup exploded off the unit again dousing thew kitchen in hot coffee and grounds. I am afraid to use this coffee maker now and will most likely destroy it and put it in the trash. I DO NOT RECOMMEND THIS COFFEE MAKER!!

review_content: We used it three times and found the coffee to be hot and strong. If you only want to make small batches of strong coffee, it is a good choice. The milk steamer is a different story. It will foam the milk for a short time and once the pressure drops, the foam immediately settles. What we found disappointing was that the milk remained cold or lukewarm. The small amount of pressurized steam is not enough to increase the milk temperature to 150 degrees, what the manual claims. We used only a small amount of milk (about 2-3 oz.) straight from the refrigerator and after frothing stopped (and the foam disappeared), the milk temperature was about 80 degrees F. or less. So we are returning the machine and will choose a standard drip coffee maker that brews coffee with very hot water.
title: Strong coffee, but the milk steamer is not what it should be

review_content:
It's been over 20 years purchasing & commenting on any Mr.Coffee brand product.
Read many positive reviews, but I was bit skeptical.
I was ready to spend over 500 dollars just to make a cup of espresso...

Wow...what a surprise...perfect crema espresso everytime and it is very quiet and super fast.
Great Espresso under 2 min. (from grinding to brew)

Operation is very simple.

Turn on the switch ..wait for steady green...press brew...turn knob to brew...get your espresso shots...
turn off knob and power switch...that's it.

Bit more better design would be nice, however that will bring up the cost anyway..
Overall it is a great simple espresso machine and I strongly recommend.

review_content:
This is a sweet little machine for a sweet little price. It makes a very, very good cappuccino, latte or whatever coffee-house espresso drink you like. Once the power is on, it is heated and ready within three minutes. I've only had it for five months, so I cannot comment on continuity, but so far so good. I use it, on average, twice per day, and I have even converted my hubby to lattes with this bad boy. Since I have former coffeehouse barista experience I had the advantage of knowing how to make espresso drinks already, and I can say that this machine can make you a fine and delicious coffee.

I used to own an Estro espresso machine from Starbucks, worth $300. It was much "fancier" and felt sturdier and more high-quality. I also had the thing for years and it worked superbly, making excellent espresso drinks. By comparison, ECMP50 by Mr. Coffee definitely does not have the really sturdy, high-quality feel to it. Nonetheless, the drinks it produces are -- if perhaps not QUITE as good -- at least very close in quality. I am impressed with this Mr. Coffee machine. A very good purchase for the price!
title: This is a sweet little machine for a sweet little price

review_content: On the plus side, it's a good looking machine.  But the minuses far outweigh the pluses.  The machine doesn't turn off so if you're not careful, it could burn out the unit.  Second, It's completely flimsy and I have to grab the whole unit when attaching the basket. Next, if you're not completely careful, the steam sprays out around the unit and it seems like it's going to explode. The whole way the basket empties, inevitably dumps the metal with the grinds.  Sure there is a catch, but it doesn't seem to be working because of tolerances.  If this wasn't more of a hassle to return than it cost to buy it, I would return it.  TOTAL PIECE OF JUNK.  If you want mine, and you live in Miami, come over and get it.  I fear this thing is a time bomb and have only made 4 pots of espresso with it.  Whoever's giving this a 5 star review either has never used a good espresso maker, or IS BEING PAID TO GIVE GOOD REVIEWS.  BUY SOMETHING ELSE.  You've been warned.

review_content: I‚Äôm in love with my Mr. Coffee cafe Barista coffee machine. Purchased in June 2016 and still going strong.  This little guy has given us and many visitors excellent expresso coffee for the last two years and we are avid coffee drinkers, between my husband, myself, family and friends we gather and have daily about 5-7 cups on a slow day and on weekends 10-15. Felt compelled to write a review about this item because of the reviews I‚Äôve been reading. First of all like all expresso machines periodically  you need to clean the cups and the reservoir every 100-150 brews, I personally use water and white vinagre equal parts and let it run until the reservoir is empty (this may take up to 15 minutes then let it brew again with clean water, do this also with your cups. This will maintain your machine and the quality of your coffee as fresh as the first day.  Remember,  your grinds should be for expresso not brewed. I noticed some of the comments that it was not working and it made noise but it didn‚Äôt work, try the water and vinagre it worked for me. I am currently replacing the cup holder, time and usage has taken its toll but other than that for the price and I‚Äôve had quite a few more expensive models I wouldn‚Äôt have any other.
title: Take care of your expresso coffee machine if you want for it to take care of you
bought_model: Color: WhiteStyle Name: Espresso/Cappuccino Maker

review_content:
49 mm tamper is what I am using, although it is slightly smaller, as I press down in the basket, it fits.
I have used this for about a week. I got my money worth and more. I am new to the game. But I wil save up slowly for a top notch one.
I have a keureg, and my wife said its more watery. But when the espresso steams, man, its so much richer, 4 shots, and we are wired. Not sure if I need to upgrade, but as I put 5 bucks aside for ever 4 shots, I will eventually upgrade, and then take this to my office.
Also...I watch a few videos. And as of right now, I don't know what espresso should taste like, but for me, this model is sooo good. And I will save and be mesmerized when I upgrade. But so much better than my keureg. One thing to mention. I spent 6.75 on a bag of espresso.
Still have a lot left. And loving it. Saved so much money.
title: Worth the money. Seriously, for 30 bucks, it extracts!
bought_model: Color: CappuccinoStyle Name: 4-Cup Steam

review_content:
Overall, especially for the price, this is a good product. It's my first espresso machine so I have nothing to compare it to. My only complaint is that on my fourth use, the plastic cover on the frothing arm melted. I like the milk pretty hot so I may have steamed it too long. Mr. Coffee is replacing the part, but I see this being an ongoing problem. I wish that the machine had a frothing arm made of a material that would not melt. I was instructed not to use the frother without the plastic cover, but I think I might try that anyway.

I'm updating this review and taking one star away. The espresso is fine, it's the frother that is sort of a nightmare. I've tried all different pitchers and containers to froth the milk in, and it splashes everywhere. There is a strong burning plastic smell. I thought it was when the frothing arm melted, but I used it again and was careful not to steam the milk too long, and it still had that smell. Not sure what is burning, but I'm sure I will figure it out after a few more uses. If I were to make this purchase again I would spend a little more, because I will probably be replacing it soon.
title: Plastic cover on frothing arm melted.
bought_model: Color: CappuccinoStyle Name: 4-Cup Steam

review_content: This machine is amazeballs! I had certain "reservations" when I ordered it such as "How can it be a good machine if it's this inexpensive?" but I went ahead and ordered it anyway. Worst case scenario, I could return it. I am SO glad that I got it! It's amazing. It's simple, elegant, takes up little space on my counter, and it makes an amazing latte (as can be seen in the attached video). May I recommend that you read the instructions, and clean it after every use. Truth be told, if you are looking for something as simple as a Nespresso or Keurig K-cup solution, this is not it. However, this will deliver a vastly superior cup of coffee, latte or cappuccino and it will do it with no fuss, no mess. Simply add ground coffee, pack down coffee, lock in handle, push button. Insert milk container if you want froth. That's it. Enjoy! I know I am.
title: The Little "Engine" That Could.
bought_model: Color: WhiteStyle Name: Espresso/Cappuccino Maker

review_content:
There are so many informative reviews, like L. Hamilton's, that I don't need to rehash them. I bought mine for my girlfriend to use as I didn't like coffee. Everything I tried from Starbucks tasted like acid. Along with the unit I ordered some well reviewed Lavazza Gusto espresso bricks. Within minutes I loved coffee (at least the coffee I make). I have since settled on Lavazza Rossa as my go-to blend. Pure arabica doesn't work for me.

Does mine leak? Yes. When I forget to empty the tray. Every time the frother is used the leftover water in the steam tank gets purged into the tray and I sometimes forget about this hidden water filling it up.

Does my water tank leak? No. I could see that tank seal getting worn from constantly removing the tank. I fill it in place and only remove it for occasional cleaning. If yours is leaking due to wear, smear a dab of silicone plumbers grease around the inlet on the machine that the seal goes over to fill in scratches from use.

Is there water under the unit? Occasionally from the steam purge as the tray spout is not air tight. I have sponges for that.

Does it froth well? Yes. I took off the rubber tip and put it in the junk drawer as it's another item to clean. I can easily froth whole milk, 2%, skim, half & half, and soy milk whether it's chilled or not.

Does super tamping help or really matter? Not that I can tell and over tamping puts strain on the pump. Unlike commercial machines, the included filter baskets force the coffee through a pinhole on the bottom of the filter to produce the crema. Heavy packing is not necessary or desirable. Firm is fine.

The only addition I made was an aluminum tamper as coffee likes to stick to the included plastic one.

Take reasonable care and keep it clean. Form a routine, including the Dance of the Buttons (stolen from another review) and all will be well.

1. Check tank and add water as needed.
2. Make your shots. Press steam button after last shot as it takes a bit to get ready.
3. Do your frothing. Clean the frother immediately after the last batch as the milk will cook on the tip (if you have removed the rubber thingie) and the stem. If you let it go and the milk has hardened, grab a warm damp sponge and wrap it around the tip for a few seconds until the milk is soft and wipe the tip. There will be a whiteish ring on the tip where it meets the stem. That's the rubber sealer for the tip so don't scrub it off.
4. Run the frother again in open air to clear out the nozzle and sterilize the frother.
5. Rinse out the filter and handle.
6. Run the brewer again without the handle in place for a few seconds to rinse off the brew screen.
7. Empty and rinse the drip tray.
8. Enjoy some fine coffee.

Yeah, it's a bit to go through each time you use the machine but the coffee is great and worth it to me for what I paid. Run some Lavazza Rossa, or any fine coffee, through it and you probably won't drink another Starbucks, again.

Tip: I like to make cold coffee and cappuccino and hate the grittiness if I have to add sugar. I make up a batch of simple sugar syrup and keep it in a squeeze bottle by the machine. Brew - squirt - froth - drink.

My apologies if folks are offended by some of this but some people just don't use common sense.

Remember, this is a budget priced home 15 BAR machine that just happens to make great coffee. You're not gonna get a Rolex for 80 bucks. Your gonna get a mass produced somewhat flimsy item and the occasional lemon. Get over it.

This unit was bought last year and put to daily use without issue or regret.

The only time I had to contact Mr. Coffee about a product, it was out of warranty and they treated me right.

If mine breaks I will get another if nothing else is outstandingly better in this price range by then. If I come across any issues I can fix (I'm pretty good at it), I will post a solution.

UPDATE 1/2/13: It's been 11 months since I bought this and I regret to say that it's still working fine and I'll just have to find something else to gripe about.

Here's a couple of things I forgot to mention:

During the occasional deep cleaning (like when you run espresso machine cleaner through the unit), remove the rubber divider from the brew head and clean under there as well. I use a chopstick to coax the 2 rubber nipples into the brew head and the divider comes out. Swipe some cooking oil onto the nipples to make putting it back in much easier. I'll post a pic or two if I can.

There is a "Stainless steel 2 cup incremental measuring cup, 1 pc" that I found here that works a treat as a frothing cup. It's the perfect depth.

Whew. All this writing - time for a cup of coffee.

UPDATE 12/1/14 Another 11 months have gone by (what is it with 11?) and I am still using it without issue. It just keeps going.
title: A great cup of espresso.. UPDATE 1/2/13
bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Automatic Dual Shot

review_content: So far the espresso maker has been great. Remains to be seen how well it stands up after some use. Good appearance but mainly plastic with some stainless steel accents. Easy operation, excellent frothing, good coffee extraction with 15 bar pump. Machine is noisy but after some use I've gotten use to it and barely notice. Probably wouldn't use for early morning, due to noise(not that bad) and time needed to make cappuccinos but for my evening and weekend espresso it's great. Machine is plastic, while NOT necessarily cheap looking, does not weigh enough to keep it from moving when placing porta filter. You need to hold one side with one hand while placing filter in other and apply equal opposite force or else machine will move or worse fall over. For the price it's a good machine, nice look to it and the most important...good espresso....Update..04/11/18....this machine is running well. Makes great cappuccinos. I‚Äôve not made lattes primarily cause I prefer strong espresso and for me cappuccinos are a good balance of milk and espresso. I have to say my wife and I love this espresso maker.
title: Pretty darn good!
bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Espresso/Cappuccino Maker

review_content:
Update: Machine died within six weeks‚Ä¶ I am dropping this down to two stars for now. I will order another one and see how quickly it gets here and how long it lasts.

This is the third or fourth Mr. Coffee machine that I have purchased over the last 10 years. It is not a genuine espresso machine because it doesn‚Äôt work off the vacuum principle. Consequently, it will not produce a nice rich crema.

However, while they don‚Äôt last longer than two or three years, they are capable of producing the strongest coffee of any coffee maker that I‚Äôve used in the quantity that I want. Most of the espresso machines are designed for a very small quantities, but this comes with a fairly large deep coffee basket, so you can make a lot of good strong coffee. (I like a deadeye or a blackeye.)

They‚Äôve made some minor improvements to the controls, which makes it easier to work with than the older models, so I bumped the star rating up to four. In addition to it not being a genuine espresso machine, the other major drawback is that the lid to the carafe (over time) does not stay seated well,

But for 12 ounces of good strong coffee, this can‚Äôt be beat.

review_content:
I had a couple of espresso machines before this, one v cheap that took me 10 minutes to make a coffee. Another that took 7 minutes. title: Perfect,  and money saving for Starbucks addict
bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Espresso/Cappuccino Maker

review_content:
So far so good...this machine makes very good espresso and cappuccino as well. I was a bit concerned with some of the other reviews, particularly with leaking and the milk steamer not working. as far as leaking, I don't remove the water reservoir, I just open the top and add the water, while the reservoir is plugged in - so far no leaks!

I've had the unit about 2 months, making 2 cappuccinos and 2 espressos daily and I agree with many other folks, the milk steamer was less effective after a month. I took the lid of the milk reservoir apart, and the mechanism is completely mechanical. I gave it a very good cleaning (milk scale does build up) reassembled and it was like brand new again. I don't want to take that apart, so I soak and rinse the top of the milk reservoir in hot water for about 10 minutes once a week and it has kept the steamer working well.

If you're using it and the steamer is not to your liking, you can turn the dial to adjust the milk/air mixture as far as you like in either direction.
title: So far so good..
bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Espresso/Cappuccino Maker

review_content: I've been wanting an espresso/cappuccino machine for years, but was turned off by the price.  My sister got me a stovetop Bialetti pot, which worked, but was a pain to use.  While doing some research online, I came across an ad for the Mr. Coffee machine and decided to buy it.  After a few "trials and errors", I began making great cappuccinos.  Really, the machine is as easy to use as a normal coffeemaker, except for steaming the milk, and the end result is GREAT!  So, ok, I'm not a "purist", who has to have the perfect espresso with crema, but for people who go to Starbucks a lot, this is the shizznit! True, it doesn't have a steamer pot (got one for $15 from Crate and Barrel, which came with a thermometer, GREAT idea).  Don't need a tamper...the simple plastic one on the bottom of the scoop works fine for me.  I went online to check out some videos for making cappuccino, and VOILA!  I've now had this for over a year, and it's still working like a charm!  Even gave one as a Christmas gift, and they love theirs as well!  Would wish for a slightly longer cord, but it's fine.  Some things about frothing I've found:  1) Start with cold milk (and if your pitcher is metal, freeze it first). This helps keep the milk from scalding. 2)Bring the milk up to the proper temperature before you start building the foam (that's where the thermometer helps).  3) Make sure you clean the wand immediately afterward with a blast of leftover steam (one reason why people may have leftover water), otherwise the milk dries inside the thin wand and blocks it (maybe why people say the wand doesn't work after 1 or a few tries).  If you want good cappuccino for a minimal price, this works way beyond my expectations...kudos to Mr. Coffee!
title: Magnificent machine for under $40!

review_content:
My wife has been using the smaller version of this machine for the last couple of years, but it's not very convenient when we have company.

We saw this machine and thought we'd give it a try. She's been very pleasantly surprised. She's a big fan of cappuccino, and says this tastes just like the drinks you'd get in expensive cafes. We use Dunkin Donuts coffee, so nothing too fancy. She doesn't really drink espresso or lattes, so I can't comment on those.

This machine does take a bit longer to clean than the smaller one, but she's used it exclusively since we opened it so the tradeoff seems worthwhile. Make sure you find all of the pieces though before tossing the box, the small filter seemed to disappear in the packaging so we had to search for it.

Look, if you‚Äôre diligent and keep the parts clean and treat the machine well, it will produce excellent tasting espresso for a good long time, definitely long enough where you‚Äôll feel you got your money‚Äôs worth. The noise isn‚Äôt that loud at all and I‚Äôll see later on if a coarser grind will eliminate the soupy grinds. Right now, using super-fine Bustelo and Pilon and the flavor/crema outweighs all the other stuff...RECOMMEND.
title: Tough to beat for the price...
bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Automatic Dual Shot

review_content: This is an excellent little machine!  My husband and I have had ours for 6 months and just love it.  It's the first espresso/latte machine we've owned and we found it very easy to use.  We haven't been to the local coffee place (****bucks) since we purchased it and we figured out that with the money we're saving, it's paid for itself several times over!  We have friends who have purchased more expensive machines that are much more complicated to use and this machine makes espresso and lattes that are just as good or better!  Plus, they've had problems with their machines and this one just keeps on going.  You'll need to purchase a frothing pitcher if you want to make lattes, and I suggest a kitchen thermometer to go with it. (You want to be sure the milk gets hot enough or your lattes will be lukewarm. I suggest bringing the milk up to 150 to 160 degrees before adding it to the espresso.) Another tip:  Getting the hang of frothing the milk is really not hard.  It just took a couple of times for my husband and I to figure it out.  If you don't feel comfortable running the frothing tip along the surface of the milk (this will make more foam and is fun to do once you get the hang of it) then just keep the tip completely submerged in the milk until it comes up the proper temperature.  Just move the pitcher around so that the milk heats evenly.  Submerging the tip the whole time will keep you from making a mess until you get the hang of how the frothing tip works.  We purchase flavored syrups from our local grocery store and every morning we have lattes that taste just like the ones we used to pay $7 for!  I highly recommend this machine!!
title: You get more than you pay for!

Just ordered a tamper, some good beans and a burr mill from Amazon to go along with it. I use a ceramic mug for my milk frothing. Works just fine.

title: It made great espresso every morning till March 1

review_content:
My boyfriend loves it. Update... I love it. Easy to use.
I dislike traditional coffee makes because of the filter and the grossness that builds up in the innerds of the machine. The glass pot gets gross and people let cold coffee sit there til the next day. So I used to just use a French press, but my boyfriend wouldn‚Äôt make himself coffee because it was too complicated. So I bought this machine.
This machine is perfect. It is easy to clean, there is no filter to throw away, it makes just enough coffee for 1 serving. The used coffee grounds are easy to clean out.
I highly recommend this coffee maker.
title: Five Stars
bought_model: Color: BlackStyle Name: Steam + Starter Set

review_content:
For whatever reason, this machine also seems to die in about 6 to 9 months (this is the 6th or 7th I am buying over the years, for lack of anything better. Delonghi makes one but that also dies in about a year, slightly better than this).

And with the design issue: the control as well as the water lid both are tapered and so they are both a little difficult to hold and operate. Normally you have some extra protrusions or rings around the edges to hold these well, but Mr. Coffee went the other way - they tapered the end and made it smooth. Mr. Coffee people, if you read this, please fix this design issue.

Other thant these 2 issues, I have no issue with this machine. It is quite good, fast and makes reasonable espresso for the price range.
title: Design issue: why taper the control and the lid? Making it difficult to operate..
bought_model: Color: CappuccinoStyle Name: 4-Cup Steam

review_content: The machine works great! It makes great lattes, and I saved money by making them myself at home. The only drawback has been that I haven't been able to use the machine for the past two months due to the difficulty of ordering replacement parts. There is a small, silicone tube that is required for making any drink that requires milk.  The tube is very light and easily lost in the process of washing (check comments on the Mr. Coffee website and you will discover this is a common problem). Although the part only costs $1.99,  it is not in stock, and hasn't been in stock for several weeks. What is worse is that there is no indication that it will ever be in stock again. Advice from customer services is to "keep checking the website", but that doesn't put coffee in my cup when I need it.  I can understand running out of an item, but reviews that have been left make it clear that this has been an ongoing issue.  Not only should the company include an extra in all new machines, it needs to take measures to ensure that this part is available.  Buyer beware, if you are going to use the milk steamer, guard this silicone tube carefully.
title: Makes great lattes - Difficult to get replacement parts
bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Espresso/Cappuccino Maker

review_content:
Having very recently returned the other, let's say "Brand X" sub-$100 pump-driven espresso machine that had 4+ stars, I was hyper-aware of the features and improvements I was looking for. This machine has hit almost all of them with just one issue that might be my fault. This unit does come with two (non-serviceable) filter sizes for single and double shots. It does not include a spoon or a tamper. Like most pump systems, it's a little noisier than a drop machine but not that bad.

Cup space. First thing I noticed was this unit is a little larger than the Brand X unit. I was able to fit a medium-small sized coffee mug under the filter so the need for tiny espresso cups is not so urgent. It does make it a little harder to see how much espresso you're making but you can tune yourself to what looks right. I also noticed my cups don't go sliding across the tray like they did on the Brand X model.

Frother: A major annoyance of the Brand X model was the frother was spring-loaded/activated. This made it feel like a juggling act with the very real risk of burning yourself. This unit has a normal swing out frother (no springs) and to activate it, you simply turn the knob to "steam". Very simple and all you need. It produces a good foam and the rubber tip comes off easily for cleaning. The height of the frother also allows you to use a normal mug instead of some special tiny frothing cup like Brand X required.

Filter handle: Another issue with Brand X was the filter was very difficult to seat fully. You had to be very strong to get it to the fully locked position and I rarely bothered to get it that far. This unit is much much easier to get to the fully locked position even with a full basket of grounds.

The one issue I seem to have is it doesn't get very hot, but it might be my cups not being pre-heated and the slow drip in a 66 degree house is just too much to keep it hot. The espresso still tastes wonderful and it's been very easy to use a normal mug for the entire process. Preheating is very quick (within a minute or two) and brewing is just a quick.

For the price and simplicity of this unit, I highly recommend it.
title: Fantastic deal and my favorite of the two options with this feature-set and price
bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Automatic Dual Shot

review_content: I am so disappointed in this coffee maker.  It was rated as a best seller on Amazon, so I decided to purchase it after my 20 year old Krups finally died.  I followed the instructions to prepare it for making coffee.  Then, in great anticipation I made my first espresso, but before I could even taste it, I could smell the plastic.  Upon tasting it, the plastic flavor was so strong I had to spit it out and dump the coffee.  I tried running plain water through at least a dozen times more with no luck, still had the horrible plastic flavor.  I left the cap off for a couple months hoping to air it out, no luck.  I followed the instructions from the Mr. Coffee site to put vinegar in the water storage to rid the unit of the plastic flavor, no luck.  After all this, my chance to return it was way past, now it is going in the trash.  I cannot imagine why any company would use a plastic product so strong you couldn't get rid of it and make a drinkable coffee.  I was also never able to get the steamer unit to work... it just blew huge bubbles around, not the small foam bubbles I was used to with my Krups.
title: VERY DISAPPOINTED
bought_model: Color: CappuccinoStyle Name: 4-Cup Steam

review_content: Our previous espresso machine was the DeLonghi  ec155 and for half the price it is the much better option. The Mr. Coffee Cafe Barista works great at first, but within 6 months the frother started acting up. The dial barely makes a difference for volume of milk it dispenses and we clean this machine after every use! Already shopping for a new machine. This is  cheaply made and not build to last. Our DeLonghi ec155 lasted over 5 years and worked great until it died.
title: Durability issues, not for regular espresso drinkers
bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Espresso/Cappuccino Maker

review_content:
Overall, this little machine makes as good a cappuccino as MUCH more expensive home machines. (of course, even the best machines won't make a good cup of espresso if you don't start with GOOD coffee, properly ground)... I definitely recommend it. HOWEVER: The steaming wand on my machine clogged after a few months of use... there aren't any instructions or anything about cleaning the steaming wand... let me make a few suggestions that I have mostly figured out by myself, with little or no help from Mr. Coffee:

The cover for the wand is unnecessary and bothersome. Just remove it and don't bother.

The tip of the wand unscrews and can be cleaned separately. Do that often. You may have to use a pair of pliers to "break it loose" and to tighten it sufficiently when you put it back on-- there is supposedly a built-in "wrench" on the handle of the measuring scoop, but it may or may not actually be effective. It's probably necessary to clean the steaming wand tip often (definitely every use, force some steam out of the wand when you're done to 'blow it clear'...

Mr. Coffee recommends that you delime the machine every 40-80 brews, same as with a regular coffeemaker (use vinegar, then flush with clear water a few times)... clean the steaming wand tip at least this often-- probably much more often.

You probably want to put a cup or something under the steaming wand while you are waiting for it to get up to temp/pressure... water will drip, the steam will be "wet," etc. while you're waiting...

Overall, a decent machine and certainly a good machine for the money.
title: Works great... needs better maintenance instructions

review_content:
I waited sometime before writing this review so that I can give you my most honest opinion about the item.

Before giving you some pros and cons, let it be known that I had to return the first espresso maker that was sent to me because it had a major water leak. Upon first use, I noticed that the machine was leaking from the bottom, which was reducing the water pressure and very likely creating some electric shock hazard. I took a peek inside the machine to see if the issue could be easily resolved but what I saw in there was an almost 100% plastic construction, some poor quality components and somewhat weak-looking water tubes. Anyway, this was to be expected given the price range of this espresso maker.

Once I received a new one, I could immediately notice the difference. The water pressure was fine on this one and there were no leaks. I'll now list some pros and cons for this machine following two months of using it once or twice a day to make espressos, cappuccinos and lates.

PROS
--------
- Can't beat that price. As far as I'm concerned, there is no other product in this price range that works as well as the mr. coffee's barista.
- It has a very compact build, it's small and will fit any kitchen.
- Very easy to use, clean and maintain.
- While its espressos are not on pair with those made by high end espresso makers, they are actually quite good.
- I like not having to handle the milk frother by hand, this machine is quite convenient.

CONS
--------
- Inconsistency! I am entirely convinced that this machine lacks consistency in terms of how much milk is frothed when it's preparing a drink, small or large. I typically use the same cup when preparing small lates (Bormioli Rocco Verdi Cappuccino Cup with Stainless Steel Handle). Sometimes the drink will only fill up about 3/4 of the cup, while some other times it will fill it up to the top, and then make some more foam and a big mess along with it.
- Inconsistency #2. While it's nice having an automatic frother, I feel like I can never trust it. Adjusting the milk dial to make a late (low froth) will often work as expected but other times it won't, and you will end up with some (or a lot) of unwanted froth in your cup.
- Milk frother often rebels and decides to spit milk in all kinds of directions. While most of it will go into the cup, some won't, so... be ready to spend a few extra minutes cleaning it.
- Construction is almost 100% plastic as expected. Given the leak issue of my first machine, however, I can only assume that this thing is not that sturdy.

Despite the cons above, I would recommend this machine because of its convenience factor, the price, and the fact that in the end, it does make a very good cup of espresso/cappuccino.
title: Compact, convenient, makes good espresso but has annoying shortcomings
bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Espresso/Cappuccino Maker

review_content:
Ask yourself this question. Is it worth spending 15 minutes making your own latte on a machine that will require you to make maybe 100 lattes before you see a return on your investment, or is it easier to go to the coffee shop and buy one?

Pros:
Nice pressurized espresso dispenser, can tamp to your hearts delight without causing the machine to strain
Milk container can be refrigerated
Functions well

Cons:
Water tank appears to be Polycarbonate (likely has BPA), don't store water in it (directions say not to as well)
Significant effort to make a latte/cappuccino.
Won't handle heavy cream, but half and half is okay.

Basic process:
Turn on machine, add water to tank, grind coffee, put in filter, tamp as hard as you can (I use stainless steel tamper, not flimsy plastic one included), put filter in holder, attach holder to machine, fill milk tank. Machine might be ready to go by this time, press button according to what you want. Takes only 30 seconds or a minute at most. Pretty fast. It is the prep/cleanup which takes the longest. Once you are done, turn the froth knob to clean and press and hold the cappuccino button and let it run hot water through the steamer. Make sure to have an empty cup under the milk spout. Repeat to fill a 15 oz travel mug (I have to basically make 4 shot latte, I fill the 2 cup filter twice).

Again, I love this machine, but consider if it is worth the effort to you. If you make a latte every day, it might be, but if you just have one every week or two I would probably stick to buying them at the store to avoid having to have the machine around taking up space. Also plan on spending a significant effort coming up with what works best for your. The coffee shop has already done this, they know exactly what grind and roast of coffee to use and how much.

review_content:
I went through 3 of these within a year.

The first one was DOA so I returned it (Painlessly--Thanks Amazon!).

The second one was buggy from the get-go, randomly shutting down and refusing to work and then suddenly working again. I put up with it for a few months until it finally permanently refused to power on. I was then amazed by Mr. Coffee's customer service as they quickly sent me a replacement.

The third one worked perfectly until just a few days ago when a plastic screw broke, and this is what I consider a design flaw: A weak plastic screw is used in a spot that gets force applied to it regularly and exhibits vast temperature changes from normal use. It is the screw that holds the water screen that disperses water evenly over the coffee basket. Without this little screw, you end up with a very weak and watery shot, and a whole lot of wasted coffee.

It hasn't been a year since my original purchase, and it's only been a few months since the replacement, so I gave Mr. Coffee a call again.

The first thing they told me was that I don't qualify for warranty.

The second thing they told me was that they don't offer that part for purchase, and I will have to buy a whole new one.

The last thing they told me was that they could sell me a new one at a discounted price. Their discount amounted to about ONE DOLLAR BELOW AMAZON"S CURRENT PRICE...! And about $17 MORE THAN WAREHOUSE DEALS!

Needless to say, I refused.

That screw probably costs them 2 cents. They could have sold it to me for 2 or even 10 bucks, and I'd be perfectly happy. But to refuse to even make it available for purchase...

I CANNOT RECOMMEND THIS PRODUCT.
title: DESIGN FLAW! QC ISSUES! DO NOT BUY! Too bad because I used to love it.
bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Automatic Dual Shot

review_content: My wife and I have been looking for an Espresso machine that also makes lattes and cappuccino but were wary of spending hundreds of dollars. The froth created is perfect and it is easy to use and clean. Some say it is noisy but to me it is music to my ears knowing that in just seconds I will be drinking a great latte, cappuccino or just a double shot of espresso. Thank you Mr. Coffee and Amazon

review_content:
After reading the reviews I decided to get the Mr Coffee ECMP50 Espresso maker due to price and overall high reviews.

The first machine I bought failed. It would not brew anything darker then a light tan, I tried different tampering, different ground and nothing. The machine leaked like a crazy leaving water all over the counter. I reread and reread and reread the instructions and it just wouldn't work so I took it back to Target and exchanged it for the same model.

The new model I got I noticed right away before even opening the box it was different; the 2nd model came in a (shades) of brown colored box and the 1st came in a pinkish/lavender colored box. I didn't think too much about it till I got home and started brewing an espresso...this one worked! Dark rich flavored espresso, howbeit not quite as good as a top Italian restaurant but as good as Starbucks, the crema is a little weak but the coffee is flavorable. I also noticed no leakage whatsoever. I only make espresso's and don't care for cappuccino's or latte's thus I don't froth so I can't comment on that aspect.

I gave it 3 stars due to the first bad machine and potential quality control issues, weak crema, flavor not quite up to par but at least as good as Starbucks, and a good value compared to other espresso makers.

So far after only a couple of uses I'm happy. I have read some reviews where the purchaser had the same problems I did, I can only assume, although I could be wrong, that you find one in the brown box and not the pinkish/lavender box.

This is an up date effective 5/14/12.

I bought this coffee maker on 9/16/10, on 5/14/12 the pump failed. This coffee maker is barely a year an half old. Thus for such an inferior product design I changed my rating of it from a 3 to a 1, and would have rated it zero stars but they don't allow you to go that low. Did it make good coffee? yes, not the best that really expensive espresso makers can make, but your not spending a lot for it either; but for any product to fail just after 19 months is just darn right bad. Another made in China product that fails to last for any length of time.

STAY AWAY FROM THIS COFFEE MAKER if you want to last longer then 2 years.

review_content: I get GREAT espresso from my machine every time! First read the instructions, it's very short, but will keep you from breaking your machine or getting burned. Trust me, it's worth it.  The way I flawlessly make my espresso is quality whole beans (not folgers) that I grind at home. Then, ignore the grounds to water ratio the instructions give! Use the standard 1 Tablespoon of grounds tampered to 1 oz. water (2 Tablespoons). Less water makes a sweeter brew and more water highlights the bitter taste coffee can have. Oh, and buy a tamper. If you are going to steam milk to make cappuccinos or lattes buy a metal frothing cup and remove the plastic cap on your frother to get the best results. Wipe with a damp cloth after frothing to keep clean. I would be kicking myself if I had spent 100s of dollars on a machine. Best coffee purchase ever!!!

review_content: This machine is dangerous!  The pressure is off the charts and the cheap white soft plastic gasket in the lid and around the cast aluminum tank creates a foul chemical smell and taste.  I took the gasket off the lid and had it tested and was told it is made of a low quality material that will break down with use and contaminate the steaming hot water it is meant to contain.  These gaskets make the coffee taste absolutely terrible.  I removed the gasket from the lid and tested the machine without it.  It was a bit better, with only some chemical taste, but still not really drinkable.  However, operating the machine without the gasket is obviously very dangerous.  I think this machine is a newer version with different gaskets meant to eliminate the exploding problem older models had.  My advice is if you have this Mr. Coffee machine, throw it out and get a pump machine.  It is dangerous and a piece of junk.

title: ICE COLD WATER AND ICE COLD MILK are key to ...
bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Espresso/Cappuccino Maker

review_content:
Sadly it finally died. My previous one lasted almost 5 years same model. This one 2 years. Sigh.
Now I will be looking for a different more expensive brand like I've always wanted.
It makes the perfect shot every time. The perfect shot is supposed to have lots of crema and layers in the body. If i follow the steps it works like a charm. (Old school barista here)
1 add water
2 turn on, it takes less than a minute to heat up.
3 add espresso, grind is important so make sure its ground for espresso and not regular drip etc.
4 tamp, press down on the espresso or it will be lighter than desired and a waste of money.
5 put wand into slot and straighten to lock in place. (Like in picture)
6 press the espresso button and put carafe under wand.
7 turn knob to espresso and it starts after an initial buzz.
8 turn knob back to center position to stop flow when done and turn off.
I've had mine for over 2 years with no problems, I maybe once used the milk frother becuase I love cold drinks so cannot comment on that. It worked fine that one time though.
I've also owned maybe 10 espresso machines, the steam ones are horrible, take longer, die quicker and are dangerous if you forget that it hasn't cooled down enough (yep once had a top shoot up to the ceiling and slight steam burns)
This is the best and most consistent. A couple of times the lights would just blink, this is usually due to sequence error. If you switch the pour button on before selecting button for brew/froth it will get confused. If it persists turn it off and on, just like any other electronic device. Once you follow the steps accordingly this time it will work just fine.
I almost want to buy a second one for when the lifespan finally kicks in. It's gonna be that or get a breville or comparable high end machine. No looking back.
title: Best espresso machine I've ever owned
bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Automatic Dual Shot

review_content: Decent machine especially for the price. The different drinks all taste great like I would pay for at a coffee shop. Only complaint is even with foam dial on milk tank set to no foam, and when making the bigger-sized latte (which should have no foam), it still makes a massive amount of foam. So much so that my average-sized coffee cup overflows with foam every couple times making the bigger-sized latte and getting on the espresso handle. Not a huge deal because the foam can just be scimmed off the latte and wiped off the machine, but could have been better. Overall, tastes just as good if not better than expected for the price.
title: Good taste and good value, but too much foam.

title: At best, it is handy as a milk steamer and ...
bought_model: Color: CappuccinoStyle Name: 4-Cup Steam

review_content:
I wanted to love this machine - I already had the Saeco Via Venezia, but the manual-ness was a turn off (had to manually stop the shots from being pulled and had to use a thermometer when steaming milk and stop it when it reached the right temperature). I had actually put the machine away for about 6 years!!

I visited my cousin who had the Cafe Barista and was in awe that all you needed to do was press a button and voila, your latte/cappuccino/espresso was made for you - automatically! I was intrigued so I purchased this to compare it with my Via Venezia.

First off, if you have nothing to compare the Cafe Barista to, it seems like like a well-made product. However, since I had the Via Venezia, which is made in Italy, the parts and pieces were so much more well made! The housing of the Cafe Barista was plastic whereas the VV was stainless steel. The handle of the portafilter (the gadget you put the espresso in) was plastic as well, where the VV had a nice rubber grip. All little things you wouldn't ordinarily notice unless comparing side-by-side with something else. I was concerned the Cafe Barista wouldn't last very long because of the plastic components.

On to the differences in how it makes espresso/latte: I use soy milk and by nature, it doesn't foam/steam easily (I worked in Starbucks so I know how to properly foam using a steaming wand). The Cafe Barista's foam using soy lacked depth and thickness and it just tasted like a thin soy milk; no froth at all, even when I set it to the max. I went as far as going out and getting whole milk to see if it was just the soy that was producing mediocre foam. While the whole milk did produce better foam than soy, there was still much to be desired.... It just wasn't right. I had to manually turn on the foaming contraption again after the automatic setting ran its course to get more foam (just to be clear, I'm not snooty about foam - I don't like cappuccinos bc it's too foamy. I am just looking for nice, thick latte foam!). With the VV, I have a lot more control on how the milk is steamed/frothed and my soy milk would be perfect - right thickness (not watery) and the foam was smooth and rich, not bubbly and airy like what the Cafe Barista gave me.

The shots. I don't really have much to say about comparing the two - they both pulled very similar shots of espresso and I could barely taste the difference. Again, I like the fact that the Cafe Barista pulled the shots with a press of a button and stopped when it was done. I didn't like having to watch over the VV and have to stop it manually. With that said, espresso shots only last about 10 seconds before they turn bitter and gross, so I guess the manual setting wasn't that big of a deal.

The cleanup. The VV was fairly easy to clean - just empty and wash the portafilter, the drip tray if necessary, and the steam wand if you used it. I would run empty water and steam through the wand first to get all the gunk out in case there was still milk trapped inside, then I'd detach and wash. Easy peasy. With the Cafe Barista, there was more to be washed - the portafilter, the milk container, the wand that pours the milk into your mug, and if I remember correctly, there was also a rubber tube that fed milk into the wand. You don't want milk or anything getting hardened and stuck in these as it'll be hard to clean later and you'll be having gross milk.

Anyway, looooooong story short (too late, right?) I felt the VV was a better fit for my needs and I already had it (didn't need to spend more on another machine). Since I worked for Starbucks, I got the VV at my discount. Had I not had the discount, I prooooobably wouldn't have purchased it for the $300+ it goes for and would settle for something that had a steam wand (i hear Mr. Coffee has one!) instead of an automatic frother contraption.
title: I have the Saeco Via Venezia and I prefer that ...

I upgraded the double-shot basket (the only one you're likely to use) to a normal, non-pressurized type from Krups, the MS-0907163 for $6.
I got a somewhat hard-to-find 51mm tamper for this unit, which is just slightly too small but works well enough. Because of the rare size I had to spend $23 on this. Maybe I'd try a 52mm tamper but that would probably have to be sanded down a bit.

This simple little machine makes a good espresso but...
it does not come with a frothing cup, the sleeve on the frothing arm pops off into your steamed/frothed milk and the cap on the water chamber needs to be tightened further and further with each use. Simple engineering will tell you that this means that the water chamber and the threaded opening are expanding during the heating process and not retracting/contracting once cooled. Eventually there will be a complete loss of vacuum which will render the unit useless.
I would not recommend this item.
title: You Get What You Pay For
bought_model: Color: CappuccinoStyle Name: 4-Cup Steam

review_content:
I was skeptical before purchasing this item; it's inexpensive and the reviews were not fabulous, but I wanted an espresso maker and we 9husbanad and I) couldn't afford one, so this was the only option. We took the plunge and I'm happy we did. This little thing has turned out to be fantastic! I don't know how we lived with out it. We have owned this product for nearly 6 months and here are my tips:
1- Buy the temper so you can pack the espresso bean
2- the pitcher is worth buying but isn't totally necessary (you can use a coffee mug if you really wanted to, the pitcher is more convenient)
3- clean the maker every time you use it, but it is especially important to clean the milk steamer every time you use it because you can get build-up (you would have to do this with every espresso maker)
4- Give the maker a really good clean about every week. I put water through it a few times, it doesn't take long.
5- make sure you use all the water every time you use it
6- don't over-fill anything

Don't be alarmed! These tasks are typical up-keep for any espresso maker. Believe me, the little extra work is worth it since you can get up every morning to a latte or cappuccino without paying the crazy prices at a coffee shop.

p.s. My friend has this same espresso maker and she has had it for over three years without any problems =)

review_content: I was very pleasantly surprised by the quality of this product.  My Senseo machine died after just a year and I was not ready to spend $200 to replace it.  This looked like an interesting product since I like using a pressurized coffee maker.  This makes a great strong cup of coffee or latte if you like to add milk.  The milk steamer is easy to use and allows me to make a latte using home ground Starbucks coffee for a fraction of the price of going to Starbucks.  Plus there are no filters to buy or replace so it is ecologically friendly!  If you buy it go ahead and get the frothing pitcher and tamper - I ended up buying them after the fact as they are pretty handy.

My husband has been very pleased with this machine so far. But BEWARE we threw it in the dish washer not thinking and the piece that holds the little filter is NOT dishwasher safe! All the chrome paint came off it. Guess we should have checked to see if it was dish washer safe first so that's our fault. Other than that issue we thought it was a good buy.

review_content: The cost is so low and the thing works so well, there is pretty much no reason not to buy one of these. Just divide the cost by how much you'd spend out buying coffee drinks and it's a no brainer. As someone else noted, even if it dies every year it's worth just buying another. I replaced a very basic Braun espresso maker and this one is far better. Makes excellent espresso. The frother works just fine. Needed to buy a carafe, but you can find cheap ones that look and fit fine. I like the large water reservoir and fast startup. The size fits well on my counter. It is not nearly as loud and shaky as the De'Longhi ECP3420 I sent back. It does have operational step sequences you have to figure out, and one idiosyncrasy after you stop steam,  but once you learn it, no problem. Easy to clean.

review_content:
I've owned this unit for about 3 years, used on average 2x daily (typical: once for cappuccino in the am, once for espresso in the early afternoon).

During that time, I've replaced the metal filter basket once (just couldn't get it unclogged). About 2 months ago, the milk pumping part just died. I tried re-ordering a milk frother, but that didn't solve my problem.

All that said, I'm going to order this unit again. I feel like I got a good amount of use out of it, and it made good coffee, and it's still the lowest-priced thing that does the milk for you. The espresso alone is the best I've had from a home unit (drinking it right now as I re-order).

Also nice: this used to cost $199, and today it's only $150. So that's even a better reason to re-up. Plus now I've got a relatively new filter basket if that goes wrong again.

review_content:
This unit is fairly priced at $199.99. It make a nice cup of espresso with great crema if the beans are ground properly. The milk frother also work well but does not get the same microbubbles and foamy consistency as typical wand frothers.

After 2 weeks of heavy use the portafilter holder started to lose the seal with the unit and steam would escape around the connection (coffee still flowed). The entire filter assembly is about half the weight of comparable models and feels very cheap. I decided to return mine before my ability to do so expired and I was stuck with a broken machine.

For someone that wants to make a nice drink a few times a week this unit is a good value. For someone who plans on multiple drinks/day i'd spend more and get a unit with better build quality.

review_content:
For $40 this is a good espresso machine. Very simple, easy to clean, measured amounts. It lasted us over 2 years with a good 1-4 uses per day. The only reason we threw it away is because the side knob handle broke off. Otherwise it was still functioning. The side knob pole that goes from the knob to the machine is made of plastic and ripped off the hinge. So one thing to be careful on is to always hold the knob at the base and turn it slowly to avoid damage. The day it broke I was in a rush and grabbed it at the tip and twisted the internal plastic pole. I suspect over time more crap got into the metal and made it harder to turn. But I will admit I wasnt very good about cleaning it, too lazy. When the coffee tasted like crap is when I ran the vinegar and cleaning instructions... bad espresso machine owner, BAD!

But I feel the "Mr. Coffee ECMP50 Espresso/Cappuccino Maker, Black" is a superior product and 100% worth the $80 they are asking. There is a significant difference. It foams, unlike this model, and the taste is better.

(Angy's lazy espresso cleaner husband)
title: Good espresso machine the Mr. Coffee ECMP50 is superior
bought_model: Color: CappuccinoStyle Name: 4-Cup Steam

review_content:
For years now I've thought about purchasing an espresso machine to be able to get my caffeine "fix" at home without having to spend $4/drink out at the mega-chain, but I never followed-through. Late last year, my nearby mega-chain started becoming VERY inconsistent with its drinks. Quality control had drastically gone downhill, and even after speaking with management, nothing changed. I made the decision to purchase one, but imagine my surprise when this espresso machine was given to me by my bf as an early Christmas gift!

First off, my unit has no leaks whatsoever. This machine heats up very quickly and is ready to go in no time flat. It took a little bit of time to get my "technique" down, but now I can consistently make my favorite drinks as good if not BETTER than the mega-chain. Between my bf and I, this machine has already paid for itself. I did the math, and when taking into account the cost of all the ingredients (espresso, a flavoring syrup, and milk) a grande-size drink made at home costs around $0.80 compared to the $4+ at the mega-chain!

A couple of tips: Get a nice tamper, the one that comes with it is just plastic and you really cant get a great tamp with it (and a good tamp is important). You don't have to spend a lot one one, the one I purchased was only $7 here on Amazon. You'll also want a nice frothing pitcher -- stainless steel is best (and put it in the freezer for a minute or two before ya froth, it helps!). Also pick up a thermometer, as you want to make sure you don't over-steam the milk otherwise it will go bad on ya (personally I steam up to about 150 degrees).

Perfect "Triple Grande Skinny Vanilla Latte": 3oz of espresso, 3 squirts of sugar-free Torani Vanilla, and about 10oz of skim milk. Top with foam, sprinkle a little cinnamon on top, and enjoy! BTW, the Torani Sugar-Free Vanilla is 100x better than the sugar-free from the mega-chain. No weird after-taste from the Torani, it tastes just like it was made with real sugar. A *definite* purchase if you like Vanilla Latte's!
title: Better than I could have ever imagined!
bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Automatic Dual Shot

review_content:
I love this thing! Followed my gut and a lot of the reviewers advice and got it. It's great.
Don't get it if you make more than 2 cups of coffee at a time, it will be too small.
Pros:
You can froth the milk for capuccinos in a flash, you just need a bit of practice.
It's small, so it doesn't take up all your counter.
Easy to operate and clean
Just the right amount of coffee for two, no leftovers, no waste.
Good price
Cons:
Not so easy to regulate the amount of coffee vs water, you just have to eyeball it. This means you have to shut it once you get enough coffee or it will continue to brew until it runs out of water. So either shut it off on time or add the exact amount of water you want.
Frothing pipe doesn't move
The lid can be hard to open and close (otherwise the steam like out of it)
Doesn't come with a pitcher
title: excellent machine.
bought_model: Color: CappuccinoStyle Name: 4-Cup Steam

review_content:
Trust me. As a stock trader & night owl who lives on the West Coast, I start every day 3 hours behind Wall Street. So, NOTHING is more important to me first thing in the morning than getting a quick, easy, perfect cappuccino. Seriously. Nothing.

When my third Krupp's espresso machine died after years of heavy use, I decided to change things up. I bought a Mr. Coffee ECM160 4-cup Steam Espresso Machine and at the same time, bought a Capresso espresso machine. This way, we have one at home and one in our RV.

I chose the Capresso because I ADORE another product from Capresso: Mllk Froth Pro (You simply pour the milk into the non-stick, easy-clean pitcher, and press start. It's perfect every time and frees me up to feed the cats while the espresso and milk froth are in the making.) I chose the Mr. Coffee simply because it was the maker of my first drip coffee machine which lasted for decades. It's a name I know and trust.

Even tho the Capresso was $10-15 more expensive, the Mr. Coffee choice is by far the best. It takes up less space on the counter and less space vertically. Its lid is crazy easy to open and close in a hurry, while the Capresso lid lacks grooves, so it's extremely difficult to open and close (it requires rubber gloves, someone who's very strong, and has lotsa patience to wrestle with it every morning in order to finally twist it on and off).

In addition, the Mr. Coffee brews faster than the Capresso espresso machine, finishing at the exact same time as the Capresso Milk Froth Pro! Ahhhhhhhhh. Perfect every time. Amazingly easy.

The Mr. Coffee espresso machine + Capresso Milk Froth Pro are a match made in heaven & absolute staples in our kitchen! =^.^=
title: Go with the Name you Know & Trust

Pros:
- Its cheap
- Espresso is good
- Almost automatic frothing, less hassle with additional cups and stuff
- Robust to coffee grind and quantity, if you do something really wrong it shuts off and saves the pump
- Big water tank
Cons
- No way to stay clean while recharging coffee
- Frothing function cheats and provides something more like whip than steamed milk
- Cleaning and washing of milk container takes some effort

review_content:
i got this machine a couple months ago and is working perfect, there are a few things i want to share, the first one and is probably why some of them blew up is because people don't clean the machine; after frothing the milk you ALWAYS have to clean it, take an empty cup, fill it with cold water and activate the steamer, do this 2 to 3 times until there is no milk in the water. second to do an espresso first heat the water in steam mode and when you start getting some steam, switch it to brew mode; turn it off when coffee reach the 2nd line (2 cups)., then after use, unplug the cord and release the contained pressure turning into steam mode until all the steam is out. ALWAYS repeat this before you open the reboiler ( you will save the top seal), ALWAYS empty the reboiler. THE KEY OF THIS MACHINE IS KEEP IT CLEAN.
great machine for value.

review_content: I tried to purchase this from Amazon but found a better deal through the manufacturer that included a burr grinder for under $150.  I purchased this unit to make flavored drinks and was pleasantly surprised at the quality of the coffee and cappuccinos! The drinks are extremely hot, which is something that I like and look for in a machine. Many units that cost more do not make the frothed milk hot enough so the cappuccino comes out lukewarm. I have more expensive machines that do not produce much better espresso, once you get the grind size correct. The automated features and removable milk container make this unit a real winner. The fact that they sell the grinder along with the unit for under $150 is an amazing purchase. You will not be disappointed. The only drawback for the machine is the quality of the handle unit. It is quite light weight and made of plastic. If you are used to a heavier handle unit and knock box, you will break the handle on this unit. Just a tip, turn the handle upside down and tap the bottom with a heavy spoon or knife handle to knock out the grounds. This will preserve the handle. The photo is of a shot of espresso, followed by a double cappuccino!
title: Pleasant Surprise
bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Espresso/Cappuccino Maker

review_content:
I could give the Mr. Coffee Cafe 20-ounce Steam Automatic Espresso Machine 4 or 5 stars. I have been making Lattes for several years and have used a number of machines which include a couple of DeLonghi's and a Capresso and one other, perhaps Krups. None of them in the very high priced range (under $200), but each making decent Latte. I can't help to not compare them.
It took awhile to get used to the Mr. Coffee since it is a bit different in use and function of the others.
Pluses:
the price is very reasonable
it makes a very creamy espresso which is delicious
the espresso flow is extremely fast, though the pump pressure is 15, it seems more powerful than others with the same rating
the latte quality is right up with the best I have had from Caribou Coffee, better than my other machines
the water reservoir is handy and easy to see
there is a guide to get the grounds cup unit into the bottom of the machine, which words very well
the buttons and indicator lights are simple and easy to use
there is a place to store my tamper, I don't use the plastic one provided, I have a metal one
my two espresso cups can be stored on top of the machine, I didn't have a need for the one which came with the unit
with practice, it is easy to get the texture of the milk froth that you prefer, if you don't use the froth cup which was provided
Minuses:
the froth cup is much too big to use without getting nothing but big bubbles
the wand is hard to get clean of the heat hardened milk unless you do it within seconds of being done frothing
the cup platform is just a bit small
the wand would be better if it was longer, though it is adequate
The indicator lights blink brightly when something is not right, but there is no indication of the problem, if the machine is turned off, unless you're out of water, it seems to take care of itself
I found that I needed to grind my espresso beans a little finer than for my other machines.

A Couple of weeks later: I have been using this machine each morning to make a latte for myself and my wife. Unfortunately it has developed some problems. The switch to turn it from pumping the espresso to stream does not always work. The switch has to be played get it the right position to work. Also, the machine will not make two espressos in quick succession. The light blinks quickly and the pump will not work. It generally takes turning off the machine and fiddling with the buttons and the on/off switch to get it to work again. Cleaning the wand from heat dried milk has also become more than a bother, it is a chore. I would not recommend this machine, I would avoid it. When I can get it to work the espresso is fine.
title: Problem Espresso Machine
bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Caf√© Steam

review_content:
My husband and I had a Kuerig for a couple years. Prior to that, we weren't much coffee drinkers. We bought one of those plastic filters and filled it up with espresso in the mornings and we were perfectly content doing it this way and dealing with a technically crappy cup of coffee. Besides this, we also frequented Starbucks for their cappuccinos and lattes. I then decided to do some research on a new machine to surprise my husband for Christmas. I read every one of the reviews and decided to take the plunge on this one. On Christmas Day, my husband opened it up and set it up right away. He made our very first espresso using the same grounds from before and we were blown away. "Is this how it's supposed to taste!?", we both exclaimed as we laughed about having dealt with crappy homemade coffee. "Look, there's no black sludge at the bottom of the cup!", we also added. We are by no means baristas and had nothing else to compare it to, but this machine is night and day to that of a Keurig. I'll never go back to those dark times. Setup is pretty easy and doesn't take up a lot of counter space. While this is made out of plastic, it looks much more sophisticated than our old plastic Keurig and looks nice. So far, this machine has seen a lot of use since Christmas morning. We are going to start grounding our own beans to get the most out of it.

My only issues are when using the frother, sprinkles fly from the cup onto the counter. Also, espresso continues to leak for a little while and we have used soy sauce plates to catch the leaks. You can see how much builds up right after making a cup of espresso in my photo.
title: Great for an inexperienced barista
bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Espresso/Cappuccino Maker

review_content:
My wife and I purchased the Mr. Coffee ECM160 Steam Espresso Machine in 2009 and have encountered no difficulties, nearly two years later. My wife broke the decanter and found the Mr. Coffee customer service staff helpful...we received a new decanter within a week (at a reasonable cost - $10, shipping included). The espresso shots are "good," while the steaming quality is "okay." However, The included scoop/tamper is "poor"(too small); we consider a 49 mm tamper a must-buy companion for the ECM160. While not necessary, we highly recommend a steaming pitcher, thermometer, shot glasses, and an espresso scoop. Starbucks sells an excellent kit (it includes all the aforementioned items), for a great price.

Even factoring the additional accessories, the ECM160 provides excellent value for the budget conscious.
title: Great Quality for the Price
bought_model: Color: CappuccinoStyle Name: 4-Cup Steam

The machine itself is not to blame. The frother (steamer) works great especially with the 20 oz stainless steel pitcher. This produces more than enough of that lovely foam for one or even two cappuccino's which makes it great (It does take some practice though).

A slight detail, this machine doesn't produce good "crema" so for all you espresso aficionados I recommend the model above this one. This machine is great to save a few bucks instead of going to the local coffee store and spending 4 bucks or more on a cup of coffee.

I would recommend this product to a friend.

review_content:
This is my forth purchase of this amazing little inexpensive machine. It is light as a feather and it is completely portable. I have taken it with me numerous trips. I like having it in my hotel room for a shot of espresso ‚Äúwhen I want it‚Äù and to have a perfect cappuccino in the morning. Yes, this is not as good as my home Breville BES920XL, but are you really going to take a $1200 machine to work and on travel. My first Mr Coffee espresso machine lasted seven years of multi-daily use at the office (3 to 7x/day). I purchased my second one while overseas in Southeast Asia and abused it for two years with calcium dense water. My third one is in my sailboat and my fourth is in my office getting major abuse again. This machine makes the coffee fun and produces excellent steam milk frothing even for the inexperienced. To ensure long lasting use follow these rules:
1-don‚Äôt over tighten the portafilter. Just tighten it enough to prevent a seal leak. Avoid damaging the O-ring, it cannot be replaced.
2-never leave the portafilter locked in place when not in use. Take it out immediately or the O-ring will be crushed and leak (I broke my 1st machine this way after leaving it in all the time for 7 years)
3-clean your coffee filters immediately
4-use low mineral water. I now use distilled water for consistent flavor and ability to judge various coffees without water flavor distortion.
5-never run the machine without water in the water tank.
6-remove the silicone steam wand tip to clean it well and to clean the steal steam wand.
Enjoy excellent coffees with minimal $$$ investment

review_content:
I really wanted to like the Mr. Coffee ECMP50 machine, but am having a hard time warming up to it. I've used other pump-driven machines in the past; most recently a Lello 1375, which currently costs about 3X the ECMP50. After using the ECMP50 for a few days, I am somewhat sorry I didn't pay the additional money to buy another Lello 1375. Here's why.

The Lello is much sturdier. It doesn't move around on the counter when you take the brew basket out. The build quality is noticeably higher throughout. Everything from the brew basket to the base unit itself is much heavier. The parts fit together more tightly, especially the brew basket and filter; it's really annoying the way the filter flops around in the brew basket for the ECMP50. You feel like it's just about to fall out every time you empty the grounds. The Lello unit lasted for years of daily use, and only required cleaning/descaling every few months. We'll see about the ECMP50 - although I don't know if I will stick with it for that long, as you might gather from what follows.

The Lello holds more water so you don't have to refill as often, and it has a more powerful pump, so you get your coffee faster, and what's more important, it tastes much better. The ECMP50 seems to be very finicky about the grind, whereas the Lello was not. Too coarse, and you get watery coffee (poor extraction). Too fine, and you clog the filter. I've mixed and tamped using standard commercially ground coffee and still haven't got anything I really like. The readily available Starbucks grind doesn't seem quite fine enough. I'm going to experiment with re-grinding to make it finer, but that seems like a lot of work. UPDATE: If I regrind the standard Starbucks coffee, to get a fine powder (yes, kind of like "salt" in size), the end result is much better. Still not quite as good as a good drip machine, but much closer. I will keep trying!

Finally, I like to make a cup of Americano coffee using a regular mug. The Lello had enough space for most mugs to fit under the brew basket, the ECMP50 is about 1/2" shorter, and so few mugs will fit underneath.

I will say the ECMP50 is quieter than the Lello, at least after the initial BRRRRR! you get when you first turn it on. It also holds onto the brew basket more reliably, so you don't feel like you have to have a hand on it during the entire brew cycle, just in case the handle disengages while the coffee is being made (the Lello tended to do that, but perhaps it was a function of not replacing the basket sealing ring more than every couple of years). One other good thing about the ECMP50 is that I expect you can get parts for it. The Lello has parts, but they are pretty expensive, and you must buy them through a New York distributor.

Part II
Well, after trying all possible combinations, I managed to get a barely passable cup of coffee out of it. Not quite as good as a good drip machine, but almost. Basically, even if I filled the filter basket full of finely ground, fresh coffee, it still tasted weak. I thought I'd be able to do better, after all, I've been using pump espresso machines for over 20 years now. But I finally gave up! It was too much trouble to turn back in for a refund (I'd have to pay the shipping to return it, according to Jarden Industries, who sells these), so I gave it away. I hope the new owner has more success than I did. As a simple alternative, I got a used Keurig machine, bought a reusable filter basket, and added regular ground coffee to it. MUCH BETTER! So I'll stick with the Keurig, and if I get ambitious, I'll buy another Lello 1375, which is what I should have done in the first place.
