review_content:
I bought this in July, 2017 (through my wife's account) for my office. I own a more traditional (better) machine at home and have been making my own lattes daily for the last 16 years. I haven't done any of the initial cleaning steps that others recommended other than washing everything with soap and water. I've made up to 4 lattes per day for myself and others with no issues for the last 6-8 weeks. The quality is not quite as good as my more traditional espresso machine at home, but you can't beat the convenience of this machine sitting on my desk. And really, the convenience is such that you won't care if it's not the best latte you've ever had in your life. The user interface to the machine is clearly well thought out with one glaring exception.

My only complaint: You set the amount of foam using an imprecise knob on the front of the milk reservoir. It's a little difficult to dial in the exact amount of foam that you like, but with a little trial-and-error it can be done. That is, until you clean the milk wand which requires turning the same knob all the way around to point down to a "clean" setting. You clean it after each use, so you can never get the foam "just right" and simply leave it there. This is really a giant nitpick because otherwise the machine is a dream to own, but it seems like such a glaring design flaw only because the rest of the unit is so well thought out.

Tip: clean the milk reservoir completely once a week (e.g. Friday afternoon before heading home) because the milk left in the reservoir will eventually go bad. I tend to keep topping up the reservoir during the week and storing it in the fridge except when in use. It's really difficult to clean the frother tubes once you've run curdled milk through them (but you _can_ do it).

Recommended accessories:
- an iced tea spoon: the coffee dispenses after the milk and tends to sit in a layer between the foam and the milk. A quick two-swirl turn mixes the milk and coffee.
- a nice tamper: I bought the VonShelf one and not only does it work very well, it's quite attractive. https://www.amazon.com/VonShef-Premium-Barista-Coffee-Stainless/dp/B00OQ82KF0
- some type of narrow pipe-cleaner brush: I haven't found this yet, but you need it to properly clean the frother.
title: Fantastic appliance with one glaring nit-picky design flaw
bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Espresso/Cappuccino Maker

review_content: Bonding with this little machine has been easy -- in fact, addictive.  In the first week I was drinking enough espresso to make a small country develop hypertension and stroke out, so I cut my regular coffee beans 50/50 with a Swiss water-processed decaf bean. After a month of multiple daily uses, this coffee snob is pleased to report that the Mr. Coffee ECMP50 meets -- nay, exceeds -- expectations.  I didn't think it possible that a machine so innexpensive could produce enough pressure to create a decent crema, but it does. I was at first an Ugly Americano in my reluctance to introduce an appliance of such low pedigree to my europhile kitchen appointed with Le Cruset, Cuisenart and Futuro, but I'm also a cheapskate whenever quality will not suffer.  Deals like this are a valuable lesson in culinary name-brand bigotry.  As long as the espresso is evenly tamped in the grounds basket, the dual streams of espresso that it produces will fill two 8oz cappuccino cups side-by-side (in fact, I've been steaming milk or breve in the individual cappuccino cups first and then just letting the espresso fill in on top). I am including a photo of how to fit tall cups by removing the drainage tray -- BUT if you use the steamer first, wait a few seconds after turning the steam off for the overflow release valve to finished draining into the tray.
title: Boasts from a Budget Barista in Big Sky Country
bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Automatic Dual Shot

review_content: Learn the product and do complete research before trashing a product based on your skill level. The first cup I made was great, the third was week, but I learned. The beans, grind, and tamp change everything. This machine does not leave a soupy mess if you tamp properly. I get the pucks one would expect. If the grind is not fine you get coffee, not espresso. I find this machine more than adequate. Read the instructions. It does not work well if you make mistakes or abuse it, but you don‚Äôt have to be an expert barista. You do need a proper tamp or substitute. I used the extra filter cup before I bought a proper tamp. Press hard. The edges take time, but it does work. This machine makes noise, but less than any grinder I use. If you want an easy drip or Keureg buy it. This machine takes a little time and care, but not that much. The result is well worth the small amount of attention required.
title: Makes a good cup if you use it right
bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Automatic Dual Shot

review_content: I don‚Äôt think there is a better cappochino machine out there for the price. Yes, I used to live in Italy and have had fantastic espresso. When my wife wanted a cappochino machine I almost overlooked this like most. I mean, how is a Mr Coffee going to give me what I want? This thing delivers. I have not had a regular coffee since getting this. Throw in some Lavazza and you are set. The separate milk unit is genius. You can pull it off and put it in your fridge until your next drink. You cannot bear this unit for the price when it comes to cappochino quality and functionality. A little disappointed on the unit being all plastic BUT it is sturdy and well built. And for the price it makes sense. Do not hesitate on this. Oh and make to follow the priming instructions before first use!

I also had the issue another reviewer writes about where the screw falls out of the coffee filter. Fortunately, mine happened while tamping the coffee and the screw didn‚Äôt fall into my drink. I would not buy this machine again. If you do purchase this machine, I recommend also buying the 4 year extended warranty that Amazon offers. It‚Äôs likely you will need to use it.

review_content: Everyone in my family (2 teens and 2 adults) loves this machine.  This is an espresso machine, not a coffee machine.  It makes either 1 shot or 2 shots.  If I want coffee, I make an Americano- I heat up some water and add a double shot of espresso.  It takes a little practice to figure out how hard to press the coffee down and how full to fill it.  These things affect the taste of the espresso shot.  If you are in a rush, the Keurig is faster since there is no clean up.  But if you have 5-10 minutes, then you have time to make a delicious cup of espresso, ice coffee, latte, americano, etc.  After each use, I dump the ground coffee and if I have used the steamed milk container - I run the cleaning cycle for the milk frother and then wash the milk container.  It isn't that much work.  I use the "custom" milk option to choose how much steamed milk to use.  The "latte" button uses a lot of milk (taste preference).  I descale it every few months using vinegar (you have to do the same thing with the Keurig).  Buy good coffee beans and a grinder.  I also bought a metal tamper.  This satisfies my espresso cravings and I never feel the need to go to Starbucks.  My daughter and I agree that we like our coffee better from this machine.  Get good quality beans that are freshly roasted, it makes a big taste difference.
title: I love this machine!!
bought_model: Color: RedStyle Name: Espresso/Cappuccino Maker

review_content:
I cannot understand why this is a bestseller. We followed the directions, watched several YouTube videos on espresso-making, and read online posts about how to do it correctly to avoid breaking the machine/making poor drinks. Unfortunately, my husband and I were only able to make three proper espressos with this machine before it began spewing grounds and steam from the filter when we turned it on. We figured it was something we did wrong, so we made a few more, changing something each time (such as how hard we were tamping the grounds, adding more/less grounds, using different water, etc.) to no avail. Each progressive attempt resulted in more extremely hot grounds or steam being spewed out. Did some more research, and it turns out that this seems to be a problem with about 1 in 5 of these little guys. Honestly, save your money and buy a better machine. That's what I intend to do.

However, I am thankful for Amazon's customer service. Although it couldn't be returned, they did issue a full refund.

bought_model: Color: CappuccinoStyle Name: 4-Cup Steam

review_content:
I'm enjoying this great cup of cappuccino this morning - thanks to the reviews I read on Amazon and other sites. I've owned my Mr. Coffee Expresso/Cappuccino Maker for nearly 3 months and love it - love it - love it! I was skeptical that a budget cappuccino maker could compete with the taste of a coffee-house and I have been pleasantly surprised. The machine has effective pump pressure and is easy to use and maintain. I really enjoy my morning coffee routine - it does take more attention to prepare than other methods but I feel luxurious savoring a cappuccino once or more a day! I haven't had to compromise taste or quality with a machine I can afford.

Caveat - As some reviewers noted, there are some tricks to getting the quality of drink you want. Expect to experiment for a while before figuring out how to make the "perfect cup". Fresh beans are key; I now grind my own just before making the coffee. I've used different brands - so far, I like Starbucks fair trade Italian Roast the best. Fresh water - I use filtered water from our reverse osmosis system. Using a near full container of water seems to deliver better steam and pressure for both the coffee and milk (creating the "puck" - like grounds that are easier to dump). To get the strength of the coffee I want, I've experimented using the recommended scoop or slightly less and then tamping it down. The frother is also easy to use. I get the best results using 3-4 Tbsp. of 3% fat half and half. I've also used Silk's soy eggnog and soy pumpkin drinks for variety.

Yum - think I'll go make another cup!

review_content:
We had a Krups model FND1 for many years and very satisfied with it. Eventually the boiler cap failed and we couldn't find a replacement, it was so old. Originally, we had paid $50 for the Krups. Paying over $100 for a new machine seemed ridiculous, and this Mr. Coffee seemed like the best compromise, especially since we could use the glass carafe from the old machine if we would break the new one. Lo and behold, when it arrived, the construction is exactly the same as the Krups with a few minor improvements in the knobs, the shell, etc. The boiler cap is 1/16" smaller in diameter, that's the only real difference. So we trust this machine will keep us in strong coffee and foamed milk for many more years. We were also very surprised and pleased with how quickly it was delivered, just two days even though we had selected the free shipping option. Of course, being in the next state from the warehouse may have had something to do with that.

Two caveats: the plastic air siphon on the steamer wand is overkill, get rid of it, and the instructions fail to note that you must unplug the machine before releasing the pressure through the steamer wand.
title: Same as KRUPS model FND1
bought_model: Color: CappuccinoStyle Name: 4-Cup Steam

review_content:
I endured a more expensive but leaking Kalorik machine for two and half years before buying this one.

The Mr. Coffee is superior in every way.

It is easy to see the minimum and maximum levels on the commodious water tank, the espresso comes out in thin accurate streams, build quality seems good, it looks good, it costs hundreds less than many machines, and the espresso quality is great: dark and rich.

It's hard to twist the parts together before brewing, but the seal seems to be getting more accommodative with each use. It's also a little unnerving for a newbie when it starts brewing then goes silent for several seconds before resuming. These are minor points to me.

This is a no-brainer for the budget conscious if the choice is high priced espresso drinks from coffee shops or multi-hundred dollar institutional type machines.

Thanks to the other reviewers who guided me to this choice!
title: Kudos Mr. Coffee

review_content: I really like this Espresso Maker. This is the first machine I have bought for coffee, we use Lavazza beans and they are so rich combined with the machine. The frother works great, but you do need to make sure you clean the lid thoroughly before you store your left over milk in the fridge...I made that mistake once and we had to scrub out mold and then run it through the dishwasher. I still works great and we have had it since the beginning of June and have used it non stop at least 2 times a day usually more. We bought a replacement 2 shot fliter and the holder..make sure to wash and dry them also, ours has begun to rust, but the replacement parts are really cheap from Mr. Coffee's website.

Based on reviews, I also purchased RSVP Terry's dual sided espresso tamper, SImpleTaste grinder with ceramic burr, and Lavazza Super Crema coffee beans. I wanted to give the machine a fair shot. I am glad that I purchased the tamper because I didn't like trying to use a plastic, spoon-ended tamper to press hard enough to compress the ground beans. The simple hand grinder I purchased was also a great buy because it has only a few adjustments, and it gave me exactly the right table-salt consistency ground beans that is required. Also, the brand of coffee was highly praised by others and did not disappoint. So, all of these together has delivered an excellent cup of medium roasted espresso coffee. Also, I have made a cappuccino and latte and both have been great! I usually make an Americano every morning by pressing the double shot twice without adding additional coffee.  So, I am very happy with my purchase by acquiring a few extra items.

When it fails we're going to a different brand, one that makes double expresso cups at same time. At this price our expectation was 2-3 years of trouble free service of a properly maintained unit.

review_content:
I started drinking lattes more instead of coffee from a Dr Oz show I watched. Lattes are better on the stomach and have more protein from the milk content. The lattes are expensive after a few times so I decided to order this. I did the reviews and decided to go with this one.

Awesome little machine, just got it yesterday and have used it to make espresso and steam milk for the latte. Get a separate tamper as this does not come with one. Don't waste money on more expensive pump driven ones as they break easier. I broke the glass carafe by accident and was able to overnight a replacement one very easily from amazon. Almost all the parts are replaceable as well. Works great to heat up and steam milk for hot chocolate for my kids too!

review_content: I'm really torn about this espresso maker.  It does make phenomenal espresso and does an excellent job frothing milk.  It works flawlessly. I requested a replacement (which took a week to arrive!  what ever happened to 2-day shipping for prime members), but the second one simply didn't work at all - straight out of the box it was non-functional.  So, a third one is currently on its way.  With a little luck, perhaps this one will work and won't leak!

review_content: Ok, let me first say, my only vice and addiction is good, rich, strong cappuccino and espressos-if I do not get my proper fix in the morning, the rest of my day truly suffers. I tried 4 expensive Italian espresso machines before I found this gem. I was a real coffee snob, thinking an American mr. coffee machine could not compare with these other machines- wow, was I humbled and so wrong! After spending another big chunk of dough on yet another  Seaco with yet another pump that died after 90 days, I thought, what do I have to lose? I also refused to settle for a machine that uses wasteful and ridiculously expensive pods or  kcups- making my choices very slim... Enter the cafe Barista by Mr. Coffee. This machine makes a perfect espresso, cappuccino, or latte, almost instantly with no waste- best part is I can use as much of my favorite grinds or add flavors as I desire, for perfectly crafted custom beverages (I love using the Italian Torani syrups). I have had the machines for over a month now but make at least two drinks daily, and it never disappoints. The creama is always perfect, the espresso hot, and foam is superb. It has become a required and enjoyable part of my morning ritual. I am leaving this review in hopes that the product sells well so I can continue buying it when this one wears out. BTW: You do NOT need to be an expert barista to use this unit. I highly recommend this machine. Note: I do not know how long it will last, so I will update my review here in the future if it does not last the test of time...
title: Amazingly good product- perfect, yet very EASY cappuccinos and lattes again!
bought_model: Color: WhiteStyle Name: Espresso/Cappuccino Maker

review_content: I am a first timer to these barista kind of machines, I've only ever used a Keurig. That being said, I'm not quite sure how I survived without it? It was very easy to prime and setup. It has also been very easy to use, the espresso handle is a bit tough to get locked into place but fine. Everything is easy to clean too. I've read some reviews that say the durability isn't there, and it is a bit on the "lighter" side of construction (meaning it doesn't "feel" heavy duty/industrial ... but then again, neither does the price) so we'll see how long this lasts (hopefully a long time!). We have a Breville burr grinder that pairs perfectly with this to do the espresso grounds. There are nicer machines out there, sure, but you'll have to pay for it. So overall, highly recommend because it's a great balance of price and functions without being complicated.

review_content:
I really like my Mr. Coffee ECMP50. It exerts the required pressure to form the crema, a rich foam.

The steamer does a great job of foaming the milk for a really good cappuccino. I wish that the process was a little faster, but I do enjoy brewing this treat. Add a little bit of chocolate syrup to the milk before foaming, and you get a really good mocha cappucino.

A really good bargain, it compares favorably to machines costing three times the price. Enjoy!

review_content:
By the time I bought this espresso maker, I had already gone through many different coffee and espresso machines. A friend raved about the Nespresso systems but I had used a Keurig for a few years and was done with the whole pod system, which seems wasteful and expensive, plus it was hard to keep it clean from icky sludge that formed in the water dispenser. Another friend raved about the Breville but the cost of that was way over my budget. This Mr. Coffee machine had great reviews and the price was good, so I decided to give it a try.
I've waited to write this review until I had some time to really get to know this machine and I can tell you I absolutely love it.
The Espresso, Cappucino, and Latte
Drinks I've made have all been delicious. The espresso comes out dark and rich and even has that crema top to it when the shots are finished pouring. There are two options: a single or a double filter and I always use the double. For milk, I use almond or rice milk and the froth on the cappuccino is great! The bubbles aren't as fine and "creamy" as you would get from a professional machine at an espresso bar, but the results are still delicious and impressive. The machine dispenses the milk first, then adds the shots of espresso, so I sometimes stir it after it's done to totally mix the espresso (especially if you add sweetener). There is definitely an advantage to using the right grind for the coffee beans. Be sure your beans are ground for espresso. I had used beans ground for pour over coffee and the espresso was watery.
The Machine
If you are looking for a brew-and-run system, this isn't your machine. But the time and effort you spend is honestly not that big of a deal and the results are worth it. Take a cappuccino, for instance. Here's the process. First, fill the water container with water and place on the back of the machine. Turn the machine on (it takes a few minutes to warm up). Next, fill the milk container with your type of milk, place the top on, be sure the setting is set to "cappuccino"* and insert the unit into the machine. Next, take the "porta-filter" and place a scoop of coffee into it, tamping down firmly with the tamper on the other end of the scoop. Insert the filter into the machine. Place a large cup under the filter (there's a pull out stand for a small cup but I rarely use that), make sure the silver tube (dispensing the milk) is pointed into the cup (yes, I've forgotten that and dispensed milk all over the counter by accident), and then press the cappuccino button twice (for a double). The machine goes to work, first dispensing the milk, then the espresso. You'll know it's working because it is loud.
After you've enjoyed your cappuccino, there are a few things you need to do to "clean up" and be sure the machine is ready for the next time. First, remove the porta-filter and dump the used grounds (they go into my counter-top food scraps bin). Rinse out the filter, and then place back on the machine and press the button for a single shot of espresso. This rinses out the espresso parts of the machine. I then remove the filter, take it apart under cool running water, and let it dry. For the milk container, turn the setting to "clean," place a cup under the metal tube, and press the "clean" button (it's the latte button, pressed and held for a few seconds until the "clean" function turns on). Now, the tube is clean and you can either place the container in the fridge (if there's milk left over) or rinse/wash and let it dry. Does this sound like a lot? It doesn't take long and it just becomes part of the process. Again, the results are worth it.
*As you can see from above, after you've cleaned the milk container, you have to turn the knob back to cappuccino or latte. If you forget, you'll quickly realize that you are dispensing steamed water instead of steamed milk into your cup (plus, the cleaning sound is different than the frothy milk sound).
Cleaning the inside of the machine is an easy process (using vinegar) and the machine seems to stay much cleaner than the Keurig machine I used to own.
Bottom line: So far, this machine has produced excellent results. Takes a bit of effort but the results are worth it.
title: The Results are Worth a Little Effort
bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Espresso/Cappuccino Maker

review_content:
Really sad about this purchase, I wanted it to work and before I purchased, I did my homework and read all the reviews and decided to give it a chance. At first, I was really pleased, but within a month on making one cappuccino a day the froth started getting big bubbles and became watery. I had been running the clean cycle after every use and went through the whole vinegar cleansing thing and it still was making substandard froth.
I contacted Mr. Coffee and they were great - sent out a new milk container w/ head and now a month has gone by and I am in the same boat again.
I'm going to return it and spend a little more $ to get a better machine. Wish I had done that to begin with.
title: Really sad about this purchase
bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Espresso/Cappuccino Maker

review_content: I bought this machine shortly before Christmas, so I've been using it for a number of months, now.  I love it!  I considered much more expensive machines, but didn't want to get locked into being required to buy certain 'pods' or 'k-cups.'  I also like mixing my coffees (half-caf, full caf, etc).  But most of all, I really enjoy MAKING my own cup of espresso or coffee.  I told my husband years ago not to buy me a push-button machine because I truly enjoy the process of creating my own drinks.  So, if you want to hit a button and have your espresso pop out, this is not the machine for you.  With this machine you turn the water on and off and, therefore, control the size/concentration of your drink. Next, the milk frother is great!  You are in full control of the frothing, as well. (I did remove the plastic/rubber sleeve the day I got it.)  I do use it with a thermometer and I have a blast attempting latte art (see pics).  What I can't do is 'free pour' art and I'm not sure if that's my lack of talent, the density of my espresso, or the density of my frothed milk.  There are tons of latte art videos on youtube, so you can certainly study up marvel at the talent out there! Finally, I made a fantastic iced coffee the other day.  I used the double-shot cup, and made about 5 or 6 oz, poured it over ice, added half-and-half and it was as good as any drink out there!  I buy beans at my fav, local coffee shop and have them grind them to the correct espresso grind. (This helps a little with the business they've lost after I bought my Mr. Coffee!)  Last run to the shop, however, I just bought beans and am now grinding my own with a Bullet.  There are videos on youtube demonstrating this exact machine, so check it out!  I found it very helpful as I was getting started.  [...]
title: Great machine!  Pays for itself!
bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Automatic Dual Shot

review_content: I bought the Mr. Coffee Caf√© bistro about eight months ago.  At first it was fun and worked fairly well, though very inconsistently.  I never knew just how much coffee it would give me.  Without changing the amount of foam desired,  I could run a large and get a super small amount, or run a small and get a mug that was overflowing,  I used the machine on average once to twice a day following all directions for use and cleaning. The machine was never used to make multiple consecutive coffees.  Two weeks ago, the coffee became much hotter than it had always been, and clear extremely hot water dripped constantly whether the machine was on or off!  Based on my experience, the Mr. coffee caf√© bistro seems inconsistent at best and dangerous at worst! Hope this is helpful.
title: Inconsistent and dangerous!
bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Espresso/Cappuccino Maker

review_content: Initially, I was really excited about this product and thought that I had finally found a good coffee machine for a decent price. I opened up the box, made my first brew, and it tasted great. The second time around, I decided to use the steamer. The steamer did not work and would not heat up the milk. I was a bit disappointed because I was expecting the steamer to work on a brand new product. I then used the coffee machine several additional times and the coffee started dripping out slower and slower. By the fifth time, the coffee would not brew at all. So now I cannot make any coffee and I cannot steam any milk after 5 attempts. Do not bother buying this product. It's not worth the headache. Returning and getting a better one.
title: Do not buy
bought_model: Color: CappuccinoStyle Name: 4-Cup Steam

review_content: Great machine for the price. I spent a good amount of time researching for an espresso and latte machine. I looked over different brands and costs and while I agree this is not a expensive or professional machine, it does make great espressos and lattes. Very easy to use and clean and definitely love the taste. My daughter loves the hot chocolate with frothed milk and even my wife likes her cappuccinos. I read a few reviews regarding water leaks and I can't see this to be a problem, it's more on if the water tank is inserted properly. I also have a Kerrigan machine and they both are almost the same size. One more thing, the machine starts and warms water faster (no more than a 5-7 minutes). Definitely a great buy so far. If you are looking for a decent price and great coffee maker this is the one for you.
title: Great machine for the price.
bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Espresso/Cappuccino Maker

review_content: We used the machine less than 20 times and the handle to the brew basket holder fell apart less than a year after purchase..  I called Mr. Coffee's warrant line.  The lady was very indifferent; said they had no replacement basket holder, said they did not have a comparable replacement machine; gave me a case number and told me to call back in 4 -6 weeks!!!  I told her I wanted to resolve the problem today and she said she couldn't.

review_content: Do not buy this machine. I am completely shocked that this product somehow manages to have a 4 star review. The first espresso maker which arrived did not work at all. It was shipped back and we decided to try to get it replaced and give it a fair chance. The machine is cheap so it is understandable that there could be a relatively high probability of getting a faulty device. The replacement worked for about 2 weeks, until it too stopped working. With such a track record, we will not be trying another replacement. It hardly matters when out of two samples, one fails to ever work at all and another breaks within 2 weeks, but I will also mention that even when the machine was working it was somewhat weird to operate.For example, the machine had to be unplugged, if not after every shot, then at least after a few. The instructions hinted at this but it was not made clear. It was the only way the machine worked though. For the short amount of time that it worked, the coffee was quite decent. But it hardly matters, if the machine doesn't work.

review_content: I purchased the Mr. Coffee espresso machine for my fianc√© for Christmas of 2009. By the Christmas of 2010 it had decided that this is a much too cruel world and ended it's life while making a delicious espresso. I should have seen the warning signs, I blame myself. First we got rid of the blender it had been secretly seeing behind the coffee grinders back, then the steam tube sized up. Soon afterwards the Coffee Pot who had mentored our young Mr.Coffee was replaced by a sexy new stainless steel one, who paid our Mr.Espresso no mind at all, and I suppose that was the final rejection in his young life, because soon after the sorry little sod wouldn't even heat up. Long story short, spend an extra $30 and get the DeLonghi pump operated machine, that's what we did. It has so much more self confidence. Did the Mr. coffee get the job done? Sure. Much in the same way that Halliburton safely drills for Natural Gas. Cheaply, and with no regard to those around it.

review_content: This was my third steam espresso maker over perhaps 15 years.  After about 3 weeks of use, after starting another morning espresso, I noted a screw sitting on the platform next to the carafe.  The next thing I noted was steam coming out all over the top of the unit.  It was as if it was going to blow up -- my two previous steam espresso makers eventually failed because the lid blew off due to years of use and material fatigue in the lid's steam relief mechanism.  When these things go, there is enormous, dangerous forces involved.  So recognizing the danger, I pulled the cord, let it cool, inspected the unit, found two other screws missing.  These screws are light weight screws, apparently that are expected to hold critical parts together under heat and pressure -- not....  I cleaned it up, and arranged to ship it back for a refund.
title: Dangerous
bought_model: Color: CappuccinoStyle Name: 4-Cup Steam

review_content: As a huge coffee fan, I have been seeking a way to make a good cappuccino at home since before Starbucks existed. The trick, of course, is frothing the milk, which can truly be done well only by those with training and practice. It's an art. I either have not been able to master using a traditional frothier correctly or I've never been able to afford a machine capable of creating a good froth. I've used external frothers with mixed results. Then I decided to investigate automatic cappuccino makers with self-contained frothers that dispensed the froth into the cup. I had my eye on a higher end one running about $500, but before investing so much, I wanted to at least look into the basic technology. I have to admit that I didn't expect much from a cappuccino maker from Mr. Coffee; one does not associate Joe DiMaggio with anything quite so continental. But I've been delightfully surprised. This little machine makes a very good cappuccinodfs that is fully automatic yet allows the amateur baristist to control every aspect of the process. I've had the machine for less than a week, but so far, I've developed a process wherein I wet the sides of my 12 oz. glass mug and coat the sides with a dusting of sugar. I then release about a half inch of froth into the mug, on top of which I suspend two shots of espresso. I then fill my mug with froth, which I swirl caramel atop. The machine would just as easily produce the entire cup automatically, but I like the white/black/white layering. The point is that I can let the machine do all the work, or I can experiment with something a little more artistic with equally good results. Not only that, but I can steam clean the frothing mechanism without pouring out the milk, after which I can place the milk-filled frother in the fridge overnight. For the first time ever, I can make and enjoy two or three large cappuccinoes every night without leaving the comfort of my. home. I couldn't be happier. I won't consider a more expensive machine until this one breaks down. It works beautifully, and I recommend it to any cappuccino lover.

review_content:
It did what it was suppose to do for about two months. For that I would give it probably 3 stars, because there was nothing extraordinary about this device.
Unfortunately contact power switch which is actuated by the plastic bump on the turning knob shaft stopped working. I suppose due to wearing out of the plastic actuator bump. The bump started missing it by a hair, and there was no way to bend blade of the contact switch to make it work again because the switch was not engaged by the movement of the blade of the actuating switch using its leverage but rather the bump was actuating the switch exactly and the blade was acting like just a spacer between the two. Poor engineering decisions about the location of the switch or the bad quality control in parts tolerances. By moving the contact switch about 1/8" lower in its assembly would make it work more consistent, reliable and protect from fast wear out.
With the current design it is going to be a 'lemon' for unlucky customers.
One can fix it by shortening the switch and adding external electric switch. But why would you sign up for doing it? I got it at the beginning of May. And I see people complaining about the same symptoms. Once the switch becomes unreachable this device will not turn on. If you are not handy with home appliances you will regret buying this product. It looks like the product was designed to fail after short time. Two months is however way too short for me to stay with the brand. I am looking elsewhere from now on...
I would not recommend it.
title: Look elswhere unless you want to keep replacing it.

review_content:
I bought mine on sale at a local discount store for $20. I was disappointed with the frother but turns out the instructions were wrong. Instead of leaving the plastic "frother aid" on, remove it and throw it away. Once I did that, it froths quite well.

In the use of this older -- original?-- model, I replaced the broken carafe with a one-cup Pyrex measuring cup. Mine came with a stainless frothing pitcher, so it's too bad that has been left out of the new model.

My routine is, start with just under one cup of water. When the brew reaches the 1/4 cup line on the pitcher, I switch to froth. When finished frothing, I return to the brew setting until the pumping is done and the machine quiets down. Then I turn it off and enjoy my large capucino. It's great, still cranking out the coffee daily since 1995. ALSO, my wife and I traveled in Italy a couple of years ago, and although the espresso and capucino we had there was superb, this machine comes very close. Finally, I removed the bottom of the machine just to see what was inside. The quality of what I could see was high. My only gripe is that the screw-on cap abraids the cast tank threads so that after many uses, you have metal shavings scattered on the top of the machine. This does not get into the machine, but it's a design problem.

Thanks for the note about the line cord. Mine was too long so I wound it up and shortened it. It pays to read the instructions, which I usually do.

But taking the filter off first risks getting grounds in your coffee. We do hold the cup up a bit at the start of the milk frothing as it tends to splatter a bit (aimed straight at center of cup). Not a big deal. So far so good, but would like to find a short fat disposable coffee cup (16 oz variety).

review_content:
I love this machine. Although It is not my first espresso machine, I would like to share some tips that will insure a longer life span for your new ECMP50:

1)Always keep the machine clean. Clean the steaming tube at least once a week. circulate some fresh water in the coffee maker or use a lemon salt. If the steaming is too weak or0 too strong(unbalanced), unscrew the frothing tip and wash it .
2)Grind your own dark rousted coffee if you can, and make sure you press it hard into the coffee filter basket.
3) Always have enough water in the tank, or the water pump will be gone before you know it. Make sure the water is above the minimum line at all times when the machine is in use.
4)Wipe the remaining milk foam from the rubber tube immediately after every use.
5)Detach the rubber steaming tube cover and wash it as frequent as possible to prevent bacteria.
6) Wipe the remaining coffee from the filter arm housing before every use.
7)listen to the machine. If it makes a funny sound, you are probably doing something wrong-look at the water tank first!

Read the manual..and enjoy a great coffee.
title: Best machine for you $$!

review_content: I have tried a number of espresso machines over the years, from high end expensive models to cheap ones.  I can say, without reservation, that this is the lowest quality machine I have owned.  After having to give a cuisinart the heave-ho, my wife picked this one up so I'd have something to generate caffiene.  The exterior is brittle plastic.  The tank cap often does not make a seal, requiring a revisit to the machine with a heavy cloth to try to coax it a bit tighter without incurring 2nd degree burns.  It's cheap. It works so far (if you overlook the seal problem).  It makes espresso, or a version thereof.  For a spare, or a temporary machine to get you by, this one is fine.  It's the flimsiest machine I've ever encountered.  If you're set on Mr. Coffee products, they make a pump machine that is much more solidly built, with a removable refillable tank.  That unit lasted me 2 years of heavy use and would be a much better choice.

review_content: I put this on our wedding registry 3 years ago after reading good reviews online and seeing the value and reasonable price.  I read the instruction booklet cover to cover and like that it came with a troubleshooting section towards the back along with a recipe section for novices.  my husband and I are not baristas so this works perfect for us since we just wanted a basic espresso or latte without a hefty price.  there were a few times within the first year that I would have issues but when I would read the troubleshooting section I was able to figure it out and it worked fine afterwards.  other reviewers are correct in the fact that you can get scolded if you open the lid right after you brew.  after the first year the steamer stopped working so I just had to heat up my milk in the microwave instead but the machine still work to brew espresso.  all in all it's been a good machine but its the 3rd year now and it's starting to really give us trouble.  we will fill it full of water but it won't brew the entire water left inside.  also it has started to leave the espresso tasting more burnt then it ever has before.  it lasted us a good three years so it's worth the money but it is time to go get a new one now.

review_content: First I want to say that I didn't purchase this on Amazon, I actually got it at a store. I love coffee, espresso, and lattes. The machine stinks of bad plastic which ends up making the espresso taste the same way. It's nasty. When I went to steam the milk, nothing. I had to add more water to the machine in order to make the steam but that was only after I burned myself opening the top since there was plenty of steam in there, it just wasn't coming out. title: Bad smell, bad taste
bought_model: Color: CappuccinoStyle Name: 4-Cup Steam

review_content:
I purchased this machine at Target about 2 years ago, hoping to find a less expensive alternative to coffee shops. I was dropping almost five bucks for a cup and figured it would be a good idea to look into getting my own machine. My top requirement was low price and this fit the bill. So far, I haven't had a single problem with the unit itself. I've managed to break the carafe (more like chipped it, a big chunk), but that was my own fault. I've had the milk steamer clog up on me, but to defuse this problem, I just unscrewed the bottom piece, soaked it in boiling water, and ran steam out of it for a bit (then screwed the bottom piece back on). My only complaint isn't even about the design, but know that this machine has quite a few pieces to clean each time you use it (which I believe is normal with espresso machines). It may take a while to get the hang of the milk steamer, so don't be discouraged if you purchase one.

I'm a latte drinker and purchase Torani syrups for my home "cafe." (A local store sells the pumps too) I buy the coffee at my local health food store and use their grinder for espresso fine coffee (Organic, Fair Trade all the way. Same price as the regular.). I picked up a milk steaming mug for about $14 as well. My Raspberry Caramel soy latte comes out to under a dollar instead of five. I also don't have to drive to the coffee shop and stand in line anymore, it was worth the investment. It paid for itself in no time.

Overall, I recommend this machine. It works for me and for the price, you can't beat it. I look forward to my morning latte, it helps me get out of bed in the morning.

Tip: To clean the milk steamer, the best way I've found is to boil water on the stove, pour it into a milk pitcher, and soak the steamer wand for about 10 seconds. If the water is hot enough, it should come off with little to no effort. You can start with room temp water and steam the water, but I feel it's more effort. I do this about once a week (I wipe it every time, but it still builds up). I've tried cleaning it with a cloth and steam like I've seen coffee shop employees do it, but I always burned myself.

Tip #2: Make sure you're cleaning the machine with vinegar every 30-60 uses (soft water can go to about 60). Don't wait until there's a problem to clean it, otherwise you may get stuck with hot espresso and no working milk steamer. The only way I could get the espresso to come out was tip the machine, so I knew there was a problem. 2 cycles with vinegar and numerous water cycles later, it works again.

Important: They're not kidding when they say to release the pressure before opening the top. Really. I've had 1st degree burns on my hand to prove it... more than once (even being careful, it happens).
title: Great Product for a Great Price!
bought_model: Color: CappuccinoStyle Name: 4-Cup Steam

review_content:
I bought this at Christmas 2009 ($26), and have been delighted with the taste and service of this unit. WOW. But, there was a little trick that I learned about my espresso maker. It needs more water than the directions indicate. So all you out there who gave it one star for not working properly - throw out the directions and try this:

Fill the glass pot to 4 cups(full) of water and fill the reservoir, and than add another half a pot (2 cups) to the reservoir. After it brews out to about 3 cups it will begin to sputter (at least mine does). That's the indication that it's reached it's brewing limit, and the taste goes down from there. Now steam the milk(keeping the tip just below the milk line). There will be plenty of steam for that. Pour the "good" coffee and the milk in a mug and then just turn it back to "brew" and let it finish. The leftover coffee can be dumped and you will have a cup of Java that will beat Starbucks in taste!
title: Taste that beats Starbucks

It worked if the reservoir was placed just in the right spot but if it vibrated a little or moved it started leaking.  It is a shame this didn't work well because it is compact and seemed to make a good espresso.  But leaking is unacceptable.  I don't recommend this product.

review_content:
The unit's port containing the sensor into which the milk reservoir's container is pushed into, broke within the month with a daily routine of two cappuccinos only. Given its essential for the container to be aligned properly to turn all three lights on, my machine is now practically useless. Given I took it out of the country, warranty is also no longer applicable.

You can't brew latte and cappuccinos without pulling and pushing the container in and out and I'm shocked at the lack of durability of the machine and unit.

Even chinese machines are expected to perform better. When it worked, the coffee was fantastic though.

title: Five Stars
bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Espresso/Cappuccino Maker

review_content:
I get good results with this machine.
The grind of the coffee is all important.
Too coarse, and you'll know since the water drips through too quickly and no hard puck is left.
Too fine, and you'll know since the water drips through too slowly and makes for a bitter taste.
Perfect will produce crema.

Having gone through different ways to grind coffee I am back to my old blade Braun grinder. Keep your grinder clean to avoid bitter oils building up.

If the grind is right I do not need to tamp. Until you get that right tamping may help you.

I froth milk using a microwave and either a french press or a hand-blender. I can still make this unit froth; I take off the external plastic parts on the wand. Cleaning a frothing wand is a pain, which is why I froth with the microwave/hand-blender. No-fat milk froths fine. Easy to get whipcream like texture in 30-45 seconds using a french press or hand-blender.

This is not a machine for a large group of people. It takes several minutes to prepare an espresso.

4 cups means about 4 ounces. A cup of espresso is usually an ounce. I like this best with a full basket to produce about 2.5 ounces. In comparison to my Starbucks Barista Espresso this produces a double shot without reloading, while I have to reload the Barista to make a double shot (plus I can only put a shot glass under the Barista). With a spare basket, the Barista is for when I have groups.

Be sure to preheat the basket, holder, and the carafe. Use hot water.
Also be sure the basket is dry before you load the coffee (use a towel).

Keep in mind this is a steam machine, not a pump. If you are thinking of a pump style start doing some research. I found I'd need to spend above a $1,000 for a machine which would make a significant difference in taste and texture.

Last thought: clean-up is all important. Be sure to spray water up into the machine, use a brush, and soak the basket between uses.
title: A good steam powered espresso
bought_model: Color: CappuccinoStyle Name: 4-Cup Steam

review_content:
Heck yes! I've had this espresso machine for probably close to 3 years now, and it's still going strong! It's endured close to daily use with no failures whatsoever.

Before I bought it, I read the reviews and saw that some people have experienced leaks. I have yet to encounter one with my unit, thankfully.

As for the steamer, I've only used it a handful of times when I first got it. I wasn't very impressed, and it seemed I had to run it through two full cycles to get a cup of milk warm enough. Not to mention it's pretty loud, and a pain to clean. I've forgone the steamer and just used the microwave or stove top if I want a hot drink. For me, this isn't a big deal. I don't like frothiness so I can get the same quality drink with faster and less noisy methods.

Recently my machine has started blinking at me when I first turn it on. Usually just flicking it off and on again works, but I'm worried I may need an upgrade, soon. But, suffice to say, this is a great starter unit!
title: Worth it!
bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Automatic Dual Shot

review_content:
The second one is now kaput. The first one lasted six months. Customer Service was good, they wanted me to do a few simple things first then once I confirmed those had been done they sent a second unit. That one lasted five months.
The first one the selection controller stopped working; it simply ran for fifty seconds or was it longer, I forget. This second unit is losing pressure, gradually putting on less and less. I've seen from all the reviews that others have the same experience.Perhaps its just not possible to create a consumer device at this price point that will work for long.
When it works its nice. I liked the integrated milk reservoir.
title: Sadly cannot reccomend
bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Espresso/Cappuccino Maker

review_content:
Hi,

I was going to start the review by saying this is a great coffee maker for the money. But that would be misleading. This is just a great espresso coffee maker period.

I've had other espresso makers and a couple of them cost more than $300. The ECMP50 beat them hands down, no contest.

Do yourself a favor and read the instructions. The machine is not difficult to operate but still, read the damn instructions. If you follow the instructions you'll get perfect espresso every time you use it.

I've had mine for a little more than three years now and came back here specifically to post this review. I'm not going in depth here, I just came here to let people know it's a great machine and an excellent value.
title: I was going to start the review by saying this is a great coffee maker for the money
bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Automatic Dual Shot

review_content: So, as other reviewers have mentioned, it isnt something you can leave and go do other tasks, you kind of need to keep an eye on it, because it's pressurized, but that is what makes the coffee and the steamer so great. My 16 yr old is a little afraid of it, but I would bet that she'll warm up to it. It takes about 10 minutes to make a latte which is about what you'd spend in the drive=thru at you know where, and for less money. I had to play with it a little to figure out the steamer, you have to add extra water for the steamer to work and for 3/4 to 1/2 cup of milk, probably is a little longer than 60 seconds to get it nice and foamy. Also, I tried to skimp on the milk (calories) and that wasnt as tastey, so be sure and add at least around 3/4 cups for 2 cups of espresso. I fill up the reservior by adding the amount indicated on the steamer icon on the pitcher first, then put in enough for 2 cups. There is a trick to making froth...you have to be patient and keep swirling your cup around in a circular motion, you can hear a change in the steamer when it starts to really heat up and that's when you really need to keep it moving and keep an eye on the froth amounts. It does take a little getting used to, the steamer wand can get furious and overzelous if you have too much milk and not enough space for the bubbles/froth but worse case scenario, you have froth on your counter, and delicous froth on your hand, easy to clean, that's from having too short of a cup and too much milk. Anyways, got this on sale black friday and even if it's not a longer term solution, it's already saved us as much as I'd paid for it, so I give 4 stars. I wouldve given 5 if it had the steamer cup/pitcher included.. finding a cup that works is a little tough, but doable.
title: I love this thing for Lattes :)
bought_model: Color: CappuccinoStyle Name: 4-Cup Steam

review_content: I'm a noobie when it comes to espresso, and I was a nervous to try this machine and have it be too complicated. It is the perfect beginner machine. I'm afraid to admit that I'm not electronic savvy and I can't figure out most things, but this is soooo easy. It makes almost perfect espresso. My only complaint is how hard it vibrates and the espresso cups vibrate off the tray unless you're holding them in place. But I understand because its a very small machine that has to put out great power. I made sure to register this product In case it goes out, but after reading the reviews it doesn't seem necessary. I will update in a year.
title: Great beginner espresso machine
bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Automatic Dual Shot

review_content:
Howdy. I'll spare you the detailed review since there are so many good ones. I had some real quality control issues with mine (I'm on my FOURTH unit) but Mr. Coffee really stood behind it without question. Excellent customer service. Thus the 5 stars. They have improved this model over the last few years, and it's sailing along smoothly now!

We love it. You can't get this kind of functionality at this cost with any other brand of device (we looked). It's a part of my day I can't live without.

PRO TIP 1) If froth is your thing (it's mine) - the more milk you put in the milk reservoir, the more frothy is gets. It doesn't say that in the manual. Took me a while to figure that out. When I make a latte, i just turn the dial while it's frothing to make the perfect Latte.

PRO TIP 2) If you grind your own beans, grind it finer than you would regular coffee bean. If you buy it pre-ground (we get Starbucks bag espresso, I just like the flavor) but the Starbucks is ground too big. We re-grind it when we have the time. It makes a better brew.

Enjoy!!

review_content:
This was on my Christmas list, based on the review strength on Amazon and other sites. I needed to read a little more carefully, I'm afraid, because every complaint I'm about to make has already been made.
1) It started out not working. Turned it on, switched the knob, got zilch. Once more, nothing. But then voila!, the third try was a charm. I should have returned it, but it was Christmas day, and I was in denial about having to return it. It continued to pump out espresso --until it didn't, 3 weeks later. We called Amazon for a return as it had actually been purchased some time ago, though not given til Christmas. They were great.
2) However, the truth is even when it made espresso, it was never hot--lukewarm at best. The frother worked well though. Better than the next machine we tried which is being returned today, a De'Longhi EC155. (sigh) No froth? Where's the fun?
title: 3 weeks of warm  espresso
bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Automatic Dual Shot

review_content:
I have tried a few espresso makers around this price range. Initial review of this left me very pleased with the performance. There were many things to like about this.

1) large removable reservoir
2) hot flavorful espresso
3) heats quickly
4) top of unit conveniently holds espresso cups and tamper
5) removeable drip tray
6) accommodates larger cup than some other machines

After about 11 months, some of those things had changed.

1) took longer to heat
2) espresso produced was only warm
3) seal for the brew basket was not nearly as tight as it used to be
4) the dual blinking lights appeared

The first time I saw the dual blinking lights, I experimented with system for a bit. I cleaned it, I ran steam from the frother, let it run longer to get hotter and after a few minutes, it was working again. I did not have anymore problems for another month or two. Then the blinking lights returned, so I went through the same steps as I did last time. I spent about 30 minutes trying to get this working again. The steam would build up, but never pass water through the filter. Eventually, steam would come through the brew basket seal.

So mine lasted about 13 months. I read many reviews looking for a different espresso machines and see that most in this price range up and a bit higher all seem to have various problems. I ended up buying another one of these machines. I bought this one again expecting it to not last much more than 1 year. For the first year, while it was working, I was satisfied with the espresso it produced. What I did differently this time was I purchased a 2-year extended warranty. When this fails in a year, I can revisit the latest espresso models and see if there is a better choice at this price point.

I give it 5-stars for initial quality and 1-star for overall reliability and product quality. I feel this is a high price to pay for this machine every year to replace.

I would not purchase this espresso machine without an extended warranty.
title: Failed After One Year - Need Extended Warranty
bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Automatic Dual Shot

review_content: The coffee machine is OK but the fact that the silicon tube so easy to lose, the manufacturer has not provided a replacement one, and a replacement tube is not available currently (and according to others has not been available for several weeks), means I can use this machine only for espresso and not for any of the drinks that would use froth... Not recommended if you are in the market for a cappuccino maker!
title: ... OK but the fact that the silicon tube so easy to lose
bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Espresso/Cappuccino Maker

review_content:
I bought this recently because I realized I was spending FAAAAAR too much money on expensive espresso every day.

If you're a coffee snob (and I mean that in the nicest way possible!) perhaps this isn't the machine for you, but for someone who just likes to get a little caffeine buzz in the morning and may or may not be bored with standard coffee, this is great.

Pros: Brews quick, tastes fine, does the job.

Cons: The steamer arm is a little short and when you're steaming in a mug you (at least, I) tend to bump the cup against the side of the machine, which leads to little spills every now and again.
It also brews so quick that you have to keep an eye on it, to make sure it doesn't overflow.

But really the cons are minimal and this is exactly what I needed.
Cappuccinos for everyone!

review_content: I am taking back my stars given I am now on my second machine. The first machine the steam stopped working. My other problem quite funny in hind sight...the steam would shoot the milk resivoure out of the machine on occasion not just out but fully across the counter. I was going to keep it and continue to be there to catch the milk but the steam is no longer working on this machine as well. Good luck to all that have bought it.
title: This coffee junkie is in love!
bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Espresso/Cappuccino Maker

review_content:
Christmas Day. This was a bought as a gift for my Latte-loving wife. We pull the unit out, clean it, remove the stickers and the red plug, and follow the priming instructions exactly. The pump never engaged. I looked up a video on priming the unit to make sure we didn't miss anything. We didn't. The video explicitly states that if nothing happens then we should repeat the process until the pump engages. So we spend the next TWO HOURS following the priming steps to no avail until the machine starts to smell of electrical fire.

At this point we've repackaged the product, and have requested a full refund (not an exchange - a product like this should work the first time, EVERY time, without exception).

My wife now doesn't get to enjoy her Christmas gift. I'll never buy another Mr. Cofffee product again as long as I live.
title: Do not buy this defective product

review_content: We have 3 of these: one for each person's office & one for home. (We also have accumulated stove-top espresso makers, aeropresses, drip coffee makers, and french presses over the years). For making a strong cup of coffee, this works quite well. We don't mess with foaming milk, and we don't expect cremas. It's extremely easy and simple for strong coffee. I use 2 coffee measures (ie, 4 T) and a full carafe for one 16 oz mug. The aeropress is my second favorite (I used it for 5 years before getting these), but it's more of a hassle when the plunger stops pushing down properly.

The second time my husband was nearby and got flying glass cuts. First time it happened, we thought a fluke. We follow all the directions and use distilled water. Someone said it earlier: you get what you pay for. Guess there's no cheap way to do espresso at the house.  If my husband would let me, I'd put it in the driveway and run it over.
title: DANGEROUS
bought_model: Color: CappuccinoStyle Name: 4-Cup Steam

review_content:
I went out and bought all high quality ingredients to make the perfect cappuccino. I've had numerous espresso machines in the past so I basically knew how to use it but went through the instructions anyway just in case this one was any different. Oh, it's different alright...definitely a piece of crap.

I cleaned the machine and made my first espresso. When I tried to froth the milk, it worked for about 2 seconds and then broke instantly. Out of no where. It was definitely submerged enough so I'm not quite sure what the problem is other than being a horrible design. I tasted the espresso anyway (which was a flavor I've used in other machine and was my favorite) and it tasted horrible. Very bland and definitely not what I'm used to. This is getting returned.
title: Worst machine I've ever heard of
bought_model: Color: CappuccinoStyle Name: 4-Cup Steam

review_content:
Third update... Nothing to see here... All we have to report now is that over 7 years later, finally, oh, I should say still .............

IS KICKING BUTT AND TAKING NAMES! Mr. Coffee........ Who knew?

Second update, Dec 2012 What can I say... this ting is the proverbial Timex... takes a licking, keeps on ticking. It is chugging along, never missing a beat two years into owning it. If it died tomorrow... it would be an easy decision, I can't afford a $400 to $700 machine like I dream of... being all automatic and washing my car too so without hesitation or even "re-shopping/researching" I would just go buy it again. My best friend gave it a real nice compliment the other day... we went camping in the 5th wheel a while back so we took it along (what would "camping" be without espresso in the morning right?) and since then he has told me he cannot get his expensive one to produce as good tasting of espresso... using the exact same ingredients. I use this almost every day... it is a winner, don't let the name fool you. BTW, the goof balls that say it is too hard to empty are, well, how to say this... STUPID. It comes with a black thumb lever on the handle of the grounds holder... you push it with your thumb when "knocking out" the grounds like ANY other style or brand. Ironically... it is many brands that do not include this which makes it even easier than the rest. If the knuckle heads that complained would RTFM first they would have enjoyed it and given it a better rating... whatever :-)

July 2011: Was doing some other Amazon shopping... reading reviews like crazy... got done shopping and made a cup of espresso and figured I oughta update my review here since I use them so much. The update is, see below. This thing still rocks and it makes at LEAST one cup a day (takes a sip) and I would buy it again in a heartbeat.

Nov 2010: Like so many other reviews... this ain't my first Espresso machine rodeo. When my last one, a cheapie, had died I started my usual online review endeavor (my wife thinks I am an excellent researcher/buyer... I think I might be obsessed) and looking at all the reviews I could find on machines under $200.00 Not to my surprise there was plenty to look at.

A little background on me. I am a lifelong coffee snob/junkie (50 years old started with espresso at 19) and a true fan of Peets coffee. They have the best beans, coffee (of all types) and service in my not so humble opinion.

I looked long and hard at many reviews and one thing that really bothered me was the poor reviews and reliability of so many of the $100 to $200 machines... almost seems like they are real cheap versions of the $1000.00 stuff and suffering from being to poorly built to meet the price range. Just my theory but the reviews were all awful. I was pretty bummed out about this because it was not looking good for finding what I was looking for and the bottom line to that was an easy, fast, reliable and especially great quality shot of espresso. Maybe I was asking too much I started thinking. I have no idea why I started looking in the lower prices... I think it was because I had looked at everything at the top of my price range so I had no other direction to go because I was set on my price limit. Anyway... I came across the Mr. Coffee machine and especially this review

[...] by K. Krueger (THANKS!!!)

So with great doubt about a brand that I thought epitomizes crap coffee... you know... the big tin cans full of the stuff they make at the office? Well I started reading all of the reviews and was pretty surprised at what I was reading... almost all of them glowing, there are a few that are not but there always is, the main theme was clear, almost everyone was happy with it. It is a pump and not steam driven, it has a large tank so refilling the water is rare (love it!) and...

IT MAKES GREAT ESPRESSO?

It is true, I went to Target (yuk, not normally ever seen there) since I could have it right then and there and have a local place to return if it was bogus, which I thought there would be a chance of.

Brass tacks

Heats up super fast to make coffee, you turn it on and it will be ready in about half the time it takes you to grind the beans. The cup warmer will not be warming the cups in this time... that takes longer and if you want that, just turn it on sooner.

As mentioned, the tank is large, easy to remove and fill and to reinstall in seconds.

The steamer works fantastic... lot of high pressure steam... it foams FAST. Nice that it swings out to the front for use (which I hardly do, I like mine straight) and then swings back out of the way... I forget it is there sometimes.

The cup/coffee basket is easy to clean, fill, remove, insert... nothing to it, sweet and simple. There is one beef I have with it, it is not as large as some espresso makers have so you will not be making a true quad shot with this... you could keep pumping until you had that quantity of coffee but you would be over using the bean. If I want a quad, I have to make two batches, which is so fast and easy, frankly it is rarely an issue.

The position of the basket is high so almost all of my traditional height coffee cups can be used... not tall coffee cups but definitely a restaurant size cup.
The cup warmer tray area is nice and works nicely with (estimating/guessing) 5 - 10 minutes of warm up but is not something I care about or use... I keep my coffee scoop and a few demitasse cups there.

The coffee... ah yes, the actual product, is fantastic. You have to personally observe the process and switch the pump off when it has produced enough espresso... I personally wait until the coffee coming out turns an approximate "blonde" and then switch off. Sometimes I will switch off a little sooner depending on the strength I want. There is no "automatic" cycle... you have to watch it but it is fast and simple IMO. BTW, fast is definitely the key work here... this makes it fast and yummy. I am always rewarded with a perfect creamy cup of espresso that personally I would compare to the coffee I have tasted ANYWHERE.

Drain tray is easy to remove and clean

One thing I recommend is, FOR ANY ESPRESSO/COFFEE MAKER is a high quality burr grinder that gives you a consistent and proper grind. I have mine (can't remember the brand but about a $100.00 model) set to "espresso" and it is indeed ground "fine." When I pack the basket I pack it very firmly by hand with the supplied scoop/packing tool and I have NEVER had ANY plugging issues.

I saved the box in case of return... hah; I love that box because now I take it on short travel trips and make espresso in my room... no restaurant coffee for me, YEAH!

Not sure what I am missing here but the bottom line is (and I am so very pleasantly surprised) this Mr. Coffee espresso machine ROCKS. If it died today, I would go buy another today. I have been using it for about five months now... I have at LEAST one double shot a day then my wife has some too now and then. It has been flawless, simple and VERY effective. I still don't think the name is impressive but I have been gratefully humbled by the awesome price, quality and effectiveness of this wonderfully affordable machine.

(Gulp) Bravo, Mr. Coffee... I am impressed.

PS. if I missed anything, or if you have a question, I will be happy to help. Not sure if I get automatic replies to this but if so I will be happy to help. I don't do reviews very often but I should do more considering how much help they are to me. Thanks Amazon for having this venue... normally would have bought it from you as I do many other items... but just had to try it that day and the price was the same.

Tech Support walked me through all of the things the manual has you do and then informed me sorry that is all the manual tells me to have you try??????? you should take it back to the store and trade it in. Very calmly told the lady that Sorry but I had gotten the last one off the shelf and the Manager isnt going to be getting anymore in because they did not sell well so if I have to take it Back I am not getting another one and I will no longer be using Mr Coffee brand any long. she put me on hold and informed me another would be shipped to me in about 8 days so we shall see what happens with that one when it gets here but not holding my breath.

While it does what it says, make a decent espresso, the whole unit has a "cheap build" quality feel to it. Some of the edges are already coming loose. title: i was super excited since it had great reviews on Amazon
bought_model: Color: CappuccinoStyle Name: 4-Cup Steam

review_content:
We love our machine for the value it delivers. We have been 100% pleased with the coffee, which we make from a combination of French or Italian roast from Trader Joe's and Verona or Sumatra from Starbucks. We use a tabasco sauce bottle for a tamper (fits pretty darn close). We've been cranking out good coffee every day for months without any problem.

Of course, the coffee isn't in the same league as what our son produces with his $500 machine, but then again, we paid only $25. And, as long as we don't conduct a head-to-head comparison, we're happy campers with our home brew.

The frother is a different story. As many folks have reported, it's a waste: steam nozzle way too short and almost no steam left over in the water reservoir after making the coffee.

As another person mentioned, the knob on the water reservoir can be a severe challenge to those without strong fingers and hands.

All in all, I wouldn't hesitate to get this baby again because it does the trick for morning brew.
title: Great for coffee, bad for froth
bought_model: Color: CappuccinoStyle Name: 4-Cup Steam

review_content:
I love this little espresso machine. For what it's worth, it's awesome. It brews delicious, foamy espresso really easily, and the milk frothing wand creates really nice, thick foam.

I love espresso drinks, but had never tried to make one on my own before -- but I got this machine as a gift for Christmas, and I had it out of the box and brewing espresso in about 20 minutes! The instructions are really clear and detailed, so beginners like myself can pick up on it pretty quickly. I started making really tasty cappuccinos right away.

The only reason I'm not giving this thing 5 stars is that the milk frother -- though it creates really nice foam -- does not heat up the milk very well. I usually end up with a lot of foam, but lukewarm milk. I prime the steamer beforehand, and also have a metal frothing pitcher for this purpose, but still can't quite heat up the milk enough. Whether or not it is my technique, or the machine, I guess I can't say for sure.

As for the other reviewers who said their machine leaked -- I haven't experienced that. But if you don't empty out the drip tray on the bottom, it will fill up with water really quickly from the steam, and I could see how that might overflow, so be careful with it.

----------- UPDATE! ---------------

After owning this for about 6 months, I'm upgrading my rating from 4 stars to 5 stars! This thing still works beautifully, and my roommate and I both use it every day. If you're on the edge about buying this -- do it. Seriously.

I was able to overcome the problem I mentioned previously where the temperature of the milk was too cold -- I basically just have to completely submerge the milk frother for quite some time (30-60 seconds?), to heat up the milk, before bringing the tip of the frother back to the surface of the milk, to create the foam.

Since I received this espresso machine, I've developed a taste for drinking strait espresso. Regular coffee is for pansies.

I also frequently make iced lattes with different syrup flavors, and I hate going to coffee shops -- my own homemade espresso drinks are so much better because I can make them however I want, and they are obviously cheaper.

Again, it does NOT leak, unless you never empty the drain tray. Make sure you empty the tray after every use, and rinse it out so that it doesn't get any gross build-up. Also, run the machine with just water every once and a while, to clean it out a bit. If you're using the milk frother, clean it immediately after every use, which will also prevent clogs. As long as you properly take care of this machine, it will reward you time and time again! :-)

(This is a lot of extra attention to be paying to something that is new) Every time I have cleaned it the kitchen, the water that ran through it and the cups smell TOXIC. I've had friends walk in and ask what the awful smell was.
I heard from Mr. Coffee and they told me to de lime it, which means fill it with white vinegar, let it soak overnight. REALLY? I've invested way too much time with this piece of rubbish already. I have had 3 other steam espresso makers, NONE had these issues. I use the correct coffee grind. There is nothing wrong with the water I use. Do NOT purchase this product. Mine is now in the garage ready to be thrown out with the next trash collection. It's not worth the cost of sending it back.
