title: Broke after just a few uses
bought_model: Color: CappuccinoStyle Name: 4-Cup Steam

review_content:
I‚Äôve had this espresso maker for about a week. It makes decent espresso, but the steamer is so ineffective that I‚Äôve had to order a separate electric milk frother from a different company. The steaming arm often shuts off for no reason and makes a loud thumping noise, sprays out water, and is way too short to steam and froth milk evenly. I have a food thermometer to measure the temperature of the milk and many times the milk about the bottom of my frothing pitcher was 150 degrees and the foam on top was barely 80 degrees.

Additionally, the water tank leaks out of the bottom with every use and the brewing basket must be twisted very hard in order to lock, so much so that I‚Äôm afraid it‚Äôll snap.
title: Quality matches price
bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Automatic Dual Shot

review_content:
After reading all the customer reviews on Amazon, I was a bit scared to even take this out of the box. Folks were using candy thermometers to check the water temp, using metal tampers to apply 30 lbs of pressure to the coffee grinds, insisting the beans must be ground at home, priming the unit a half dozen times before using it! I thought I might need degrees in chemistry and physics to make a cup of coffee.

Instead, I took it out of the box, followed the manufacturer's simple priming instructions, and gave it a shot. I had just bought a pound each of good coffee ground for use in my drip pot before it broke, and couldn't just throw them out. So I bought some Starbucks espresso blend (ground) and mixed them all together. I used the tamper that was provided (plastic), and started trying out the various settings.

The first cup was okay, though not quite strong enough for my taste. (This might be where doing that additional priming pre-use comes in.) The second cup was amazing. It is so easy to use. Turn it on, wait for it to warm up, and press a button. Play around with the different settings to get the frothiness to your taste, as well as the coffee:milk ratio. I go for more froth to start, because I can always add another shot of espresso in less than a minute. Cleaning is just as easy -- there's a setting to clean out the milk tube automatically.

I've had the machine for less than a week, so I can't comment on its durability. But it sure is fun to make cappuccino now!

My one complaint is that when I ordered it the stainless model wasn't available, and there was a $50 price differential between the white and the red. I went with the white to save money, and now the stainless is back at a lower price, and the price on the red dropped substantially.
title: Easy, fun -- and delicious
bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Espresso/Cappuccino Maker

review_content:
I realize that for the purists out there they would never consider Mr Coffee a legitimate manufacturer of a good espresso machine. I too am a big espresso nut and have to say after owning this machine for a year that I am pleased with the results. I use it in my office since there are no espresso places nearby. I also didn't want to spend much money on machine for the office either. So I honestly knew exactly what I was after when I purchased this machine - low expectations - but wanting a daily espresso fix outside of home.

Yes it is a noisy operation - you have to do the steam prep, and you have to monitor it while it pours. It's not obnoxious loud but it's loud. Despite the noise and the button sequencing dance you have to do between steam and pour, the result is a nice pull. The crema is there and I don't think compared to the other machines I have owned (Breville, Gaga, Nespresso, De Longhi) the taste is miles and miles away from these higher end machines. Of course if you are an aficionado you will taste a difference - I do - but again if you can find the right fit and use for this machine it's pretty good.

Bottom line I am satisfied with the output and I recommend it. As I mentioned - I have used it every day, sometimes several times a day, for over a year and no problems whatsoever. I can't say that for the expensive machines I have owned that experienced pump problems after six months.
title: Decent little espresso machine
bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Automatic Dual Shot

review_content: This is a great little espresso maker except for the fact that the INSTRUCTIONS ARE WRONG RE THE AMOUNT OF WATER TO USE FOR 1 CUP OF CAPPUCCINO under How To Make Cappuccino. It's astounding that no one seems to have caught this and called Mr. Coffee Customer Service as I just now did (though a woman giving a demo of the machine on YouTube states that the instructions for the amount of water to use for 1 cup are CLEARLY WRONG without having notified Customer Service about it, but then proceeds to only add an oz. of water, thinking the 2 Cup mark is 2 oz. when it's actually 4 oz., and wonder why there's not enough steam to froth the milk). Customer Service amazingly said that after years of using the same wrong instructions that I'm the first person who ever contacted them about it (or did others call and they ignored it?) and essentially agreed that I was right and would document all that I said (including the YouTube woman who also said the amount of water was wrong). The "2 oz." for 1 cup of cappuccino should be 6 oz. to brew the espresso, turn it OFF after it reaches the 2 Cup line in the carafe which is about 4 oz., put the Frothing Aid in a little milk pitcher and then turn the control knob to STEAM with 2 oz. of water left to froth/steam the milk and VOILA, cappuccino (or latte). When I saw the instructions said 2 oz. of water for 1 cup and about 10 oz. for 2 cups (which is about what it is to "Fill to top of metal band of glass carafe") I immediately saw there was a problem with the 1 cup directions. How unbelievable that this has gone on for years with incorrect instructions! I see that a number of people on various sites have said the milk steamer doesn't work on their espresso maker and they would return it, with people telling them it probably didn't work because there wasn't any water left in the reservoir but almost no one seems to have caught the reason why there's no water left which is because the instructions are wrong and say to use much too little water (2 oz. when it should be about 6 oz.). We'll see how long it takes for the instruction booklet to be corrected, if ever, since after all, it does make great espresso and cappuccino or latte, especially for such an inexpensive machine.
title: This is a great little espresso maker except for the fact that the ...
bought_model: Color: CappuccinoStyle Name: 4-Cup Steam

review_content:
I received this machine this past February as a birthday gift from my husband. I use it 3-4 times a week. It worked well for the first month or so.
PROS:
- The stainless steel pieces didn't break. (yay?)
- The water tank doesn't leak
- The knob still turns
CONS:
- EVERYTHING ELSE BROKE. Within three months I'd replaced the carafe, the handle on the grounds holder broke (I was not rough with it) and the plastic sleeve over the frother broke. Neither of those had replacement parts available, and I'm not a latte/cappuccino person anyway (I just spike my coffee with extra espresso), but it I was, I'd be livid.
- This machine is loud. (Not that I want to listen to my kids bicker at 7am, but this noise isn't much better.)
- Cheap and flimsy. Seriously. The tray underneath the carafe is starting to go, and I have no hope of this machine lasting until my next birthday.
CONCLUSION:
- This machine is $35. You get what you pay for. If you just need to spike your coffee with an extra shot of espresso, this machine will do that. It won't be pretty, but it will function. If you need your foam or enjoy fancy stuff, save up and get a better machine.
- Once this machine goes (probably before Christmas, honestly), I will not be getting another one. Nor would I recommend it to anyone else.
title: Would Not Recommend
bought_model: Color: CappuccinoStyle Name: 4-Cup Steam

review_content: The ‚ÄúMr. Coffee‚Äù Espresso, Latte and Cappuccino Maker is a mid priced, starter machine for your coffee enjoyment; it contains all the accouterments for becoming a home barista. It comes with a detachable transparent water reservoir, a stainless steel frothing pitcher, a single shot and a double shot steel filters, a small white china cup for your espresso, a measuring spoon, frothing wand (with removable cover), and a easy to operate brew machine which will look fine in your kitchen. It comes with a one (1) year limited warranty and an informative and easy to understand English/Spanish manual with recipes.  The machine and its operation takes some time to finesse the making of the best espresso; one hint: tamp/press down hard on the coffee grinds when filling your filters.
title: a fine,  mid priced, starter machine for your coffee enjoyment !
bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Caf√© Steam

review_content:
You have to consider the price of this machine (I paid $29.99) and how much it saves you from running out to the coffee shops for your coffee fix. This little machine is great. As sensible reviews note, you have to play with the amount of water and the kind of coffee (and grind) for you to get it how you like it. Curiously enough, the machine does not know how you like it right out of the box. Most importantly, you have to understand you get what you pay for. They make professional-grade espresso machines that have more features and equipment, but they cost a professional-grade price. I will share some things that I learned:

I use an organic dark French roast I got at the local big warehouse store (and had a $1.50 hot dog and pop on my way out). I used their grinder on the way out. I set it to 4 (out of 10 with 10 being most coarse) and it has worked fine.

I generally use the recommended settings--water level at 2 = coffee level at 2, water level at 4 = coffee level at 4.

Yes, you should tamp the coffee. Yes, you 'could' use the back of the rounded scoop. Hilariously, I use the bottom of an unused K-cup (mine is a vanilla caramel that nobody wanted to drink, but you could use any flavor, I suppose).

If I want to steam, I PUT IN A LITTLE EXTRA WATER. You need water to make steam (#science). If you brew your espresso, you won't have much water left over for the steamer. Therefore, I steam my milk (when I decide to add this perk) BEFORE brewing the coffee. After adding the water (and setting the coffee), turn the knob to steam and then wait. After you steam to your caffeine-addicted heart's content, set the machine to brew and the coffee will brew immediately as the water is already hot. When I'm in a hurry in the morning, I'll just throw a mug with milk into the microwave. Still tastes good.

When you are done, you need to turn the machine back over to steam to release built-up pressure, which makes taking the water lid off easier. You'll find that hours later, there is still pressure in the machine. If you do it immediately after, put a mug under the steamer because some will come out.

I use this once or twice a day, and it is great. Dollar for dollar, you aren't going to find anything better. Just be realistic about what you are getting. You want a frothing pitcher and a tamper? You can find machines that do that, but they cost more. Some people look for everything to complain about. Would you buy a Ford Focus and then complain about it's lack of towing power? I didn't think so. You won't regret this little wonder.
title: You get what you pay for, and this is great!
bought_model: Color: CappuccinoStyle Name: 4-Cup Steam

review_content:
I love saving a lot of money making my unsweetened almond milk latte! Iced or hot! Or cappuccino! Or add an extra shot or 2 of expresso! Or just plain espresso!

Leave it to Mr. Coffee to make it easy to do!

Make sure you follow instructions before using!

Comes with:
It's own (almond or whatever milk) container that's kept in fridge till ready to make coffee, then pop it in place.

It's own auto foamer built in. My lattes look just like the photo!

It's own metal coffee filters to make 1 or 2 cups. (NO PLASTIC)

It's own box to elevate a small espresso cup.

It's own cleaning system built in & just push button to flush hot water/vinegar through.

I love it! Mr. Coffee is less expensive than other brands & easier to operate. (I tried Ninja at a friend's, can't compare!)

It's so simple to operate!

The best lattes, cappuccinos, espressos, hot chocolates & teas!
title: Mr. Coffee does it again!
bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Espresso/Cappuccino Maker

review_content: I am a coffeeholic! And I especially love expensive coffee that comes from Starbucks or other cafes. My favorite type of coffee is a hot latte with a great deal of milk froth and honey. I asked my husband to purchase this for a Christmas gift. I believe he paid around 140.00 for the black stainless steel one. It was initially a little challenging to figure out how to use. But 3 months later, it's so simple and now I can make my own lattes at home! Honestly, my lattes and cappuccinos taste better than most cafes. I use a dark roast coffee for the espresso maker and whole milk in the froth section. You have a choice of making a single or double shot. I typically make a double with heavy froth. For this, you need a very large coffee cup. You also have the options to make espresso independently,  A latte, or a cappuccino.  I also have a standard coffee maker for mornings when I want a cup of basic coffee. It's easy to clean..and actually has a self clean steam option. Love it!
title: A Christmas Gift! I absolutely love it
bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Espresso/Cappuccino Maker

review_content: I have owned the last three iterations of this machine (I only get new ones because we are military and move often...just not worth packing up, etc...). I have loved them all. I used to work at Gloria Jean's Coffee as a young adult, and learned much about coffee making then. Yes, this machine is super cheap, but it works really well. I can't complain, I've had this one for about half a year, and it's still going strong with several times daily use. I just follow the instructions as far as tamping (not too hard for this model), I don't use the rubber thing for frothing because I know how to froth without it. That rubber thing sure makes frothing foolproof though! If you'd like to get into espresso, cappuccino, latte, and mocha making...and don't want to invest too much, start here...end here. It's great! I've included a few pics of some of the drinks I've made with it. Yes, "coffee snobs" need not apply. (:
title: Love this little guy!
bought_model: Color: CappuccinoStyle Name: 4-Cup Steam

review_content:
I bought this machine three times: in 2011, 2012, and January 2016. The first two were exactly what we needed: simple, functional, compact, without a pump, and inexpensive. Similar to the trusty old Krups Espresso Minis, which I used in the 1990s and 2000s, but which got discontinued and replaced with needlessly complicated and overpriced models. Unfortunately, the third Mr Espresso had the nauseating plasticky smell coming from the lid, that many others have written about here. No matter how many times I washed and soaked it, or how long I aired it, the smell wouldn't go away and would seep into the coffee, which would obviously ruin the experience altogether - not to mention that it can't possibly be healthy! I ended up putting the new lid away and reusing the one from the previous machine, which solved the problem for a while. The other week my wife and I were cleaning our storage and found the lid from the most recent machine: it still smelled as strong and unpleasant, almost two years later! We're now on the market for a new machine, so I thought I'd check if this issue had been resolved, but judging from several recent reviews, it has not, which is unfortunate.

I'm giving an extra star for their good customer service: my wife accidentally threw away the metal tip at the end of the steam wand (I had taken it off for cleaning), and they mailed us a replacement for free.
title: Can't believe they still haven't resolved the horrid smell issue
bought_model: Color: CappuccinoStyle Name: 4-Cup Steam

review_content: Unit smells very strong like chlorinated plastic...hasn't gone away after running water through it 7 times.  Unusable
title: One Star
bought_model: Color: CappuccinoStyle Name: 4-Cup Steam

review_content:
I bought one of these at a local superstore. My first copy was poorly built and had a catastrophic failure within two weeks by blowing out an internal hose. Minus one star for poor quality control. If your machine doesn't vent steam out the drip tray after steaming, you will probably experience an unhappy surprise soon.

My experiences with the second copy have been excellent. Give it good coffee and it will give you excellent espresso with delicious flavor and a nice head of crema. I've had wonderful results with Caribou Coffee espresso ground at the store and Lavazza Caffe Espresso Ground Coffee, 8-Ounce Cans (Pack of 4) pre-ground. The improvement in richness and flavor from my old steam machines was like night and day, showing through nicely even in a cafe mocha. The machine is also less fiddly than the steam machines I've owned and not hard to use at all.

My complaints about this machine are all pretty minor. The machine will sometimes leak under the drip tray. This usually means there is some foreign object like a coffee ground preventing the drip tray from seating precisely in the purge port and is easily enough remedied or cleaned up. The mode buttons are not particularly sensitive to quick presses and need to be pressed a bit longer than expected. The steam function will automatically stop after a few minutes, just long enough to get 16 oz. of milk hot. I then have to act fast to keep milk from backwashing into the steam tube and causing more cleaning effort.

Bottom line: It's no Saeco Via Venezia, but it's close. (I haven't tried yet but it might even be compatible with Saeco parts, for those looking to upgrade or replace the pressurized portafilter.) If you have $100 to invest in an espresso machine, this machine is good, solid value for money.
title: Solid value, but save that receipt
bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Automatic Dual Shot

review_content:
For the price, this machine is hard to beat. I've been using it for over a year and a half now and I'm honestly ready for an upgrade.

As far as semi-auto espresso machines go, it's deserves a solid 3 stars. Why? Frothing wand is one of my biggest complaints. It isn't long, sits under the machine and really makes for a cumbersome frothing experience. The espresso that comes out of this machine isn't heated properly and seems to be a bit watery. Large reservoir, which I love. Sturdy construction considering it's made out of a cheap material.

If you're on a budget you should consider this machine until you can make an investment on a better one.
title: For the price....
bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Automatic Dual Shot

review_content: Took receipt of the machine on Monday. Primed it, and followed the excellent posting of using vinegar to get temperature past 150F. Worked wonderfully... for a day. Tuesday, turned on the machine. The three control panel lights flashed, and flashed, and flashed. They flashed continuously for about 5 minutes. Turned the machine off, then back on. The flashing lights were joined by a clicking sound. Tried turning the machine on and off a few times, waiting in between. Still flashing and still clicking. Decided to push a few buttons, and the machine began working! Excitement was short lived - the water that came out was only 150F. And the lights continued flashing and the clicking went on. Farewell Cafe Barista!

review_content:
I had this coffee maker for under 1 year and it never really made great coffee. it was just about okay. this afternoon, however, to our total shock, the coffee maker just burst in the middle of the brewing process. we clean the coffee maker after each use and it was very well maintained so the fact that it burst was a total shock for us. to be more precise, the glass carafe was broken to pieces and scattered all over my living room and kitchen. we ended up dumping the whole thing for the fear of it injuring family members in case we ever tried using it again. like i said, this coffee maker isn't bad - it makes okay coffee, but i recommend that you buy something else coz this is definitely a safety hazard in your kitchen.
I believe the coffee maker creates excess pressure for medium to fine ground coffee. Most of the famous brands like Peet's of Illy has grounds that are tending towards fine. So having a machine that is only safe for coarse ground makes you want to compromise on the quality of coffee.
title: Safety Hazards
bought_model: Color: CappuccinoStyle Name: 4-Cup Steam

review_content:
Purchased this maker at Walmart for about $30 about six months ago. It takes a few tries to learn how much water you'll need to froth your milk after you brew enough for your latte, but the morning routine now is fun, the coffee smells great too. Tell you Starbucks ain't that good anymore. One thing is that if you're looking for espresso only, the brewed coffee isn't very hot: drip flow into cold glassware. I learned to enjoy a great latte:
- Using a good ground gourmet blend, I measure about half the marked amount for one cup (too strong otherwise).
- Press the coffee ground down, otherwise the steam will make a bit of a mess over the cup. I use a simple flat bottom measuring spoon for this.
- Pour two cups of water from the glass pot into the boiler, seal the lid shut
- Brew about one cup, turn off
- Fill frothing pitcher halfway up (pitcher not included, purchased separately)
- Froth milk to top of pitcher
- Pour coffee and milk on cup

Plusses
Can't beat coffee quality for this price, steamer wand, simple & compact, fun!

Could be better
Frothed milk isn't thick enough for art, no quick pressure purge valve (takes a minute or two sometimes), maker doesn't heat glass pot, so it's difficult to make hot espresso.

Overall wonderful value!
title: Works great!

review_content:
Just bought this at the local grocery store as I'm an espresso fanatic and would love to be able to pull a shot whenever I want at home. I knew it was cheap but it was the only one they had and I figured it doesn't take much to pull a shot of espresso.

This isn't an espresso machine, this is a miniature drip coffee machine made to look more complicated. I've never seen shots of espresso pulled the way this machine pulls them. A shot of espresso should steadily pour, making three layers in the shot. This machine brews a cup of coffee, but periodically stops to sput out a random foam meant to be the crema apparently. In a normal shot the crema appears naturally.

The steam wand does not create the ideal fine foam you want to see in a latte/cappuccino. It has holes at the top of the wand meant to create the foam but it just bubbles it making the foam large and frothy. Which is exactly what you want to avoid. It is very weak also, I followed the instructions the first time I used it and I was left with a glass of cold milk. Also the wand doesn't move which makes it very hard to steam the milk.

Overall, if you want a mini coffee machine that takes twice the work to brew in, worth every penny. If you want a machine that actually pulls those wonderful, caramelly shots you love, $500 is worth it sadly.

review_content: Received as a gift about a year and a half ago, and I've used it about once or twice a week on average.  I recently noticed that the tip of the milk steamer was corroded. review_content:
Bought this as a gift for a family member locally (not from Amazon). While doing the initial cleaning and setup per instructions, we noticed the reservoir was leaking all over the counter. I thought perhaps I didn't seat the reservoir properly, so refilled (yeah, only partially this time :-) ) and after a few minutes, same thing...leaking profusely.

My theory was that the gasket in the base unit did not form a tight enough seal around the reservoir's nozzle. So as an experiment I wrapped a few layers of electrical tape tightly around the nozzle to essentially make it thicker in diameter to create a tighter seal. And it worked !

I left it that way for about 30 minutes without a leak, confirming my theory that either the gasket is too wide or the nozzle too narrow. However, after about 45 minutes I could see water starting to seep out from the bottom, and notice wet tape was starting to unravel.

I did also notice that the nozzle itself on the bottom of the reservoir is tapered ever so slightly, but probably just enough to undermine the gasket's seal. Since I just got this, I'll exchange it once just to see if perhaps the unit I got was defective. But more than likely I'll keep shopping for a different unit. After all, for the price I paid, I shouldn't have to engineer a solution on a brand-new unit.

review_content:
I'm giving it two stars rather than one because WHEN it worked, it was GREAT.

I first bought one of these about 10 years ago. It worked for SIX YEARS with no problems. Amazing coffee every time.

When it finally died, I bought another one. It was rubbish. I think I got two months out of it. It leaked all over the place. I tossed it and bought another one because I thought it may have just been a fluke. That one didn't work properly either.

After a couple of tries with more expensive machines, I thought I may as well give this one another go. I bought the one I have now about 8 months ago. It's been great....until tonight.

Tonight I was very nearly injured using this machine. It randomly overheated and exploded as I was removing he brew handle with the coffee grounds in it. The grounds basket went flying across the room! I was so lucky it didn't hit me in the stomach. If I had just been a couple of inches to the left, it would have nailed me. The explosion was so bad that it even expelled an interior rubber ring that fits on the inside of the area where the brew basket makes contact. It was rather scary.

I think I am done with these machines now. None of them seem to work properly.
title: Exploded as I was using it.
bought_model: Color: CappuccinoStyle Name: 4-Cup Steam

review_content:
This little machine is awesome! And all these reviews complaining about the milk frother breaking & not working anymore, it's NOT the milk frother itself that is breaking. I noticed 1 day after hand washing my milk reservoir top, where the round tubular connector piece slides straight into the frother port coming from the actual machine itself. There,+ on the black top part of the reservoir, on the outside, in the back right corner (if ur looking at it from the front) there is a little hole coming out of the back & if u look inside that little hole, there is a very tiny little black plastic looking screw thats very fragile.. One time, while I was cleaning the milk residue out of that little hole, I realized that a tiny little black plastic piece had broken off while i was cleaning it. And i couldn't fix it or glue it back so I tried to go ahead & run my frother & it wouldn't do anything but spit very little, plain liquid out that had zero froth. Turns out, that little insignificant screw was VERY IMPORTANT! Its the part that actually froths the milk! Without it, the entire milk frother was totally useless.. After that, I figured I had just ruined a $200 machine that I had less than 3wks & was fixing to toss it out when I realized that I could just buy a new entire frother assembly or even just the top part itself for around $6. They were having a sale on all their extra parts for my barista, so I just went ahead & bought all new back up parts just in case I ever needed them.. I put the new milk reservoir into my machine, and it works like brand new!

So I wanted to let everyone know that you don't have to settle on just using your expresso side of your machine & do without your frother.. Because, with this piece being so tiny, I guarantee that if you had actually lost it, you would most likely not have a clue that you did. And every review I've read stating that their frother broke on them, sounds identical to what happened to mine. Its so simple to FIX!

But, other than t
title: This little machine is awesome! And all these reviews complaining about the milk ...
bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Espresso/Cappuccino Maker

review_content:
I loved this, and used it every day for over a month.

However, it uses a proprietary portafilter that's hollow plastic, glued, and breaks after a month or so of use.

The manufacturer states they no longer sell it online, and that you must call their number to order a new one (with steep shipping cost), but when you call, they say they're no longer selling these on the phone, you'll have to check online to see when they become available.

Save yourself the money, go with another company that doesn't use proprietary portafilters, or at least has replacements available.
title: Portafilter Breaks Easily
bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Espresso/Cappuccino Maker

review_content: We received this in June of 2010 as a bridal shower gift. While my husband and I enjoy coffee and cappuccino, we had never owned an espresso maker before. Without reading the directions, it took me a few times to understand how the handle locked the cup of espresso grounds in place, but my hubby quickly figured it out for me. I love, love, love that this machine also steams milk! Something worth noting is that you have to have a good amount of water in the reservoir tank or the steamer will not work appropriately. I did not know this at first, but it only makes sense. Also, you need to turn the machine on, select your mode (brew or steam) and then wait for the light to turn solid red before you can turn the knob to start either process. After steaming or brewing our machine makes a little "decompressing noise" but I feel that is perfectly normal. Another thing to note though is that you need to keep the overflow tray attached at the bottom because the machine is eliminating water when it decompresses and this is where it goes. Overall we are extremely happy with this machine and we would recommend it to anyone. I love the design, the look and the overall quality of the machine. One more thing - be sure to use the "wrench" that is built into the coffee scooper to take off the bolt at the end of the steamer tube so that you can properly clean it out. This will keep things running smoothly and it only takes a couple of minutes to do. Just be forewarned that the bolt will be hot!
title: Great home espresso maker!
bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Automatic Dual Shot

review_content: If I could give this less than one star, I would. Let me start of by saying, I was a barista for a few years and know how to pull a good shot, steam milk with good foam, etc etc. Since I have since moved on with my career and am no longer a barista I decided getting a home espresso machine would be great to satisfy my craving for delicious espresso drinks without spending $6 at a coffee shop. I was very impressed with my first few drinks, even though the plastic feel of the entire machine bothered me. This is a very straight-forward machine and perfect for beginners. The glass carafe has line guides to show you where to fill the water to and steaming milk and pulling shots is pretty simple. Keep in mind you will need to tamp the espresso so without a tamp, you will have to buy one. I used my stainless steel coffee scoop and while annoyed, it did get the job done if you didn't get a tamper right away. Anyways, my excitement quickly turned to frustration. The machine stopped pulling shots and instead began to sputter water and would stop when there was still water in the chamber. I did everything I knew how to do, asked a friend who has the same machine and called Mr Coffee. In fact after a few days of trying to fix it, the machine stopped pulling shots completely and would expel bubbles from the portafilter. I came to the conclusion that it was a combination of me making multiple drinks a day (although a drink for myself and my husband shouldn't be too much to ask for from a machine, even at this price point) and the cheap build quality. If you are a college student or single or anything of the sort and just want to be able to make a drink on occasion, I suppose you could get away with purchasing this machine. I ended up returning the machine and getting a Saeco pump driven Via Venezia espresso machine, while much more pricy at $300-400 (depending on where you buy it) it makes 2-3 drinks a day without hesitation and is a wonderful little work horse.
title: Only lasted a week!
bought_model: Color: CappuccinoStyle Name: 4-Cup Steam

After checking many reviews, I realized my steam espresso maker was the reason my espresso was disappointing, and that the Mr Coffee model appeared to be a mighty good deal. The user reviews steered me right, it's excellent, easy to use, quick, and makes excellent espresso, for nowhere near the money I was afraid it would cost to have an espresso machine. It's not super-automated like the expensive ones, but who needs that when 2 minutes of slightly manual activity can give you a double shot of excellent espresso?
I cannot review the milk steamer; I don't like milk and use this only for the espresso.

review_content: I'm a coffeeaholic! Seriously, I have an addiction! I love this machine and several of my friends use and love it as well. The only problem is cleaning it. As most reviews state the machine has issues frothing milk after a while. Regular cleaning as mentioned in the manual are necessary, but every few wks you should unscrew the top of the milk frother, take it completely apart, and soak it in vinegar. The steamed milk creates a slime and clogs the frother. Very similar to sippy cups it can mold and make you sick. I mean it's milk of course it's going to get gross sitting around. I've had mine for over a year and I love it so much I pack it for any vacation we take.

My first cup of espresso lacked the froth on top because i packed the grinds to hard. The second one was great.. The unit comes with a single and double strainer. Couldn't  find the single..Looked in the box three times before I found it. It was packed in  the cord cardboard sleeve. I've been using Lavazza pods and Caffe Borbone in my old unit, so... a little research revealed that you can order the pod screen  from Mr. Coffee separately (2.99).  I like the 2 level coffee cup bases. 2nd level is under the milk unit.  Con: The only complaint I have is I wish the was a pilot light for the on/off switch. That's it.

review_content:
I had a Mr. Coffee Caf√© Barista and loved it, until it stopped working properly about two years after purchase. I liked it enough that I decided to purchase a replacement. Amazon had the best deal, so I ordered it here. The package arrived from UPS more than a day late. The box had a hole in it, the box had clearly been opened and a "fragile" label had been stuck on. Having purchased this before, I was surprised to see that it didn't have the plastic covering, that the parts were stuck on the side and even the Styrofoam was broken. It was clear this was not a new product, and seeing crossed out labels to a previous customer confirmed this. I doubled checked the Amazon listing, and it was clearly sold as a new product (there was a link to used ones at a much lower price).

My low rating is more for Amazon than the product. What a disappointment.

review_content:
I bought this a while ago at walmart, and decided to post a review about it.
First, this is a cheap product. Exploded in the kitchen with my family around. I'll explain more later because we did get a replacement.

I'm a barista but I'm also not a picky person. However, this is the worst tasting "espresso" shot I've ever tasted even though we had fresh espresso beans and bought our own tamper. It's fine if you want to use it in a flavored latte, where you wont taste the espresso. Personally, I just want to take a espresso shot in those sluggish mornings to help get up, when coffee isn't doing it. The espresso shot is very bitter and tasted old. The steam wand works fine, it works good for cappuccinos. I only use the wand now to make hot chocolates, because i like the milk foam. The product is pretty scary in general. The pressure that builds up makes this noise and I'm afraid it's going to explode (again), taking off the cap you can hear the pressure being released even if you wait a day to unscrew it. Sometimes the cap will pop off in your face, one time it hit my eye. I do not use this product unless I want steamed milk foam, even then I use it with caution. Any weird noise and I back away from the product.

EXPLOSION WARNING
The reason I gave this 2 stars and not one star is because of the costumer service.
The glass coffee pot exploded with glass flying everywhere. I wasn't too far from the unit with my back turned, glass flying everywhere. My entire family was in the room. Luckily no one was seriously injured, my mother suffered a scratch from the glass on her eye. I posted it on facebook, and tagged Mr coffee in the picture. Received a message right away on how to get a new one.

This unit is a law suit waiting to happen. To anyone considering buying this crap, you get what you pay for. Spend the money, and get something that will actually work and not explode in your face.
title: Customer service is good, but unit exploded.
bought_model: Color: CappuccinoStyle Name: 4-Cup Steam

review_content:
Very cool little kitchen appliance. We received one for our wedding, and it took about a month before we took it out of the box and actually read the instructions for how to use it. It really couldn't be any easier. Pour yourself some milk, measure out your coffee, set the dial, and press the button. In less than two minutes (probably less than 1 minute, although I haven't timed it) you'll have your drink.

The only suggestion that would make it better would be to have a few lines printed on the milk container, so you have an idea of how much milk to pour for the drink you're making.

EDIT: We've had this appliance for over a year now, and it is still one of our favorites. We use it only a couple times a week, but it's just so versatile. I'm not a huge coffee drinker, but I'll use it just to get the steamed milk for hot chocolate, or to steam milk for a hot tea. This thing is really great.
title: Very cool little kitchen appliance
bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Espresso/Cappuccino Maker

review_content: I've had the Cafe Barista for almost a year and I absolutely love it!  It makes delicious coffee of all types with the touch of a button.  I wanted a machine where I did not have to foam or steam my milk separately so this is perfect.  I like a LARGE cup of coffee in the morning so I can easily click on a double cup of cappuccino, then do a single serve of espresso and it does not weaken the coffee at all (without even refilling the coffee). I noticed that some reviewers mentioned that the steamer didn't work well over time.  The key is to keep it clean, so I clean it after every use - takes 30 seconds and done.  Perfect coffee every time.  In addition, I was using half and half, and now with the steamer I can use skim milk with just a "touch" of half and half, so I've cut down on calories and fat and cannot tell a difference.  It's as creamy as ever.  I had actually received one of the $300 fancy espresso machines as a gift and ended up sending it back and getting this one for half the price. I have much more flexibility with this one.  Also got the extra 4 year extended warranty for just a few dollars more.
title: Fantastic Product!
bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Espresso/Cappuccino Maker

review_content: We had the Mr. Coffee ECM-250 for about 5 years but I broker the plastic frothing piece and my brother just bought this new model for my husband and me for Christmas.  This machine is horrible!  The last one frothed the milk EVERY time.  This one just bubbles the milk.  The plastic frother was actually broken on arrival but we didn't notice until after we used it.  I called Mr. Coffee and explained what happened and they promptly sent out a BRAND new machine (covered under warranty) even though I suggested that the frothing tip would satisfy me.  Well, the new machine stinks too.  Again, it doesn't froth the milk...just bubbles.  I can do that with a straw!  PLUS, it just about exploded while brewing an espresso, 3 times!  I know how to use this machine...it's pretty much like the last one we had so it's not a user error.  The coffee grounds exploded out of the filter all over the counter along with half the carafe of coffee that should have gone into the carafe.  Will be calling Mr.Coffee again tomorrow with my disappointment of their product.  I don't want this replaced with the same piece of garbage.  Considering the number of similar complaints on here, I'm about ready to get a completely different brand product.  Their customer service is good (based on them responding so quickly to my first issue) but they need to recall this before someone is seriously injured.  DO NOT BUY!  If you can get the older model (ECM250) I highly recommend it over this one.  Those of you having no problems, perhaps you have the ones that are not lemons.  I'm not willing to take another chance.
title: BLEW OUT COFFEE GROUNDS AND DOES NOT FROTH!
bought_model: Color: CappuccinoStyle Name: 4-Cup Steam

review_content:
I've only had this little guy a couple days and I am already in love. I am an avid coffee drinking, and have been drooling over machines that cost hundreds for years. Always wanting something big and fancy. Having worked at Panera for a year as a Baristo (Male version of a Barista) I had a decent idea of how to make a few drinks. I moved out of my parents house and now I'm buying all the small appliances I can fit in my humble abode. One of my very well off older coworkers recommended this to me as I was spending somewhere around $100+ a month at starbucks. He bought the same one and said it pays for itself. After using this, I can tell you the espresso is fantastic, I am a little miffed it didn't come with a steam cup or a tamper, but for $40 I am not complaining. You absolutely have to clean after every use, no questions about it. If you don't, this thing won't last, nothing will. Also, after a while it's probably good to run some coffee machine cleaner through it or something like that.

I am super impressed by the power of the steam. I like to brew my espresso first. I put in a little over 4 cups of water,til the water level touches the metal in the top. After my espresso has almost reached level 4 in the pot I quickly switch to steam, the extra water should be enough to get your milk going and make a great little cup.
Also, it's super impressive when you can bring a potential mate over and make fancy coffee drinks, they don't have to know you bought the cheapest espresso maker available, and this little guy would never give that impression either. I look forward to many many years of coffee from this machine, and might just by a 2nd in preparation as I know that prices will only be higher years down the road.
title: Best espresso machine for the money - Buy a steam cup and tamper
bought_model: Color: CappuccinoStyle Name: 4-Cup Steam

review_content:
Let me say that as of one month of everyday use I am keeping this coffee maker. I had serious reservations when I first started using it. In my opinion the machine has a serious design flaw in the way the water tank sits on the base.
What happened to me was after several uses I noticed that the water tank was leaking water on the counter. I have wood floors in my kitchen and this looked like a deal breaker for me.
I decided to troubleshoot the problem and my first step was to call Mr. Coffee support. Of course the rep I spoke with said they never heard of this problem and to send the unit back. No surprise there.
I checked to see that the silicone gasket in the base was not damaged. Check
The valve in the bottom of the water tank was working properly. Check
I then happened to press lightly on the side of the water tank after resetting it into the base. I could see water starting to leak between the tank and the base. Sure enough it continued to leak on to the counter. I then pressed lightly in the opposite direction and the leak stopped.
I was able to duplicate this leak on a consistent basis.
So long story short this unit has a design flaw that can create a leak if the tank is moved out of position.
I am sure this can happen by how the unit is handled when moving it or repositioning it on a countertop.
I have continued to use the unit because it does make a great cup of coffee and the milk frother is a great feature. So if the unit does not break down I will be careful with the water tank. So far so good.
title: Good Home Unit With Reservations

I have never returned a product that i had used but this was the exception. if you are a coffee connoisseur stay away from this machine and invest in a better choice, although I still have not replaced my Barista and am still looking for a replacement that uses real coffee and not pods. review_content: I have had this for over a year and am really satisfied. Sure, it's not a "real" espresso maker, but it does the job fine and is fast. It really doesn't take longer than to brew a pot of coffee -- probably less time. I was looking for something that was simple to operate and made espresso and lattes that taste good. Prior machines I had made awful espresso, broke, or were difficult to operate. I love the water reservoir, which means I'm not constantly pulling the machine out from under the kitchen cabinets to add water. This is a time saver. It comes with two espresso filters -- single and double. It's easy to make espresso without foam and foam without any coffee drink. The buttons are easy to use and straightforward. It's safe -- you aren't going to get a shot of steam or milk splatter in your face. What I like best is that you don't have watch over it and babysit it. It's all automated, though you can also customize the amount of foam. It's easy to clean by hand or in the dishwasher. The only drawback is that although the foam is supposedly customizable, it doesn't get quite to the quality of what you'd get at a coffee shop.
title: ... had this for over a year and am really satisfied. Sure
bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Espresso/Cappuccino Maker

review_content:
First of all, what does it take to make a good espresso? The most important thing are the beans you use. It doesn't matter what kind of machine you have, blah beans = blah espresso.

I was using a push button machine for about six months until it broke. At first I was considering replacing it with a Nespresso machine, but thankfully I came to my senses and got this at my local Wal-Mart. I'm very glad I ditched the world of automatic machines. This just take a little bit of effort, but with a little practice you don't even notice it.

A note about the steam wand / Frother: There is nothing wrong with it. Making a good froth just take a little practice. The results can be inconsistent sometimes but that has everything to do with the technique, not the frother.

Make sure you have plenty of steam. I usually make two shots, so I fill up the carafe to the 2 shot mark, then fill it up more (about half way to the 4 shot mark). When brewing I wait for the espresso to reach the 2 shot mark then stop the brewing and begin frothing immediately.This ensures that you have plenty extra steam left over to froth/steam the milk.

Use a thermometer when frothing/steaming: Mine cost about $5. You froth the milk until it gets to 120 degrees, then steam it to 140.

A frothing pitcher helps, but isn't necessary: I'm just using another coffee cup to froth right now, the result would be better with a frothing pitcher, but I still don't have any problems getting a good froth.

You don't just stick the steam wand in the milk and magically get a good froth. You want to tip of the wand to be just under the surface of the milk to froth. As the milk heats up the level will rise, adjust the position of the wand as needed. There is a certain sound that is made when it is properly frothing, it's a small gurgling/suction sound. If you hear a loud bubbling sound it isn't in far enough, just a tad deeper will get you there. If you don't hear much of anything it is in too far. You will know it when you hear it. Keep that sound going until the milk reaches 120, then stick the wand all the way in to steam to 140.

Once you are done frothing don't forget to depressurize the remaining steam. This is most easily done buy going back to the brew mode. Make sure you have already emptied the carafe before depressurizing.

Finally, any espresso machine, regardless of price needs to be descaled periodically, don't forget it.
title: Great espresso on a budget
bought_model: Color: CappuccinoStyle Name: 4-Cup Steam

review_content:
Having taught eBay classes for about 10 years and even writing an electronic book on the subject, I am addicted to cruising thrift stores. That's where I found a virtually unused unit with accessories for $6.50.Had somebody donated a dead unit to get a tax credit or with the mistaken idea that "maybe somebody can fix it." [You can't].

With dual lights flashing and no apparent water leaving the generous water tank, I thought it was clogged or the pump was no good. But then I remembered to PRIME THE PUMP. I did this by switching over to the steamer and letting it chug until some water came out. Then I switched back to espresso and pumped out some water. Presto! Problem solved. I wonder if some folks here have forgotten to do that when no water comes out?

Cheapos are getting better than a few years ago. This (Chinese) maker is ready to dispense a shot in very, very short order.

Like the "better" machines, this unit sends a pre-brew squirt of water before the main flow begins. The taste is about the same, and my only complaint is that the "push the button and then turn the dial" is a bit odd. Probably a way to keep costs down, less complex.

Obviously Mr. Coffee's holding company is not in the business of stocking parts or making repairs, but this is more common everywhere now that these devices are all from China. It is cheaper to send you another one than paying some tech a large hourly wage to swap out a gasket.

The alleged complaints that some have been told the units are out of warranty at the time of purchase because they are "new old stock" is intolerable. What they are really saying is that they have moved on to another model or found another supplier and have no replacements. That is THEIR problem, not yours! People experiencing such a dodge should contact their elected representative so they can contact the FTC. Trust me, it works!

Regarding leaks, I strongly suspect that many never read the instructions or did not keep track of how many drips finally filled the holding area below the metal shelf. You can't fix stupid.
title: Better than low-end units of a few years ago!

title: I love this machine

review_content:
IMPORTANT TWO YEAR UPDATE!!!! PLEASE READ!!!! YOUR MACHINE MAY NOT HAVE DIED!!!!! I DID THIS &FIXED IT!!!! CHECK YOUR INTERNAL FILTER! THIS IS NOT IN THE MANUAL! See Below! (Original One Year Review Follows, so skip this if you just want a review, but read it if you plan on buying it because it might save you a few years down the road!) It is a good machine for the price!

I noticed into the second year that we started having problems with the coffee forming muddy sludge and not being able to tamp it the same as we used to. The espresso wasn't as strong and we thought it was Starbucks grinding the espresso differently. We prefer Illy Brand or other brands, but Starbucks is close and can grind it fresh wo buying a burr grinder. Not my favorite, but does the job for everyday espresso. The machine would stop brewing and we would have to take out the filter & basket, clean it out and replace with new espresso very loosely in the basket. Not very happy about that because it wasn't as strong and was wasting A LOT of espresso! Finally this morning it completely stopped working when I went to get my morning espresso!!!! OH NO!!!!! I tried cleaning it again internally with white vinegar, flushing it with water, but only the steam wand worked and water would only come out if the filter & basket weren't attached. Sadly I thought the seal had died and that was why it would build enough pressure to even allow water to run through the empty filter. I read the manual and there were no. answers. I checked on Amazon and saw sadly that many had theirs die around 2 or 3 years and happily replaced it. I got mine one HUGE sale around Black Friday and really didn't want to wait until next month. I honestly didn't want a new one. SO I went back a few hours later and took a good look at it, deciding it was no longer under warranty and only useful as a milk frother so WHY NOT TAKE A LOOK! DO THIS PART AT YOUR OWN RISK!!!!! IT WORKED THOUGH! Take off the catch pan, water reservoir and unplug the machine and turn upside down to empty internal water over the sink. DO NOT PUT IN SINK!!!! Put down upside down on the counter on a towel. You will see in the middle of where you attach the filter and brew basket to the machine a BIG BLACK SCREW! Carefully unscrew the screw, as it's plastic and can strip easily. carefully take it off and be aware there's a spring directly under it that you MUST NOT LOSE! Now you've reached the round, silver INTERNAL FILTER! It is FACE DOWN with the bottom facing towards you (it looks just like the bottom of you filter baskets.) Carefully take it off and look at the side that was facing the machine (when you take it off and flip it over it will be slightly concave-this means you are looking at the top face of the filter.) THIS WAS MY PROBLEM!!!!!! MY INTERNAL FILTER WAS COMPLETELY CLOGGED ON THE TOP FACE (machine side) with espresso grounds forced backwards into it over time and there is NO WAY for them to come out when you clean it regularly as per the manual!!!!! I washed the internal filter and it cleaned easily. I also wiped out the inside with a damp towel gently until clean. I dried everything, replaced the filter front face down, put the screw in with the spring on the end and screwed it back in place. I flipped it over, put everything back together, filled the reservoir and plugged it in. Poof! I started it up and attached the empty filter with the basket and it WORKED!!!!! I ran about 16 shots worth of water through it until no residual grounds came out.Then I filled my double shot with the last of my espresso and attached it and WOW!!!! It was back to new!!!! It EVEN SMELLED like it did when brand new! I had forgotten over time! It had never lost the crema, but the crema was even better and the espresso darker and stronger like in the 1st year!!!! Now I wonder how many people threw theirs out after two or three years because this internal filter gets clogged and there's no instructions how to clean it. Knock on Wood! I hope mine keeps going for much, much longer and I hope I've helped many others save their machine!!!!! Cheers! It REALLY is a good little machine for the price! I grew up and owned the professional ones and WAY more expensive home ones and no, it's not that level, but it's still good espresso. Buy the expensive machines if you want excellent perfection. Read the review below. I still stand by it. :)

I bought this machine last year at the beginning of the holiday season as an early Yule/Christmas gift for my whole family. We're still amazed how well it works a year later after daily use (often multiple times a day.)
It comes with both single and double shot filters, but I'd prefer if it came with two double shot filters as we never use the single shot. I suggest hand washing the filters. It only takes a second.

It comes with a plastic scoop with a plastic tamper on the other end. The scoop is fine, but buy yourself a stainless steel tamper as the plastic is the wrong weight and does not pack the shot properly (too loose.) There was a very reasonable double ended tamper I bought on here that works perfectly.

I love that the tray is removeable! It not only makes cleaning easier, but if you want to make it in a mug instead of a demitasse cup for maximum room for foam and you don't want to disturb the crema, remove the tray and just keep a kitchen towel right there for the small amount of water that comes out. After quickly wiping, slide the tray back in!

The wand moves back and forth which is super convenient. After steaming milk (I prefer steaming half and half...super rich foam...but trickier to make) put the wand into a glass of clean water and quickly blow some steam through to clear the steaming wand of milk. Cleaning the wand while still warm is much easier.

All in all, thrilled that we bought this espresso machine! It was $65, but it went on sale right after I ordered and Amazon adjusted the price! I definitely can't complain about $45!!! Even better, Amazon conveniently carries the brands of flavored syrups (we love peppermint regular and sugar free), chocolate and some really great espresso from Italy, although we do get our daily espresso freshly ground at a local establishment for less.

Mr. Coffee don't ever stop making this machine! I even put it back in the box and brought it on our yearly trip to our cabin. Lol, of course that's only possible if you're driving. :) Definitely worth it to have my espresso!!!

And we named him "George" :)
title: Fantastic after a year! So good we named it! ***2 YEAR UPDATE!!!! READ IF YOURS STOPS WORKING!!!! I FIXED IT!!!!

review_content: This kind of espresso machine is great for the price. It does a great job of steaming milk and you get a reasonable crema on the coffee if you use the right roast and grind (espresso). If you live where there is hard water you may need to occasionally run some vinegar through the machine to dissolve the scaling inside which can block the steam. We have owned 4 or 5 of this style machine over the past 20+ years using them daily. The design flaw is the knob that switches from steam to brew. Eventually (2-3 years) the knob will either freeze up or break off. We have tried several different brands and the result is the same which leaves me to believe the mechanism is made the same way, possibly in the same factory. Still, for the price you can afford to buy a new one every 2-3 years.
title: Good bargain for the price but a design flaw

I have been using the daily for almost 2 months and have had great results. It is quick and easy to use. It is very low maintenance and easy to clean after using. The only down sides are:

title: ... the daily for almost 2 months and have had great results. It is quick and easy to use
bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Automatic Dual Shot

review_content:
This is my first espresso machine. I make two to three cappuccinos a day. It's easy to use. The pump has plenty of pressure, and it heats up fast. I removed the rubber nozzle from the steam wand immediately. I learned to froth without fancy gadgets, and it's a skill you'll be proud of if you do it that way. Steam pressure seems good, and the espresso comes out in two golden heavy streams of froth, gradually condensing into a rich, dark liquid with good crema. I use Brazil Santos coffee, and it makes superb espresso. I have used it every day for three months with no problems so far. I got it on sale for $69.99, and I figure even if it only lasts a year, I got my money's worth of espresso. It's fairly easy to clean, and comes with everything you need to start making espresso right away. A few tips; do not grind the coffee too fine or tamp it too hard--this can make steam pop out of the gasket between the portafilter and the group. Grind and tamp require a little experimentation and practice, but it's not that hard. Also, as with any machine, don't store the portafilter on the group, or the gasket will compress and the seal will not be effective. So far, no negatives to report. I'll update this review if anything changes.

Update: May 2009. I have used this machine virtually every day (I say virtually every day because I use a Breville on the weekend). I make 2-3 cappuccinos a day with it. I have yet to experience any problems with it. I've decalcified it once in the last eight or so months I've used it, but only as maintenance. Easy to use, easy to clean. Water temp could be higher, but for an entry level machine, I'm still happy with it. Pump is still strong, steam is still very good. I would recommend this machine to anyone who wants to try making home espresso, but doesn't want to make a large investment in case they don't find it to their liking.

Update: March 2010. Still going strong! I trade every week between this machine and a Breville. The Breville
makes better espresso, but this machine makes better steam and is still easier to use. I still consider it just
an entry-level basic machine, but it's earned my respect. I've decalcified it several times in the last year, and the steam and water output is still strong. Honestly, even if it took a dump at this point, I would replace it with another one just like it. If you want to try making your own espresso, I doubt you'll find a more user friendly machine.

Update: December 2010. This machine functions the same way it did the first time I used it. Steam and water output is still strong. Yes it has some annoyances as others have pointed out. The drip tray is small and it leaks a little on the counter. I guess if someone really wanted a Gaggia or Saeco and bought this, it would be pretty disappointing. For me, however, this is my feel-good machine. It doesn't owe me a cent. I've probably made $5000 dollars worth of espresso drinks with this machine. It's easy to use, easy to clean, and doesn't require a lot of maintenance. I guess this is my final word on this unit. For the price, it can't be beat.
title: Great espresso, zero problems
bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Automatic Dual Shot

review_content: If my Caf√© Barista dies, I will probably buy another one. I used to be a SB addict - probably spent $30 a week there. But since I started making my own coffee drinks, I have been saving money.  Yay!  I purchased mine from the BBB store 2 1/2 years ago because for some reason, it was $99 and with 20% off - wow, what a deal. I love it even more because of that.  I'm writing this because I have made a cappuccino every day for 2.5 years, and just discovered... it's wonderful with WHOLE milk!  I can't believe the difference. It's twice as good now. I had been using 1 or 2% milk and freshly roasted espresso beans from a local coffee shop which I grind, and it was OK.  But now, it tastes awesome.  Try it!  I used to get big bubbles of milk that would overflow my cup, but whole milk seems to be creamier/more dense.

The guarantee requires contacting Mr. Coffee, so beware of that issue. You cannot return it to a local vendor (such as Target) after their 90 day return policy runs. bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Automatic Dual Shot

review_content:
Piece of garbage! - Please save your money and don't buy this product
-My husband and I could not dislike this machine more. We tried to use it for two months before returning it to Walmart

Pros
-small and compact so doesn't take a lot of room on the counter
-brewing is quick
-milk does get very hot

Cons
-the instructions for making an espresso or cappuccino are wrong and terribly inadequate; they don't tell you that you have to actually stop the brewer before it's done in order to save water for the steamer part.
-the insert (part above the pot) is not easy to remove and replace as there is only one way to do it, and there is a high risk of accidentally rethreading it; also removing it tends to move the whole system as well because it is so tight it and out
-the handle on the left of machine that turns the brewing & steaming function on and off is very stiff so it feels like you're goring to break it when you try to turn it, especially when you have to interrupt the brewing cycle
-there is no frothing pitcher and the coffee packer is very ineffective
-the frother makes a mess. We have owned espresso and cappuccino makers in the past and only had to let our previous one go because we couldn't bring it when we moved. Now it's discontinued and I regret not keeping it
-it says 4 cups but it is not, so you have a to go through the motions twice to make two coffees; it is more like 2 cups in the little pot provided
-both my husband and I tried to use the frother and it splashed so much milk that it burned both of us on separate occasions
-in the end, every piece of this product is cheaply made and poor quality with little attention to detail
-extremely poor value for money
title: Absolute garbage - not worth a penny let alone $35-$40!
bought_model: Color: CappuccinoStyle Name: 4-Cup Steam

review_content:
I have owned my Mr. Coffee Espresso maker for about 5 years now and it has never disappointed. I make a latte/cappuccino for my wife and myself almost every morning and sometimes at night as well. The steam wand works great once you get the simple procedure dialed in. The espresso comes out great every time. This has been one of the best investments because before we bought this unit we made a stop at Starbucks quite often and that get pricey. And now that we figured out you can purchase the flavors from Starbucks, such as vanilla, I can make a latte that taste almost exactly like the latte we used to get at Starbucks.

I had trouble at first figuring out a good procedure to fallow so for those who are interested,
Procedure I use to make Latte/Cappuccino:
1. Fill reservoir with 4 cup water. (I use store bought drinking water)
2. Fill 2 large coffee cups with about 1/3 cold milk and 4 pumps Starbucks vanilla flavor. (Starbucks vanilla flavor purchased from Starbucks)
3. Fill espresso filter to top and tamp down to about 2 cups. (purchase a decent tamper because the scoop does not work great for tamping)
4. Put espresso filter and carafe into position for brewing.
5. Plug Mr. Coffee unit in and turn dial to steam. (Good idea to put an empty cup under steam wand tip to catch and dripping water while steam gets up to temp)
6. Wait to see that the steam comes out of the wand without dripping water. (looking for a "dry" constant steam)
7. Turn steam off
8. Holding the coffee cup containing your milk, insert the seam wand into the milk and turn steam back on full.
(while steaming milk I like to move the wand in and out of the cup, don't take wand out of milk, until the froth reaches the top of the cup, almost overflowing the cup. Try not to create bubbles as much as you can. It's a little unavoidable at first. After froth reaches desired level I'll put the wand deep into the cup to get the temperature of the milk up. Hot to the touch.)
9. Repeat step 8 for second cup.
10. Turn Mr. Coffee dial to brew and brew two cups of espresso.
11. Pour espresso into coffee cups with frothed milk, stir mixture with spoon, then serve.

Make sure to clean your machine after every use! I am sure this is why my unit has lasted so long.
title: Great Espresso Maker
bought_model: Color: CappuccinoStyle Name: 4-Cup Steam

review_content:
I owned this machine for about one year, it worked fine until yesterday when it literally blew its top!! Fortunately for us neither my wife or myself was near the machine when a very loud bang occurred as the hot water blew from the counter top up to the ceiling!! Could have caused serious burns but as I have said neither one of us was not directly in front of the machine.
Following the breach of the safety cap I examined the failed part and discovered the cap to the heating pot holding the hot water was made of very thin plastic less than 1/32 of an inch and the pressure release valve failed!
BE CAREFUL OF THIS MACHINE IF OLDER THAN ONE YEAR AS IT COULD BE DANGEROUS!!!

review_content: It was fantastic... until it stopped doing just hot milk and only frothing now. I get this thick froth that I hate no matter what setting I put on the milk container. I end up throwing out all the skimmed froth which is about half a full cup of coffee. I have taken excellent care of it, run the clean cycle on a regular basis and clean it after every use but I can tell it is winding down. I used to have it perfectly timed to stop once the cup was full but now it keeps going until it overflows. Small issues... but I feel like it has run its course after three years. It's a little overpriced for something that doesn't go the extra mile. I've had $35 espresso machines that lasted six or seven years with the same amount of use. More parts, means more ways something can wear down I suppose. If I could go back, I might have stuck with the $30 to $40 range instead of the $130 I paid for this (I think it's less now). It requires a great deal of upkeep with the added feature of the separate compartments.
title: Lasts about three years with heavy use
bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Espresso/Cappuccino Maker

review_content:
I have just purchase my second Mr Coffee Espresso Maker! Recently, my old Mr Coffee machine was passing more water down into the drip tray then through the coffee brew basket. I tore apart the machine and discovered a defective solenoid. Thinking that a year and a half of service was poor, I purchased a DeLonghi EC155 Espresso Machine.De'Longhi EC155 15 BAR Pump Espresso and Cappuccino Maker Boy was THAT a mistake. It has a separate water frothing steam tank adjusted by a knob on its top. But when I tried making frothed up milk like I always do, I ended up with watered down milk! Its totally steam driven unlike this Mr Coffee Espresso maker which is pump driven like the espresso function. The DeLonghi EC155 Espresso Machine has a very short steam stem making it difficult to get a pitcher under with any ease. Its nozzle at the end is plastic and just doesn't fit the bill. And directly under the brew basket on the DeLonghi EC155, there is barely room for a shot size container. The fit of the metal drip tray cover is extremely poor. And finally, the Espresso product produced, is very close to each other. I would have to say that the DeLonghi Will produce more crema than does the Mr Coffee maker.

So why did I comment more on the De'Longhi EC155 Espresso Machine then the MR Coffee, cause the Mr Coffee is Everything the De'Longhi is NOT. And it is in the same price range for home low price espresso makers.

Summary:

- Frothing function is Pump Driven and has a Metal Frothing tip.
- There is ample room under the brew basket for good size espresso type cups.
- The Drip tray can be removed to allow for a larger cup (DeLonghi s removes but leaves a front lip in the way)
- The water reservoir for the Mr Coffee is larger.
- The Warm-up period is less than a minute (DeLonghi 15 minutes! )
- The brew basket and filters are easy to use almost fool proof (DeLonghi s have to be carefully assembled and attached to maker
and need to be disassembled to clean - more plastic parts!!! )
title: ecmp50 mr coffee espresso maker
bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Automatic Dual Shot

review_content: Great espresso and froth "but" poor nob designs. The reservoir and brew-off-steam nobs are 2.5" and 3" (respectively) in diameter at base. They are extremely smooth in design. Other than these, great buy for the price, so far.

I had the Mr Coffee espresso maker before this one and after 4 years the gasket went out. Bought the newer model, which has a kind of retro 70's look to me that I personally don't really like. There are a couple of other things wrong with it though that I thought would be worth pointing out. First, the machine is so small and light-weight, that it moves all around the counter when you are opening the water tank, closing it and putting the coffee basket on. (Sorry I don't know technical terms to use here!) Anyway, the other major thing for me is that the lid for the water reservoir is so smooth and domed, or angled, that it is very difficult to grasp as tight as you need to to open it - it does have a great seal. I'm a normal 40 year old with normal hand/wrist function, but my hands can't grip it well. I make espresso twice a day and this machine is just not worth the struggle.

Espresso - Decent, Ergonomics - Lacking.

review_content:
We had been buying cheap espresso machines and began replacing about once a year. We decided to splurge and by this one (for us $199 is a splurge). I read a bunch of reviews but there really wasn't anything like this in this price range. There was just no way we were going to spend $200+.

We absolutely love this machine (5 days in). Did not buy from Amazon but from local Bed Bath & Beyond due to the 20% off coupon. Love that we don't have to stand there while the milk is being frothed. We pick the double or single, cappuccino or latte and walk away while it's all being done, come back and have the perfect cup. We haven't tried any custom settings yet. The ones provided suit us just fine. I like that the milk reservoir can be refrigerated since we have mixed milk with flavored creamer or with half & half and that has worked out well. It comes with two filters - one single, one double. Also comes with a scoop and press. When you first turn it on, it does blink for about 30 seconds before it's ready. I was impatient in the beginning and thought I was doing something wrong.

Only major con is having to "force" in the milk reservoir. There have been times that I didn't push in far enough because I was worried about breaking it. One minor thing to watch out for...the double latte puts in a LOT of milk and has overflowed our coffee mug so be careful of that the first time you make one.

As long as this outlast our previous machines then I'm very happy with this purchase, but only time will tell...

review_content:
This is a nice machine, though I anticipate from experience it has many parts that can break- fortunately you can opt at Wal-Mart at least for a 3 year replacement coverage for an additional $20.00.

My frustration I guess is that among the many options it just doesn't make a normal cup of coffee.
There are a couple nice conveniences, first it is really easy to clean with removable drip trays and an actual 'clean' button for the frother, which automatically sanitizes the creamer. You can also pull the creamer receptacle out easily and store in the fridge, and pop it in when in use. The water tray also removes and fills easily though it seems rather fragile and thin to me. The rest of the unit is solidly built enough, stainless steel accents and the filter are all metal.

My suggestion is to get a normal coffee maker for everyday use and have this out for special occasions. If you have the bucks to buy both, as this alone is about twice the cost of a normal one. I was hoping for a coffee machine that 'did extras' as I saw all the buttons but this appears to be specifically an expresso and latte maker only.
HOWEVER...... as someone who currently works from home, I have to add that after buying a normal coffee maker for mornings, I have been intending to return this but instead I find myself making a latte every afternoon and looking forward to it too. What a conundrum! :P
I may be forced to keep this after all lol.

With no hassle, they said that this model was out of stock, but that they would send me the lesser model as a temporary replacement.  I was to call a month later when they had restocked the original ECMP50.  I did just that, and they then sent me the ECMP50, telling me to keep the other replacement as well.  All I needed was the receipt, I didn't need to return anything, and service was pleasant and easy.  I highly recommend this product for its performance, and for the support I received.  Enjoy!

review_content:
1-year update:

After one year of making two cappuccinos a day, this unit is still performing beautifully.

Len

After 8 1/2 years of service, my Solis Crema SL 90 died. Well, it turns on, but doesn't heat. Just a tease...

So I ordered the Mr. Coffee, mainly because of the positive reviews, and had it delivered overnight. Hey, I need my Cappuccino. :-) Shortly after arriving, I unpacked and started to read the manual. Now, you would think that's a good procedure, however, if you see the Recipe Guide booklet, TURN IT OVER for the Quick Start Guide. Inside you'll see "IMPORTANT" where it says you need to prime it before use.

I used it for the first time this morning and it made a nice Cappuccino. Kind of odd that it froths the milk first and then pumps the coffee in. The exact opposite of how I used the Solis.

So far (1 day) a good experience. I'll see how it goes and maybe upgrade the star rating to 5.

I'm on Day 2 now. Everything went smoothly in automatic mode for Cappuccino. For my size cup, I did double shot Cappuccino and then single shot espresso. I'm going to keep playing around with options.

I'm on Day 3 now. Tried the manual override. I might continue to use it this way. For my cup size: 2-2 shot and 1-1 shot espresso. Then manual milk froth in Cappuccino mode.

It's now been a week and I'm raising my Stars to 5. I've been using it in manual mode and it works great, once you figure out how to do that. ;-)

Update: I've been using this machine daily for the last month, primarily in manual mode. But in the last week, I've started using in Cappuccino automatic mode. Odd to me, it froths the milk and then the coffee comes out. For my size cup, I do a 2-cup and then 1-cup auto mode. Off to make another "batch."
title: Replacement for dead Solis Crema SL 90
