review_content:
My wife researched a replacement for our 20yr old Krups and this is what she found as the best bang for the buck given our current income level....

My biggest problem is that it took most of a year (we only use it on Sunday mornings) to figure out the foaming technique for this machine:
1. Low fat milk in a 1 Cup Pyrex pitcher
2. Place in freezer for 10+ minutes
3. Start brewing
4. When the espresso reaches the top line, start frothing by moving the Pyrex UP AND DOWN as well as around. You'll hear the different sounds and learn how to use the sounds to manage the level of foam.
5. Turn off
6. Make your Latte's
7. Unplug unit and wipe down frother
8. After a year - watch frother tip break off and you start reading reviews for another brand.

Expresso anyone?
title: A year of challenge followed by failure
bought_model: Color: CappuccinoStyle Name: 4-Cup Steam

review_content: Gave one star because no stars is not an option. I would not recommend this machine. Purchased this machine for my deployed boyfriend and had it sent to him for the length of his deployment (1 year). The machine stopped working after 4 short months. The machine would boil the water but would not drip through. This machine was also used with bottled water only and had no build up in the system. With limited communication to and from him, I contacted customer support to discuss the issue. The customer service rep was unable to help with the situation because I did not have the machine. I explained to her that it was in another country and was not accessible and the limited communication with the soldiers. Not only did I spend money on this machine, but had to pay the additional $16 to ship it to an APO address. Now 4 months later, we are in the same spot because the product is unreliable. I can now assure you that I would never purchase another Mr. Coffee product. I would spend an additional $20 for a different brand just so I can insure the machine would last longer than a couple of months.
title: Unreliable. Don't recommend.

review_content: I have had this machine for about 4 months. I use it daily to make a double cappuccino. It has worked flawlessly and makes great cappuccinos and lattes. I got it on sale at Walmart for $139.99. I think it is crucial to follow the start-up instructions to the letter and to do the same with the cleaning instructions after every use. It's just a couple of button pushes and the machine cleans itself. I am amazed that this machine works so well, especially for the low price (compared to $1000.00+ machines). I am going to get a 50 mm stainless steel tamper because the one that comes with the machine is flimsy plastic one and I can't pack the coffee as tight as I would like. Other than that, I'm a happy camper!

review_content:
You can't beat the price of this thing. I paid $39.99 at Walmart and thought that was a good deal. Amazon has it for $29.99. If you buy espresso coffee, or something dark and bold like an Italian roast, it will make great espresso. Just be sure to pack it snugly into the chamber.
PROS: Exceptional price for what you get. Makes great espresso.
CONS: Frother stopped working after three uses. The company will only let you return it to them or have them repair it. You can't take it back to the store (or they discourage you from doing so). Additionally, the cover of the water area and the knob that turns it from brew to froth to off are both very awkward to turn. The shape is odd. The top one is especially annoying to twist off and on compared with other models I've used. Even though the frother broke, I just pour in the milk and heat it in the microwave. It's a latte, not a capucchino, but it still tastes decent.
title: Frother only worked 3 times. Price was the most dominant buying factor. With the right coffee, still makes great espresso.

When I brought the issue to their customer service they took 3 weeks asking me for model information over and over then never got back to me. When I followed up again they dismissed me and didn't even offer a way to fix the machine.

This is the response I received:
Thank you for providing information regarding your ECM160. Based on the information you have provided, your ECM160 is no longer covered under the 1-year warranty.

If you have a sales receipt or invoice from Amazon dated within the warranty period, please respond via email with a copy of your sales receipt attached as a .jpg or .pdf file.

review_content:
I've been using this for a few months now and it's simply.... awesome. Is it the best cup of espresso/cappuccino/latte I've ever had? No. But it didn't cost $1000, it easily fits on my counter top, and I can be drinking my espresso/cappuccino/latte in 5min with never leaving the house.
While it's not the best I've ever had, it's still better than probably half the coffee shops I've been to! Which is pretty amazing. So unless you live next door to a great coffee shop (no not starbucks) I'd highly recommend this.
I believe the key is that it has a 15bar pump, which is what high end machines run at. Similar counter top machines I looked at only had 3-5bar pumps and they all had poor ratings. FYI, 15bar = 217psi. That's a lot of pressure.

review_content:
Going on 10 months of using this machine pretty much daily. I grind my own beans but have used pre-ground as well. The machine works very well especially considering the price! It was a little tough to prime the very first time and it gets a little cranky if the water runs out and you have to re-prime. I also find that the frother works best when full. It provides less froth as the level of the milk drops. I'm not too concerned about this as I prefer less froth for my cappuccino, and none for my Americano. It does do a really good job for hot chocolate!

So far it has held up pretty well though it does show some wear and tear from the ceramic cups on the plastic and aluminum. I have cleaned it up after each use and have even unscrewed the screen from the group head a time or two to ensure it is good and clean. A small bottle brush is handy to clean up the frother by the way.

Given the convenience of the machine and the quality of the coffee made, I give it two thumbs up. No, it's not an Italian espresso from a $1000+ machine but for the price it does a great job.

review_content:
I got this 4 months ago and I'm very pleased with it so far with multiple daily use. My girlfriend is a heavy coffee drinker, so we make at least 2-3 drinks a day.

Pros:

-The silver and black finish looks well in a kitchen, and the unit is fairly compact
-The warm-up time is about 1-2 minutes, not bad at all
-Automatically turns off after maybe 15 minutes or so
-Water container is large and you can make many drinks with just one fill-up
-Milk frother is automatic so you can make your drink with just push of a button
-The frother level is adjustable so you can pick the amount of foam you'd like for your drink
-The cleaning function is good for flushing the frother to prevent build up
-The spoon that comes along has a packing end so you can scoop and pack the coffee without having to grab another tool
-There are two holes on the mug base plate right below where the coffee nozzles are, so the dripping after you make the coffee falls into a container beneath and it's easy to empty and clean

Cons:
-The noise from the pump is a bit loud, but it's acceptable
-The power cord length is limited so the unit have to be next to a wall plug
-The temperature of the milk/coffee could be a little higher
-Could be a little taller to accept taller mugs. Standard mugs fit under it fine.

Overall it's a good espresso maker for the price. I'm glad I bought this as it has saved me a lot of money from buying coffee at coffee shops

review_content:
Works as advertised. End result tastes great. I was originally concerned about maintenance but after working with this unit it's a non-issue. We'll see if it will stand the test of time.

What does this unit do? It makes great Expresso, Cappuccino or Lattes in either single or double at the press of a few buttons.

What do you have to do? Setup unit, perform initial priming per instructions and then keep water and/or milk in the appropriate tanks. Note: milk is only required if you choose to make cappuccino or lattes. Yes you can use any type of milk (whole, low fat, organic or soy). I assume you use 2% or cream but they are not specifically listed. You'd just have to experiment to see if they froth and meet your taste requirements. Put a fine grind in the appropriate Porta-Filter (for single or double) and install in the unit. You also need to place a cup under the Porta-Filter. Once system is loaded you press a button once (for singles) or twice (for doubles) and you're in business. From there the system takes over and makes whatever you have selected.

After use cleaning is simple. Turn a knob to "clean" and press the Latte button for 3 seconds. This will clean out the milk frother. You can leave milk in the tank during this process. After the "clean" cycle runs you can remove the milk tank and stick it in the refrigerator until you need it next time. Aside from wiping things off (as you would do with any appliance) there really is nothing special here. Certainly nothing inconvenient.

Periodically you'll need to clean the tanks (water and milk). The water tank is NOT dishwasher safe and you'll have to hand wash it. The milk tank IS dishwasher safe for the top rack. Let's say this is a 5 minute job if you're having a bad day. Remember you don't have to do this every day either.

The Porta-Filter is NOT dishwasher safe and they recommend cleaning it every 90 days by disassembling (1 minute job) and soaking in warm water.

Depending on water hardness you will have to perform a deliming every 40-80 brew cycles. This is to demineralize the unit which again is something you'll have to do with anything that boils water. This is more effort since you'll have to fill the water tank with vinegar and let it sit overnight. Then the following day you'll have to run some vinegar through the unit to clean everything out.

If I can get a couple of years out of this unit I'll be happy for the price. If it fails before then I'll be back to update my review. But so far this thing rocks.

review_content:
I'm not an espresso nut, however I do enjoy the taste of espresso over that of regular coffee. This machine has been absolutely wonderful for me. Initially knowing nothing about making an espresso, this machine does just about everything for you, and is rather easy to care for. It froths/heats milk for you at the right temperature and adds it to your cup. The milk reservoir is removable so that you can store unused milk in the fridge for later use. The machine only takes about 2 mins tops to heat up, and will let you know when it's ready to brew. It also comes with a scoop and tamper. I would definitely recommend this to anyone looking for an affordable and dependable machine that's easy to use and care for.
As for shipping, packaging and what not, all was great. It came double boxed with styrofoam inserts and everything wrapped and sealed. Also came on time.

bought_model: Color: RedStyle Name: Espresso/Cappuccino Maker

review_content: I am not a coffee snob, but I enjoy my espresso.  I have owned a DeLongi that did not meet my expectation, and then laid down roughly $300 for a "Coffee Gaggia", because Consumers' Report rated it highly.  I purchased the Mr Coffee to replace a Mr Coffee steam driven machine that I had in my office.  The steam brew was not as good as my Gaggia brew but it was much cheaper.  When the steam brewer finally died due to aging plastic of the coffee cage handle, I looked around, and decided to try the pump Mr. Coffee.  Very pleased! It makes a better cup than my Gaggia for 1/5th the price and does so with much less trouble.  Turn it on and mount the coffee cage while it heats up - voila!  The crema is much better than I get with the Gaggia.  In addition, the Gaggia is unable to draw a double without waiting for the chamber to reheat.  I have not tried to draw two cups, but a simple double is absolutely no problem for the Mr Coffee: a clean draw with good crema throughout and the smooth almost sweet taste that accompanies a quick brew.  The coffee this makes is superior to any I have made except with a machine that a friend purchased for his lab at a cost of ~ $3000.  That is not to say that there are not better machines, but in my experience, no better at anywhere near this price.  I drink only espresso, so I have not tried the milk frothing spout.  Also, I have used this machine for only about a month so I am not sure how well it will hold up, but at this price I can replace it 5 times for what I paid for my Gaggia!  If my Gaggia ever dies, I'll have a Mr Coffee at home as well.
title: Excellent coffee for a reasonable price.

review_content: My wife and I like coffee so much, so we decided to try Mr. Coffee after friend recommendation, the machine works great, looks nice and it does what we bought it for, my wife loved it, so nothing to complain about. title: Good deal
bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Espresso/Cappuccino Maker

review_content:
I'd just burned up my Melita espresso machine which was less than a year old. I needed to replace it, but didn't want to invest tons of money if these machines didn't last more than mine did. I saw the Mr Coffee forty-dollar-wonder and thought why not?
There's a bit of a learning curve here. The Melita machine was pump driven, Mr. Coffee's is steam driven. I didn't realize this when I bought it. (I'm not sure I would've understood the difference) The first time I used it, I blew milk all over the place....the coffee was good, tho. I fiddled with it for a day or two and stopped hating it rather quickly. I foam into a receptacle that is wider on the bottom to help contain the bubbling.
I love that you can make 4 shots worth of really, really good espresso at a time. I love the steam-driven foamer, which makes the milk very hot and nicely foamed.
I really love this little machine...it has a small footprint and makes really, really good espresso. I love the lattes made with it, as well. I'm happy with it and will get another as back-up.
title: Great Little machine!!
bought_model: Color: CappuccinoStyle Name: 4-Cup Steam

review_content: I only have this machine for a week but as of right now it's working great and makes lattes comparable to starbucks. If you use the right coffee grinds and know a little bit about quality beans then I deff recommend this product. It makes a mean latte... overall happy with how it performs. title: ... a week but as of right now it's working great and makes lattes comparable to starbucks
bought_model: Color: WhiteStyle Name: Espresso/Cappuccino Maker

review_content: I ordered Mr. Coffee ECMP0 for myself after Christmas, received it in early January'10.  This isn't my first espresso machine.  My sister worked for StarBucks as a regional VP of human resources and gave me a refurbished unit with her employee discount, cost around $200.  Worked great for about 3 years.  Of course, by then I was hooked on enjoying cappuccino from the comfort of my own kitchen every morning:-)  I was also spoiled by the fact that my refurb had a built in burr grinder.  After extensive searching, I purchased my 2nd espresso machine from Amazon - La Pavoni PA-1200 Napolitana Stainless Steel Automatic Espresso Machine.  Yes,  Amazon still sells this fancy machine at well over $600.  It lasted about 3 years, same as my previous refurb.  Woe and dismay, much wringing of hands, it appeared to be an electrical problem, kept blowing my protected circuit, plain stopped working.  Brings me to my review today of my humble Mr. Coffee pump espresso machine.  I LOVE IT.  Makes espresso with crema and froths every bit as great as the more expensive machines AND it's easier to use.  I thought it had quit steaming, but ahem...just looked up the manual online from Mr. Coffee, cleaned the steam wand as instructed - and voila!!  Back to nirvana.  If my friend, Mr. Coffee fails to serve me well after a year of daily use, I'll consider it money well spent and happily purchase another!
title: Nearly 8 months later...
bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Automatic Dual Shot

review_content:
Making espresso at home is amazing with this machine. It makes the perfect cup every time. (I stopped buying coffee out, I bought another one for work ) You have many choices to fit your taste. I even took this on vacation for 15 days because I couldn't be without.
I have owned several machines before and this is by far the best.
title: You will be pleased!
bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Espresso/Cappuccino Maker

review_content: I love my machine. I've had it for just over a year and use it 3-5 days per week depending on my schedule. It's really easy to set up and use, just follow the instructions the first few times. :) Learning how to pull a good espresso shot takes some practice, so be sure to watch videos on YouTube and don't give up if your first few shots don't taste great. Overall, great machine!
title: Great espresso machine for beginners and casual drinkers
bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Automatic Dual Shot

review_content:
There is a bad metallic or chemical taste when using the frothing wand & it just shoots out water doubling the amount of liquid in my pitcher. I've tried de-liming w/ vinegar as the manual states & Ive tried running distilled water straight through to clean it out but it's still awful!

Praise to Amazon's customer service - they are amazing & I was refunded but I would not recommend this product. I have emailed Mr. Coffee through their website to report the problem, hope they recall these machines.
title: Don't buy if you intend to use the frothing wand...
bought_model: Color: CappuccinoStyle Name: 4-Cup Steam

review_content:
This is perhaps the fifth Mr. Coffee espresso maker I have bought in my life. They are not expensive and need to be replaced about once every couple of years if you use it every day - but they are way cheaper than buying cappuccino everyday, even if you buy the machine once a year! That is how I look at it.

They produce great foam (I automatically remove the plastic cover that comes on the foaming apparatus and do not use it; I just don't need it and I feel like it foams it before it heats it - probably because I steam the milk right in my coffee cup, which is small compared to a foaming carafe). And they produce a decent espresso. It is not thick espresso, but it is adequate. I know espresso is supposed to pour at a certain thickness per second - but I am not that technical or picky.

I have bought a model every couple of years since I was a freshman in college in 2001 - I recommend it to someone who likes cappuccino, doesn't want to pay three dollars a day for coffee, and who is not an aficionado.

How do I know when it is time to replace my machine? Either the foamer or the espresso making part just quits working, it sputters and takes forever to produce coffee, even after I give it a vinegar rinse. Then it is cheaper to replace than to fix.

Tip: using distilled water from the grocery store prolongs the life of this product significantly.

Another tip: if your water is hard, like well water from Michigan or Florida, DO NOT PUT IT IN THIS MACHINE. Hard water clogs this thing fast. I think this would be true of any espresso maker, however.
title: Still worth the money, even though you have to replace every couple of years.
bought_model: Color: CappuccinoStyle Name: 4-Cup Steam

review_content: So far so good, but time will tell.  This little espresso machine does what I want it to do as far as making espresso. I have read the other comments and some suggest to wait some months and see how long it will last. I don't make espresso every day so maybe I'll be lucky. I don't use the steamer.
title: So far so good. Time will tell.
bought_model: Color: CappuccinoStyle Name: 4-Cup Steam

review_content:
I've had this for a little while now and I think its time to let you know what I know.

Background: I'm an espresso addict. Prior to this machine I drove to Starbucks every morning and bought 4 shots of espresso on ice. That was my everyday. I also am a bit of a Foodie and an avid home cook. I am not a huge fan of kitchen appliances with 1 function, HOWEVER, this one here has changed my mind.

I have had espresso machines in the past, but this one so far works wonderfully. I bought the protection plan, YOU SHOULD TOO. Aside from getting a lemon, protecting your investment is a big deal.

READ the instructions before you start playing around with it. It is NOT automatic you do have to shut off the drip and pump for the espresso. But oh well. I have noticed that my grind doesn't make as much of a difference, but sometimes the leftover grinds are sludgy. I'm assuming that this has more to do with water temperature than anything else. So what i do to help this, turn the machine on about 10 minutes or more before i plan on using it. Then on the first cycle, i add NOTHING no grounds. I let the machine make 2 shots of hot water, this helps clean out gross stuff and it warms all the internal parts. THEN I start making my espresso. Clean up isn't bad. The amount of space isn't bad. If your drip tray is not in the right place, it will put water on your counter. (not fun before you have had any caffeine)

The only downside for me is that it is LOUD. My significant other is gone every morning before I start this process, but it would def. wake him up if
I wasn't.

Buy it, try it, if you on the fence, this is good for beginners and caffeine freaks.
title: Easy to use. Easy to clean, Low maintenance.
bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Automatic Dual Shot

review_content: This coffee machine works well, and is easy to use.  It makes lattes that are almost as good as the ones from the fancy coffee places, but are cheaper over the long haul.  Plus we have the convenience of being able to make them at home, and I find the machine to be fun to use.  I have to spend a little more time cleaning up than with our old cheap coffee maker, but that's okay.  This machine has been a fun addition to our house, and we think it was money well spent, provided it doesn't die on us in the next few years.
title: Has worked great for a few months now.
bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Espresso/Cappuccino Maker

review_content:
This is a really great little espresso machine. After a little practice, I'm making latte's to rival the coffee shop! As others have pointed out, the first thing to do is get rid of that plastic cover over the steamer. It only makes a mess, and perhaps keeps their lawyers happy. If you just position the nozzle barely under the surface of the milk, you can make a beautiful foam.
The reason for 4 stars rather than 5... the cap and the knob are both too smooth and do not allow for a good grip. You really need to be careful not to accidentally cross thread the cap when sealing the tank. While they're pretty, they're not very practical. Earlier models had a much better surface on both for better control.
Overall, a very good espresso machine, especially for the price.
title: Great machine!
bought_model: Color: CappuccinoStyle Name: 4-Cup Steam

review_content:
For the price this is not bad (at least given that other similar products cost much more). The coffee it makes is great.

This is the second machine I own--the first one failed after a couple of years (an electronics issue) and it was out of warranty. I looked around for a different brand/product but this is significantly cheaper than the competition so I decided to bite the bullet and give it another try.

The milk reservoir and associated tubes are somewhat difficult to clean.
title: For the price this is not bad (at least given that other similar products cost much ...

First, it's super easy to use. I like the fact that it stops automatically after making the amount of water you put in there. Second, it brews a consistent cup, which I like as well. I never use the steam feature so I can't comment on that. I enjoy this everyday!

The espresso comes out luke-warm but I froth the milk until it's hot so the overall drink (latte) is as hot as one that you would get at Starbucks. Definitely worth the $$$ and it's easy to use.

review_content: Bought this as a Christmas present for my husband. He has been wanting an espresso machine for a while, and was becoming overwhelmed with the different options, prices and functionalities of what is on the market. I opted to buy him this to gauge whether he would really use it before we threw a bunch of money on a fancy one. Right out of the box this is an easy to use machine, very simple and straightforward. You will need to purchase a frothing cup to froth the milk, we've done it in a coffee cup a few times, but we were putting way too much milk in. The frothing cup that we purchased has measurements on the side to help with that. Overall I am happy with this purchase, my husband uses it, it's easy enough for anyone to use and it wasn't too expensive
title: Right out of the box this is an easy to use machine
bought_model: Color: CappuccinoStyle Name: 4-Cup Steam

review_content: I am so impressed by our Mr. Coffee espresso machine. The size is great for us. We have limited counter space in our house, and the espresso machine is so compact that it has a permanent spot on the countertop. I was intimidated because I did not know how to use an espresso machine. It is the easiest thing in the world!!!! Easier than brewing coffee--seriously! it is super self-explanatory. The ONLY "negative" thing I found out about it is the milk frother. I don't even hardly use it because it doesn't come very far out from the machine itself, so to actually swirl the milk to get it frothy and heated through consistently is a pain. Believe it or not, I have scraped my knuckles trying to swirl a glass measuring cup underneath it. I just heat my milk in the microwave while the espresso is brewing. It doesn't give it that frothy texture, but who cares....when you have 10-15 minutes in the morning before going to work, you are not going to mess with the milk frother anyway! Overall, I give it a 10/10!
title: GREAT espresso machine, so well worth the money!
bought_model: Color: CappuccinoStyle Name: 4-Cup Steam

review_content: As I type this, I am sipping on a large expresso from the Mr. Coffee ECMP50.  I've been enjoying the best home brewed coffee of my life since the purchase of the machine.  My expectations were low considering the comparison of the price of the Mr. Coffee machine and the other more popular and much more expensive machines on the market.  But after trying several different coffees, the machine produces the best coffee I have ever been able to produce in my own kitchen. Yes, it is a bit cumbersome to use and clean, especially the milk steamer, and it took a bit to learn to use, but for the price, I could not be happier.  I find I enjoy the expresso more than cappuccino, so that in itself makes production simpler.  I hope it proves reliable and long lived in use, but we will see.  I use it every morning, and like the clean looks of the machine sitting on the counter.  All in all, a great buy for me - even more so being that the machine was used (looked new) and purchased at a nice discount. As my first adventure into the world of producing high quality coffee drinking experience, this machine was an excellent choice, so far.

review_content: This is the second time I have purchased the Mr. Coffee ECM160.  The first machine lasted about two years, which is a lot less than the 10 years a different make/brand (that cost twice as much money) with exactly the same functions lasted before it gradually died.  One morning I went to make my usual cup and without any warning - it just didn't work, the water wouldn't heat, nothing.  So I purchased this model again because it is easy to use and for my purpose which is making one cup of coffee without any steaming it is fast and no fuss.  The cost is reasonable even if I only did get 2 years out of it.  I did not use the steaming function or wand at all so I cannot review those functions.  If this machine lasts substantially longer than 2 years, I might change my rating which is average at this point.  It is what I would expect for the price but I thought I would get at least 5 years from the machine, hence only 3 stars.
title: Mr. Coffee ECM160 4-Cup Espresso Machine

review_content: I have had my Mr. Coffee ECMP50 for a couple of months and it works great.  I had the same maker from a couple of years ago and the pump went out, but after 2 years I was satisfied for the price.  This machine makes a consistent espresso and the foaming wand works great; not too aggressive that the milk is foaming all over the place like another machine that I had bought first, but replaced for this much less expensive one. I actually read up on how to foam milk, temp and wand depth really influence how your foam comes out!  The foam is dense and creamy when you use cow milk and a little more light and bubbbly when using almond or flax milk, which is what I use. I removed the rubber thing from the foaming wand. I am very satisfied and am happy to have such an inexpensive product that is reliable and does exactly what it says it does!

review_content: Anyone who rated this product with more than one star likely didn't use it very much or didn't have it for very long.  After a couple weeks of using this maybe every other day, the top cap broke inside causing steam to explode out from the top of the unit loud enough to compare to a gun shot.  Thank god no one was close to it.  Just to see if it was a one off mishap, we looked at other sources and noted that this is apparently extremely common with these brewing devices.  Some reported the brewing tray exploding out of the bottom, causing the glass to shatter all over their kitchen.  This think is a bomb waiting to explode.  Don't buy it.
title: Anyone who rated this product with more than one star ...
bought_model: Color: CappuccinoStyle Name: 4-Cup Steam

review_content: I always loved Mr. Coffee.  It was the first machine I bought for my mother and her machine lasted over 25 years.  It was a coffee maker.  So when I wanted an espresso-cappuccino machine, I bought a Mr. Coffee.  That was about 10 or 12 years ago. It worked quite well. This is a newer generation of the machine - and I've tried 2 of the same model.  I am convinced after time after time of trying every instruction, knowledge of using their products for years, reading on frothing, speaking to customer reps ... that the thing cannot ever produce a decent anything.  Not a decent espresso (too weak), not a decent latte (no good steam) and certainly never on this earth a possibility of a decent cappuccino.  I do not care what "READS THE INSTRUCTIONS" wrote.  Sorry, but that's baloney. I did it to the letter.  Perfect grind. Perfect temp for the frothing pitcher. Tip just "barely" under the milk ... Oh, it can SCALD the hands well .. It cannot froth.  It cannot.  I would know.  I tried it for month after month.  Read every darned instruction and did it to the letter "T".  And I know darned well the first machines I had of Mr. Coffee Espresso-Cappuccino worked. I know how to froth.  I went to the library. Read several books.  Talked to people who do it for a living.  Talked to customer service for suggestions. And heaven knows I did every single thing it said to in the instructions. The thing DOES NOT WORK.  I am certain that it is incapable of frothing.  I think the new generation machine has a frothing mechanism fault and brew problem somewhere.  I don't care what anyone else here has written - I'm telling you - it's not a good machine and quality control should recheck the thing. It used to be (early version) a better, useable, workable, good product. It no longer is. I don't care what anyone else has written here.  The machine does not froth. It doesn't.  These people do not know what steam or froth is, apparently.
title: I'm Sorry - But It Sucks - Honestly

review_content:
I really do not have any idea how to rate this. I bought it as a replacement of my old and loved Mr. Coffee.
As usual the delivery from Amazon was super-faster. The problem was, the 2 filters did not have "holes", so, they were useless.
I contact Amazon and they asked me to send it back and they will send a new one, the usual. But, I realized the filter of my old Mr. Coffee, fits perfectly, and the coffee I prepared with the new machine was superlative, really a delicious espresso. So, I told Amazon Customer Service I did not want to send the machine back, that they can just send the filters. Well, they do not work in this way, THEY SENT ME ANOTHER MACHINE AND ASKED ME TO KEEP BOTH !!!!. AMAZING AMAZON !!!.
But, as soon I received (3 days) and I checked, could you believe, the filters had the same problem, no "holes".
I couldn't tell Amazon, I think all they have, have the same problem, and I can use mine with the old filters.
For the price, this is a great Espresso maker, faster than the previous model I own. I gave 3 starts, just because the problem with the filters, but, do not hesitate to buy from Amazon, they know how to deal with this kind of problems, they are five starts.

review_content:
I gave this thing 4 stars despite the fact that it leaked water all over my counter...twice. Based on the other rave reviews the unit has gotten I'm certain that this has to be a manufacturing defect, and not a design flaw.

I would call this the perfect cappuccino/espresso machine but for one thing: the portions are tiny. I really wish MC offered a "4-cup" model, or a replacement, large capacity porta-filter. Even if I use the "Double"/Large filter basket, the resulting "Large" cappuccino barely hits the halfway mark on a regular coffee cup.

I can find nothing else like this in a 4-cup or double capacity size for less that $500 on the web - anywhere. I'd trade my kid for a 4-cup version of this...
title: So...close
bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Espresso/Cappuccino Maker

review_content:
There are few adjustable settings but it makes good espresso. Milk system is easy to use and clean. ESE coffee pods are a little tight but everything works.

Addendum:
After a few weeks I ordered a filter basket for ese pods from Mr Coffee. It works great; perfect volume and lots of crema.
title: well designed
bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Espresso/Cappuccino Maker

review_content:
First of all I have worked at a starbucks cafe in which I got to use the more industrial machine as well as had training in how to make the various drinks that people are so familiar with.

This machine is definitely a good and reliable machine for home use. I have had no problems with this so far and I have owned then for some time now. It has also helped me curb my latte budget. I do recommend that whoever buys this gets a good stainless steel steamer container with a good thermometer as you will need that to gauge when the milk is ready (generally 160 degrees is good for adults, 170 to 180 degrees is good for extra hot, and 110 to 120 is good for children...at least that the starbucks way).

The brewing seems to be good. I have had no issues with the taste of the expresso at all. Please note that I do not consider my self a coffee connoisseur. I am more of a tea person but I do drink a lot of coffee and I am very picky about the brand of coffee that I drink.

If you want a home machine this will do well and since it is a pump machine this is better then a purely steam driven machine.
title: Great machine for home use
bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Automatic Dual Shot

review_content: This machine does what it's supposed to do. It makes really good drinks. The only drawbacks I've found is that it's rather loud. It would be nice if it had a little storage thing attached to it too for all the stuff that comes with it. The first time I used it, it also leaked a little water out of the tank at the bottom. However it hasn't done it since so I must've not had it sealed correctly. Overall I'd recommend it, it's an affordable machine and will save you a ton of money if you visit the coffee shacks twice a day.

review_content: This machine worked great in the beginning but the frother started to break down over the course of just months.  I have owned this machine for about  1 1/2 years and it worked wonderfully when new.  I had a problem when after about 4-5 months it stopped frothing.  I contacted the company and they were very quick to replace it.  Now on my second machine and I have the same problem.  It's actually the top of the milk container that has the frothing unit built in, I have twice ordered new ones and it worked great for about 4 months and then started to break down. What happens is the  milk comes through very fast not heating up at all and not frothing.  Disappointed because other than the problem with the frother it's a good machine.  Just for reference I use this machine on average twice a day so about 14 lattes/ week.
title: Great unit until problems begin after 4 months
bought_model: Color: RedStyle Name: Espresso/Cappuccino Maker

review_content:
I'm not a barista, but have owned those $20-$30 espresso makers for years and have frothed my own milk with them.
I got this for Christmas and I think it's great, but here are a few things to keep in mind.

First, at this price point, it does a great job. Especially frothing the milk. It's nice to just press a button and it makes it all for you.
Clean up is fairly quick as well.
Keep in mind the price point though. Don't expect this to compete with those thousand dollar machines. There's a reason why this costs $800 less than those.

2nd, In all the pictures, they show a full cafe style cup. It takes 2 cycles to get that. The espresso "porta-filter" can do 2 shots at a time, as opposed to most espresso machines which can do 4. So to run 2 cycles, you basically load it up, press your drink selection twice, then you got to clean it out, and reload it for the 2nd cycle to get enough to fill a cup. So that is a bit of a hassle.
I've looked at the Mr. Coffee website for a quad shot filter and portafilter (what they call the thing with the handle as it can't fit a larger basket than the double shot) and the double is the largest they sell.
I had hoped I could use the one from my espresso maker (it is a Bella) but it doesn't fit. The it has 2 tabs while the the mr. coffee one has 3 so I can't line it up to use it. Probably for the best.
That would really be my cheif complaint.
I'd like it to be able to hold enough espresso to do a complete cup full without me having to clean and reload the espresso basket after the first "2 shot" cycle.

Something else I thought was odd:
In all my years of using those $20-$30 espresso machine, even when using a full 4 shot basket of espresso grounds, after making it, and removing the espresso grounds, they were always dry, no moisture left as it had all been pushed through the grounds into the cup. Makes sense.
With this Mr. Coffee Barista, despite trying different levels of grinding, I never get that "dry brick" of grounds. It's always wet, runny, and once even had a puddle in it. So it's like it's not even fully using the double shot of espresso grinds I give it.
I did read the complete manual before use so I didn't take any shortcuts.

Overall though, I think it is a great machine for the price and I'm still new to using it so maybe I'll figure out these quirks as I get used to it.
title: Overall it's great and worth it, but here's what I think could be better.
bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Espresso/Cappuccino Maker

review_content: This was a great purchase.  It makes delicious, effortless espresso drinks.  The best part is the milk pitcher, which can be stored in the fridge when not in use... meaning that you don't have to fill the milk up every time you want a latte/cappuccino, and you don't have to throw away the extra milk left in the pitcher when your done making your latte/cappuccino.  That being said, it is not a perfect machine.  Here are some cons: (1) I always add an extra shot of espresso to my coffee drinks because I think that the amount dispensed is not enough to make a small latte; it's not a big deal, you just push the espresso button after the latte function is finished and voila, problem solved; (2) the finished product could be a little hotter - I like the temperature but my husband prefers a hotter beverage.  I have no reservations recommending this.  I will say that I purchased the 4 year warranty because some negative comments here suggested that the machine leaked or lost pressure over time - I figured that I would risk it because the machine is at a much lower price point than its competitors ($400+ less!!) and the warranty gives me 4 years of unlimited repairs/replacements/refund for a measly $10 bucks or so.
title: Buy with the super-cheap 4 year warranty - its a no brainer on price/value.
bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Espresso/Cappuccino Maker

review_content: I have had this for two years, purchased at Walmart. When I first used it, it worked fine, but it takes some trial and error to get the perfect cup, but I eventually got the perfect cup of coffee (you have to pack the grounds or you'll get weak coffee, but not too tight or you'll have issues with the machine). The frother didn't work well for me, so I stuck with creamer. The machine is slow for only one cup of coffee. I rarely use it in the morning because it is so slow and only use it on weekends. After two years, even with regular cleanings, it started smelling every time I brewed. I thought it just needed another cleaning. Nope, after another cleaning, it still stunk. Not a normal coffee smell, either. It was a metallic smell. I may try another cleaning to see if that does the trick (and I have deep cleaned the metal parts to get rid of the tarnish. Still no luck).  If it still stinks, I'm getting a Keurig because I love the one at work (I may get one anyway because this one sits on my counter all week since I don't have time in the mornings to use it)!
title: Worked great for brewing at first, now is slow and smells
bought_model: Color: CappuccinoStyle Name: 4-Cup Steam

review_content:
Hello Amazon! I bought this for a gift and recently had a chance to use this item first hand. Here is my review. The machine comes with everything pictured and works great. The coffee is excellent and easy to make and the frothing was excellent....especially with the Soy milk used for mine. Simple and tasty. If I had to complain about anything (and the person I bought this for pointed it out have a good deal of use)...is that the switch on the side does not allow for you to switch between one action to the other without activating the drip....which causes a small mess when it shouldn't. It would have been easier to simply have 2 buttons to push...one for brewing and the other for frothing..... That being said the rest of the experience is excellent and the coffee is very good! The unit is well made too! Enjoy!

Mr. Coffee Automatic Dual Shot Espresso/Cappuccino System
title: Not your parents Mr. Coffee machine!
bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Automatic Dual Shot

review_content: I start my day, everyday with 2-3 cappuccinos made with the least expensive machine you can find here on Amazon or at the big box stores. I've made thousands and thousands of cappuccinos over the years! I've used a couple cheap Braun machines in the past - can't find them anymore. So now I make a cappuccino or latte that I'll take the Pepsi Challenge against Starbucks or damn near any other American coffee shop - with a $28 Mr. Coffee espresso machine and Jacobs coffee. That's right $28 here on Amazon - I just bought my second Mr. Coffee machine. The one I've had for 4-years wore out. I laugh when I see these idiots at Starbucks pounding the stainless steel pitcher full of milk on the counter. Making all that racket - for what? You steamed/foamed milk and now you need to pound on the counter to beat the foam down? Watch them closely someday - watch how much milk these numbskulls waste! Moreover, the machines they use cost thousands of dollars. They've been trained and some of them have worked there for decades - and they still don't know how to make a decent cappuccino. I love how they brag about how good they are at "pulling shots." They're goofy. The Mr. Coffee espresso machine will last 2-3, maybe 4 years with the multiple/daily use that I give it. The steamer nozzle wears out and the moving parts get loose. Chuck it - buy a new one. Also, ignore the comments about tasting metal and plastic. These people are on crack. I've actually tested the water that's been cycled through my Mr. Coffee machine 6 times - no metals detected down to 5 PPB level. I don't smell anything except the Jacobs Kronung coffee. Which btw I also highly recommend. You can buy that here on Amazon in bulk. Check it out - you'll be glad you did!
title: I'll beat those numbskulls at Starbucks any day with this sucker!
bought_model: Color: CappuccinoStyle Name: 4-Cup Steam

review_content: Although I did not purchase this from Amazon, (I actually got it at the W) I would like to write a review that may help people. First off, so far (and I have had this machine 1 month) this is the best Espresso Machine I have ever had so far. I ONLY drink lattes. I never have regular coffee at home. I only have regular coffee at work because unfortunately they do not have espresso. But this is really a great machine. I bought it because I have the Rivo and 1. It's really hard to find the coffee pods and 2. They are VERY expensive. The reason I like this machine so much if you can do many different combinations for your prepared drink. I have found my favorite brew is to push the espresso button once, then I push the Latte button twice. This way I get a single shot espresso first then steamed milk then a double shot of espresso again. Also, note that the knob on the front of the milk frother can be adjusted depending on how much foam you want. I usually keep it in the middle. I like a little foam but mostly steamed milk. I wanted to make sure you knew you can do many different combos. You can also push the button to stop it if you are getting too much milk.Sometimes I want a large cup so I will push the espresso button twice then the latte button twice. Also note you can add more froth by holding down the cappuccino button for 3 seconds then stop it whenever you want by hitting it again. I usually clean it every week by putting water with a small amount of white vinegar in the frother and following instructions for cleaning the machine with vinegar in the reservoir. Make sure your espresso grounds are not too fine or packed too tight or the the water won't go through. I like Lavazza Perfetto or I grind my own. Amazon sells a great coffee I buy by the 5 pound bag. Coffee Bean Direct. And I also like Lavazza's Super Crema. I think if this machine is cleaned regularly it will last. I may be wrong as I have seen some people have gone through several machines and I use this hard. 3-4 cups a day. So we shall see. I will do an update in a year.  Do not ever removed the reservoir. Just use a pitcher to keep filling it. This way you won't damage the port the water goes through and it won't leak. I have found this is the best way to prevent any damage. Enjoy.
title: Love This Machine
bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Espresso/Cappuccino Maker

review_content: Makes excellent espresso-based drinks! Comes with a nice booklet of recipes/ideas as well.  Would rate at 4.5 stars if I could.  Why not 5?  1) After brewing, there's always a little bit of coffee grounds stuck to the underside of the water discharge (above where the porta-filter attaches), which needs to be wiped off and is messy. 2) Our first machine broke within one week (would no longer pump water through the coffee/espresso porta-filter), but Amazon quickly sent a replacement and prepaid UPS return label for the old one, and the replacement machine is working fine after 3 weeks.  3) Once finished brewing, it continues to drip a little (unlike our Keurig), which means the little tray under your coffee cup always needs to be cleaned/rinsed.  Not a big deal tho.  I really like how the milk part of the machine has an automatic steam-clean function that cleans the milk-related plumbing easily.  Definitely recommended.
title: An Affordable Machine That Sounds and Works Like the Expensive Ones
bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Espresso/Cappuccino Maker

review_content: I researched based on value. I wanted the best espresso for the least cash. I looked at many different options and chose based on our needs. I wanted a real coffee experience and not pods and the potential chemicals that may be associated. This is not as convenient as a pod machine, let me say that. However, I can choose my coffee, make my own blends, grind fresh roasted beans. In my research I discovered that coffee loses some flavor once ground and not used shortly after. Many coffee intellectuals seem to be committed to two things. First a high-quality grinder, some say to budget at least half of what you spent on your espresso machine. A good grinder makes for a consistent grind, maximizing your flavor. The other is that you grind fresh and high-quality beans. We have yet to experiment with fresh ground and I can gladly say I'm already pleased. We've tried Illy Medium roast and Peet's Major Dickason's Dark Roast. Peet's is great as drip coffee, but it shined in our Barista machine. I'm glad we spent the extra for the milk frother included with this machine. Minus a couple minutes to load the coffee, this is nearly as convenient as a pod machine (there is a bit of cleanup too, but something I can live with). You'll have fun trying the different options. I found I like to do a double espresso, then use the cappuccino button with the frother set to latte first, then to cappuccino froth (via the dial) for the last third. If you want to bump up your experience put a few drops of vanilla in your milk prior to frothing. I haven't seen any quality concerns, especially if you clean properly and follow directions. It appears leaving the coffee arm in the machine can weaken the seal over time. Also, slacking with frother cleaning doesn't seem to be wise. Again, it seems easy enough to clean. I think we may purchase the extended warranty, only because we enjoy this machine so much. In closing, So, I've purchased a manual ceramic burr grinder and will mod it with my drill (yes, this is a thing), and combine that with some fresh beans in my pursuit of very delicious coffee. I'm not the world's greatest coffee connoisseur, but I enjoy the finer things and pay close attention to culinary experiences. I've enjoyed very flavorful coffee further enjoyed when combined with the creamy/frothy milk addition. If Starbucks or the local shop is vastly superior, I can't tell the difference, I can only see the savings.
title: This is the sweet spot for excellent, yet affordable coffee.
bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Espresso/Cappuccino Maker

review_content:
My husband ordered this for me for Christmas. I was thrilled! I had read the reviews and decided that this was the best one for me and put it on my wish list.
I opened it, read and followed all the directions for setup and excitedly made my first cup of coffee. I was rather surprised to find that it was rather weak! I loved the steamed milk, but the coffee kept dripping out of the basket, like in a drip coffee maker.
I tried again, thinking I had done something wrong - same results.
I continued like this for a couple of days, trying different combinations of latte, espresso and cappuccino, not really liking any of the product, finding it more like drip coffee than an espresso product - NOT what I wanted.
I came back and read the very helpful review from the person who suggested running vinegar through it. (That was a GREAT review!)
I followed all of the directions in the manual again for the vinegar rinse-out followed by plain water to remove the vinegar - took about 3 hours in total. (I was VERY dedicated to making this machine work!) I got out my candy thermometer and the temp never reached above 170F - not quite hot enough.
I tried another cup of espresso, finding the same results of about a 1/4" of water still remaining in the grounds. *sigh*
I called Mr Coffee. They immediately offered to replace the unit with a newer model (1102, even though there IS an 1106 being produced). This had appeal to me, but would then void our warranty with Amazon, if it did not work correctly like the one we purchased.
In the end, we returned it to Amazon for a refund. I am not willing to spend that amount of money for drip coffee - bottom line.
I believe we were treated fairly by Mr Coffee (which is why I gave it 3 stars and not 1), and by Amazon, but ultimately, this is not the machine for me.

review_content: Makes awesome cappuccino, but mediocre espresso. Basically there's no crema on the espresso it produces, but this is to be expected with a steam based espresso machine. You need a pump based one for the really good stuff. Still, for making quick, strong, coffee this thing cannot be beat. Also unlike traditional coffee makers, you don't need to buy any filters. The downside is that to do it properly, you probably should be grinding your own beans because this thing is designed to use super fine ground coffee, which you just can't get at grocery stores. Even the store bought Starbucks Espresso Roast coffee isn't fine enough, as it's ground only good enough for traditional coffee makers.

review_content: I watched a video online about this machine before purchasing that was posted by an individual which helped me take a chance.  I'm GLAD I did! I wanted to wait a couple of months before posting my review to make sure there weren't any issues.  You definitely want to get the 8 or 10 oz stainless steamer cup if you want to do Latte's or Mocha's (our favorites).  So Far I've made over 50 beverages using this and LOVE every cup.  I've actually become a fan of just plain espresso drinks (with the "S" company's "Expresso/Espresso?" Blend coffee beans, don't cheap out get the good stuff in a dark espresso bean).  The steamer function works great (again after watching a "training Video") and no issues.  Saves me a lot of time on the weekends driving to the "S" place to get my wifes skinny vanilla latte, and mine taste EXACTLY the same!  Awesome and a great Value.  Even if it craps out now, I'd by another one to replace.

review_content: This is awesome!  We've used the milk frother with regular and chocolate milk.  The chocolate doesn't froth as much but it makes making a mocha easier.  It's super easy to use and clean.  It's paid for itself already in saving us trips to buy fancy coffee drinks.  I highly recommend this.
title: It's paid for itself already!
bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Espresso/Cappuccino Maker

review_content:
I just wanted an inexpensive Espresso maker (I don;t use the foamer but accidentally turned it on once and can tell it definitely works!!) and Mr. Coffee has never failed me. I have a Mr. Coffee drip coffee maker but grew tired of making a pot in the morning if I was only going to have one cup; I was wasting coffee and it was the strength I was looking for.

I use this to just make a strong cup of coffee. I buy lighter roast beans, grind them right before I use the machine (seriously like an extra minute - and tastes so much better - if you're going to use a machine like this, at least grind the beans!!) pack a two-shot of espresso (comes with a one-shot and two-shot insert) and let it fill almost to the top of a regular coffee mug. If your mug doesn't fit, you can easily pull out the tray (just be sure to wipe up the tiny bit of water than drains out of the machine, which is meant to go into the drainage tray) to fit a larger mug. You get a beautiful frothy top and a great tasting cup of strong, fresh coffee!!! If you want a shot or a cappuccino, that's all up to you!

It's SOOOO easy to use. May seem a bit cheap because of the plastic water reservoir, etc., but nothing feels loose or like it's going to just fall off. Easy to clean, easy to lock in the coffee holderoony, and to use! Just BEWARE, it does not stop itself (wouldn't make sense if it did), so you have to watch it - you'll get used to how much time it takes for the amount you want. And it doesn't have auto-shutoff which is fine, I'm good at remembering, but my boyfriend is not, therefore a sticky note was in order.

The holding tray at the top is mighty helpful for storing the little shot holders (sorry, do not know what to call them), and the packing spoon. Be sure to fill up the water reservoir!

Overall, very easy to use, makes great coffee, and you don't have to spend hundreds of dollars!!
title: Exactly what I was looking for!
bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Automatic Dual Shot

review_content:
Don't be fooled by its little size. This espresso maker will brew enough espresso to make 2 - 20 Oz. lattes at the same time in less then 10 minutes. I have purchased bigger fancier units that only brew half the amount of espresso, causing you to have to brew 2 times every morning (we returned that one).

Hint: warm your milk in the microwave while the espresso is brewing and it will steam/froth much faster.

title: HIGH MAINTENANCE, HIGH RISK
bought_model: Color: CappuccinoStyle Name: 4-Cup Steam

review_content:
I'll tell ya just how good this machine is. I've spent many months looking to replace the $150 DeLongi machine I had for 2 yrs which began leaking after the 4th week. I caught the reviews on this machine and decided to give it a shot since it was only $60. Much to my amazement, this machine ROCKS! I've been using it DAILY making a minimum of (60-80oz) of Espresso for the 3 of us here for over 3 months now and it keeps running like a champ. (60-80oz) PER DAY is alot of espresso and a enormous task to ask of a $60 machine but this things handles it no problem.

The Tamper isn't to hot but it works decently. Most people like to have their own special tamper anyways. Heat up is quick, the crema is plentiful, simple controls, & takes up little space. The ONLY downside I can think of to this machine is it IS a bit noisier than others, but not by much, but it makes up for that in speed, quality of espresso & reliability + cost. For the price, I didn't care if I had to pay an extra $5-10 for a frothing pitcher ( I had one anyway from the prior DeLongi).

When you consider just how much Espresso I've made so far, it could of died within the first month and I still would of saved a bunch of money compared to paying $4 a drink at SB. I have my beans ground at SB on their espresso machine setting which makes them very fine and this machine has no problem pushing the water through. I believe the secret lies in not tamping the grinds to much. When done correctly, very fine grinds produce a better flavor IMO. The adjustable frothing wand is a nice touch, but definitely toss the rubber tip. I'm so impressed with this machine for the money, I bought a 2nd one and stored it away just in case they quit making it.
I have made my version of a SB white Hot Mocha for dozens of my friends & neighbors and ALL say mine tastes much better than the SB version. I wipe off the grinds from underneath each time to keep the seal tight and to prevent any bitter taste from occurring. I also use water that's filtered through my home water softener system then through my R/O system (a must here in AZ as tap water is horrible) and that improves taste and no calcium build up at all yet. I will update my review in 6 months time and then again at 1 year. I do believe this machine is about the best deal one can get on a espresso machine under $100.

title: Daily cappuccinos

review_content:
This is a review for both the original one that I ordered with a defective steam wand, and for the replacement that came with the control knob that broke off my second time using it.

I've had this machine before, albeit, it was ten years ago and I believe I bought it at Walmart, but I figured it could have only gotten better with time (I gave my old one to a friend, but it worked for many years with zero problems). It also helped that the price had dropped and there was a $6 off coupon (I had been watching this for months, debating whether or not it was worth the purchase).

So let's get down to it ... The first package arrived only in the Mr. Coffee box with a shipping label on it, which I was pretty peeved about, considering it is "sold and shipped by Amazon." The box was also beat up, which concerned me since there were fragile elements inside like a FLIPPING GLASS CARAFE. Luckily, nothing was broken. I used it about three times before I realized the steam wand was just sputtering out yucky hot water into my milk cup, and I knew there was a problem, so I figured I would try again with a replacement.

I should also mention, the multiple reviews that state that there are metal shavings in the water upon initial uses are absolutely true. I flushed this baby out five times, and I still had little, itty bitty metal pieces in my carafe. NOT GOOD.

So the replacement is ordered. I'm a Prime member, so I expected two day shipping. I ordered the replacement on a Thursday. It should have been here Saturday. Apparently not. I get a notice saying it's an hour away from me and also delayed. The Amazon rep tells me it's being delivered VIA POST OFFICE. Um, no. That's not why I pay for a Prime membership. So I'm annoyed but still patient and the package arrives on Sunday -- AGAIN NOT IN AN AMAZON BOX BUT IN THE MR. COFFEE BOX ITSELF WITH JUST A SHIPPING LABEL STICKER!!! Oh, and the box was beaten up and the tape was undone, so the side of it was partially opened. THANKS, AMAZON!

Everything looked okay inside said box, so I made a latte. It seemed to work fine that night, but the next morning when I went to make another, while doing the espresso, the knob broke clean off -- so the other reviewers are correct. THIS IS A TOTAL PIECE OF CRAP. If you're going to buy it, you should probably buy it from a reputable company and not Amazon (because their selling and shipping department is rubbish).

TLDR; DON'T BUY IT. ALL THE REVIEWS ARE TRUE. IT'S CRAP.
title: DON'T BUY IT.
bought_model: Color: CappuccinoStyle Name: 4-Cup Steam

review_content:
I have had this little espresso machine for about 3 weeks now. I really love it! I've read up on lots and lots of introductory information about espresso. I've watched countless online videos. Although I felt a little overwhelmed in the beginning, I think I'm starting to get a hang of how to use this particular machine. Here's what I've learned --- (feel free to correct me if you see that I've gotten something wrong!):

In the beginning, I tried to to put 17 grams of fresh grinds from a conical burr grinder into the double basket portafilter. Seventeen grams was the number I kept finding online. I just couldn't make this happen. This was too much coffee. I finally came across a site where someone mentioned that some semi-automatic machines (which I think this is) have smaller baskets. The commercial portafilters and larger consumer machines have baskets that are closer to 53mm-58mm. This one is around 49mm-50mm. I dropped the grams down to 13 grams and that amount fits with very little brushed off the top.

I tried tamping to the recommended 30 pounds of pressure, but found that the water couldn't get through the grinds very well - causing long pulls - even when I changed up the grind size to drip coffee size. After watching some videos of this particular machine with novices who didn't really tamp at all and seemed to be making great drinks, I found another site that stated pressurized portafilters don't require the same type of tamping because they are designed more for a novice with less room for error. Since this machine is meant for this type of user, I wondered if that might mean this is a pressurized basket. Again, correct me if you are certain this is wrong, but I do believe these are pressurized baskets based on the sloping screen forcing the water into a holding space before pushing through the bottom holes. I'm assuming that's why tamping at 30 pounds of pressure actually created a water holding puck instead of a brick puck.

So, for science's sake, I tried to tamp at 15 pounds of pressure and found the water moved through at a rate of about 25 seconds for a double shot. The espresso was not bitter or sour and the after-puck wasn't water-logged. Although this tamp pressure is not recommended on the 'here's how you pull an espresso' sites, this seemed to produce a better tasting product. And that's ultimately what I wanted, right? :)

At this point, I've made many lattes and affogatos (espresso over ice-cream). The only true negative I see is that the temperature comes out exactly drinkable, which means the drink cools VERY quickly. I wished that it came out about 10 degrees hotter. I did prime it as recommended and ran vinegar through it to see if that helped the heating element (it didn't).

Overall, I'm very pleased with this purchase. I can see myself using this for a year or so to get the hang of things and then possibly upgrading to something that gives me a bit more ability to influence the steps along the way.

If you want something that is basically automatic, I think you will be overly pleased with this purchase!

review_content:
After reading the reviews on this I asked for this for my Birthday. My very old steam Oster Espresso maker was literally on its last legs, and wow, I even hate to compare the two. The ECMP50 is so far above it, I can't believe I didn't get it sooner. The water reservoir is great, its quiet, it heats up FAST. . .I LOVE THIS APPLIANCE. Okay, I said it! I do not make many unequivocal recommendations, but if you are looking for a way to make your latte at home, this is totally the machine to buy. You can have a latte in your hand in less than 5 minutes.

Like other reviews, its easy to use, I have not noticed any leaks - others may not be emptying the drip reservoir under the stainless plate - just a guess. It fills more quickly than you expect-I probably empty it twice a week and I use my machine at least once a day. I generally don't use a steaming can for my milk and just steam my milk in the mug. I have found that my stainless travel mug works great and easily sits under the steamer without needing to hold it there.

As recommended by another reviewer, I do not use the rubbery thing over the frothing arm. I just cant believe its sanitary and the arm wipes clean easily if its cleaned right after use.

I have a coffee grinder that allows you to select the fineness of the grind and the Espresso setting is perfect. (Its a Hamilton Beach, but I'm sure there are others.) Recommend grinding your own that way you know the grind is right.

The only problems I've had with this have been user error! Like not realizing the water reservoir was dry and leaving my milk frothing too long and it boiled all over. What a mess, don't do that! LOL

Great product that makes a great gift for yourself or another Espresso addict!
title: Absolutely Wonderful!
bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Automatic Dual Shot

review_content: I am so disappointed in this version. I have now gone through 3 new ones - exact same model and they ALL LEAK. I have already had two of these exact models in the last 10 years easily and they all work(ed) great back home. I got this one as a gift for my sister - mostly so I can make lattes when I visit her - and I've given it every chance and have replaced twice.. guess third time is not a charm. It will be getting returned tomorrow and I'll be moving on to another brand. That's a bummer and a waste of my time, Mr. Coffee. You lost another customer.
title: Third one and they all leak. Waste.
bought_model: Color: CappuccinoStyle Name: 4-Cup Steam

review_content:
I bought this machine in September 2009 to stem the cost of my grad school latte habit. It's worked well for me for almost 4 years but has succumbed to the problems many other reviewers have had. About 4 months ago it began leaking from underneath. The leak steadily grew worse to the point that it now will not pump water through the grounds. This was actually the 2nd of this machine I had because the first, purchased at Target, did not work at all and was immediately exchanged.

It seems like there are some design flaws that result in an inconsistent lifespan. My other issue with this machine was how short the frothing wand is. I don't always use steamed milk, but it was very difficult not to get A LOT of froth because the wand just didn't extend far enough into the milk (I always used a coffee mug because nothing else was short enough). It makes good espresso and mine had a nice long life, but it seems like that may have been the exception.

review_content: Received this as a Christmas gift. It's so easy to use . Milk and espresso shots are nice and hot. Easy to clean. Also pretty fast I'm able to make a double shot latte in about five mins.

review_content: I was giving this as a gift about four years ago. This has leaked since day one. A trip to the hardware store for a small runner washer was enough to have it limp along for a year of limited use, even then I couldn't fill it much more than 1/3 full of water or risk having it leak. It got bad enough to where I didn't really use it. Now it leaks all the time. It's sitting in a cookie sheet so it doesn't cause too much havoc. Giving it two starts since it works fine when it isn't leaking like a rusty boat. Hate to throw out a $85 (price I paid at the time) coffee maker, but it may be time. I would NOT by this model of given the choice.

Maybe it is because I am inexperienced at frothing, but I usually get so many light bubbles that they overflow. I solve the problem by constantly blowing on the bubbles to pop them and while this works for my husband and I, I wouldn't want to do that for company. I am only frothing 1 cup of milk at a time in a 12 oz container. I do find that the espresso is pretty good. Tips on frothing would be appreciated.
title: Mr. coffee espresso/steamer

review_content:
Purchased this early May 2016 for $29.95 (model ECM160-NP) so I can save money on my twice-a-day lattes. Very happy with how it works but it took some practice for the first five or six brews, so do not get frustrated. I found out that the key is the how fine the coffee is ground. I found that the pre-ground coffee you buy at stores is too coarse for this machine. So, I bought a $15 Mr. Coffee blade grinder, and it works perfectly.

Do not listen to the marketers when they tell you that you need an expensive burr grinder for espresso machines. You don't. You just need to be careful with an ordinary, cheap blade grinder. Do not use the grinder's automatic setting. I used three-second grinding sessions with its manual push-button, and shook the grinder in between for the coffee to even out inside the grinder for a consistent grind. MAKE SURE that the ground coffee grains are about only as coarse as salt. I did once a bit too fine (like powdered sugar) and it made the coffee machine container jam. Check the grains consistency in between every two 3-second grinder runs.

Also very important: must tamp the coffee down in the coffee puck. I bought a $7 aluminum tamper (50 mm size) that works perfectly well. If the coffee is not well tamped down in the puck, the water just runs thru the coffee grains puck without giving rich espresso.

I followed the instructions in the machine's user manual. The steamer arm on this model is fixed, not adjustable, and a bit too close to the machine. I carefully forced the steamer arm with my palm to about an inch further away from the machine (measuring the bottom end) for more room for the milk pitcher to move around. I also tried the steamer by screwing off the steel frother tip from the end of the steamer arm (inside the plastic cover sleeve) but it made the steam come out a bit too fast and in burst that made the milk splash all over, so I put the tip back on.

I do not like much froth/foam on my latte, so I use 1% fat milk.

Friends -- this machine works well, and it's less than thirty bucks! How long this thing will last -- who knows.

review_content:
After a month of owning and using this product consistently, I have to say this is one of the best purchases I have made in years. Sometimes you simply want a latte and not coffee. The Mr. Coffee Cafe Barista provides a user-friendly, consistent experience that makes great lattes for pennies compared to what you can get at Starbucks. When I set up the machine, the only thing that gave me concern was the water pump was not pulling the water in right away. Letting it sit for about an hour let everything naturally fill up and I haven't had any issues since. I also followed the top product reviewers advice and thoroughly cleaned the machine, running vinegar through it and descaling it. Some reviewers have complained about this step but logically you would clean other dishes when you buy them from the store, why wouldn't you with this?

I also bought the Gourmia GCG195 Stainless Steel Electric Coffee Grinder to provide a consistent grind (settings 4 or 5 work the best). I use it primarily for two sets of double shots. The frother is not great on the cappuccino setting but for the latte setting it provides a consistent result (I drink lattes so make your own decision on cappuccinos). I also run one empty shot before doing anything with actual espresso. It clears out any grounds and also heats the water more.

The only criticisms I have of the machine is some of the design elements. The drawer that comes out for taller glasses is great but the side plastic part being fully removed would work better so I could slide my tall 16 oz glass out of the way as opposed to trying to tilt it in. Otherwise, it is really easy to clean and use. My roommate and I use this about 5-10 times a week and we haven't seen any issues so far. I would recommend doing a full cleaning every other month.

I can't reitterate how user-friendly this purchase is. If you simply want to push some buttons with little fuss, this is the machine for you. I was not paid or given this machine for a review. I bought it with the hopes that it was as good as the reviews made it seem to be. You should consider getting one too.
title: User-Friendly, Affordable and Consistent Results - What More Do You Want?
bought_model: Color: WhiteStyle Name: Espresso/Cappuccino Maker

review_content:
UPDATE ON 14 MAR 10:

Well I originally had nothing but praise for this machine in the first month of operation but after that I became sorely disappointed with it. The frothing arm is too easily blocked. I clean the chamber and frothing arm regularly but it seems that after a few weeks, it simply won't steam anymore. Additionally, before it stopped steaming altogether, the blockage would cause what I considered to be a significant safety hazard. The machine would not steam, but then eventually explode spewing steam and espresso all over the kitchen. I still use this machine when I want a Cafe Americano or just espresso shots but I definitely regret buying it as I can no longer steam milk or do anything else fancy.

ORIGINAL REVIEW:
First I'll preface my review by saying that while I like espresso drinks, I'm NOT a hardcore coffee snob. On a scale of 1-10, with 1 being "I only drink hot chocolate" and 10 being "I only drink the finest coffees straight from Columbia," I'm probably about a 7.

So when I decided to give my coffee maker a break and mix things up a bit, I was pretty intimidated seeing espresso machines running upward of $300. Clearly I was not in the market for something that expensive but I also didn't want something so cheap and worthless that I would never use it. This thing is a home run.

It's easy to use, reasonably stylish, works great, and is priced just right. Although the process of making espresso drinks is much more involved than making a pot of coffee, I find myself going the extra mile often because the flavor is just so much more pronounced. I really can make drinks on par with the local coffee shop for what seems like pennies (espresso uses fewer beans than a pot of coffee too)!

You probably will need some practice to get the process down and find out how best to set up the machine for what you're trying to make (i.e., figuring out how much water you'll need to still have steam available after the espresso is brewed) but after that, it works great.

I fully recommend this product and do yourself a favor and get a frothing pitcher, thermometer, and tamper to make it as smooth as possible.

bought_model: Color: CappuccinoStyle Name: 4-Cup Steam

review_content:
I used to have a steam expresso maker made by Krups. It was terrible. It was a little scary with the high pressure nature of the steam pressure chamber and I had a few problems with removing the filter holder too soon. The milk frothing never worked well. I quit using it because the results were so disappointing. When the coffee maker side finally failed, we chunked it. I didn't have another expresso / cappuccino maker until this Mr. Coffee one. It has a pump and that is essential. The end result is excellent. Frothed milk that is as fluffy as meringue. The grooved black plastic top serves as a "drying rack" for the filter holder and coffee scoop after washing. The steam nozzle is movable to that it protrudes in front when you need it and then swivels beck underneath when you don't. The removable water tank is easy to remove and easy to fill and re-install. There are buttons on the front. Push the coffee brew button and when the ready light turns green, rotate the side control down to brew expresso. When your expresso is done, rotate the control up. It does require watching the process, as noted by others, to cut it off before the brew is too weak. Then to froth milk, you push the steam button and wait until the ready light stops blinking. You then rotate the steam control up for steam. I have a frothing pitcher but use a cup with milk in it and then pour the expresso over it after it is ready to save on dishes. Makes great cappuccino. I would highly recommend.

I received a selection of Austrian coffees for a Christmas present. When I brewed the ones that were not expresso in a drip automatic coffee maker, they were not that great. They were Helmut Sacher gourmet coffee. I have tried brewing these "fine ground coffees" in the Mr. Coffee and the taste is excellent. I remember that in Europe they brew coffee one cup at a time in this type of machine. So it only made sense that to get the "gourmet" part of the coffee, you have to brew them with the right equipment. This is the right equipment.
title: Working great!
