review_content:
Espresso taste is great for as long as the machine last. After only 4 months, my machine's power and ready light started blinking which is an indication that the internal regulator is blown. Customer service is HORRIBLE for Mr. Coffee.

6 month update: My machine was replaced by warranty. The second machine only lasted 2 months before the exact problem happened again. A third machine is now on it's way. If you have not purchased a machine yet, save your money and frustration with this one.
title: Invest in a real machine or do not expect espresso
bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Automatic Dual Shot

review_content:
I've had this Espresso Maker for over a year now, and I have to say this is one of my favorite appliances ever. If you're committed to making coffee daily as an exchange for a store-bought latte or espresso, this machine will be a definite return on your investment. You have to make everything manually, adjusting the knob to

A couple of notes though in my 1+ year of brewing with the Mr. Coffee ECM160:

- The reason I gave this a 4/5 is you need a few other items for the espresso to taste genuine. Most important is a tamper or similar device. It's key for compacting the espresso in the metal basket. If you're on a budget, shotglass is the right size to even compress the espresso grind for an ideal brew.

- You should have a dedicated metal steamer cup. Plastic and Ceramic will get warped if you use them for steaming milk (in my cheapness, I've experienced both).

- In my area, mineral depositing is a problem, so every month or so it's valuable to do the vinegar/water wash of the internals to help clean the inside of the maker.

Anyway, I found this a definitely excellent investment for the espressophile inside me. If you love good espresso but hate the prices, you'll find that this provides a fun alternative with the added bonus of being able to create your concoctions.
title: An Excellent Introduction to the World of Brewing Espresso
bought_model: Color: CappuccinoStyle Name: 4-Cup Steam

review_content:
Firstly, for the beginner or average espresso drinker, this machine is superb and an unbelievable value for the price. I've had no issues with leaks. Also if you're going to buy a espresso machine, make sure it's pump driven...Don't fall for those ~$30 steam powered coffee incinerators.

I've used expensive machines in the past, and I normally wouldn't even consider an espresso machine under $250 but I wanted something cheap for my college apartment.

For the espresso aficionado like myself, I have a few gripes; If you're not SERIOUS about espresso just skip over these:
1. It uses double wall filters. Yes, it takes a lot of guess work out and makes it easy to pull a decent shot, but also takes away part of the experience. I would have liked to see single wall filters included.
2. The steam wand is either 100% FULL ON or OFF. It's also almost impossible to purge the wand. When you turn it on for a moment to purge and then back off, it thinks you're done, the pump recycles, you have to press the steam button again, then it takes another 10 seconds or so before you can turn it back on. This is probably the most annoying thing about the machine.
3. The steam wand is underpowered, it can hardly swirl milk in a 20oz frothing pitcher. Not surprised for the price though.

General Tips:
1. PLEASE don't use pre-ground coffee. It's far too course and will have long oxidized by the time you take it out of the package. Get yourself a quality burr grinder that allows for consistent finely fresh ground coffee.
2. Take off the stupid rubber foam enhancer/silencer. It does nothing but introduce far too much air into the milk, making huge bubbles.
3. Get a nice stainless steel frothing pitcher AND milk thermometer. Ideally you want to surf the milk until about 100*F and then dive it deeper to texture until about 140*F.

If you don't get a grinder and milk thermometer, you might as well just forget about getting an espresso machine and go to Starbucks.

That's my take on it. Feel free to ask questions. :)
title: Great for the price, but a few gripes for the espresso aficionado.
bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Automatic Dual Shot

review_content: I was so happy with this machine that I bought in March until the frother stopped working in July..... I wasn‚Äôt expecting much of this machine because of the price, but 4 months.. seriously? I also cleaned it every time I used it. Don‚Äôt expect Mr. Coffee to give you any help or send you a new machine because they couldn‚Äôt care less. Thanks for Amazon who let me return the machine and refund me my money. Now I can buy a new one that won‚Äôt be from Mr. Coffee..
title: Frother stopped working.
bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Espresso/Cappuccino Maker

review_content:
Going on 2 years. Doesn't make creaa on top of the espresso but still makes very good espresso. Excellent cappuccino maker with plenty of foam. Easily makes hot milk. Quick to bring water to boil. Buy a coffee tamper to compress the grounds in the portafilter basket(Terry's tamper works great and is cheap) because it can make all the difference in the taste of the espresso.
Espresso Tips: Pour filtered water into reservoir then leave cap loose and power it on while preparing to get the coffee ground. Measure the coffee into the filter then tamp it down. (Italian coffee grounds is much smaller than American grounds.) Put the filter and carafe into place and the water should be making a rumbling boiling sound. (To prevent burns, if you see steam is already coming out of the top then turn power off and wait until the steam stops then screw cap tight and turn on.) If you don't see steam yet, quickly screw the water reservoir cap tight. If you put Italian coffee in, it will take more time for the espresso to flow through than American sized grounds. out.
Cappuccino Tips: I make mine in directly in a coffee cup. Put skim or up to 2 percent milk into cup about 1/2 or 3/4 full. Whole milk doesn't foam as well. Sugar as sweetener tastes better than honey. I submerge the steam team in the mug before turning on the steam. After 15 or 20 seconds, the milk is hot then I raise it until the steam tip is just below the surface and the foam is rapidly forming. Shut off then pour espresso into the milk.

Broken glass replacement carafes can found on Amazon.
title: Makes good espesso and great capucino at great price
bought_model: Color: CappuccinoStyle Name: 4-Cup Steam

review_content: Super easy home espresso brewing! If you want to make espresso and cafe drinks at home, but aren't a brewing expert, this is your machine! No manual "pulling" of shots, the machine times the pulls for you. The milk dispenser is easy enough to use, but probably isn't worth it to use and get dirty every time unless you really want foam. This machine does not make coffee, so you might consider a different model if you also want to make traditional drip coffee.
title: Easy Espresso at Home!
bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Espresso/Cappuccino Maker

review_content: I had an $80 per week Starbucks Latte habit.  I know my espresso drinks and am picky about flavor, temperature, and foam.  Recently, I began looking for a home espresso machine to help cut down on my coffee expenditures.  I have had a Starbucks Barista that I spent over $400 on.  It never made good coffee and the steam feature worked so poorly that it would water any milk you tried to heat up using the steam wand.  Then it broke and just didn't seem worth the expense of fixing it. I began looking for a new machine a few weeks ago.  It seemed based on reviews that I would have to spend $500-$700 for a machine that could make decent espresso.  Well, I have a kid in private college and I'm looking to save money at this time, so though it might pay for itself over time, the spotty reviews on the high end machines kept me from making the expenditure.  I finally decided to try the very inexpensive Mr. Coffee ECMP50.  I figured that relatively speaking, it was so inexpensive that if it goes out in a year, I could still buy one yearly for several years and not pay what the high end machines cost.  I didn't expect much.  Boy was I surprised.  The machine makes a really good cup of coffee and has enough power to produce a nice crema on top.  The steaming wand works really well.  I heat my milk up a bit first to get it going, but the foaming action is great.  So far, I'm really pleased.  I'm still experimenting with the fineness of the grounds since I like my espresso fairly stiff, but the coffee I've gotten so far is robust.  Best of all, my machine will pay for itself within a couple of weeks with the savings I'm achieving over retail lattes!  Good job Mr. Coffee! Joe DiMaggio is smiling down on this machine.
title: Excellent Value for a coffeeholic with college tuition bills to pay.
bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Automatic Dual Shot

review_content: I must of needed a caffeine fix when I ordered this as I rarely drink espresso. I just used this machine for the 3rd time since owing it (several months) and it had a major seal leak with steam/water coming out in places it shouldn't. This is the same issue many other reviewers mentioned. It was about half way thru the cycle before I had to pull the plug as I was afraid it would blow apart like others have reported. The other issue with this is that it has a horrible plastic smell to it and despite washing it thoroughly with hot soap and water, it still has a very off-putting smell to it.

After checking it was still under warranty, Mr Coffee sent me a new machine that arrived in five days, and a prepaid postage sticker to return the old unit. title: Very disappointed.
bought_model: Color: WhiteStyle Name: Espresso/Cappuccino Maker

review_content:
I had one of these that lasted for three years of daily use and loved it. I bought this one when the other one finally gave out, which I thought was a great idea considering the low price and how long the old device lasted. When the new one came, it worked beautifully, but it left a horrible plastic smell that lingered in our kitchen all day. I rinsed it with vinegar, etc., and the smell, after a week of use twice a day, still is just as strong and horrible. I called Mr. Coffee, and they were very polite and helpful, said they had heard of this problem before and said they would replace it. They sent the order through, but it hasn't been shipped yet. I called today, and the representative was not nearly as nice as the first representative, and said he had no idea when it would ship. Meanwhile, I am going back to "cowboy coffee" while we wait (and wait and wait) for our new coffee machine.

Apparently when these work, they work wonderfully, but when they don't, it's awful. The smell makes me want to gag and I'm sure it can't be good for you to drink the coffee that comes out of this pot.

If the replacement espresso machine comes in timely manner and doesn't smell and works properly, I will update this review, but for right now, I'm disgusted.

UPDATE: I finally received the replacement coffeemaker over two weeks after I ordered it, arriving two days later than they promised me after I called, but it did arrive. The new one has a very slight smell similar to the other one, but just barely there. It works great, and for the price, you can't beat these little coffee makers (as long as you don't get one that smells).

Crema comes out when you tamp good. The frother is short, but I got used to it after a week.
This machine is good. I use it all the time with GOOD coffee and FILTERED water. Like starbucks or DD. Not chesp bustelo. Its worth the price, and love it.

review_content: I just bought the Ecmp 1000 for my husband for his birthday after reading over countless reviews of all types of espresso machines. This one seemed to be the best one based off of all the reviews I read. People frequently had issues with the machines water not being hot enough, but a reviewer stated this problem and a fix for it! Clean the internal parts. So the first thing I did after prepping the machine was run a full tank of water through to ensure it would work properly from the get go! The portafilter is a bit hard to turn! I don't really mind it, I'm sure it will get easier over time but we haven't had any leaking problems from it yet and I just make sure to wipe down the space where the porta filter sits on the machine after every use, just to be on the safe side! We also bought a metal tamper to replace the plastic one that came with the unit And so far so good! Love this little machine! Ill never buy a mocha again!

review_content: I bought this from Amazon for $29.99 for my Christmas present.  My husband and I had recently started frequenting the local coffee house for lattes and mochas, and at $3 a pop it was getting expensive.  This product was one of the least expensive espresso machines, but got great reviews so I decided to give it a try.  After owning it for about a week I am totally impressed! In addition to the machine, I bought a tamper for about $6, a 20oz steaming picture for about $12, and a Mr. Coffee bean grinder for about $19.00.  I bought some espresso beans, vanilla syrup and chocolate sauce from my local grocery store.  Overall, I made about a $75 investment.  The machine works GREAT!  I have managed to make DELICIOUS lattes and mochas that taste just as good as what we were buying at the coffee house.  My friends and family have been impressed with my drink creations.  This machine and accessories will totally pay for themselves in a couple of months.  I can't comment on the durability of the machine since I've only had it for a short while, but even if it dies in a year it would have been completely worth it.

review_content:
I had a combo espresso and coffee maker. The steamer port would steam while brewing, and I didn't with to purchase another combo and just went with this stand alone unit. Everything is great! There could be knurls or bumps on the steam lid to open if you have slight moist hands. I guess maybe this is a safety feature so people will not open it as often hot like the older style.

Dislikes:
The plastic top to the glass container is horrible! It will not stay latched in the container and I have to take it off while pouring out my coffee, or I get that in my cup as well.

They changed the pour "tear drop" on the glass container and it is not as big as the previous model that I had in the combo. It spills out coffee unless you pour it out very slowly. So, you have to pour it into your coffee cup over the sink, not a big deal!

Overall, very happy for the price. The size and easy-to-clean bottom catch pan is nice. Would purchase again.
title: Works great! Compact in size

dancing around as it does vibrate some. Good price to performance. I would recommend, especially for anyone who wants cappuccino and doesn't want to spend more than the "steam" maker prices. Much better than a "steam" cappuccino maker for close to the same price.

review_content: This is the third time I have purchased this model.  The first time it lasted approximately 5 years and the second time it lasted almost 4 years.  My husband and I calculated that we use it approximately 4-5 times a day, so that's 6000+ uses for the $40 price tag.  No complaints!  We never once did the recommended "inside" rinse/cleaning, so perhaps it would have lasted even longer had we done that.  The carafe is very easy to break as is the carafe lid.  The lid fell on our tile floor a couple of times and little plastic bits came off.  We learned to not put the carafe anywhere near the edge of the counter :)  Our family really does not use this unit for true espressos with crema - we have a better espresso machine for that.  We basically use this unit to make very strong coffee, so we fill the carafe pretty full and the unit does have enough pressure to get all that water through.  We clear any extra pressure by turning the nozzle to steam after the carafe is filled (every time).  I have used the steamer to steam milk and it works well.  In our experience, we can tell the unit is at its end when it takes longer and longer for the carafe to fill.  There's not enough pressure to push through the water.  Again, maybe if we cleaned the insides as recommended. For $40, knowing we get a few years and several thousand uses, it's perfect.

bought_model: Color: CappuccinoStyle Name: 4-Cup Steam

review_content:
I got this on sale at the big red bullseye for 32$. I've never owned a cappuccino machine, but drink a lot of regular coffee everyday. I do like vanilla lattes, so I decided to try out one of the machines. It's it on a very small counter space and has the small glass carafe that the coffee brews in, some machines don't come with anything, you have to supply your own espresso cups or the like.

After having the machine for a few days and making around 10 lattes or so, I decided I did like having the machine, and decided I would buy a more top of the line machine. I went and purchased the delonghi ec155, which was 3xs the price at 100$.

The first thing about the DeLonghi, did not come with a caraffe, and I had no cups small enough, so I had to use a little bowl. The first annoying thing about the so called better machine. After reading the instructions it tells you to let the machine get to temp but turning it on about 10 min before you were going to use it, second black mark, as the Mr. Coffee, starts brewing in only a min or so. So I did that, got it to temp, and turned it on to brew. Bump..bump...bump, it was like a miniature jackhammer on my counter. The Mr Coffee is very quiet, & I guess because it doesn't use a bar type system of pressure like the delonghi , which from what I've read is a better system, hence the hundred dollar price tag, the mr. Coffee, can brew very quietly.

Next was the frothing arm, it's too low on the machine, so if you have a decent sized frothing pitcher, you're going to have to hang it off the side of the counter, third black mark.

The next thing I didn't like about the DeLonghi is the tamper for the grounds is attached to the machine, I guess you will never lose it, but it's much harder to tamp like that with the brew basket, rather than holding the brew basket still and tapping it with something that could move around, it's like holding your holiday lights still and turning your Christmas tree to string them on.

Anyway, after three trips to the big red bulls eye, needless to say I paided $29, yes it was on sale when I went back, so I actually saved another $3, and cost me $29 and change, it's happily parked on my counter. I'm sure the DeLonghi it's a great machine, but I much prefer this one. Noise wise, space wise, the mr. Coffee just works better for me. And the most important part, I love the lattes it makes.

I just wanted to give buyers an idea about which machine might work better for them. Good luck.
title: Took back a DeLonghi for this one. Yep, i like it better
bought_model: Color: CappuccinoStyle Name: 4-Cup Steam

review_content: I was SO excited to find this product at such a great price, but alas, there was a reason: it's crap!  Motor sounds like loud drill, and the coffee you want, never drips.  Amazon, why sell this item when you know it's the WORST expresson Non-Maker on the market - shame on you!
title: Black Friday Garbage deal!
bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Espresso/Cappuccino Maker

review_content:
The machine works decently well, particularly at this price point. However, it is not without flaws, particularly as regards longevity. My wife and I are very heavy users. We probably make (between the two of us) 8-10 drinks each and every day. I think that I have probably owned just about every brand that makes a sub-$200 cappuccino/espresso machine (DeLonghi, Krups, etc.). The fact is that at the sub-$200 price point, some of the components are going to be relatively cheap regardless of the manufacturer. The longest one of these units has ever lasted me is three years, and that was a $200 machine. This Mr. Coffee unit makes good espresso. The frothing functionality is only so-so, and the frothing wand is somewhat cumbersome to clean. After 10 months, the unit started leaking out of the bottom (while making espresso, but not while frothing). My guess is that one of the components has sprung a leak that appears when the system is under pressure. Given all the negative reviews regarding Mr. Coffee (i.e. Jarden) customer service, I was prepared for a nightmare trying to get the warranty honored. Imagine my surprise when after asking me a few questions, the customer service rep told me that they would immediately ship me out a replacement along with a prepaid shipping label to send my existing unit back to them. It was as easy as could be.

So, I figure that between the original unit and the replacement I will get a couple of years of use out of these machine. At a $60 price point, that's pretty good. Most of the competing machines are >$100, and many are $150. They are, IMO, no better than this one w/respect to the quality of the espresso/cappuccino. Reliability will always be a crapshoot.
title: A positive experience with customer service.
bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Automatic Dual Shot

review_content:
*Update* I've had mine since July 2013. It was one of the first models. It's now 6/2016 and it's still holding up nicely. I use it at least once a day sometimes more. I switch between lavazza medium or cafe bustlo. Still no issues or real complaints.

I wanted an espresso maker that was cost effective but didn't feel cheap. The Delongi was $100 but after seeing it in person it felt very cheap and flimsy. I love that this froths the milk for you. Which makes it easy for my husband to make his own latte without making a mess or burning the house down. I use the cheap cafe bustelo espresso and it tastes great. Also da vinci syrups are the best. I bought a different tamper, but the one that comes with it does work well. Over all I'm glad I purchased this. No cons that I can think of. Though I haven't owned an espresso maker before. Bought mine over at bed bath and beyond using a 20% coupon, it's cheaper new with that then it is used on here.
title: Better than expected
bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Espresso/Cappuccino Maker

review_content:
This machine makes decent espresso based drinks, but sucks the fun out of it.

1) Potential health hazards / clean up. There are 15-20 pieces to clean. The parts dissesamble into individual parts, and because of the steam and milk involved in this machine, not thoroughly breaking it down to its individual parts and cleaning them often will result in mold build up.

2) Leaking / Mess: This machine is inheriently messy. Some have said it is not, I feel it is and here is why. The frother shoots milk past your cup. The part where the shots are poured from continues to drip well after the coffee is made. It‚Äôs a juggling act to switch my cup of coffee with an empty cup to catch all the drips, every time I make coffee, resulting in another cup to clean.

3) Coffee grounds in coffee: leak through into coffee cup, resulting in gritty coffee occasionally, I‚Äôm using grounds that are ground up by a barista at a coffee shop to an espresso machine‚Äôs appropriate specs.

4) Durability and self-cleaning: certain parts feel they are close to breaking after one month, despite me using baby hands with this machine. Specifically the nozzle used to switch from latte to clean mode (something you must do each time, in order to clean the inner parts of the machine, which it does not do well, resulting in my having to use q-tips to scrape out old milk and prevent contamination from the tubes.) because this part is so crucial and used each time, it was a poor decision to use a cheap plastic and rotator mechanism for it.
This has already resulted in the machine not registering the proper setting occasionally, and preventing me from making drinks on the first try, a jiggle to the part is needed to get it to work.

5) The default size of the drinks are quite small. Maybe 6 ounces for the large setting. I‚Äôve not tried the small setting because of how puny the finished drink looks in my coffee mugs. My small tea cup size mugs do not get filled. Large mugs are ¬º filled.

6) Time: after one month of owning this machine, knowing its kinks, and how to combat them, it takes 10-15 Minutes to make one latte, and do a bare bones rinsing of only the essential to clean parts, waiting for the dripping to stop, etc.

There is probably more I can not think of. I am giving it two stars because it does its job: make espresso based drinks. I only suggest buying this if you are patient and willing to put in effort.
title: Mold risk, hard to clean, makes a mess, grounds in drinks.
bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Espresso/Cappuccino Maker

review_content:
Review with updates

Initial review: May 2014

Unit just arrived and was setup today. I'll do my best to keep this concise, (I'll try). Well packed, good instructions. Unit did leak at seal-point, (bottom)of water reservoir, this is a common complaint. Contemplated tossing back in box and returning but this is not my style. Pushed reservoir side to side at base when in place, (full of water). When pressed to one side the leak increased, the other direction water remained sealed. I cleaned male insert at base of reservoir. Then I wiped down into clear silicone type seal on unit. I then carefully inserted a small round screwdriver to the seal slightly lifting the seal and working around it in an effort to re-seat it within its housing. The seal is tough in material, don't be afraid, but do use good judgement. The reservoir was set back in place and it no longer leaked. I am absolutely sure there was no debris causing the leak, the leak was a cause of the seal being out of alignment with the spigot on the base of the reservoir.

I then ran through the priming sequence and made test drinks of all sizes and types. No problems, worked great! Tried a mocha-latte using my morning standard coffee cup. Two shot filter, Lavazza black can, filled filter and tamped/pressed until felt firm. Froth to latte, 1 tbsp of Hershey liquid chocolate. Left spoon in cup, placed in machine and selected double latte. Swirled spoon several x's as milk came out, (used 1% milk), removed spoon. Unit dispensed espresso. A final couple spoon mixes and ready to drink. Hot and pretty darn good, I was surprised it was as good as it was.

My final impressions: Makes a good espresso and whatever else you want. Don't freak on the tamping thing, follow directions and use coffee ground for espresso! Changing the coffee, (e.g. dark Lavazza or Blu...etc), milk type will make biggest differences. Appearance of my spent coffee in filter was tight, clearly no air pockets. And what you've been waiting for; THE LEAK? Well, so far it has not returned. If it does I update this article otherwise you'll not likely hear from me soon. I believe the seal problem is a quality-control issue with assembly, which is why some people have no issue and others do. Could the seal itself need an engineering change, maybe, hard to tell at this point. I'm sure Sunbeam is well aware of this no matter what customer service may tell you.

CONCLUSION: Here is my rationale for this machine; it makes decent espresso drinks quickly and easily. You'll still go to your Barista on occasion for fun, that's life. The more automated design allows consistency as many variables are reduced. This matter alone makes it a better home unit choice than a far more expensive manual unit. Spend $1000 and you'll not likely be any happier with the taste, in the end. Not as impressive maybe to look at, but if this matters to you then open your wallet and pass on this unit. Rather than spend $1000 or more I recommend giving this unit a try given the price gap. If you encounter the infamous "leak" think about what I wrote or trade for another unit. It's worth the hassle in my opinion considering the ample savings. Star rating? I based on espresso ability/quality, not the leak issue. If my unit continues to leak or has any problem of this nature, it will be returned for refund, end of story. Then it receives (1) star and a nasty-gram in this review. Enjoy your buzz.

UPDATE: Jarden sent a new water reservoir in an attempt to resolve the leaking seal problem. Their customer service was immediate, too immediate as you'll read. The problem is the new reservoir is identical to the original so there is no chance it would seal better. Fortunately my fix method of re-seating the seal is still working, (see above) and I am exceedingly happy with the espresso drinks I make with this machine.

A COUPLE MONTHS IN: All is fine. Been making 2~3 drinks per day. Unit is somewhat inconsistent with dispensing milk volume. This should not be seen as a problem. Why it does this is difficult to confirm. Differences in milkfat, time unit sits before brew, barometric pressure, humidity %, etc? (You see my point). Consider a Barista will mix manually to maintain consistent volume so automatic is bound to show small variations. I'm not talking about liquid running out over the cup, I speak of froth. Always fill the milk container to the full mark as this does affect dispensing. To assure perfect volume just run manually. A 2-shot?, press 2-shot espresso followed by press/hold the cappuccino button. Fill with milk amount you want, push button to stop, perfect every time. Have tried Espresso pre-ground from Trader Joes, pretty darn good. Ground espresso roast from Trader J in their machine at espresso setting, consistent but a bit coarse. Taste however was quite good. Do grind in a high quality grinder or risk plugging your machine and damaging the pressure side of system. Be adventurous, try different coffees, enjoy. Still saving me a ton of money over going to coffee hut.

Oct 2014:

Still works fine, must give a 5-star. I do see some people report fails after a year. If mine dies I come back here and tell you. Automatic tends to be messy at times due to the reality foam varies a bit, typical when making drinks. You simply can't think the drinks will not over-flow foam on occasion if you try to use the standard coffee cup.

Ever notice a Barista makes them in separate containers and combines? I'm suggesting you do similar. This is what I've found to works well: Use a 1 qt pyrex or similar size container to initially make the drink. This assures there will be no mess from over-foaming the cup. Warm the pyrex and your cup with some hot water if you can, keeps the drink hotter. Mix your drink in the pyrex then pour into your favorite cup. Foam comes out last, scoop it in to the top. If there is some left over I suggest not pouring it down the drain. I've gone to the Cafe Bustello vs the Lavazza or TJ's. Lavazza is good, no complaints. But for the price difference I favor the Bustello. If you drink raw espresso, this is another matter and you'll simply have to experiment until you find the flavor you enjoy.
title: What you are getting into? Suggested read.
bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Espresso/Cappuccino Maker

review_content: Just got this for a Christmas gift and its going right back to the store. I love a good espresso so my friend thought it would be nice to get me my own machine, knowing little how much goes into properly prepared espresso and that this machine will never cut it ( part of the reason I shell out a few bucks at a proper cafe with a proper machine). This machine gives you virtually ZERO crema and crap tasting espresso, which is far more bothersome than some of these other reviews that are mainly complaining about the tamper and the frothing jar -- not a big deal. Seriously, what you get here is basically blacker coffee and a machine that give the illusion that you are making espresso. If that is what you want then perhaps this is your machine, but I've made better brews using a papertowel as a filter with finely ground and tightly packed coffee- I kid you not... Otherwise I don't know how you could give this more than one star unless you don't really pay attention to the taste of your drink, are paid off by the company to write a decent review ( plenty of people doing that these days), or perhaps are used to Starbucks or something equally bad and/or cover it all up with loads of sugar and cream so that it really doesn't matter what you are drinking. So many variables, but what a waste of human effort here...
title: The Illusion of Espresso
bought_model: Color: CappuccinoStyle Name: 4-Cup Steam

review_content: This is the best espresso machine ever!  I love it and use it religiously every morning for a big frothy cup of delicious hot coffee. It is a learning curve if you want to go off road and do custom brews but I figured it out.  If something breaks, they send a new one right away quick and inexpensive you.  (I broke the milk canister). It‚Äôs like anything else to clean when milk is involved and you must periodically clean the coffee screens and in little spots where milk and old milk can hide.  Overall, it‚Äôs a heavy, takes up space on your counter but there are No pods, like some others it‚Äôs easy to use and it makes great coffee I make a big mug doing 2 runs of custom coffee shots, and a custom froth from the milk. Mmm mmm I‚Äôm going to have some now!
title: It Makes a Great Cappuccino
bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Espresso/Cappuccino Maker

review_content:
I am like one of the other reviewers that found this machine to have a good core design and features but it never fails to die just after the warranty period runs out, usually before 18 months. As such I have bought at least 6 or 7 of these over the years...to the tune that of I have lost count. While Mr. Coffee has tweaked the design to improve certain things on this model (notable over the last 10 years) but they never fixed the leak issue and took quality hit for the cost reduction. This things leaks like there is no tomorrow. If it didn't leak at day 1, it will definitely develop the leaking issue, it's just a matter of when. No amount of proper maintenance (cleaning and de-calc) will prevent or cure these issues.

The Chinese workmanship quality on this machine continue to drop over my 10 or so years of owning these machines, over various design tweaks and production year. Don't let the price reduction fool that, you are not getting a bargain - you are getting a cheaply made unit and it's getting cheaper and crappier each year. The plastics are no longer properly trimmed and/or polished, so that there are sharp, skin piercing corners/edges all over this machine. The water tank lid is now slightly bigger than the tank itself and no longer closes properly. The selector knob could break if you are not super super gentle with it. Leaking issue has now grown. I just had a brand new unit leak out of the frothing wand during brewing... And my new unit had burning plastic smell if you make more than 1 drink at a time - heating up the unit definitely releases a very unpleasant possible toxic smell.

Of the 6 or 7 units I have owned, only 1 unit was in good quality with no issue but it succumb to 2 shots a day after about 2+ years. The rest had pump ceased, or started to develop dangerous leak right around 1 year warranty period. Leaking at the tank connector area, or leak collected at the bottom from some internal plumbing leak, or leak from the bad connection to the drip tray, and now leak coming out of the frothing wand when in standby or brewing mode, which should have kept the wand water path fully shut. Basically, this model has leak issues from every conceivable orphus.

My advise to you is to skip this machine and go for a comparably priced DeLonghi. While DeLonghi low-end machines do not have features of this unit, mainly build-in pre-infusing and wait period, and a standard nozzle-on-the-tip frothing wand, the DeLonghi's are much much better in workmanship quality. The quality of this machine has deteriorated significantly that it no longer warrant a recommendation or re-buy.
title: Utter garbage quality and it's getting worse with each production year.
bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Automatic Dual Shot

review_content:
I've owned 2 units in just under 5 yrs (got replacement after mis-threading the steaming tip back on after cleaning, couldn't get tip back off again). This works GREAT, and after years of heavy use it consistently produces great espresso. In case you didn't already know, you will definitely need practice (and maybe some helpful advice from YouTube videos) on how to effectively use the machine, and make great-tasting espresso drinks...but your time and effort will pay off! Be sure to clean and regularly maintain the unit, and I'm confident you'll get plenty of use/enjoyment out of it.
My advice/warning would be regarding the steaming tip: be very careful when screwing/unscrewing the tip, as it's threads are super thin and quite easily able to be mis-threaded. Don't over tighten it either; finger/hand tighten is enough to keep it securely on without allowing steam to escape. (If you DO over-tighten and/or mis-thread the tip, it will be almost impossible to remove it without breaking the stem....trust me, I KNOW!) Lastly, I would suggest running the steam tip into small cup/serving pitcher with water immediately after use, to prevent milk from hardening and clogging inside the stem/tip, as well as keeping the outside clean and free from dried-on milk residue.

Overall, after owning this espresso maker for nearly 5years, I think this is a great product, at a great value, and I highly recommend it!
title: Highly Recommended for overall quality, price, performance!
bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Automatic Dual Shot

review_content: We LOVE this machine!  Over 20 years we have had a Saeco, a Breville, a DeLonghi, a Gaggia and loved them and wore them out.  We bought this on Amazon Prime day because we'd worn out our last machine and were using our back up...our old trusty pump machine. But missed our automatic machine. Snatched this up for a great price and absolutely love it. Was skeptical about it being a Mr. Coffee, but we've had it for 6+ months and brew 3-6 cups each day and it's still going strong. Love the milk frother. Love the simplicity of the machine, so much so that we don't mind that we have to pack our own coffee.
title: We LOVE this machine
bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Espresso/Cappuccino Maker

review_content: We've had this machine for a few weeks thus far. We use it every other day. It makes very nice expresso's and latte's. We use bottled water to avoid mineral deposit build up inside the heating element. Like others have pointed out, after every use, a bit of steam condensate enters the drip tray, but this is a minor issue in my mind since we clean and pat dry the tray after every use. You also need to watch how much coffee you brew through the machine as it does not automatically stops. A small 3 oz expresso shot glass with markings ensures you brew the precise amount by indicating when to turn the brewing knob to the off position. Overall I find these to be minor issues, and the machine a good value for the money and highly recommend it.
title: Good value for the money!
bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Automatic Dual Shot

review_content: Very cheap price but the steamer stopped working after using it for two weeks.
title: Two Stars
bought_model: Color: CappuccinoStyle Name: 4-Cup Steam

review_content: hard to clean, easy to cook but can't cook the good coffee quality
title: easy to cook but can't cook the good coffee quality
bought_model: Color: CappuccinoStyle Name: 4-Cup Steam

review_content: It's a great purchase, worth a lot more then I paid. Easy to use and clean and espresso comes out perfect every time. Highly recommending buying this product.
title: SWEET
bought_model: Color: CappuccinoStyle Name: 4-Cup Steam

review_content: Very nice machine
title: Five Stars
bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Automatic Dual Shot

review_content: good machine
title: Five Stars
bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Espresso/Cappuccino Maker

review_content: What a good little machine this is!  The coffee comes out strong with a bit of coffee foam on top.  The milk steamer/foamer works well.  It only has four stars because the milk steamer is hard to clean.  I would take it out and flush it with hot tap water, but it got that sour milk smell none the less.  I now put water in it and hit the "clean" button, which forces hot water through it.  It comes out cleaner, but a bit of work.  I also have cleaned it out with warm soapy water as recommended.  Anyway, I am loving my lattes every morning.  Great for the price!
title: Strong coffee, hot steamed milk -
bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Espresso/Cappuccino Maker

review_content: Totally worth the money. Took me a couple of hours to figure out how exactly to utilize all of the functions properly because I had never even tried espresso before, much less making it myself. This was a gift card binge purchase with Amazon gift cards; for once I decided to get one big thing instead of a bunch of cheap stuff. One thing I will say is that the way the brew head fits into the unlock/lock positions makes it tough to twist it - you really have to muscle it. BUT what I do now is just only twist it about halfway to "locked" while I use the machine, and it still works perfectly fine. If you want to feel fancy and have fun learning how to create your own drinks instead of wasting money at a cafe, I think this is a good option.
title: Definitely legit, especially for $75.
bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Automatic Dual Shot

review_content:
I really love this product as it is very easy to operate and does what it should do. The milk function doesn't really work with the consistency, but it still does its job.

The quality of the product is very cheap compared to my Nesspresso machine(s), but it brews so much better coffee. Highly recommend it!
title: Amazing value for the price. Better than Nesspresso Virtuo and Original line.
bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Espresso/Cappuccino Maker

review_content: We are experienced home espresso makers - having a manual machine for about 15+ years.  Our last machine (Delonghi EC155) was fully manual and worked great UNTIL it started leaking within a year!  We decided to try this.  Regardless of which settings I used, the coffee ALWAYS tasted burnt - plus it doesn't allow enough steamed/frothed milk, compared to our liking.  Anyway, I checked their recommendations for this problem - it said our coffee was old, or we needed a better water filter, or fresh milk, etc.  All "sensible" ideas EXCEPT for the fact that our old leaky machine made great-tasting coffee (and STILL does!) with the exact same coffee, water, and milk.  Don't bother!!
title: Don't buy this unless you like your espresso to taste burnt!
bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Espresso/Cappuccino Maker

review_content: I must admit I have been an espresso machine snob. I learned to make lattes etc as a barista at a coffee bar where we had a really good professional machine. So over the years when I bought smaller machines for at home, I bought the little bit more expensive inexpensive machines with names that sounded fancy. I avoided the Mr Coffee one because... well... it just didn't sound right. My old one was starting to have issues but was still working. I decided to try the Mr Coffee machine and if I didn't like it I would give it to my son and his wife, and keep my old one until it died and then I'd buy a new fancy-named one. Turns out... I love this Mr Coffee espresso maker!!! Why did I wait so long to try it!! Except for grinding the beans, it does everything in one step. So easy! And it tastes amazing! If you've been avoiding it because it doesn't have an Italian name, stop it! I love mine. And my son and his wife now have my old machine. :)
title: I was amazed at how wonderful this machine is!
bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Espresso/Cappuccino Maker

review_content: Love this espresso machine for the PRICE and I actually got it delivered a whole day earlier than expected which was super cool. My only complaint, and why i'm doing four stars is that it actually burns the ground espresso. It's a very strong, distinguished smell in my house and in my beverages. I use Cafe Bustelo and have never had an issue with this brand having a burnt taste to it (in general) and when I used it for other espresso machines. I'll likely venture out and try other brands of ground espresso too at this point. Low key hoping that over time this machine chills out with the over the top temps so I can have a non-burnt cup of espresso & cream.
title: Love this espresso machine for the PRICE and I actually ...
bought_model: Color: CappuccinoStyle Name: 4-Cup Steam

review_content:
There are several poorly designed aspects of this espresso machine that have broken on ours in the month we've owned it:

1) the black plastic cover that goes over the steamer cracked and broke. It's pretty thin, and without it, the steam doesn't get dispersed as much, making the steamer less effective.

2) the glass pitcher's handle broke off. There is a small screw that holds a metal strap around the glass, which holds the handle on. The screw sheared off during hand washing, and the whole assembly fell apart.

3) the thing that holds the espresso in place while it's brewing seems slightly misaligned, and so now it doesn't make a tight seal. This results in hot coffee water coming out the seam and making a mess.

The price was awesome and the espresso and usage was great until it fell apart. I would not recommend this machine. I wish we had bought something else even though that meant spending a little more.
title: No catastrophic failure like others, but multiple small ones make this a bad choice
bought_model: Color: CappuccinoStyle Name: 4-Cup Steam

review_content: Given the price of this machine I was very hesitant to try it but we were pleasantly surprised! Makes decent espresso, I get crema every time, easy to use and clean. If you take the plastic frothing aid off the steaming wand I found it much easier to use and makes fabulous foam! There is a lot that goes into making good espresso including learning your machine, the freshness of the beans, the proper ground and tamp. Fit the people that have this machine such a poor reviewiI am assuming they didn't use it enough to get used to it and experiment with the different factors. My only negatives for this machine are that you cannot steam while it is brewing and there is  way to see if there is water in the resivoir. These are not deal breakers for me, just personal preferences.
title: very nice for the price
bought_model: Color: CappuccinoStyle Name: 4-Cup Steam

review_content: Love love this product...Here is what I have learned to ensure a great cup of coffee. This product is easy to operate and works well, but Only use filtered/ spring water to avoid calcium build up and do not use espresso ground coffee. Espresso ground is too fine and ends up clogging up the cup. You want a medium fine ground and it works every time. I was having issues with clogging and thought my machine was broken until I figured out it was just the grounds. Mr coffee‚Äôs customer service is stellar . They will help you with anything you need
title: Love love this product
bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Automatic Dual Shot

review_content:
Great little basic espresso machine. I love it for iced coffees in the summer, and adding an extra boost to my regular coffees too. Everything about this machine is wonderful, but three things to know before you buy it:

1) The scoop you get free with this machine has a tamper built in... The scoop is very small and the bottom doesn't tamp down well. I spill more grounds when I try to use it. I use a 2TBSP flat bottom measuring cup which is great for scooping and packing, but the scoop works, just buy a tamper.
2) Steam escapes from ALL around this unit. Be sure not to have anything that shouldn't be moist near of above the machine while brewing or steaming.
3) The glass carafe is very delicate. It cracks easily with sudden temperature changes, and shatters if it drops a few inches.

It really is a great value, despite these few issues.
title: Great little basic espresso machine
bought_model: Color: CappuccinoStyle Name: 4-Cup Steam

review_content:
First off.. I am a former barista and I was very hesitant to buy this machine but the price was absolutely unbeatable. So I went for it. I read that it did not come with a steam pitcher, so I also got one of those. It comes with a plastic scoop that can be used as a descent tamper if you do not want to buy one separately.

READ THE DIRECTIONS FIRST! and ALWAYS BREW THE EXCESS WATER OUT BEFORE OPENING THE RESERVOIR! It is written on the machine and it explains it in the directions.

The steam wand steams milk very slowly, but it gets the job done. It makes very nice velvety foam. I took off the plastic tip.

It's possible to get a good shot with crema (sadly, I've only been able to do it once.. my grinds have been off) but most of my shots are just strong coffee. I'm fine with that. I add sugar and crap to my drinks anyway.

Ultimately, It's a great machine for someone who doesn't want to pay big bucks for good drinks! Cheers!
title: Former Barista.. This is a good deal!
bought_model: Color: CappuccinoStyle Name: 4-Cup Steam

review_content:
UPDATE**************************************************************************************************

July 30, 2014 - A couple of years later and still no issues. Not sure what has been the problem with all those bad reviews. This machine has been used almost every day. We don't have reverse osmosis water filter or even use bottled water. Water straight out of the tap.

Still going strong with no issues. Pulls are hot with nice cr√®me on top. Heats up within a about 30 seconds. No flashing lights unless you turn the knobs the wrong way. No gasket leaks - we wipe the basket gasket after each use. No leaks on the counter.

The steam wand gets clogged every once in a while, but that is due to poor cleaning. All you have to do is take off the jet with a pair of pliers and clean out the jet with a pin. Probably could prevent that with a shot of steam after every use, but I think the kids are lazy.

My 18 year old is about to move out and the fight has already started about who gets the machine. Guess we will end up getting another one and even though there are a ton of negative comments, I just don't see that we will have any issues.

Will update if we do.

UPDATE**************************************************************************************************

January 21, 2012 - And still a great unit. Everyone in the house had adopted our little friend. Absolutely no issues being used a couple of times a day.

Want a variety of really different but sometimes questionable coffee. While you travel, grab those extra packets in the rooms. The 1 cup variety fits perfectly in the small shot, the 4 cup fits a little short on the 2 shot. Cut open the little bags. I feed them to the teenagers here and keep the fresh ground roast for myself....

Having fun with Mr. Coffee

Original review Decmember, 2011**************************************************************************

We have a 4 person family and this thing has been running almost non-stop since we got it.

Not only has it been on our counter making continuous cups all day, my teen age sons have taken it out almost every night to parties over the holidays. On Christmas eve alone, we did about 50 pulls with ablsolutely no issue. Family of 25 coffee drinkers couldn't get over how good a cup the unit produces. And it is easy enough for just about anyone to use. Point out a couple of the controls and it starts producing coffee in about a minute.

So as for the bad reviews...

1. Break down and get the matched Mr. Coffee Automatic Burr Mill. Model number BVMC-BMH23. In the manuals, it talks about having the right grind for Espresso and calls out this model on the fine setting for a perfect pull. So no one is an expert barista around here, but using the 2 diffent size filters gave perfect pulls every time - even for the 8 year old serving grandma. If you use the right grind, you will save your pump and keep from overflowing.

2. There is a water tray under the cups on the front of the unit. Excess water is ejected into this tray. Keep it emptied. If you don't, you will have water on your counter (duh).

3. On the box is a picture of exacty what you get in the box. And a full size standard 16 oz coffe mug (ya know those ones with 'I Love Mom' on the side) will fit under the filter with no issue by tipping the cup just slightly as it goes under. For large cups you can take off the tray. As far as the cups shown as suggestions for serving on the box, they don't come with the coffee maker and the don't have coffe in them either. Come on - look at the price and break down and get a coffee cup and a stainless steel frother.

4. I just burned my mouth on a pull. The water temp is plenty hot. Now for reading the instructions. When you first turn on the machine, let the check light stop flashing. Hit the steam button and clear your steam wand for 30 seconds. This starts the heating process for the water and clears the wand of a little built up water. It will spirt that little cold water for just a second. The instructions say to run the wand in water in your frother for 30 seconds, but I just take my towel and put it over - recleaning the wand (because the teenagers are really lazy). If you go through this process when you turn the machine on and when you refill the water you will get the right temp coffee.

5. Blow through your wand for a few seconds and clean it after every frothing. Another thing I have done is to lose the rubber cover for the frother. It works as a jet, but milk browns to the wand and is very hard to clean up. I would say a real bacteria issue after a while. My teenage sons who had gotten used to the jet told me the frother then didn't work. It is an art then of placement of the wand, temp and cup position to get a good foam on the milk. If you can't figure it out, go to you tube and watch some video. Not one of the professional machines have a rubber 'crutch' on the frother.

I just went back and read the reviews and it looks like all are related to the grind. So, as for all those leaking issues, try using the right size grounds and see if that helps.

As far as this family is concerned, we have pulled maybe 100 shots and had absolutely no issue. At this point, the machine has paid for itself (if you consider the cost of that high priced corner store). Even if it was to blow a gasket at this point, I would still say it was one of the best purchased I have made.
title: Highly recommended after 2 years use with no issues
bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Automatic Dual Shot

review_content:
I have used this machine regularly (not quite daily but a minimum of twice a week up to every day of the week) for about 5 years. Still works great. I haven't even had to replace the carafe - and I am clumsy!
The machine takes some practice to get the espresso just how you like - trying different roasts and grind settings - but I like that. The instruction booklet was helpful and I have never really had a brew turn out horrible. I can use different brews and grinds depending on the flavor I want for the day and I enjoy that optional versatility versus say a Keurig type machine.
I don't use the frother, however, so I can't say anything in regards to how that works or its maintenance etc. When this machine dies (which I don't see happening soon), I will gladly buy another one.
I would highly recommend this to someone who likes espresso drinks but doesn't need a top of the line type machine. I would say it is Starbucks equivalent espresso if you get the right roast and if you cut Starbucks the machine will easily pay for itself. The cost savings alone made it worth it for me. :)
title: Can't beat if for the price
bought_model: Color: CappuccinoStyle Name: 4-Cup Steam

review_content:
I've been using the Mr. Coffee Espresso maker since about 2009. Not the same one, because they don't last forever, but what does anymore? I use mine almost every morning to brew a 4-shot, 20-oz, steamed milk mocha, in about 6 minutes. This machine is simple to use, easy to clean, and heats up quickly. The first one I had to replace was because the activation knob broke on the inside, and was not repairable. The second one I replaced because I had not cleaned it frequently enough for our hard water, and it would no longer steam. Now I run straight vinegar through it about 3 times a year, and this unit has lasted 3 years!
This is not a "professional" espresso machine. This is a home use unit, made for people who like their foo-foo coffees, but are sick and tired of paying ridiculous amounts of money every month for something they can just make for themselves at home. Get one!
title: Get One!!
bought_model: Color: CappuccinoStyle Name: 4-Cup Steam

review_content:
Bought at Target last week. Have made about a dozen 4-shot pots since. All except two were great. The first brew out of the box was great. The second weak, as we learned the right tamping pressure. One time I put too much coffee in and it tasted burnt.

Makes great smooth afogado americanos -- that's our drink. You heat up water in a cup and pour the expresso into it. "Drowning" the expresso. So smooth they do not need milk, or sweetener. Better than Starbuck's.

A very simple machine. A metal pressure chamber that can hold 4 shots of water, a knob that operates the steam valve and also turns on the electric heater of the pressure tank. Three positions -- steam, off, brew. Simple very easy to clean metal cup expresso filter.

This is true expresso. The steam is pressurized in the pressure vessel by becoming steam. Takes about three minutes to make one pot of 4 shots expresso. Takes 30 seconds to clean up. The grinds come out as a steam-dried puck.

We make ours on the short-shot side, using a Starbucks bean grind set at 5.25, maybe a little drip grind put in first to get a better crema. True, not much crema, but that's not important to our tastes.

Needs to be unplugged, but that's just a testimony to the pure elegant simplicity of this machine. Looks like it'll last a long time. GREAT BUY!
title: Simple, elegant, makes smoother Americano than Starbucks
bought_model: Color: CappuccinoStyle Name: 4-Cup Steam

review_content: Mine broke after a few months use. I called Mr. Coffee. Customer service was the most hassle-free I've had in a long, long time. I always steel myself for these warranty service phone calls. This wasn't the case here. A not-too-long bit of wait time, five minutes with the rep, and a new unit is in the mail.
title: Good service!
bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Automatic Dual Shot

review_content:
I had received a different Cappuccino machine for Christmas, it was the Delonghi EC5 to be exact. That machine worked well but did not have a knob to switch between foam and drip, which made making cappuccinos a big hassle. However this little Mr. Coffee ECM160 I got in it's place is just plain amazing. The knob is present as it should be, the frother is extremely strong and easy to use, the coffee tastes great, the machine feels sturdy and well built. It's perfect for people who don't want to spend much but want to learn how to make cappuccinos, or for someone who knows how and is just replacing an old machine. My only tiny gripe is the grip on the top of the machine cap. It's shaped sort of funny and is a little hard to grab when opening to pour water in. Otherwise, it's great. A+! all around

Update* 1/26/12

After having this Espresso machine for almost a year exactly, it started to spit out weaker Espresso. It more so started to taste like coffee, or even bland coffee. I decided to chuck this one and grab a model up which uses pressure as oppose to steam. Thus far my experience with the new machine is great. The new one is a Mr. Coffee ECMP50. =)

Due to it only lasting a year or so, I dropped it one star. But keep in mind I normally made about 2-3 batches a day of four shots a piece. So perhaps I just overworked it a bit lol.
title: Excellent, cheap and well built!
bought_model: Color: CappuccinoStyle Name: 4-Cup Steam

review_content: I love this little machine! I‚Äôm honestly only sad I didn‚Äôt buy this sooner - it‚Äôs super simple, takes maybe 5 minutes from start to finish and is easy to clean. The only thing I would change is to make the metal milk thing bigger to fit more milk as it does increase in volume when frothing. I‚Äôve tried dairy milk, almond, and pea milk and I get a really great froth on the non-dairy milks which is awesome for a tiny machine like this! Photo is using Pea Milk and you can see I was still able to get a good consistency with the foam.
title: Love it!
bought_model: Color: BlackStyle Name: Steam + Starter Set

review_content:
A pretty fantastic beverage aide... though to be blunt, I have no experience with these kinds of machines. What I do know is that everyone thought I was so fancy when they saw this, and that it produces a very classy drink. I'm still figuring it out, but so far I have absolutely nothing to complain about.

Overall I think it's a great product, and easy to figure out/operate.
title: Easy, For A Newbie Like Me
bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Caf√© Steam

review_content: I bought this when my Melitta died, which I loved. I'm having the opposite problem that some people are having in regard to the steam wand. Mine is too powerful; I'm a former barista so I know how to froth milk to make it silky and creamy. This machine doesn't allow me to stretch it; instead it heats up so fast that it's practically boiling and it's really hard to froth without making crusty bubbly milk (undesirable). The coffee is also WEAK!!! I've tried stuffing it with more grounds, or shutting it off before it brews past the "2" mark (even though I fill it up all the way) and it still tastes way to weak. I hate this machine and will be returning  it.
title: Hate it - makes WEAK coffee and practically boils the milk
bought_model: Color: CappuccinoStyle Name: 4-Cup Steam

review_content: Good coffee - and good coffee maker, but I got a defective unit. It was really hard to fit the coffee pod into the machine, also I was getting grains on my coffee, It is a lot of work for me, but the coffee is delicious, I cannot disagree with that.  I used the Illy brand and it was a hit.
title: Great machine if you don't mind the work,
bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Espresso/Cappuccino Maker

review_content: Makes beautiful foamy espressos, both with the single and the dual-shot filter. I've used it at least 2 -3 times per day for the last 4 months and it still performs as new.
title: Makes beautiful foamy espressos
bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Automatic Dual Shot

review_content: We originally purchased a DeLonghi machine that was about 3 times the price of this one on sale.  It worked for a dozen cups of coffee before dying, and was difficult to clean.  This machine makes excellent coffee, has not pump to maintain, and my wife says it makes better coffee than the more expensive machine.  This machine comes apart easily and is very easy to maintain.  The only problem my wife has run into with it is figuring out the steamer function, but that's likely just an issue of not reading the directions...
title: Great machine
bought_model: Color: CappuccinoStyle Name: 4-Cup Steam

review_content: Just what i was looking for. Makes everything easy.  If it had a timer it for when you're on the go it would be perfect.
title: Great little espresso machine.

review_content:
I bought this coffee maker last November, it was being used on a daily basis. This morning it blew up! No, I'm not making this up, it sent broken glass, coffee and grounds all over me and my kitchen!

Before buying this unit last November I read the reviews of this product and came across a couple of reviews where this happened to others, I thought they were making it up, I was wrong. Before you think that I did something wrong please understand that I checked everything before turning on the coffee pot, the coffee basket was tight, I had enough water in the unit and the coffee grounds were not over packed in the basket. I was standing by the coffee pot waiting for it to finish making my coffee, the pot was about 3/4 full when it just plane and simple blew apart, the basket got blown off the coffee maker latch and was driven into the coffee pot blowing it apart and sending glass, hot coffee and grounds all over me and the kitchen!

Do yourself a favor and buy another brand......it just isn't worth it!

review_content: I initially purchased the Cafe Barista from Amazon and was disappointed to find it did not work according to the directions provided. You're supposed to prime the unit before using but I couldn't complete the process because the unit would not pump water through the system.  I contacted Jarden, the owner of Mr. Coffee, and, after speaking with their representatives several times, received two additional units, neither of which worked properly either.  Even the customer service managers I spoke with were perplexed as to why the units weren't working and told me the only thing I could do was return it. I tried everything - removing all of the packaging (including the little red stopper at the bottom of the water reservoir), unplugging and restarting the unit and confirming both reservoirs were filled to capacity but, in the end, I couldn't get any of them to make a single shot of espresso. Should you choose to purchase the Cafe Barista, I hope your experience is more positive than mine was. It's a great appliance in theory but, after trying it three times, I had to throw in the towel. Not sure if I got a bad batch of them or what but it was truly disappointing and a waste of my time.

review_content:
This thing really is junk, and probably extremely dangerous to your health to boot.

First off, the boiler is aluminum. Aluminum and hot things are a VERY bad idea because aluminum leaches into hot and/or acidic things and is extremely neurotoxic.

Second, the metal on the coffee filter holder is god only knows what. It turns black after washing and leaves black smudges on my towels after drying. Seriously? I don't even want to know what this thing is made out of. Is it so hard, really, to make things out of safe stainless steel???

Third, if you are undeterred by health hazards or think I am a crazy hippie and still buy thins, don't get espresso ground coffee. You'll even be pushing it if you get fine grind for cone style filters. The machine will make coffee up til about the 2 cup line, if that, then starts hissing and spitting hot things at you. It does it to some degree at the end even with a coarser grind, but at least it finishes making the coffee. Yes, I read the directions, I know how to use it and not overfill or overtamp (which, for this machine, means do NOT tamp at all) and to remove all grinds from the rim.

Fourth, it will break. We've had ours for a few months and I went to make some coffee today and the handle came clean off of the coffee holder.

This thing is garbage. Look around, and email me if you find something that has a stainless boiler and a stainless coffee holder. I'll give you a $20 finder's fee.

review_content: There is absolutely nothing negative about the operation of this appliance, but there are some things unique to these Espresso Makers that people should be aware of.  First; you cannot just set it up and walk away to do other things like you can a normal coffee maker.  You have to simply stand there ready to stop it once the cup is as full as you desire.  So, you will have to allow some extra time to make your 1 or 2 cups of coffee in the mornings.  Secondly; most people today use bigger cups than the standard small ones.  You cannot put a large mug under the nozzles.  Even if you remove the metal plate, most of today's larger mugs just will not fit.  Other than these 2 considerations, it does make a delicious cup of Espresso coffee!

review_content: Quite literally the worst. And not in the figurative sense. This machine is by no means, by any definition, an espresso machine. It's a glorified coffee pot; and I use the term "glorified" in the same way that we call prostitutes, "Ladies of the night" - as if semantics is really the problem with their chosen profession. This machine is worse than a coffee pot and the only thing it is good at, really good at, is making an utter and annoying, steaming, raging mess. I wouldn't have a problem with it NOT being an espresso machine if only it didn't make me livid when I have to clean up after it. It doesn't have enough bars of pressure needed to make espresso, but I knew that going in when I bought it. I some how thought, maybe I could find a process that would make this a "decent" espresso machine rather than the disappointing prostitute that it is. No, I'm not having sex with it, not for money at least, but I spend nearly as much time cleaning up after. The portafilter of this bathos fails to make a seal with the group head. Not only does it lose pressure because of this flaw, it spews out steaming hot water in every direction like a cracked out whore spews out disease ridden spittle as if she were looking for her next hit, and you owe her money. The only thing to do at that point is to run away and hope to not get any mess to land on you. So why do I keep it? Mainly, it was ridiculously affordable and by now, I've tossed the box. The effort of making a complaint to return it is greater than simply writing a demeaning review on a third party web site I bought it from. As for you, I'd recommend against getting something simply because it's more affordable. Like an escort, you're going to be sorry later on, and wish you would have just splurged on a decent piece of work. In other words, you'll be spending more later to make up your loss.
title: It's like "Pretty Woman", but only slightly more talent than Julia Roberts, and when talking about enjoying espresso, thats bad.

title: LOVE LOVE LOVE
bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Espresso/Cappuccino Maker

review_content:
To the engineer that posted detailed instructions on how you should use this machine. Your a genius! I have followed your advice from day one and not had one problem with this unit. This is a great little machine for not a lot of $$$$. I have saved a lot of $$$ making my own latte's. Sorry Starbucks I love you but....... I can make my own now :) I

Here are the instructions I follow. If you follow the directions included with the machine to a tee your going to get disappointing water logged coffee. But if you have a basic understanding of pressure and steam you'll need to modify your operation of this little machine. What I do is fill the coffee filter holder to max shot coffee level line and use a coffee tamper to compress the espresso but don't pack it to tight just a simple tamp is all you need because your going to want to stop the excess water rush when the thick black coffee and cream stops pouring. I use only purified water unless you want your machine to last only 1 year from mineral deposits, and I fill glass carafe to reach the bottom of the metal band to ensure more than enough water and steam to do the job. With everything in place i.e. power off, coffee filter holder fully locked in, steam cap screwed down tight, frothing arm extended and ready with cup and milk standing by... I then turn the machine to knob to steam first to allow the machine to build pressure and steam without prematurely diluting the coffee filter holder, as soon as the frothing arm starts to sputter and produce steam with a hint of water I quickly switch the control knob to brew coffee position which brings in only hot steam and water trickling out only dark thick coffee and this is where you have to be rehearsed to act fast and operate the machine effectively! With the thick black coffee trickling, get your milk cup ready sitting under the frothing arm ready to be lifted up as soon as you see the brewing coffee go from slow tricking thick dark coffee to cream foam. It should have reached the first like on the coffee pot at this point. Now GET READY to turn the control knob back to steam the INSTANT you see that the slow dark cream foam trickling out slowly starts to speed up. The moment before you see the slow dark cream foam trickling out start to speed up to water, I Instantly raise my milk cup submersing the frothing arm under the milk to avoid splatter while simultaneously switching the control knob to steam, which instantly stops the brewing process to the coffee filter holder preventing water dilution. Turn the knob slowly once on the steam side and work your way up to full steam if you switch too quickly you will get a milk volcano lol. Once your milk is frothed to your liking. switch the control knob to off. That's it, perfect Espresso. Be sure to once you've made your coffee clear the rest of the steam from the unit once your done and clean the froth arm. I wipe the outside of the plastic cover then take it off and wipe down the metal portion to clean the steamed on milk off. Then I replace the plastic cover and turn the steam back on to clear out all the rest of the water and steam from the unit. This will clean the frothing arm but also release all the pressure that has built up in the machine. Once all the steam is released take the lid off the top of the water compartment and let the machine cool. Doing this when not in use will help prevent premature compression damage to the sealing gaskets, I only slightly keep both the steam cap and the filter holder screwed in place. If you lock them down to full tight position when not in use, I find that it will prematurely compress the sealing gaskets and they will start to leak early making brewing ineffective. Having said all of this, as a protective disclaimer I must say that this is what ‚ÄúI DO‚Äù and I'm not recommending any of these operating actions to anyone. "You should use the instruction book to a tee for OK strong watery coffee if that's what your after." Thanks E. Gonzales for your review. My coffee machine works like a charm and I have beautiful crema on my espresso every time. I did tweak his original instructions for user use and understanding as well as maintenance. ENJOY!! Your now a barista!
title: Awesome Espresso machine for very little $$$$$
bought_model: Color: CappuccinoStyle Name: 4-Cup Steam

review_content:
I just ordered our second one of these. The first one lasted 16 months, averaging about 5 double shots per day. It recently developed an internal leak that is related to the inexpensive and fast PEX type fittings used in assembly, so repair is more trouble and expense than it is worth.

I purchased the replacement with a 4 year replacement warranty offered by Amazon, so when it also fails we can hopefully get another at no cost. You can't beat the price on this thing. It makes a great cup of espresso and the steamer is far ahead of anything else in this price range. The only real issue I have with it (other than the leak problem) is that the pump is noisy. Not air raid siren noisy, but everybody in the house knows you're making a cup of espresso noisy. I'll put up with that for the price and performance of this thing.

review_content: This espresso machine is awesome for the price! The quality of the espresso is incredible. I'd say it's on the brink of dangerous because it's so easy to have an incredible latte or espresso. I would highly recommend it. I have not had any issues. I also like that I grind the beans and put them in. review_content:
I had the DeLonghi 155 for 3 years and my wife and I made cappuccinos 4-5 times per week. A few weeks ago it finally died for good - would no longer heat water for espresso or steam - but I figured we had more than gotten our sub-$100 worth of money from it. I figured we might as well as try a different machine in the same price range. I read reviews of the 4 or 5 models I could find, and this one seemed the most comparable, perhaps even better with a 1200W heater instead of 1000W, much faster warm-up times, and pumping action on the milk frothing wand as well.

Unfortunately, with the exact same coffee grinds and milk, this machine produces coffee and milk that are noticeably weaker and more watery, and very little milk foam is produced. The pump doesn't seem to even heat up the milk than the non-pump does on the De'Longhi. So I'm sending back the Mr. Coffee and ordering another De'Longhi.

review_content:
After my own issues with reading the instructions to get past the "learning curve" I am absolutely impressed with how well this machine makes espresso, cappuccino (my favorite) and cafe latte.

While I don't use Mr. Coffee products for making my "Cafe Americano" because, for whatever reason, they refuse to use a "conical #4" coffee filter in any of their designs, the design engineers of this espresso/cappuccino/latte machine deserve compliments.

The machine not only works amazingly well, but it was well thought out for "ease of cleaning" as all of the parts that might ordinarily be "difficult to clean" are completely able to be thoroughly disassembled for thorough and complete cleaning.

Most of the wetted components are full stainless-steel.

It is also very nice how the separate milk-storage container is easily removable for storage in the refrigerator until its next use.

I highly recommend this product.

I know it is not the machines fault that I sleep later than my wife, so she gets a trouble free cuppa, but dang! I am the one always has to futz with the coffee maker!

It takes awhile for the machine to warm up, and it likes a full milk container before every cup, so I have to say there is not going to be a repeat purchase, I will be spending a bit more money on our next unit. I dislike the 'pod' concept, but I do like an all in one unit, so my search for the perfect coffee maker continues.

review_content: I worked at Starbucks for five years and have a fairly decent knowledge in coffee and espresso use. This machine is not intended for the 'coffee snob' so don't buy it expecting the world's greatest espresso shot. However, if you know even a little bit about how to brew shots and make your own coffee it's absolutely perfect! I build my own 'Cafe Mocha' how I like it with any additive and know exactly how to make it with this machine. Again it is not for people who spend tons of money on 'showy' machinery or for the 'coffee snob' but it is for people who know how to make a cheap machine work like a $1k machine.
