review_content: Do not waste your money on this piece of garbage. 1st machine: leaked water with grounds every time it was run. Muddy water running down the sides where the espresso holder connects to the machine. Amazon made me pay for the return shipping and finally sent a new machine. 2nd machine: same exact problem of water leakage. Tried adjusting the kind/amount/stamping of the espresso grounds but it did not make a difference. The most annoying part is that because of the excess water in the espresso holder, every time I go to dump out--what should be a nice, dry puck of used espresso--it is a muddy mess that I have to carefully unlock and maneuver or risk dripping everywhere. Will have to pay for shipping AGAIN to send back this piece of junk. I've owned multiple machines and this one is by far the most expensive and shoddiest of the bunch.
title: Major water leakage in TWO machines purchased -- DO NOT BUY
bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Espresso/Cappuccino Maker

review_content: I had a steam expresso for over ten years and loved it. A gasket started leaking so I discarded it and purchased a DeLonghi EC155 pump machine. It was not up to the hype of pumps over steam as it made only marginally better expresso. The bad was it only lasted about 18 months. I purchased another EC 155 and it also died in less than 2 years. So why fight the pump failure go back to steam. The ECM 160 was touted as one of the best steam machines so I purchased it. What a piece of crap. It will not make even a mediocre expresso. The steamer wand is also poor. My old machine had a separate power switch, a expresso on/off, and a steam control knob. This has only an expresso and a steam position that also turns on the power. Unless steam is on full blast the heater is off. Coffee, NOT expresso, starts flowing as soon as temp light comes on so you get mostly water instead of steam. Some guy on Utube has a video on how to make this thing work but it requires a lot of extra steps and effort. Why, because this is a horrible, flawed design made on the cheap.
title: don't waste your money and time

review_content: The Mr. Coffee ECMP50 is on amazon for $68 new, but I chose to try amazon's used (sold/shipped by amazon) of this for $38.  I don't mind a little scratch/dent if I am able to get a good functioning unit for only $38.  The unit arrived appearing brand new (even the box) other than a few coffee grounds here and there and the box had been retaped/repackaged.  I was able to make 1 cup of expresso and was so excited because it was so fast and so simple to use.  When I had the 2nd cup ready to make, the unit would not power on.  Several attempts were made by unplugging, and powering on and off several times..nothing worked.  This will discourage me from purchasing used from amazon.  I did order the brand new version $68 thru amazon and has been working great so far for almost 2 weeks...a little quirky/glitchy here and there..but overall finally makes a great simple/fast expresso!!  I will say that amazon is great on resolving shipping/faulty product/returns/refunds issues.

I rated this 4/5 stars because it didn't come with a frothing pitcher, which isn't made clear on the box or in the instructions. The booklet refers to using one, so I searched through the box looking for an included frothing pitcher, but it turns out you have to provide your own. I found a nice one (Krups) and bought that separately - I just wish that the instructions had been more clear, like, "Use the frothing pitcher (not included)..." or something like that.

title: Overflows on the large lattes
bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Espresso/Cappuccino Maker

review_content:
I while back, I had read the reviews on this machine (they were great at the time) and really liked how it looked. So for Christmas, hubby bought it for me (he actually remembered that I had wanted one!). I was so excited to try it out...but wow I had no idea what a headache it would be. Now maybe I'm a tad spoiled from the ease of my Keurig brewer, and the simplicity/taste of our french press, I don't know. But not only did I have to read the directions several times before using the machine, but I had to keep the booklet on the counter next to me to follow along while I was preparing my coffee. Here are my main frustrations:

1. Seriously how many "DO NOT"s can you have in one set of instructions?? It sounded dangerous and confusing already.
2. You can only pour in the exact amount of water you think you'll need for just that use, and if you didn't add enough to steam your milk, then you have to completely shut the thing off and unplug it before you can open up the water reservoir to add more. By this time, your coffee is sitting there cooling off.
3. Coffee takes a long time to brew for the small amount it's brewing.
4. The frother is just ridiculous. It bubbles. That's it. Plus, you're supposed to move the pitcher in a circular motion--how? You hit the side of the machine because the frother points straight down. ALSO, because it bubbles almost out of control, I had hot milk splashing on my counter and other appliances. Making coffee should not be this messy.
5. The taste was sub-par. Wasn't awful, but I like my coffee shop lattes, and this just didn't cut it.
6. Basically, this machine is a slow coffee brewer with a milk "frother" on the side. You could use your own regular coffee brewer/french press (which is so much simpler), and then just use a hand-held frother. Which I plan on buying soon, after this gets returned.
title: Really Dissapointed!
bought_model: Color: CappuccinoStyle Name: 4-Cup Steam

review_content: You get what you pay for, the milk frother blows the milk out of the frothing pitcher I use and basically is useless.  Amazon customer service however, is the best.

review_content:
I love this machine. I used to have a Starbucks Barrista which was incredibly noisy and, not being an expert, difficult to get the foam I like on a cappuccino (either too bubbly and not creamy enough or too thin a cream). This does virtually all the work for you and makes a very nice creamy foam (as shown in the picture is definitely accurate). Hint: lower-fat milk (e.g., 2% rather than whole or cream) makes more foam. I use it every day.

DO remember to extend the spout for the milk over the cup - I forgot to to do this once and what a mess to clean up! Also, be sure to use a large enough cup to accommodate all the creamy foam it makes (if you like it foamy). Fortunately everything comes apart. The only detraction is that the spout/rubber hose are a bit tricky to clean. Running water through to "self-clean" it doesn't do the job adequately; but using a q-tip and a toothpick to get any residual milky clots out works fine and rinsing thoroughly helps limit this. (I don't necessarily rinse every day because I simply refrigerate the container if I happen to have any leftover milk in it.)
title: I love this machine
bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Espresso/Cappuccino Maker

review_content: I am changing my review unfortunately because the frothed quit working after a little over a month and I can't seem to get an customer service and product support has expired. If there is a rep from this company out there who can help me, please respond.
title: Quit working after a month
bought_model: Color: WhiteStyle Name: Espresso/Cappuccino Maker

review_content:
Overall I love this machine. It took a few tries and my smart daughter to figure out how to get milk, since the instructions don't mention inserting the small, flexible tube into the milk chamber lid. Now it produces terrific espresso with plenty of crema on top, and very tasty cappuccinos and lattes in assorted sizes and with adjustable froth. The only oddity now is that, after making several drinks in a row it seems to only want to make a single instead of a double, but I may just be pressing it's little heart to much! Love the cup warmer shelf on top, the slide-out shelf for demitasse cups, and being able to just pop the whole milk container into the fridge. Much better than I expected for the money, especially after getting it "Used-Very Good" for sixty bucks off the regular price! There was no indication the box had ever been opened

Additional 10/30/2013: This machine is rocking along. Figured out using the manual override to make larger drinks and only occasionally use the automatic settings anymore. Someone asked a question about storing the milk container in the fridge with left-over milk and I told them, yes you can and the instructions say the same. I would now say to just pour the milk back into the carton because, after a day or two, the milk leaves a hard-to-clean scum line on the plastic container.
title: Wonderful Device
bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Espresso/Cappuccino Maker

review_content:
I have been using one of these for one year. The strength of this machine is the convenience of pressing one button and then being able to walk away. In practice however, you actually do end up staying close to the machine to prevent overflowing foam because the volume of foam is dependent on the type of milk/cream and its temperature. If you are a nitpicker, the foam is not consistent; it has a "hard" top layer (like laundry suds) and the desirable "silky" foam is underneath. So I ended up spooning off the top 1/2 inch of "hard foam" every time.
The most important thing about a coffee maker is that It makes a good tasting cup of cappuccino, and this one does - equal to Starbucks. (after I learned Starbucks little secret of adding a tiny bit of heavy cream to the bottom of your cup - it makes all the difference!)
Then after about one year of use the foam apparatus just stopped working. I replaced it with an identical machine, and the foamer didn't work on the new machine either, and so it went back. So two broken foamers on two identical machines gives me very little confidence in the foaming system. Having to buy a new machine at $165 per year makes this a very expensive buy!
title: Beware, more expensive than it seems ‚Ä¶
bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Espresso/Cappuccino Maker

review_content:
I bought this because I was tired of paying the high prices for espresso where I live ($5+, it really adds up). I have to say that I'm glad I did. This thing can make some great tasting drinks once you get down the basics. Two things I want to remind people of though:

First make sure you pull the little tray out of the bottom in the front and dump it out after use or it will fill up and overflow. I've seen a lot of people complain that this machine leaks, which I haven't had a problem with and I think this might have something to do with it.

Second, be sure to remember to pull off the little rubber piece on the steaming wand and clean it after every use or you will get burnt milk and nasty sludge built up under there that is nearly impossible to get off.

Other than those two things, this is a great machine and I would highly recommend it.
title: I have to say that I'm glad I did
bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Automatic Dual Shot

review_content:
Does it's job as I would expect it to. For the price it's a good product. Includes tamper which is a big plus.

UPDATE Aug, 12, 2018 to 3 out of 5.

As with many others mine started giving me issues. In my case it started leaking from the bottom after 1 year of use (I have bought it 1 year and 1 month ago). It is leaking from somewhere inside, I don't even know from where and I would need to disassemble it to find a reason. I would expect something worth $80 to work at least 2 years without issues.
On the bright side, it was doing its job perfectly all this time.
title: For the price it's a good product
bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Automatic Dual Shot

review_content:
This was a gift I got for my husband. For a couple months I went back and forth between this and another espresso machine. I read reviews and learned how each worked. In the end I decided to order this one because while we drink coffee, cuppacinnos, and lattes often, I wasn't sure how much use this would get. I wanted to save a bit of money just in case. Overall, I and my husband, are very happy with this machine. It works well and very quickly considering it's affordable price point. I saw reviews of it being loud but that is the nature of an espresso machine. That said, if you are steaming milk, if you create a layer of foam first and then steam the milk the foam insulates it and keeps it from being obnoxiously loud.

We had some issues with one of the two spouts being clogged right from the beginning even after running water through it nearly ten times. (Highly recommended! Run it repeatedly until you no longer see that yucky film or haziness in the water.) To solve this we just cleared out the clogged spout and it works better. It still doesn't force the same amount of water through on both sides but it's nearly equal and likely a result of the way the machine works.

As far as quality of espresso goes, I highly, highly recommend getting a coffee roasted and ground specifically for espresso machines such as Illy. Yes it's expensive but oh so tasty. If you have your own grinder, go for it, get whole beans! But make sure to do the very fine ground that's necessary to achieve a good espresso. We have yet to experiment with our grinder to test out exactly what's best. That's the next step for us.

Lastly, as a note, if you are making more than one or two shots, use the larger grounds basket. Otherwise each shot gets more watered down as you make them. The first will be extra strong though!

Overall, this is AWESOME for the price and we couldn't be happier with it. We use it every day. If recommend it to anyone whether they were wanting to try making espresso at home or already do and want a different, well-functioning machine.
title: Affordable, Quality, and Yummy Espresso!
bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Automatic Dual Shot

review_content:

3. The coffee grind holder was almost impossible to turn during initial uses. Getting a little better, but was concerned I would bust it.

Pros:

1. Price very reasonable when purchased as it was half off original listing
2. Built in water tank
3. Easy use

review_content:
My 13-year-old has become quite the barista. He has been making coffee for my dad and me for about two years now. He makes it up the night before and we have coffee for the next day. He has done drip, french press, cold brew, Keurig and whatever else he has been able to get his hands on. We traveled to Seattle and when we were drinking coffee there he saw people put designs in the coffee and he was hooked.

I told him to pick a decent priced espresso machine and this is the one he picked. It took him a week to decide and he read the reviews on all of them and determined that this was worth the risk as there is a 200 dollar jump in the cost of machines after this one. Regardless, when it arrived he was very excited. He read the instructions and made his first cup.

This is a good machine. It does exactly what it says it is going to do and makes a good cup of coffee. You do however have to read the instructions carefully and follow them. If you dont you can end up with a pretty nasty mess. You steam clean everything after each session and so far this has worked great.

This is a good entry level espresso machine. If you are getting started and want to feel out the water this is it. It is low priced, it makes a good cup of coffee and is easy to use.

On a final note my son has mastered the heart design and he puts one in every cup he makes!

title: Five Stars
bought_model: Color: CappuccinoStyle Name: 4-Cup Steam

review_content:
EIDT. January 2013: I have now worn my first one of these out,or more accurately beat it to death. It was still working but I had gotten more out of it than I had ever hoped and it was time to retire it and buy another mostly due to operator abuse. I am on my second one for myself and I have given one as a present over a year ago which is still working well. I can't imagine morning without it.

**ORIGINAL REVIEW FROM 2009**

I had one of those steam pots for making espresso for years. (See my review of the Capresso Mini.) The little steamer was still working fine but I had banged it up a bit over the years. I went in search of a replacement and came across this machine.

I am not an espresso nut. For some people creating the perfect shot of espresso is reason to live in itself...not me. I just want a tasty cappuchino in the morning with the minimum of fuss. That is exactly what this machine delivers.

The quality is a bit plastic-y...but what would you expect for the price? Even so it is attractive enough that I don't mind it sitting on my kitchen counter. The foot print is a bit bigger than what I was used to with my Mini, but I do not think it is overly large when compared to other pump style espresso machines.

Like many other reviewers I immediately removed the rubber tip from the frothing wand and stashed the single-brew porta filter in the back of the junk drawer. doubt I'll ever use either one.

The coffee it produces is very good. A real step up from the old steam pot. Steaming for the milk is adequate though hardly robust. Still I have never failed to get the steaming results I wanted, so no complaints. One thing I do like is that the machine can be ready to froth milk in a few seconds without ever having to brew espresso. There are times when I like to use frothed milk in various "Adult" winter beverages, and now it is easy for me to to whip them up anytime.

As has been mentioned by other reviewers there is enough room beneith the portafilter (that's "brew basket" to the uninitiated)to place a full sized mug...not that you would want to brew a mug full of espresso all at once, but so that you can directly brew your shot into what will be your final cup. That is the real convenience of this feature.

The porta filter basket is a bit strange in that it has a double bottom to it. On the inside there is a layer with very fine holes to act as a filter as one would expect,....but turn the metal filter over and on the bottom there is only one single tiny hole. I believe that this may be a crema enhancing trick, but I am not sure about that. What I do know is that I have never seen another one like it. I also know that it causes a lot of constriction to the brewing of the coffee. Perhaps it is designed to make the dosing and tamping less critical in achieving a good cup of espresso? I do not have the answer, but so far it works, so I'm not complaining.

If you buy this espresso maker you will also need to get a tamper. The plastic one that comes with the machine is pretty flimsy. I got this one:

RSVP Terry's Tamper

Which fits properly and does the job just fine without a lot of expense or fanfare.

If you are thinking about trying an espresso machine, but are not sure if a fancy one is worth the expense, this is a great choice.

UPDATE: After 9 months I haven't had a single issue with durability. I have discovered by trial and error that it is possible to over pack the filter basket (portafilter) and when that happens the pump struggles. But by now I have gotten my "dosing" down to a system and I always get excellent results. The leaking that other reviewers mention is caused because the pump purges into the drip tray when you are done brewing. If the drip tray isn't emptied regularly, or if it isn't seated in the base correctly it will leak water onto thte counter. The instructions tell you this. I have never had a leak problem with my unit.

I love this machine! I wold buy another without hesitation if I had need of one, or I would give one as a gift with confidence. Good job, Mr. Coffee!

review_content:
My reviews are usually very positive but I've got to let the steam out on this machine. Update: 6-9-2014 The third replacement is much better than the first two. I've been using it daily and have had one delicious cappuccino after another ! The nice folks at Mr Coffee provided excellent customer service and I'm thrilled!

I've owned a dozen cappuccino machines in the last 25 years and each lasts about 2 years. The knob on this one that controls the on, off and steam snapped off after just 12 weeks, because the inside of the knob that connects to the coffee machine is made of cheap plastic. All the other machines I've owned have a metal insert. I'd encourage you to look at other cappuccino machines and avoid this cheapo !

Good luck!
Neil Wood

Dec. 17th ! 2:30 ~ In fairness, I should note that I just called Mr Coffee Customer Service to ask for a replacement. I spoke with Glen and explained what happened to the machine. He was terrific and told me a replacement expresso maker would arrive within 6 business days! Excellent service!!

Feb 7th, 2013 ~ the replacement machine broke just 6 weeks after it arrived. Mr Coffee has offered to replace it for free, so I'll try one more time. This lost all power, wouldn't heat up at all.....which is really bizarre. Oh well.....maybe I should stop drinking coffee? LOL

review_content: We had purchased a $300 espresso machine, during the day to use for our family dinner before Christmas Eve last year, from a department store, by a major brand name. Had all off the recommended features, First machine made it through two cycles, both were very weak and not acceptable, then the pump failed and it peed all over the counter. Never made another cup. We went straight back to the store and got a replacement unit that only lasted most of the night. We then upgraded to a different manufacturer and paid over $400. This one made it  almost a week, before the pump failed. Took this one back and did not buy another one. This year, my wife suggested that I get a cheap unit just so she could have a latte at night. I bought this with a $30 gift certificate and took the slow freight ($9 out of pocket). You have to experiment with it a bit to get it just right to your taste, but it has been great for the espresso for the latte. We also found that it works better if you make the espresso, then put more water in and stream the milk as a separate operation. Just make sure you don't leave the coffee carafe in place or you will weaken your espresso. My wife was drinking a latte every night ($5) plus gas. Now she makes one when she wants it and we just use a pound of coffee every two weeks. Maybe the $1000 are better, but don;t waste your money on the $3-400 ones.

After having some expensive machines like Francis-Francis that cost at least 5 times what this one costs (and they don't last that long either), I have to say that you can't beat this one. Another of the pros (at least in my opinion) is that they use regular bulk coffee and they do not require the pods. Not only this saves you money in coffee, but I also believe that the preparation of the coffee by putting the right amount of coffee and applying the right amount of pressure with the tamper is an important part in the art of coffee making!
The machine is ready to make your espresso just instants after turning it on, so that is also a big plus.
Note: It works great with Lavazza Crema e Gusto Ground Coffee, which amazon has at a very good price also:
Lavazza Crema e Gusto Ground Coffee, Italian , 8.8-Ounce Bricks (Pack of 4)

review_content:
I have been using this machine once a day for about a year now and it still works great. It is definitely worth the price. There are a few things about the steamer/milk frother that you should know:
1. In my opinion, the black rubber piece that goes on the tip of the steamer is pointless. It's just another thing to have to clean. I took it off and threw it away.
2. On rare occasions, after turning on the steamer, it might not actually start shooting out steam for a few seconds. This doesn't happen often, though, and it only doesn't work for a few seconds, so it's not that annoying.
3. There isn't any way to purge the steamer, because after you turn off the steamer, the machine thinks you are completely done using it and it takes like a whole minute to shut down the steamer and get rid of the steam inside the machine. In my opinion, the lattes, cappuccinos, etc. it can produce are still great though, even if you can't purge the steamer before and after frothing the milk.

title: I still used it for a while and it made pretty good coffee
bought_model: Color: CappuccinoStyle Name: 4-Cup Steam

review_content:
(Two important cleaning/maintenance tips included at the end of the review)

I went on a trip abroad recently and whenever I ordered coffee, it was consistently absolutely terrible... however, on occasion I was actually served freshly made espresso, and it was consistently absolutely fantastic.

I always thought that buying an espresso machine was a bit over-the-top and snobbish, but based on that experience, I decided to just break down and get one anyway.
I was appropriately and inevitably warned by some 'coffee connoisseurs' how you need to spend at least $500 and up, if you want even a remotely decent espresso machine. That might have been the case at some point in the past, but in my opinion, this little machine well under $100 bucks produces some amazing results.

I started off going really cheap - with Mr. Coffee steam driven Espresso Maker. While the frothing ability of that one was quite wonderful and the cappuccinos were surprisingly good, the espresso lacked "crema" - the coffee froth on top, which is my absolute favorite part.
I realized that the pump-driven machine is a way to go, so I passed the first device on to my friend, who loves hot chocolate, and uses it to froth the milk.

This machine was my second choice.
I still did not want to spend a fortune and hesitated a while between this one and DeLonghi (EC155), but got discouraged by the amount of the preheat/prep time on DeLonghi (about 25 mins based on most of the reviewers' accounts).

So far I am completely delighted with this one... it is astoundingly simple to operate and clean, the prep (preheat) time is minimal, and the espressos are JUST GREAT - there is plenty of froth (crema) on top to stimulate you visually and to satiate your taste buds as well... and also it froths the milk fabulously.

Yes, it does seem to leak a bit, but I was prepared for that, reading other people's reviews. The container with the water has a hole on the bottom, through which it attaches to the machine, and the water runs through there during the brewing, so it makes sense, that some miniscule amount of that might leak in the process.
Not a big deal, I just wipe it off periodically.

I highly recommend reading other reviews on here - you get quite a few helpful tips about the coffee grinding, the best coffee grounds to use, tamping, milk frothing etc ....

Bottom line: if you like a really good espresso, and either don't want to be spending megabucks at some *(star) bucks kind of place or don't want to plunk down couple of hundred bucks for a fancier-looking machine - then this one is a way to go.
Will pay for itself in a short time, and unless you are a true espresso aficionado, you will never notice the difference between your home-made espresso shot and most of the store-bought ones.

And finally, these are two maintenance tips, that I have picked up along the way and added:
1.
The cleaning instructions do not mention this, but make sure you always wipe out the part, where the filter holder attaches to the machine (I think it is called the filter head).
Most of the time there are some leftover wet coffee grounds that float up from the metal filter and get stuck to the machine after each brew, and of course you won't see them unless you look from underneath.
And if left uncleaned after a while, the old dried-up grounds will make each new batch taste bitter and/or stale.
2.
this addendum is written Jan 19th 2010, about a year later (BTW the machine still works perfect, even though I do not use it daily, as I am trying to cut back on coffee):
Whenever the coffeemaker just sits around for couple of days without being used, remember first to run through a cup or two of plain water before you start the next brew, so all the metallic parts inside get chance to clean and freshen up.
There were several times, when I made the coffee, and had to throw it away, as it had this weird, hard to describe metallic/oily taste... not completely toxic tasting, but just very unpleasant and WAY off.
Then I realized that it happened always after I have not used the thing for a while, and the problem got solved completely once I started running the water through first.
title: Great machine for the money - both espresso and cappuccino taste excellent!
bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Automatic Dual Shot

review_content: My spending at coffee shops, including SBux, was way out of hand. Some days I visited 2 or 3 times. I knew I needed to save money so I started looking at home espresso/cappuccino machines. Plus, I am a big fan of organic milk and organic fair-trade coffee, so I am able to create healthier, better lattes at a fraction of the cost as coffee shops. I happened to see this one at Target on sale and bought it. At first I was cautiously happy. It seemed to work fine for my purposes, although I could never successfully make more than 2 shots of decent espresso without it leaking. After a couple weeks, it started spurting water out from the filter basket (leaking) during every brew cycle. I tried to clean everything perfectly, thinking maybe grounds were stuck somewhere. I didn't tamp too much. I used coarser grounds, but it still kept doing it. It seemed dangerous...steam and hot water spurting everywhere. And every single time you were done, you had to let all the steam out. And if you didn't put enough water in to steam the milk, you had to add more before you could continue steaming the milk. I also read the reviews where people said it exploded, and after seeing the water start spurting like crazy and leaking everywhere, I could see where that would happen. So I returned it to Target and got the pump-version of Mr. Coffee ECMP50. It was $30 more, but OMG what a difference. It is so easy to deal with. And the espresso is rich and creamy, not weak. 1 shot is enough for a big mug now! Before I had to make a sort of cafe au lait because the "espresso" from the ECM160 wasn't really espresso at all...it was a mix between drip coffee and espresso. For those of you out there considering this machine, please don't get it if you like good, rich espresso. It is a huge hassle. At least for me. And I consider myself to be adept at learning pretty quickly.
title: Just didn't work for me
bought_model: Color: CappuccinoStyle Name: 4-Cup Steam

review_content:
Purchased Sept 2013. Frother failed after 6 months or so; got around to doing something about it after 9 months passed. Emailed Mr Coffee customer service. They asked for copy of receipt (sent PDF of purchase order). They replaced it and told me to toss the old one. I can live with that...

Reduced from 4 to 3 stars - November 2015 - After about 15 months, the same problem occurred in the replacement. The milk steaming function seems to work but no milk. I have been careful to clean after each use. I use this about 5 times per week. I can still make expresso but can only manage steamed milk on Cappacinno "froth" setting and then only after repeated cycles. Also, at 13 months, the screw inside the handle of the portafilter that holds the handle to the filter head came loose and needed to use some creativity to disassemble and repair.

At $200, I will guess I made about 200 cups of expresso with steamed milk so cost of machine is about $1 per cup plus materials.... I will try another brand.
title: Machine failed but Customer service did not.... then UPDATE failed again after warranty expiration
bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Espresso/Cappuccino Maker

review_content: I worked at Dunkin Donuts and Starbucks making espressos and espresso based drinks.  I haven't tried any other at-home espresso makers, but after reading the reviews and comparing prices, my husband and I purchased this at Target.  LOVE IT!!  I can see how some people would have some trouble using it if they're not used to making espressos and frothing milk.  The techniques take some time to learn.  I use a ceramic cream pitcher to froth the milk; we have yet to splurge on a stainless steel pitcher.  Just remember to follow the cleaning instructions for the frothing wand (I followed the advice of other customers and removed the rubber tip on the frother)and just follow the directions on everything else, and you'll be in good shape.  Remember to empty the water from the drip tray after a few uses or the drip tray will overflow and leak (kind of common sense, but you know...).  Also to help those amateur frothers, after heating the milk with the frother, pull the wand out of the milk so that the tip of the wand just "kisses" the surface of the milk to froth.  We've made 1 inch plus thick foam this way with whole, 2 percent, 1 percent and skim milk!  Excellent, excellent, excellent.  Espresso takes some patience and love, but it's worth it!  We've now owned our machine for 7 months.

review_content:

Of course nothing is perfect, so Cafe Barista has some negatives but only a few minor ones. My machine leaks where the portafilter gets attached in order to brew the espresso, but there is a drip tray beneath it so not a big deal. The amount of milk that is frothed I don't think is enough, so I always froth more after the espresso brews which is easily done. It can also be kind of noisy but not too bad. The tamper isn't the best (it's plastic) but does the job.
Overall, I think this was a smart purchase and I don't regret it.

Before I purchased this I saw the youtube videos of other customers that this happened to, but I thought they just must not have had the top and the coffee container on tight. I was wrong! Mr. Coffee is going to be getting a not very nice letter from me. I have bought Mr. Coffee machines for 4 decades but if I don't get a refund .. this will be my last!!

review_content:
My wife loves lattes and cappuccinos, and this machine is acceptable for this. The steam wand is well positioned, though it takes a long time to get going and spurts a lot of water before it gets up to speed (about a 3oz of water, honestly). The taste of the espresso is fine, because it will be masked by your milk and flavors.

However, I prefer to drink espresso neat, and this is where the machine falls short. It is not brewed hot enough (or properly). No steam passes through the grounds, instead the water is dripped like a coffee machine - this means you will not have any crema, and the espresso is short of full flavored. The temperature can be fixed by preheating the machine (switch on the steam wand for a while), but there is still no crema, and it is still on the bitter side. The bitterness dominates the flavor (using Lavazza Super Crema).

I had my father come over and make a pot before I submitted this review, because he makes outstanding espresso and I wanted to make sure I gave the machine a fair chance. It tasted better, but still didn't come close to the taste from his $60 Krups machine.

Perhaps I got a lemon. But I'm not gonna buy another one to find out. I'm moving up to the DeLonghi EC155, and selling this to my brother for lattes.

review_content:
The unit was delivered to me on March 26. This is my second unit. It worked perfectly initially. Right amount of milk & espresso for every cup of latte and I used it daily in the morning to make a 2 cup-latte. I also followed the cleansing instruction to clean the milk reservoir after each use.

Three days ago, I started to notice the milk was not coming out as it used to. For a 2-cup latte, only approximately 100 mL milk would came out from the froth tube, and a large amount of milk was left in the milk reservoir (I pretty much put the same amount of milk to the reservoir everyday). I had to push the froth button to make more frothed milk to my latte. This morning (May 26), it's even worse, only approximately 50 mL came out... it is noticeable the milk was not suctioned up... I tested it again this afternoon, the only way the milk would come out from froth tube is if I hit the clean button...

Since it's over 30 days, it cannot be returned anymore. And product window was closed YESTERDAY, May 25, 2017............

Update: I contacted Amazon customer service and let them know what happened after I wrote the above review. Customer services ordered me a replacement. The replacement arrived on 5/28/2017 with missing critical part to make latte or cappuccino (no milk reservoir, no way to froth milk). The machine was put into its original box without Styrofoam protection, so you can hear rattling sounds when carry it. (I still cannot believe this was shipped to me.)

review_content: Not a bad machine. Two things that need improving:  1) If you have a problem with the espresso dripping slowly after using the machine 4-5 then you are grinding too fine. I am grinding beans in the Mister Coffee Automatic Burr Mill Grinder and I have to set it in between fine and "drip coffee". If you grind the beans on the fine setting the machine can not handle it. 2) Takes 1-2 minutes to heat the water, but for this price, you get what you pay for. Overall for the price, great machine to make coffee.

review_content:
Because of the bad reviews, I purchased this at Wal-Mart because returns would have been easier (and it was $20 cheaper..sorry Amazon!). But, I have to say, it's a decent machine.

I was leery to purchase it for 2 reasons: Mr. Coffee Drip makes TERRIBLE coffee (yuck); and the bad reviews of the leaking problems was a definite red flag.

I've owned 2 DeLongi machines, both leaked like sieves. The Mr. Coffee has not leaked after 4 months of making 3 espressos a day. Water is kept in the reservoir all the time and none of it has spilled out on my counter. It works like a charm.

The Mr. Coffee Espresso makes a good cup like to the Delongi, but the Delongi, but takes FOREVER to finish. Not so with the Mr. Coffee. I have left it unattended several times and the cup overflows before I can get back to it (user error).

So why only 4 stars? I question the materials from which it was made. The cover that closes the water reservoir appears to be VERY fragile (cheap plastic); and I feel like if I was startled or sneezed while opening or closing it, the cover would crack off. So, I treat it with kid gloves.

Not sure how long it will last, but for now, I'm very happy with the purchase. It's not the quality of a $400 machine, but at $50, it was well worth the investment.
title: Makes a good cup o' joe!
bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Automatic Dual Shot

review_content:
I like my Mr. Coffee espresso machine. This is my second one and for the $ it does what it was designed to do. It gets some getting familiar with. Here are the directions I use to get a couple of cups of joe.

first pack the finely ground coffee down nice and tight. Fill the machine with the amount of water with which you want to use (I use the hand pot), then turn the machine on ( counter clockwise). It will fill the cup about ¬º the way up with coffee then rotate the handle clockwise to froth. Froth till the milk or cream gets warm and place the knob to the off position. Remove the milk from under the frothing tube and blow some steam for a few seconds so the tube dose not get clogged. Continue with the coffee (counter clockwise) till it stops coming out. Rotate back forward so all the steam is evacuated from unit. I like to then unscrew the filler cap so when I use it again the cap is easy to open. If you do not do this the vacuum can cause the cap to be tight. I like the unit and it will last for a long time if it is properly taken care of.
title: Like It
bought_model: Color: CappuccinoStyle Name: 4-Cup Steam

review_content: My rationale in purchasing this inexpensive machine was that  it would pay for itself with just 7 to 8 lattes but the "espresso" is just a small cup of mildly strong coffee and while the steamer wand will heat the milk (primarily by shooting it full of very hot water) it WILL NOT foam.  My theory is that you cannot foam milk that is half water.  Note also that the reservoir only holds enough water to fill the carafe so if you fill it you will not have any water left to create steam to heat the milk even if you were willing to forego the foam.  My advice...if you really want to make a decent espresso, cappuccino or  latte at home save yourself time and aggravation by investing in a quality machine and expect a longer ROI.
title: You get what you pay for.
bought_model: Color: CappuccinoStyle Name: 4-Cup Steam

review_content:
Man, I bought this 5 years ago, tried it a couple of times, hated it, and let it collect dust. A recent month-long trip to Florence got me hooked on espresso, so I dug this out and tried again. Crema comes to those who wait!! For people disappointing in this machine, don't give up! Keep trying. (Unless you really want the frother to work...yeah, still haven't gotten that to work, hence the 4 stars)

See, I believe I was using too large grind size back in the day, and I got NO crema whatsoever. I got bitter, weak, overextracted coffee that tasted sour and looked like engine oil. Now, with the big ole espresso machines in coffee shops I believe you can adjust the pressure settings yourself (hence the term 'pulling' espresso). This little baby isn't gonna let you do that. You just have steam, so the only variable you can really control is the ground size, and the tamping. To get smooth espresso with crema off of this machine, I needed to get fine grounds. I used preground Lavazza with some success, but using my hand-held burr grinder and Trader Joe's Espresso 5 origin blend I got it to about the same size as those grounds, perhaps a bit more fine, with better results (probably also because the beans were fresher). If you're getting excessive coffee residue/grinds in your cup it's too fine, slowly go coarser. However, the key part for me was pressing my thumb into the grounds, if it left a clean impression then that was good enough. The coffee grinds have to 'stick' to each other.

Tamping: I used my thumb! Haha, didn't feel like waiting for the tamper to come in the mail, and honestly with this machine I'm not expecting perfect control every time so in a fatalist sense I didn't feel like it was worth it. Pat down firmly with your thumb, make the grounds as flat as possible. You can get it pretty flat and firm with just your thumb.

Make sure the coffee machine is full when you start--I think the pressure is better that way. Haven't opened it up so I can't say how the boiler works, but fill up the tank. I use spring water from my work cooler, I imagine tap is okay too but at least try to filter it to get out some of the minerals. Descaling is a headache I don't want to deal with too often.

I didn't heck around with letting the boiler preheat to steam and then switching around, just turned it on brew and let it go to town. I'm pretty happy with the results of thumb-tamping and flipping a switch in this photo I attached with crema! (apologies for the messy espresso cup)
title: crema IS possible!!
bought_model: Color: CappuccinoStyle Name: 4-Cup Steam

review_content: This automatic Mr. Coffee Cafe does it all easily, with little effort and has the tools necessary to create a rich flavored espresso or Cappuccino.  This is easy to use and froth to your hearts delight.  There are many different coffee makers out there on the market these days, but the old reliable Mr. Coffee still leads the pack for quality and convenience.  This is one of those great items that will make a great wedding gift for your favorite newlyweds!
title: Mr. Coffee comes through again with a great product!
bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Caf√© Steam

review_content:
I'm revising my earlier review and raising the rating from two to four stars. . Some of the problems listed below are still correct (the amount of milk still varies). But now that I've gotten used to its idiosyncrasies, I am consistently making terrific drinks every day (okay, maybe two or three drinks).

My advice: Try it (yes, it's still messy, a bit hard to clean and somewhat inconsistent on the milk side), but for the price it DOES make great drinks.

_______________________
Previous review:

I wish I could give this a good review. Yes, it makes good espresso drinks. Sometimes.

It is a bit messy and the milk container is not a great design. The real problem (on two machines now) is that the flow of milk is very inconsistent. The first cup of the morning ALWAYS overflows. Calls to Mr. Coffee customer service will simply get you a brusque representative and a new machine, which will take a couple of weeks to arrive (you must return the old one to them).

I have tried two different machines, and both had problems and had to be returned. It could be quality control, but it looks like a defective design that Mr. Coffee is willing to sell knowing that it's cheaper to keep sending replacements to unhappy customers until they fix the bugs in the next model. Also, the customer service reps could really use some lessons in patience or at least listening. They've been trained to do one thing: send a replacement.
title: I've upgraded the rating after several months of use
bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Espresso/Cappuccino Maker

review_content:
If you are thinking about it, if you drink your Starbucks daily, if you are tired of inconsistent results or burnt coffee, this is your solution. The milk reservoir means no more having to clean a too low frothing wand. The espresso scoop is very easy to load and (with the right grounds) requires minimal tamping, the drinks come out at a very *immediately* drinkable temperature, with no burnt taste. Combine this with Lavazza Blu, whatever milk you like, and a set of syrups (we started with the 25.3oz 6 pack and honed our favorites), along with their pumps and you will save time, money, and your tongue! I have been to Starbucks ONCE in 3 months, and it tasted gross.

Pros:
- Water and milk reservoirs extremely easy to fill and use. Milk reservoir contains almost the exact amount for 2 large lattes every morning (16 oz). If you use the quick clean cycle daily, you only need to really clean it once a week - other than that, it goes in the fridge. No more waste.
- Compact - does not take up a lot of space, comes with everything needed for the machine.
- Temperature -- while not adjustable, we haven't needed to. Perfect for all 3 functions, and just steamed milk for chai or hot cocoa.
- Sturdiness - no piece feels like it will break, we use it at least once a day , every day, and at 3 months everything works the same as day one.
- Push the button and go -- you get in a routine, 30 seconds attention and about a 3 minute wait gets you your daily latte, americano or cappuccino.
- Cost effective - we have seen a $300+ decrease in coffee expenditure over 2 months. We drink a lot of coffee, but this saves you so much.
title: Make the leap, you won't be sorry
bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Espresso/Cappuccino Maker

review_content:
Bought it when I wanted a good single-cup brewer but couldn't find one that was any good without spending too much. I was impecunious so I waited until this one went on sale for $25 and tried it out. Short report: Could not be faster or easier, has never failed me, cleans in 15 seconds, makes great coffee. I use a variety of coffees including espresso grinds and drip grinds and they all work great. Also the single cup aspect means no waste, which cuts way down on my coffee costs. I figure the little darling has saved me several times its purchase price already just in coffee savings and not buying coffee bar coffees for $3-4 a cup and up.

Also I call this the Anti-Keurig. Why pay $140 for a machine that does the same thing and doubles your per-cup cost for the coffee grind? Figure out the price per pound you would pay for K-cups and in about a week, you'd save enough to buy the Mr. Coffee instead and have at least $100 left over on the machine price while you are at it. And the K-cup coffee does not, repeat not, taste better than what this little gem makes. The K-cup is the biggest ripoff in the grocery business today, by far.

Also ignore reports of "exploding" machines. The machine cannot explode, the tank will not rupture and the cap cannot come off. Failure to follow directions can lead to an overpressure which will release pressure through the cap safety valve, and make a noise and some steam, but there's no explosion and nothing gets hurt. The main thing is to just remember to turn the thing off when you are done brewing.

Caveat: I do not like steamed milk and I do not use that feature, so I have no opinion about it.

Note: No, it does not come with a tamper, although the little scoop works okay. Also my old salt shaker works just fine. Tamping is not really necessary, it just makes you feel better. Don't overtamp, you can block the brewing cup that way and create an overpressure or delay/stop the brew.

Note: Flavor depends on the coffee you use. Cheapo supermarket espressos are ... okay but not wonderful. To get wonderful, you have to use premium coffees, such as the Lavazza products that are very reasonably priced on Amazon. Rule of thumb, the cheaper the coffee, the more bitter it will taste. For non-bitter, spend for better coffee. Use filtered or bottled water. You can actually put your Yuban in this thing and get better coffee than some of the cheap espressos out there. I know, I tried it.

I could tell a difference between good and great coffee through the machine and the amount of crema, but overall it was pretty disappointing - the crema barely covered the espresso. It also steamed the milk very messily - not to mention that I could never get a big enough cup for a cappucino. Lastly, the espresso and coffee drinks it made came out warm - I don't need piping hot coffee, but I certainly expected more than warm coffee.

It certainly looks like the Lattisma Nespresso machine and I thought it would be a good alternative to a capsule system, but it certainly does not even come close.

review_content:
I am an experienced barista, having made lattes for the past 13 years. I bought this machine because I thought it would be a cheaper alternative to buying my lattes in cafes. I was wrong. The first time I used it, the glass caraffe exploded on me. As someone with education in both chemistry and physics, let me assure you that this is not normal. The molecules of a well-made glass container are not supposed to respond to the change in heat from putting cold water into the caraffe to fill the reservoir to espresso then filling the caraffe. This change in heat is too small to have an effect. However, if the glass is made poorly, cheaply, and without regard to surface area conditions, a smaller change in heat can affect it to the point where the glass molecules expand too quickly and the gas explodes. This often, unfortunately, happens with outsourced product-making done by people who do not plan the product to meet engineering requirements because they would rather save money. I have filed a complaint with the company and requested a recall. I repeat: this machine is dangerous and could have either killed or seriously harmed me. I was lucky to not have large glass shards in both my face and abdomen. PLEASE buy a different machine. I don't want this happening to anyone else.

Also, the machine was not made with proper latte-making in mind. When making a latte, the espresso has to be made last, so that it can be poured into the foamed milk within 15 seconds of the shot being poured. The shots of espresso itself on this machine pour way too slowly, taking 15 seconds if not longer just to finish. The foamed milk has to be made after making the espresso, at least according to the instruction manual. At this point, once you have drawn your shot and are waiting to foam the milk, the espresso itself will have fully acidified from mixing with oxygen in the air, and your latte will be quite bitter.

And finally, the machine has to be relieved of pressure because it is, again, cheaply made and not well-designed in terms of engineering. To do so, you must run the milk foamer to exit the pressure from the machine as steam. This can take you forever, as you will see the foamer run and run and run. If you stop running it, hoping the machine has been relieved, and then try to remove the espresso pod-holder or the reservoir cap...it again has explosive results.

If there is any way you can save about $40 more to buy a better machine, I highly recommend it. I am currently a student again earning another degree, and can sympathize with the allure of buying a cheaper machine. Unfortunately, this truly isn't worth your safety. Please be careful.

review_content:
Just to put it out there:
I don't drink espresso so I can't really comment on how "authentic" this machine makes espresso. I love my coffee with cream and sugar, and the main reason I bought an espresso machine is to avoid the long line at Starbucks. This is the 1st machine I own, 3rd one I tried in my life.

Anyway, let's talk about the machine.

What I like about it:
1. The water tank is easily accessible; it holds a large amount of water; I can see how much water is in the tank very easily.
2. The drip tray is removable, makes it super easy to clean, just because to clean it often other wise it will overflow
3. There's two holes on the drip try for you to lay the portafilter in (I love this feature!)
4. It came with both 1 shot and 2 shot basket (but I always use 2 shots when making my latte
5. It came with a spoon with tamper on the other side. Not the most ideal method I know, but since I can't find a 51mm tamper, this will do for now. The fact that it's detached from the machine already makes it so much better than some other home machines
6. Machines is not any louder than other ones I've tried.
7. Milk heats up really fast, and it's not as loud as some other machine. (though I stronly recommend moving the rubber thing on the frothing wand for easy cleaning

What I don't like about it:
1. I sometimes see little water leak, but a lot of reviews say they seen the same problem
2. The portafilter doesn't drip completely. my personal habit is to leave portafilter on the drip tray until it's dry then I dump it outside as compose. not liking when I pick up the portafilter some coffee drip to my shirt/things
3. Cannot restart. sometimes it's a hassle to make more than one cup of espresso at a time, the mahines takes just a long to warm up for later cups as for first cups.
4. basket is not a common size; I am having very hard time finding a right size tamper...

That's pretty much it. This machine is very easy to use as a experienced-beginner and I love how my beverages have turn out in the past couple month!
title: Nice little counter top machine for homemade latte
bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Automatic Dual Shot

review_content: I've had this for 2 years and I still adore it. I am an avid coffee/espresso drinker and this hits the spot. Please do yourself a favor and do get good coffee like lavazza and grind to appropriate coarsness. In a bind I get their ground coffee here on Amazon. Extremely dissatisfied.

review_content: I got this from walmart and not through amazon, so it wont be a verified purchase. This machine is great. I use it daily to make a cappuccino for work.It isn't the greatest, but its also not priced anywhere close to what the better machines are. Advice i was given by my local coffee shop for better espresso is use filtered water and freshly ground beans, those are 2 of the most important things in any coffee. My few days using it I wasn't getting any crema, but I stopped worrying about it and i noticed after a week or so that it was starting to have a decent head on it. The frothing arm does a pretty decent job and overall i would say its a great machine to explore espresso with and not having to break the bank. You will want to get at least a 49mm tamper and a frothing pitcher (the frothing arm's angle doesn't allow any sort of deep cups) to get started with it.

It also seems if you tamp the espresso too tightly (which is, almost any tamping at all) the water can't seem to get through the basket. It worked great at first, but it's almost useless at this point, having owned it for about 6 months. We are already looking for another machine. I'm not too upset, as it was only $40, but I would have liked for it to last a little longer and perform better.

-overall I like it a lot.

Cons-takes a long time to clean.
-the screw cap for the water reservoir is an awkard shape and finish making it difficult to ensure it is screwed on properly or tightly until water starts spewing out the top (only happened the first time-I've been careful ever since).
-ditto for shape and texture of power/brew/steam knob; just difficult to grip and turn.
-labels on carafe are only on one side, so handle must be turned to the right to know when to stop brewing; I prefer the handle on the left because it is awkward for me to be on the right (and I'm right-handed).
-As all the other reviews state: order a 20 oz. frothing pitcher as a minimum; I tried using a measuring 4C. measuring cup and it spewed milk all over my counter and kitchen. I froth 4 oz. of milk in the 20 oz. pitcher and make only a little mess now. I am still no pro at frothing-I end up with a lot of hot milk and a few bubbles after the "frothing" process-looks like someone blowing huge bubbles in your milk-is done.
-SUPER ANNOYING: it has an 8" power cord. What is up with that? It is hard to reach on a deep counter and it makes a huge mess all over my back-splash while frothing/cleaning. Since I am an amateur, I have to turn the machine this way and that in order to froth and it makes a mess because I tip the entire machine over, almost get burned, etc. Going to have to find a place on my counter where I can place it and use an extension cord.

Overall-a great purchase and value for not having to stop at Starbucks for a real cappuccino (time and expense). I am just nit-picky about the little things. I also wish I had a magic button to clean it all up when my coffee is brewed so I can sit and enjoy my coffee-sometimes stopping at Starbucks is enticing just so I don't have to clean up the mess.
title: Great for a home-made cappuccino!
bought_model: Color: CappuccinoStyle Name: 4-Cup Steam

review_content: Have been using it daily for around 5 years. Occasionally need to order new drop-in basket as (any machine) they tend to clog up after a year or so. Some people complain about "water leaks" but it's just the drain system -- you DO have to empty it routinely or it will overflow. Always keep the water level above the line or you'll generate problems!  If you forget and run it empty, you have to re-"prime" the pump (get the tubes filled with water). Grind should be fairly fine for best results, but if too fine that's when you might eventually clog up a basket. That's all I can think of.  This is a workhorse and makes gooooood espresso!
title: Grind should be fairly fine for best results
bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Automatic Dual Shot

review_content: ... with that said, this machine is AWESOME. I had an issue with my first machine in which the frothing knob stripped itself and would turn left or right very easily while making a crunching noise. Amazon has terrific customer service and took care of me and my new machine arrived less than a week later. Despite my issue with the first machine, this setup is the greatest espresso device I've ever seen. Load the coffee, place the milk bin into the machine, wait for it to warm up, then press your desired espresso style. It does everything for you. It used to take me five to seven minutes with my old manual machine (which was a very nice machine) to make a latte... now it takes a fraction of the time. I'm in love with this machine.

review_content: Great little gadget and will step up your caffeine game. I'm currently on vacation and am really missing my espresso machine. I feel I make the best ice espressos. I fill up my stainless tumbler with ice, pour a quad shot, add Almond milk and and sugar free Italian cream creamer and it's THE BOMB! It makes Starbucks drink seem lesser once you are able to craft your favorite drink. It's also perfect left warm but will require steaming or microwaving you cold mixes. Get it!!! I use mine all the time and not a leak or squeak.
title: Great little gadget
bought_model: Color: CappuccinoStyle Name: 4-Cup Steam

review_content:
I would like to preface this review by stating that I'm a pretty serious coffee snob (BUT WAIT!!! That doesn't mean I hated the product). I work as a barista at a very high end gourmet coffee shop that pays a fanatical attention to detail. I wanted to purchase an espresso machine for my home, and I ventured into my local target and walked out with this one. While it is pretty much impossible for a small, consumer-level espresso machine to keep up with the larger professional models, I was pleasantly surprised by the quality of both the espresso and steam wand.

The espresso actually had a decent amount of creme (the layer of foam laying over the liquid in an espresso shot), which you don't get in a lot of low end espresso machines, mostly because a lot of the smaller machines can't control the pressure going into the espresso grinds, but this one seems to do a pretty good job. I would recommend warming the machine up a bit before you make your drink. The keys to good espresso temp control and attention to both the grind of the espresso and the way it is situated in the puck, so if you get the machine hot before you brew and make sure that you take care in packing and tamping the espresso into the puck, it will go a long way.

For steaming the milk, the directions in the manual are actually pretty decent. The wand is fairly good, its not as powerful as the larger espresso machines, but for the size and cost it's actually quite good. Turn the steam wand on for a second or two, then turn it off, then insert the wand into your milk and start steaming. Otherwise the wand (as with all other espresso machines) will discharge cold water into your drink. Also, run the wand for a second or two after you finish steaming, this clears the milk out of the tip of the wand, so it won't wander back into the boiler.

If you people aren't yet sick of listening to me talk, I would recommend doing some youtube surfing and watching some videos on milk steaming and also on espresso grinding and tamping. It will help a lot. If you find that you are getting really large bubbles in your milk, you are probably trying to "stretch" the milk too quickly, so settle the steam wand further into the milk. You want to the wand to "chirp" every couple of seconds, that will get you a proportional amount of foam for a latte or cappuccino. Check out videos by David Schomer (ignore the fact that he looks like the kid you used to beat up in highschool, he actually knows his coffee pretty well), and once you get the foam down, check out some latte art videos and try to play with that. It's fun. If you would like to know more about the technique and things of that sort, I've just decided to start a blog, so go look for it.

To recap:

Espresso machine is really quite good for the money.

hope this helps!

Also, when you brew two shots at the same time, the two holes will pour the coffee unevenly, so it's annoying that you can't have both mugs with exactly the same amount of coffee. Moreover, the machine vibrates when brewing, so your mugs will move enough to get the espresso all spilled over the drip tray if you're not holding them. This wouldn't happen if they had designed a larger distance between the holes. Moreover, the plastic clip attached to the brew basket is so poorly designed that it gets stuck with the upper part of the machine, and you have to really force it to turn it to the right before brewing. And, finally, the machine is really too big for what it does. I'd rather stay with my same old stovetop!

When using the beans from our local coffee shop, it's almost as good as their best barista can make on their specialized italian machine, and better than the three other baristas that work there - probably because they just don't know how to tamp the beans or adjust the grind. Moral of the story: a lousy barista can screw up the work of even a great machine.

But if I use my own preferred blend of beans, I find the coffee is way better than any of the shops in town. With a little experience, a good coffee blend on this Mr. Coffee trumps a so-so blend even if brewed by a great barista on a great machine.

So, definitely, for $70 on sale, this is a great machine. And if it turns out be not so durable, I'll just get a new one!
I've already saved 2x more than its cost in 90 days, and I get a reliable delicious double shot (or two!) espresso every day.

About two months ago the water that drips from the machine into the coffee pod didn't pass through and ended up bursting (due to the pressure) and splashing the grounded coffee and water all over my kitchen (not to mention it's frightening to be near it when it happens as VERY HOT WATER can potentially splash in your face and produce a very serious burn). The coffee itself doesn't have a course grind and I only use that coffee on that machine.

I really can't find an explanation as to why the machine is suddenly having trouble passing water through the pod (I don't press is it very hard or too lightly). Anyway, beware of the potential dangers this machine may bring (especially if you have small kids around).

title: Wake up Mr. Coffee
bought_model: Color: CappuccinoStyle Name: 4-Cup Steam

review_content:
Update: After 5 Days of Use

The machine is still a good low cost espresso machine and I retain the 4 stars. However, I have to take back the fact that it's a fantastic coffee machine. If you use the specified amount of beans with the water, it makes a great espresso. However, trying to use it as a coffee machine by adding more water is not so good. The problem lies in the the fact that the pressurized steam water literally shoots like a jet rocket half way through. This cause the water to essentially pass through the grind that's already been drained of flavor super heated, adding a cigarette/ashe taste to the robust inital drain. I wasn't expecting so much pressure from the machine. Expensive pump based machines aren't like this and can be used as a coffee like machine. I'll just use it as an espresso machine, as it was meant to be. My Mr Coffee 4 cup coffee machine, which is discontinued i think, still is the best coffee machine.

-----------------------------------------------------
I'm a very picky coffee drinker, who is also budget conscious. I've gone through years of evolution in my coffee brewing techniques to try to brew the best tasting coffee at the lowest price. My current setup is a 4 cup Mr Coffee coffee maker with a Krups burr grinder. Previously, I used to use a Krups coffee maker with a cone filter and the typical low end spinning blade grinder. I was reasonably satisfied with the current setup, but wanted a stronger punch to the coffee flavor, closer to an espresso. The Mr Coffee coffee machine is the best coffee maker, because it had a water drip that wasn't just a one hole in the center like 99% of the coffee makers, but had multiple drip holes that truelly spread the water over much of the beans. This extracted the maximum flavor from the coffee beans. However, I still felt that a hotter water like steam and more concentrated wetting of all the beans would bring out the maximum flavor. This is where Mr Coffee ECM160 espresso machine came into the picture. Because the water comes down as super heated steam level into a tiny sealed container spread over the entire surface area, the maximum flavor extraction is achieved. This makes a fantastic strong flavor coffee with equal amount of beans as my previous coffee machine, which means I can use even less beans and still make a better tasting coffee. I can put in 2 servings worth of coffee grind with 4 servings of water (espresso), which equates to about 2 cups of coffee, and it still taste better and stronger then when i used twice the amount of beans in a regular coffee machine. If your used to using a coffee filter so u don't get the fine coffee grinds, you will initially be dissapointed with the murky trasparency of the coffee. However, the way to get around this is use a metal mesh Krups cone filter, as a filter to pour the coffee into your mug or cup. This removes any large grinds and you end up with a fantastic coffee with incredibly strong robust flavor. As far as making an espresso, all you need to do is just use less water. It does create that mild foam that most expensive espresso machine make, but not as good. But the flavor is almost identical to a $200 espresso machine I've used in the past at work. I can't speak for the foaming stick, cuz I don't make cappucinos.

Now, why only 4 stars ?
Well, the huge power on off wheel on the left is an overkill, and takes up alot of space. They could have just had 1 on/off switch for brewing and 1 button for the foaming stick. As mentioned by another reviewer, the aluminum molded water container/heating element could be health issue if it ever degrades over time. IMO, it will be fine as long as u follow the direction to NOT open the pressure lid until the machine has fully cooled off. This is to prevent the water drying up inside the aluminum holding tank while it's super hot, causing the minerals to deposit and break down the aluminum from both heat, minerals, and chemicals.

It also does not come with a tamper, and the plastic scooper it comes has an inadequate tiny flat bottom that your supposed to use as tamper. It does not fit properly to tamper down the coffee without making a mess. You do need to use a real tamper or, if you don't want to buy a tamper, you can use anything round that is flat and large enough to press down the coffee grind uniformly. A 49 mm tamper fits perfectly, as it is large enough for full 4 servings of grind and small enough to go lower to press down 2 servings of grind.

It doesn't come with a foaming container, but I didn't expect it to. However, I think it should have come with atleast a cheap plastic tamper that fits.

Now the bonus of using this machine over a regular coffee machine, is that you don't have to buy coffee filters AND you don't have to use those white cholorinated 4 cup coffee filters. That means your not drinking any more chlorine or any chemicals that came from the paper. A health benefit.

Other then that, for the price of $37, it's a great deal. It makes the best coffee u could possibly make and will save you on beans to pay for itself over time.
title: Good Low End Espresso Machine
bought_model: Color: CappuccinoStyle Name: 4-Cup Steam

review_content:
DISCLAIMER:
1. I have never owned another espresso machine.
2. I have been using this machine consistently for about a month.
--
DETAILS:
I purchased this machine because years of experience with products in general has taught me that one should go cheap on the first go and then when one has some level of expertise with the medium (be it coffee or cooking or computers or musical instruments)--THEN go spend the "bigger bucks" for something which you can utilize with some acumen.

The first few times you will probably fail to tamp right and get either a too-bitter slow brew or a too-weak fast brew; but if you're that skilled as a barrista you wouldn't be mucking about with this type of machine anyway!

The build quality seems acceptable for what is a truly entry-level device. The carafe, however, seemed frail even when I first handled it; and the frailty was proven when the other day it fell a few inches and shattered on a granite surface. Luckily I have thick-bottomed glass tumblers which serve as an adequate stand-in; measuring water by eye is easy enough anyway.
--
PROS:
* CHEAP.
* Quick and easy setup (3-5 minutes to create a latte; parts are pretty idiot-proof in handling).
* Easy cleanup (all parts removable, and the wand is easily wiped clean with a coarse brush when the plastic sleeve is removed.

CONS:
* Treat gently as the parts are as fragile as the price suggests!
--
CONCLUSION:
Definitely worth it as a "my first espresso machine" as at this price point you really can't go wrong and it's too simple to screw up too easily.

**********
EDIT
**********
I've upped it a star. Why? I have finally mastered the frothing procedure properly. Turns out you should just keep frothing the milk, keep frothing, keep frothing... THEN it will be "proper".

I've removed all my "novice error" complaints. One star off still for the cheap carafe.

**********
EDIT #2
**********
Keeping it at 4/5 stars even tho this one got consigned to the rubbish bin (lost the attachment for the wand) as I learnt something quite useful for frothing:

1) Buy a proper metal pitcher (12oz will do).
2) CHILL IT.
3) When frothing a chilled pitcher will allow the milk to froth properly!

review_content:
OK I figured I might as well add my 2 pennies worth for this machine since I always ready reviews before I buy. This machine was a huge upgrade over my old (steam driven) mr. coffee espresso machine. The pump seems pretty strong. It does create a nice crema. The steam feature on the machine starts off kind of weak, but after about 30 seconds of frothing it seems to pick up so I'm not sure if it's taking a while to actually heat up enough or what. Like a few people said on here, my machine did not come with the scoop/tamper that it was supposed to come with. I was a little disappointed with that but I already have one of those double sided tampers so no big deal. I think I will contact the vendor to find out if they can send me one though.

Something that I found kind of odd is while frothing you can hear a clanking or thumping coming from the back every second or so. I think this is just a water pump but I didn't read anywhere that it's supposed to do that. I'm guessing it's fine since it still produces steam.

Something that is kind of annoying is when you remove the porta-filter after pulling a shot it is still fairly wet, almost soupy sometimes. I'm used to having a nice dry puck I can knock out, but on this machine I have to scoop it out with a spoon. A little tedious if you're trying to pull multiple shots, no big deal if you're only doing one.

Time will tell how long this machine lasts but so far I've made ~ 10 shots on it, so its well on it's way to paying for itself.
