review_content:
Several days I spent reviewing 'all in one' espresso machines, and there's a lot to filter through (get it? ah my jokes are too corny anyhow). After doing a heavy amount of research I was satisfied with this choice. Took me a few weeks to pull the trigger, but I couldn't be happier that I did. I was addicted to kwik trip lattes, Starbucks lattes, anyplace that has a latte you name it. I'm quite positive this has already paid for itself by not having to go to all those places.

But let's talk more about the thing!
It's kind of big but it has its own dedicated spot in my kitchen. It's nice enough to be left out and not have to store away in a cabinet. What I REALLY like about it is that it's pretty much an all in one system without the thousand dollars plus all in one cost. I push one button and all the magic happens, and it's quite entertaining to watch the espresso cascade through the milk and create separate layers. I also like that I can take the milk and store it in my fridge. I've done some temperature tests and only noticed a 5-degree increase after making a double latte before I put it back in the fridge. This is nice as you would think to be so close to all that heat it would be a much bigger temperature fluctuation. Just make sure you put the blasted spout up otherwise you'll have a fun time cleaning up a giant mess of milk. I really wish there was some sort of sensor that assisted with this issue as I guess I'm stupider than I thought when it comes to lifting that lever.

For anyone who wanted to know, it fits a full-sized pint glass underneath it if you remove the drip tray. It is a tight fit as you will have to angle the pint glass to slide it in but I use pint glasses for my large lattes consistently. The latte puts out almost double the amount of milk that the cappicino does. I think all single servings should be able to fit in your regular sized coffee mug.

Another aspect I really like is the cleaning aspect. Just hold the top button for the coffee grind connector (w/e you call it) to get cleaned and hold the bottom button for the milk frother to get cleaned... that's pretty simple! I did notice that the milk froth cleaner doesn't get all the milk out of the metal tube, but since it slides right off and is pretty easy to clean it's not that big of a deal to me.

So ultimately how does this compare to all the places I regularly go to? It's spot on. Sure it's not the sugar loaded 1500 calorie Starbucks grade latte, but as far as the espresso taste goes it's very close. I actually prefer not adding any sugar or other diabetes contributing nonsense half these latte makers add and find this is a much healthier option for me as well.

If you enjoyed my review please like it. Cheers!
title: I don't know how I managed without it.  Read on for cup sizing details, cleaning, etc :)
bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Espresso/Cappuccino Maker

review_content:
I love this machine! I've been using my Mr. Coffee Cafe Barista for 9 months and it's still going strong. I mainly bought it because I was spending way to much getting coffee drinks like lattes and macchiatos at the coffeehouse. My favorite feature is the fact that it steams and froths the milk at the same time. You can also control the amount of froth that it makes which is an awesome feature. I also have a Mr. Coffee burr grinder Mr. Coffee BVMC-BMH23 Automatic Burr Mill Grinder, Black/Silver so that I am making the freshest coffee possible and I buy my coffee freshly roasted from a local company. The results are great!

Here are some tips from an experienced user:
1. The milk container lid is where it connects to the main part of machine. Be gentle with the little hole in the back because it can break if pushed too hard. A replacement can be found at Mr.Coffee website for a reasonable price, though.

2. Buy a couple of replacements of the clear plastic straw looking part because it will probably get lost and leave you feeling sad that you can't steam your milk! (from experience).

3. Never wash the portafilter in the dishwashing machine. Just don't do it. It will lose the nice shine because it is aluminum. (yes, again I know from experience).

4. Before going out and buying another machine if one of the parts fails... see if they carry a replacement. Pretty much everything that can be removed can also be replaced on their website. I was impressed with the reasonable prices and quick shipping on the Mr. Coffee website.

I had another machine that had great reviews made by Hamilton Beach back in the day, but it was really lacking compared to this machine. I am so happy with my purchase. Long live the Cafe Barista!
title: Perfect Budget Espresso Machine
bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Espresso/Cappuccino Maker

review_content:
I just ordered our second one of these. We purchased the identical model almost 10 years ago and it finally died. We make a full batch of espresso every single morning for homemade lattes with the occasional second round (if we have guests or want an early afternoon bonus latte on the weekends). The device is simple. Because there aren't any fancy options or electronic buttons, there are less possible things that can break on it, which is a plus for me. Since we make two lattes every morning (= 4 shots of espresso total, or one full carafe) I find it more efficient to microwave the milk instead of using the built in steamer/frother. As a former barista, the froth on top was fun, but not worth the effort at home.

In the last ten years, we have had to purchase a replacement carafe once because the original was accidentally set down too hard on the counter and shattered.

Update 7/11/15: Moving from 5 to 2 stars. The first one we order years ago was WONDERFUL. Unfortunately, when it finally died, the replacement leaked all over. When brewing, water would drip from the top and get all over the counter. Clearly it was defective. We contacted Mr. Coffee directly to let them know about the issue. They rushed a replacement to our house (thanks!) and it worked well at first. After 1-2 months of daily use, this "leakage" problem is re-occuring with increasing frequency. While this USED to be a quality-made product that stood the test of time, I'm not going to give them another shot. Sad.

Update 6/5/16: Don't buy this. 10 years ago this was an awesome machine. I'm now on #5 because I refused to believe that the quality had dropped that much and I wanted to leverage all of the spare accessories that I'd accumulated. Go with something else. Not only have all of the new ones leaked to varying degrees, but filter holders now are all made of cheaper parts and the handles snap off easily. I was putting up with it, but now they don't make spares of those! RUN!!!
title: Simple and durable
bought_model: Color: CappuccinoStyle Name: 4-Cup Steam

review_content:
*Update*: Still like this machine but just beware that the screws in the water tank rust. The rust crumbles off and falls onto a ledge inside the water tank, not directly into the water, but it's possible little pieces of rust can tumble into the water.

This machine is a great value for the quality of espresso you get out of it. The portafilter (the thing that holds the coffee) is pressurized (read up on pressurized vs non-pressurized portafilters), which is the key to why this is a safe beginner machine. A pressurized portafilter will not release coffee until enough pressure has built up within the basket, extracting dense flavor, the key to a good espresso. Non-pressurized portafilters rely on the fine grain of espresso ground coffee being tightly compacted into the basket (called tamping) to provide a similar resistance (fyi, espresso snobs demand a non-pressurized basket supposedly because it gives more control over the extraction process). This machine is designed to work better with coarser regular ground coffee (for drip machines), but I HIGHLY recommend you do not do that. Buy a burr grinder and find a grind somewhere between coarser filter coffee and very fine espresso coffee that you like best. Very fine espresso coffee will clog in this machine's portafilter, which is actually good because you won't have to buy a $500 coffee grinder in order to get the right size grind (by the way, very fine coffee works best in non-pressurized portafilters, which the snobs like). Another complaint about pressurized baskets is that the crema can be watery, flavorless, and dissipates quickly because it's basically water bubbles. For some reason, this machine makes great oily crema that is creamy and long-lasting. I love making Americanos with this machine for this reason (it creates a creamy cup of coffee much different than a regular cup of coffee). Milk steamer is adequate, but I suggest beginners watch youtube videos on how to steam milk properly. Buy a small milk pitcher because the spout is short (I use a 12 oz bought on amazon). Love this machine.
title: The key is the  pressurized portafilter design, guarantees a quality espresso shot
bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Automatic Dual Shot

review_content: Great machine for the price.  Steaming arm actually works on this generation.  A few notes: 1. Take off and throw away the rubber/plastic thing on the steaming wand.  2.  prime the steaming wand; a good squirt of water comes out first; you don't want that in your milk!!.  3. prime the brew head as well for a few secs--twice; some cold water will get in your coffee if you don't.  4. after you're done brewing and have removed the portafilter, rinse the brewhead by just priming it for a couple secs--twice.  This will get any coffee grounds off the "showerhead."  5.  ALWAYS brew into clear shot glasses; 25-30 secs MAX.  If you're not getting two oz.  of espresso by 30 secs, your grind is too fine or too packed.  Less than 25 secs???  Grind finer or pack more for good strong shots.  A simple digital kitchen timer is all you need.  Also, if you don't know what a good shot looks like; heart, body, crema, ask a Barista at your Local GOOD Coffeehouse; not Starbucks.  They don't even make their own shots!! THIS CANNOT BE OVER-EMPHASIZED:  Don't run shots for volume; run for time.  Pump Espresso machines are under A LOT of steam pressure stress as they're working, and this one at less that $100 of course is not gonna be beefy and overbuilt inside for strength.  Using good technique as mentioned above, I've gotten months of trouble-free use outta this Baby and not had to pay $4 a day for lattes at the shop.  I also De-scale it after every 2 pounds of coffee with Goo Gone's cleaner.  Enjoy!!
title: Great for the Price--Treat with care tho.  How-to tips below:
bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Automatic Dual Shot

review_content:
I'm a former barista and I love this machine! I've worked at a quite a few local shops and one chain(not Starbucks). I've worked on fully manual and semi-auto commercial espresso machines so I'm familiar with making drinks, proper maintenance, and minor repairs. Five years ago I would have cringed at the thought of having an almost full-auto machine in my home. Now that I've grown up quite a bit and have a normal, M-F 9 to 5 kind of job with a commute and all the fun stuff that comes with it, I'm willing to sacrifice my coffee morals for convenience but definitely not taste. I still grind my own beans because that's really the only way to do it in my opinion. I'n not saying it's the perfect machine but unless your willing to spend a lot more money on a "pro-sumer" machine(a professional grade machine but only has one head for brewing) then this is a great option. I recently got it on Prime Day when there was a lightning deal on it. I'd been looking into buying a new one that was more powerful than my old machine and this was a great fit. Overall, if you're looking for a good machine to save some money on your morning coffee and save some time before your commute, this is a wonderful option.

****Note: Please remember to properly clean and maintain the machine! Run the cleaning cycle after every use. Always, always, always use filtered water, never tap. There are too may minerals in tap and it will mess up your machine very quickly. Be sure to descale your machine at the very least once a month depending on usage. They sell excellent and easy to use descaling products on amazon as well.****

Pros:
-It has a pump that's powerful enough to steam milk quickly and thoroughly and the machine doesn't overheat (I've had this issue before with different brand)
-The water reservoir holds enough for several drinks. I didn't track it closely but I think I made about 8-10 drinks before running low on water
-The milk reservoir holds enough milk to make two 15oz drinks and then some if you want a little extra
-The controls are easy enough to use. One quick read through on the instructions and I was set
-The machine has a cleaning setting for the steaming wand. It's still very important to go through and descale the machine and wash everything properly but that setting is really helpful if you know you'll be using it later in the day as well
-I can fit a 16oz size coffee mug in it
-You can adjust the amount of foam in your drink. So if you want a latte a little dry, you can definitely get that.

Neutral:
-Volume. I wouldn't say it's a loud machine by any stretch, but it's not exactly quiet when steaming milk. But if you've ever used an espresso machine or been around one, you know that's not the quiet part of making a drink anyways
-The filter basket in the porta-filter twist locks into place. Not really an issue but it can get a little annoying when it spins as you're trying to tamp espresso

Cons:
-If your only goal is to get beautiful, coffee shop style latte art, this is not the machine for you. It's practical, not artsy. It makes a darn good latte or cappuccino but it doesn't get frilly. I knew what I was getting so that wasn't an issue for me at all.
-I can't fit a tall, travel tumbler in it
- If you want a "no-foam" latte, you won't be getting that. The machine always produces foam. This is not an issue for me but I realize it may be for some people. It's easy enough to just scoop the foam off the top. In reality, anytime you steam milk your're going to get foam. Whenever you order a "no-foam" latte at a coffee shop, the foam is still there the barista just has to use a spoon to hold the foam back from pouring into your cup.

title: Decent espresso maker for the price
bought_model: Color: CappuccinoStyle Name: 4-Cup Steam

review_content:
First off, I am in no way a coffee snob. I don't even like coffee. I love cappuccinos from Panera Bread though. I might have one once a week or so.
We bought ours from Target for $59 on sale. I read all the reviews and figured it would be the easier return then shipping back to Amazon. My worries were for nothing! We've had this for 2 months now, it gets used almost daily- my cappuccino habit has become much more now that I don't have to go out and buy them. This machine is very easy to operate, just a few touches of a button and a flick of a switch. You will need to purchase a small frothing pitcher and a coffee grinder. I bought both from Amazon for under [...] for both. I grind my beans before making the cappuccino. I have no problems at all with the flow. A "regular" size coffee mug fits under the spouts fine. I always use the 2 serving "basket" for a normal coffee cup, which I fill maybe 1/2 inch from the bottom with the coffee/espresso. I use flavored syrups from Torani which are amazing- [...] is phenomenal for prices and shipping of them. ( I searched everywhere and their prices and shipping speed can't be beat) I have had absolutely no issue with leaking at all. You do need to be sure to empty the drip tray after each use, that solves that problem. I leave the water tank in and fill as needed with a pitcher of water.
The only cons I can think of are that I wish the streaming wand was a tad longer. I have burnt my hand once or twice until I got the hang of it and it can be noisy at first, it doesn't last long.
Also the fact that my coffee habit has shot up tremendously! It's so nice to stay in nice warm jammies and not have to drive to get a cappuccino when I want one.
The taper works fine for me, it's not heavy duty. But it does the job and packs the espresso down fine. Maintenance has simply been to wipe down the steam wand immediately after each use and to wipe off the coffee grounds from where the coffee comes down. The tray on top of the maker is excellent for storing everything. I am thrilled with this cappuccino maker.
I'd buy another in a heartbeat.
title: Saves me a lot of money, works fantastic
bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Automatic Dual Shot

review_content:
I've owned the Mr. Coffee ECM20 Steam Espresso Maker and the Mr. Coffee ECM250 4-Cup Espresso/Cappuccino Maker over the years and they've all worked like a charm with peculiar issues. The ECM20 had weak plastic covering the frothing tip and it broke easily within the first couple weeks. Which when broken, makes it a bit difficult to froth milk without it. The same went with the glass carafe lid. The plastic tabs that held it onto the carafe broke after a month of removing it in order to clean it. The ECM250 improved by shortening the length of the frothing tip and it never broke since I bought it, but still had the issue of the plastic tabs on the carafe lid breaking. Another drawback for the ECM250 was the print of the steam/off/brew functions directly on the control knob so that your fingers would actually buff it off after so long. I've had the 2 ECM250's over the past 5+ years and that was the only problem I had with it. Just that the last one I owned had the plastic Filter basket handle break from the inside. I noticed the screw had also become rusty over the couple years of use. I'm sure it would have lasted longer if the handle was made differently.

As for this ECM160, I like what's continued to be improved on. The flat top next to the reservoir cap is an awesome design function to keep the measuring cup and the carafe organized and clean away from the filter basket so any left over water passing thru the coffee as the machine is cooling won't get in your carafe. The wider, open base for the carafe doesn't feel so constricting. The silver band around the top is a nice aesthetic addition to make the machine look like one you would see at a cafe or Starbucks.

Just that there is where the problems begin. The control knob on the left side of the machine isn't as easy as the previous models were to turn. The ECM250 had that extra bit of plastic material on top to grab onto so you could hold the machine as you turned the knob. It may have been just a design just to distinguish the model, but it gave functionality to the form. The metal band on the ECM160 wraps around the front of this machine gets hot... REALLY hot when you're brewing your coffee. The only way I've had to hold anywhere on the machine is the reservoir cap so that I can turn the control knob from brew to steam so I can froth my milk.

Which brings me to another issue of grip. The ECM160 knob and reservoir lid are a bit of a design weakness for this model. The knob and lid edges are softly rounded which makes gripping it difficult. The way control knob is installed on the machine requires people to either grip it with the palm of their hand or turning your wrist backwards in order to grip it. If they had kept the squared grip like the ECM250 for the reservoir and the round control knob, I wouldn't have any problems with using it. The round control knob didn't require me to turn my wrist at all in trying to grip onto it. It would have been better if I could use just my fingers and not my entire hand to turn, like I used to with the ECM250. At least it wasn't like the ECM20, it's reservoir lid was the shape of an airplane propeller nozzle. It was very hard to grip without using a paper towel to screw on or off.

Despite those flaws, the ECM160 does brew a good cup of cappuccino. Just that if anyone was getting their first machine to make their espresso/cappuccinos, I'd try to get them to find the ECM250 and use that model instead of this one. It's just those functionality issues with the machine that make all the difference in the long run.
title: Brews a good cup, but it has issues.
bought_model: Color: CappuccinoStyle Name: 4-Cup Steam

review_content:
This is our first espresso machine and I too read a lot of reviews to make up my mind. The reviews earlier on this page by L. Hamilton (Chattanooga, TN USA) and by M. Krueger (Austin, TX) were very helpful. Thanks for being so detailed and honest. After reading theirs and a few more from other people I decided to buy this model. I'm happy I did. The espresso machine does indeed work great.

My husband and I both use the machine for different reasons: he loves espresso and I love (a lot of) frothed milk in my coffee.

The espresso: turns out very nice with a creamy top - perfect. We buy our espresso in the supermarket. Some brands are even cheaper than regular ground coffee.

The frothing: I had to get used to the frothing tube. Since this model does not come with a frothing pitcher I had to search for that first and then ended up buying this one:

Krups stainless steel frothing pitcher, 12oz.
ASIN: B000TVDEE4

I bought this frothing pitcher because it is not too tall for the frothing tube, but still wide enough to get a good amount of milk in it. Don't fill the frothing pitcher to the top - just about 1/3 would be enough - the liquid grows as you steam it it. Yes, it took indeed a few times to get used to making the "perfect" froth, I admit. But now I enjoy a great cup of coffee with a one inch topping of creamy frothed milk - yummy!

Note: In the review by K. Krueger he suggested to take the frothing tube CAP off (to avoid build-up of bacteria). Please do not follow his advice. I did, but the difference in noise the tube makes without the cap was amazing. I thought that a plane taking off next to my house couldn't be any noisier. So, please, leave the black frothing tube cap on and simply slide it off after you frothed the milk to clean the entire frothing tube and the cap. Your ears will thank you for it ;)

There were two things I would like to point out:

1- Since we never had an espresso machine we were a little surprised by the noise it makes. Certainly more than a little hissing of a coffee maker. The rhythmic "knocking" while steaming milk at least helps me count to 45 or so it takes to froth it :)

2- My husband uses one of Bodum's double-wall Thermo Glasses - it is very light. When making espresso the machine trembles a bit and the glass underneath the brew basket starts to dance away from the middle. Keep an eye on your cup to find out if it stays in place.

Mr. Hamilton mentions in his CONS that he notices regularly a small leak. On the Quick Start Instructions it reads:"Note: Once the brew (or froth) cycle is completed, steam will be released from beneath the drip tray to remove any remaining water from the heater." It may help if you empty the drip tray right after using the machine?

Overall: great machine - super value - no regrets.
title: Works nice - love the frothing

review_content:
Mr. Coffee Cafe Barista - I am in LOVE with this machine! If you're going to drink coffee, shouldn't you make it the greatest coffee ever?!!!! And this is the best kitchen appliance ever!!! It is so easy to use, even I could assemble it, prime it, and have it pumping out Latte's before hubby got home. And we've been making Espressos, Cappuccinos, and Lattes ever since. I am in heaven.

This is NOT a pod machine (which reminds me of buying those office color printers and then having to buy the proprietary ink constantly which amounts to a "subscription" ha ha!) - you use your owns beans, which means dark or decaf or organic or anything you want (you do have to grind them and tamp them yourself), your own milk (even almond or coconut), and your own flavorings (sugar free, sugar alternatives, quality spices, etc). But you push a button, walk away, and your magic custom Latte (or whatever you want) appears! Clean up is super easy, too.

Goodbye Starbucks, you won't be seeing me around...

Good beans will make an espresso that is delicious to drink straight.
title: So great and so cheap!
bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Automatic Dual Shot

review_content:
Steamer: pretty good! It steams about the same speed as my Breville Infuser. I was able to get good microfoam.

But: the steamer wand does not move any. And it doesn't match some of the photos here.

Coffee making: it doesn't make espresso. But it does make really-strong coffee that's quite good. It's similar, or stronger, than what you can achieve with an Aeropress.

I first tested with an espresso grind, 18 grams (2 scoops), tamped. The machine just couldn't force the water through the grounds. The safety steam vent spewed, but no coffee came out.

I went down to medium grind, 18 grams (2 scoops) tamped. This made strong coffee, about 45 ml extract in 35 seconds' time.

Remember: at least 75% of the coffee drink quality comes from your BEANS and WATER. I tested with excellent CounterCulture.com beans.

Four stars because:
-- Steamer works well
-- Portafilter and steam boiler can achieve strong coffee
-- Steam wand does not articulate
-- What's this giant pot for? It can only make 45-90 ml (2-3 fluid ounces) at a time.

review_content:
I purchased this Espresso Maker after reading the reviews on Amazon.com. I have to say, for me, this was a good investment. I've owned this Espresso Maker for 6 months and I've brewed well over 100 drinks. Here are some things to consider before making your decision:
- The quality of drinks is very good for homemade. Certainly not the world's best but I've noticed that my homemade drinks are better than some restaurants and coffee shops. That's a proud feeling!
- The grind size of the espresso/coffee bean is extremely important. I use Cafe La Llava - quality/price it's perfect.
- It takes 2-3 minutes for the machine to heat up. Once it's heated you can use multiple times.
- The crucible needs to be cleaned and refilled after each use.
- Cleaning the appliance itself, not the crucible and reservoir attachments, is bothersome. Splash-back from the espresso and froth will occur, and it will seep into the cracks of the appliance's plastic exterior.
- You can heat water through this machine for tea. Although it's not very hot.

When I look at time and money this appliance has paid for itself. I can have an espresso, cappuccino, or latte in minutes for pennies. Before I would walk or drive to a shop, wait in line, and spend dollars for similar quality. So yes, I am happy with my investment, but I will eventually upgrade for a few reasons:
- While the quality is good, it's not amazing. I've spent time in Europe and the quality of their coffee is far superior and I believe some of that has to do with the espresso machine.
- I want an automatic and self-cleaning espresso machine
- Call me shallow but the allure of owning a professional appliance
title: Great investment
bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Espresso/Cappuccino Maker

review_content: This machine is awesome. I‚Äôm so glad I purchased it. My Partner & I have been having gourmet coffee everyday since it arrived. So, so good. Coffee shoppes will only be stopped at while on road trips. This gormet coffee machine makes espresso, latte and cappuccinos as good as any reputable coffee shop. Great buy and great product so far. We love it!
title: Best Home Made Gormet Coffee Thus Far...
bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Espresso/Cappuccino Maker

review_content:
The greatest thing about this machine is indeed the price. You can buy a new one every year and still pay less over ten years than you would for some of the expensive machines out there. And there is nothing to say that the expensive ones will even last that long. It does make a good, strong cup of coffee, and that is its major strength. It is also easy to operate and keep clean. The frother is quite effective. Overall, I like the simplicity of the design. There are lots of extra, unnecessary parts to fuss with. This is the third one of this model that I've had.

There are, however, several negatives. First, this is not a real espresso machine. It uses steam, not pressure, and it will not give you any real crema. The selector knob can be a bit difficult to grasp if it's dry and/or you have dry hands. The lid to the carafe becomes increasingly loose as the tabs designed to hold it in place gradually give way. I had to glue rubber surface savers onto it to keep the lid from falling off. The carafe lip is poorly designed and will dribble if you aren't careful.

The plastic "keeper" for the coffee basket won't last. I prefer to put a little duck tape around the inside basket and have it stick in the holder on its own.

Finally, the selector knob on my first machine broke after about eleven months of use, and my replacement machine has just died due to the same problem. So, it's lasted a bit over a year and a half, and that is probably not too bad, but I'm thinking of moving up to something different to see if I can still get a reasonably inexpensive machine that will make good coffee.

Bottom Line: Good coffee at a low price.
title: Great Price But Not A Real Espresso Machine and Not So Durable
bought_model: Color: CappuccinoStyle Name: 4-Cup Steam

review_content:
Im new to espresso and latte coffee so I started with this machine to see if these coffee drinks would be something I would want drink a lot.
On my 4th mug of coffee the black plastic tube that fits over the steaming tube mechanism, broke. Even though I didnt spend a lot of money on this coffee maker Im pretty dissappointed that I only got 4 cups of coffee out of it before something broke, Havent even had it a month.
title: Plastic tube on steamer mechanism broke after only 4 uses..
bought_model: Color: BlackStyle Name: Steam + Starter Set

review_content:
I had this machine for awhile before I bought my Capresso Classic 18 bar pump machine. (which I really love)

For the price, this machine is really quite good. It makes lattes that are even better than my current pump machine, which I paid nearly $200 for. (Probably because I haven't mastered the technique of making the latte with the smaller shots of real espresso from the pump machine).

This espresso machine puts out a good deal of strong coffee. It is not technically espresso, which requires higher pressure than a steam powered machine can muster. So I agree with the reviewer who says that if you're looking only for espresso shots, you don't want to go with this machine. It will not give you that amazing taste that comes only from a proper shot of espresso pulled from a pump machine that is at much higher pressure.

But if you're looking for a machine only for lattes, cappuccinos, and other such drinks, this is definitely worth the money. (Currently $29! What a deal!)

I give it 4 stars not because it is 4 stars when considered beside other espresso machines in the market. My standard, rather, is that it is an amazing purchase for the price and will definitely fill the craving for those who are putting all the money into Starbucks and want to cut back on this costly, overpriced habit.

I recommend also investing in a 6 pack of Torani chocolate syrup, which is what you need to make a delicious mocha latte. You can also get it in other flavors. This machine will also be more than sufficient to make a frappuccino. What I do with frapps is to freeze the espresso, put a little more ice in the blender with the frozen espresso (you may not even need more ice given how much "espresso" is produced with this machine which, as I said, is far more than with a pump machine), some milk, and then some Torani syrup. You will be making frapps and lattes that rival Starbucks with this machine (and a little practice).
title: Good for the Price
bought_model: Color: CappuccinoStyle Name: 4-Cup Steam

review_content:
I'm a beginner when it comes to making espressos, cappuccinos lattes and what not and this thing fit the bill entirely. Depending on how you tamp your grounds and how fresh your beans are the crema comes out really nice. On a bad pull you'll get two black spots with no crema, but more often than not the whole entire top is covered in crema. I read about this false crema thing and I'm pretty sure this thing doesn't have it. I used a Cuisinart machine a few times and the "crema" vanishes after about 10 minutes. For this machine I've accidentally left a cup of foam out over night and it's still there in the morning. I don't know what the literature says but I'm pretty sure the stuff that sticks around is actually crema.

This machine does take a little getting used to. I've read some reviews where people are having trouble with the steam wand. This thing is not a professional espresso maker you can't just turn on the steam and expect steam to come out. You need to tell the machine you want to steam and each and ever time. I learned that the best way to do it is to hit the button wait for it to go solid, pour the milk, put the tip of the wand into the milk, turn on the steam, and start texturing. When I'm done turn off the steam (important), take out the milk, turn the steam on for a second to clear it out. The second time you turn on the steamer you'll only be able to for a few seconds before it starts spitting. It's really just to clean it anyways and a few seconds is plenty.

Pros:

1. It's big enough that you can fit mugs under the group head AND the steam wand
2. Good crema (I think...)!
3. It's pretty quick tbh less than a minute to brew, less than a minute to steam.
3. Good price.

My only complaints

1. You can't buy replacements (that I could find) for the portafilter.
2. The steam wand is pretty wimpy.
3. It's noisy
4. Personally I think it's an ugly looking machine, but function over form right?

My advice to you if you decide to get this machine. Is first take off that stupid rubber thing over the steam wand it's useless and just makes a bunch of bubbles. The second thing look up videos on how to texture milk, this thing can do it with a bit of practice. Third thing is when the light stops flashing and goes to solid for the steam you can't turn it off anymore you need to finish steaming. There's a little steam left when you're done frothing milk to rinse it out but after that it's going to spit hot water at you.
title: This is pretty awesome
bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Automatic Dual Shot

review_content: I waited a few weeks before rating this machine in order to put it through it's paces. As far as I can tell, it is every bit as good as machines costing 4 or 5 times as much. Espresso, cappuccino, and latte all come out perfectly. I also use the Senseo coffee pads in it and they work perfectly without as much mess as plain coffee grounds although cleanup is not that big of a deal. If you're in the market for an espresso machine, this one is a great choice.
title: We Love This Thing!
bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Espresso/Cappuccino Maker

review_content: This is my favorite Coffee Maker! I have this machine for over a year now, and still is working very well. It is not big machine and you can do a lot with it. Good froth, good expresso, an autocleaning system, what else I need? Cons- once you finish with your drink, it will continue dripping a little bit of more coffee (releasing pressure from pump) so you will want to place a cup and drinking it after your first coffee o leave your first coffee a minute or so for  a stronger coffee. It is not much dripping, though.
title: This is my favorite Coffee Maker
bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Espresso/Cappuccino Maker

review_content: Fairly Simple to use, great for the espresso drinker who doesn't have a desire to be an espresso nerd. I'm not after the "greatest"-but rather a replacement for costly (time and money) stops at coffee shops. In half the time it takes to go through a drive through coffee shop I can have a drink similar if not better than what I would have ordered. This was purchased as a christmas present for our house Dec. 2017, and its been 1 month now and I don't believe we have stopped at a coffee shop since when it used to be part of the daily routine. No doubt this machine is one that will pay for itself and then some.
title: Replaces the costly coffee shop
bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Espresso/Cappuccino Maker

review_content: This Barista is super!  It is so easy to use. I offer different flavored coffees and they are all so yummy.  I run a B&B and my guests just love creating their own morning brews!
title: Espresso, Cappuccino, Latte -- They all turn out Great!
bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Espresso/Cappuccino Maker

review_content: Has been used approximately 10 cycles a day at work for the last 3.5 months without any issue. I de-scale monthly for preventative maintenance. The pressure output is consistent and powerful. Does not work on packed Turkish grind (? microns), but that is to be expected. Takes about 30-60 seconds to initially heat up.
title: Has been used approximately 10 cycles a day at work ...
bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Espresso/Cappuccino Maker

review_content:
Simple and easy to use, pulls crema out of even cheap ground coffee. The rubber cover on the frothing wand seems to make frothing impossible, but it simply slides off (they probably did not want to get sued if someone got burned).

Update: after 10 months the machine leaks from portafilter attachment so you cannot brew anything. The filter screws into plastic which will wear out. Mr. Coffee will not warranty this defect or even coherently respond to your emails despite claiming a one year warranty.
title: Simple and easy to use, but simply garbage
bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Automatic Dual Shot

review_content: This is the regular guy espresso maker.  A true espresso maker unlike the Ninja, etc.  Further, I can't understand the whole pod deal.  Coffee isn't exactly cheap when you calculate the yearly cost so why multiply it by having some company make a plastic cup, put coffee grounds in it, put a nice label on it and then charge you accordingly.  I would love to do a taste test with a more expensive espresso maker to see if I could taste subtle differences so I can't speak to that.  I will say that the convenience and easy-clean/maintenance make me not regret the more expensive espresso machines I was going to purchase when first shopping.  I fill up the reservoir 4/5 skim milk and 1/5 sugar free liquid coffee mate and a splash of vanilla.  I've had it 3 months now and it has been used every daily.  I put it on the clean cycle 2x weekly which takes about 30 sec and weekly I rinse and hand wash the reservoir.
title: Spectacular!
bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Espresso/Cappuccino Maker

review_content:
I used the Mr Coffee ECMP50 daily for 15 months and loved it. In those 15 months, I really only had a few (minor) complaints:
1) The thing vibrates and moves my cup when I'm brewing coffee -- if I'm not paying attention it can result in a spill. My solution was to coat the metal on which the cups sit with rubber (automotive rocker-guard spray).
2) You have to be careful filling the reservoir, whether you take it off or just pour water in it, so as not to end up with water all over the counter.
3) You have to remember to clean the rubber piece of the frothing wand after each use (or it gets caked in milk residue... this isn't the machine's fault, it's mine).

I read a lot of reviews before picking this machine, and have to say I didn't have any of the daily problems other users have experienced. Every time I've had a problem, it's because I've done something wrong, or wasn't paying attention. That said, it gave out on me after 15 months; it appears the heater isn't working, or maybe it's the pump. Luckily, my credit card extends the 1 year warranty by another year -- I was pleased with it up to the end, so I'm going to replace it with another ECMP50 and buy it with the same credit card.
title: I loved this thing until it died after 15 months :(
bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Automatic Dual Shot

review_content: Amazing espresso maker. If you purchase torani white chocolate syrup and sauce you can make a cappuccino that tastes just like starbucks white chocolate mocha. I have to stop myself from drinking too much cappuccino. It's so good and I'm saving money by not going to starbuck's anymore!
title: Superb white chocolate mocha
bought_model: Color: RedStyle Name: Espresso/Cappuccino Maker

review_content:
put it in my office and my employees love it. It has already paid its price back as we used it to replace nespresso. The pods for nespresso are costly while this machine uses regular expresso coffee.
quality is good and the variety and assortment of coffee that produces is nice. Capuchino, latte, expresso.
title: it paid back its price the second week from the nespresso savings
bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Espresso/Cappuccino Maker

review_content:
I received this machine a week ago and LOVE it so far. I am not having troubles with my tank leaking like some have. It makes a good latte, which is the primary reason I bought the machine. It is super easy and I liked this model over most in the price range because you do not have to froth the milk separately. It makes it super convenient. From the time that I turn the machine on, I can get the espresso ready and put my milj pitcher on and it's ready. You have to make sure the machine is ready to bre or your espresso will come out weak!!
I will update down the road if I have any complications, but I've used it several times a day for a week now and wanted to let others hear about the machine from my perspective :).
title: Great lattes!!
bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Espresso/Cappuccino Maker

review_content:
I just got this machine today and was enjoying my first latte within an hour! I have never made one before, but read up on it (including some of these reviews) and had no problem pulling off my very first try! Not to mention, with the money we saved by not buying a pricier model (we were also considering the Cuisinart) we decided to buy a burr mill. I know things will only get better from here! I do recommend two things: as other reviewers have said, read the directions! That way when all the lights start blinking or its not working the way it should, you'll know why! (like I did the first time I used it!) and take some time to read other reviews. They will give you good tips on how to make a good espresso, especially if you've never done it before! I also recommend buying from Amazon. I have read other reviews where they purchased the item from a local store so they would have the option of returning it, but Amazon is very good about returns. Besides, the prices are always lower, add on the super saver shipping, and in my case, there was no tax. So it saved me about [...] and I had my machine in less than 7 days!Before you know it, you'll be enjoying your Sunday morning latte, or mocha, or whatever you want at home and not at some overcrowded, overpriced cafe.

Update- It's been a week and I'm in Latte heaven. Realizing how easy it is just peeves me more when I think of how much money I could have been saving all this time! Just one note. As an previous reviewer said, the steam quality does decrease over time, but if you gently pull off the steam wand tip, and clean all the gunk, it will be as good as new. In fact I think I will just do that on a daily basis to avoid having wrestle with it after a week. That ealier reviewer mentioned leaving the tip off all together, but I'm not ready to do that. We'll see how it goes this way. I don't forsee any problems.

By the way, a great big THANK YOU to all you reviewers out there! You made all the difference with the way I shop online! Especially with this! I never make a purchase if the item does not have good reviews!

Update- DO NOT TRY TO STEAM WITH WITHOUT RUBBER TIP! It doesn't work! Just make sure to take off and clean often. Also, ivest in a good tamper. I just got the RSVP (for only [...]) and it makes tamping much easier! Just be sure to pay attention to size. This Mr. Coffee takes a 2" tamper! (or 49mm)This RSVP is perfect!

Update- OK, so it's been about 6 months and this machine has paid for itself many times over! I live in a warm climate, so this summer, I have replaced my usual morning latte with a nice cold iced latte, EVERY MORNING! Oh, I also figured that it costs me about $1 to make a latte hot or cold( and that's using organic agave and organic soy milk). And my teenage daughter loves the iced latte too! I can't even begin to guess how much money we have saved by skipping the expensive lattes and making our own! Even when we go out shopping we take our lattes from home to go, where we used to stop at the well known place and drop a $10 or a $20. Think of all the money we've saved!

Update- It's the end of November now, so I had this for over 10 monthe and it still works great! No problems at all! And I still use it at least once a day, but mostly twice a day and sometimes four or five! I would just say that how well it works will depend on how well you take care of it. I "blow" the steam wand at least every couple of days and decalcify at least once a month. In between I do run plain water through the brewer and brush off the screen where the water enter the filter. I think this extra effort is well worth it!
title: A coffee lover's must!
bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Automatic Dual Shot

review_content: Have purchased two of these in the past two years, liked it so much I bought one for work.  They coffee maker is the most resonable priced unit out there and have had absolutly no issues with either machine.  If you like expresso and you're on a budget you can't go wrong buying one of these.  Once I took this on a vacation with us and ended up breaking the pot, was able to find a replacement on Amazon so parts are even available.

review_content: I got this cappucino maker as a wedding gift from my wedding registry. I have always been a fan of Mr. Coffee, so I assumed all of their products were trustworthy. My new gift worked perfectly... Until the 4th month. Then the steam-frother stopped working. To this day, the espresso part works just fine. The frother part stays cold. How sad; I don't like espresso.
title: Well, at least the espresso part still works...
bought_model: Color: CappuccinoStyle Name: 4-Cup Steam

review_content:
Maybe this is not a SECRET to you, but for the first week it was a SECRET to me. My problem is my milk was not steaming or frothing (sniff). Why me, Lord, I wondered? It turned out the SECRET was in the Instructions: Put water up to Top of Metal band, i.e. put in more water than you want to come out for your 4 ounces of expresso, then TURN OFF the machine when the four ounces comes out (!). This leaves a little extra water behind, and this is the water for steaming the milk. (Duh).

For any and all in Great Gratitude for this Revelation, simply Submit a modest donation to the charity of your choice...or else treat a friend to a real cappuccino.
title: The SECRET of Frothing & Steaming
bought_model: Color: CappuccinoStyle Name: 4-Cup Steam

review_content: I don't know how long this machine will last, but for the past two weeks since I bought it, I've had the best tasting espresso shots. I use Aroma espresso ground coffee (2-3 dollars at your grocery store) and it tastes better than anything I've ever tried at  Starbucks. I read the negative reviews stating that the machine dies after only a few months. If that happens, I'll have to change my product rating, but at this point I have no reasons to complain.

review_content: We loved this machine at first. I read some reviews that it leaked a little but thought it was worth the gamble. One year later it started leaking and within a few weeks the thing leaks like CRAZY every single time it's used. Unfortunately, we have to buy a new one because it's such a mess all the time!
title: LEAKS
bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Automatic Dual Shot

review_content:
I had a "Mr. Coffee BVMC-EL1 Cafe Latte" maker the fall of 2011 and had a lot of fun making the different drinks. But it wasn't near as nice as this one is. For making the milk frothy it used a funky whisk like thing run by a little motor in the lid for the little coffee pot. It worked great, for a while. But the little motor that made the milk foamy wasn't big enough or powerful enough to last very long. Using it 2 or 3 times a day it quit working after only 3 months. With the way this one, the "Mr. Coffee BVMC-ECMP1000 Caf√© Barista Espresso Maker" does the milk it should last for a long time.
I also like the way I don't have to worry about how much water to put in the tank or how much milk to put in its little tank either. The machine automatically uses the same amount every time. And if I want a little more water to my Latte or Cappuccino I only need to press the Espresso button and it will give it another shot of hot water.
On the little tank for the milk there's a little knob that you use to select Latte on one side or Cappuccino on the other. With it set to Latte the milk comes out nice and hot and lightly foamed. On Cappuccino the milk is frothier or more aerated than on Latte. You can adjust just how foamy or frothy you want your milk, from lightly foamy (Latte setting) to very foamy with lots of bubbles (Cappuccino setting) just by where you set the knob. It's just like turning the volume knob on a radio.

For the amounts that it brews, a Cappuccino single serving is a little over ¬Ω cup (150ML). A double serving is a little under a full cup (225ML).
A single serving Latte is about 1 full cup, 8 oz. (225ML) A double Latte is 1 ¬Ω cups (350ML).
An Espresso single serving is between ¬º and a 1/3 of a cup (75ML). A double serving is a little under ¬Ω cup (125ML).
So when brewing any one of the selections a double serving is actually 1 ¬Ω servings instead of 2 full servings.

There is one thing that might become a problem with it. And that is the little filter cups. As a retired machinist and seeing how these were made I can see a problem with them getting clogged up with fine debris &/or mineral build up from the water. They have a double bottom in them with several tiny holes smaller than a needle in the inside piece. There is a small gap between the part with the holes on the inside and the outer piece that has a single hole in the middle that's a little bigger than the ones on the inside. The only way for water to pass through it is by being under pressure. And as small as the holes are it won't take much to clog them. And when enough minerals from the water build up in the tiny holes and between the bottom pieces they will have to be replaced. I think it will be just like the holes in a shower head getting clogged up with minerals. Except the holes in a shower head are several times larger than the size of the tiny holes in these filter cups. I'm only using water that has been run through one of the Brita water pictures with the replaceable filter to help prevent the buildup. If only bottled water is used in it that might help prevent buildup in them too.
I think it's a bit over priced. $200 for a machine to make coffee a cup at a time is a pretty high price for something made mostly of plastic. And of course, it is made in China. So it probably cost about $2 to manufacture it. So personally I'm not very comfortable with recommending buying this one at this price.
title: A nice Coffee brewing machine, but over priced.

review_content:
I went on Amazon to purchase my 3rd Keurig frothing pitcher (they are such junk that they self-destruct starting a month after purchasing & are unusable 6 to 9 months out), when I noticed Mr. Coffee had an espresso machine with a milk frothing device. I thought, Mr. Coffee, that's a company (unlike Keurig) which one can trust to make a well engineered product. (I now have 3 Mr. Coffee burr coffee grinders, so I reason to believe this was so.) So I bought it, & can say, it took a little time to get into a routine of using it without spilling coffee grinds all over the place.

I have purchased several espresso makers over the years, a good European electric one w/o a frother, a good Senseo w/o frother that requires pods, a that makes good but weak espresso, an expensive European stainless steel stove top one w/o frother that makes strong espresso, the Keurig that requries expensive pods, makes bad espresso, takes too much time to use, is in every way poorly engineered, and has a milk frother that costs about $35 to replace every 6 to 9 months merely because it is made of cheap plastic.

With all that in mind & with the Mr. Coffee machine routine mastered, I can say, & my partner says every day, the Mr. Coffee machine makes the best tasting espresso/cappuccino ever experienced, better than Starbucks by far, better than all my other espresso machines, better milk frothing too, better engineered by far at such a reasonable price and without expensive pods (where who knows where the coffee is from).

If Mr. Coffee comes up with a new & improved espresso machine w/milk frother, I will purchase that one too, not the least of which is because I appreciate a supporting an excellent company that makes the investment in Research & Development to come up with a great product that does what the customer is led to believe it should do.
title: a good European electric one w/o a frother
bought_model: Color: RedStyle Name: Espresso/Cappuccino Maker

review_content:
This machine is pretty compact so it does not take up too much counter space which is great. I have to admit I didn't have high expectations for an espresso machine at this price point, but my boyfriend and I are totally amazed by the espresso this machine produces. There is a slight learning curve but you figure it out really quick. I use Cafe Bustelo ground espresso and have been using the plastic tamper that comes with this machine. The majority of my shots have tasted pretty good but I always mix my shots with milk. It does produce a crema but the shots are not super syrupy or thick. There were only two times that the espresso turned out bitter but I was playing with different amounts of ground in the filter and tamping the espresso using different pressures.

I noticed a lot of reviews complain about the frothing arm for milk. My frothing arm did not look the same as the one in the picture (it was actually located towards the rear of the machine - not the best location) but I figured out the best way to get hot, steaming, foaming milk. When I use this machine I have to move it toward me because of the location of the frothing arm. I removed the plastic sleeve from the wand because the plastic sleeve was causing milk to splatter everywhere which seems to be a common complaint in reviews. By removing the plastic sleeve I no longer have the milk splattering issue and I also have more control over the amount of foam I want. I can heat the milk with minimal foam, or heat the milk longer to get more sweetness and more volume.

Another word of advice is to make sure you use enough water in order to get enough steam for your milk. The espresso craft holds 8 oz and numbered for 2 ounce shots. If you want four shots you need to fill water up to the top of the metal band on the craft. If you want two shots (4 oz), you need to fill the water up to the imaginary 3 shot line or higher to get enough steam to heat and froth the milk. General rule of thumb is to add 1.5 to 2 additional ounces of water for frothing the milk. Keep in mind you have to manually change the brew feature to the steam feature once the brewed espresso hits the desired number of espresso shots in the craft. Have your cup of milk ready and submerged in the frothing arm when you change the brew feature over to the steam feature. By adding the additional 1.5 - 2 ounces of water you will have more than enough steam to heat and froth your milk. I usually have enough steam to clean the frothing arm with a clean cup of water after my milk has been heated. I also noticed that milk also tends to cake the wand so have a kitchen towel or bar mop towel handy to wipe it down after each use.

If you are unsure or on the fence about purchasing this machine, you should buy it! I have been using this machine every morning and multiple times on weekends to make shots of espresso, one morning I drank 8 shots.....not sure if that is healthy. But that should tell you the quality of espresso this machine produces, no one drinks 8 shots in a day if the espresso tastes bad right??? Yes, you may need to tweak your espresso brewing skills a bit to get the taste you want, but making espresso is considered an art form you perfect to get the taste you want. You cannot expect to press start, walk away, and have the perfect cup. You have to create it the you way you want it and you can with this machine.
title: Good for the Price, Makes Yummy Lattes
bought_model: Color: CappuccinoStyle Name: 4-Cup Steam

review_content:
I REALLY LOVED this coffee maker, until suddenly it quit. Was having a bad day, finally shoved the worries aside, saying I‚Äôll just have a cup of coffe and then I‚Äôll think about it.
Well the machine dribbled out a teaspoon of espresso and stopped. I washed everything carefully, tried again. Made a lot of noise, got very hot, nothing. Tried resetting it: turned it off, unplugged it let it sit. Again, lots of storm and fury, no coffee.
Nothing left to do but cry

bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Espresso/Cappuccino Maker

review_content:
Negative stars if possible. Mr. Coffee has changed their product to now come with a "premium" ESE pod holder and no filterz. I contacted customer service and they offer to do you the favor of allowing you to buy (for an additional $20 after shipping) the 1 and 2 shot filters. Don't worry though, you will also need a different Porta-head to hold those filters and that will only run you an additional $20 after shipping.

Aren't they ever so nice? Now you are out a ridiculous amount for the machine and if you ever wish to use your own coffee with it you can either spend the amount an entire expresso machine costs for the parts or buy a pod maker and individual filters to diy your pods adding 20 minutes and a nice mess to your morning routine.
title: Machine part change - only ESE Pods now
bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Espresso/Cappuccino Maker

review_content:
I bought this coffee machine after a tip from a friend, a tour of how it works, and a lot of additional research, so I knew I was going to like it. It's easy to use, WAY cheaper to run than my Nespresso machine since I can buy regular coffee instead of pods, and it's easier to clean too, between the clean cycle on the milk reservoir and the milk reservoir being dishwasher safe. I do have to say I prefer to do custom amounts of milk, since if I use the latte button, the first one always overflows the cup with foam no matter what I do, perhaps from water in the system after the clean cycle the day before? But this is a small issue and not a problem at all.

I love this machine so much, and have used it nearly every day since buying it months ago, so I was devastated this past weekend when I accidentally broke the retainer clip on my porta-filter (the thing with the handle -- the clip holds the filter in when you dump out the used coffee grounds). I checked the product documentation and figured out it was still under a one-year warranty, so I contacted Mr. Coffee and told them what had happened. They IMMEDIATELY sent out a replacement. No questions asked! And I received it today, a Friday, only five days after I emailed them Sunday night. WOW!

With that kind of warranty and customer support, there's really no reason not to buy this amazing machine!
title: Great coffee machine and GREAT warranty support from Mr. Coffee!
bought_model: Color: RedStyle Name: Espresso/Cappuccino Maker

review_content: I loved this product when I first got it.  I had read the reviews in which people reported problems but there were also many positive reviews so I thought that perhaps the negative reviews were a result of failure to consistently follow the cleaning instructions. I made sure to follow the cleaning procedure exactly.  When after only 1 month and 1 week of use, my machine suddenly lost suction and would not deliver milk from the frothing tube I was forced to conclude that Mr. Coffee engineers need to go back to the drawing board and come up with a product that is more reliable.  I would not recommend that anyone purchase this product if they want to count on using it for more than about a month.
title: This was a big disappointment!
bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Espresso/Cappuccino Maker

review_content:
The machine's sensors are sensitive. It takes practice getting this machine right. My tips:
1. Don't forget to run the vinegar deep clean as mentioned by a previous user. (the manual doesn't say to do this in the initial setup but drinking a cup full of bitter chemicals doesn't taste good)
2. The espresso light keeps blinking, make sure it is locked all the way
3. If all 3 lights keep blinking, the milk container is not in correctly. You must line up the whole "just so" for the sensors to read the container is in place correctly. It usually takes me 3-8 tries to figure out the "just so" position
title: The machine's sensors are sensitive. It takes practice getting ...

I skipped that and it was not coming out right, did it and now it's perfect. Make sure you tamper it well (30 pounds of pressure). I've played with all settings and it works perfectly! Great, rich espressos (and I'm from Miami where we drink Cuban coffee), great cappuccinos and lattes, great foam, and great temperature (hot). I'll update in time, but so far so good!

After researching a lot of machines the old mr coffee had a lot of mix reviews, but in a lot of reviews for other machines people were recommending them.  I saw this was newer model no reviews but it was at $105 so I love amazon and if it bad I can send it back.  Next day it goes on sale $83.  Wtf.  Lucky I was able to cancel and rebuy this on sale. Your first time you have run a test run just water, it took machine 5 min to warm up.  Now it‚Äôs pretty quick, turn it on and ready go in few seconds.  You have to manually turn knob to stop machine from shooting the shot which I don‚Äôt mind. Machine is not too loud which I heard was a problem on others.  The frother works pretty good the cappuccino tasted good, the espresso I‚Äôm sure can‚Äôt compete with professional machines but it‚Äôs decent and gets job done.  Wife likes machine and so do I for the price.  If It last 2 years I‚Äôll get my money worth. It has a small footprint I like.  Ya it‚Äôs not super high quality but good enough.  Only thing I don‚Äôt like it water container top is not sealed, it just falls on water container.  Comes with everything you need which makes the price even better, the milk tins run $8-$15.  The little cup is cool, good size.  Comes with 2 filters for single or double shots.

bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Espresso/Cappuccino Maker

review_content:
I would not call myself a true purist of coffee, that being said I am frugal with my money and I do love my espresso so when I say this coffee maker can put out a shot of espresso or more extravagant drink as good if not better than any coffee store that I have been to, I know what it means. It is fairly cheap and it is very easy to use. I have only owned the thing for a week so I cannot speak to durability. I bought this along with a grinder(bur mill cuisinart for $40) and a bag of quality beans all also available here. It produces a wonderful shot and also creates that cappuccino which I crave in the morning. All said this cost just over $100 and within a month and a half it will have paid for itself. The only thing that I would warn about is that this is not turn on and walk away unit. You have to manually turn off the brewing process and you have to clean it yourself instead of Barista at Starbucks which means that all said it will take about 15 minutes in the morning to brew and clean up the machines. That being said the coffee really takes less than 2 minutes to brew the first shot so you can pause it for satisfying the craving and then finish the brew. I do not find this a tremendous imposition and I have fallen in love with the machine.

Things to be aware of:
- the scoop that comes with can be used as a tamper but it is easier to have a proper tamper to tamp the grinds. It requires about 49mm tamper to cover the filter completely maybe a mm or two more would fit as well.
- does not come with a frothing pitcher which is needed for creating a cappucino, latte, etc.
-I would recommend reading up on espresso making so that you understand the possible mistakes that can be made(how to store beans, reasons for bur mill over blade grinder and such)
-Be careful to unplug the machine and then switch to steam in order to release the pressure so that you do not burn yourself when removing parts for cleaning.
title: For the price, cannot go wrong

review_content: You can make a latte in about 1-2 minutes, maybe another minute if you have to turn it on and wait for it to warm up, and you have to wait a minute to take the coffee out of the basket or it will spray all over. If you buy premium coffee beverages consistently for $5-6 a cup, it pays for itself; less the cost of the coffee and whatever milk you use you'll probably save ~$4 per cup. Not to mention the fact that it's still cheaper and way more environmentally-friendly that K-Cups. If you get that burnt taste from espresso it's probably your choice of coffee (the best thing to do is to get the bulk coffee at the store (whatever kind of coffee you want) and then just grind it "espresso fine" ) or you're letting the coffee sit too long (pretty much 10+ seconds) before either drinking it (it's hot af) or adding whatever is you want to add to it to seize the rapid oxidation process. Relatively easy to clean, I put the drip tray parts, the carafe(you can use a mug if you have one that will fit), and steam cup (that did not come with the appliance itself) in the dishwasher. You can't put the filter baskets in the dishwasher, and if you put the brew basket handle in the dishwasher it will stain, although that wouldn't really hurt the functionality at all. Great appliance, not for rapid production at all but it will give you a nice cup of coffee in the morning without much hassle.
title: Save a ton of $$; WAY BETTER for the planet than K-Cup Machines

review_content: If your even thinking about getting an automatic espresso machine just buy it you won't be disappointed.  Keep in mind only a handful ever write a review anyway.  Just FOLLOW THE INSTRUCTIONS on initial priming,  That and I'll go over a few things I know about the machine.  There are a lot  of complaints about the milk frothier. It is on the heavy side when it dispenses milk if you want a latte keep the dial closer to the cappuccino setting.  Or as I do it dispense the milk manually that way you can put the exact amount you want.  the other thing was the milk reservoir was a pain to clean every time  you used it.  I just run the automated clean on the dispenser portion of the tank and I keep my tank refrigerated.  That way I only clean it when I refill it.  If it went tits up today I would buy another one without a second thought.  If you follow the break in instructions it makes very hot delicious drinks.  Enjoy.
title: ... automatic espresso machine just buy it you won't be disappointed. Keep in mind only a handful ever write ...
bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Espresso/Cappuccino Maker

review_content:
CCB Coffee Cafe Barista is a compact machine. It tucks in neatly into a corner and can be operated easily without needing to move the CCB. The double shot once charged makes tasty lattes even with coarse grounds.

Personally I have RO reverse osmosis water which is at 7 ppm for TDS (means it's soft water). The machine takes a few minutes to pressurize and heat the water. Currently this unit is peculiar in that it overflows on the first cup after having being switched off for a while. Since this is in the morning it is a hassle. The only way to mitigate the problem is to dial the foam setting down to latte and use less milk and then refill later.

The espresso shots are tasty even with the coarser ground. The cappuccino and lattes can be messy but are also delicious.

Compared to the De'Longhi EC155 you get a bigger machine with more weight that does not shiver during operation and can accommodate mugs. The output IMHO justifies the price point with the quality of the shots and latte. I am not sure about longevity since the pump clearly has a problem already in 2 weeks of use with the overflow problem.
title: Good not great and may not last
bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Espresso/Cappuccino Maker

review_content: I purchased this machine to replace my keurig rivo that stopped working and replacement parts were pretty expensive, so I figured i'd just get something new. I am very happy with this machine so far. I love that I can pre fill the milk container and leave in the fridge in between uses. It's awesome how it automatically steams and froths the milk and puts it into your mug. It doesn't use pods, you use your own ground coffee or espresso beans. I like that I can try different types now. With the rivo they only have 1 type of espresso. The machine is super easy to use, you just turn it on and touch the button of what you want. Press it twice for the larger size. The only negative for me is that you cannot put a large travel mug under it. It will not fit. So if you want to fill up a tall mug you have to pour it in from another cup. That is why I gave it 4 stars instead of 5. The coffee it brews comes out very very hot. I got a bundle that included this machine plus mr coffee automatic burr mill grinder for the same price as just buying the machine, so I was thrilled about that. The grinder has 18 different grinds so it was a great deal. If you like lattes and cappuccinos I think this is a great machine for you.
title: Great Machine, easy to use, great lattes
bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Espresso/Cappuccino Maker

review_content:
I have owned this machine for slightly less than 3 month now, I find it to make very good cappuccino and lattee, but espresso on its own is not so good.

Pros:
1 - Very easy to use and clean. Ok drinks with the click of a button.
3- Large volume reservoirs both for milk and water; milk reservoir easy to store in the fridge.
Cons:
1 - Brew (& froth) size highly depend on water (& milk) level in the reservoir! This sounds very strange, but you get very different sizes depending on how your reservoirs are filled.
2 - Pressurized (double wall) filter basket: this really ruins the machine, it makes the brew less sensitive for the tamping/ground finess = you always end up with the same "not so good" espresso, no matter how hard you tried adjusting the different parameters.
3 - Cheap plasticy porta filter nozzles: yes, the porta filter dispensing nozzles are made of very cheap plastic, fixed with a little screw to the body. (I wasn't aware that with pressurized filter basket tamping doesn't matter that much and I ended up breaking the nozzles while tamping, but it still operational). I believe this entire plastic fitting (with a weird pocket to store the initial few drips of the shop) do more harm than good to your espresso.
4 - Froth setting from Latte to Cappuccino is not very difference, you always get lots of froth regardless of the setting.
5 - Although the porta-filter has two nozzles, you cannot by any mean fit two cups under it = must always brew twice for 2 persons
6 - Temperature control seems to be a joke on the machine. Leave it to heat up before using it and it will "burn" your espresso as the water becomes very hot.
Longevity: Can't comment on that yet.
If you are serious about espresso, I highly recommend getting a different, higher end machine, this will not work for you.
title: Cappuccino/Latte are OK, not so good espresso.
bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Espresso/Cappuccino Maker

review_content: This little machine really exceeded my expectations.  I read many, many reviews for a plethora of machines.  I was initially going to buy one that was a couple hundred bucks more, but saw this one, and saw how many stars it has, so I gave it a try ( why not? Amazon has a great return policy).  This machine makes a good drink.  I prefer lattes and mochas and this machine makes them taste like my local coffee shops.  I'm really pleasantly surprised.  I got all of the equipment I need (tamper, frothing pitcher,  machine, and thermometer) all for under a hundred bucks.  Just make sure and read the directions before use and always use filtered water.  Quality ingredients are key as well.  I've only had this thing a couple of weeks now, so as far as how long it will last- not sure yet.  In a couple more weeks this thing will have paid itself off for the money I save not going to coffee stands.  I definitely encourage giving this machine a try.
title: Pleasantly suprised
bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Automatic Dual Shot

review_content: Thought this would be great, but the pastic smell would not go away. Also it looks like the top part inside where the water is poured is cast aluminum which is not a healthy metal to use for something you are injesting. I was going to contact the manufacturer about it and ask but the strong smell of plastic made me stop using the product anyway. Amazon was great about refunding. Also a lot of steam comes throught the front plate at the very end. If you dont mind "that new car smell"  in your coffee and pulling the machine to the end of your counter so it doesn't steam the cabinets above then this would work for you.
title: Bummed.
bought_model: Color: CappuccinoStyle Name: 4-Cup Steam

review_content:
The good: easy to use. Had fun making cup after cup finding what works for my coffee beans and grinder, etc. Easy to clean up. Inexpensive yet powerful. I also use an aeropress and a French press depending on my mood. This unit is faster than my electric kettle and I seem to use less coffee per day.

The not-so-good: the frothing wand. Could never get good results from it. Yes I removed the rubber sleeve. Yes I had a cold pitcher and cold milk and all that. After several failed attempts however I noticed...

The ugly: the drip pan fills up when you use the frothing wand. If you look at the drip pan, there's a little channel on the back left. It appears that after you're done using either the coffee making part or the frothing wand, something internal releases some water into the drip pan via that channel. I figure it's pressure release or something. Which is fine. But two or three attempts with the frothing wand filled it up. Not good. I won't be using the wand anymore. The shaking method works fine for me when I want foam.

All in all a decent unit to put in my rotation.
title: The good: easy to use
bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Automatic Dual Shot

review_content:
Pros:
- all in one compact unit
- removable convenient milk container
- easy to use, fill, clean
- one touch operation

What I'd wish they changed:
- milk container unreasonably hard to pop in, and then sometimes pops out on it's own preventing operation
- buttons don't do anything until heated up, why not accept the mode and then brew when ready
- no way to use any kind of travel mug, no space for anything but a small mug
- no tamping suggestions, should this be tamped with a lot of pressure, seems not?
- unit still goes and goes when water is empty, should stop and wait for water imo
- customization options not clear, when and how to start and stop those modes

suggestions:
- medium grind in a Cuisinart burr grinder seemed to make a nice grind, important for the final product
- i think overtamping makes a worse cup, lots of dry grinds leftover, tamp just a tad with the plastic tamper
- milk is customizable if you want less or more...more froth=less milk, then leave the dial there
- use non-dairy milk and less need to clean, imo
- one cappuccino + one espresso = the perfect cup, imo of course
title: Really great cup of coffee.
bought_model: Color: RedStyle Name: Espresso/Cappuccino Maker

review_content: Great espresso, cappuccino, & latte maker! I've only had the machine for a week or so, but I would recommend this machine!  Semi-auto, but it doesn't include a coffee bean grinder. But that's okay. It includes a storage container for milk that can be stored in the fridge til ready to use. The container quickly snaps into place. Simply pick a single or double shot filter, select your grounds, aim the frothing spout on the milk reservoir, select the level of frothing, and push the button for the type of coffee that you want - espresso, cuppaccino, or latte.  The only complaint I have is the milk / frother is a little inconsistent in the volume it produces, but not a big problem.
title: Makes great espresso, lattes, and cappuccino

Yes maggots up in the milk well....not the milk container, in the machine above the milk container!!  I did t even calm anyone, I was so disgusted and grossed out I threw it in the garbage ...no way to clean that part ....design flaw !! ugh. I loved this till then....just the thought??? Eeeewww... No way...no no no way!!!
