review_content: This espresso machine is well worth the money  I have had it for almost 3 months now and use it everyday.  It is very easy to use and clean.  I give it 4 stars because even with cleaning after each use the milk container starts to smell after a few days.  It's not the milk but something from the container.  After a few days I fill the container with water and run water thru it like I am steaming milk.  The smell goes away after that.
title: Great Espresso Machine
bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Espresso/Cappuccino Maker

review_content:
I will give this product the benefit of the doubt early on. It is extremely easy to use, reasonably small, has a decent sized reservoir, so I am not constantly trying to pour water into it like many espresso machines, and it is attractive.

It is also extremely easy to clean!! Most is dishwasher safe except the xxx.

It makes a good espresso (not great espresso), which is what I bought it to do. I do not drink other coffee drinks often. I wanted one that used the pump and pressure to make the espresso, and this does a fairly good job. It is NOT a $600 espresso machine. LOL. But it makes a decent shot and the shot has that jolt you only get from espresso drinks.

One thing I learned right off the bat is that the coffee is very bitter if you use too fine a grind. Apparently, it is explained online that is true for many espresso makers, because they will burn the coffee in the process of making the espresso if the grind is too fine. I grind my own, so it was easy to adjust, but it may not be for some that buy their espresso coffee already ground. If it comes out bitter, that is why. Once I adjusted the grind, it was fine. One way to know if the grind is too fine is that water remains in the coffee grinds so they float. You will notice it when you go to make your next cup.

My issues with it are few.

1. It is a very light appliance, which is fine, but when you try to lock the xxx in place, it moves the entire thing, so you really need to grasp it two handed.

2. The grind issue is important. This cannot deal with overly fine grinds and is not adjustable to manage them.

3. It does not automatically stop when a shot has been delivered into the cup. It keeps going until you shut it off. As such it can make a regular cup of coffee, so that is fine, but YOU must wait for it and shut it off. To get a shot, you must use a cup that let's you see when the proper amount of coffee has been dispensed. Would be nice if that was automated so you could select the number of shots to make.
title: Give the jolt and makes a decent shot...
bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Automatic Dual Shot

review_content: This machine makes the process simple enough to make a good cup throughout the day and not have too much maintenance in doing so. You still need to clean out the puck, rinse your filter holder and grounds basket, and wipe the milk wand with each use. Also know that it continues dripping when done; so, I put an empty cup under it until I can finish my espresso and get back to clean it. But it is very simple to use and tastes great if you have freshly roasted beans and a good burr mill bean grinder set to fine for espresso. Drip (store ground) coffee will not work well and is probably stale by the time you buy it from the shelf. My wife loves the double latte and I use the cappuccino setting. Replace the coffee grounds press with a simple 50mm one here for $7 (all metal to support a 30 lbs down force) and you will be happy. Use a folded towel or better yet a silicone mat or cutting board for the press surface so as not to damage the drip holes on your filter holder. Beware that full "foam" setting (at the before 3 o'clock position) will overflow your large 10 oz. coffee cup and run down into the drip tray. Make sure your milk tray is not missing the silicone pickup tube inside (mine was, not available to order; but you can make your own with a 3/8" i.d. tube cut about 4 inches long). You will find many tutorials on You tube to get started. Enjoy!
title: Keep it clean and it will serve you well, very well in fact.
bought_model: Color: WhiteStyle Name: Espresso/Cappuccino Maker

review_content:
The search is over! I was looking for a good coffee maker for a long while now, this is the best I came across so far.
-Doesn't take long to heat up.
-Fantastic automated frothing.
-You can run rinse cycle to clean milk path daily, don't really feel good about stale dairy in the pipings.
-Starbuks quality outcome, given you get good grinds in, couldn't achieve this before.
-Can't really fit travel mugs in, pictured 16 & 20 oz travel mugs I have. However, you can make coffee in a large cup and pour over, larger setting fills them up.
-Milk container is easily removable, and can be placed into the fridge with the lid, easily keeping milk cold between cups.
- I used espresso and regular drip coffee drips with no issues, coffee comes out stronger than anything else I've used.
title: So happy
bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Espresso/Cappuccino Maker

review_content: I purchased this Espresso maker due to it's reviews and being an "Amazon's Choice" product.  It is a nice little machine and pulls beautiful shots. I am disappointed because I couldn't figure out why the shots don't have the distinctive flavors of the beans. The coffee flavor essentially disappears in a 4-shot Americano once I add a small amount of half-and-half. I used to own one of Starbucks small machines that ran about the same price and did not have this challenge. I have a nice burr for grinding and have had two professional baristas try their hand. They agree with me...the flavor is weak regardless of the fresh grind size, tamping pressure, water, etc. We figured out that the water temp is not getting above 167F (without) running through espresso, when closer to 190F is recommended.  The temp drops even more when it is ran through espresso beans. This matters, as does the pump pressure. Unless I find some magical answer to fix the temp, I'll likely get a different machine that provides the coffee flavor I'm looking for so that I don't go back to my coffee stand habit.
title: Good if you don't like strong coffee flavor
bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Espresso/Cappuccino Maker

review_content:
I got this machine because I was so tire of Dunkin' making cappuccinos I was throwing out and even Starbucks product being very uneven. Also, it saves you money if but only if you make more than a hundred coffee drinks.
Cappuccino tip: If you use the larger coffee holder and press the button twice for the large cappuccino you still get quite a small cappuccino--like maybe 4 ounces of milk and 2 of coffee. To make a large cappuccino, I aim the frothing tube to the cup, make sure the dial is on "froth", then press and hold the cappuccino button for 3 seconds, until it starts up. This will make a continual amount of milk that will not stop until you press the button again. So don't walk away. Now you have the amount of milk you really want. Once you have turned off the milk, press and hold the espresso button for 3 seconds till it starts up, where it will run till you press that button. This will allow you to run a bit more water through the grinds and get all the flavor out of it. Now you have a great cappuccino of the size you want. And if you like it stronger, leave the cup in the machine and refill the coffee holder and run another espresso through it. CLEANING: If you want this machine to last, keep it super clean. So when you are done, clean the mild container, then replace it. Put a cup under the brew area. Turn the dial to "clean", then press and hold the Latte button for 3 seconds till the machine starts. It will run a designated amount of time in which it will shoot clean steam through both the plastic tube that draws the milk from the container and the metal tube that puts milk in your cup. Remove the milk container and clean all the parts with soapy water. Next, remove the coffee holder from the brew mechanism, throw out the coffee, and clean both pieces. Clean off the machine portion where it brews with a sponge (careful, it's hot), replace the coffee holder (both pieces), and run a double espresso amount of water through it. Now remove it and clean it. This will keep the machine very clean and extend its life. A bit of work but worth it!
Great machine for the price!
title: Great Machine - Tips for Using and Cleaning
bought_model: Color: RedStyle Name: Espresso/Cappuccino Maker

review_content: This is my 2nd Mr. Coffee Espresso maker.  I was very happy with the 1st one, also ordered via Amazon, until the brew selector dial broke about 8 months after I purchased it. This unit is much less expensive than most steamer units and I did not expect it to last for years but I hoped it would at least last one. So I ordered another one via Amazon and the water tank on that one smelled of plastic or glue so badly that it rendered the cappuccino undrinkable and never washed out now matter how may times I flushed it with water. I now have a 3rd unit purchased directly from Mr. Coffee and although the water tank has only a slight odor to it (which leaches into the coffee), steam flowing through the steamer stem into the frothing milk tastes as bad as the coffee from the 2nd unit. Just a shame - the first one made delicious cappuccino.

review_content:
I got this for myself for Christmas last year and have thoroughly enjoyed it over the past year. I have made at least 100 cappuccinos and a few Lattes (it comes with a recipe book). I tried a pumpkin spice latte this past week and it was perfect.

I consider it sort of a hybrid between the computerized machines and the old fashioned. The things I like most are : Low cost (uses off the shelf espresso ground coffee), easy cleanup ( maybe not as easy as the pod machines, but it really takes 90 seconds max(I timed it) to rinse the parts), and easy to use (one button press).

Oh, and after a year of use I've had no problems.

I just bought it few hours ago from target. It works as it should.

Pros.

- Cheap! Even it last only half-year, it's still cheap and worth money.

Cons.

review_content: I purchased this "Espresso Machine" about a month ago and i'm tossing it and getting a new one. I'm surprised it survived this long. To call this thing an espresso machine is an insult. What you get is not espresso but more like four ounces of watery burnt drip coffee that tastes horrible. The milk frother makes a mess all the time and there is no dampener for the coffee. If you don't pay attention to it while it is brewing it will brew all the water and you'll have to open it while it is hot to add more water so you can froth the milk. I don't understand how people can be rating this thing at four and five stars. To give this thing more than two stars is ridiculous. I guess most people reviewing this don't know what espresso is. If you can't afford anything better than by all means get it. But I warn you that you get what you pay for. I'm headed to the store to buy a real espresso machine.

review_content:
I have been looking for a way to spend less cash on Starbucks and Pete's while at the same time not spending 500+ on a latte machine. I found the Mr. Coffee Latte machine and went back and forth on getting it. Well, Santa asked me what I wanted and as I really do not need anything else, I decided to get this unit. The reviews were mostly positive and ease of use was mentioned over and over. Looking forward to not spending $10 a day on Latte and food at the Bucks.

The real test will be to see how long the machine lasts.

At the time of this article, they are giving away free samples of of espresso. I did not read the fine print and thought I was getting 3 bags as shown in the picture. As I had the machine sent to my parents house for Christmas, I did not see the samples until Christmas morning. To my delight, there were 30 bags of espresso. We got about 4 shots per bag. So, 120 shots for free! Good times.

Enjoy!
title: So far so good. And the 30 free samples were a nice bonus!
bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Espresso/Cappuccino Maker

review_content:
What can I say? I too had fallen to the obsession with espresso drinks! I read about espresso and its history and all the different types of espresso drinks, and began to really want my own espresso machine, but I didn't want to pay tons of money. Just when it was beginning to look hopeless, I discovered this machine, $40 and great reviews? Well, like so many others here, I just bought it because I figured with the low price and great reviews it was worth the risk.

And I must say, this machine works great for my purposes! The drinks I make taste just as good as in any coffee shop I used to frequent, plus I can customize them and experiment however I want - even try weird additions. But in the end, I do keep returning to the basic cappuccino, so delicious in its simplicity. I haven't bought a drink in a coffee shop for so long, now that I have my own espresso machine.

I have noticed, however, that if you try to make 4 shots at once then the espresso doesn't turn out so great and you don't really get a good crema on the top. So the only issue I've had with this machine is I try to only make 2 shots at once. But, since I'm really only making these drinks for myself, that's probably a good thing. It also seems to take a long time for the steam to be heated up enough to make espresso and froth some milk, but since this machine only cost me $40 I am not complaining about those nit-picky things.
title: Makes great espresso drinks, very good deal
bought_model: Color: CappuccinoStyle Name: 4-Cup Steam

review_content: Tank leaked badly, not a good design.
title: Bad design
bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Espresso/Cappuccino Maker

review_content:
If it would have worked like advertized, we would have been very pleased. I expect in life you get a few lemons. I consider this machine dangerous, since it can have an almost full reservoir of water and your "pour" of espresso finished and when you move the knob to the steam setting for a latte, nothing happens, like you are out of water.....soooooo you unscrew the cap (put a towel over it first or you will be scalded)and lo and behold, the reservoir has plenty of water.
We will probably throw this away, not give it to anyone who could get hurt on it.

I have had lots of espresso machines from my first steam Rowenta to some up scale pump types. Lattes are a staple here in Olympia.

I am not mad at the manufacturer, you drop an egg now and then, making an omlette. However, I would not recommend buying this product.

Tom

review_content:
I bought this item along with the following: RSVP Terry's Tamper &New 20 oz Espresso Coffee Milk Frothing Pitcher, Stainless Steel. The cappuccino's I get out of it are on par w/ Starbucks. At $4+ per drink this item pays for itself in about a week. I don't think you need a tamper for it as I've not noticed difference in taste between the tamped vs. untamped other than espresso shot strength. The frother's arm is quite short and discovered the arm's length to equivalent to that of a Pyrex 1-cup container (if I'm making a single cappuccino); for more beverages the above mentioned frothing pitcher is perfect. I found the small size and appearance of the machine to not go well in a large, high-end kitchen. It looks out of place. The water chamber does get a bit difficult to open if you don't do so immediately after using due to the cap design and the vacuum effect once the water vapor cools down. The machine is light, easy to move and clean. I would recommend this item for anyone that is looking for an inexpensive alternative coffee shops for their morning fix. The machine has more than paid for itself in savings since I purchased it.

12/28/2011 - To release the vacuum in the water chamber and make opening it easier move the knob to the steam setting. This will suck air into the chamber through the frothing wand and make opening the cap easier.

PROS: The price is ok. Doesn't take long to make 1 cup. Makes good decent espresso. I prefer this over starbucks and Dunkin. Saves me lots of $$$. It has a large water reservoir for espresso water in the back that is clear plastic and removable.
In all it is ok but not the best. Will upgrade in a few years when I can afford it.

review_content:
Given the low price, I was very skeptical about buying the Mr. Coffee Steam Expresso machine. However, with the many positive reviews I figured I'd take a chance. I've been very disappointed, but you get what you pay for. Even good quality expresso tastes weak, and it is impossible to steam milk into foam. It seems to boil the milk instead of steaming (no matter how I try to adjust the steaming level or position the steamer in the milk) so you basically get hot milk with a thin layer of something resembling foam (which disappears after the first sip).

I'm going to replace it with a real expresso machine, either going back to Krupps or trying Nespresso.

review_content:
We were looking for our first espresso machine in hopes of saving a few dollars by making coffee drinks at home. We ended up at Target and had two to choose from, this one and the smaller ECM160, which sells for half the price. We went with this one for the extra features.
After reading the instructions, we set it up for brewing. As soon as we turned it on, it made a very loud humming sound and vibrated violently. So much so, that we had to hold it and the cup in place. After 10 or 15 seconds, we shut it off. Nothing came out of the machine. It was obviously defective. We packed it up and returned it to Target with no questions asked.
We ended up buying the Mr Coffee ECM160 for half the price of this one. It works great!! It doesn't have a removable water tank or lighted controls, but it works fine for espresso and steam-see our review for it, we gave it 5 stars.
Know also that this model does not include a pitcher or cup. The smaller ECM160 comes with a useful pitcher.
Happy Brewing!!!

title: Christmas Present

review_content:
I'll give tips after a little background info, what wasn't right and what customer service said to do, that WORKED!

First off my background. I am not, nor have I every been a barista. I am an average person who likes mochas from the coffee shop, but I live 80 miles from town, so I don't get them very often and wanted to try making them at home. This is my first espresso machine. I read a lot of blogs and watched online videos from real baristas giving tips how to make good espresso drinks at home before purchasing this. I got this thing and things didn't taste right to me, bitter. So I did more research and figured out the problem, it wasn't heating up well. I checked temperature and it was only getting to 157*F on average (too cold) and took 14-15 seconds to make one shot (too fast). NOT what the online advice says you need. Online advice says 170-180*F and 27-30 seconds is about right. So I called Mr Coffee for help before I sent it back to Amazon. GLAD I did.

The call: In short, customer service told me to run a cleaning cycle per directions from page 16 in the user manual. Which is 1/2 tank of white vinegar, hit the button for double shot. Repeat as many times as you need. Also run a cleaning cycle through the milk dispenser. My thought was, "what the heck, its a new machine! I did the priming as directed before use, how can it be dirty?" But I had to give it a try or send it back. Well I'll be go to heck, it WORKED!

While directions said you only need to run it few times. I had the time, so I ran the whole 1/2 tank white vinegar through (double shot at at a time) since I has to toss the vinegar anyway, so why not really clean it eh? Anyway, after a couple times running the double shot espresso button the temperature went from consistent 157*F to 175-182*F. Wahoo! It seemed to matter how long I let it warm up between shots. Running two times consecutively got the 175-177*, which is just what you want. Letting it sit and warm up a few minutes before runs got it 180-184*, which is getting a little too hot. BTW, I was using a good quality quick, calibrated thermometer that I use for caramel making, which is a very exacting process to do right. So I figured it could accurately measure the espresso before it cooled from air temperature, which by the way is mere seconds I found out.

NOTE: The higher temperature is NOT for drinking comfort (how hot you like it) it is what the espresso NEEDS to properly extract and not be bitter. You can let it sit a few minutes if you don't like it that hot, personally I don't want a burned tongue, so I wait a little. Coming out of the machine perfect drinking temperature is NOT a good thing.

SECOND NOTE: Running the vinegar through is NOT descaling, it is cleaning. Descaling is something else you do, read the manual on how. The vinegar clean is NOT priming, it is cleaning. Don't know why you need to clean the new machine in addition to priming, but DO it anyway. Make sure to rinse the reservoir out, then run some PLAIN water through to remove the vinegar afterwards, do it as many times as it takes to get the smell out, mine took a full reservoir. Honestly though it's faster shipping it back and waiting for a replacement machine because it doesn't get hot enough, this WORKS.

When I first got it, as I said it was taking 14-15 seconds to run the shots through. During the cleaning process they got longer and longer. Now that it's clean, it's about 28-30 seconds. Again, just what you want. I use my cell phone stop watch feature to be accurate.

In summary, based on what I've read and how I got it to work well, at least for "normal" person standards. This a good machine. Here's my TIPS TO GET IT WORKING RIGHT:

1. Learn to grind grounds well. Do NOT buy pre-ground, buy beans and grind them yourself. It has to do with when the oil is release one how well it works. If you are going to the trouble to use a machine like this (rather than just normal a coffee machine) you can go to the effort to grind as well, it's just part of the process.

You can use the hand held cone burr grinders for the most accurate fine ground. Or you can spend a bundle on an electric burr grinder. From what I read, you REALLY do need to get a good one if you go electric. In fact that is almost more important than the machine they say. Inconsistent size of grounds will yield inconsistent shots. Too fine (Turkish grind, which is like flour) and it clogs the filter making the machine unable to push all the water through. Too course (regular coffee machine grind) and the water goes through too fast making it bitter. Espresso grind has to be the consistency of table salt.

I'm cheap, so using the hand grinder does work and I advise it for other cheap people. However, in the morning I am cranky and impatient, I'm also lazy, so I've ordered a couple different electric burr grinders to see if that works as well. I plan to return which ever (or both) that don't grind as the espresso NEEDS (good ol Amazon prime and their return policies). No, I did not take the online baristas advice and buy a $200 burr grinder (I am cheap after all), but I did spend about $50 on a burr grinder and $20 on a blade style. Will update when I have decided what works or not, which I kept or if I end up just doing the hand grind.

2. Learn how full to fill the cup. At least to the top of the rim, or a little higher. You want the end result about 1/8-1/4" from the top. The amount in the cup DOES matter.

3. Learn how to pack your grounds to 30lbs of pressure. How to do that, put your bathroom scale on the counter. Use your tamper to push until you get the feel of 30lbs pressure. Repeat several times until you can push it pretty accurately. This is very important. Also, but a metal tamper, the plastic one isn't sturdy enough for 30 lbs pressure, it bents and packs unevenly. You can get metal tampers cheap, it's worth it.

4. Before you make your cup each morning, warm the machine as directions indicate, but ALSO run a shot of plain water through first. The second time through will be hotter, and it only takes 30 seconds.

5. Even though it's a new machine, and you did the priming as the manual says, run 1/2 tank of white vinegar through it (directions on page 16 of manual) and it will make a tremendous difference. Don't argue, just do it.

6. You can open the lid and fill the reservoir with it ON the machine with a pitcher if taking it on and off is too hard.

NOTE: I did NOT receive this at a discount in exchange for an honest review. This is a good machine for the average espresso based specialty coffee drinker. I gave it a full 5 stars because it's pretty idiot proof (I'm not the most mechanical person) and it makes mochas that are pretty darn good in my average persons opinion. I have no idea what a real coffee expert would say, and really, shouldn't they have a professional machine anyway? [...]
title: TIPS THAT WORK!  From an average person, not a barista.
bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Espresso/Cappuccino Maker

review_content:
I love my Mr Coffee Cafe Barista. It makes great espresso, cappuccino, latte, etc.

However, there is a dangerous design flaw that needs to be fixed ASAP. There is a tiny wood screw holding the 3 pieces of the portafilter together. This tiny wood screw works its way out of the plastic piece and falls into your coffee!

I discovered this when I poured a shot of espresso into my new $215 Nutri Ninja Auto-IQ Blender to make a bulletproof coffee. The tiny screw tore up the metal blades before I realized what was happening and turned it off. I guess I am lucky because ordinarily I would have just gulped the shot and the screw would have ended up somewhere in my digestive system.

When I fished the screw out I couldn't imagine where it had come from. I saw the tiny hole in the bottom of the portafilter but I just could not believe that Mr Coffee was using a wood screw into soft plastic to hold the portafilter together! Especially when, as was bound to happen, if it worked its way out, it would end up in the coffee! But later when I was cleaning the portafilter I saw that it came apart into 3 pieces and it had never come apart like that before. I had saved the little screw and I saw that, incredibly enough, this was what had been holding it together!

I have included pictures showing the pieces of the portafilter and the tiny screw that is supposed to hold all it together. The translucent thing is a seal between the other 2 parts. The red arrows point to the places where the screw goes.

Mr Coffee needs to fix this issue and provide a free replacement portafilter to everyone who owns a Cafe Barista.

If you own or buy a Cafe Barista I urge you to be proactive and remove the little screw before it works its way out on its own and you end up drinking it. The portafilter leaks and drips without the screw but that's better than having metal pieces in your coffee.
title: Dangerous design flaw drops metal screw into coffee
bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Espresso/Cappuccino Maker

review_content:
While shopping for an espresso machine, I went back and forth on this machine and a similarly priced Delonghi. I came very close to choosing the Delonghi, but what pushed me to the Mr. Coffee was my intended use. I wanted something that was very automated, while still allowing the freedom to use my own ground, not pods.

My out of the box experience was that the item was simple to unpack and prep for use.

TIP: this ships in it's product box, so if you want extra protection or this is a gift, check off the "Ship in an Amazon box" where offered. After setting up the maker, washing it's compartments etc. I was ready to prime it. This took just a few minutes.

The unit comes with all you need - just add electricity, water, milk, and coffee. It includes a water tank, milk tank, two filers (single and double), a porta-filter and combination scoop/tamper. It has a 26" cord and is 1,040 watts. It is advertised as 15 bars.

The unit heats up quickly and is easy to use. The advertised drink sizes are pretty accurate, so choose the right glassware! You can also make custom sizes by overriding the Espresso button.

TIP: Consider buying another filter so you can prep two or three filters with coffee and make several drinks faster when serving a small group.

The drinks you can make are:
* Espresso: Single (1.25 ounces) Double (2.5 ounces)
* Cappuccino: Single (6 ounces) Double (10 ounces)
* Latte: Single (12 ounces) Double (15 ounces)

TIP:
As far a tip on glasses, I ended up buying:
* Bormioli Rocco Easy Bar Espresso glasses - these are TOO small for a double espresso. They claim they are 3.5 ounces but actually measure out to be 2.5 ounces filled to the brim.
* Bormioli Rocco Oslo Cappuccino Cup - excellent glass and at 7.5 ounces easily fits a single cappuccino and allows for extra froth.
* Anchor Hocking glass mugs - about 16 ounces and great for lattes and the double cappuccino.

The Mr. Coffee heats quickly, and each set of lights pulsates until at a ready temperature.

The entire setup is simple to use, add water, add milk to the froth container, add your coffee and you are ready to go.

My lone complaint about this product is the porta-filter. I find mine requires an abnormal amount of strength to lock it into position. I am not overfilling with coffee, and even tried it with empty filters inserted in the porta-filter- same problem. I actually ordered a replacement machine but had the same issue.

Other than that quirk, it is really a great machine. It makes excellent drinks, and with minimal effort on your part. You can customize your froth simply by using the Cappuccino button override. After you are done making drinks, clean up is easy. You can store your froth container of milk for later use in your fridge. To clean up, just set the froth dial to 'Clean' then hold down the Latte button to override drinks and put the machine in "clean" mode.

Basically, outside of the On-Off button on the side, you do everything with three buttons (Espresso, cappuccino, and Latte). Press once for a single drink, twice for a double, and hold down the buttons to override (custom drink size, extra froth, and clean).

There are little tray areas you can pull out or remove, depending on your glass sizes. You can also fit the smaller filter in one of these tray compartments when not in use. Do NOT leave the porta-filter attached to the machine when not in use, as this may add wear to the filter assembly.

I would absolutely recommend this machine.
title: Amazing convenience - Great Caffe!
bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Espresso/Cappuccino Maker

review_content: So i'm really sad to write this review. If you had asked me for a review during the first month of use (3 double shots brewed daily) I would have rated this machine 5 stars but after less than two months of use this machine will no longer brew espresso.  The pump starts to sound like it's working and then goes quiet when it starts to "brew" and nothing comes out. Prior to this issue the machine made the sound the entire time the espresso was brewing. I followed the manufacturers instructions to ensure the porta filter was not clogged. I've let vinegar sit and ran vinegar through the unit a few times to "delime" it as Mr. Coffee suggested in their response email to my complaint with no success. I've wasted a ton of espresso trying the unit again after each unsuccessful "fix". There is no reason for an espresso machine (for whatever reason) to stop working in two months. I'll update this review after I have time to sit on the phone with Mr. Coffee as they walk me through more "fixes" for a two month old machine. Can you tell i'm not pleased?
title: Worked amazingly well...for two months
bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Espresso/Cappuccino Maker

review_content:
I‚Äôve had the machine for 3 months now, and I have grown very fond of it.
When I purchased the machine in early February (2018), I was initially disappointed but it has since won me over. I was seeking an upgrade from my less fancy Mr. Coffee 1-stream 4-cup (BVMC-ECM260-RB I think). I very much liked my original Mr. Coffee 1-stream but I was looking for a machine that had an open-tank removable reservoir that refilled more easily.
Overall, this machine is hands down an upgrade; I do have a few issues with the product description though...

Name:
Mr. Coffee Caf√© 20-Ounce Steam Automatic Espresso and Cappuccino Machine, Silver/Black
‚Ä¢ Maybe I misunderstand what automatic means when in reference to espresso machines, but I thought it would shut off after it pulled the shot. It does not, you will have to watch the machine and shut off the flow of water.
‚Ä¢ I don‚Äôt know what they mean by this claim. Nothing is in the portion of 20oz- except for the glass decanter, which is not included. The filter baskets are for one (1 oz) and two (2 oz) shots of espresso respectively. These filter amounts are not marked accordingly, but one is taller/larger than the other. The water reservoir is a quart (32oz).
Description:
Easy-pour 20 oz. glass decanter features a stay-cool handle and drip-free spout, and serves up to 4 shots---
o Glass decanter was not part of this package and the 4 shots refer to the decanter size
15-bar pressure pump system allows for optimum flavor extraction----
o Very nice pressure makes creamy frothy espresso.
Steam espresso machine brews up to 20 oz. of espresso---
o Maybe 20oz is how much you can brew without giving the machine a rest? Not sure on this one.
Easy to use Milk Frother for creamy cappuccinos and lattes---
o Froths and heats milk very well; user will need to practice to get it right.
Removable, washable drip catcher keeps brew space tidy----
o Convenient for cleaning
Includes measuring scoop for a perfect cup of coffee---
o Scoop doubles as tamper. I prefer my metal one over this plastic one, but it works fine. I really appreciate the fact they include one with this pack. If you don‚Äôt have one yet, this one works well to get you started brewing.

Start-up
I think it took longer the first few times, but is very quick now. The blue light on the front fades in and out while heating. Then the light stops flashing, you‚Äôre ready to go!
Brewing
Super fast! The water reservoir makes this process so fast and easy.
Frothing
Very nice.
I truly appreciate the included accessories. The metal feather cup they give you is great.
Cleaning
Pretty easy.
The removable base is a plus. The filter and basket clean easily as well.
title: I‚Äôve had the machine for 3 months now, and I have grown very fond of it.
bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Caf√© Steam

review_content: I am not a professional by any means, but I was a barista at a successful "mom n pop" coffee shop for a year, so I know how to pull a good shot and properly steam milk.  I like good coffee, but I'm not a stickler. I wanted to be able to make my own espresso for americanos and the occasional latte at home. I did my research and decided on this machine because it's under 100 bucks which is what I was looking for. I also was looking at the Hamilton beach one that's under 100, and the delonghi. I know that's a better brand but this machine was a little cheaper and had similar reviews. This one is very user friendly, you definitely don't have to have barista experience to get a shot from it. Extreme coffee people might say it doesn't pull a "real" shot because it doesn't require espresso fine ground coffee (real espresso grounds should be as fine as powdered sugar and fit between the lines of your fingerprint) you can actually use it with regular ground coffee for a drip machine, although I use a burr grinder and have it set somewhere in between the two. You don't need to buy a different tamper; the one it comes with is definitely the worst tamper I've ever seen, but with this machine you really don't need a heavy tamper to pack it down hard, because it doesn't make pucks. Even after a decent shot, the leftover grounds come out as sludge instead of a puck, but it seems that's just how this machine works. It's definitely not coffee shop quality but if you want to be able to make coffee that is more than just black brew from a drip machine, then this gets the job done. I like it a lot, it's not for you if you're going to be picky about a syrupy vs runny shot, or how many seconds it takes, but if you just want some espresso with a good layer of yummy crema from your own home for well less than a hundred bucks then this is for you. I can't speak for how long it lasts because I've only had it for less than a month but I've used it multiple times every day and it's working great.
title: Great beginner machine, not for picky or professional baristas
bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Automatic Dual Shot

review_content:
We are a Cuban family of 5 that drink espresso multiple times a day, and two of us drink lattes every morning. We have a traditional espresso machine and were looking into another one to make the lattes, and during that search, I found this amazing machine for both espressos and lattes!
The set up was fairly easy and straightforward, just MAKE SURE THAT YOU REMOVE THE RED COVER FROM THE BOTTOM OF THE WATER CONTAINER before you start using the machine. The water container is extremely convenient, as it holds a large amount of water and you won't need to fill it every time you make an espresso -unlike traditional espresso machines.
There are three different options: ESPRESSO, CAPPUCCINO AND LATTE. You have one button for each option. If you press the button ONCE, you will get a small portion (single shot). If you press it TWICE you will get a bigger portion (double shot). Under those buttons you have another feature that lets you set the amount of froth that you want (little to none for Lattes and lots for cappuccinos.) After you plug the machine your three buttons will start flashing. You have to wait a few minutes until their light is fixed, when that happens you can start using the machine.
To make an espresso you simply fill up the filter with your desired brand of ground coffee (you have a single and double shot filters between which you can easily switch) and press the espresso button either once or twice. Your coffee will start pouring within SECONDS. To make a latter of cappuccino is the same procedure, except that you will need to fill up the milk container. To remove the milk container simply pull it horizontally towards you; to put it back, push it horizontally towards the machine until it "clicks" into place. You have arrows on the container and on the surface of the machine that will touch each other when the milk container is correctly inserted.
The only inconvenience for us is that even a double shot is not enough for us 5, we have to make TWO double shots. But since it takes seconds for the espresso to be ready, we can't complain. With our traditional espresso machine we had to wait 5 minutes for the espresso to start pouring. Besides, sometimes only my parents are home and if they made too much then it would go to waste, so they do a single shot with this machine and that's just enough for both of them.
I was hesitant before buying this machine because of all the negative reviews about how fast it broke down, but I'm glad I decided to take the risk and buy it. I have been using for almost three weeks now Multiple times a day for both espressos and lattes and I have not seen any sign of deterioration (fingers crossed). I will update my review if this changes, but so far, my family and I are completely in love with this awesome machine!
title: Works very fast and the espresso is delicious
bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Espresso/Cappuccino Maker

review_content:
I've had a semiautomatic espresso maker/machine for the last five years. I've brewed about 4600 cups of espresso with it. With that said I have some idea of what a good espresso shot is about.

First off, this machine requires a thorough cleaning before you use it. One other person recommend cleaning it with vinegar, and this seem to help.

In order to produce a good espresso shot, you need to have the right amount of coffee, the right amount of pressure for tamping, and finally a length of time for brewing that is not too long or too short. Get one of the variables wrong, and the quality suffers. Lastly, a good-quality blend of coffee. I use a local roasting house, and coffee that's about $17 a pound. Avoid the cheap supermarket stuff, and go to a local roaster.

If you use the enclosed spoon you'll get somewhere around 11 or 12 g of coffee. Most sources I've read recommend between 14 and 18 grams, so you'll want to use a rounded spoonful. You'll also need about 30 pounds of pressure for tamping, and the enclosed tamper they give you will bend under that kind of pressure, and will probably result in uneven compression. (Hint--Buy a steel tamper!). No professional uses a plastic tamper.

If you get about 14 to 15 g of coffee in the porta filter, then brewing time is around 25 seconds, which is just about perfect. This produces nice crema. I preheat the machine on mine by running a double shot through the porta filter while empty, then wiping dry, and finally go on to making the cup of coffee. if you follow these steps you can produce a pretty decent shot.

As to the milk frothing mechanism, I think it's a joke. I can make a wonderful froth from about 4 ounces of milk, and this uses way too much milk. I want to taste coffee not milk. I guess if you like lattes, that you may like the frothing part. I use a standalone frother, and find it a whole lot more economical and easier to clean. By letting it sit for about 30 seconds I can get the perfect blend of milk and froth for cappuccinos. There's less control with the built in one Mr. Coffee uses. I can also say it's a pain to clean this built in one, and residual milk tends to build up on the plastic if you let it sit. Again, I'm much happier using a standalone frother, and they are only about 30 bucks to buy.

I also picked up the Mr. Coffee Burr grinder, and it seems to produce a nice grind for this machine, and also seems consistent in its output. The two seem a nice match for one another.

I think the week part of this whole system is the frothing. As an espresso maker, I think it does a fine job. Quality is not quite as good as my semiautomatic machine was, but decent for the price. I paid about $147. Price seems to go up and down a lot on Amazon. Currently it's $181. Not sure I'd pay that much for it.

Time will tell just how good of a value this is, but pump seems to be quite capable, and I'm told you can order parts for it, which is more than I can say for a lot of the machines out there. Packaging was outstanding. Probably something we all take for granted these days until you get something that arrives in pieces. I admire a company who takes the time to engineer a good packaging system, and Mr. Coffee did it right. The machine comes well protected, even the plug receptacle end is protected. Nice.

Overall I think it's a good machine, but again I would recommend a standalone frother for best results and economy.

One other thing worth mentioning is you can get this machine for about $70 without the milk frother, and that's what I would do. I found after trying the frothing a few times my coffee taste like milk, and is on the warm side instead of hot side. I don't see any reason to pay for something that is really subpar, so again, if I had to do over I would just buy the standalone machine without frother.

Update: Tried the milk frother a few more times, and it overflows a 12 oz. cup every time, and froth is pretty loose. Foam should be dense. I now run a double shot of water through before I brew, and this helps with temp, but milk frothing is still sub-par IMO. I think I will send back, and just get the $70 version. A stand alone frother works much better, and is consistent with nice dense foam/froth.
title: Decent quality expresso, poor milk froth
bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Espresso/Cappuccino Maker

review_content: My husband and I had this model 10 years ago.  I was hoping that this one would be just as reliable and easy to use.  Unfortunately, I was wrong.  The body is light and the espresso arm did not snap into place strait, like it was supposed to.  It's too tight a fit.  Sorta strait was the best we could get it to... Also, the main knob was stiff to turn, making the transition to espresso to steam messy and they CHANGED THE STEAM WAND.  Now, this plastic nozzle has holes at the top that forces the user to completely immerse the tip and NOT be able to make foam like a regular barista.  It fries the milk and leaves it flat.  You should be able to put the tip near the top and pull foam for a latte.  With this model, if you do that, it sprays milk all over the place.  And the steam wand gave way too much powerful steam and not in a consistent stream, but irregular blasts!  It's dangerous, in my opinion and it makes poor quality, bad tasting espresso on top of that. If the steam wand wasn't so horrible, it might have salvaged a 3 star review, but this is so disappointing, I want to return it.  I betcha it's made in China, now.  It is.
title: Not what it used to be.

review_content:
I suspect this product is keeping Mr. Coffee in business. You cannot expect a product at this price to perform well, yet this machine has not let me down.

I have made a latte daily in my own house since 1998; usually two or three. A day. I have no shame.

I have owned a variety of expensive machines, including pump machines. The volume at which they operate is ridiculous. Next door neighbors should not be able to HEAR you simply making coffee! The Mr.Coffee model shocked me when I gave it a try about five years ago. I could not believe how well it worked and at such a quiet volume. It makes a lovely latte and perfect foam.

I am certain the machine was never designed for the use ...er ...abuse I put it through. After my two to three a day habit, the machine gives out in about 6 months. That's okay by me! For the price, it does not bother me to replace it.

Also, be mindful that the first five or so drinks in the new machine may have a slight metallic/plastic taste. This is normal with this (and other) machines. It will go away.

review_content:
This is a pretty good budget item. I was really dreaming of the one that automatically froths milk but it's $140 more. This espresso maker DOES have an awful plastic smell. I noticed it when I opened the box and became alarmed. I ran a water cycle twice with no improvement. I then put a 50/50 water/vinegar mix in and let it soak for over half an hour before letting that run through the system. Ran another 2 water cycles and noticed improvement but plastic odor was still there. Did the vinegar water cycle once more (this time letting it soak for an hour before running it through). Ran hot water twice more and noticed the water did not smell or taste like plastic. I left the lid off the machine over night to let it off gas and today I made my first espresso. Not too bad if you're not super picky. If your frother isn't working, add water to the reservoir. Keep the plastic tube on otherwise it makes a terrible sound.

The plastic odor is stronger if your device was more recently produced. Off gassing takes time. Many other coffee machines deal with this problem. For this machine you might see some success with my method mentioned above. I also recommend leaving the lid off as much as possible until odor is gone.
title: This is a pretty good budget item
bought_model: Color: CappuccinoStyle Name: 4-Cup Steam

review_content: Well, you get what you pay for I guess. Had this for 2 months and I'm sick of it leaking all over the place. It was great for the first two weeks once I got used to the metallic taste it generated. After that it started to steam and drip about a quarter of the water out around the basket. There's no resistance when you try to lock in the basket anymore, they must use a really cheap gasket in there or something because at first it sealed when it was only about 3/4 of the way into the locked position, now even turning all the way to the right it leaks like crazy. I tried not tamping the grind as much, even not at all, and it helps a little but then it doesn't get as strong. Also, the knobs are the stupidest design ever, very hard to turn on and off, and very hard to open the water chamber.

review_content:
I bought this coffee maker for my birthday 4-5 years ago. I used it very sparingly, was gentle with it, and did not use it daily or all that regularly over the years I owned it. It worked perfectly well until one day when it suddenly stopped working.

I had ground coffee ready to make espresso, and the espresso came out slowly dripping into the carafe instead of the speed it normally would.

I released a lot of the steam from the other steam valve for 10 minutes, turned the machine off, unplugged it, waited 15 minutes and slowly opened up the compartment where you put water into, and got burned by the steam.

I packed up the espresso maker and gave it to a local thrift store. I'm sticking with moka pots.
title: Not that good of an espresso maker.  I'll stick to moka pots.
bought_model: Color: CappuccinoStyle Name: 4-Cup Steam

review_content:
I recently purchased the Mr. Coffee ECM-160 on the strength of the reviews here on Amazon. So far I am very pleased with this purchase.

It seems pertinent in a review such as this to note that I'm not an extreme espresso aficionado, and in fact, I've only recently become interested in making espresso at home. I understand that the espresso this machine creates is different in viscosity than that of a 'pro' machine, but I'm not interested in investing hundreds of dollars into this hobby. For anyone looking to tentatively try their hand at brewing espresso at home this seems to be the perfect machine to, if nothing else, gauge your interest.

The ECM-160 is extremely compact, so it won't burden your countertop with excessive clutter. The nice brushed aluminum trim belies its price tag, although the plastic drip tray does not. Operation is extremely simple, with a nice rotary knob on the side that selects between brew and steam modes. I'm still experimenting with grind size and tamping force, but I've made espresso that is far stronger than any other coffee brewing technique I own (French press, percolator, drip) contrary to some of the reviews. It even creates a nice layer of light brown foam in the final 10 seconds of brewing that resembles 'crema' (again, I'm no expert). Brewing 4 cups only takes a few minutes.

The frother works well, although it is awkwardly close to the body of the machine. I've been able to create very rich milk foam with a little practice, which helps make a great latte/cappuccino. The plastic `frothing aid' and metal frothing tip are both removable for easy cleaning, which is a plus. No, it doesn't come with a frothing mug, but at this price, who could expect that? Some stainless steel mugs cost half as much as this entire machine. The flattened bottom of the scoop works well enough to tamp the grounds in the filter, too.

So in summary, this is an excellent little espresso machine for the mild enthusiast not looking to break the bank. A few trips to the local coffee shop will pay for this machine, which is reason alone to give it a try - so it's an added bonus that it works so well. Highly recommended.
title: Excellent espresso maker
bought_model: Color: CappuccinoStyle Name: 4-Cup Steam

review_content: If I have bought a thousand things on Amazon - and I probably have - this was the best purchase of them all. I bought it because of the other reviews and everyone was right. Easiest way to make a great cappuccino or latte multiple times a day. It‚Äôs amazing

review_content:
After reading all of the positive reviews I decided to buy this machine rather than a more expensive brand. I had a previous version of a Mr. Coffee cappuccino machine which was decent but broke after a few months so I figured I could replace this machine many times for the price of one of the more expensive brands.

I don't think that my machine is defective, but it might be. The problem with the machine is that the amount of coffee (and even watery, milky-foam--not the best foam) produced is quite variable from cup to cup. Not only is this annoying, but the ratio of milk to coffee is always changing the taste of the cappuccino. I use the same mug every morning. Sometimes it is 1/4 full, once it was completely full--all by pressing the cappuccino button twice (for a large).

According to the manual, I should use a larger grind of coffee and/or not tamp down as much. I have not tried changing the grind (an "espresso" grind from a very good, local coffee shop) but tamping clearly makes a difference. If I tamp it firmly, little coffee comes out. If I barely tamp it, roughly the proper amount of coffee comes out but the taste seems different. I wonder if this means that the pump is not strong enough?

A few weeks in, I am still using it and it produces drinkable results every morning--but turns out to be less automatic than I was expecting. I usually have to add more coffee or milk once my "automatic" cup if ready. Cleaning is relatively easy.
title: Variable Results - Pump Problem?

review_content:
Received this as a gift for my birthday. Decided to get this one to see if it works as well as a high quality one before investing the money into a more expensive machine.

I've had this machine for several months now and it works great. Would recommend getting course ground espresso and to use the larger filter basket. With course ground espresso, packed tight, I pull 1 shot of espresso in ~30 seconds, the espresso being pitch dark with a beautiful creme on top. The arm is tight and took some time getting used to, even months later it is still tight and requires me to grab the machine real firm before locking it into place.

I do not use the steam nozzle because I drink soy milk and soy milk doesn't really foam up that well. Instead, I put my soy milk in the microwave to warm up, pull my shots of espresso in a high baller glass, and mix once both are ready.

It is hard to go out for coffee anymore. Even when I buy lattes from local roasters it just feels tasteless compared to me making it myself at home with their beans.

Will definitely be buying this machine again when, or if, mine goes out. It works fantastic and it is a fraction of the price of the more fancy machines.

review_content: I have tried three times now to make a nice strong cup of cappuccino, and all three times have failed. I am using Starbucks Espresso Roast already ground coffee and I am using the 2 shot coffee filter, tamped down well, and I push the cappuccino button twice, as directed. It comes out looking great -- well the froth on top does anyway -- but it is so weak it just tastes like frothy brown milk. I always order extra froth when I buy these at Starbucks. So I'm thinking maybe I have too much froth being generated but if I turn down the frother it's not the amount of froth I want. I just don't see how to fix this problem but I doubt the company will take the product back now. It is $150 down the drain in my opinion, unless anyone has some magic fix for this crappuccino maker. If so, please let me know and I gladly will revise this negative review. Oh, and the only reason I gave this a double star rating is because the frother works really well.
title: I have tried three times now to make a nice strong cup of cappuccino

review_content:
When I was hunting for an espresso machine on Amazon, I was confused between this product and the De'Longhi EC155 15 BAR Pump Espresso and Cappuccino Maker, which had 6 times as many reviews as this one with nearly the same rating. In the end, I chose this product instead. And even though the De'Longhi product is $12 more expensive than this one (at the time of this review), it wasn't so much for the face value price difference that I bought the product instead. The reasons I finally went for this product were the following:

1. You can easily fit a 10 cm tall cup under this one (for both the portafilter and the frothing tube), which means that I did not have spend money buying demitasses. The De'Longhi machine has a small clearance and therefore you can only fit demitasses under it.
2. This machine comes with a tamper thus saving more money than buying the De'Longhi version that does not come with one.

Of course, this one does not come with a frothing pitcher, so either you can buy one (which you will need to do for the De'Longhi machine too) or use a narrow adequately sized container.

In the end, I don't find any difference between the espresso produced by this machine and the one I get in coffee shops. Therefore, I don't see why I would go for a $200 - $2000 machine instead. This product is easy to use, involves following straightforward instructions and makes good espresso. Also, you can choose how much water you want in your espresso as you control the water flow in this machine.

As with any electronic machine, it is always best to follow instructions if you want good performance from it time and again. Do not leave the portafilter on the machine if you do not want the spoil the seal and clean thoroughly and often. Don't leave the machine turned on and let it cool often enough. Do spend time reading the instructions before you operate this for the first time. It takes no more than 15 mins if you were to read carefully.

In conclusion, I am glad I went for this product instead of the De'Longhi one. I saved me a lot more money than the face value price difference and I can use this machine to make me a tall cup of espresso on the days when things are just not going my way :)

title: Great machine for the Price

review_content:
I received this as a xmas gift. I was excited to try it out, as I was spending quite a bit on lattes at places, and I figured it would be nice to save money. Unfortunately, this machine seems to fall flat.

I have a burr grinder and ground to what I read was espresso consistency; between powdered sugar and salt. I had mine closer to salt when you rub it between your fingers. Apparently that's too fine for this machine, even though it says to grind to a salt consistency in the directions. I even tried using my scale to get an exact weight for the double shot filter. No matter what I do, it just can't push water through the double shot. It took me about 5min to get 2oz because it just drips out so damn slow. I tried packing it a little looser, i tried packing tighter, i tried using slightly less. So forget about using the double shot filter unless you use a coarser grind (at which point it doesn't seem like it could be considered an espresso grind).

I had to switch to using the single shot filter. Even then, it seems to push water through slower than it should. And that was with a weighted/measured amount of grinds. A whole lot faster than the double shot filter, but still not within the 20-25sec range I've heard is optimal. But it's awful that you can't use the espresso grind with the double shot filter because it means you have to brew two individual single shots. And that means you have to brew a shot, then empty, clean, and dry the filter, and then you can brew the second shot.

On top of all of this, the brew really doesn't seem to come out that warm. Using pre warmed mug & shot collection glass, by the time you're done with everything and have it combined for a latte, it's only mildly hot, and is lukewarm within 5min.

I'm a bit disappointed it didn't come with a couple cups, or at least a metal frothing cup. Kind of hard to make anything when you're just starting out and you realize you don't have anything that can work as collection cups, and finding a frothing pitcher locally is impossible. You can't even fit a doubleshot glass under each spout because they are too tall. You can't fit an average mug (pretty sure mine are 8oz and typical height) under it. Can't easily find smaller sized mugs/cups that will fit. You pretty much have to use regular shot glasses. I had a small measuring glass I bought that worked while also allowing me to see how many ounces I was getting out of what time frame.

I've seen people mention the filter basket is very hard to lock, and that's true. I have to wrap my arm around the machine to hold it while the other hand locks the thing into place. However, I would rather have the tight seal than have to worry about water spraying out due to a loose seal. My overall opinion of the machine is that it can do an okay job, and is fine if you are okay doing only single shots, or using a coarser grind. But if you aren't okay with that, then I would look for a better machine. I'm sure there must be one out there.

If it matters to anyone, I have been using Death Wish Coffee (barrel brand and valhalla java) in my machine. Both came out looking great. It's just the machine itself that I seem to be having issues with.

review_content:
I owned the first generation of this product. It lasted about a year with moderate use and came out far ahead when compared to daily trips to Starbucks. Rather than tweak an already good machine, it's obvious they took the we need to make it cheaper approach to increase margins. Everything is now cheap and flimsy from the decanter handle to the milk frother. Overall, functionally it works the same as the first generation. The performance at least has not suffered. It works ok. The first generation I bought for <30 and was a far better deal. The only improvement to this model is the power indictor (which the previous model did not have).

Update: After 9 months of once a day use, it exploded like everyone else's. Coffee grounds and a mess everywhere. Looking at the filter basket locking mechanism, it's pushed out. I imagine that the constant pressure of pushing hot water thru the filter basket stressed this area to failure. It's plastic..I don't see it as a if it is going to fail but when IMO. The previous generation did not have this issue.

review_content: I had previously had a Krups espresso machine that I thought was a fair.  It never really produced crema on the espresso pulls and it spit and leaked more times than not. But I don't make espresso enough to spend tons of money on a big, fancy machine.  This little unit is the perfect thing -- and from Mr. Coffee, for heaven's sake!  It just works.  You get crema on the espresso, it doesn't leak, the steamer works beautifully.  And by the way, you DON'T need a tamper, folks!  Take a closer look at the coffee scoop that comes with the unit.  It has a flat bottom designed to be used as a tamper.  If you want to buy a separate tamper, I suppose you can.  But why not use the bottom of the scoop, the way it was intended to be used!?!  Bottom line, would I buy this again?  Absolutely.

review_content: Well, Mr. Coffee does it again. I've never owned a Mr. Coffee product, but I notice that Consumer Reports always gives good ratings of Mr. Coffee coffeemakers whenever they conduct an evaluation. Not only are the makers the most reasonably and value priced, the products CR reviews are reliable. The Café Barista, which I purchased December 6--and I've used it every day since, is a very pleasant surprise and is so far consistent with the CR overall review of Mr. Coffee makers. I was looking to spend upwards of $500 for an espresso maker and then I thought, give Mr. Coffee a try. This is definitely a machine for home use and probably not heavy use, but what it does...it does well. I have been making cappuccinos daily and the frothing component is pretty good. Make sure you prime the machine as directed and make sure if you're making a double, you have at least a 10-12 ounce cup. For a an extra little perk, buy the Torani Syrups and believe me, you'll feel like you've just ordered your beverage from Starbucks. A dash of organic cinnamon and voila-caffeine heaven. In fact, this machine produces the same quality beverage I get at Starbucks and I love Starbucks line of coffee drinks, but I'm a home body espresso maker now.
