Then came the daily flooding of my counter, at that time I should have packet it back in the box and returned it to Target... The leaking went worse, I had to put the espresso maker on top of a container to collect all the water pouring from underneath.
Then ... Came the much feared ( and often described on the web ) Blinking red light... Basically the espresso maker thinks that the espresso//steam button is not in the proper position, hence refuses to operate at all. Of course I wasted my time cleaning it out, but this won't help. Makes you wonder if this electronic control is set up to malfunction after a given number of uses; all the comments I have been reading seem to indicate that this issue starts after about a year of use...
Good luck, I have learned my lesson and won't buy from this company ever again.
title: Flooding and Blinking = waste of money
bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Automatic Dual Shot

review_content: I got this because I was going broke from spending $5/day on coffee from my favorite coffee place. It makes the perfect shots and my americanos taste even better than when my barista makes (made) them. I will say it's really hard to move the filter into place before starting the brew process, but for the price, I can't complain. The water tank holds a lot which I like, and the machine is easy to clean. I like the option of doing a single or double shot.
title: Great Espresso Machine for the price
bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Automatic Dual Shot

review_content:
After owning several espresso machines( including the Capresso Ultima), I purchased this one. Actually I purchased it at Target, because I had a gift card, but the price is the same, and delivery has always been good for me from Amazon.

I have owned this machine for almost a year, and I love it. This is only a 2 person household, but it gets constant use...at least 3 times daily, for multiple cups. Makes great crema, cappuccino, etc...and a just a great cup of coffee. Small footprint, so easy to fit in a small space with other applicances in a tiny kitchen. Very easy to clean, I know there are comments about leaking, but you do have to remember to empty the overflow reservoir, and otherwise, I don't have any other problems with that. I had at least 2 Capresso Ultimas that I had to return that had leaking problems from the water reservoir. I still have a regular drip coffeemaker, but we use that on occasions when we have company, and that was my incentive, because we were wasting a lot of coffee. Now I buy whole beans and make a cup at a time, since we both have different standards.

Anyway, just want to emphasize that this machine is very durable and delivers great results. I previously owned a little Mr. Coffee cheapie espresso maker (probably the original model) and that thing lasted forever. I have to admit that I don't use the steam wand, because I use a manual Bon Jour frother that is also great, but most of the time I drink the regular crema, and it is just as great as the more expensive models. Good value.
title: Great Inexpensive Espresso machine
bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Automatic Dual Shot

review_content:
I have been on the fence about buying a home machine for a very long time. I kept reading review after review and never took the plunge. I saw this model for $50 on sale at target so I figured what the heck. I think this is one of the best purchases I have ever made. My wife loves to go to starbucks a few times a week and spend $6 bucks a pop on a cup of coffee. This machine saves her the trouble and she raves that it makes a better cup than she usually gets at starbucks. It took about an hour of practicing when I first opened it to figure out how to get the most out of it, but it has been totally worth it.

It is important to read the instructions, otherwise you will be confused by the blinking lights and wonder why it wont brew your coffee. I was very suprised at how quickly this things heats up. You turn it on, the light blinks for about 30 seconds. press the brew button, the light blinks for about 10 seconds and then you are ready to brew your coffee. when that is complete, press the steam button, wait ten seconds and you are ready to start frothing. This thing is really quick and easy.

The only negatives about this are that it does not come with the little espresso cups pictured so you have to be carefull about how long you let the coffee brew, and that it does not come with a frother. I have made due so far by using a standard 2 cup pyrex cup and it works just fine. I will be purchaseing 2 little espresso cups and a 12 ounce frother once I get back to the store. Other than that, this thing works like a dream. It holds more than enough water in the tank to make many cups without refilling. It is a good idea to grind your own beans so that you can get them to the right consistency, it is also important that you fill the filter but dont compress it. If you do, it will drip espreso slowley and you will think the machine is broken. Overall, buy this machine. you will not be disapointed.
title: first espresso machine
bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Automatic Dual Shot

review_content:
Just got this machine today. Super excited. Just open the box and do all the "normal" things to make a regular coffee as a regular human beings........ guess what? It does not work!!!!! It keep making loud noise like a water pump!! My kid even got scared of this stupid crap machine

I want a exchange of the machine asap or my money money. I don't want to keep a bomb in our kitchen counter.

Thanks
title: The most stupid and laud machine ever used in my life
bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Espresso/Cappuccino Maker

review_content: I was purchasing a latte every morning....approx $5 per day.  I decided I needed to buy a latter maker and try it at home to save money.  I chose this unit because it was inexpensive, thinking if I can figure out how to make these successfully than I will get a more durable latte maker.  Well, let me tell you I have had this unit over 4 years.  I use it daily to make one cup on weekends I make some for the whole family.  This unit is still going strong.  In the 4 years I have ran the cleanign cycle in the unit itself twice and I clean the carafe, steamer and espresso holder daily, which takes about a minute or two. I highly recommend this machine....there is NO NEED to buy a more expensive one.
title: GREAT LATTE MAKER
bought_model: Color: CappuccinoStyle Name: 4-Cup Steam

review_content: I've had two over the course of 10 years and aside from the current handle design I love it.  Check out my hillbilly-asian mods in the picture!  The chopstick and the nail are for leverage on the horrible knobs and the paperclip is for reaming the frother.
title: Works but knobs need mods
bought_model: Color: CappuccinoStyle Name: 4-Cup Steam

review_content:
up date.....
after buying in january and almost daily use the thing gave up.(on a day of majoy test!!!!!!!!!!!!!!) so not even a year of use (jan - nov), i have re-placed it with the cusinart espresso maker(bought a 2 year replacement warenty too). wish me luck

--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

this is the 4th or 5th espresso maker i had.
no. 1 was a stove top barelli maker and it melted the handle
no. 2 was a steam non brand that exploded (not really)lasted about 7months
no. 3 was a delongi pump which i loved but then one day it just stoped working
no.4 was a hamalton beach pump 15 bar pressure. it did the job well but i gave up the ghost by way of the steamer.it lasted over a 1yr and 1/2.

now no 5. is mr coffee. i was reluctant to buy the mr coffee. i had read reviews in the past that mr coffee was cheep or poorly made. but with the mid range brands breaking every other year i thought i would try mr coffee. im really impressed with the quality of the brew, the crema, the steamer is just ok . (i would really recomend buying a shallow metal frother container, the regular ones you have to warm to much milk and get bad results, with the shallow you get great froth).i like the way that excess steam is drained to the drain pan, really good thinking mr coffee.

i found the controol a little for the first couple uses but now it is ok.
the coffee maker looks just as good as the more expensive modles i have gotten. i really hope this last at least 2 years...
title: mr coffee...i was so wrong
bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Automatic Dual Shot

review_content: Makes a really good latte and wonderful cappacino!  However, the frother seems to fizzle away and die after about 9 months.  This is my second machine.  However, Mr. Coffee stands by it's product and has replaced my Barista now for the second time.  I still consider it an awesome machine as I can whip up any type of drink I want ,including a hot milk chocolate with frothed milk. I can purchase Starbucks syrups and make a latte as good as theirs, or experiment with my own ideas.  I think you might be replacing this product every year, But don't dispare if you have issues with yours, call Mr. Coffee customer service and they will replace your broken machine (if within warranty time period).
title: Mr. Coffee stands by it's product
bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Espresso/Cappuccino Maker

review_content: I used to have a little Mr Coffee espresso machine that ran based on steam.  What I mean is I had to wait for the steam to build up before I could make coffee and this could take about 15 minutes.  With my new ECMP50 model that has changed.  I turn it on, and by the time I put the grounds in the filter it's ready to go.  The coffee comes out so much better with the added pressure of the pump that is built in to this one and the steam never loses pressure.  The water reservoir makes it really handy too since I don't have to be measuring water every time like I used to with my other machine.  One thing I would suggest to the manufacturer however is to include a separate tamper instead of the cheap plastic one that is part of the measuring spoon.  I purchased a separate one so I'm happy.  I did not think I could get coffee this good from a sub $100 machine but I now stand corrected.
title: Best purchase this holiday yet!
bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Automatic Dual Shot

review_content:
This espresso maker has been my favorite so far, in its size and workings, although it has a few peculiarities.

Before going on to other things, I would mention that it is now September, 2012, and I insert this paragraph. We bought this machine in February, 2011. It has become enough of a leaky fountain, squirting a steady stream of water from the frother while it expresses coffee, that we have decided to retire it. It didn't start out that way. It was good for about four cups per day for a year and a half. Maybe it can be repaired; not sure. We're back to using the Hamilton Beach machine, which leaks much less so far.

We like to have our cappuccinos twice a day, and we have been through a couple of steam pressured Mr. Coffees and a Hamilton Beach model with a pump. One immediate preference for us is to be able to make a good cup but not spend hundreds of dollars.

At first, we didn't relate to people's complaints about water leakage, but after about 14 months we repented. One possibility for leakage, of course, is removal and reinstallation of the tank. I tend to just fill the tank using a small pitcher, which I think is easier than moving the tank around. Leakage from the tank hasn't been an issue for me. Then, this machine ends its cycle by clearing its lines, as far as I can tell, and that pushes a fair amount of water into the catch tray. If you don't empty the tray periodically, it sometimes overflows and gets water on the counter. On the happy side, the catch tray gets washed a lot and doesn't get grungy. The third source of water after a year, though, came to be the steam spout. It would sputter away and drip quite a bit while the espresso was being made, and at other times, so we often put a wash cloth under it to catch the drops. It was a small bother that we could tolerate, at least while it wasn't too bad.

It seems as if every espresso maker has its own personality. When we got this one, it spewed quite a bit of steam up along the tube, inside the rubber tip, so it seemed as if the machine was getting steamed more than the coffee. I soon found that the metal tip under the rubber was not screwed into the end of the tube. I screwed it in, and that stopped the back rush of steam, but then the milk, which I was steaming directly in large mugs, tended to bubble up and overflow. After that, I used the steamer with the tip pretty much unscrewed but pushed close in position, allowing some steam backup but not having the milk bubble over. Like so many things, there is what the book says, and then there is the extra touch that you get to learn with experience.

The height of the steamer and the bay are nice for my use. I froth the milk directly in mugs, and I can let the mug rest on the edge of the stand and hang against the steam nozzle, building froth while I do other things during that short period until the milk just begins to boil. After a certain period, usually just about the time the milk in a mug starts to boil, the steam cycle shuts off. While this is fairly reliable, I have to keep an eye out so that the mugs don't boil over.

To froth a second mug, the previous frothing cycle normally has ended. One can wait for the lights to flash and the lines to clear, or it appears quite fine to shut off the machine, wait a moment, turn it back on, and get to the next frothing a little sooner.

Two particular things we have learned: Don't put an extremely fine grind into the basket, or it will block the brewing flow. Espresso grind is good. Also, when filling the basket, be careful about coffee getting under the rim, between the basket and its holder. Even a little of this can pack tightly and make it difficult to clamp the basket in place for brewing. If the clamping is difficult, check this and thereby avoid damaging things.

This espresso maker gives an excellent crema, as many have said.
title: Not perfect, but we liked it.  Not a long life, though.
bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Automatic Dual Shot

review_content: This machine is one of the best purchases of my life. It‚Äôs so easy and automated, but has enough that is customizable. I like that the machine will clean the milk frother tube so easily, and I love that you can put the container of milk right in the fridge! That was a genius way to design it. I use almond milk most of the time and it turns out so delicious!
title: GREAT purchase for someone looking for a straightforward process
bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Espresso/Cappuccino Maker

review_content:
I received my unit a while ago and, after getting used to fiddling with all the pieces and waiting for the "explosion" described in other posts, I am completely satisfied and somewhat disappointed (no explosion). I can see where other reviewers might be mislead into thinking the cord is very short but all you have to do is turn the machine over and actually look at the place where the cord is stashed to see there is a pretty lengthy cord wound around a very clever stem in a hidden compartment.

As for the quality:
I had been using a Hamilton Beach machine that is very different in operation so reviewing the instructions fully really was a must. Based on other comments, clearly most people don't read or follow the instructions because everything you need to know is there in black and white.

The brew function is very quick and only takes about 15-20 seconds to heat the water in the reservoir and start running hot water through the grounds. The whole process is very quick and you can fill the carafe with 4oz in less than a half minute. My other machine had a reservoir that you could leave full but this machine discourages that. I use a Brita filter for all my water so the chances of mineral buildup are reduced a little. Seeing how hot the reservoir gets, I would not recommend leaving water in the reservoir.

The carafe has a slotted lid so the spout from the filter fits neatly into the top of the carafe so there is no spilling or splash. The steamer arm is fixed with no allowed movement but it is spaced high enough and far enough out from the main body that using a pitcher or coffee cup to froth milk is very easy. The booklet goes into very specific detail about how to clean the froth arm but the pressure of the steam basically blasts the nozzle clean if you allow the unused water in the reservoir to exit through the froth arm when you are done making your foam. A barrista friend of mine steams a clean towel then uses that to clean the foam nozzle on her own machine. I find that works well between proper cleanings. One note is that Soy milk froths well but leaves a film from all the dissolved solids. If you use Soy milk, plan on cleaning the nozzle frequently as the particles get to be like glue if they are not wiped off shortly after being warmed.

As for which grounds to use, I have tried both standard grind and espresso grind coffees and you definitely need to find a finer ground of coffee for use in this (and any) espresso machine. I have a lot of Starbucks standard grind coffee to use up so I simply sent it through my Cuisinart for a few minutes to get it broken up finer. It seems to work equally as well but there is a noticeable difference in brewing strength.

Overall, I am very pleased.
title: A delicious expresso in less than 20 seconds!
bought_model: Color: CappuccinoStyle Name: 4-Cup Steam

review_content: I really wanted this to work! The first one I purchased, the milk frother  stopped working within two weeks. It gets boiling hot when steaming a single cup. It might not be the same with a larger frothing pitcher. I have noticed that using fine grind espresso can be a bit of an issue if you tamp it down too firm. The pump is not strong enough to push the brew water thru tightly tamped coffee. I just lightly tamp it and it's fine. The brew is as good as any I've had on other machines and the steamer works fine, so I am happy at this price.

Excellent for iced coffee and hot lattes.  When I don‚Äôt use all of the milk in the frother I just pull out the inner tube and store the container in the fridge.  Easy to use the next day. Its cute and nice for anyone that has no idea what an americano is suppose to taste like, def a half step up from folgers but for everyone else, look elsewhere.
title: little more than an expensive toy
bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Automatic Dual Shot

review_content:
If you are expecting to brew a nice cup of capuccino using this machine straight from the box, then you might be disappointed. You can, however, make some mediocre espresso or latte. Here is why:

Need to buy the following first, as these does not come with the product:

1. Tamper - you need to tamp coffee with 30 lbs of force to make good espresso. this will also help build the pressure for the frother to make microfoam (and not dishwasher foam) for your capuccino.

2. Milk thermometer - scalding the milk will just not work out

3. Frothing pitcher - least important of the three as you can improvise.

Another tip for foamy capuccinos: after brewing the espresso, turn the knob to the Off position and let stand for about 5 seconds. Slowly turn on to "Froth" to start frothing your milk. You can swirl the milk while frothing to dissipate the larger bubbles that ocasionally pop up, or knock the cup down on the counter. For people like me who is obsessed with getting creamy microfoam, this took some time to master. Industry practice tells you to put the tip of the frother just below the milk to get good froth, but the inconsistent pressure that this machine builds you sometimes have to put the tip all the way down to minimize the large bubbles (but by this time, I would have realized I did not tamp correctly or the coffee ground size is too big. However, good tamp and grind as there may be, this machine still churns out inconsistent (or weak) frothing pressure!)

Would recommend this as a "practice" gadget before moving on to the more expensive, indulgent pump espresso machines :)

Good luck! :)
title: Great machine, if you know how to use it!
bought_model: Color: CappuccinoStyle Name: 4-Cup Steam

review_content:
I purchased new one (Mr. Coffee ECMP1106 Cafe Barista Premium) from ebay about a month ago and enjoy cappuccino every day. I won't compare taste with one made from cafe. That coffee made by real barista with thousands of dollar cappuccino machine.

Making a cappuccino with Mr. Coffee Barista is pretty easy. Fill up coffee, push espresso button, and push cappuccino button. That's it.
No messy countertop. No forth milk.

However, I have to take out one star from the review.
It takes about a minute for ready making coffee after turning on the machine and another minute for ready froth milk. 1 minute warming up time for coffee is fine, but coffee gets little cold because of milk froth warming up.
Do I have a defected item from ebay? or Dose all cappuccino machine have same warming up time?
This is the first cappuccino machine that I have and there is no way to compare with other machines.

Overall, it's good product with this price. I may buy cappuccino from cafe from time to time for better taste and scent, but this machine will serve me good coffee everyday.

One thing.... you may not want to use it early in the morning. It's very laud.
title: Thanks Mr. Coffee! Free cappuccino everyday.

review_content: Just bought another one for my husband's office, he has to have his espresso. The one at home is about 6 months old and going strong, no problems. Simple to clean, froth stem works fine, looks nice on the counter, only takes a few minutes to make lovely espresso. Recommend.

Don't like this at all and went out of my way to share this with others.

review_content: Worked ok when I bought it. I purchased this 5 months ago and have used it lightly for pure espresso shots. The lights won't stop blinking at this point, even when I try to turn the machine off - the lights remain on and blinking. You can't select the coffee icon until the blinking stops, so it's trash now and Amazon won't assist since it's 'outside the return window' of 1 month. I say, invest elsewhere. Most of the pieces are plastic as well. What bothers me the most on this machine is that it doesn't auto stop per shot, the coffee keeps pouring out unless you shut it off. Shots should be measured by the machine.
title: Meh. Look elsewhere - stops working after a few months
bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Automatic Dual Shot

review_content: great for the price for a first time Espresso maker
title: Five Stars
bought_model: Color: CappuccinoStyle Name: 4-Cup Steam

review_content:
We bought this unit to make Espresso for our lady fingers, that we made, for our home-made Tiramisu. Yes, we paid $70+ to make espresso for that ONE dessert! I am, truly, a Tiramisu aficionado. :-D

That being said, this unit has NEVER let me down. The ONLY time we had an issue was when the water reservoir's outlet plunger got munged up with calcium deposits and the unit... as you'd expect... started leaking! Upon removing the deposits, the unit worked perfectly, as before! It has NEVER failed, in any way, since! We have had this unit since Feb. 2009, according to my wife. So, it's going on 3 yrs. of use (not day-in-day-out, but several times a week at least) with nary a hiccup, except once.

My only question is, if there is anyone here that can tell me how to get the absolute BEST performance out of this machine.

We use Brita (filtered) water.

I use a Black & Decker burr-mill grinder which I've modified to make a much nicer espresso grind (I don't use it to make any grind other than espresso).

If anyone knows what the BEST espresso tastes like (let's say that's a 10, on a scale of 1 to 10), where does the Espresso this unit makes come in at? A 5? Lower? Higher? Just curious.

If you take care of this unit and need an affordable 15 bar pressure pump Espresso maker... looks like this should fit the bill. Others seem to like it, too!

review_content:
First, the machine works great and offers an easy to make cup of coffee‚Ä¶I gave my Aeropress away. But there are some design features that aren‚Äôt so great.
1. The water reservoir cap is hard to remove‚Ä¶it need a knurled know instead of the smooth surface.
2. The plastic coffee basket holder to hold the basket to the handled dispenser is a joke and it came out the first time I used it and I just threw the plastic holder away.
3. The carafe tray is smooth and the carafe tends to easily move around‚Ä¶the tray needs a depression for the carafe to sit in, therefore keeping it from sliding.
4. The carafe lid is loose and moves around and falls out when pouring the coffee‚Ä¶a tighter design and non-turning lid would work.
5. An auto-off switch would be a nice feature, this way you won‚Äôt leave the thing on and have it overheat.

I‚Äôm sure that they have made hundreds of thousands of these machines and they are not about to change all the machining of the parts, but that having been said, the machine is a marvel and works great. I purchased an extra basket for when I have company.

review_content: Milk canister didn't "click" into place so it wouldn't click into the milk pump in the back or allow the brewing buttons to illuminate/activate. When looking from the side view, there was a visible bend upward on the front (C-shape of the machine was bent upward, wider than 90 degrees)...so I'm guessing the bend caused the milk canister not to align square. Even if we tried forcefully holding in the milk canister, the espresso pump worked but no milk pumped/steamed and the pump sounded like it was clicking on and off rather than pumping consistently. This was not an easy fix or something we could live with even for the lower prince of a Warehouse Deal item. Other reviews online have these same issues and there seems to be a common theme with this model: either you luck out and get a well manufactured machine or you get a lemon. If you purchase, save your receipt in case yours is the lemon. If you are buying this from Amazon Warehouse deals, beware because I can imagine the "lemons" are being returned and potentially resold through Warehouse Deals. I have never had issues with the Warehouse Deals and usually it works out, but not in this case. I ended up getting a different model at Wal Mart: Mr. Coffee Espresso Maker, BVMC-ECM270, no milk canister however, it's very consistent and easy to use so it's a good starter machine for us.

review_content:
There's not much I could say about the unit that has not already been said. The quality of the lattes, espressos and cappuccinos are excellent. I couldn't be happier with it in that respect.

However, I would strongly encourage you to be mindful of which seller you choose to purchase the product from. The first unit I purchased was packaged in a cardboard box with the unit in its original box. The original box had been slashed at one corner so that no scissors were even necessary to remove the unit. The tamper/measuring scoop were missing, and the whole thing was loosely packed in paper.

After taking it out and assembling it, it was very evident someone had used it and had neglected to clean it. Espresso grounds were still trapped in the brew head ‚Äì the metallic part to which the portafilter attaches ‚Äì and the steam wand reeked of sour milk when I went to clean it.

I am returning this item and have bought a new one. So far, I love it. I will periodically update as time goes by.
title: Excellent Product But Do Be Careful

review_content: I just received this yesterday so I cannot provide a seasoned review, but so far I'm in love! My husband and I just returned from a two week vacation in Europe and were dreading the mediocre espresso and cappuccino we get at home. The machine was really easy to set up - make sure to follow the directions - and in my opinion the first cappuccino I made was fabulous! I made one for my husband when he got home and he was shocked at how amazing it was. The frothing tube is a bit difficult to clean, but I can see that it totally makes a difference in the pressure of the steam and quality of the foam. After removing the black frothing tube cap I used a tooth pick to remove any residual milk/foam from the small opening in the frothing tube and I noticed the pressure was stronger on the next round. I'm hopeful this will last us a long time, but for the price it's worth enjoying it for as long as possible!
title: but so far I'm in love! My husband and I just returned from a ...
bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Automatic Dual Shot

review_content:
Have had this machine for 18 months now, and both my husband and I love the results. Fortunately I'm a reader of directions; you really need to study them carefully before you brew your first pot. It took half a dozen rounds of delicious experimentation to tweak the original instructions. Now I have the process down to a science, with detailed instructions posted next to the machine. In all these months, after many expensive comparisons, we have yet to taste a commercial cappuccino that tastes as good as ours.

I did order a steaming pitcher with the machine but found it much too small for our milk use. I have ended up using it just for depressurizing the machine, for which it's perfect. For my household, the best steaming pitcher is an ordinary one-pint glass measuring cup. And the best tamper turned out to be a flat-bottomed scoop from a can of protein-powder I had sitting around.

As other reviewers have pointed out, the quality of the coffee beans is critical. We buy the best organic espresso beans we can afford (Trader Joe's has a great blend) and grind them fresh each morning for that morning's two batches. We also use distilled water for the most flavorful coffee of any kind. I had read that caffeine reacts with the chlorine in tap water; it certainly makes a noticeable difference in taste.

Tip for a good foam: cold milk in a cold pitcher. At the start of preparations, I pour 1 1/3 cups cold almond milk in my 1-pint glass measuring cup and stick it in coldest spot of the refrigerator. The colder the pitcher, the thicker the foam. This morning, I had placed the pitcher right underneath the freezer motor and the milk had ice crystals on top. For the first time, the froth came out so dense and hard that it looked and behaved like whipped cream!

So far, this sounds like a five-star machine. Unfortunately, early on, it developed a problem that cost it one star. The screw at the end of the steam wand lost its thread and has to be carefully forced into place. Last weekend, it came loose at the end of the second round and the machine spewed steam all over the place. I had already steamed the milk to near-perfection, so nothing was lost. The depressurizing process was messy and noisy, and the screw had to be forced out the plastic shield with a sharp metal object. But this weekend I managed to get the screw back in place both mornings, and our cappuccino was better than ever. Not to gamble with our future weekend treats, I'm now ordering a spare machine, just in case. Fortunately the price is right!
title: Makes the best cuppa cappuccino in this town!
bought_model: Color: CappuccinoStyle Name: 4-Cup Steam

This is a very cheap product. The very first time I went to use it the handle snapped off of the part that you put the coffee in to be brewed. I was still able to use it, I just had to use a hot pad to remove it after brewing. I felt like I could never get the steamer wand clean enough and it always seemed to have some burnt mild on it.

If worked well enough for what we needed for a short amount of time and then we found a higher quality machine that I like better at this time.

review_content: This little guy has saved me SO much money! (Sorry Starbucks!) It makes delicious cappuccinos and lattes or just plain espresso. I prefer the latte setting and I use a pump of hazelnut syrup to sweeten it. Delicious! A few things: 1.) It's a little quirky - fill up the milk all the way every time. It's weird about getting that last inch of milk. I just keep the entire milk reservoir in the fridge. 2.) It's loud, if you get up when everyone else is still sleeping, it might wake them up. 3.) The scoop/tamper they give you is a joke, it's just flimsy plastic. Invest in a nice heavy tamper. Other than that I haven't had any major problems. Just use a good quality coffee, & make sure it's ground for espresso. Then kiss those $5 lattes goodbye.

title: Love this! Works great
bought_model: Color: CappuccinoStyle Name: 4-Cup Steam

review_content:
I had this machine for a couple of weeks, and it did not work from the very beginning. The pressure is not even close to the advertised 15 bar. It is so low that cannot push water through coffee. I experimented with different grinds size, and tried not to tamp coffee too tight, but i did not help. I only wasted several ounces of coffee beans. If you use a small filter, coffee comes out just for a couple of seconds, and after that it just drips slowly while the pump is still working. When you use a two-shot filter, water only drips slowly or is not coming through at all. Just FYI, I used only distilled water, and usde it only 5 or 6 times, so there could not be a problem with limescale.
I called the manufacturer and explained the problem. They asked me to give them the serial number printed on a sticker located at the bottom for the machine. I had to remove the water tank and overturn the machine to read it, but it was hard because it is printed in a small font. They suggested that I replace the item. But after reading reviews that mention the same problem (weak pump), I am not even trying to play a lottery by replacing it because it may stop working any time. It looks like this machine has an inherent engineering flaw, and the manufacturer must know about it. However, they continue selling this faulty product. Returning it now. I washed filters and wiped out fingerprints, and nicely packaged the machine (it took me about an hour). It now looks like brand new, and some of you who did not believe bad reviews and decided to play this lottery is going to get it soon. I have to add, it was very nice of Amazon to issue a free return after I called them.
P.S.
I bought this machine for $125, now I see it's about $200 (probably, because it's about Christmas time). Don't waste your money, especially if this is supposed to be a gift. You have been warned.
title: Waste of money, time and coffee
bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Espresso/Cappuccino Maker

review_content:
I've only have it out of the box for about a month, thus far 110% satisfied. I read many of the reviews that claimed leaking or that they didn't like the tamper, whaa. It is used 4 times daily and has yet to do anything other then work perfectly. It always handles 4 shots at once, however it will not set any speed records. It takes up very little space on the counter. It is simple and easy to use. As a guy, reading directions is not a big part of things. Even still, it's pretty hard to screw up. The first few times I used it I had some variety in results, but due to getting the perfect grind and tamping and not due to a defect in the machine. The steam powers through my finely ground beans with no problem, and the tamper is just fine. Same with the steamer, it works great. I bought five of these in 2010, four as Christmas gifts and one for myself. Never got a chance to use it as I was soon back overseas. When I came to do this review, I actually thought I had paid $79.95 for it, only to find it was only $39.95. As good as it works, I would have been happy either way.

Update; 12/14/12 It's been nearly 7 months since I posted my review. Happy to say after around 600 uses it is still going strong, even though there have been days where I have ran 10 four shot lattes through it.

Important: make sure you release the pressure as soon as your done(best to just release any steam left over through the wand) I love mine.
title: Deserves 5 stars, very capable machine
bought_model: Color: CappuccinoStyle Name: 4-Cup Steam

review_content: When Momma is happy, everyone is happy.  This makes Momma happy
title: Five Stars
bought_model: Color: CappuccinoStyle Name: 4-Cup Steam

review_content:
This machine is amazing, does it all with a push of a button! Making expensive coffee shop drinks at home for a fraction of the cost. Regret not buying something like this a long time ago!

Update: 11/30/13 - As we used this item more, (my wife and I) it has proven to be possibly just a faulty machine we received as the porta filter area drips about 6 drops of water if the espresso isn't in the porta filter section. Also, the o-ring for the milk cartridge after a month also makes a leaky squeaky noise. I would like to mention Mr Coffee had excellent customer support and sent me a new unit, BUT all the leaking should have not been doing tins after only 2-4 weeks of ownership. Again, I would purchase this item only new for warranty coverage or buy from bed bath and beyond and exchange it forever if it does fail which is possible as long as I didn't just get a faulty machine. But works great and makes great drinks so we still would buy again just warning to make sure buyers spend the extra change and get a brand new warrantied model like we did.

I dropped my 5 star rating to 4 just because $200 brand new machine should not have issues like that but appreciate the customer service and replacement, although somewhat of an unnecessary hassle.
title: Better late than never! UPDATED! 11/30/13

review_content:

bought_model: Color: CappuccinoStyle Name: 4-Cup Steam

review_content:
My husband bought this one for me for Christmas and I've been cursing at it since. The cord is frighteningly short. I can barely plug it in with it flush against the back wall of the counter.

The coffee filter basket has a different insertion style with those I've used previously. You insert it on the left-hand side of the machine and slide the handle to the middle. This is contrary to most machines where the insertion point is in the middle and you slide it to the right. This is awkward and I've ended up spilling coffee all over my counter if it does not insert correctly. Once, it was not seated in the slot correctly and spewed coffee grounds and watery coffee all over my counter.

The frother does not work as instructed. I found that if you waited until the coffee was 3/4 brewed and then frothed, it would give you better results. Also, that plastic thing on the frother did not improve the function, so that got taken off.

The top of the caraffe falls off when you try to pour out the coffee. The knobs are not conducive to trying to take it off with that half-concious effort that most of us have in the morning.

My recommendation for an espresso machine would be a Melita (one without the pods). They steam and froth well and are well-designed.

** ETA: After using this maker for a year, I still think there are issues with it. The cord issue is fixed, thanks to another reviewer. There is more cord stored underneath. But the basket handle sticks out 6" from the front of the machine. Whenever I work on something on that part of the counter, I have to turn the machine 90 degrees. The frother still doesn't work right, and the coffee pot was broken 6 months ago. I use a coffee cup instead. The rounded knobs are also hard to turn when you are 3/4 asleep.

review_content:
We bought this machine a few days ago as a treat for ourselves. $28 (on sale) at Target!!! I wasn't expecting much, but thus far it's great! I drink cappuccinos & my husband likes espresso. He said the espresso is good and the frother works great! Some reviewers said their frother didn't work - well it's not in the directions, but you need WATER IN THE RESERVOIR TO STEAM THE MILK. Obvious...but it's not printed in the directions. And you can't brew & froth at the same time, so if you froth the milk after you brew, you have to turn off the machine, add a bit of water, then froth the milk.
It'd be nice to be able to brew & froth at the same time, but for $28 what do you expect? Also there is no burner under the caraffe, so you have to drink the espresso right away or it gets cold.
I don't see the need for a tamper (the plastic one included is fine), and I use a coffee mug to froth the milk in. It's not ideal, but it works! If you're spending a lot of $$ on lattes or espresso in a coffee shop, this machine will be great for you! I love not having to go out for a fancy coffee!
title: If You're Buying Espresso/Cappuccino at a Coffee Shop - Buy This!
bought_model: Color: CappuccinoStyle Name: 4-Cup Steam

review_content:
I purchased this machine because of all the great reviews here on Amazon. But, while I do really like the coffee that it makes most of the time, the plastic smell is very strong in the steam that comes out while brewing, in the water reservoir and the plastic tube in the milk reservoir when they are wet. Also twice (and only after making multiple cups, (one right after the other), the 3rd cup tasted like plastic. I was really liking this machine for the froth and the customizing option but I cannot get over the taste. The smell, not so much, after all, it is made out of alot of plastic so I suppose when heated up you are going smell it, especially when new. That might go away. I did write the manufacturer to get their response and would appreciate your comments too, but it looks like this is going back to Bed, Bath and Beyond.
Update: The company did write me back to run vinegar thru, I did several times, it did not work. Returned item.
title: Am I the only one concerned about the plastic smell?
bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Espresso/Cappuccino Maker

review_content:
This is a poorman version of a semi-auto espresso maker but a very very crappy one at best. It doesn't do any one thing well. If you are looking at this unit to save time, then be warned it will NOT save you anytime over manual espresso makers. Because of the poor design, it requires A LOT OF CLEAN UP after each use and there is no way around it.

1) one button espresso shot maker - I can never get an equal shot out of this machine, it's either over or under, never consistent amount of espresso. This is especially true when you use the latte or cappuccino button, you can tell sometimes it just stop the espresso shot when the shot just started.
2) milk frother - not really a frother, more of a bubble maker and it splatters milk droplets all over the places because of the fast and violent high temperature boil it does to the milk. Because of the unit is black, it's very easy to see the milk droplet splatter after every use. Your drink will have hot milk, espresso, and milk bubbles - no milk microfoam whatsoever.
3) milk container is poorly designed - as several reviewers said, it requires a lot of force to insert the container or remover it, you can actually splash milk out of it during insertion or removal because the energy required to insert or remove the container. Because you will need to store the milk container in the frig, there is no getting around of not removing the container after each use. Also, there is a sensor that detects the milk container and it will would not let you start a drink until it thinks the milk container is properly seated. The sensor seems to be effected by temperature. After the milk frothing process starts and the mechanism is heated up a bit, my unit would randomly sudden-stop the frothing process as if the milk container was removed or loose, even though it is pushed back as far as possible and perfectly seated. This would require removal and reinsert the milk container to reset the fault condition before unit will allow you to restart a drink.
4) milk pick up tube problem - the tube pick up design has problem dealing with the changing vacuum force needed to draw the milk to the frother. When the milk container is full, it has no issue pulling the milk but as the milk level gets lower and lower, the tube struggles to draw enough milk. In my experience, when the milk container is about 1/3 or 1/2 full, the latte or cappuccino created will not have enough milk, or become extremely inconsistent. In those cases, you will have even more milk bubble as less milk gets the high temperature boil, creating an even bigger mess.

I think the idea of this machine is to partly automate the creation of an espresso drink. Since it doesn't grind the coffee, the only thing it automates is the milk frothing. However, the milk frother and related mechanism are so riddled with design flaws, the process is anything but consistent and require a lot of clean up after each use.

I actually clocked myself, factor in clean up time, it actually takes less time to make a latte or cappuccino using a less expensive manual espresso maker with a standard build-in frother.

review_content:
As one of the early reviewer, I bought this machine from Bed Bath & Beyond with 20% off coupon.
I have used it for a week now and invited a friend, who is frequent Starbucks customer, to taste the machine made cappuccino. I ground the coffee beans and made it with 2% fat milk. She said it was better than the one she bought from the shops. Discounting the politeness factor of my friend's comments, I think the machine made coffee is comparable to the shop made ones.

The unit is easy to clean and I have not seen water leaking problem reported by one of the reviewers.

Update:
After a month, the machine can no longer suck the milk, we cannot make Latte or Cappuccino. We can still get Espresso. Fortunately, Bed Bath & Beyond allowed me to return the unit. I wish the machine could have lasted longer than that. I reduced the star from 5 to 3. Two stars are for their design concept, the other star is for still working Espresso.

title: Not for Italians
bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Espresso/Cappuccino Maker

review_content:
11 months ago, when I read the review of this product, I concluded that it was a great bargain that was likely to be defective when I received it or to fail a short time later. I trusted that the 12 month warranty would be protect me in that case, but I wondered if it would be worth the hassle if I had to use it.

Fast forward: I really like the product. I brewed probably 300 cups of espresso and it worked well. Then it blew a gasket. When I called Jarden, who now owns the Mr. Coffee Brand, the customer service rep assured me that the product was manufactured at least 3 years ago and was therefore not in warranty. He had no interest in my purchase receipt, dated 11 months early. When I refused the steam expresso machine that he offered me as a "one time courtesy" and because the comparable unit was "not in stock" I went to the Mr. Coffee website and confirmed that it was indeed in stock, for purchase. When I refused the replacement and insisted that because I had purchased the unit less than a year ago, that the company should honor the warranty. The response was that the unit was not in stock, and they encouraged me to check back with them in 4-6 weeks.

I'm sure many people give up at this point and the customer service objective of not paying warranty claim or paying them at a much reduced price is realized. I bought the product and the warranty. I didn't realize until I needed it that the warranty was not actually included. When I asked for it, I was told that I didn't really buy it. Interesting! I'm probably powerless to enforce the warranty. It's certainly not worth any more of my time to try. But I can avoid buying another Mr. Coffee device and I can tell many, many people about my experience.

Caveat Emptor.
title: Lying is an interesting customer service strategy
bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Automatic Dual Shot

review_content:
I'm a barista by profession, and I wanted something to make espresso at home so I didn't blow my entire paycheck on trips to work on my off days. Now, to be clear, I know enough about how espresso machines work to know where to keep my expectations when buying a $40 steam espresso maker (when at work we use a professional machine that cost more than some new cars). That being said, this someone managed to fall short of even my lowest expectations...

It arrived last night and I excitedly put it on a 2-shot test run (yes, after reading the manual carefully). The very first thing I noticed was that a good deal of steam was escaping from the screw top. I had read similar reviews of this happened and ensured that the lid was screwed on tight, but thought maybe it wasn't tight enough. The machine is obviously slower than what I'm used to at work, but for what it was, it didn't take *too* long to pull a double shot.

This morning I decided to put it to the test and pulled 4 shots- the max the little carafe (which feels about as fragile as an eggshell) can hold. I did everything the same, triple checking this time that the cap was screwed on tight this time. Not only did it take 15 (yes, fif-teen) minutes to both steam my milk and pull the 4 shots, but it started leaking and cracking on top of it! Even more steam was spitting out the top, and through a newly formed crack where the top of the machine is literally pulling up from the body. I noticed a great deal of condensation around the shot pulling mechanism (triple checked this was fully locked in place) and the "backsplash" of the machine. When I checked though, it wasn't even leaking from the shot bit, but condensation was forming out by the screws that keep it all held in place.

tl;dr- There's a reason this machine cost $40. It is so incredibly cheaply made that it would be laughable if I didn't honestly feel that it was potentially dangerous. Haven't even had it for 24 hours and already going to return it because it's ALREADY falling apart. To add insult to injury, the shots taste like burnt dirt. I fully admit this could be in part due to my own inability to properly grind/tamp espresso manually, but any shot that takes 15 minutes to pull is going to be exposed to heat for too long and taste burnt.

Don't buy this product. For the same price, you can buy a Bialetti stovetop pot and get closer to espresso than this hot dirt water...
title: Cheap Hunk O' Junk
bought_model: Color: CappuccinoStyle Name: 4-Cup Steam

review_content:
The fact that you're reading this review means that you're looking for an espresso machine (yeah, I know - duh). The fact that you're looking for an espresso machine means that you probably want either the convenience of making fun little coffee drinks at home, and/or you want to save money because you've been spending a significant portion of your disposable income on similar concoctions at the overpriced coffee house down the street. To which concern I can most assuredly relate - we have the misfortune to live half a block from what is arguably the best coffee shop in Seattle, and I don't even want to think how much of the owner's retirement fund has come out of my pocket. Good thing he's a friend.

So anyway, here you are on Amazon, trying to filter - ha ha, please note clever pun - through the endless product choices, which range from cheapo plastic crap to espresso machines so expensive and complicated that you wonder if you'll need a degree in engineering to operate them. Your head is getting ready to explode as you read about things like burr grinders, with some Amazonians subtly implying that if you don't use one of these for your home-roasted gourmet coffee beans - the ones you import weekly on a private jet from an exclusive estate in the Ethiopian Highlands - then your intellect must compare unfavorably with that of certain lower primates. And then there are the reviews that provide detailed instructions regarding this or that machine's temperamental foibles and intolerance of idiots, advising you sternly that if you don't do X, Y and Z in a very particular order, accompanied by ritual chanting and animal sacrifice, your $2000 espresso machine will never perform in the optimal way.

Or so it sure seems sometimes.

So here's the key question: WHY do you want an espresso machine? Do you truly want to become an espresso master, the envy and talk of all your Yuppie friends ("Wow, Bob has a Lockheed-Martin X-320 Parisian-Bistro-Espresso Cafe Super-System with built-in burr grinder and rocket launch module, and he sure knows how to use it!") Or do you just want a machine that costs (way) under a thousand bucks that'll make a tasty latt√© or cappuccino in the morning, and in so doing save you from supporting your local coffee shop owner's boat payments?

If it's the latter, then I humbly recommend this fine little machine. It's easy to set up, and if one uses decent ground espresso (for the record, I use Lavazza) it makes excellent coffee drinks with a minimum of fuss. You don't need to fiddle with frothing yourself - just hit the right buttons and it will turn out coffee that will have you saying "Mmm, that's good!" before you proceed with your day. Unless, of course, you're a coffee snob who wouldn't dream of using anything smacking of "automatic" that doesn't involve multiple complex steps, a $300 grinder, manual frothing, a degree in engineering and animal sacrifices. But then if you're that person you're probably not looking at this machine.

Put the machine through a clean cycle regularly, and DO delime it at least once in a while. It's a tedious procedure but not doing so may affect performance (we had some issues a few months in and deliming fixed them).

Do follow the setup instructions carefully, especially with regard to priming the machine the first time. And don't do what I did, which is to wonder why nothing was happening - specifically, why no water was coming out - and then finally notice the sticker on the back of the water tank that said "Remove plastic plug before use".

Duh.

UPDATE, JUNE 2014: A year after we bought this, using it every day, it has started to exhibit issues with the frothing. Despite deliming, it is having a harder time getting up to pressure and producing froth. It still works, but doesn't froth as easily and I have to usually run it a couple of times to get the volume we had a year ago. This machine has nonetheless saved us a ton of money over the past year and I'd still recommend it (and perhaps buy another when this one finally dies).

As some others have noted, the reservoir sometimes leaks water. My stupid but effective solution to this was to insert a strip of thin cardboard (part of the flap of a small cardboard box works) between the machine and the reservoir (i.e. behind the reservoir). Apparently this "pushes" the reservoir back enough to set it right, and it fixed the issue.
title: Great little machine... not sure about durability (see update at end)
bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Espresso/Cappuccino Maker

review_content:
Love this machine and it's not as complicated as other reviews say. Taking off a star because I'm on my second machine in under a year, but it's still cheaper than if I buy a Starbuck's latte every day. I used the Mr. Coffee steam espresso machine for several years and it's nice to be able to push a button and walk away for a moment. For those who want to make coffee every day with this machine, here is how I make Starbucks-like mochas and lattes without all the fuss mentioned in some of the other posts.

Easiest way to keep your machine clean is to use distilled water. Run distilled water through both coffee and milk areas to clean after use.

I get Starbucks Espresso coffee ground for espresso. I recommend that you buy only a little at a time, like 1/2 pound or 1 pound to make sure it's fresh. Keep the coffee out of the light (in a cupboard) and don't refrigerate it. I pick it up at the Starbucks drive-thru. The plastic tamper works is fine for a great tasting coffee. The barista's at local coffeehouses do not use a plastic tamper and some advocate not tamping at all. The grounds shouldn't be too packed.

I bought a 28-30 oz Turkish coffee stainless steel pot to hold my drink while it's brewing. Be sure to order one that is the right size, mine is 30 oz, bought on Amazon.

Turn on the machine a few minutes before you start making your drink to give it time to heat up. I like to make two lattes, one that I drink right away and one that I save for an hour later that I keep in an insulated Thermos cup that stays hot for hours. If you put your drink in a thermos (for hot drinks), it will actually get hotter.

To make sure the milk container is in all the way, press it in at the top and the bottom. Bottom should align with arrow, but don't just focus on bottom, top needs to be pushed in too.

After you've made your drink, remember to put the milk container in the refrigerator and return the dial to the left (after cleaning) to your coffee preference.

Starbuck's will sell syrups by the bottle, I get Vanilla or Caramel. For mocha's, you can get a chocolate syrup or hot chocolate mix at the grocery store (I buy a fancy hot chocolate powder like Silly Cow Farms Chocolate Chocolate) and put some in the bottom of the cup and stir it as you pour the coffee into your cup. Use syrups and powders to taste, start with a little first. I also like to mix the Caramel syrup with a teaspoon of chocolate powder for a turtle latte.
title: Simple Tips from someone who is not a barista
bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Espresso/Cappuccino Maker

review_content: We LOVE our Cafe Barista . . . which is why after 4 months of owning this fantastic machine we are disappointed the frothing component on the machine has stopped properly working.  We make coffee every day with this coffee maker so if is heavily used, but still . . . 4 months for nearly $200 is a pretty hardy expense.  We are currently in the process of communicating with Mr. Coffee to seek resolution.  Bummed this has happened.  It is so awesome to have your own lattes at home anytime you want!
title: Great Machine . . . Short Life
bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Espresso/Cappuccino Maker

review_content:
-- I have used this every day for two years - still going strong
-- Creamer attachment was a pain to clean - now I just heat up milk in the microwave in a mug and combine it with the espresso from this machine
-- I use a combination of 2/3 Cafe Bustelo espresso and 1/3 Lavazza espresso in the machine for the perfect-tasting cup of espresso.
-- Take the coffee grounds out of the unit immediately, and empty the water dispenser immediately after use. If you leave them on the unit all day, your next cup of espresso tastes weird. (I buy wax paper to dispose of the coffee grounds in an environmentally sensitive, and easy-to-clean way.)
-- The espresso tastes funny after about 3 weeks. The funny taste means it's time to run vinegar-water through the unit as if I was making espresso (without the coffee grounds, of course) for about 5 cycles, and then clear water through the unit, again, as if I were making espresso, for about 5 cycles. After that, your coffee tastes great again.
This machine has saved me hundreds of dollars over going to a coffee shop, and I frankly like my soy latte from this machine (combined with the heated soymilk from the microwave) better than what the big-name coffee shop makes anyway.
title: WONDERFUL FOR THE PRICE; BUT DOES TAKE MAINTENANCE
bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Espresso/Cappuccino Maker

review_content:
Although ours was given to us as a wedding gift, I still would like to review this on amazon as most go here for reviews. I've used several espresso makers over the years and so I'm pretty picky on features and how I like them or not. Mr. Coffee has made a quality espresso, this machine has been running strong for almost two years now.

Pros:
-Programmed settings that are a simple one button push
-Milk reservoir works well and you can easily adjust the amount of froth or milk you want
-Not messy at all, has a nice catch for drips after a cup is removed.
-A lot quieter than steam machines (probably because of the pump)
-So far hasn't hiccuped once, running strong

Cons:
-The handle that holds the grounds worked lose, ended up using lock-tight on the screw to keep it from happening again
-I wish there was a setting to keep pumping hot water until you tell it to stop (all settings are automatically timed on this machine)
-Not enough clearance for tall coffee cups or mugs (I use a large measuring cup and then pour into my thermos)
-Really wish there was just a hot water setting or spout somewhere for the times you want tea
-Takes a lot longer to warm up than other models I've used.
title: Excellent Espresso, glad we own it!
bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Espresso/Cappuccino Maker

review_content:
I received this item as a Christmas gift. I love coffee, Starbucks, and Alton Brown, so when I added the phrase "an espresso machine might be fun" to my Christmas list, I had a more manual machine in mind. The automatic controls and frothing "compartment" had me thinking "Keurig" not "hand-crafted espresso" like I was hoping for. (Entitled thinking, I know... but it was a Christmas wish list, after all, and this is an honest review. So out with the confessions! lol)

After a very careful unboxing (it's quite tedious), I took some time to read the instructions before diving in. I completed the priming, which is similar to priming a Keurig. I used Cafe Bustelo pre-ground espresso coffee and half-and-half creamer for my first few cups.

It comes with a coffee scoop, but I've found that it's a bit of a liberal measure for the metal filter. Go just shy of an entire scoop, then tamp it down. I didn't bother with a scale (forgive me A.B.!), I just used the weight of my shoulder straight down onto the grounds, tamping in between scoops for the double shot filter. Watch the coffee / espresso episode of Good Eats to get a great tutorial on how to do this. It might be worthwhile to invest in a tamper if you use this every day, as the one that comes with it is a bit flimsy, and feels like it will break if used at the wrong angle. The filter was very tight to lock in place, but from some of the Q&A's I've read, it appears that reducing the amount of grounds will make it a bit easier. (Hence my comment about the measuring scoop.)

I usually like the feel of a large mug in the morning, so all my coffee mugs are big. If you're like me, you're going to struggle a bit to get your mugs under the machine spout. It takes a bit of finagling. And some of my mugs simply don't fit. So choose your mugs carefully. The slide out lifter for demitasse cups is nice, and you can always brew your espresso shot into a rocks glass and transfer into a coffee mug, but that's a lot of work.

Using this method, I brewed several shots of espresso. Every shot came out consistent, rich, and tasty. Each had an impressive amount of crema (that frothy-brown-coffee part at the top of your espresso). No grounds in the cup, and all grounds seemed to have been "used" during brewing. Smooth espresso taste. Very pleasing.

As for the milk frother: In the beginning, I frothed the milk into a separate cup and poured it into my espresso for cappuccinos and lattes. I'm EXTREMELY impressed with the quality of foam, temperature of the milk, and flexibility of the ratio (milk-to-foam). Using the separate-cup method even gives me the option to try for those pretty designs the baristas do at my local coffee shops.

Cleaning was a big concern for me as well. That milk compartment looked a bit sketchy. However, I've found a cleaning regimen that seems to work well for me: 1) Clean before first morning use; 2) Make my morning coffee; 3) Clean after last cup of coffee; 4) Put entire container back in fridge. I probably won't let it go more than a few days without cleaning the entire thing in the sink. The instruction manual says that the milk frother and lid (!) are dishwasher safe, but I'm skeptical about that. I'm erring on the side of caution and simply washing it in the sink.

Overall, I'd say this is a great start for anyone wanting to venture beyond their Keurig or drip coffee maker and explore espresso at home. I'll try this for a while, and perhaps graduate up to something a bit more sophisticated later.
title: For So Much Automation, I Was Pleasantly Surprised

Then the control knob came off and can no longer be used to switch the machine between Off and Brew or Steam. Up until then I was very happy with it!

A few months in, the metal steamer was very loose - not sure how it's connected to the water tank, or if that played a part in the machine breaking.

In short, don't expect it to last for very long, and repairing it (even in warranty) seems like more effort than getting a new one.

title: Sorry Starbucks-We just broke up
bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Espresso/Cappuccino Maker

review_content:
I've had several espresso machines: I moved up from a Krups steam machine to a very expensive pump machine that only lasted a few years and then tried this one for a price in the middle.

PROS: It makes espresso that tastes just as good as any of those machines. (I buy good coffee beans, grind them with a burr grinder, tamp the grounds to the right pressure, and use filtered tap water. If you're not getting good espresso with this machine, buy better coffee or water, and practice your technique.)

CONS:
1. Clean the steaming wand frequently.

When I make cappuccino or latte, I usually have to clean the wand very thoroughly before I get enough steam pressure. Maybe it's because I have hard water and don't clean the machine often enough with vinegar--your mileage may vary.

This doesn't bother me because I drink espresso every morning so I don't use the steaming wand very often--usually only when guests want something else.

2. It only lasts two years.

Two years ago, after having the machine almost exactly two years, the machine stopped working. I shopped the local stores, looked at the online reviews, and I couldn't find another machine under $200 that might beat it.

Last week, the same thing happened--again, almost exactly two years after I bought it. I shopped again to see if something new and better is available. I don't think so.

At this price, I can afford to order another one of the same. An $80 machine that lasts two years is costing me about $0.75 per week. I certainly save that by drinking coffee at home--and the espresso I make on this machine is better than anything I get at SixBucks or any other coffee shop near my house.
title: GREAT espresso.  I'm buying my third because the machine breaks after only two years.
bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Automatic Dual Shot

review_content: Read the previous reviews, figured since Mr. Coffee stood behind some of the issues some buyers had, we'd try this since it was 1/2 off on sale.  I have to admit the frothier works REALLY well.  Was rather surprised how well.  I used to have to hand froth with my old unit whereas this is automatic.  We're still getting used to it, having only made 8 Caps and Lattes so far, but seems better than expected, especially for the price.  Will update as needed.
title: So far....
bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Espresso/Cappuccino Maker

review_content:
We purchased this to replace a beloved De Longhi, which began leaking after a decade of use. This machine does not seem to be as solidly built as the De Longhi, which in addition to being cheaper, also produced a creamier espresso. That said, this machine DOES make very decent espresso, and the convenience of having it shoot frothed milk into your cup is unbeatable. The presets (1 shot, double shot, cappuccino, latte) are great, but I love the versatility of being able to control how many shots of coffee and how much milk you pour into your cup if you want a more customized drink. The kids use the milk frother to prepare hot chocolate.
We have been using this machine multiple times per day for a little over a year, and have not had any issues.
title: Going strong after more than a 1 year of use
bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Espresso/Cappuccino Maker

review_content: I would give it 3.5 stars if I could.  The reason is because the portafilter- the thing you put the coffee in and twist on, has never twisted all the way on.  You are supposed to twist it from the far left to the middle of the machine like you see in the picture.  I can't move mine more than 50 degrees because it is incredibly hard to twist.  It barely fits on and the machine is so light, there is absolutely no leverage.  It's a hassle.  But I love the flavor of the coffee.  And I have trouble with my frother working sometimes.  I have to turn the entire machine all the way off and on again, sometimes several times before the frother/steamer works.  You will hear it pump, but the steam does't come on. I clean it each and every time and have plenty of water in the machine, so I'm not sure why it is temperamental.  I have used almond milk just fine in the frother.  I would recommend getting a pitcher to steam your milk that is not too large because the tip of the wand doesn't reach very far down.  And don't get one very small because the volume doubles.
title: Great coffee but some problems
bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Automatic Dual Shot

review_content: I hesitated to order this when I saw the reviews, but now it's clear that most low ratings were from purchasers who expected too much from a bargain-priced machine or clearly did not read the instruction manual before operating it. I actually think it is quite user friendly and easy to operate after spending a little time reading the instructions. The handle did feel tight at first, as mentioned it might in the manual,  but has gradually loosened up. It's important to clean the steamer after each use, which is easy enough. I just let the pressure release through the steamer after unplugging the machine and then wipe it with a mild cleaning detergent. Anyway, I love this thing! Highly recommend for first time espresso machine buyers or cheap folk like me.
title: I actually think it is quite user friendly and easy to operate after spending a little time reading the ...

review_content:
I've bought refurbished items from the Amazon Warehouse before with good luck. This machine is a steal for the price I paid for it, even though it is an older model by now. I am only on my first few attempts making espressos and cappuccinos but so far so good. They will continue to get better as I improve my grind and learn to tamp the grounds properly. I have a feeling that with the proper maintenance, this device will last me a good while.

But...someone definitely purchased and returned this just for the double shot filter. The machine and scoop were still wrapped and taped from the factory, but the brew head attachment looked like it had been unwrapped, and there was only the single shot filter inside. Whoever did this, I don't like you.

The double shot filter for this machine is not available anywhere, not even the Mr. Coffee website. Seeing as though this device is marked as "Best Seller" when searching for espresso machines, I think it would be worthwhile for Mr. Coffee to stamp out 10k of these, both for replacements and for people like me. If there was an issue with the filters, fix it and then get some made, because I bet there are people that want them. But I digress. It is an inconvenience, but I won't stop me from using the machine. I don't mind swapping out the beans to get two or more shots.

I regret giving them a chance before returning it, I cleaned it multiple times and used it thinking the bad taste of both the espresso and the steamer would leave, but now I am stuck with the machine.

title: ... to set up the coffee marker and to my disappointment I find that the machine has been used and ...

review_content:
This Mr. Coffee machine provided my first experience with a specialty coffeemaker.

I rarely order anything other than breves from coffee shops. My husband sticks with mocha lattes from the shops, but he is an aficionado of coffee, always interested in new ways to grind and brew coffee at home.

We have fiddled with this new-to-us type of machine long enough now to have figured it out for the most part.

I always start with cream in my cup before brewing, adding milk or cream from the frother after brewing.
I top it with a sprinkle of nutmeg or cinnamon sugar.
The result is comparable to coffee shop breves, but the foam is never quite as tight.
Milk froths better than cream, but no type of dairy product keeps its frothiness for long using this machine.
Foaming is not its star attribute.

The metal pitcher that came with our machine is useless for frothing. You need a much smaller container, preferably glass, in order to see what you are doing. The container needs to be small and narrow enough for the arm to reach to the bottom. The longer you froth, the hotter the milk becomes, but you can froth till the cows come home and never get a tight foam.

Plain espresso shots are easiest to make, and they turn out quite well, depending on the quality and type of beans used.
The finer the grind, the stronger and tastier the drink.
You should always use a fine grind when using this type of machine.
Using this machine, a shot of espresso comes out with a nice layer of foamy coffee on top.
The cute little espresso cup that came with our machine is perfect for this.

I did some research to determine what makes espresso different from other coffee drinks and was surprised to learn that ALL specialty coffees begin with espresso.
The addition of steamed and foamed milk makes a cappuccino, more steam and less foam make a latte, cream turns it into a breve, the addition of chocolate adds ‚Äúmocha‚Äù to the name, and so on.
The variety is endless, but it always starts with a shot of espresso.

We have found that it is best just to pull the plug between making each drink.
Don't bother to turn the machine off first.

Be sure to clean the area where the handled filter cup attaches to the machine, as well as the filter itself.
This assures a good seal.

Clean your machine after you use it each day. It's not that much trouble, and it will keep your machine in good working order.

I would say that this is a fine first espresso maker, but if you are accustomed to using them, you would want something more advanced.
This is the ‚Äútraining-wheel bike‚Äù version of espresso machines.
If you are a ten-speed biker of brew, this machine would likely seem laughable.
title: Great as a starter machine.
bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Caf√© Steam

review_content:
Like most who purchased this product, it was my first espresso maker. And I found out quickly that hunting for these things can be overwhelming! I purchased it at my local Target for $79.99 for convenience in case I had to return it -- with all of the mixed reviews out there, I was incredibly weary of choosing one! However, I will most likely not need to do so. It is perfect for all of my needs!

PROS:
1. Incredibly easy to use! Directions and trouble-shooting pages in manual are simple and helpful.
2. Compact size, looks nice sitting on the counter.
3. Easy clean-up. All parts that need to be cleaned detach easily.
4. A standard sized coffee cup will fit under the spout -- not so with many models!
5. The steam feature is simple, fairly powerful, and works well. No problems here.
6. As long as you get a good batch of coffee grounds, this machine can turn it into delicious espresso!

CONS:
1. I have been experiencing a small leak onto my counter after use. I haven't caught it in the act yet, but if I return to the kitchen a few hours later, there is a wet spot near the machine. I read another review that mentioned the same thing, so it might be a universal issue with this product. However, it is a small leak, and not enought to cause a real problem in my opinion.
2. I would suggest making 2-3 cups before wasting any milk product on your first trial. This model does not have an automatic drip feature and you will need to manually tell it when to stop pouring. If you are not used to this, you might end up with a few nasty batches on your first try. No biggie. Just watch the color of the drip. It starts out as a medium brown, and changes to a much lighter brown if left alone. I would recommend shutting it off a second or so after it changes to the lighter brown. I have made perfect batches every time by this method. This all takes place over several seconds, so keep an eye out.

YOU MIGHT NEED TO KNOW:
It mentions this in the manual, but make sure to get the right size of grounds. About the consistency of salt. I would recommend griding your own either at home with a grinder or at the store at a grinding station. They taste better for one, and you won't waste your money on a mystery bag that doesn't work well with your machine.

Also, it does not come with a frothing pitcher. You will need to buy one separately. I purchased mine at Bed Bath and Beyond -- a Krups one, stainless, about $10? It fits fine. Just make sure you don't get one that is too deep, or the froth wand will not reach the milk. It is a countertop model after all. If you don't want to use as much milk you can turn the pitcher at an angle.

That's it! Definitely more pros than cons. I feel that for the price I paid, I could not have hoped for a better quality machine. I would highly recommend this model if you want something easy and you don't require tons of frills. If you want something more frilly, go ahead and spend $300 to $3000 on one. But I purchased an espresso maker to SAVE time and money (so long, Starbucks!), and this one's just right for me!

review_content:
After reading the instructions, it's very easy to use. You've got to make sure to let all the pressure out before opening the top at the end. Everything is easy to clean except for the metal part of the steamer. The milk splashes a lot when steaming and gets cooked onto the metal part. You can't really avoid this either since the steamer doesn't have real settings. Just on and off.
In the picture, it shows the steamer sticking out making it look easy to access and use but it only sticks out a little bit and can't get into very deep cups. It's perfectly fine in that sense if you're using an actual steaming cup but I using use my coffee cups. As for the coffee, you need more coffee grounds in ratio to water than it states in the instructions for you're just getting strong coffee, not an espresso shot.
All in all, it's not a bad price for what you get. It suites my purposes just fine and I like using it. The end result if done right is very delicious.

It can foam your drink, steam your milk. I was quite impressed.

I can't add much else above what others have added except for one thing which is a little confusing.

The filter metal plates do go inside the holder and if you look very carefully it does have a hole in the bottom for the coffee to come out. I had to look at this 5x before I realized there were many holes on the top and 1 on the botton of the metal filter.

(Angy's husband)
