review_content: Easy espresso machine to use, makes amazing drinks, user friendly cleaning is great! This is not a regular coffee maker so if that is what you want then do not get this machine, this is for making espresso, lattes, and cappuccinos. I also read about people complaining about cleaning the milk frothers and attachments on it, im not sure if you are supposed to do this but i clean my milk frother in the dish washer with the two attachments in the part with the silverwear so they can't come out during cleaning. I absolutely love this machine, I've only been back to starbucks one since I've bought it. I use skinny flavored syrups to flavor my espressos and cappuccinos and it is amazingly quick and easy to use.
title: Five Stars
bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Espresso/Cappuccino Maker

review_content: After reading the reviews of this product, I decided to purchase Mr Coffee because of the high ratings.  (Although I was skeptical since it is so reasonably priced and you know the old adage "You get what you pay for".)  While many reviewers mentioned that it may take some time to get "the hang" of frothing, I can't imagine that my problem is simply that I need more practice.  I have owned an espresso machine in the past and was very successful at making mounds of froth.  (I think my old machine was a Krups.)  The instruction booklet states that "typically 35 - 45 seconds will deliver the proper milk temperature".  I can't imagine that is possible, but then . . . .  I am using a stainless milk pitcher as recommended; I make sure the pitcher is cold as the recommended; I use 2% milk as recommended,  yet the steam function only produces steam for a few seconds - I would say no more than 10-15 seconds - then it stops.  The milk has a very light froth but is still ice cold.  I have tried turning the steam control off for several seconds, then back on, but nothing.  I have turned the entire machine off and waited a few minutes before trying again - no luck; it does NOTHING.  I did consider returning it, but discovered that I had carelessly put the manufacturers box in the recycle bin so that ended that.  I guess I am stuck with it.  I have convinced myself that I need to keep trying but I find myself avoiding the frustration.  I recognize that the disappointing results could be due to my own ineptitude but my past experience with the other machine was spot-on (however, the steam function in that machine remained on until I turned it off - it didn't shut itself off like Mr Coffee does).  I think that this machine would work well IF the steam function didn't turn off automatically.  Perhaps I will time the steam function on my next attempt to see if it actually steams for 45 seconds or if, in fact, it steams for a shorter period.  And if it does stay on for 45 seconds, then I will KNOW that it isn't me -  that it takes longer than that to heat the milk!  Should I achieve success in future attempts I will update this review.  In the meantime the machine sits silently on my counter (sigh).
title: Disappointing - but is it me?

review_content: I had one of these several years ago and used it all the time.  When I started looking for a new machine I tried a higher priced unit and ended up sending it back because it was horribly loud.  I decided to get new and improved version of my old one and it works great.  The frother doesn't seem to work very well but I found that if you take the little plastic thing off it works great.  This isn't an expensive elaborate machine but it works very well for the money.  Looking at the reviews for the more expensive and even the real expensive machines I notice that this machine got the most and best reviews.  Now that's saying something.
title: Tried and true
bought_model: Color: CappuccinoStyle Name: 4-Cup Steam

review_content:
I LOVE, LOVE, LOVE this machine!!! I used mine for a year and it just died on me after over 400 uses. I'm sure it would have lasted longer if I would have descaled it (run vinegar through it) more than every 6 months!! I just ordered a second one this week and I will be diligent about descaling it. Amazon has the best price I've seen anywhere though not many big box stores carry this model. It's a little hard to clean the dried milk off of the steamer when you use it a lot and it gets really caked on, but a little elbow grease every day takes it off pretty well. I calculated my cost per use for 400 uses and it was $.17 per use. When you add the coffee, milk, whipped cream, and syrup (I buy directly from the Starbucks stores - it's cheaper than buying it online), it's less than $1 per day (even with Organic milk) which really beats $4.85 at Starbucks! I would highly recommend this machine.

***UPDATE: First of all, the coffee maker I purchased this year (2011) broke so I took it to an authorized Mr. Coffee shop who confirmed it was an internal issue and I got a new one very quickly. I took it in on Monday and the new one was delivered on Friday. VERY FAST!! Second, I have to share that when I purchased this on Amazon, both times, it was around $70. I would recommend it at that price. However, I see that it has recently increased to around $100 and I'm sure you could find a higher quality coffee maker in that price range. Also, the steamer is funny. If you don't use it every day, it takes a while to work or it doesn't work and you have to descale it. Not good when you're in a hurry to get out the door in the morning!
title: Great machine for the price & cheaper than daily Starbucks!

review_content: I bought this machine November 2009 and used in 1 -2 times daily. Finally the rubber screw that holds a stainless filter became brittle and broke. If I can find that screw my machine will be back up and running.  If your coffee starts slowing down this filter/ disc has become clogged and cleaned. Just unscrew the rubber screw , wipe down and put back together.really simple. Pull off the water reserve, the tray, and lay it on its back. Look under top and remove screw , clean and put together.  Have a cup of espresso now! I don't know if the manual says anything about this cuz I just can't keep manuals that long. Lol

review_content:
Things that I didn't like but really didn't matter overall:
1. Machine is very loud.
2. No automatic shut off at end of shot

The reason I'm giving this one star however is because after about a year, this machine started leaking like nobody's business. It's not that the tray is filling up because the water never makes it to the tray and just leaks from somewhere under the machine. I'm soaking 2-3 hand towels each time I brew 4 shots because it leaks so badly.

I've read enough reviews on here to realize this is a common problem with this machine, don't waste your money on it.

I love this machine! I was raised making lattes and cappuccinos and this really performs well. I did see multiple complaints about the machine not having the longest of lives, which concerns me. But, I'm hoping since I'm diligent about cleaning it that I can get at least a few years out of it.

Updated from my November post. So it it has been over three months since I have had this machine and I still use it multiple times a day. I did come across a few things that might address some of the issues others had with the machine.
My machine also slowly started to loose act like the milk reservoir was clogged, or losing steam pressure. It was by accident that I discovered I was NOT cleaning the the frother correctly. I'm referring the the metal part that shoots out the steamed milk and it's handle. Because that part will actually come out of the top and you can clean inside of it. Which it desperately needed (It was gross) I don't recall this being in the manual and I couldn't find mine to check, however I haven't had any problems with it since.

My final note, the milk frother seems to have issues pumping out the correct amount when it comes to any non diary substance. But that is fixed. All in all I would say it's awesome.

Die hard espresso fan here, and a bit of a coffee snob. Used stove top espresso makers for years and decided to give this machine a shot (no pun intended :) I didn't expect much- it's only 200 bucks and made by Mr. Coffee (not a bad brand, just known for simple coffee brewers). Turns out, this little machine makes a damn fine espresso. We've even used cheap grounds and it still turns out a strong brew with lots of crema. The milk frother makes a great amount of foam and everything is super hot! We use it about 3 times a day, every day, and it's still going strong for over 6 months.

Only complaint- the milk frother. Although you can keep milk in it and store in the fridge, the plastic parts start to smell sour. We take it apart and clean it regularly, but if you don't have a dishwasher, it's kind of hard to clean There are lots of recesses and screws that get covered in milk). We finally gave in and bought a new part.

review_content:
Another update: this is terrible. I really didn't want to write a bad review on this product, but after the second one died within two months with the same symptoms (two lights blinking, and no longer pumps water), I genuinely believe this product has a faulty design that causes serious unreliability. I will not buy a third one.

An update: alright, I wrote an enthusiastic review of this product a year ago. But I hate to report that this thing didn't last. It stopped making coffee last week, just a bit over a year since I bought it. Don't know what the problem is, but it gives out constantly flashing lights, and pumps out nothing. I guess the pump is out. So the other complaints about the durability of this product is probably real.

But this I hate even more to report: I liked this thing so much that I went out to buy another one immediately, knowing that I might be making a mistake, because likely this may not last very long either. So I'm hooked to this. I have no backbone.

Anyway, the following is my original review. Everything I said is still true, as I mentioned nothing about durability.

The original review:

I'm completely satisfied and very pleasantly surprised by this espresso machine. I haven't tried the cappuccino feature yet, but the coffee it makes is top quality. I'm not a coffee snob, but I generally know what good coffee is. This is far better than the Senseo by Philips. I can use it make coffee that is just as good as Starbucks espresso coffee, if not better.

The fact that it takes any ground coffee you have, instead of requiring specially made coffee pads, is the great plus. It allows more freedom of choices and results in big savings in a long term. Quite easy to operate as well. Highly recommended.

The only problem I have with this is that my friends will think I have indulged myself by buying a very expensive espresso machine.
title: Durability issue (Old title: Never thought an espresso machine under $100 would be this good)
bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Automatic Dual Shot

review_content:
Pros: affordable, saves money, makes delicious coffee for two people from about three tablespoons of grounds
Cons: No auto-shut-off, shape of water compartment lid not super easy to grip, sometimes sputters water from milk steamer

This machine is wonderful. We've had ours since last Christmas and have saved hundreds of dollars in coffee costs by making lattes. It is compact, simple to operate, and easy to clean.
We debated giving it four stars because of the fact that it does not have an auto shut-off and because the shape of the water compartment is not as easy to unscrew as possible due to the smooth shape. One more less than perfect thing about it is that the milk steamer sometimes comes on when it is not supposed to, sputtering a little. But these are minor, and I rate them far lower as cons than I weigh the pros, especially considering the price, which makes the imperfections hardly noticeable.

We enjoy our machine. I get a surge of prickliness when I think about being without it. :) I came online to see if I can still get one for $29. I may just buy another to have in the cabinet for that far off day that this one might finally be worn out from brewing us delicious lattes several times a day.
title: Five Stars for the Price
bought_model: Color: CappuccinoStyle Name: 4-Cup Steam

review_content: Made by Oster for Mr.Coffee so it's a good name brand. I upgraded from the Cuisinart EM-200 Programmable 15-Bar Espresso Maker, Stainless Steel which is a very good semi-automatic for $184, to this fully-automatic (aka Super-Automatic). After a few hundred cups of cappuccinos and lattes I'm amazed that I didn't get this one first! Super easy to use and clean and it makes a great crema on top (a foam with a creamy consistency).and it can also make a variety of drinks such as a caff√® latte (with only one push of a button), cappuccino, caff√® macchiato, cafe mocha, or caff√® Americano.. It comes with a recipe booklet. At 15 bars of pressure the only thing this does not offer is a refrigeration unit for the milk.like some units costing several thousands of dollars do offer. Save your money and put it in the fridge! LOL!!!!

review_content: I read a lot of reviews before buying this product at Target and am sort of pleased with it. It's extremely pressure sensitive and even though I follow the specific directions, I've had a lot of trouble getting the steamer to froth the milk well. My first problem was that I took the black piece off the steamer like many of the reviews said. DONT DO THIS because it makes it so the steamer doesn't work correctly. Otherwise the steamer sometimes works great and sometimes barely froths the milk. Seems to be really sensitive to whatever pressure is in the machine, even though I depressurize it every time. It has frustrated me a lot. That being said, it is very inexpensive for an espresso machine and does produce lattes regardless of how finicky it is. So I would recommend it if you're looking for a cheap latte machine but just know it might give you some troubles.

review_content: This is literally the greatest machine ever.  I've owned a delonghi before and was disappointed by how limited it was for the cost and within 6 months it stopped working.  I ended up throwing it out. I have had this machine now for almost three years and it still works perfectly!  It makes delicious cappuccinos and lattes and the milk frother is perfect for making hot chocolate as well.  It is SUPER easy to clean and even easier to use.  This is a no muss no fuss machine and while it may not have all the bells and whistles of a more expensive machine, I'd take it over a fancier version any day!  I have never had any issues with it and would recommend it 100%.  What's really great about this machine is the milk container is easily removed so you can store any unused portion in the fridge without having to transfer containers.  Seriously, I cannot say enough good things about this machine. I LOVE IT! And if it ever dies, I'll buy it again.
title: After 3 years, it still makes the perfect cappuccino!
bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Espresso/Cappuccino Maker

review_content:
I bought one of these at a store. At this point, it is dead, having exploded. Yes, EXPLODED.

Used it an average of a few times a week for 6 months. I would make the coffee, sometimes steam milk, then crack the steamer valve to blow off pressure when done.

Life cycle:
Month 1, worked great. Steamed milk fine, but be sure to clean the metal part hidden under the plastic, while it is still hot or there is a really bad buildup.

Month 2, handle broke on pot. It is poorly designed.

Month 3, teeth that hold the pot lid on broke. Yah, the plastic can't even handle being take on and of to clean the pot.

Month 6, exploded. Poor construction. Poor materials. Made my latte, put it on table, and before I got back to blow off steam, unit exploded by blowing off the lid. Again, this was the plasic. So basically, they have used the wrong plasting in every part of their design.
title: Worked well, but lasted poorly.  Waste of money.
bought_model: Color: CappuccinoStyle Name: 4-Cup Steam

review_content: I bought this at a department store, it was a little more expensive. The inside smelled like spray paint and when I did the cleaning routine that they recommend before you use it, there were little bits of debri in the water. I did it several times and there was always debri. I couldn't tell what it was but I figured the coffee grounds would catch it. I used it for a week. I left the lid off after use to try and air it out but the spray paint smell never went away. It was still just as strong as before. Also the frothing wand is way too short and too close to the machine with no adjustments. I returned it.
title: Spray paint smell and badly designed frothing wand
bought_model: Color: CappuccinoStyle Name: 4-Cup Steam

review_content: Birthday present from a friend because I liked Starbucks and I would stop there every day for a large latte at $4 plus (California).  I finally used it and it's a great machine. To me, the coffee is better than what I had been buying at the shop. A lot depends on what brand of espresso coffee you buy. The machine makes the espresso, the taste is up to you. There are differences in coffees, for example some people prefer Yuban over Folger and can tell the difference between the two. The machine heats the water quickly, takes only a couple of minutes, just enough time for me to pour  the milk into a small pitcher to steam it. By the time I have the milk ready, the espresso is pouring into the coffee pot. The first time I used the machine I didn't know what to do with frothing the milk. And it was a disaster. Milk splattered everywhere. I learned by placing a metal pot under the frothing pot so if it spilled it was an easy clean up. I don't need that extra pot anymore. It just takes a little experience. I recommend it highly, I'm very pleased with it. And no, I don't pay for lattes anymore at Starbucks.
title: better coffee than starbucks

review_content: Great machine. I've made all variety of coffee in it, and while it won't compare to professional level machines, it's great for a quick at-home coffee maker, that makes a variety of drinks. Recommended.
title: Works well!
bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Caf√© Steam

review_content:
I have been using this coffee maker for more than 2 years, so I can say I've have plenty of experience on it. I have the copper-colored one which is very nice, every guest notices it.
It's very easy to use and the water reservoir is very convenient to fill since it is detachable from the machine.
Some general tips which are not covered int he manual:
1. The coffee filter will get clogged at some point and the first wall of filter (with the holes) is not meant to be easily detached from the bottom of the filter (which has only one hole). The way I detached it was washing it hot water and then putting into the freezer. As soon as I got out from the freezer, I hit it upside down against the table and the first wall of the filter popped out from he bottom. This is the main difference from other expresso machines which have filters where the two parts can be easily separated and washed.
2. When you use milk, get used to start with minimum froth and increase it at the end to generate the froth like in the picture. Use a timer or watch to estimate when you need to turn the froth dial to get the best mix.
3. Use a very good grinder than can grind fine coffee as for expresso. I use the Hario manual grinder which is cheap and I enjoy turning it manually. You can shop for an electric one but be sure that it has been well reviewed for fine grinds. I can't stress enough the importance for a good grinder, it is more important than the coffee maker itself. The most important of getting coffee percolation right (which makes that oily coffee flow) comes from using the ideal grind for the coffee.
If you pay attention to these tips, you should be able to make better coffee than most coffee shops. And what about the coffee beans? Well, in the US any Starbucks coffee beans are well rated so it's my baseline reference. This coffee maker has had the privilege to make more exotic coffees like the Jacu bird from southeast Brazil ;)
I am very happy overall with this coffee maker which is very convenient for everyday use. I may buy a more traditional one at some point with the steam wand and automatic grinder but still my desire hasn't come to the point to spend 3x times to what this coffee machine costed.
title: Awesome Coffee Maker if You Follow this Tips
bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Espresso/Cappuccino Maker

review_content: I purchased this Mr.Coffee 4 cup espresso maker and was very excited to use it to make my carmel macchiato's at home saving me some $$ from going to Starbuck's everyday...well luckily I decided to run some just "plain water" through the machine using the brew cycle just to clean it prior to my first use...sure glad I did as the first water cycle I ran I saw something shiny floating all over the top of the water...upon further inspection my husband and I discovered it was tiny "metal particles" floating all over in the water....okkkk...so I took the machine to the sink rinsed out the water resavoir well and cleaned everything...I than ran another plain water cycle through the machine on "brew" I was shocked to see the same thing...tiny metal particles floating all over in the water...I repeated running clean water through on brew cycle over 35 times!!!!! Not ONE cup of water was clean ALL had "metal particles" floating in the water...I pulled some out of the cup onto my finger inspected under lighting...they are tiny metal shards/particles and at that point my husband and I said no way we cant use this. Who wants small metal shards in their coffee??? Not safe and obviously couldn't drink anything that came out of this machine. We tried everything to get this metal flushed from lines of machine but nothing worked. Terrible product and I'm thinking most people probably are unaware this is happening if they are running coffee through machine into their cup they most likely wouldn't see the metal particles floating all over. We packed this machine back up and returned it. Completely unsafe to use, and very dissapointed. I would stay far away from this machine there is a component somewhere inside of the machine that is flaking these metal particles into your cup after running through inside of machine. Like I said we ran plain water on brew cycle over 35 times trying to clear out the metal particles but not 1 cup was clean. Stay away from this machine.
title: Metal Particles Floating in Every Cup!!!
bought_model: Color: CappuccinoStyle Name: 4-Cup Steam

review_content:
When all I have experienced with these type of machines is said and done---for the money, this machine is the best available buy out there anywhere. Yes, bells and whistles may come on more expensive products for making expresso, etc. but Mr. Coffee offers here a machine that is well thought out and in the first two months of daily use here continues going strong.

We are very pleased. I question if perhaps those that have written much negative have actually taken time to follow enclosed instructions so to point them in the first-right possible direction during intial use? I don't know. We did and were careful from the beginning. It wasn't rocket science or anything but helped us to know just what was intended to get to a quality cup of expresso. Many reviews on Amazon for many of these machines--over time, I have read all kinds---none say it as simply as we have found. if you are simply looking for decent pump machine for a reasonable cost this machine will do it for you too. We do buy top brand grounds to put into our maker and it does just fine. We often clean the gasket at the top of the basket too--just to be ensure that no grounds accidentally get into places that (in our minds) could indeed cause leaks, etc.

Some have written of noticable leaks leaving water on counter, etc. we have had none of it. Water heats quickly and pump works very nice. never any leaks around the basket or other concerns. I intentionally waited to write this review thinking that it would be wise to let you know after two months how all is going; and, this is it---very well.

Congratulations Mr. Coffee. Well done. To the sellers that also offer at reasonable costs a bit below retail---thank you................. !!!
title: surprisingly satisfied - now very pleased... ECMP50-Expresso/Cappuccino

title: Doesn't heat enough.
bought_model: Color: CappuccinoStyle Name: 4-Cup Steam

review_content:
Having been a coffee drinker for over 25 years and used to all types of coffee machines - percolators, french press, drip machines ....

Unless you are willing to spend a grand on a coffee machine - I've found Mr Coffee to be the best coffee machine overall.

Here is why:
(1) Produces excellent coffee as long as you use the right coffee
(2) Never fails - used it for over 3 years now - still working well
(3) Excellent for single serve as well as can brew up to 4 cups of coffee.

What is not good:
(1) Forget about using the steam wand - is useless - it produces so much of water to heat the milk that by the time you have your Latte - it would be watered down heavily.

If you are buying this machine exclusively to prepare Lattes & cappuccino and planning to use the steamer - forget about buying this machine.

Safety:
As a safety precaution - before you open the top lid for water, turn the on-off knob to the steam position to release all the steam and then open the top lid to pour the water in

Recommended coffee:
(1) If you are tight on budget - try Great Value 100% Arabica or 100% Columbian coffee - for under $3 - it is as good as starbucks or any other premium brand

(2) If you are ok to shell out a few $s more - Lavazza Espresso Roast is the best coffee
title: The only cheap thing about this machine is its price
bought_model: Color: CappuccinoStyle Name: 4-Cup Steam

review_content:
At first, I thought about giving this product a lower rating, but I changed my mind, and here's why:

First, and most important to me, this machine makes good espresso. Furthermore, it makes it fairly quickly and quietly. Couldn't be happier with that result!

Second, and here's the negative, I need to address the auto-frothing wand. I don't know if anyone else has experienced this or not, but the auto-frothing wand that came with my machine was a piece of plastic crap. I had to experiment several times, but each time I used it, I was disappointed. The results were always the same, huge bubbles in the froth on top and hot, thin milk on the bottom, not exactly the foamy, creamy experience everyone wants! I watched some videos on how to froth milk, but no matter what I tried, it was always the same. Then I had a friend who works as a barista at a local coffee shop try it, but she also could not get anything but huge bubbles and hot, thin milk. We decided that the machine produced too much air pressure. I was considering returning the machine, but I decided to try to take the plastic auto-frothing wand off and try to do it manually. My expectations were low, because I thought the fault was with the inner workings of the machine. I'm glad I tried the manual way though, because it actually worked! Using the video techniques I found for manual frothing, I was able to get much closer to making the smaller bubbles for the foam and a creamy consistency throughout the milk. Obviously, it wasn't perfect because I'm still a noob, but I'd imagine someone who really knows what they're doing would easily pull it off. Having said that, I believe the issue was that the auto-frothing wand actually allows way too much air into the milk in the initial frothing stage. However, going manually, I was allowed to control exactly how much air was being added and how quickly it was being added. So, my advice, ditch that little plastic piece of garbage and go manual! It may take a little more practice, but I believe it'll pay off.

Third, as pretty much all the other reviews have said, the scoop really does not work as an effective tamper. However, I would not pay the $10-$18 necessary to buy an espresso tamper. For one thing, it's a uni-tasker, which is almost always a big no-no and a good indication that you're wasting money. For another thing, if you have tools at home, you could easily make one yourself. Or, you can do what I did and just use the top of a medicine bottle that you have lying around. A lot of them have the 49mm diameter you need or close to it.

Finally, in summary, you can't beat the price on this machine, and it does it's job well. I've had it for about a week now, and it's already been through a quite a few uses. It's worked great! Just make sure that you're cleaning it properly, releasing the pressure after every use, and making sure that no water is left in the machine between uses (that should solve the "exploding" problems that other customers have experienced). The only reason that I didn't give it 5 stars were for the uselessness of the auto-frothing wand and the scoop. Other than that, it's a fantastic buy!

review_content:
I gave it 4 stars because for such a simple small machine it does exactly what I need it to without paying a high price. I was hesitant to try it but it got pretty good reviews and was the cheapest machine I wanted to buy. It's not fancy like the ones I wanted but the espresso tastes fine. If you enjoy espresso and don't want to blow your budget on an expensive machine get this one.
If you are making a single "2" serving I would add extra water so you have enough steam to froth milk then steam wand clean in water after wards.
It seems if you vent all the steam there is really only one drop or two of moisture left in reservoir which will quickly dry if you leave the tank lid off for a minute or so.

update 1/12/2014 the machine still works fine but I am upgrading to a De'Longhi BAR32 Retro 15 BAR Pump Espresso and Cappuccino Maker. I really prefer the espresso with thick crema. This Mr. Coffee is a steam driven espresso machine, it makes espresso a bit on the sour side for me.

But if you aren't that picky this machine will do nicely for you.

review_content: After using mine for 6 months, I can say that this makes perfect cappuccino every time! I experimented with different types of milk such as skim and coconut and found that most produce great froth. I like extra froth and it's easy to add. Suggestion to users: Clean it thoroughly (especially the milk reservoir) after every use and you'll have no problems. Treat yourself!
title: Treat Yourself!
bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Espresso/Cappuccino Maker

review_content:
I have never owned an Espresso machine before this one and for the week that I have had this one I can tell I am going to love it more each time I use it. It took a few days of trial and error to get down a good process, and for being newbie this is fairly user friendly. Do purchase a tamper and a frothing pitcher in addition to this machine. I will say that if you over tamp the coffee you will end up with leaking and water everywhere so do make sure you read the instructions fully just so you understand how the machine works. It does smell like warmed up plastic the first few times you use it, so it would be wise to do a dry run with just water a couple times to avoid your coffee smelling like that. Now, a quick instruction set that I have found good for me is as follows: for a 16oz drink
1. Fill water to the 4 cup mark and put into machine
2. Turn machine to steam and let warm up and wait for a constant stream of steam to come from the wand (till there is no water dripping, place a cup under wand to catch drips till its warmed up)
3. While machine is warming up, fill coffee filter to the top and then tamp down to the 2 cup mark (do not pack down to hard or machine will leak), then set the filter wand in the lock position
4. Once a constant flow of steam is coming from the wand turn machine off and then place frothing pitching with 3/4 full of milk under the wand and submerge. Turn machine back to steam and warm milk to desired temperature
5. Once milk is hot turn machine to brew
6. While espresso is brewing, in your desired coffee cup place any flavoring/cream/syrup (I use a sugar free white chocolate syrup, approx 2oz worth)
7. When espresso is done brewing (should be around the 2 cup mark on water craf) turn machine off
8. Pour espresso into cup, then add steamed milk while stirring the mix
9. Take cold water in a cup and submerge steam wand and turn back to steam to release any pressure left in the machine, once is done turn top cap slightly to finish releasing pressure
10. ENJOY
title: Perfect for a Newbie
bought_model: Color: CappuccinoStyle Name: 4-Cup Steam

review_content: I hate this machine. I'm probably going to return it. It runs the water through way too quickly, even with tamping, resulting in somewhat weaker coffee that isn't hot enough, And no layer of crema whatsoever. I have to microwave my coffee before I drink it. The knobs are horrible. The top knob is set down in a well, which ironically holds all the water you spill because its harder to aim correctly.  And the shape of the knob is not ergonomically good if you have any arthritis issues. The handles of pot and basket kind of stick too far as well. But really, it's the damn coffee it makes. It's just not as good as it should be and no tamping is going to help that. I've30  been using these low end espresso makers for almost 30 years and I've been through dozens of them. This machine isn't well designed. It's cutesy little design do nothing to make it a better machine.

review_content:
At first I really liked the Mr Coffee espresso machine because of convenience. I was tired of having to drive through the local espresso stand- not to mention the extremely high cost for anything other than an Americano. Add some flavored syrup and steamed milk and pay three bucks or more. Twice a day for many people. You can make payments on a good used car for that kind of money.
I also liked the espresso/cappuccino it made. It tasted good.
So, quality and flavor are just fine.
A couple of bad design characteristics. The main control is on the right side. Twist clockwise for steam. Counterclockwise for coffee. Or is it the other way around? You can't SEE it! Early in the morning I want to see the controls I use.
But my main grievance about the machine is the part that gets the dirtiest (read old, wet residue coffee grounds) cannot be removed to be cleaned, and it's located so that cleaning is a guessing game at best.
Does it affect flavor? How can it not? But since I can't really clean it, I'll never know.

We've replaced it with anoher Krups (XP601050). It just came and sounds stronger than the Mr Coffee machine. We'll see.

Origninal: I wanted to wait a few months before writing a review. We had a Krups for about 10 yrs prior and the hard water finally did it in. I didn't want to spend much, so I took a chance on the ECMP50. Everything is fine except that the threads inside the steamer nozzle arm stripped about a month after we got it. I never used the rubber cover on our prior machine and didn't use it on this for cleaning purposes. Now, I just leave the rubber cover on all the time and hope the machine lasts me a few years.
Other than that, it works fine.

I now own two of these ‚Äì one in the office and one at home.

I bought the first one for the office, skeptical of the unfamiliar brand, but willing to give it a shot given the low price point. I was pleasantly surprised. It's a little on the ugly side, but heats up incredibly fast, and has a great pump in it. Every bit as good as the Breville I had at home.

When that years-faithful Breville finally gave out (gasket, as always), my first replacement was a gift of a 15bar DeLonghi ‚Äì a far more expensive (though comparably ugly) machine. Useless. review_content:
This is a good machine for beginners and people who aren't gourmet critics about their coffee. It gets the job done and makes it fairly simple to brew espresso. I have only brewed "2 cups" at a time and not attempted 4 yet, but I've consistently gotten a well-balanced brew with a nice crema. Although a devoted coffee snob could find criticisms your average Starbucks drinker should be satisfied.

As others have noted you should buy a frothing pitcher if you don't already have one, as this machine doesn't come with one. Don't get one too large or the steam wand won't reach deep enough (see below).

The main weaknesses are related to the steaming function, and each can be resolved with a work-around:

1) The steam wand is just a bit short, meaning even with a relatively small 12-oz frothing pitcher the wand can't quite get as low as you may want because the rim of the pitcher will be bumping up into the arm of the wand. You can compensate some by tilting the pitcher to make the milk deeper at one end.

2) The wand is also positioned directly up and down with no tilting possible, which makes it difficult to get the necessary angle to get the milk rolling--though after some practice I was able to achieve rolling milk by tilting the pitcher towards myself (front) and keeping the wand on the left side (machine side) of the pitcher. Although the manual instructs you to move the wand around, being able to get the milk rolling without moving the wand around is critical to creating the velvety microfoam that is the difference between a great latt√© or mocha and an OK one.

3) The steam wand also came with a "frothing aid" - a plastic cover with additional holes in it. I guess this is supposed to be helpful, but for my part I was unable to produce microfoam until I removed the frothing aid and just used the naked wand.

4) You can't easily steam without brewing espresso first (ex: to steam some milk for a child's hot cocoa, sans espresso), because the brewing process is needed to heat up the water for a few minutes to build up the steam heat and pressure. If you try to turn the steam function on without brewing first, the heating element comes on but you don't achieve enough pressure because the steam valve is open. If you try to run the brew function without coffee in the filter, the water floods through much faster and you end up trying to steam without enough pressure because the the water isn't hot enough yet, or you run out of steam very quickly because so much of the water ended up in the carafe instead of coming out as steam. Thus, the only way to steam without brewing first is to add a full carafe of water to the machine, set to brew, and let the carafe fill up to the 4-cup mark before switching over to steam.
title: Good entry-level machine
bought_model: Color: CappuccinoStyle Name: 4-Cup Steam

review_content: I bought this item after reading mixed reviews on Amazon, hoping for the best and wanting to try it for myself.  After a month, I couldn't be happier.  It makes perfect cappucino, espresso.  I even got crema the first time.  I think it's important to make sure that you are grinding the beans the right way, down to espresso grind.  I think this makes a huge difference.  I have a burr grinder (which I also got from Amazon and is great) that allows me to set it to different grinds. I use the espresso grind when I use this machine and it comes out perfect every time.  This machine is super simple to use, and fast.  The milk (i use soy) froths perfectly, and I use a little stainless pitcher.  I don't see what the complaints are about unless people are using regular coffee grounds or something.  It's also important to tamp down the coffee.  You can buy a little stainless tamper which works great for less than 10 bucks and it will last forever.  It's the little things that make this machine work to it's best potential.  Just do them and your espresso/cappuccino will come out great!

review_content:
Five stars because it performed exactly the way I was hoping it would. Never owned an espresso/cappuccino machine before, so I cannot honestly compare it to other brands. Was looking at the all in one brands which had excellent reviews but they were $600 and up during the holiday sales. And since I never had a machine like this, I was sure I'd make mistakes and waist money. So I bought this for $144 on Amazon, was a little cheaper on other sites, but didn't want to wait two weeks to get it. Instruction were very clear, some misspellings, but clear. Cleaned, primed the pumps, and then made a double cappuccino. It came out perfect the first time. I was amazed. I'm learning that reading instructions really does help when it comes to machines. I used an excellent crema espresso bean, also purchased on Amazon. I kept making different size/types of coffee drinks until I was wired to the max.

I did purchase the Mr. Coffee burr grinder for use with this Barista. Worked perfectly also. This Barista, and the attachments are easy and quick to clean. I noticed that the device has to stages for various cup sizes. I missed that in the instructions somehow. You can also remove the bottom stage to place a small/short travel mug in with narrow bottom. The Mr. Coffee Barista photo shows the cup sitting on the bottom stage. The first stage for smaller cups, slides out from under the milk foam dispenser. Since my travel mugs are too large, I pour two large cappuccinos into my travel mug. I put hot water in the metal travel mug first to warm up the inside, pour out the water, then the cappuccino stays hot. I have been using the large/wide Starbucks city cups in this Barista. They work perfectly. So wide isn't an issue, just tall.

I do enjoy this machine and will continue to try the various drink recipes I see posted for this Barista.
title: Great Espresso/Cappuccino Maker
bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Espresso/Cappuccino Maker

I have not had the water leaks other reviewers have noted, but I chalk that up to user error. It is similar to the Keurig in that if you pour water directly on the valve when filling the tank, it has a tendency to let a bit out because the water pressure opens the valve. Just be careful when filling the tank. Also, remember to empty the trap where the steam exhausts as it fills up after a few times.

review_content:
11/27/207 Reviewed updated: I have now purchased three of these. I didn't mind when they lasted a couple of years but now? The last one lasted about 6 months. Additionally, the price has gone up to 47 plus dollars when it was previously 35. STAY AWAY. They are not making these the same anymore. The heating elements die out within 6 to 8 months. They are complete GARBAGE. It's a shame, because this used to be a decent product.

Original review:

My 5 star review will hopefully not upset some of the 1 star reviewers who don‚Äôt realize that water under high pressure - when released quickly - will cause explosive results.

Basically this means if the device is on and one uncouples the coffee holder from your Mr. Coffee espresso machine (or any other espresso machine for that matter) you‚Äôre going to turn your kitchen into an explosives ordinance proving ground.

Yes, I have accidently ‚Äúdetonated‚Äù a few sub kiloton ‚Äúrounds‚Äù of espresso myself. My dog won‚Äôt talk to me and it‚Äôs been months since the cat ran off into the closet to hide but we hopefully expect to see her by the holidays so take it from me (or RTFM) and understand that water under high pressure is EXPLOSIVE!

In spite of these nearly fatal atrocities, high velocity ‚Äúpeppered‚Äù coffee wounds and thousands of dollars to repair blown out windows, door frames and part of a ceiling, I love this espresso maker.

I‚Äôve also got a nice 12 cup Bialetti Italian/on the stove type device and while I‚Äôd honestly have to say that makes a better cup of espresso, for 39 bucks you can‚Äôt go wrong with this - and it‚Äôs much faster, too.

I‚Äôve gone through two of ‚Äòem because the knob on my first one (which I had for three years) broke but hey - whaddya want for 39 friggin‚Äô dollars. HELLO I don‚Äôt think for that kind of money you‚Äôre going to get NASA quality control here boys and girls.

Too bad Joltin‚Äô Joe DiMaggio isn‚Äôt still around to be spokesperson for Mr. Coffee as he would have enjoyed a nice cup of Italian espresso from this machine. I bet he‚Äôs still knockin‚Äô ‚Äòem out of the park in heaven with the Babe and Mick, though. RIP fellas - those were the good old days and we miss yaz - but - on the other hand - we can now make a helluva nice cup of ‚ÄúJoe‚Äù with this handy machine.

review_content:
We have been using this coffee maker for just over two years. On average we make about 3 cups of coffee daily. More on the weekends and less when I am the only one home. There are five coffee drinkers in our household and it can get a work out some days.

About the machine:
The water resevoir holds 55 ounces and the milk resevoir holds 16 ounces of liquid.
You can select the amount of frothed milk you want by adjusting the knob on the milk resevoir
You can manually add more milk/froth , or a longer shot of coffee by using the manual mode (hold the button until it starts and press it again when you get the desired amount, or let it turn of by itself)
There are pre-determined espresso, cappuccino, and latte modes for single and double sized cups.
There is a drawer/shelf that slides out from under the milk resevoir for brewing with smaller cups
The shelves that hold the cups are removable for cleaning

The manual for this item is on the Mr Coffee site under the service and support tab. It is a pdf and gives good information.

As far as ease of use and quality....
add the coffee grounds, tamp, push a button. Pretty easy. Of course, make sure the water and milk resevoirs are full. Just do not grind the coffee too fine or you may find the filter clogs.

Quality. This has been a sturdy and dependable coffee maker for us. It takes a minute or two for the water to heat initially. After that making a cup of coffee is pretty much instant unless it has set long enough to go into a hibernate mode. Then it will need to reheat the water again before making the coffee again. Do make certain that you are running the clean mode and occasionally making a cup of just hot water to keep the unit cleaned. I even add about a half a drop of dish washing liquid once in awhile as well as run vinegar through to keep it cleaned. If you do not, you may find that the machine appears to lose pressure and won't dispense coffee. At this point, you will need to spend some extra time cleaning it and it should be ok after that. Of course, you could actually be having pump issues. Try being aggressive about cleaning it before you give up. Especially so if you use dark, oily coffees. It is advised in the manual to NOT use coffees that have been roasted with or have sweetener added to it.

It is noted that you can fill the milk resevoir and store it in the fridge. I do not recommend this. The amount of calcium buildup on the frothing tube, etc is remarkable. And it gets as hard as the bone it helps your body to make. Save yourself a headache and rinse it right away and then if you want to store it in the fridge, fill it and put it in the fridge nice and clean and ready for the next cup of joy.

So far, after over two years, we are still enjoying this coffee maker. Yes, I have had to get aggressive about cleaning it after being less than diligent about not staying on top of the regular cleaning.

It does make a nice, flavorful cup of coffee. The espresso and coffee have a nice bit of crema and the milk frother is steam operated and also does a nice head of steamy, frothy milk on top. Is it the same quality that you get at a coffee house? Not quite. However, it is very good and much less expensive. I have not used the expensive versions of this. I wanted to try this as an entry level machine to see how often we would use it and if it was worth the money. We will used this until it quits or one of our college aged kids nabs it for their own use. Then I might consider a more expensive fancy machine. At this time, this does exactly what we need it to do. Regular coffee for the rest of the family, a light tar like substance for me, and flavored coffee drinks for those days that you say "to hell with watching calories". To make a standard cup of coffee fill the double shot filter basket, hold the espresso button for manual and it will dispense a nice cup of regular strength coffee in about 60 to 90 seconds.

If you are curious about the amount of coffee you get when making a cup of coffee........

HOW TO SELECT THE RIGHT CUP SIZE FROM THE OWNERS MANUAL (manual mode will vary, of course):
Please make sure to select your cup according to the following chart:
BEVERAGE AMOUNT
Espresso Single ( ) Double ( )
1.25 oz 2.5 oz
Cappuccino Single ( ) Double ( )
6 oz 10 oz
Latte Single ( ) Double ( )
12 oz 15 oz
NOTE: The total amount of the beverage can vary depending on the type of
milk used and Froth Control Knob setting.

Would have given it 5 stars, but as a former barista, I know that to make a good latte I need a steaming pitcher and a tamper. So for an espresso machine not to come with these items is like getting a pair of sneakers with no laces. I have had no problem with leaking, and as long as the user READS THE INSTRUCTIONS, they shouldn't have any problems either. For $40, I've already gotten my money's worth in the last week. And anyone interested in buying, I would say "GO FOR IT!!!" but order a steaming pitcher and espresso tamper along with it.

Note: P.S. Get a 49mm espresso tamper to go with it. Doesn't fit "perfectly" but its as close as I could find that wouldn't be too big.

review_content:
UPDATE‚Äî10/26/18‚ÄìI had this latte maker for over 3 years and still doing strong. Everyone loves trying it out when we have company. Saves my wallet from going to Starbucks all the time. Also, I‚Äôve used Almond Milk, milk and soy milk in mine. The milk for sure comes out more than the almond and soy but that‚Äôs because it‚Äôs thicker. I‚Äôm super pleased with mine and if the price tag was a little cheaper I‚Äôd buy more as gifts. I highly recommend this!

UPDATE--4/21/2016-- I have now has this coffee machine for over 6 months and use it almost daily and I still LOVE this machine. I thank my husband everyday for letting me get this. I use both creamer and soymilk for the frother. If you are using milk or soymilk, the latte will dispense more liquid giving to what you would expect in the size of drink you want. However, if you use creamer or heavy whipping cream both will not dispense as much since it's thicker consistency but this is probably a good thing as I would prefer less creamer/whipping cream than I would if I am using milk/soymilk.

I love this machine!!!! I am a long time user of Mr. Coffee, we own a traditional Mr. Coffee maker and a Mr. Coffee Keurig, both of which I've been super happy with. Mr. Coffee did not disappoint with this machine either. I love my latte's but I don't like the $6 price tag. I drink soy milk so I was so happy I can conveniently make my latte's at home. I've used the cappuccino feature as well. I have not used the espresso portion by itself yet. Husband bought this maker for me as an early Christmas presents. I also use creamer for frothing as well. My husband who only occasionally drinks coffee and mainly just cappuccinos out of my Mr. Coffee Keurig was less than pleased with yet another coffee machine. I made him a latte the other day for the first time and he said that was best coffee he had ever had. All I can say, that's a miracle in itself. I love this machine. Follow the direction as noted in the manual. Especially as others noted that you need to remove the red plastic piece where the water filter is. Also, please note the cleaning instructions. At first I was overwhelmed with all the pieces and how I would need to clean the frother after each use but honestly it doesn't take much time. This is a great machine for those espresso novices. Mr. Coffee has made it super easy to make a latte/cappuccino/espresso.
title: Latte's for the novice
bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Espresso/Cappuccino Maker

review_content:
My husband bought this cafe barista for me as my anniversary present, so I don‚Äôt show that I‚Äôm a verified purchase, but my review is genuine, nonetheless.

I combed through hundreds of the positive and negative reviews to get tips on using this product correctly. There are some useful tips from other users that definitely helped me. There are some negative reviews that don‚Äôt make any sense at all, though.

What I took away from a lot of the negative reviews is that people seem to be disappointed in this machine for not functioning as a coffee maker. If you purchase it expecting to make large unattended quantities of coffee like a coffee brewer, you will be disappointed and will think this is a bad product. If you purchase it expecting it to make small-batch, delicious barista-quality espressos, you will be very pleased with it.

I started out making the automatic two-shot lattes and cappuccinos but soon realized I was consuming far too much milk product. Using the latte or cappuccino setting will include about 6 ounces of milk. If you have two or three, then before you know it, you‚Äôre consuming a gallon of milk in just a few days, which really isn‚Äôt healthy. We‚Äôre not fond of almond milk or other alternatives, so I needed to find a solution to over-consuming dairy. We love our caffeine, so what I figured out to do is make 4, 2-shot espressos and just put a small amount of creamer in the bottom of a regular coffee cup. I‚Äôve gotten to a science with my process, but it is time-consuming. But the delicious result is very worth my time and effort.

If this helps anyone then that‚Äôs great. My system for delicious espresso drinks without consuming boatloads of milk or milk alternatives is as follows. Note: I tried using the custom selection of the Espresso selector in an attempt to not have to make so many double shots, but the espresso would taste watery to me.

Start with filling the water reservoir:
1. Use good quality espresso roast. Any coffee can be used, but if you want barista taste, use the darker roasts. Buy pre-ground, or if you buy whole bean, grind it to the size/consistency of salt granules.
2. Fill coffee filter correctly. If you use too much or too little, the shot won‚Äôt brew correctly. I fill to just a small mound above the rim of the filter before tamping. This amounts to about one tablespoon per shot.
3. Tamp it well. There shouldn‚Äôt be any cracks and the coffee grinds should be a smooth surface. It should tamp down to just below the rim of the filter. I hold the filter in my hand because I feel like the plastic could break eventually with the repeated force of tamping it against a countertop.
4. Twist filter slowly but firmly into the brewer opening. If it won‚Äôt twist all the way to where the handle is straight under the front of the machine, then this means that the filter is too full and the shot won‚Äôt brew correctly.
5. Position your cup under the brewer opening.
6. Press twice on the button of the top Espresso indicator, which will set it to brew a double shot.
7. When the shot is brewed and machine stops, remove the cup and set aside on a cup warmer.
8. Remove the filter and dump grounds into trash or compost. Rinse it thoroughly under water to clean away used grinds.
9. Before brewing the next shot, put another empty cup under the brewer and again press twice on the button of the top Espresso indicator. This is to help rinse away the used grounds from the brewer. If this isn‚Äôt done in between brewing shots, your drink won‚Äôt be as good-tasting. I also use a wet paper towel to clean the used grounds out of the brewer opening in-between brewing shots.
10. Repeat the above steps until you have a full coffee cup.

I‚Äôve only been using my barista for about 7 weeks, so there may be cleaning maintenance required that I just haven‚Äôt encountered yet due to the short duration that I‚Äôve used it.

This may seem like a lot of effort, but I‚Äôm a patient person and the result is a truly delicious espresso drink that is of the same high quality as can be obtained at a coffee house, but at a fraction of the cost. I typically pay $6.89 USD at my local grocery store for a pound of ground Starbucks espresso roast. The math at a glance is that at my local Starbucks, a standard venti latte is $5.40 USD. This is just a two or three-shot drink, so the amount of money saved by making them at home is pretty obvious.

I thoroughly enjoy this cafe barista and when using it as intended for small-batch espresso drinks, it is well worth the cost of the machine.
title: Well worth the comparative low cost
bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Espresso/Cappuccino Maker

review_content:
My family decided we wanted to enhance our in-home coffee brewing capabilities with an Espresso machine. I was looking for one that wouldn‚Äôt cost too much (dang those things can get expensive!) and would be able to froth milk. This little machine seemed to have everything we needed to fill that missing niche in our kitchen setup.

I purchased this from a local home goods store just after Christmas and it has more than paid for itself. My daughter is a Starbucks barista so we are up to our eyeballs in Starbucks coffee beans and since our main machine is a Keurig this Mr. Coffee machine lets us put those beans to good use. There is not a day that passes that we‚Äôre not brewing expresso or making a cappuccino with this machine. This brews a nice cup of Espresso (one or two shots), Cappuccino and Lattes. It includes a milk steamer/frother that does a decent job of steaming and frothing. We‚Äôve used it to froth soy milk, coconut milk, whole milk and almond milk. It doesn‚Äôt miss a beat.

I‚Äôm a coffee lover, but not a coffee connoisseur so as long as my coffee tastes good I‚Äôm usually happy. Sometimes I want a little something special like a Latte or Cappuccino and other than high calorie powders I was never able to accomplish this at home which meant a trip to Starbucks. Until now...

There is only one downside to this machine‚Ä¶ it is loud enough to wake the dead! I am not kidding‚Ä¶ this thing is LOUD. It‚Äôs a trade-off I‚Äôm willing to make because I like this machine so much, but if you‚Äôre thinking of buying one just be aware of that little downside.

We‚Äôd never be able to justify the cost of some of the more expensive espresso machines and I‚Äôm pleased that Mr. Coffee had this versatile machine on the market geared more toward families like mine‚Ä¶ those that love coffee, but are not willing to invest their first born children to do so. I have noticed there‚Äôs a huge gap in prices for Espresso machines, you either pay around $200 for an entry level machine or you‚Äôre looking at something $400 and up. I did not want to invest that heavily so I kept my eyes at the $200 range. My two main choices were this machine or the Keurig Rivo. Since the Keurig requires specific Espresso pods I decided to try this machine first and I'm glad I did.

Tip: DO NOT FORGET TO PUT MILK TUBE INTO CUP *BEFORE* FROTHING/STEAMING MILK
I did this and oh what a mess it made! I had milk all over the counter, in every nook and cranny of the machine and it was not fun to clean up. I will never make that mistake a second time.
title: Brews Great Espresso LOUDLY!

review_content:
I bought this machine after somewhat careful research, but still was feeling a bit cheap, and since this one had such great reviews, decided to get one ($30 including shipping from Ebay).

The frothing part was flawless, and the cappuccinos were almost perfect. However, as at least one other reviewer noted, if you really like espresso, opt for a pump-driven machine, as the steam-driven ones will not produce the coveted "crema", the froth on top of the espresso.

The espresso I got from this machine was not bad, but really not THAT different from a coffee produced by my beloved french press.

So I decided to give this machine to a friend, who likes it's milk-frothing ability (to make delicious hot-chocolate beverages) and bought for myself the pump-driven Mr.Coffee ECMP50 Espresso/ Cappuccino Maker.
I have had that one over a week, and so far am completely delighted with it. The espresso is fabulous, very comparable to (and often better than) some of the ready-made espresso drinks in the stores, and frother works perfectly as well.

Overall - if you are on a tight budget and do not really drink espresso much, only cappuccinos, definitely go for this machine, it is a hard-to-beat deal. It takes minimum amount of time to get ready and is very easy to operate and clean.

If you like the crema (coffee froth) on top of your espresso, then skip this and look for a pump-driven machine (the model I mentioned earlier is very affordable and nearly perfect).
title: Great little gadget if you like cappuccino only.  For a really good espresso, go for a pump-driven machine.

review_content:
I gave it a shot without getting my expectations too high. I realize there is a massive disparity between a $60 machine and a $400 machine, but the key things any espresso maker must have, regardless of price point, are that the pump can generate the required pressure to push the water through the grounds and that the water gets hot enough. Beyond those two things everything else is mostly fluff and preference. This unit can provide the needed pressure and the water got pretty close to the proper temperature, but it only took one day of use to decide I would be sending this item back for a refund.

Here are the items I appreciated about this unit:
1. The price is low enough that even if it broke after a year I would feel I got my money's worth
2. It comes with a manufacturer's 1 year warranty, and you can get an additional 3 year's of warranty from Amazon for around $8.50 more...which I did.
3. Simple to use, easy to remove water tank, minimal cleaning involved. This really is a minimalistic device.
4. It heats up quickly and you can have a hot brew in your hand in around 90-120 seconds from a cold start. Pretty impressive.
5. It produces a respectable espresso and the water temp once it reached the cup was around 180 degrees F. Ideal brewing temp is around 200 degrees, and I expect to lose some heat during the filtration process, but that's quite a delta between and ideal temp and actual temp.

Here are the reasons why I'm sending the unit back:
1. Filter basket is very lightweight and fragile. Looks to be made from aluminum instead of steel, and the plastic handle is very cheaply made. The lock for the filter (the one used to keep the filter in place when you go to dump out the used grounds) is a complete failure. It gets in the way when trying to secure the basket to the main unit, and doesn't keep the filter from falling into the garbage when you go to dump out the grounds. There is also no way to remove the plastic guide in the bottom of the basket (which allows the coffee to drip out of both ports equally) for deep cleaning. Not sure if it's secured via a tight fit, or if it's glued, but if you can't easily remove it expect to have something nasty start to drip into your coffee after a couple weeks of use. Extremely poor engineering overall for the entire filter assembly.
2. The filter basket is not able to be easily locked into place. I'm a 240lb guy that is used to swinging a hammer and I can barely get this thing all the way into locking position...and doing so I feel like something is going to break (the main unit housing, the handle, or myself). My 120lb wife can't even come close to getting it into proper position. It was even a challenge to lock it in place with with just the basket...no filter. Adding the filter and coffee required significant more force to get it into position.
3. There is no auto shutoff for the brewing function. This is either an unbelievable oversight or a brilliant conception. Personally I like to push a button and walk away while the machine does the work, knowing how much water needs to be pushed through automatically depending on if I'm wanting one shot or two. There is no dual-option on this unit. You're either brewing coffee or your steaming milk. However with this unit you will need to stand by and watch how much water is passing and then manually shut it off when you think it's enough. If you walk away and forget about it, the unit will keep going until the reservoir tank runs empty. Now...if you want to be able to adjust the strength of your coffee by either using less water or more, then you will likely love the manual nature....just don't get distracted while using this or your going to have a massive mess and likely burn out the motor when it continues to run even after the tank runs empty.
4. Plastic, plastic, plastic. Again...I wasn't expecting much for such a low cost unit, and this is likely a large reason why the cost is what it is, but the smell of hot plastic does not entice the senses. The housing is plastic, the base is plastic, the heat plate is plastic. Seriously...the heat plate on top where you warm up your cups is plastic.
5. Poor quality control. While I understand you need to use cheap materials to provide a low entry point product into the coffee market, what's used in this product is simply a too fragile feeling. However the filter basket was the ultimate dealbreaker. Without being able to lock into place using a reasonable amount of force, it is mostly unusable for anyone who can't bench press at least 200lbs.
title: For the price and the number of positive reviews it's worth the risk, but keep your expectations low
bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Automatic Dual Shot

7/2/2014....So now I've had this piece of junk for a little over a month and it just gets worse every day. If I try to make 4 cups, at least a cup steams out of the top and bottom holes, ending up with 3 cups or less and a mess all around the coffee pot on the counter. Definitely have to buy a different brand. Would definitely NOT recommend this at all. I've changed the 2 stars to 1 and that's doing it a service since there is not a 0.

review_content:
This espresso machine combined with a 3-year warrantee from SquareTrade is probably the best deal out there in the low end espresso machines. The machine is attractive and works well. I'm not sure if it's luck or engineering by Mr.Coffee, but I had no problem getting a 25 second pull to yield a 3oz double shot with plenty of crema. Also the steaming nozzle works well. I was able to stretch skim milk to 2x its volume on my 2nd try.

I did experience the counter leaking problem that other reviewers had mentioned. After some careful observation over the weekend I determined it can be caused by one of two things. First, the drip tray fills up fast from internal drainage from the machine. It needs to be emptied before each use. If you do that and still get leaks, then you need to empty or remove the water reservoir when you are done using the machine. Once I started doing this my leaking problem went away. If the machine did not have this issue I would give it 5 stars.

review_content: My 2 year old, very expensive, Gaggia died on the 4th of July!  I was so mad, I need my 2 cups of cappuccino everyday.  So I got in my car and drove to the Starbucks at Target, only place open close to me, to get my morning fix.  I thought while I was there I would see what Target had to offer in cappuccino machines---find something cheap to get me through then give it to my daughter.  I had no idea that Mr. Coffee had an espresso machine and I thought what the heck, it was a pump system and I have had a regular Mr. Coffee machine for over 10 years now, I do not drink regular coffee, I keep it for company, and I never had a problem with that.  I was so surprised when I brewed my first cup, the crema was very nice and the forthing system was wonderful.  It was so easy to use and so much quicker than any Gaggia I have had.  I always thought you had to spend hundreds of dollars to get a good working machine, boy was I wrong.  Over the past 17 years I have had 3 or 4 Gaggia's and I am so surprised how far home espresso/cappuccino machines have come.  I will be keeping this machine and saving my money!  I do agree with other reviews, you do not need the rubber tip and the single dermitass is too small.  So far I am really happy with this machine, I know it has only been a few days, but 6 cups later I am still happy with my purchase!!

review_content:
I purchased this from Target and not Amazon and it definitely does not work. I purchased it, and the first time using it, there is water popping out the top and spilling all over my counter. The expresso didn't even make. I'm not sure if I have a defected one, but I'm not understanding the rave reviews some people have given this machine. It's going back to the store for a refund, and I will just invest in a nice one instead of going the cheap route, sometimes you get what you pay for!

UPDATE 3/2017

Okay, I did a review on this a few years back and I decided to give this expresso machine another try. This has to be the worst expresso machine on the market. So I did purchase one that wasn't defective this time and still was disappointed in this machine and had to take back to the store. This machine waters down the coffee/expresso. It takes away the bold flavor of the coffee/roast. I bought two different roasts of beans thinking that might have been the issue but all the various dark roasts I used with this machine, it watered down the flavor. It taste like water! I know how expresso is supposed to taste because I was a former barista and I know the difference of good expresso or not. Technically this machine is a coffee maker because expresso requires a certain amount of bar pressure. Yet, even most coffee makers/expresso machines leave the flavor of the coffee beans this one leaves a strange metallic taste and it waters down the coffee. I used it several times and it still left a strange metallic after taste! Don't waste your time or money on this machine.

review_content: My husband and I returned from Italy and realized that life is too short to put up with conventional coffee.  So, for Father's Day, I decided to get him an espresso maker.  Since neither of us were sure we'd actually enjoy using the machine, (some appliances turn out to be more hassle than they are worth), we decided not to spend much money on one.  That way, if we dreaded using it, no harm...no foul.  I researched long and hard on all the reviews I could find.  This Mr. Coffee SCMP50 espresso maker had mostly good reviews (especially if you read the ones with tips on how to use for best results); the bad ones focused on  the machine not working from the get-go, or no longer working after a year.  We decided that for the money, this was the machine to try.  Well,...it worked right out of the box and has given us delicious lattes for 4 months.  I have a cup almost every day,...and it is fast and easy to use.  The richness of the coffee is heavenly, and the milk frother works very well.  The water reservoir is a great feature.  I clean up during and after each use and it is easy and quick.  The entire process from putting in the coffee, frothing the milk, dripping the coffee, and then cleaning, takes about 3 minutes.  We love our Mr. Coffee ECMP50.  Now, we only visit Starbucks when we are out of town.  And really, it doesn't taste any better than the lattes we make at home. Spending more on a machine will not necessarily yield better results. At about $70, this machine has proved to be a bargain.
title: Great Lattes! Great Price
bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Automatic Dual Shot

review_content:
quality is terrible and milk frother is a joke. Instructions were followed to a T but it splashes everywhere without creating foam. Not enough room to circulate frothing pitcher as advised and the nozzle is way to short and close the machine.
Thank Goodness Amazon was really helpful and assisted me in getting a refund.
title: quality is terrible and milk frother is a joke
bought_model: Color: CappuccinoStyle Name: 4-Cup Steam

review_content:
This is one of the worst-entry level "espresso" makers on the market. It's not true espresso, as the steam pressure isn't enough to properly brew espresso.
Here are some issues:
-Cheap quality materials--feels extremely light and mostly plastic
-Steam arm is stationary--it won't swivel
-No temperature sensor for boiler--continuously heats as long as red light is on
-Reservoir lid has a rubber washer that leeches into the water and steam--smells and tastes highly of polymer
-Reservoir lid is difficult to open, impossible for someone with arthritis.
-For the steam setting, there is no way to open/close the steam arm without also turning off the boiler--you can't get the strongest steam flow possible
-The reservoir lid burst on mine from pressure, and is now non-functional because it leaks water and steam.

Pros:
-Heats quickly

When I was steaming milk, the reservoir lid exploded from the pressure, splattering boiling water everywhere, including on me. I now have burns from it. This is a terrible design. For an entry level espresso maker, look for a pump system with a pressurized portafilter, such as a Delonghi.
title: Avoid--poor quality
bought_model: Color: CappuccinoStyle Name: 4-Cup Steam

review_content:
I was pissed when this things rubber gasket came off the top... then I realized it was removable by design. Good little design, I wouldn‚Äôt leave it on by accident too many times like you could with its forefathers. By the taste, I‚Äôd say there 50% less chinesium lead, which is nice if you want to make babies
Will report any catastrophes
title: Good little design
bought_model: Color: CappuccinoStyle Name: 4-Cup Steam

review_content: This machine works amazingly well. It's block heater has the H20 ready before you can place the coffee in the machine. A Cuban friend recommended "Cafe La Llave Ground Espresso Coffee" coffee (green label but definitely not decaffeinated) The 15 bar pressure produces coffee exactly like you find on the multi-thousand dollar commercial machines. They recommend you use a stainless container for milk frothing, and the Farberware Classic 5/8-Quart Butter Warmer with a pouring spout works very well. Steam heat the 2% milk longer than you may think watching the cold milk go through 3 stages coming out almost like whipped cream in part. We add a level tamped scoop of La LLave and fill a low profile 8 oz.coffee cup about 1/3 to 2/3 full. We add a rounded teaspoon of sugar and add the frothy hot milk. You must use a cappuccino grind as regular coffee blows the water right threw before proper extraction. We have tasted no "cafe con leche" or frothy cappuccino better anywhere, at any price. Although the water container is removable, we usually leave it in the machine thereby reducing the wear on the seal. When refilling, be careful not to pour the water on the hinges attached to the cover as water will show up on the counter perhaps leading to claims "the machine leaks"! (This is very easy to avoid) The steaming process expels excess water in the generous sized drip tray, so empty frequently or else "the machine leaks" (the drip tray is full) Please note the yellow sheet (top paragraph) for 1st time priming procedures. The combination coffee scoop/tamper is found on the bottom of the side foam packaging. It's light and could be thrown out unnoticed. To sum it up, you can't buy a better performing machine by spending more, even much more. We recommend using distilled water or reverse osmosis water for maintenance free use. Walmart sells distilled water dirt cheap. Enjoy! (We have been making about 6 cups a day for 3 months now with no problem whatsoever.)
title: Excellent Coffee
bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Automatic Dual Shot

review_content:
I got this machine for Christmas last year and I love it! It's nothing fancy, but it's so much better than spending $4 for a latte at the coffee shop. My recommendation to make this a great gift would be to also get a 12 oz frothing pitcher, 2 (two) espresso shot glasses, a bag of espresso, a grinder (if you buy whole bean espresso), and vanilla syrup (if the recipient likes vanilla lattes... if he/she likes skinny vanilla lattes, then get sugar free syrup). It comes with a tamper. You might also give them milk (or have it on hand) so lattes can be had immediately :) I received a grinder and a bag of espresso with my machine (which was awesome), but I bought the frothing pitcher, shot glasses and vanilla syrup soon after. I also bought a pretty soap dispenser that I put the vanilla in (so I can just pump vanilla into the latte) and a canister for my espresso - now I have a whole pretty setup!

One major tip if you're looking for an espresso maker: get a pump machine (NOT steam).
title: Create the perfect gift :)
bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Automatic Dual Shot

review_content: I just bought this machine tonight, albeit at Target instead of Amazon.com. The machine works quite well. It produced a thick crema that held sugar on top of it until I stirred it in. I'm not a coffee snob but my friend who is, after having lived in Italy for a few years, told me that the crema should hold sugar for at least a few seconds. It passed the test. I use Vergnanno espresso. It's delicious. My coffee snob friend has some Italian-made machine of which only a set number are made each year, and the espresso I made with this machine is comparable. He actually told me that if I bought a Mr. Coffee, he would come to my house to smash it because there was no way it could be any good. Turns out it does just fine. As the title of my review says, it's about the coffee quality. I know I would not receive the same results using lower grade espresso. The instructions were easy to follow. I suspect that some of the problems other reviewers had were a result of not taking care of the machine and following the directions. For the money, the machine was worth it.
title: It's all about the coffee quality...
bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Automatic Dual Shot

After 2 weeks of purchasing, there is no steam thru the Sprout. The steam itself builds up. But sprout does not give me any steam - so for all the froth lovers, no luck
I guess you get what you paid for.
title: Stopped working in a couple of weeks.
bought_model: Color: CappuccinoStyle Name: 4-Cup Steam

review_content:
I purchased this machine around 1 month ago. It lasted around 4 weeks before the milk frother stopped working and would only produce water not hot milk. So basically it now only produces espresso shots the milk function is completely useless, meaning no lattes or milk based drinks.

I contacted Mr Coffee who told me the warranty is only valid in America/Canada, I currently live in Singapore. So they're offering no help whatsoever despite that fact the unit broke after a few weeks of use.

Avoid buying one at all costs. There are clearly quality control issues and the lack of after sales support offered by Mr Coffee is pathetic. I have read numerous other reviews of units failing so i feel this is problem they know about but still continue to sell the product then offer very little after sales support.

Poor product, rubbish company. AVOID.
title: AVOID - poor product, rubbish company
