bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Espresso/Cappuccino Maker

review_content: I will never buy a Mr. Coffee product again.  I have to admit that it is fast and the coffee is good, but the portafilter has a habit of sliding open so that steam escapes and I was afraid it would totally come off and cause harm to me or someone else.  I cleaned out the area of the pot that it slides into and made sure the the rim was clear and it still happened, not once but quite a few times.  In trying to tighten it, the handle broke off.  Also, when the carafe is placed as shown in the picture, coffee splatters all over the place.  I solved this problem by always turning it so that the pour spout faced the rear of the machine.
title: I have to admit that it is fast and the coffee is good, but the portafilter has a habit of sliding ...
bought_model: Color: CappuccinoStyle Name: 4-Cup Steam

review_content:
I bought this machine in February 2010 at Target. I had reservations about buying a low end machine from a maker known for it's price point products. Not to worry. It has exceeded my expectations in every way. Everything worked perfectly out of the box.

The unit warms up in just a couple of minutes and makes nice espresso, assuming you are using a quality coffee to begin with. It produced adequate crema and has low suspended solids, so the portafilter is doing it's job. In my opinion, the espresso I get from the Mr. Coffee ECMP50 is better than I typically get from the coffee chain stores and nearly as good as the best from a recent trip to Northern Italy. Maybe with more experience, I can equal the Italian espresso experience... I think the machine is up to it.

The steamer works well for milk steaming and frothing. There may be better on the market, but this one has no obvious shortcomings. Well, maybe one.. the rubber tip of the frothing wand is not easy to remove for cleaning.

There is a "shelf" on the top which gets warm after 20 minutes or so and is a handy place for the tamper and other items. I suppose it would warm cups, but I'm not patient enough to turn it on a half hour before I need it.

It is quiet enough, but being a light weight unit, it vibrates when the pump is running, so you need to hold the cup(s) still while it is brewing. I solved the problem with a piece of rubber shelf/drawer liner. Shelf liner works great on the top shelf too.

I've had no leaks or other problems. I would recommend it and would buy another as it seems to be a terrific bargain which does what it is designed to do with excellence. I'll change my rating to 5 stars if it holds up for a year or so.
title: A bargain that works great
bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Automatic Dual Shot

review_content: Cute small machine. Frother is loud but i guess thats normal..wish it was quiet especially for those early mornings. Simple to use. Gets very steamy. Wish it came with milk compartment so i don't have to sit there and hold it up while frothing and steaming but you can get that for an additional $50 it seems seeing another product on this site. üòí also should have come with stainlesd steel pitcher.  Hate buying everything separately.

Makes delicious espresso and lattes but within less than a week the steamer is broke. I only used it once a day and the black plastic casing cracked within days of use. I am very upset about this since it was a mother's day present and I've been wanting this for such a long time. It's very disappointing.
UPDATE:
after 3 months the whole machine stopped working. It wont even turn on now to make espresso.

bought_model: Color: BlackStyle Name: Steam + Starter Set

review_content:
The first one I got had a piece that was broken because it was flimsy. I returned it and when I got the new one no matter how many times I cleaned/used the machine (with water and/or vinegar), the coffee taste like swimming pool toys...very chemical. I brewed 15 to 20 pots in order to hopefully get the smell/taste out and I feel it's getting stronger! Plus, the coffee isn't very thick and I bought high-quality espresso which I've wasted in this little machine.

You get what you pay for and what I'm getting is a refund. I implore you to just spend an extra $20 or $30 on a different brand. If you read this and you still buy it you're going to reflect and think to yourself, "I should've listened that guy."
title: Chemical taste won't go away. DONT BUY!!!
bought_model: Color: CappuccinoStyle Name: 4-Cup Steam

review_content: This was a great coffee maker that made an easy and delicious cappuccino... until it stopped working properly after only 18 months. My regular Cuisinart coffee maker has been working faithfully for more than 5 years and cost less than $100.  I expected more than 18 months of use from an appliance this expensive.  I will try another brand.

review_content:
This machine is incredibly easy to use. Other than the need to prime the machine, it can be used pretty much right out of the box. I love cappuccinos, and this machine makes amazing frothy milk. It takes about one minute to make a small cappuccino, and you can decide to add more froth to your drinks simply by holding the button for frothing yourself. This way, you can get the exact amount of froth you would want from the machine.

One con: it's a little concerning how loud the machine is when you prime it for it's first use. However, after having used this a few times, the noise level has decreased, and now it's much more enjoyable.

Pros: perfect for busy individuals who don't have time to manually hold their cups to froth milk. The most time you'll spend is putting the espresso in the machine and pushing the "on" button.
title: This machine is incredibly easy to use
bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Espresso/Cappuccino Maker

review_content:
It's a cheap espresso machine, so you get exactly what you pay for. It makes great lattes, but there's some design flaws.

The steamer handle is short so you can't reach the bottom of a normal sized cup.

It takes a while to switch from the espresso to the steamer, and the little button/nob combo is annoying.

It will literally vibrate your cup off of the platform and spill everywhere so definitely keep an eye on it.

For coffee I use Cafe Bustello in the little bright yellow can from Walmart. Perfect taste and grind. I've tried a variety and that one gets the best response from anyone served, plus the price is good.

PS. Don't forget to aim the little milk spout into your cup! I did that twice.
title: This is what you need
bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Espresso/Cappuccino Maker

review_content:
I only use this to make Americano. It works well and simply. Discard the frother and milk reservoir (milk in coffee!) you won't need that. Throw out the cup height adjusting tray, you will want to fit in a 10 ounce, wide cup. Start with your 10 ounce cup in place and the Porta-Filter attached without a Filter. Press and hold the Espresso button and the machine will deliver about 5 ounces of hot water. Remove the Porta-Filter and install your properly filled 2-Cup Filter. Again press and hold the Espresso button and watch the Espresso as it fills your 10 ounce cup to the brim! You've now got the Americano you've been looking for. You only need to remember to clean the loose grains of coffee from the underside of the brew head before your next cup. ENJOY!
Please de-lime the unit often, this is my second machine as I neglected to perform this vital operation the first time.
title: Americano, Clean and Simple

review_content:
Well I love my current espresso machine...

First one gave first steam and then never worked again... HAVE NO CLUE WHY... we were EXTREMELY careful... followed each step to the letter... because they said was crucial... but it would not brew or steam after first steam prime...

UP SIDE IS AMAZON WAS WONDERFUL... we had waited weeks to try the espresso maker for the first time because we were reading how and wanted enough time to do it right... we are REALLY REALLY busy... so we once we had a morning to devote to doing it right... it died... almost immediately... we tried everything before calling it... nothing worked

I contacted AMAZON with my tale of woe and disappointment at thwarting our starbucks addiction and they sent a replacement within 24 hours free 2 day shipping... NO QUESTIONS NO HASSLE... I was VERY VERY impressed... no better service at sacs 5th ave... the customer is always right attitude... greatly APPRECIATED THAT. this was daughter's Christmas present and she was devastated ANNNNNYWAY....

Second one works amazingly well... only issue is that it was dirty and obviously used return from someone else... BUT the coffee/latte/frother was SOOOOOOO cool and works so well... we decided not to complain and clean it up and keep it.

I never drank coffee before... just chi lattes green tea lattes... (which you can also do with this because of frother) this machine makes great starbucks replacements much less expensively and what I like most is that YOU have complete control over ingredients... you control what kind of milk... what kind of sweeteners... the coffee itself... you know what you are putting in your body and I think and my daughter agrees these are just as good as a starbucks with more variety on what goes in them.

I would not necessarily go mr coffee again... I might try the brand that starts with a D they seem more reliable with about same cost... but I will definitely continue to buy with increased confidence at amazon.
title: First one died after first steam Sudden Espresso Death syndrome I guess
bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Automatic Dual Shot

review_content:
I have owned at least 6 espresso or combo espresso/coffee machines over the years. At first, most of them have worked ok (some better than others). I've had machines that cost $300 down to $99. This machine, in particular with the frothing component, is by far the best machine I've ever owned. I am particular, I only use Illy coffee. It tastes beautiful and smooth coming from this machine. Some other machines burnt it. And the frothed milk is glorious!!!

I waited until I owned the machine at least 6 months, using it about 10x a week, to make sure it lasted before writing this review. It works so well, still, that I'm buying another one to have in the event this one ever breaks. I wouldn't be able to live without it!

review_content:
Apparently I'm the only one who had a bad experience but take it from me, this thing's flat out weak. It doesn't come with a tamper or metal steaming pitcher (as mentioned in other reviews) and hello- those are two rather important aspects of a proper espresso extraction and milk steaming. Sure, you can use a little plastic cup or spice jar, anything round with a flat base and small enough to fit within the filter to compact the grounds... but a heavy metal tamp really works best (30 lbs is the proper/preferred pressure that should be applied to a dosed shot prior to extraction). The instructions tell you to "gently press down" using the scoop provided which is just ridiculous, considering it does absolutely nothing. Incase anyone noticed, there are still DRY GROUNDS in the filter basket from your supposedly extracted shot. You don't see them on top when you first look into the filter but go ahead and dump the extracted grounds into your sink and take a look; you'll find perfectly dry, untouched grounds among the wet. So you aren't even getting all that you can from your coffee - its literally being wasted right from the get-go. BIG ISSUE.

On to the steam wand - this puppy just simply sucks. You can't use it to steam while brewing/pulling a shot, you have to wait until after its done, then wait for the machine to cool/release pressure because you have to remove the top to add in more water in order to steam. Don't dare try and remove the back cap immediately after brewing or the built-up pressure will spit at you like wildfire and likely scald your hands/arms/etc. due to such high temperature (its hot enough to burn you but is nowhere near a solid 200¬∞ where it really should be for optimal extraction).

The steam wand comes with a ridiculous rubberized tip on it called a steaming/frothing "aid" that doesn't help or aid you in anything whatsoever - just spits the milk up, out and everywhere inbetween. The wand doesn't even begin to exert force or push out steam for a good ten-fifteen seconds, its like you have to wait for the little thing to heat up which is annoying because your so-called shot is siting there getting cold. The pressure isn't strong enough to stretch and airrate the milk, get it to 'whirl pool' when steaming, nor thicken it to proper latter or cappuccino thickness, it just pushes the milk around and adds big bubbles which are exactly what you don't want.

One last thing-- to put on and lock the filter and filter holder in place, you have to hold onto the little machine with one hand because it weighs practically nothing and feels incredibly cheap. Looks/design of it are so-so.

I know it was a cheapie ($39.00) but was so hopeful that I'd be impressed and proven wrong, especially considering the great reviews but I'm just left annoyed and on the hunt for something that'll live up to my standards without costing an arm and a leg.
title: Dissatisfied and Decaffeinated
bought_model: Color: CappuccinoStyle Name: 4-Cup Steam

review_content:
I bought the cheapest Mr.Coffee Expresso maker at Walmart years ago; so many years ago that it was under $30 otd with tax. I also bought their bean grinder for $8. It took a while to figure out that all you need to do in order to get a superbly delightful cup every time is to do exactly what the manufacturer recommends. If you don't- THAT'S when you have trouble with the common complaints listed here.

Yes- mine leaked at first. It took a while to figure out that I had over ground the beans, and this little steam only machine didn't pack the wallop needed to force the steam through the grind when I did that.

If you set the Mr. Coffee grinder to the "fine" setting and shake the grinder every few seconds while it does its thing, the grind comes out a bit coarse compared to most "expresso" grinds. Grinding for an additional 2-3 seconds doesn't hurt, but if you do what I did for the first year or so and over grind the coffee beans till they are powderized like flour, all you'll end up with is a half cup of still nice coffee and a counter covered in hot water.

It seems many who have written reviews of the Mr. Coffee products have blamed the machine, and not their own presumtuous ideas about how to use it. It strikes me as odd how there is still this ongoing narrative that anything produced by an American company is inferior to the foreign equivalent. This started with Japanese cars in the 70's when there may have been some truth to the claim, but the fact is that despite having no personal spiritual faith, a great many people these days sure have great faith in foreign manufacturers, even after Honda's recent problem with deadly air bags, or Toyota's accelerator issues. And as far as value goes- the new Avalon is about the size of a ten year old Corolla. Toyota lovers claim that's because it gets better mileage that way but if I want mileage I'll buy a scooter not a $50k luxury car.
title: Don't Blame Mr. Coffee

review_content: Ok so i got this espresso maker at target for only $25. coffee is one of my favorite things and i drink it all the time. For only $25, i didn't care if it was going to be crappy or not. To my surprise, it has worked really well. Its really easy to use- an 8 year old could work this thing. I went up to starbucks and got a $10 bag of their dark roast espresso and its seriously amazing. Ive made hot mochas, frappucinos and countless other drinks that have been almost as good if not better than starbucks. I would definitely recommend this cheap machine to anyone who asks. The only thing i didnt like was that it did not come with one of those frothing pitchers. But hey, you can't get everything in life and for $25 i honestly could care less. Hopefully it will hold up well over the next few years cause i'm gonna put this bitch to work.

review_content:
I got this and followed all the directions...the coffee was thin - about as thin as drip coffee - had a weird, harsh metallic taste to it. I don't know why. I varied it by adding more coffee and tamping more firmly, but the results were the same: no crema, watery and foul.

The steam wand is a little short, but does a good job overall. If you have a small enough pitcher, you can froth milk pretty well with it. But, when I combined the milk with the coffee (which was thin and tasted weird), the results were lackluster. For me at least, the entire point of owning an espresso machine was to make ESPRESSO with it.

On the other hand, reviewers here had better results, so it's possible that I just got a defective machine. I might keep it now that I have it just for the steam wand, but I'll stick to my Aeropress for the coffee.
title: The steam is great; the "espresso" . . . not so much
bought_model: Color: CappuccinoStyle Name: 4-Cup Steam

review_content:
OK. Not too long ago one could spend $40 for a real espresso machine. Real. Having a pump. This is really more of a drip coffee maker working off of a little pressure from boiling. Espresso grind in a drip maker will work better than this machine as it will not get the water over the burn point of the beans, but you can't steam the milk that way. If you like espresso, I mean can taste coffee as well as you can store-bought wine or the difference between 2 different varieties of apples, then you will NOT like the results of this. The coffee will most likely come out burned if you are making "4 cups". By the way, the cord is so short that the GFCI can short out when releasing the steam. So short that with deep counters, you may have to reach a ways.

On the other hand, if you don't care about taste too much and just want a cheap machine that can also froth milk, go for it! Seriously. Some times there is nothing better than a cup of strong joe with a bunch of milk.

title: It is very nice espresso maker.
bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Automatic Dual Shot

review_content:
I bought this machine after spending a large amount of time enjoying coffee bar drinks at the typically hefty price-tag. I was glad to find that I could brew my favorite drink all month for the cost of 6 cups of cappuccino or so at my local coffee store. This machine has a bit of a learning curve, but it is generally simple and works well if you follow instructions meticulously. the most important things I felt should be noted:

- A real tamp is CRUCIAL to making good espresso with this machine, but not included.
- Same goes for frothing pitcher and a thermometer to know when your steamed milk is ready, ABSOLUTELY REQUIRED.
- You should run a full pot of water through before brewing espresso in order to warm the drink.
- The pressurized lid can be hard to grip when producing a beverage, especially if you screw it in backwards or "overscrew" the lid. (My biggest complaint, the knobs are simply much too big rounded and clumsy for the size of the actual machine. It does not make sense from a design point of view considering how quickly things need to be engaged in order to pull the best possible beverage. Keep dry rags handy, and if you see steam rising from the knob do not feel tempted to twist it shut quickly: at that point it's scalding hot and you will simply have to turn off the machine and wait for things to settle down.)
- The machine needs a 5-6 "warmup" sessions before the materials within the water tank cease having an odd factory odor (I don't think I tasted anything in the actual drink, but the protruding "plastic" scent was rather odd.)
- Be sure to give all those knobs a few hard turns to break it in as well.

That being said it's a lot of fun grinding and tamping my coffee beans into a surprisingly refined and great tasting drink. It's a slow and quirky process. Novelty set aside I can barely discern Mr.Coffee's espresso from what I get at the coffee store.
title: A very cool, cheap, and (fundamentally) efficient American steam espresso machine!

review_content: Apparently, there is a big difference between steam-powered machines (which this is) and pump-driven machines. Any benefits? Yes: it works quickly and is not too loud. And you can make a few cups at a time, rather than the 1 or 2 cups of most espresso machines. Live and learn.

review_content: I've always liked a cup of cappuccino or a latte from Starbucks. Obviously nothing high-end, and one day I saw the ECMP160 at Target on sale for $49. I've always wanted my own machine and bought it on a whim. I was able to make some decent lattes and cappuccinos with it, at least as good as Starbucks, but that's not saying much. Over the next few months I developed a taste for espresso and just couldn't make it at home with the ECM160, which is steam driven. After doing a lot of research on [...] and [...], I had my sights set on a Bezzera BZ07 and a Vario Baratza grinder, which come to around $1500. I was surfing through youtube and saw someone making an espresso with the ECMP50 and it looked really good, so I bought it here on Amazon for $65. I've been buying my coffee from Terroir Coffee, already ground, and with this machine it makes a fantastic espresso, great crema, as good as any of the high end coffee shops I've tried. I am (temporarily) over my lust for a prosumer machine, but time will tell.

review_content: This is a total disaster. I bought for my son's cabin when we were expecting guests, I tested it before I took it to the cabin. It was rocky but I chalked it up to operator error (leaking water, failure to brew). When our guests arrived, I offered them a cup of java - what a mess. The reservoir leaked so badly I had a 4 foot puddle on the floor after the first cup and needed to add additional water. Three of us checked to make sure it was properly seeded and it still continued to leak. After brewing a cup and removing the porta-filter, water continued to stream out of the machine so I had to put a cup to catch it. Unfortunately, one of my helpers disposed of the box as we were packing up so I could not return it. I normally do not write reviews but this was the worst appliance purchase I have ever made and would hope this review will save others the expense and frustration. I strongly suggest that you look at another brand.
title: Total Disaster

review_content:
What do you call an espresso machine that can't make espresso?
You call it the Mr. Coffee Automatic Dual Shot Espresso/Cappuccino System, ECMP50.

When putting in the portafilter to pull a tasty, tasty espresso shot, the group head (which "unscrews" in the same direction and distance as the portafilter when putting it in) becomes unattached and unusable... as you can see in the picture I provided.

So.. in short, It broke on the first day.... It earned 1 star because for a few moments, I DID have dreams of making myself a latte, but more importantly, it earned 1 star because I cannot give it a "0," which is the same number of mornings I got to enjoy a homemade latte.

However, if you like getting your hopes well up, and then quickly and thoroughly crushed, this is the best disappointment machine on the market.
title: I'll have a double-shot of dissapointment, please.
bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Automatic Dual Shot

review_content: Easy to use after unpacking. I am not a barista, or whatever, so my review is written for the regular person without fancy coffee terminology.  I read up a bunch on what to buy, with a budget up to $300, and I kept coming back to this Mr. Coffee product.  Yeah, surprised me, too. Just fill it with water, load your espresso (I do the double), turn it on, wait for the lights on the front to go solid, press the caf√© button, and turn the nob on the side to pour out how much you want. I do 2 oz. pull, but you can do more, or you can do less, its up to you. No auto shut off, so you have to stop the pull yourself.  I like that feature. Good and silky coffee cream from the 15 bars of pressure, and it is fast!. Okay, so the residue is a little saucy and not some steamed-out dry puck, but don't listen to the whiners. A quick rinse under the faucet, and voila, all clean!  The only downside is that because it is so light (and certainly no rubber feet would help) you need to hold it when you load and unload your espresso. If it was made of solid stainless and brass and weighed 10lbs+ with rubber feet, then it would be amazing, but of course, it would cost a lot more. So, do you want a great 2 oz. pull from a machine you have to hold on to for, I don't know, say half a second x 2, or do you wanna spend $600 bucks so you don't have to hold it?
title: Gets the job right done for a lot less!

review_content:
Summary: This espresso maker is simply for the budget minded. I say that because it doesn't make high quality espresso, BUT it makes it good enough to satisfy most. The package comes with everything minus the cup, coffee, and water, though I will say the scoop-tamper design is nice for scooping, but doesn't do well as a tamper. I went out and bought a third party tamper and called it a day.

The positives of this unit are the price first and foremost. It's not too high and the device is pretty reliable. In addition it's easy to use and steps are easy to understand. And ultimately, it's a pretty quick machine at what it does. From a cold state, it'll brew 4 shots of espresso in about 5 minutes.

The negatives are quite a few... For starters the unit lacks an auto-off feature. So you're best to sit close when using it. The cool-down time is a bit longer than most espresso makers I've used (but for a single user it's not a big deal). In order to froth milk, you're best to brew first (Even if it's only brewing water) or you'll sit there for quite some time waiting on the water in the reservoir to get hot enough. The frother is a bit low, to the point where I had to position my machine on the corner of the counter to be able froth with a normal coffee cup.

Other notes: If you buy an after market tamper, don't use too much pressure, the compressed grounds will create a block and pressure will build up and you'll have hot wet grounds spread across your counter-top AND in the water reservoir. The power cord can be a bit short for some, it's just over 12" long.

Noted regarding other reviews: I've been using this machine at least 5 days a week for the past 4 months and it's been working just fine for me. I've had zero issues, aside from the day I compressed the grounds a bit too much with the tamper.
The machine is not at all great, but for most it will suffice your desires for espresso. If you're an espresso enthusiast or you're particular about your espresso, you should avoid this and purchase a real deal espresso maker.
title: Inexpensive and easy to use budget espresso maker with frother.
bought_model: Color: CappuccinoStyle Name: 4-Cup Steam

review_content:
If i could rate this higher than 5 stars, I would. I am an entry level espresso drinker. I am switching away from drinking brewing drip coffee in favor of espresso so this machine was a great starter. Out of the box, this machine was super easy to assemble and the instructions were pretty clear on how to prime it. I gave it a quick wipe down before priming just to ensure that it was actually clean.

I brew about 6-8 shots of espresso a day; some are straight shots and some are utilizing the cappuccino option. Not once has this thing failed when used correctly. It comes with a list of drinks that you can make that are very simple and not at all daunting to a beginner. The only thing I don't like about this machine is the knob to adjust the foam/steamed milk is fairly unpredictable. The first brew of something after a long while is excessively foamy regardless of the selector being all the way to the left (latte.) After that first brew though its pretty consistent. Additionally, I would advise a better tamper (thing that you use to press the espresso down) the perfect size would be a 51mm. For a beginner, I HIGHLY recommend this machine. It puts just the right amount of responsibility in your hands and still delivers a high quality drink.
title: Easily the best entry level automatic machine on the market
bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Espresso/Cappuccino Maker

review_content:
We bought this back in February, and it was terrific for about the first six months. It made some of the best coffee either my wife or I ever had, the foaming function worked really well. If not for the following, we'd give it four or five stars.

But.

In September, it stopped working properly. One of the neat things about it is that it will automatically brew one or two shots of espresso, as well as as much as you want, up to about a full 8 oz. cup. Well, it is neat until that's the ONLY thing it will do, regardless of whether you pick one or two shots. It made a lot of messes, and it was still under warranty, so we called Mr. Coffee (Jarden Customer Service), and they said all they needed was a proof of purchase and they'd send us a new one, no problem. They didn't even want the old one back.

Except it was a problem. I called them a few days after we sent them the Amazon invoice, they said they never received it. So we sent it again. And Again. Each time, we asked them to include some kind of acknowledgement that they received the email, and we heard nothing. Finally, I wrote them a fourth email nearly a month after we'd originally sent the invoice telling them that we'd sent the invoice to them several times and had heard nothing from them, and we needed to know what was going on. It was about this time they responded to our FIRST email--the one they said they never got--and said that the replacement was on its way.

We got that one early this month (October), and it worked well--until a couple of days ago; now it simply will not turn on at all. So, call Jarden Customer Service again.

Now, they want us to ship the now-defective replacement with a shipping label that will be emailed to me...in 3-5 weeks, because of the system they use (for what it's worth, the woman I talked to seemed to sympathize with me on how ridiculous this system is). Once I get that label around Thanksgiving, I should call them after 24 hours after we ship it so they can put it into their system. Then, presumably, they'll start the process of shipping us a replacement machine that will no doubt arrive around April Fool's Day, because why not, and will operate, if the trend holds, for approximately 27:45.

I'll consider revising my review depending on how they resolve this, but right now the fact of the matter is that product doesn't last, and Mr. Coffee / Jarden is completely indifferent to taking care of their customers. This machine is expensive enough as it is, and if you have the opportunity to buy another 15-bar pressurized espresso machine from a reputable manufacturer, take it. You'll actually be able to use it for a while.
title: Machines Keep Breaking, and Jarden Keeps Taking Their Time Making It Right
bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Espresso/Cappuccino Maker

review_content: All I can say is WOW. Now, that's a cup of java! I'm impressed. I was hoping it would live up to the positive reviews; I wasn't disappointed. The frother works way better than I had expected. As another reviewer had strongly recommend, I primed and then cleaned the system with 1/2 tank straight white vinegar followed by flushing with a full tank clean water before the first use to assure all manufacturing lubricants and impurities were properly removed to achieve the best quality brew possible. I did invest in some high quality beans (Lavazza Espresso Super Crema) as well as a metal temper and ground my beans fresh with a decent coffee grinder I already owned. The results were wonderful. I had to experiment to find the right balance of espresso and cappuccino that  gave me  the strength and body I was looking for but once accomplished, just add syrup, sweetener,  and/or the extract flavoring  of your choice and you have a coffee drink that rivals Starbucks (at a fraction of the price!). Yum. The automatic clean cycle also makes clean up pretty easy and quick.  The unit is fairly simple to operate and doesn't take a rocket scientist to figure out. Goodbye plain ol' cup of joe, hello smooth, yummy coffee house creation! My only gripe with this unit is the ridiculously short power cord. I had to use an extension cord to reach a nearby outlet. By the way, I'd advise that you wait for a sale. I purchased 3 days ago at $140 but today it's all the way up to $I87, my word! I guess I lucked out and bought just in the nick of time. This is a definite buy though, an excellent machine worth investing in.
title: Mr. Coffee Cafe Barista Premium Espresso and Cappuccino System
bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Espresso/Cappuccino Maker

review_content:
So, you love lattes and cappuccinos, maybe a shot of espresso in your iced coffee, but you don't really like hitting up Starbucks every time you want them? Well this guy will get you going without breaking the bank, and with a little research on using it, you will surprise yourself in no time.

I read up for quite some time before choosing this machine. I am very pleased with it's performance thus far, and have had almost no issues pulling nice strong shots of espresso or frothing milk. I make frappuccinos, lattes, cappuccinos, and iced coffee regularly with this machine.

Accessories you may need will be a food grade coffee thermometer, and a stainless steel frothing cup (both not included) Optional are espresso or cappuccino cups.

Unit comes with 2 filter baskets, you will only use the large one.

Most espresso grinds like Lavazza and Starbucks brew fine and the grind is quite small. (The grind is important for espresso quality)

Brew as much or little as you like, hand controlled shot allows you to stop brewing when your ready to increase or decrease strength overall.

My tips for using this machine is to go online and watch a review. Don't over pack your coffee puck, think lighter pack. This has caused some people to complain in the past. I have had no issues of a bad shot due to under or over packing so far.

Frothing milk, first and foremost, remove the little rubber thing on the steam tube, you can't get a good froth with that thing, plus it's harder to clean. It will go back on but it's hard to get there, so plan on leaving it off. This aids in cleaning the tube with a hot rag after steaming.

Remember to remove the little tray and rinse after use, some steam may be released into this pan after use to relieve pressure from the unit.

Pro:

Heats up fast
Takes little room on counter overall, with storage for cups and accessories on top of machine
Pulls good shots for average coffee connoisseur and makes a good froth
large reservoir holds enough water for several uses
Well known brand and available at many retailers
15 bar pump (rare in this price range)

Cons:

Some cleaning required after use (this is anything right?)
Doesn't hold as much coffee as more professional machines so strength may not be acceptable for the pro's

Overall impression. This little guy packs a punch, and easily adds a degree of gourmet to your coffee time. Whether hosting a get together, or just enjoying a cup in the morning or afternoon, this little machine is guaranteed to please. It's simple controls and user friendly design will quickly have most anyone making their own coffee drinks at home. Makes a great gift for a coffee fanatic.

Don't forget your flavored syrups and sauces to make copies of your favorite coffee shop flavors right at home. Instructions on these drinks are available all over the interwebs :-)
title: A real surprise for any coffee fanatic!
bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Automatic Dual Shot

review_content:
Very nice device as long as you keep in mind the price range and what you should use it for. For beginners, don't get too caught up in the snobbery of it all. I used fresh beans + burr grinder as normal and got a good shot, and used scissors to cut open a Kcup and used those grounds and thought it tasted even better.

As long as you use this to make the right thing, you'll be very happy. The way I use it is as follows: put a half spoon of creamer in a small espresso teacup, and pull the shot and enjoy the nice little cuban coffee type drink, and it tastes amazing. However, since the espresso it makes isn't super boiling temp, if you try to make starbucks type lattes you'll be disappointed with the taste (it'll be lukewarm.) This is due to one thing- the milk frother is awful. I avoid using it.

Cons: portafilter twist requires superhuman strength to twist fully, so I just twist only halfway and it remains perfectly tight and fine. Feels very plasticky and moves on counter easily.

Overall: makes a good, buzzy shot of espresso quickly and easily. Stick to making cuban coffee type drinks(small shot of espresso w/ smaller amount of milk/sugar) and don't expand much out of that range and you'll be happy. If you like frothed milk, buy a separate milk frother

review_content: i am writing this as i sip on my earl-grey-steam i somewhat cautiously made with my mr. coffee espresso machine, and overall i must say i am impressed. judging from previous reviews, this product is something you will either love for the reasonable price or hate because it just straight-up exploded in your face.  take my review with a grain of salt, as i have yet to actually make an espresso yet so i can't comment on the flavor of espresso it produces  (haven't had a chance to go to the store), but i have run water through the machine for my tea and i have used the steaming wand to froth milk for my steamers.  so far i have had a very pleasant first impression with this little machine.  though it doesn't swivel like the one i used to use as a barista, the steaming wand is easy to use, strong, and is capable of producing very frothy milk if that is what you're after-perfect for dry capps. i didn't bother buying a stainless steel pitcher to steam my milk in and instead just steam it right in my coffee mug before adding my tea, which i would recommend doing in order to save yourself $10.  also, because the steaming wand is so short i imagine one could potentially have an issue getting it to reach the milk in the bottom of a normal pitcher anyways. it is extremely lightweight, which could be taken as a pro or con, though personally i would prefer something that feels a little bit sturdier. initially i was terrified to use this machine after reading reviews saying their machine literally exploded in front of them, sending shards of glass flying (it seems that the pressure from the machine propels a tray from behind the pitcher out, causing the pitcher to violently shatter). this could be due to loose/cheaps screws used to hold the machine together, or because the pressure has not been properly released after each use. but as they say, an ounce of protection equals a pound of care, so i never stand directly in front of the machine while it's plugged in. oh, the things we do for caffiene. :)
title: Caffiene is love, caffiene is life.

review_content:
Good espresso maker. It make strong coffee. I tried cleaning it with vinegar but could not get rid of the smell. The smell does not affect the taste though. If you fill coffee grind and water to the 4 cup mark, then stop the machine from brewing below half of the actual cup size (2 cup) for good tasting coffee. Letting the machine make coffee above the half way mark will result in bitter coffee.

update: still a good machine but i usually pour the water above 4 cup mark. Then let the machine run until the water that came out is hot. usually 1/4 a cup of cold water run through the machine before the water became hot. I turned the machine off, put in the coffee and start brewing. I listened to the reviewer who use soap to removed the smell and it seem to work. For first time user of the machine, use vinegar to get rid of the chemicals, then use soap to wash the smell away.

Update(12/15/2016): I was turning the dial on the machine and it broke off with little to no effort. The plastic bar inside the machine could not handle the heat. This was not even 6 months of use. Cheap products stay away.

title: It's great! The espresso it brews is of course not ...

review_content:
I got mine back in July 2014. What prompted me to write a review is because it starts to lose its pressure after 1 year of light use.
It was the cheapest automatic espresso+froth maker in the market, and it worked great!
It was very easy to use. Just put milk in the milk reservoir, pack the coffee in the espresso portafilter, with a press of button, you'll get a cup of espresso drink as good as Starbucks can make. (still a distance away from some finer coffee shop, in my opinion.)
It's easy to clean, too. After you are done, just load the mile reservoir with water and it'll clean itself.

We regularly make a cup or two everyday for the last year. Recently we noticed after making espresso, water remains trapped in portafilter. Usually it will be really hot and dry as the hot steam pushes all the water out. It is the first sign we noticed about the machine losing pressure. Then soon after we start see the milk frother "getting stuck", which you can hear the pump attempting to draw milk and froth it but nothing coming out. At this point we have to prime the machine with water first to get the pressure up and prime the internal parts to get the milk froth.

We are pretty good at running water through after using the machine, so it may be more than just having buildups in the tubing inside.
We still use it but just less frequent due to the hassle of priming and cleaning and the mediocre coffee it makes now.
I guess now the question is if this machine last 1 year and the more expensive machine with 5x the price last 5 years, which one should you get?
title: Great for the first year, now it's just ok.
bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Espresso/Cappuccino Maker

review_content:
I got this looking for an affordable espresso machine that was fast enough my husband could use it in the morning before work, even though he's a get up and leave sort of guy. He says the coffee is good and it only takes a few minutes, most of which is hands free.

It takes this about 2 minutes to heat up, which can be avoided by putting it on an automated timer to turn on before you wake up. You can prep it the night before with grounds, place a cup under it, fill the water reservoir and milk (store in fridge until morning) then all you have to do in the morning is press a button, walk away, do your other morning stuff and within 5 minutes, you've got your favorite coffee shack snack sans the like $7 a cup price tag. We even buy the ghirdelli chocolate for mochas in 30 lb bags here on amazon to cut costs further.

(I did time this, warm up ~2 min, large latte ~2 min to done, so without timer 4 minutes to done, with auto-on timer 2 minutes!)

It's easy to clean, and for the price, the closest you'll get to an automatic espresso machine on a timer.

Setup note: Don't forget to remove the plastic cover from the water reservoir.
title: Great for non-morning people

review_content:
This machine is a lifesaver. I worked as a barista for years in college and got used to having free espresso drinks whenever I wanted. However, when I got a non-coffee providing job I needed to find a way to get my coffee snob fix on a college budget. This was the machine I could afford, and it has far exceeded my expectations!

The "tamper" is useless, go ahead and buy a better quality one. The steamer, though slow, creates really beautiful, velvety, milk that is full of microfoam and capable of producing latte art. And the espresso (obviously the most important part) that it makes tastes pleasant with nice crema. The larger cup for coffee grounds does not quite brew two full shots, so keep that in mind when making your drinks.

I only wish that I could pull a shot and steam milk simultaneously. But, for the price, I have no complaints for this machine!

bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Espresso/Cappuccino Maker

review_content:
I finally got my first cup brewed after spending an hour on the instructions (I try to always be thorough the first time) and everything ran just fine. Luckily, I felt like trying the machine fully tonight and thus I was going to make a cappuccino. I followed all the instructions, however, once I got to the part where the milk is supposed to froth into the cup, to my surprise...it never did. I re-read the instructions and noted that I followed everything. I even chose to just do froth again manually to see if I could get something to come out, but at last no avail. My cup was froth milkless. I went onto the Mr. Coffee product support and looked it up there and there was still no answer, it was basically the instructional booklet all over again. Myself being an engineer decided to take a step back and look for something missing. And then it hit me, there was no straw for the milk to be pulled up into, luckily I had not thrown that piece away. In shipping they had installed the piece into the metal piece that the milk comes out, I had originally thought it was an extra guide for the milk, but before I had received the machine I had watched a couple of videos on it and noted that the straw was not used there. I then took the straw and inserted it into the bottom of the cap where the milk is stored, hit the froth manually again, and wallah frothed milk came out. So please note to NOT throw that piece away if it is not installed where it should be, the instructions never tell you to install it.
I gave the machine 5 stars because the machine worked perfectly and its nice that I don't have to manually froth my milk. As I type this review, I am enjoying my cappuccino.

Pros
-Hands off Frothing
-Instructions display the amount of ounces expected to dispense
-Recipe booklet included
-Water reservoir (that has enough storage for multiple uses)
-Milk reservoir
-Auto frothing/steaming milk
-Compact

Cons
-Failed to mention any straw for the milk reservoir (even in the part by part display). See the story above if you are confused of why you aren't getting frothed/steamed milk.

I will updated again after a couple weeks of using it, but I can tell if the piece is durable, I will enjoy it :).
title: Excellent Espresso machine, however there is a step missing from the instructions...
bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Espresso/Cappuccino Maker

review_content:
This is my third Mr. Coffee espresso machine, first one on sale on an end cap at the local Meijer store. When it died (got two or three years out of it), I bought another. It was the economy model and I thought it made a good brew. It died last week, and I decided to look at one that would do more, so I bought this model. I read the reviews carefully, and was very glad I did. Read The Rancher's Wife's review. It is what sold me on this machine. I followed her instructions exactly, including cleaning it with vinegar before using it the first time, which is not in the instruction manual. She called the company when she wasn't getting the performance she wanted from her new machine, and they told her to do the vinegar wash right away. Too bad that isn't in the instructions in priming the unit. I could tell that it was taking longer to produce a cup after the vinegar cleaning. This is GOOD! It means it was heating better. Go to her review for why that is important.

So after doing the vinegar clean and then making sure I had all of the vinegar residue gone, I FINALLY made my first cup. Absolutely fantastic! Same coffee I always use, only difference was the machine, and it was a perfect double shot! Rich, great flavor, nice crema. This machine is a winner, and I am happy, happy, happy! And the price is fantastic! (Hint: buy the four year warranty.)
title: Happy, happy, happy!
bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Espresso/Cappuccino Maker

review_content:
I've spent a couple thousand bucks on new kitchen appliances this year, and hit the jackpot with my $40 espresso maker. I'm a sucker for stainless steel products, and this one looks and feels like a $200 machine, and I would've paid it too...

It may not be pump-driven, but the taste is not burnt and the speed is more than sufficient. What more could one ask for? I'm a Starbucks goer, and this machine fulfills that craving. Please note, I'm not a yuppie taste connoisseur, but I know good coffee/espresso when I'm drinking it, and the taste is more than satisfactory. Let's put it this way, I'm not shopping anymore for an espresso maker, my mind is mentally content with this machine. I have no reason to upgrade...

I'm using this primarily as an espresso maker, but I did use the frothing tool to release the pressure from the machine, and it works sufficiently. The longer I leave the machine on brew when the steaming is complete (extra 30-40 seconds), the more pressure will build and the better frothing capabilities.

I'm using a protein measuring cup as a tamper, and it works just fine. The cost of a tamper is nearly 40% of the cost of the machine! Hmm???

I don't know what else to tell you about this machine besides putting water & extra bold grounds into it. I'm satisfied I bought it, and can make multiple brews of espresso in less time and money it takes me to drive the 15 blocks to my local Starbucks.
title: Spend the $40, then donate the remaining $200 to the charity of your choice...

review_content:
I recently purchased the ECMP50 and have been playing with it for only a few days. I've been very pleased with the espresso it makes, though I wish the unit was a little taller with a longer steam wand, so as to better fit the frothing pitcher I already had. At a mere 4" tall, my current pitcher is too deep for the steam wand to reach deep enough to properly heat the milk. A minor inconvenience for now.

However, this review is about "the leak". A lot of reviewers here have reported having leakage problems. Right out of the box, I, too, experienced water leaking from the unit. For the record, the leakage is not from an overflowing drip pan (as some non-leakers have implied) Rather the leaking is coming from the point where the valve assembly of the water tank fits into the base of the machine. Picture a plug fitting into a hole. The "hole" has an o-ring which is intended to seal around the "plug" of the water tank as it fits down into the machine.

When the tank is seated into the machine, the valve is always open, in order to feed the machine water as needed. Unfortunately, the o-ring lining the hole does not seem to seal well enough as to keep water inside the machine from draining back out once brewing and steaming has ended and you've turned-off the machine. The result is that water leaks back past the o-ring and out between the water tank and the seat it sits on. The water ends up spilling out between the two and onto your countertop (and under the machine itself, which can be mistaken for water leaking out of the bottom itself.)

I have tried a very simple (and cheap) fix which, so far, seems to be working to keep the machine from leaking. I went to my local hardware store and got a container of Plumber's Silicone Grease. It's non-toxic and can be used in places where it might come into contact with drinking water. All I did was smear a small dab of the stuff over the o-ring in the hole of the base of the machine. You don't have to glob it on. Just a light smear.

So far, this seems to have cured my leaking problem (of course, as soon as I post this review, my countertop will be flooded.)
title: For those experiencing the leak...
bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Automatic Dual Shot

review_content: If you are using this machine to make caps or lattes do not waste your money. The milk frother does not work properly. There is not enough pressure/steam left in the machine after brewing the espresso to froth or even warm the milk. I used a 12 ounce frothing pitcher with about 5 ounces of milk in it and it wouldn't even warm the milk let alone froth it. I had to pour more water in the reservoir in order to froth milk which takes extra time and effort. So after you brew your espresso it sits there getting cold while you fart around cleaning the grounds out of the filter and reassembling the whole thing again just to brew hot water in order to get enough pressure/steam to froth your milk. I owned this same machine several years ago and it worked great. If you read reviews like I do and judge the worthiness of purchasing a particular product by the reviews, pay attn to the year the review was written. Today is December 10, 2014 and I am on my way to UPS right now to return this crappy machine. You get what you pay for folks. Two reviewers also said this machine malfunctioned to the point where one person got burned and another had his machine blow up! Yikes! Sorry Mr Coffee :-(

review_content:
This is not a machine with lots of bells and whistles, but it is perfectly serviceable, especially at this low price. You do have to be vigilant to stop brewing when the amount you want has finished, but as some other reviewers have said, adding a shut-off component would no doubt raise the price.

I removed the black plastic frothing aid after the first use and now make fantastic micro-foam with the bare steam wand.

I wouldn't recommend this machine for someone unfamiliar with the espresso/steamed milk process (I'm a former barista), but definitely for anyone who has used machines before.

review_content: Let me say first that I am pleasantly surprised at the quality of this Mr. Coffee machine. I never thought that Mr. Coffee could be now known for making high quality espresso coffee, but they are. I can compare this espresso maker with the Singolo that I also own. I found this coffee maker much more compact than the Singolo and fits, and looks, well on my already cluttered countertop. It's attractive in stainless, is very easy to use (far easier than the Singolo) and cleanup is a breeze. I will say that I think there is something about the Singolo which is nice when it comes to the actual finished product, with the foaminess of the coffee froth. Outside of that, I really like the Mr. Coffee Barista and would recommend it to anyone looking for a nice, attractive, easy to use, espresso maker. You will not be disappointed.

review_content:
UPDATE:
The plastic filler cap cracked (no, I did not drop it). Naturally I need to replace it because I don't want it to come apart and explode under the steam pressure. The only place I could find this part is on the Mr. Coffee website. The part costs $2.99. They charge nearly $6 for shipping. So I'm paying $9 for a $3 part. Nice racket.
=====================
I got this to replace a leaking Krups machine which is very similar in appearance. This is cheaper at this point on Amazon. The Krups machine is no longer sold by Amazon; it was a $50-$60 machine and now it's being sold for the absurdly profiteering price of $300 for anyone foolish enough to think they will get what they pay for at that price.
Anyhow, the Mr. Coffee (made by Sunbeam, by the way). It's a little light and plasticky, but I don't mind that so much. So far it works; they all do, so that's not really a plus. I mean, it's supposed to work, right?
Good parts of the design;
--Knobs are shaped so they are very easy to turn, which is good.
--There is a sort of bobbin to wind excess electrical cord underneath, which is good.
Bad parts of the design:
--Filler cap has a cool tapered shape, which of course makes it impossible to get a grip on it and lift it if your hands are wet (which often is the case in kitchen and food prep situations).
--Partly due to cool tapered shape, the filler cap can easily be cross threaded, or it can slip into the surrounding recessed area (which is also very cool design) and it can get stuck in there.
--Note to design staff: form follows function. Or it should. Cool is not always functional.
--Unlike all other espresso machines like this that I've owned, the metal filter is just sitting in the holder, with nothing to keep it from falling out. So when you go to knock the "puck" out into the trash after you make coffee, the whole metal filter also will fall out into the trash every time, so you will have to fish it out. And of course if it's hot you will burn your hand. STUPID design flaw. (Solution: knock it out into a plastic cup, but of course it's still hot so you have that to deal with.)
--Cord is very short.
This is probably worth the ~$40 I paid for it, but no way is it worth the $88 original indicated price. That said, I would rather pay a bit more and get something better, but there doesn't seem to be anything available in this type of machine.
title: Decent quality for the price; dumb design flaws.

review_content: The milk will froth just fine you fill the froth cup half way with milk and then stick the stem up in the milk. After that turn the knob slowly untill it stops.  Then you want to line up the top of the milk with two tiny hols in the stem. Alow the milk to slowly push through the holes.  If it's not right in the perfect spot you will get a bubbly mess of hell. Watch closely and it will start to flow into the holes and gradually froth the hell out of the milk.  I froth till it reaches the top then slowly pour the steamed milk in and spoon out about a half inch of froth. Only use 1% or skim milk and to add a tad of flavor add a flavored coffee creamer to the milk. I use about 1/8th of the am out of milk I use.  My bad problem is the directions suck and it's really hard to get the froth stem clean because the milk cakes to the inner metal stem. Also manual says nothing is dishwasher safe so I just hand wash now. I also wish there was a water level indicator. I learned to deal with the flaws because it's worth the money once you get the hang of it.

review_content: This espresso make works well just as it describes, but it is also missing key features that makes it easier to use. For one, it will brew the ENTIRE tank of water if you do not watch it. There is NO auto-shutoff feature. The filter and holder IMMEDIATELY rusted once I washed it. It also kept putting these white chips of something in the coffee as water passed through the filter. I had to brew about 30 cups to make this stop. MAKE SURE YOU DO THIS FIRST. Also, the frother has a plastic cover over the metal piece. Just cleaning the outside will not work. You have to make sure you take the plastic piece off to clean the milk from the metal pipe. This is a HUGE design flaw. And finally, the machine cannot brew and froth at the same time and there is not regulator for either. It either all ON or all OFF. I wish I would have spend more money on an espresso machine that included all the features lacking in this one.
title: Product is okay for the money you spend.
bought_model: Color: CappuccinoStyle Name: 4-Cup Steam

review_content:
I really wanted to get into making espresso at home as I always found myself going to Starbucks or other local coffee places multiple times every week. I investigated buying an Illy Pod machine, however when I went to visit a friend in L.A. she has this exact machine and made me some espresso and it was wonderful. So instead of spending $150+ on a pod machine or a super fancy machine I decided to give this little guy a chance since she loved hers so much. I am glad I did an I will tell you why:

Design:
This is a really nicely designed espresso machine, it is small, simple, and overall looks nice sitting on the counter. It isn't fancy as it just has a turn nob to make espresso or use the steamer. The top of the machine can be used to hold anything, I put a few small espresso cups on top and it looks nice.

Ease of use:
It really doesn't get any easier than this to make espresso. Simply fill the water up to the 2 or 4 (cup) line and pour into the top, and pack the espresso into the holder up to 2 or 4. The espresso holder simply lifts and locks into place. Turn the nob and it will start brewing, and once you no longer see espresso coming out you can turn it off.

Espresso:
I have used Fresh & Easy Espresso and also Lavazza espresso and it tastes great with this machine. I mix mine with a bit of soy half and half and I am good to go, or throw hot water in for an americano. Many people rate the espresso machine based on it's ability to make that nice froth on top of the espresso and you will see a bit here when you make the coffee. It is complete steam based system and it seems to work fairly well. The froth on top of the espresso isn't extremely thick and I am assuming higher end machines will do this better. I will say that once I bought a Tamper to pack down the espresso it helped a lot, so invest another $6 or so to get one of these and it will make a pretty decent difference, if not just for the ease of use.

Frother:
On the side of the machine is a milk frother/steamer. I didn't read the directions so I honestly didn't know how to use it until my friend from L.A. came to visit. All you have to do is add water to the little steam icon on the cup and pour it into the machine. Then turn it on and give it a minute. The steam is hot and pretty intense. It actually does a nice job of frothing milk or soy as long as you figure out how to use it. TIP: I like to turn the machine onto Brew after I am done frothing as there might be some water left over.

Summary:
This machine by far is the best bang for the buck. I have had it for around 2 months, and my friend has had it for a year and it is great. I still occasionally go to Starbucks, but it is great to just have it available right in my house. For $30 definitely give this little guy a try.
title: Great beginner espresso machine
bought_model: Color: CappuccinoStyle Name: 4-Cup Steam

review_content: Love!!!!!! This machine is the best sound in the am lol. Only had it couple weeks so far but working great!
title: Buy it!
bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Espresso/Cappuccino Maker

review_content:
Let me start by saying that I am not a coffee drinker, and much less an espresso drinker. As such, prior to ten days ago, I knew just about nothing regarding espresso machines. However, my daughter's birthday was coming up; and being as she is a former barista who obviously enjoys drinking her espressos, I wanted to give her something nice which I knew she would appreciate.

After a fair amount of research on the web -- Wikipedia, Amazon, etc. -- and being as I am an elderly man who lives on a fixed income, I settled for this Mr. Coffee ECM160 4-Cup Steam Espresso Machine.

Naturally, my daughter was quite happy to receive this gift from me, and we have both enjoyed a few espressos made with it. However, yesterday, while I was in her kitchen, I noticed that the top of this machine was off. Upon looking in, I was really taken back to discover that the boiler is actually made of aluminum, and not stainless steel.

For those of you who are reading this who may be young, the reason for my concern and alarm is that for decades now, a debate has raged regarding the safety of using aluminum in cooking utensils, such as pots and pans. If you conduct your own personal research, you will quickly discover that there is a wide diversity of opinions on both sides of the fence. What is stated as truth and fact depends on who is making the statements: scientists, medical professionals, beverage industry reps, manufacturers of such items as this one, etc. Who you choose to believe is really up to you.

Be that as it may, just the fact that high ingestion of aluminum has been potentially linked to maladies such as Alzheimer's Disease, stomach cancer, pancreatic cancer, etc., by certain parties, was enough to convince me to abandon aluminum cookware many years ago.

Thus, my concern with this espresso machine. If just boiling hot water in an aluminum pot or tea pot results in a small amount of aluminum being dissolved into the liquid, I can only wonder how truly safe it is to boil water under high pressure in an espresso machine which has an aluminum boiler, such as this one.

While others may disagree with me -- that is your right -- quite frankly, I feel that listing "stainless steel" as one of the selling points for this espresso machine is misleading, deceptive, and borders on false advertising. Yes, some of the outer parts are in fact stainless steel. However, the most important part -- the boiler -- most certainly is not.

For those of you who may doubt my words, I got the truth straight out of the horse's mouth; that is, from the Mr. Coffee support team themselves. In the question and answer section of their website at http://www.mrcoffee.com/specialty/mr.-coffee-steam-espresso-and-cappuccino-maker--ecm160-np-/ECM160-NP.html, one person asks:

Q: "Is there any aluminum used in this machine or is it stainless steel?"

A: "The water boiler portion of the brewer is aluminum. All other metal parts of the brewer are stainless steel."

Another concerned person asks:

Q: "How much aluminum is leached into the water that I am consuming. Why did they not put stainless steel inside instead?"

A: "At Jarden Consumer Solutions (JCS), we are committed to producing trusted household products that meet or exceed applicable product standards. All aluminum used in the Mr. Coffee Espresso Maker are recognized as safe for food contact applications by the United States Food and Drug Administration (FDA). JCS purchases aluminum from trusted suppliers, who monitor to ensure what they sell complies with all current federal, state and local health and safety regulations."

Please notice that Mr. Coffee did not directly answer either of the person's two questions.

The bottom line is that you get what you pay for. I bought cheap because that is all my finances allowed, and I am now left disappointed. I love my daughter, and her health is of great concern to me. Thus, I just purchased her another espresso machine which costs five times as much as this one; and yes, it has a stainless steel boiler.

In conclusion, if you are ignorant regarding espresso machines as I was, or if you are on a limited budget, you may be happy with this espresso machine. However, if you are concerned for your health, you may want to consider spending more money, and at least getting something that has a stainless steel boiler.

PS: Also worthy of note is the following information regarding the Mr. Coffee Espresso Machine which is also found on the Mr. Coffee website:

"The ECM160 espresso maker has a maximum pressure of: 1.24 bar with 14g of coffee powder 3.62 bar with 24g of coffee powder."

From what I have read online, and based on what my barista daughter told me as well, by any standard, that is TERRIBLE pressure, and will NOT deliver a very strong/concentrated shot of espresso. It is substandard. For a decent shot, your espresso machine should produce at least pressure of 15 bar. Such machines cost at least a few hundred dollars . . . such as the new one that I just purchased for my daughter to replace the Mr. Coffee machine; that is, this one:

DeLonghi EC702 15-Bar-Pump Espresso Maker, Stainless
title: Beware! The Boiler is Aluminum, And Not Stainless Steel!

review_content:
Three stars is an average, b/c I had to send the first one back when it wouldn't pressurize AT ALL ON CHRISTMAS MORNING when we opened it and tried to use it. That was frustrating. But that's part of why Amazon is so great, b/c I could file the exchange claim and have another one in the mail, ASAP. And the second one works fine. If I wasn't so cheesed off about getting a faulty first unit I'd be giving this a higher score.

And yes, I took the orange thing out of the reservoir the first time. It was impossible to miss; they must have added more stickers to the packaging to make sure that doesn't happen based on all the reviews. The first machine wouldn't prime at all, just clicked a little then started blinking at me. After about 30 minutes of desperately hoping things would start working I gave up and put it back in the box. A few days later I tried again with the new one and things worked fine. Hopefully they stay that way for a long time.

I got this as a gift for my wife since a milk reservoir might save a few steps in her coffee routine. We'd seen way more expensive versions of the same thing and always said they were out of our budget. This is definitely not, but it brews very nice espressos and is pretty quick about it too. That's a big plus when you've got two kids going crazy on a weekend morning and all you want is a cup of coffee strong enough to silence the screaming.

This hasn't replaced our regular coffee machine, but it's a welcome addition to the kitchen. And since our regular machine did replace our old coffee/espresso double brewer, it's like welcoming an old friend back after a time away. If the first one had worked properly I would be raving about this machine, but I can't help holding a grudge. I like the one that works fine, but think I'll be suspicious about it for a long time.
title: Thankfully Amazon gave Mr. Coffee a second swing.
bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Espresso/Cappuccino Maker

review_content:
This espresso machine is A-mazing! I bought the recommended tamper and 12 oz. pitcher to go with it. I fill the pitcher up just about 1/2 way and when I steam the milk, I get so much froth it almost overflows! The key to small frothy bubbles is to keep the steam handle fully emersed in the milk. To have enough steam you need to add about 2 to 3 ounces extra water to the water reservoir (if making 4 cups I usually fill the espresso pitcher to the top of the metal band). When the espresso has brewed the requested # of cups simply switch the power to steam from brew (less mess if the frothing arm is in the pitcher ready to go when you do this).

If you follow the directions, clean after each use (Especially the frothing arm...immerse in water and run a small steam cycle after each use and scrub with a scrubbing sponge), and this will be a great addition to your kitchen for a long time! We are hooked. My husband is already talking about getting rid of the coffee maker! Love it!!!
title: A-mazing little espresso machine!!!
bought_model: Color: CappuccinoStyle Name: 4-Cup Steam

review_content:
This is a very disappointing purchase and I do NOT recommend at all. As other reviewers have noted, the coffee produced is a VERY STRONG DRIP COFFEE, NOT ESPRESSO. It is acceptable to drink as long as you don't try to think of it as true espresso. The picture is for marketing purposes and not an accurate representation. The "frother" is a disaster. It does steam but does not froth the milk no matter which method you use including the booklet's minimal instructions. I used a frothing pitcher, the recommended 2% milk, moved the pitcher in the right direction (both circular and vertical) but GOT ONLY STEAMED MILK, NO FROTH. The frothing wand of the machine also has a tendency to spit the milk upward making a mess. I don't need to start my day with these hassles and still not get espresso and frothed milk. Also mentioned by another reviewer is the design. It's definitely a case of design for eye appeal not utility -- form over function. Despite the appearance of metal, it is made of CHEAP PLASTIC. Look closely at the on/off knob and water compartment cap. That sloping contour is extremely smooth with no surface variation making it VERY DIFFICULT TO GRIP OR TURN. If you have any grip problems with your hands or weakness in your fingers, it's nearly impossible to turn either of these. I'm not a newbie to espresso machines or to frothing the milk. I've had positive experience with another brand machines (no longer made) that is in the same price range. Unfortunately, the company doesn't make the lower $$ machines anymore. I may have to reach deeper into my wallet to buy a better espresso unit but it won't be Mr. Coffee brand (I still like their drip machines though). The reviews here on the Mr Coffee ECM160 4 cup Steam Espresso Machine were mostly positive which is why I bought the machine. In the end, I WOULD NOT RECOMMEND it for anyone else and I regret my purchase. I'm returning it if permitted.

UPDATE: Amazon rules do not permit the return of this unit because it is now used and not new. I wanted to clarify also that extreme caution should be used when using the "frothing" feature. When we were using it, part of the spitting I mentioned resulted in droplets of steamed milk landing on the hand holding the pitcher. Your immediate reaction is of course to let go of the pitcher which would only cause greater problems spilling out steaming hot milk. Frothing with Mr. Coffee is not for children.
title: Mr Coffee ECM160 4 cup Steam Espresso Machine
bought_model: Color: CappuccinoStyle Name: 4-Cup Steam

review_content:

The only gripe I have is that the reservoir top is an odd shape which makes it tough to screw on and off. I've had this for about 2 months and use it almost daily. Time will tell if it's as long-lasting as my old Krups machine that I had for about 15 years! Go ahead and get this one, though. It's good and will save you some cash.

Steaming is good for a home basic coffee machine. Honestly the steaming is better than my older model ,is faster. I really enjoy the coffeea in this machine. #coffee lover.
title: Good machine. Love the coffees.
