title: As close to an Italian cappuccino as I can get
bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Espresso/Cappuccino Maker

review_content:
I've purchased many espresso makers. Most the old steam variety. You don't really know espresso until you have used a pump machine. My first pump machine was a complete disaster (I won't name the brand but it has the same initials as myself). It failed continually because the basket had a rubber gasket and coffee would get into it. Ugh.
I was happy when I bought the Mr. Coffee Barista because the baskets are all metal. They don't lose pressure because of coffee getting under the rubber, although they will clog if you use unevenly ground coffee. If that happens you can buy replacement baskets at a very reasonable price from many vendors.
Even better! No mud!! Yes, if you are a former steam espresso user you are accustom to a dry solid brick of used coffee grounds that you can easily dump in the trash. Not the case with pump machines, they leave you with a puddle of mud because instead of dry steam the coffee is pushed through hot water. Except for this espresso machine. Why? Well it has an auto-off feature that turns the power off after about 15 minutes after use. The result of that is, it continues to heat the basket for a while and that dries out the grounds, so they can easily be scraped out. Not as nice as the solid hockey puck that you get from a steam espresso maker, but still not mud! So much nicer than other machines that leave you with a basket of mud the next time you use it!
That alone makes this espresso machine a great deal!
So get over the low brow name brand (I was able to rub it off mine). This espresso maker is a damn good deal!
title: Great Espresso machine, no mud
bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Espresso/Cappuccino Maker

review_content: üëéüèªüëéüèªüëéüèªüëéüèªüëéüèª
title: One Star
bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Espresso/Cappuccino Maker

review_content: This item is selling for $125. This was my worst purchase ever in terms of price, but I have learnt my lesson. I will order directly from the store and have it shipped to me or have my sister collect. Will save so much more.
title: This was my worst purchase ever in terms of price
bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Espresso/Cappuccino Maker

review_content:
I should start this review with the headstone: RIP Born, January 2014, Died August 2015. I am torn about the stars - when it worked, it did a decent job of automatic cappuccino creation as long as you are not a perfectionist/barista etc. It is BY FAR the lowest priced, non pod based semi-automatic cappuccino maker. If you buy pre-ground (I used Bustello) or have a grinder (which I used for decaff espresso), and buy a decent tamper - it is a great quick cup of basically ok espresso or cappuccino. It is not going to approach a true coffee house version of those drinks, but it is also not 2K dollars. I used it about once a day - so lets say it did about 500 cups before it gave up the ghost. By my calculations, that is about 35-40cents a cup, not including the coffee and milk. I figure the coffee was about 10 cents a cup, and milk probably 5cents, so all in this was costing me in 50-60 cents range. Not bad per se.

My issue is that about 1year in, of course right about the time warranty expired, it started having trouble frothing the milk. I performed regular cleaning as per recommendations. It became very sensitive to the milk (temperature, freshness). About a week ago, I turned it on and the pump would not shut off. RIP. I think these things should last 3 years. At 3 years the cost per cup is in the 15 cent range. Not sure what I am going to do at this point . . . but was disappointed with the lack of longevity.
title: DId not last as long as I expected
bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Espresso/Cappuccino Maker

review_content:
I LOVE this Machine! It changes my mornings to enjoy an easy-to-make great quality cappuccino, vanilla latte, or whatever I'd like to have in coffees.

I'm a coffee lover and I went from Keurig, to Cusinart, to Nespresso looking for the best options in Coffee, until I met this Mr. Coffee maker. Its "milk" container option allows me to serve all kinds of milks and, as I prefer, mix them with almond or coconut as vegan options; an you gradute the thickness of the cream with the integrated knob.

The cleaning is as easy as removing the container and putting it into the sink for a warm water run. Same as for the coffee basket, firm turn and easy remove. It comes with three basket sizes, double, single and the third on for PODs.

Some people says worth the price, I believe this is a great product for its price and don't bother to go for the bigger more expensive model, besides a bigger container, the variation is the barista pump but one won't notice the difference.
title: I LOVE this Machine! Great Coffee maker in many variations
bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Espresso/Cappuccino Maker

review_content:
I'd bought this at Walmart but Amazon is the first place I go for reviews before purchasing a product so I figured I'd put my two cents for this item.

Quick review: steamer attachment doesn't warm the milk, only froths so the milk needs to be heated before. There was no tamper so the espresso grounds don't get pressed well.

I was a barista for over a year, an avid coffee drinker since my early teens, and I've had espresso machines in the past. My last machine broke and I got a keurig that just wasn't working for me....spending $6 daily on my 4 shot lattes is ridiculous when I know how to make them so I bought this after a recommendation.

For me personally the machine is okay because I drink lattes over ice. I do need to plug the machine in and turn on the brew just a little for about 10 minutes before it is hot enough to actually brew.

The steamer doesn't get hot! I've waited and waited leaving the machine on but the little frothed does not heat the milk so when I do make hot lattes I heat the milk in the microwave before frothing.

I know this was the cheap machine but other Mr. Coffee products have a tamper attached to the scoop, cheap but works. This machine does NOT have a tamper! Also, the filter doesn't actually lock so each time you empty the grounds you needs to wait for it to cool then take the filter out which is sort of inconvenient.

With the additional purchase of a tamper that actually fits the filter as well as the steamer that doesn't work, I don't feel like this machine is work the money. There is a machine for 89$ that is much better in my opinion.
title: Should've bought the one for $89
bought_model: Color: CappuccinoStyle Name: 4-Cup Steam

review_content:
I was looking for a coffee machine that does it all. I was so excited when I got a great deal on this machine. I have been using it for a month or so now and I like and duslike several things.
Pros
Really froths the milk nicely
Great tasting espresso
Easy to clean

Cons
You cannot make a full cup of coffee with this. Even on the manual setting it barely gives you half a cup. You have to brew it a few times to get a full cup and then the coffee tastes watered down. This was very disappointing to me because now I have to buy a seperate machine just to get my full cup I like in the am.

Overall its a great machine for small amounts of latte or espresso, but if you like a big cup of coffee like me dont waste your money or counterspace.
title: Brews very small amount
bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Espresso/Cappuccino Maker

review_content:
I'm not going to compare this machine to 200 or 500 dollar machines, but if you're looking to spend below 500, you might as well buy this one because it works and its affordable. I don't think you get much more before you spend around 500. I grew up with a commercial machine in my house, and I've been contemplating getting one for us now, but I didn't want to spend the 500 dollars on a good machine until I figured out what I wanted out of a machine. And that's really where this model stands out.

It's cheap enough to last you a year until you're ready to upgrade, but its good enough that you aren't going to "outgrow" it or crave something better right away either. Its a good machine for what it is. Most espresso machines at this price range and higher are pressurized baskets. If you don't know what that is, its basically just a basket that you put the coffee in that maintains pressure so that if your grinds aren't good, or you don't know how to tamp the basket, it'll still make a pretty good shot of espresso. I recommend getting an unpressurized basket though, as you have much more flexibility. Don't skimp on your grinder! You're better off spending 200 on a grinder and 70 on an espresso maker, instead of the opposite. But if you want to try owning an espresso machine, this one won't let you down. It's not the best, but it holds its own. I've never given my gf a latte and she said ew.
title: Good machine in its price range
bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Automatic Dual Shot

review_content:
Without disparaging the fine engineers and designers at Mr. Coffee, and not to imply this is a mere toy, this little machine is something like the Easy Bake Oven of espresso makers. It can be fun to play with, but it is for coffee dilettantes, not coffee snobs.

Here are a few tips I have picked up from daily practice and from other reviewers:

1. Yes, there is a distinct metallic tinge- it reminded me of a clothes steamer I used to have, and I think it comes from the heating element, not plastic parts. This DOES go away.

2. The flat end of the scoop make a very bad tamper, but you do not need to buy a tamper as an accessory. I have been using a teaspoon.

3. The best word in the entire instruction manual? "ceramic." As in 'stainless steel or ceramic pitcher.' If you have a 16 oz. ceramic mug, you do not need to get a stainless steel pitcher.

4. The best drink you can make using this machine is one double latte. Make a double espresso, steam 8 oz. of milk in a 16 oz. pitcher or mug, pour your espresso into a glass or mug, top it with the milk- THEN put the carafe back and make a 'bad brew' expelling the extra hot water. Do not drink this coffee- give it to your mother-in-law... (Just Kidding!)

Expelling the extra water is a very good tip I picked up from an early review. If you think of the reservoir as your 'kettle,' then you know fresh cold water is always the best thing to start with... but now I think I've given away my tea-drinking past.

A great birthday present.. Thank you, Erica!

Have had this machine about two weeks. It's worked fine, makes decent shots (and I'm no connoisseur, I just like shots on ice and I'm on a budget, and it works for that), but I am shopping for a new machine and kicking myself for not putting out another $20 for a better product. Here's why:

1) Lots of plastic parts. I make sure to be gentle with the controls.
2) The dishwasher destroyed the finish on the filter basket holder (part #5833) and Mr. Coffee no longer sells the replacement. Seeing the cheap construction of this part in particular and how the visible areas have reacted to hot water makes me wonder what it's been depositing in my drinks, and if that has anything to do with why the replacement part has fallen off the face of the Earth despite the ECM160 still being on store shelves.

However, the machine is simply not durable. The first one started leaking out of the bottom just after the warranty expired; the second one, which is now 15 months old and also out of warranty, just started leaking.

As much as I like this espresso machine, I can't really recommend it. And it looks like we'll be looking for another brand.

Update: we purchased a DeLonghi unit. It's horrible. Aside from the fact that it doesn't make good espresso, the shape of the thing makes it nearly impossible to secure the strainer unit. It's going back, and we've purchased another Mr. Coffee. I guess, for the price, we'll end up buying one of these things every year, or until I can get the manufacturer to tell me why it leaks all over the counter after a year.

title: Medioacre coffee
bought_model: Color: CappuccinoStyle Name: 4-Cup Steam

review_content:
I purchased this unit about a week ago and I decided to write a review that targets a very specific audience.

If you really enjoy Espresso, Cappuccino or even a Latte and you don't like having to pay the high cost of purchasing them from your local coffee shop...AND if you don't have a lot of money to invest in equipment...then this review was written for you.

For the money...you will not find a better Espresso machine out there. This is by far the best value on the market as of today (12/2012).
I started off with an Aeropress and a hand powered burr grinder from Kyocera that made a very very good substitute for Espresso. And my wife and I were very happy with that system. But we found that the time involved kept us from enjoying our morning Espresso as often as we would have liked and I ended up going out pretty often to a local shop when I felt the need.

So I began reading reviews online, watching youtube videos and talking to folks to see what my options were. I was pretty pleased to find out that I did have an affordable option available to me..and so I took the plunge.

From Amazon I purchased a Baratza Encore grinder ($130), Mr. Coffee ECMP50 ($80), and an Espresso Tamper. I already had an Aerolatte milk frother (Highly recommended).

The combination of this equipment produces an outstanding result that is better than a lot of local shops in my area...and probably yours too! If you can afford to spend $250 then THIS is the way to go...and I can assure you that you will not be disappointed in the result.

Go out to a local coffee roaster and get a recommended Espresso blend whole bean (FRESH is BEST). Grind it in the Baratza Encore at the 9 setting for the Mr. Coffee ECMP50 and follow the directions to produce the Espresso. Pour milk into your coffee cup and get it hot in the microwave....then use the Aerolatte milk frother to almost double it in volume. Add your flavorings and sweetener as desired and then pour the Expresso into it to enjoy a WONDERFUL treat.

Now think about it...if you just spend $4 per drink and buy just 2 per week (1 for you and 1 for your wife) you will spend $416 per year. With the system above you can produce two drinks EVERY DAY for less than $600 for the YEAR (INCLUDING THE COST OF COFFEE BEANS and MILK!) And even if you have to replace the Mr. Coffee every year....you still come out on top of the deal!
So you get 7X the coffee at just a little bit more cost than going to a local shop for just 1 per week. How can you beat that deal?

Having said all this I again HIGHLY RECOMMEND this system for those who can spend $250 on their equipment and who love Espresso/Cappuccino/Latte drinks. You will NOT be disappointed, I promise you. Life is too short to not enjoy a good Espresso/Cappuccino/Latte...and the economy is too bad to go to your local shop on a regular basis. So make the plunge now and give YOURSELF a present that you will enjoy for years to come.

*** 1 Month update ****
Everything is still going strong and I have had ZERO problems. The one thing that I now realize is that I should have taken into account the cost associated with cleaning the grinder and Espresso Maker. There are a few options that you can run through your grinder to clean the parts that are not designed to be easily removed for cleaning...but I have not chosen one for recommendation yet. Once I do, I will refactor the the costs shown above and amend them. The cost of cleaning the Espresso machine can be mitigated by using quality water and following the cleaning recommendations in the manual.
I do not expect for the additional cost of cleaning to significantly reduce the value....but it is something that should be taken into consideration, as proper cleaning will increase the life span of your equipment and therefore reduce the cost per serving over the performance period.

*** 10 Month update ***
Well, we have been using this machine for almost a year now and it is going strong. I just cleaned it for the first time to get ready for the fall, when our latte drinking increases.
I still highly recommend this machine if you are looking for something in the sub $300 range. Save your money for a good grinder and go with this machine. Quality ingredients, good water, and investing in a good grinder and you are all set to save big $$ while making drinks better than you can buy at Starbucks!

**** 32 Month update ****
This machine is still are big part of our family routine...and is going strong. I have heard of folks who have had issues with this machine, but can attest that mine is still working great. Again, maintenance is a big part of ensuring that the system operates trouble free. AND, using good quality water. It is easier to NOT gum up the machine, than to have to descale it constantly!

While this has been a staple in my home, I am now making the plunge into a more expensive espresso maker. Having gone from prepping for 1 - 2 frequently during the week to 3 every single day, I feel that I can justify the expense of a step up machine that is designed to take that kind of production. But I will always remember this machine, like a first love, it go me though my initial exploration into the wonderful world of espresso. Thank You Mr. Coffee!
title: BEST Option for the money by far!  (2 1/2 year update)

Regardless, sent it back and purchased this one instead (a lot cheaper to begin with) and it worked 100% right out of the box. Just made my first double shot (will work on my tamper pressure) and it came out with a nice layer of crema atop of the espresso brew.

Clean-up was 10 seconds. The puck came out in one tap of the basket and I simply washed out the few loose grinds in the filter and washed my two bodum espresso glasses.

If you are just entering the world of espresso, don't know what machine to get, but want to just get one to get started. You will not be disappointed with this machine.

review_content:
I received this for Christmas from my loving wife who noticed a slight cloud over my weekends since my espresso maker went out several months ago. I had the Mr. Coffee model previous to this one. It served me well for over a year with regular use before I learned the hard way about not overpacking the grounds.

After taking this one around the block a few times I have to say I'm extremely impressed with the design improvements they've made. Overall, this machine is a tremendous value for under $100 (mine was $75 on sale). You would really have to be a coffee snob (and have a lot of disposable income) not to love what you get for the money (I'm a poor coffee snob.)

To sing this machine's praises, I'll highlight the improvments they've made:

1) You no longer have to remove the water container to fill it up. It's an awkward shape to try to fill from my refrigerator. So I just use my frothing pitcher and pour directly into it. This also chills the pitcher - which is good for the frothing I'll do soon.

2) I LOVE the top tray. I store my espresso cup, tamper (from the old machine - the new one is the only downgrade I've noticed), brew basket, and espresso pitchers on it. Did I mention I love the tray? It's a great design perk.

3) It still heats up quickly. A little faster than before for frothing.

4) They upgraded the design of the filters. Smaller holes that all converge into one hole on the bottom. Note: Don't put these or the brew basket in the dishwasher - you'll tarnish them.

5) The bottom of the brew basket is really cool, the single hole from the filter drips onto a silicone (I'm assuming) cone in the basket which appears to guarantee an even drip between two cups of espresso. This only matters if you're pulling separate shots. It may be overdesigned, but I think it's cool.

6) There's more clearance under the brew basket! You couldn't fit a coffee mug under there before (which is why I have the two espresso pitchers). One (or two) fewer thing to clean!

7) The drip tray has two larger holes in the middle. When your espresso is done (and the machine is off) you can take out the brew basket (it's bad for the valve to keep it there) and set it on the holes to drip and cool off before cleaning. It's a brilliant improvement. Also, the drip tray has a spout on it to make it easy to pour out.

8) The frothing wand swings! Very cool.

Here are my tips (echoing other reviews).
-Read the directions first! It'll last longer if you do.
-Make sure you use the correct roast and ground size and don't overpack.
-Play with the brewer until you figure out how long you want to brew (I count to ten).
-Ditch the single filter. You'll never use it.
-Get some demitasse cups.
-Get a frothing pitcher and use 1% milk.
-Ditch the rubber tip on the frothing wand. It's useless unless you want to easily grow bacteria.
-After frothing, blow a little steam out the wand so no milk dries and clogs it. Wipe the wand with a damp towel shortly after steaming (it's easier to clean when it's hot).

That's about it, folks. You get a lot of bang for your buck with this one. Even if it only lasted a year, I'd buy another one to replace it and I'd still save money over the more expensive models.

Enjoy!

UPDATE AFTER ONE YEAR: I use it off and on and it's still working well. The frothing works as well as it did day one. The espresso function works, but I made the mistake of pregrinding some beans at the grocery store with the "Espresso" setting. The machine struggled to force water through even with minimal packing (Next time I'll try the next largest size). It also seems like the seal isn't as tight as a year ago. That said, it still pulls a decent shot. For the money, I'm still pleased.
title: Mr. Coffee really did their homework on this one
bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Automatic Dual Shot

title: Informacion
bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Espresso/Cappuccino Maker

review_content:
I've had this machine for over a year. I have tried other machines, even a pump. It makes good cappuccinos/lattes when the milk is steamed properly at the right temperature. If your only into espresso shots, I would go with a different pump driven machine.

PROS
-Inexpensive, Small
-Frother is strong, plastic tip is removable
-Quiet (then a pump machine)
-Latte art hearts (SEE picture)

CONS
-Supplied tamper is just a slightly flattened end of the coffee scooper.
-No frothing pitcher.
-Multiple shots requires de-pressuring the machine.

NOTES
There seems to be a lot of reviews stating it works fine in the beginning then after a while is poor or just stops. Ive noticed that during regular use, water starts to build up in the tank. This is because you never really use all the water in the tank per brew. This excess water I believe causes a problem. Either dump it out after, or what I do is, brew it out "before" I make a cappuccino as to warm up the machine on a cold start.

There also seems to be a lot of reviews saying it's not real espresso or there is no crema. This is true. It's a steam driven machine they've been making this type of machine for years. It can not match the pressure or the amount of crema produced by a pump driven machine. BUT it can produce a decent 'steam' espresso w/ crema ready to be made to a latte/cappuccino. The problem with the reviewers is that there are so many factors involved in why are not producing crema or a good cup. It could be the bean, the grind, the tamp, perhaps it's a cold start, not enough water, or too much water, etc etc the list goes on. It's something you'll have to figure out yourself.

Another thing to note is that the bean grind/freshness is directly proportional to the effectiveness of the steamer wand. If the beans are old and/or too course the water will brew through the coffee so fast that no pressure built up for the steamer wand to be effective. Likewise if the beans are too fine or the tamp too hard, the water will have a hard time passing thru the coffee and too much pressure will build up which isnt good either for this machine.

Do the descaling with vinegar per instructions.

Also want to note I added a picture of a latte heart I made, just to prove minimal latte art is somewhat possible with this machine.
title: RECESSION SPECIAL!
bought_model: Color: CappuccinoStyle Name: 4-Cup Steam

review_content:
I'm a coffee fiend. I've used all manner of espresso machines from the cheapest to the most expensive, fully manual to completely automatic. I was interested in reviewing this Mr. Coffee machine, because I'm always keen on manual machines and was curious whether this sub-one-hundred-dollar machine could pull a decent shot. The answer is: yes, but with reservations.

First off, the machine comes boxed in eco-friendly packaging. I'm a huge champion of that. It includes everything you need to pull your first shot except ground beans and water. The way you manipulate the machine lets you actually "pull" your shot, determining exactly how much espresso you serve. In addition, you tamp your own grounds. This is where it gets tricky. I found that in order to really get a drinkable shot, you have to tamp...hard! The machine isn't forgiving and you can end up with a soupy mess if you don't press down with gusto.

This is where my reservations come in: A cheaper espresso machine like this one has to cut corners somewhere, and Mr. Coffee did it in the build quality. It's not that well made. Given the force required to tamp and the fact that the portafiler (the handle with the filter basket) doesn't smoothly lock into place, I can tell this machine has a limited life span. That said, if you want to try your hand at home-made espresso and aren't sure you want to pull the trigger on something much more expensive, this Mr. Coffee can give you a taste without breaking the bank!
title: Can pull a good shot with a solid tamp and some practice!

review_content: Simplicity at it's finest... this machine is easy to use and makes a great cup of espresso. Clean up is a breeze..  On the downside this is not for your experienced baristas out there due to the fact it's all automated..  but for regular everyday normal people.. it's awesome !!
title: Simplicity at it's finest..
bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Espresso/Cappuccino Maker

review_content:
It's been a month since I bought this machine. After I owned two DeLonghis, this one is a desperate attempt to bring my Beloved Espresso days back. So, my opinion is a comparison between what I had and this one. If I had had this one first, I would have probably thought THIS is the best machine on the market (at this price). I admire the manufacturer's effort, though.
PROs: it is automatic (you choose the single or double espresso, you choose small or large latte, etc.)
It froths milk
It warms up fairly fast (2-3 minutes)
It has a support for small espresso cups
The milk container can be easily washed after use (which I strongly recommend you do to avoid bad gone milk smell)
It is sleek and (after only a month) resistant
It is easy to operate
It shuts off automatically if not used for 5 min or so (yay!)

Cons: TASTE
After 4-5 espresso, I could get rid the taste of new machine
The Coffee /Espresso does not taste as rich; maybe a bit too bitter (I changed 2-3 brands); In fact, I don't like the taste of it, now I realize that I just hoped that it will change; after a month, I think this is what I will get. Period.
The crema is not so rich
My Latte Frother is making Capuccino froth (which I don't mind; I don't like lattes w/o foam) -- buttons are probably inversed, capuccino with latte
I have to remove the milk container right after (Or I will forgt to do it) and either wash it or put it in the fridge to save the rest of the milk. And wash the frother mechanism (otherwise it stinks later). It is an unpleasant chore because (no, I am not spoiled) all I want to do is sit and enjoy my coffee.
I am now thinking if the coffee holder (the one you put your scoop of coffee in) is made of a too cheap material and it is therefore the chief responsible for the lack of Great Espresso Taste. I am not an engineer or physicist, but it could be. (D'Longhi one's was made of sturdy material).

I pondered if to send it back, and was close to do it and invest again in a D'Longhi ($200), but I did not. Complacent, lazy, unwilling to wait another 2-5 weeks until my D'Longhi gets in stock), give it a chance, not so bad after all (excuses, excuses).
All in all, it is NOT a bad machine. And if you haven't dated a Brad Pitt or a Cindy Crawford before, Mr. or Mrs. Coffee is just the right partner for you.

Cheers! Drink caffeine responsibly.
title: Dear Mr. Coffee
bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Espresso/Cappuccino Maker

review_content:
I'm on the fence about this machine. I've actually bought it more than once. The first time I picked it up at a Target and it worked well. My wife used it pretty much ever day and it lasted FIVE YEARS. That machine probably produced over 1,500 cappuccinos. So when it finally gave up the ghost, I figured it was a solid investment and it would be money well spent to buy another one just like it. But less than 5 months later, the machine can't make a decent foam and half the water it uses ends up leaking all over the counter. Reading some of the other reviews (for this and for other Mr. Coffee products), it seems as though the quality of their products has taken a serious dive since being acquired by another company. Having said that, if you decide to buy it (it is VERY inexpensive, especially if you get it on sale), know that if you get a good one, it will work quite well--but there is an above-average chance that you'll get a lemon. I believe the issue to be that the water line that feeds the steam wand will come loose (or split) and you'll get uneven foam (very bubbly and not smooth and silky), and the water will drain out the bottom of the machine base.

Pros:

It's cheap.
The coffee it makes is pretty good.
If you get a good one, it will last a pretty good amount of time and you'll get your money's worth.

Cons:

It's cheap.
The finish is mostly cheap plastic and you're not going to impress anyone that sees it on your kitchen counter.
If you get a bad one, there's a good chance it will leak all over the place and it's definitely not worth the money.

Overall, if you're serious about your coffee, then you shouldn't waste your time with this. If you just want something that spits out a decent cup of espresso and aren't too picky, then this is the product for you.

The ease and convenience of the milk vessel - not to mention the safety from not trying to steam milk in a frothing pitcher when not professionally trained - has also been a major plus. You could spend many times more money and still not match the results from this fabulous machine. Thank you, Mr. Coffee, for making such wonderful espresso treats accessible to those of us who don't have the time or skill to master what this amazing machine does with the press of a button. Bravo!

review_content: This is a great litter espresso maker and YES it does pods.This unit replaced a maker that my wife, the coffee drinker, Her old unit became temperamental. It took too long to perform, clogged often so she stopped using it. The one brews and froths milk at the same time. It DOES do coffee pods but not out-of-the-box. You need a pod adapter from Mr Coffee for ESE Pods. It is a Café Barista ESE Pod Filter part #162427-000-000. Check out Mr coffee website. My wife is in love with it!
title: Great maker that DOES do Coffee Pods
bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Espresso/Cappuccino Maker

review_content: Great machine.  I discovered it at a convention, professional coffee house .Baristas had three set up  they told me the machine was what they use for mobile set ups. It does everything the expensive machines the use do.  There was a learning curve to using it.  Takes patience to wait for it to heat up from cold and have all the lights go on.  Recommend buying extra milk resovior and coffee grounds holder  make multiplemwithout having to clean as often.  The milk thing snaps out and stores in the fridge.  But tube milk goes through can get gross.  All and all great machine love it and use it all the time.
title: Great machine, makes great capaccinos
bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Espresso/Cappuccino Maker

review_content: It took me over an hour to set this up and figure out how to use it.  It makes perfect lattes and cappuccinos with one press of a button.  All you have to do is add water to the reservoir and add milk to the milk container.  Then, just place a coffee mug where indicated and the machine froths the milk then adds the espresso.  Delicious.  Worth every penny and we haven‚Äôt spent a dime at cafes and coffee shops.  Easy to clean and maintain.
title: Makes delicious lattes
bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Espresso/Cappuccino Maker

review_content: I purchased a Mr. Coffee Steam Espresso System with Milk Frother for a friend about a year ago and was really impressed with the quality and functionality. So I decided to finally replace my old Krups espresso maker. Regretfully, this one is not of the same quality as the Mr. Coffee unit I previously purchased for a friend. Although functional, every visible component is of cheaper quality in comparison to the unit I purchase before; i.e thinner and lighter materials and a smaller unit overall. Being a pressurized unit while in use, I hope these materials will hold up and not explode on me! Had I realized this was not the same unit, I would have made a point to discover the model number of the other one. Who would have known that Mr. Coffee would deceptively make two almost identical units and make one using lower quality materials. I will be scratching Mr. Coffee off my trusted brands list!
title: This is not a quality espresso unit
bought_model: Color: CappuccinoStyle Name: 4-Cup Steam

review_content:
I do like this product - it made a good espresso/latte. Replacement parts became an issue. Their system is antiquated and incomplete.

The double espresso holder thing ended up in my disposal - when I went to look for the replacement part on line you could find the single but not the double. Eesh - called them (half an hour on hold just to get through) but they were so so nice and sent me a replacement for free. Inconvenient but nice.

Unfortunately then we lost the small plastic tube which fits inside the milk reservoir and sucks the milk up into the frothing apparatus.

This became a major issue. I attempted to order what I thought was the right piece from their website....there was no picture but it seemed right.....it wasn't...it came and was wrong (it was the little silver tube that fits over the frothing tube). So I went back on the website - no other tubes to be found - called them - apparently you can't order this piece by itself (ridiculous as this is the piece that is most likely to get lost or damaged) - you have to order the entire milk unit - OMG- really! They very nicely said they would send me a new one for free but two weeks later and it's still not here - I've now been going to Starbucks for my lattes for the last month due to a non-functioning machine. I called them yesterday - 45 minutes on hold to just talk to a human being and about twenty minutes more trying to figure it out - a call back from a supervisor who still did not know what was going on. All for a simple plastic/silicone part.

The supervisor was supposed to figure it out and call me back to let me know what's going on - still no call back. I've given up and am ordering a new machine from another company - I just don't know what else to do. I would like to have a machine where I could easily order replacement parts for the small items that are actually likely to need to be replaced.
title: replacement parts diffulities
bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Espresso/Cappuccino Maker

review_content: My wife and I have been using this for just under a month. We want to tell you this is one of the best Espresso Machine purchases we have made. (Even being former Gaggia Stainless Steel owners). We were hesitant with 4 Stars on 1300 reviews because folks complained that they had problems with it in the first year. (big deal, why not spend the couple of bucks and get the three year warranty? )  Well we have had NO problems. Reading the manual took a few minutes and understanding the features make this a must have for the kitchen.  We have saved over 100 bucks by using this and not going to the corner coffee house for the 5 dollar latte.  Even if it breaks down in the first six months it has paid for itself in the first two‚Ä¶ (Hence the warranty makes it even a sweeter deal). I won‚Äôt bore you with pictures but it makes a Great Carmel Latte and Mocha Latte. What I can say is two words Goodbye Sta*Bucks!
title: This has almost paid for it self in the first month!
bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Espresso/Cappuccino Maker

review_content: I am writing a follow up to my previous recommendation: My first recommendation was glowing, and the only concern I had was how robust the machine really was and how it would hold up with heavy use. Used multiple times daily, it has performed flawlessly! I have used a range of coffees and grinds, (espresso's , French roasts etc), and with use have learned its capabilities, (probably could have read about it in the manual). The best feature of this machine is the frothing attachment. It is a real convenience and time saver. After use, there is a purge feature which thoroughly cleans the milk from all of the "frother's" passageways. If there is still milk in the "frother" the entire attachment can go directly into the fridge until its next use. In addition to metering a perfect 1 or 2 shot espresso, cappuccino or latte', it also permits automatically brewing a 6 oz. cup of coffee simply by holding the espresso button a couple seconds. It also allows for adding additional froth by holding the cappuccino button a couple seconds, when it has frothed enough a tap on the button shuts off the "frother". The purge cleaning function is accomplished by holding the latte' button a couple seconds. By eliminating the need to wash the frothing wand, the froth pitcher, the spilt milk etc., it makes having a cappuccino practical even if one doesn't have much time. The motor continues to run strong without any noticeable increase in noise level. I had planned to purchase a new brew cup for my $300 Briel , but have come to the conclusion that I won't use the Briel as long as the Mr. Coffee is working well, (which I believe may be a long time). I'm honestly surprised that this machine has not gained a wide following. It is no more effort to use than a Keurig and produces a better cup because of the lower temp water and high pressure extraction.
title: After hundreds of cups, it is still working beautifully!
bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Espresso/Cappuccino Maker

review_content: This is exactly what I have been wanting.  I've had expresso machines in the past, but none this good.  I add a sugar free dark chocolate sauce to my cup to make my mocha latte's and it is absolutely delicious.  I bought the Mr. Coffee grinder for about $35 so I could have freshly ground beans, and it is better than what I get at the coffee house.  In a matter of 2 weeks, the cost will have paid for itself between what my husband, son, and I buy from the local coffee house. I love the options of large or small cappuccino, lattes, and expresso.  You can use the double shot or single shot filter.  You can also make less or more frothy and add extra froth.  I love this Machine!
title: Makes a delicious cup made your way!
bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Espresso/Cappuccino Maker

review_content:
Recent cappuccino lover and the biggest thing this has going for it is being able to press a button and have the drink ready. However...

- not remotely consistent with the milk. Sometimes it overflows the cup, other times it doesn‚Äôt. Best to use their manual milk option to get the amount you want.

- The milk isn‚Äôt actually frothed. It will taste wildly less smooth and different than that of one you froth yourself with a steam wand.

- It pulls an ok espresso shot, however if you‚Äôre the type that is looking for a depth of flavor, you can‚Äôt beat a manual machine.
title: Step up from Keurig, out of league with manual/nespresso
bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Espresso/Cappuccino Maker

review_content: Bought this machine a year ago, only used filtered water and did clean the machine about once a month with white vinegar but the steaming wand died suddenly this week and the espresso water outlet is having less pressure so it's only a matter of time before the whole thing dies.  It's such a shame because we enjoyed this machine.  For the original price under $60, I didn't really mind replacing it EXCEPT now the same machine is selling for just under $100 and that is more than I am willing to pay for a machine that lasts just under a year.
title: Good while it lasted
bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Automatic Dual Shot

review_content: My wife loves her lattes. (I prefer a good strong cup of dark roast coffee.) Over the years we have gone through numerous espresso machines. We finally tried Mr. Coffee and were stunned to find that it outperformed all other brands. It was also less expensive.  After several years her Mr. Coffee machine began to malfunction. The cost had dropped and the design had become more streamlined. Its shorter height suited my height-challenged wife. She loves her lattes and her new latte machine. BTW: She doesn't use the milk steamer. She microwaves her milk and used a battery-powered frothing wand to produce her foam. Cheers!
title: Mr. Coffee makes a great espresso machine. This new model replaces one we have used for years.
bought_model: Color: CappuccinoStyle Name: 4-Cup Steam

review_content:
As the headline suggested, this stopped working for me after about a year (it began to leak). This was just after I moved, so I won't necessarily blame it on the machine.

Compared to other latte makers, I think the design of the milk frother is very good. You don't have to spend time adding steam...it's all done in one step. You have a few automatic brew options and some manual ones to get almost whatever you want.

One thing to note is that the description says this handles big travel mugs. I'm not sure what kind of mugs they have, but if you try using a mug that's tall enough to hold more than 1 cup, it's not going to fit.
title: Worked great for a year
bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Espresso/Cappuccino Maker

review_content:
First off, if you want to go full professional, you would probably be looking at the other units that cost $1000 or more. But who really needs to get one of those when the Espresso with them is only slightly better but requires much more work?

The Mr Coffee Cafe Barista is perfect for what it is supposed to be - to give you a decent Espresso without breaking the bank. The built in frother is a time-saver and works fantastically. The water tank is large enough to last a few days before needing refilling. It isn't very loud and doesn't have a huge foot-print on the counter. This is a solid buy for an automatic espresso machine. It is used every day and performs as expected.
title: Now you can have quality Espresso at home for cheaper
bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Espresso/Cappuccino Maker

review_content: Not sure how many stars to give. These work well to make espressos, but they seem to be the only ones on the market around this price range that make a decent brew. My only problems with these is that (a) they break down after a few months (even with cleaning, I've seen multiple of these get clogged and break down, maybe it's because of all the calcium in Florida tap water?); (b) they're made with solid metal piping inside, so even when they get calcium buildup, you can't break them open and fix them yourself, you just have to buy a new one); and (c) the espresso gets cold fast, leading me to believe it wasn't hot enough to begin with. Maybe that's a safety feature.
title: Best I've Found For the Price, still a few issues with it
bought_model: Color: CappuccinoStyle Name: 4-Cup Steam

review_content:
I have owned this machine for 8 months and I absolutely HATE it. I'm a cappuccino junkie and make it every morning and have done so for at least the past 7 years. I've 'used up' many steam driven machines and when my Capresso finally gave up the ghost I decided to move up to a pump driven machine. I wish I hadn't wasted my money on this one.
The PROS: It makes a fantastic espresso with good creme and if you like lattes the foamer works well for that. It also tears down completely so it can be fully cleaned.
The CONS:It is VERY finicky about how much espresso is put in the basket and how much it's tamped (which can sometimes interfere with the steam pressure). The frother is very touchy on the temp.and amount of milk used, and there's only one setting, on or off. When the milk bubbles past the rubber frothing arm there's no way to turn down the pressure to continue frothing. Whatever you got is it. I think I'm going back to a steam driven machine and use this one for target practice!
title: Good for espresso but NOT for cappuccino!
bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Automatic Dual Shot

review_content: Actually, this is a pretty good little machine. I have a cappuccino every morning..... and it makes a pretty good one. I realized when I bought it, it was not top of the line. It was very INEXPENSIVE, comparatively.  So my expectations were, that this was NOT going to be one of the expensive machines.  That said, it works better than I expected. The milk is foamy and HOT. The espresso is hot. To me it tastes good.  I ordered this because while I was in France, I had a cappuccino every morning....this little machine does a nice job. Not top quality, but impressive. I like it.
title: I like it
bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Espresso/Cappuccino Maker

review_content:
This is a great little machine for making lattes and cappuccinos at home. Just a warning that if you select a double latte (which makes a lot of foam), be prepared for overflow. I had to buy a tall thin glass mug and remove the platform completely so it would fit into the well. It still overflows the cup when I choose a latte. One other caution, be sure the milk reservoir is more than half full when choosing a double. Otherwise, there won't be enough.
It has a great cleaning process for the milk dispenser and holds a lot of water. Tools are also provided for single and double cups and for pressing the coffee.
title: Great machine but be careful with those doubles.
bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Espresso/Cappuccino Maker

review_content: It's not great. The machine came quickly and was packaged nicely, and I've made 7 lattes so far. I bought the Mr. Coffee espresso maker to replace the more expensive DeLonghi machine Ive been using for the past few years. My DeLonghi broke probably due to me not cleani mg it enough but it was an impressive little guy. But going by the reviews on here I decided to be more frugal and go with a cheaper model. Having been a barista back in college, I am somewhat of an espresso connoisseur. This Mr. Coffee machine does not pull a good creme on the espresso. The coffee is also a bit bitter, even using the same brand as I had used with my DeLonghi. It froths good enough I guess. I also find it inconvenient to have to add more water between the espresso and frothing in order to steam the milk. I wish I had bought another DeLonghi, but I guess I will get used to the Mr. COFFEE.

I tried to clean it by running several cycles of water through the machine and three cycles with vinegar and it still smelled and tasted like burning plastic. review_content:
This is a wonderful way to make a fast cup of coffee or espresso. AND when the kids come over with the GRAND CHILDREN it makes excellent cappuccinos!

This is my fifth ecmp50 espresso maker. First one lasted 2 1/2 years. The second one about 18 months.

Pro's
** FAST. It takes less than 2 minutes from start to finish to make a coffee or espresso. ...Wait...I'll go time one NOW...
1 minute 45 seconds... From turning it on, to cleaning out the coffee grounds from my last round of caffeination to BURNING my sipping lip.
** You use the coffee of your choice (no expensive plastic prepacked coffee shots to purchase)
** No bad chemical smells or after-taste in your drink from the coffee maker.
I plugged it in, ran 1/2 a container,about 20 oz of Distilled Water thru it, then made an espresso. It was perfect !
( I have bought other coffee and espresso makers that reek of a chemical smell, and impart a strange after taste to your drink for months,
until you throw the machine away and start over.)
** No screw cap lid to BLOW OFF, if the machine gets over pressurized or cap gets old.
( This actually occurred here before we bought this model. The Mr Coffee Blew its screw lid off into pieces.)
** Inexpensive. Well worth the price and convenience.

Cons
** Over caffeinated from ease of use

I also purchased the extended warranty... just in case... seemed like a good deal...

Coffee Up...
title: Caffeinators Heaven

review_content:
As others have noted a steam espresso machine like this one will not produce the visually appealing crema that one expects with espresso. It does, however, produce an excellent, very rich and very dark cup of coffee that you will never get from a drip coffee maker. It is easy to use and the first cup of espresso was excellent. I roast my own coffee beans so while I am not an expert on espresso I do take my coffee drinking seriously. I likely will never use the frothing feature but that doesn't make this machine any less of a bargain. BTW, the tamper sold by Amazon has a 51mm diamter that will work with this machine even though it touches the sides of the basket (but at a level below that used for even one shot).

3 month update: I still believe this espresso maker is an incredible bargain. The only advice I have is use espresso beans and don't use too much ground coffee. Over packing of coffee may or may not shorten the life of the machine but it will definitely produce coffee with a bitter taste.

8 month update: I purchased the De'Longhi EC155 that I now use at home. The steam espresso machine is now in my office. At work I prefer an actual cup of coffee and as noted above it produces a very strong dark coffee of java. Better than any drip coffee machine can.

12 month update: Still working perfectly and producing excellent coffee. I've come to appreciate the espresso made by the De'Longhi with its incredibly thick crema but at work I seem to need a larger cup of java. Two of the three tabs on the coffee pot lid have broken off but the lid stays on when you pour out coffee. I inadvertently left the machine on brew for about an hour when there was no water in it and surprisingly it has continued to work perfectly. This machine may outlast several drip coffee makers I've owned!
title: incredible bargain
bought_model: Color: CappuccinoStyle Name: 4-Cup Steam

review_content:
UPDATE: It finally gave up the ghost 06/2015. I feel like I got my money's worth and will be purchasing another just like it.
UPDATE: Purchased 02/2012. Still going strong 03/2015 after two coffees (or more) per day over the last three years.

I bought this espresso maker 16 months ago and it's still going strong. I chose it because I didn't need any bells or whistles, and I was only interested in the lower-cost machines. I'm afraid to say that it has converted me and my non-coffee-drinking spouse into daily coffee drinkers. I'm no espresso buff, but I love the foam (crema?) that it makes on top of the espresso, as well as the milk frother. I don't mind waiting 30 seconds for it to warm up and another 60 seconds for it to brew a cup. If you want an affordable, simple to use espresso maker that can handle daily use, this is the one for you.

This little gem is a lot of fun! Cheap and it does all the work for you. Just add espresso grounds and it heats or froths milk and then pulls your espresso. I am very impressed with the ease of use and consistency of the device. I also like that the milk container has a cleaning function and allows me to detach it and store it in the fridge. No waste of excess milk.
I have had more espresso and Lattes in the last week or so than I have had in the last few months. Its so easy to operate!
title: Great Purchase
bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Espresso/Cappuccino Maker

review_content:
I have owned espresso machines for over 30 years, German/Italian, etc. I bought this one as a temporary while waiting for my shipment to arrive from overseas; my 'good' espresso machine was in the shipment. This machine cost less than half what I paid for the other machine and what a surprise!! This is by far the best espresso machine I have ever owned. When making espresso it 'wets' the grounds, waits a few seconds and then pumps a really great cup of espresso... with 1/4 inch of foam on top!!

The only drawback is that the basket needs to be washed between cups (due to the design), but, this is a small item compared to the outstanding quality coffee it makes. The cleaning is required due to the basket design, which I suspect is partly responsible for the foam (creama).

I recommend this machine to anyone that values really great coffee. The machine is part of the story, you also need very fresh dark roasted top quality Arabic beans that are fresh ground.

In this case, Mr. Coffee has hit a home run!!

I cleaned the machine several times, thinking it could be dirt or left over coffee from before, but still, the coffee just doesn't taste the same, and we are using the exact same espresso coffee I always used. Also, I like big espresso shots. This machine only makes decent small espresso shots. When you let it pour a bit more than an small espresso shot, it gets too watery and the taste is awful. I give it a 3 stars because the machine does its work, I just don't enjoy it after one year the taste of the coffee that makes it any longer.

review_content:
well I liked it for the money, it made a good latte but it quit working after 4 months. I should probably give it one star because of that but maybe my unit was a fluke.

If you do purchase this first thing to do is toss the rubber frother that goes over the wand. you won't want to purchase anything larger than a 20 oz pitcher to steam milk in as the wand is very small and the machine will shut down the steamer after a minute or two so there is no way you can make enough milk for more than one latte anyway. the whole process from steaming to the espresso function is rather slow. It's not a big deal for one person but if you have a few people over it's a bit of an ordeal.
I have purchased cheap espresso machines in the past and they all have been crap so I take that into consideration and I have to say that I enjoyed this machine quite a bit for the price - while it worked.
I bought the extended warranty and it's probably still under the manufacturer's warranty but dealing with this is a real pain in the behind and I am without coffee for the foreseeable future.

Edit: I had to lower it to one star as I have been blown off by both the extended warranty company and the manufacturer trying to get this replaced. I was told to contact amazon and try to get my money back but that of course is not an option since the return window had closed. no rma or any further information was sent about how to return this defective hunk of crud was given. what a pain in the behind this has become. the cheap espresso maker is not so inexpensive after all.

Icing on the cake!!! I would appreciate any assistance as this has been the most frustrating purchase!
title: fine, etc and nothing
bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Espresso/Cappuccino Maker

review_content:
I love steam espresso. It's the only way I've liked coffee for over 15 years. My first steam espresso maker back in the '90s was made by Mr. Coffee, and it was wonderful. Since then, I've owned a Melitta and two Krups. The Krups were by far the best, but apparently Krups has stopped making steam espresso machines. The page on their website is now blank.

Anyway, all my previous steam espresso machines were pretty much the same, except for a few quality issues. This new one looks about like all the others. But don't be fooled. This is pure junk. Having used it for a week, I'm going to have to admit I wasted my money and buy a different brand. I suggest if you want a steam espresso machine, look elsewhere.

This thing makes strong espresso one time, and weak watery espresso the next time. One time, it has plenty of steam pressure for frothing, the next time, no steam whatsoever. Sometimes it spits coffee all over the counter. Sometimes it starts filling the carafe with cold water even before it has started to heat. It feels like flimsy junk. The frothing wand isn't long enough for anything but a very small pitcher. The plastic top doesn't really fit the carafe and falls off if you're not careful.

Take my advice. Buy a different machine. This one is pure junk.

FOLLOWUP AFTER A FEW MONTHS:
This unit didn't cut it. It's sitting out of the way gathering dust. I miss my Krups. I've gone to making espresso with a pump machine. They're more expensive and the flavor of the espresso is duller, but at least the machines are good enough quality to work.
title: Worst possible junk -- Do not buy!
bought_model: Color: CappuccinoStyle Name: 4-Cup Steam

review_content:
In the beginning this was a great alternative to not going to the coffee shop down the road, for 4 dollar a double espresso shot, macchiato, or cappuccino. As i said...it did work great, but quickly dwindled.

As with my other regular espresso machine, I cleaned, washed the decanter, etc. after each use. Used distilled water, and cleaned with vinegar after the appropriate amount of cups were made. Yet three months into it it started failing.
First the milk canister did not want to froth, instead I received sputtering, as if it were clogged, tried whole, 2% and nonfat- same results. I chalked this up to the milk, so I used the steam cleaning method to "wash-out" the system. Re-tried, yet nothing changed. I then started stemming before each use, for it to give me a sub-par milk froth.

After 3 weeks of working with it, the espresso itself started not working. I would choose single or double shot, for it to only half way through excrete a small amount of coffee, leaving me with a un-made shot of espresso. I even wasted making four shots of espresso to amount to a one double-shot.

This product worked for the minuscule amount of time I have had it. Now after the espresso part failed, the milk frothing is completely obsolete. Yes, it worked great, yet only for half the time of ownership. Now I am going through the process of returning the unit to Mr.Coffee, since it is out of return time for Amazon. Mr. Coffee is replacing mine, hopefully it last longer than before.

****Update:
Mr. Cofee without hesitation sent me another replacement, as with the first it worked great every morning, until 3 months later it simply decided to not froth, then the shots became less and less, until the sweet coffee of love did not even come out. Literally....not one drop of sweet nectar of love.

I wanted to love this machine...but sadly it does not even stand up to my original espresso machine, ironically , my 4 year old... 50 dollar steam espresso machine-works and froths with the frothing wand without problem- and I love seeing it every morning.

I uploaded a video, of the second machine with the loud struggling noise. (Both progressively became louder by the week.....the original gave a sputter....along with a high pitch wining noise..it sounds like my foodsaver....but 'tis it is not)
title: 1st and replacement broken in 4 months. WHY won't you let me love you Mr. Coffee
bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Espresso/Cappuccino Maker

review_content:
Update April 21 2018. I've owned a bunch of these now over many years ‚Äî new, used, and refurbished, paid $50‚Äì$85. Just ordered another. Takeaway: buy new for $85, with free shipping. It will produce five excellent coffees a day for two+ years, then die. Used or refurbished will die fast (like three months in one case).

Pretty much everything is right about this; it just works great. In particular it does NOT run super-heated steam through coffee like the delonghi we bought recently as a try, which we're now selling on craigslist. (Horribly bitter coffee results.)

Figure you're renting the thing for $40 a year.

Update March 27, 2015. Just died. Flashing lights only. The repair process described on the web is FAR too involved.

So two years of daily multi-cup service and good-quality coffee for $75. (My previous cheap Delonghi started breaking within nine months and was dead in 18.)

Now maybe a machine that costs five or ten times as much would last longer. But really: five or ten times as long? I'm ordering another one of these.

Update Nov. 2 2013: Now at seven months and going strong, so it's already outlasted the Delonghi.

Just replaced my Delonghi Bar 32 which worked pretty well but disintegrated over 18 months.

http://www.amazon.com/review/R20S4H2K6MG0UR/ref=cm_srch_res_rtr_alt_4

Much prefer how this one works. Heats up much faster -- less than a minute, and only about 15 seconds to get steam up to heat after making coffee.

With the Delonghi if I let the steam light turn on (so the heating element went off), it would run out of steam power before finishing the steaming. So I had to let the steam heat up to *just before* it got to "ready," so the element would stay on and maintain steam pressure. Annoying management in the early hours of the morning...

The steamer is much more effective with plenty of steam power, makes very rich, stiff foam even with whole milk.

In general this machine is much "smarter" than the Delonghi. Won't explain boring niggling details but it manages things for you more.

And I don't have to refill the water reservoir nearly as often as with the Delonghi.

And it's $72 instead of $120.

I've had it less than a month, so we'll see how long it lasts.
title: Works very well, lasted two years of daily multi-cup use. $75. Just ordered another one.
bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Automatic Dual Shot

review_content: I looked at all the "systems" & chose this one because some of the higher rated ones seemed to have design flaws & stopped working & because I refuse to be tied to a pod.  I wasn't even sure exactly what I liked except I like coffee & froth & used to adore the Sensio system which is obsolete as u can't get the pods.  Well now I can tell you I'm a double cappuccino girl!  EVERYONE who comes to my house LOVES what they request -- espresso, cappuccino or latte.  Every morning as I sip my first cup I reflect that coffee doesn't get any better.
title: Buying double glass cups really keeps your cappuccino hot & looks ver fancy--doesn't get any better!

After 2 months of trying to get a replacement from Mr. Coffee, we‚Äôve realized that the piece isn‚Äôt replaceable!  It‚Äôs an important piece because the milk won‚Äôt froth as well and it‚Äôs aparently a sound muffler, as well. So now I have this. Cappuccino/espresso machine that‚Äôs worthless to me after 1 weeks use that I spent $60 on. Very disappointed in Mr. Coffee and now will only buy local.

review_content: Yes, I still use it, but I would not recommend it. I don't know how, but some grounds got stuck in the duct and it took about a half hour of running water through it in reverse to get them free. Back pressure from the frothing wand sucks liquid from it back into the tank, so after each time you turn the frother off, let it run for a second to get any foreign liquid out of the pipe. The plastic cover for the frother wand broke after about three months. If you're looking for something cheap, I'm sure there are better options to consider if you want to pay a just a little more.
title: TL;DR, it works, but it's very cheap and has lots of problems\
bought_model: Color: CappuccinoStyle Name: 4-Cup Steam

review_content:
I have been a barista for ~4 years so I might be a little biased when it comes to the quality of espresso machines as I'm used to the really really expensive ones. Anyway, I wanted a little machine for my apartment so that I wouldn't be spending a bunch of money on coffee during the school year and I have never been a huge fan of Keurig coffee as it's too weak. So I bought this machine because it was cheap and had decent reviews. It makes pretty good espresso with CREMA, which is awesome for such a low price machine. The steam wand is really short and it doesn't really heat up your milk very well... I have found that the milk is foaming and about to overflow before it's even at a good temperature, which sucks. It might just take some getting used to. The other annoying thing about this machine is that it is LOUD. I haven't seen anyone put that in their reviews and I really was not expecting it to be that loud.

All in all, I got what I paid for and I'm not disappointed as I know it's probably that I'm just used to the more expensive machines at work. It will take some getting used to but it really does make decent espresso and if you work at it, a decent latte/cappuccino too.

review_content: Bought first one at Target. Set up machine and followed instruction exactly as stated-even priming the frother. The machine started smoking from top and a plastic smell started to permeate my whole kitchen. There was also a terrible knocking sound-not sure if this is normal with pump espresso makers. Between the loud, annoying noise, smoke, and smell, I decided I bought a "lemon." I returned it to Target and bought another one. After following instructions again, I brewed my first cup of espresso (very noisy machine) which came out fine. I then proceeded to froth my milk-well, guess what, frother didn't work! Same annoying knocking noise started coming out of machine as well. My husband and I fiddled with it and re-read instructions 10 times. Frother was just sputtering along and then finally died. I am in the process of packing this up and returning it as well. I won't try for a third "strike." I'm done with this espresso maker-total piece of junk!

review_content: I give this a 5 star review based off the value and quality. Sure, it is not a true pump driven espresso machine, but I now prefer my homemade mocha's over those at the coffee shops. I have saved myself thousands of dollars with this little beast. They do clog up over time, you should run some vinegar or other solution through it per instructions every now and then. I also advise using filtered water, especially if you have hard water. Whenever I want a little something special with this baby, I put a bikini on it so it's just like I am at my local bikini barista lol! Seriously, I did Photoshop a bikini on this when I first got it.

review_content: This machine will work good if you take the time to learn how to grind the correct beans at a good espresso grind and more.  You must clean the frother hole when it plugs...it IS NOT broken when this happens.  I am not an expert, but I took the time to learn things on youtube.  You also need to pack the correct grind tight to the top, but not too tight.  I used a medium  roast by Carribue, and it worked pretty good.  The expresso must come out light brown and foamy most of the time.  It just takes experimenting.  For the price, it makes a delicious mocha or Chino.  I imagine the bad reviews are people like me when I made mistakes and didn't clean it properly when the frother clogged, and when it didn't shoot out expresso perfect when I did it wrong....keep trying.  Good luck peeps.
title: Machine takes a little knowledge, you can't be oblivious

review_content:
Overall, I have had a positive experience with the Cafe Barista as a simple, no-nonsense espresso machine.

Cons:

- You still do have to grind beans and tamp the coffee yourself. This is a lot of work. For approximately double the cost, you can have a super-automatic espresso maker that will do this for you. Something to keep in mind.

- A big part of the front section of this machine is dedicated to, perhaps even crowded by, a milk frother. This is a total waste for me, since I like to drink my espresso (brewed as a 'long shot', i.e. more dilute) as coffee with just a touch of creamer instead of ruining it by dumping it into scalding hot milk. In other words, I am not a big fan of lattes and cappuccinos, so this focus on the milk frother seems silly to me.

Pros:

- Makes a nice espresso. This might sound simple, but there is actually a lot that goes into this (perfect temperature, pressure, timing) and this machine seems to get it right.

- Nice size water reservoir. I personally don't like removing it and filling it at the tap (because it gets heavy!). Instead, I use a wine decanter to fill it.

- Straightforward buttons on the front panel

- All that coffee grind tamping is a really great arm workout!

Overall, if you are looking for a semi-automatic espresso maker, then this is a great option.
title: Mr. Coffee Cafe Barista Espresso Maker

review_content: I use this as a 1-cup coffeemaker.  For me, it is the Keurig I never bought.  Keurigs are IMHO: 1) overpriced appliance, 2)overpriced coffee, 3)fewer choices of coffees, and 4)too big.  I love this Mr. Coffee.  An ordinary coffeemaker can't do a single cup well.  I read somewhere that as a matter of physics, it takes time for the grounds to absorb hot water and then leach out the tasty oils needed for a good brew. Single-cup drip pots yield a flat yucky brew even if you put extra grounds in.  I had found that with one of those silver stovetop expressomakers I got a nice, layered single cup of coffee, I suppose because of the forcing of steam through the grounds.  With this nice Mr Coffee expressomaker we get to use our favorite coffee which it took us forever to find.  I haven't tried to do cappuccino or latte.  Don't care if I ever do.  This machine is just a tad flimsy but for less than $40 I am thrilled.  I just love the coffee I am drinking!!

title: Best machine ever!!!!
bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Espresso/Cappuccino Maker

review_content:
I got this thing right around the holidays thinking that it would make a nice treat for guests and family, and because I secretly want to be a Barista. It was at first a disappointment. It took me about 2 months before I figured it out and got it making good shots. The first pot of "espresso" I got out of it by just letting it run tasted like it came out of the back side of a horse. But it was on par with the coffee I had been drinking out of an auto drip machine all my life. There were many reasons for this, mostly because of my own fault but the machine itself has a lot of quirks that must be accounted for before you get a good cup out of it. But I will say, with practice it is possible to get a good cup out of it. Rather than going through the good and bad things about the machine I'm gonna tall you how I was able to get a good shot out of it and general tips to make it work for you.

General Tips:
1. Get a good grinder. A burr grinder is a must. The hand grinders are good and cheap but take a lot of work. A decent auto one can be had for under 60. If you try to do it with anything less the brew will be pretty terrible. Use a pretty fine grind, but not as fine as "true espresso".
2. Use whole beans, dark roast, and grind them yourself. Pre-ground coffee doesn't do well in this thing, and its often too coarse. ALthough they do sell some preground "espresso beans" that have the right grind and may work okay.
3. Fill the tank up almost to the top with water before brewing.
4. Buy a decent tamper. The one that comes with it wont work.
5. If you fill the portafilter (the basket) to the very top with grounds, its good for about 1-2 shots and no more. Not the 4 that it advertises. If you fill it to the top and tamp it down its just about right for a single cup.
6. The steaming wand is funny. Once it is up to pressure it puts out a good amount of steam. The bad is that its short as heck and it doesn't move. Use it with a 12-ounce pitcher and tilt the whole machine to get the angle right. It takes a lot of work to get it right and its like you need 3 hands but its possible. Also the froth assister only works if you line the intake hole right up against the surface of the milk, otherwise throw it away and learn to steam without it. Also the steaming wand MUST be cleaned after every use with soap and water, otherwise the milk will collect on it and stay there and make you sick.
7. I don't think I've been able to use this thing without making at least a small mess in some way. Clean after every use.
8. Start with making Americanos which are diluted 1:1 with water. They are very forgiving. Once you nail that, then try venturing to making a good espresso shot by itself and other milk based drinks.

Brew Method:
1. Fill the water tank.
2. Clean out and dry the filter basket and head.
3. Dry the basket and fill with grounds to the top, then tamp (fairly hard, this helps build up pressure when brewing). This is good for 1 shot. For 2 shots fill the basket again on top of the first tamp and tamp again. (Although if you don't tamp at all you can get decent americano like coffee)
4. Put the head, without the basket with the grounds on the machine. Turn the machine to steam and wait for it to build up pressure.
5. Once steam is coming out a full pressure (still without the grounds or basket in yet) put an empty cup under the spout and turn it to brew. This flushes out the water spout of old grounds, heats the head and the cup, and helps get the pressure up.
6. Once a bit of water starts coming out turn the machine to the off position. Dump the water that came out and replace the cup, take off the head and put the basket with the grounds in it. Put it back on the machine and lock it in.
7. Turn the dial to brew again. And begin the brew.
8. Stop it after about 2-3 ounces for a single shot, or about 5 ounces for a double shot. Remove the cup immediately. The drops that continue to drip taste terrible. Either let it collect in the drip tray or put another cup to catch it and throw it out.
9. Add water for an americano, or steamed milk for a latte or cappuccino. Or drink it straight if you're hardcore.

Steaming Milk with the Steam Wand:
1. Add cold milk to a cup or steaming pitcher. You only need about 3-6 ounces. Make sure its a pretty shallow container. The wand's not very long.
2. Turn the dial to steam to let it build up pressure. Stop it after its at pressure.
3. (Froth assister) Immerse the the milk so the surface is right at the intake hole on the black plastic piece. Turn the steam on and let it froth keeping the hole right at the surface, until the milk is just about too hot to touch. Turn the steam off.
3. (No froth assister) If you're not using the froth assister then put the tip just below the surface and tilt the machine about 30 degrees. You are aiming for a smooth churring. If it sounds like a snake hiss you're too deep (can burn the milk) and if it sounds like blowing bubbles through a straw you're too shallow (losing texture). After you get enough air into it (about 10 seconds) sink the tip deeper and let it whirlpool. If it screeches, you need to bring it back up and get more air into it. Keep the angle the whole time. Once its just too hot to touch turn of the steam.
4. Stamp the container on the counter a few times to get rid of the big bubbles, and swirl it for a bit to polish the texture and infuse the foam.
5. Pour it into your drink. Use a spoon to hold back the foam, and scoop it on top for a cappuccino. If you want latte art, its possible but you'll have to learn on your own.

Overall: Comparing this to other espresso machines that cost 10 times or a 100 times more, this machine is pretty terrible. But as a way to learn how to make a good shot this machine is perfect. If you can get a good shot out of this thing, you can get a good shot out of almost anything. Its perfect for what I needed, but if you just want it to work, look elsewhere.

review_content:
After a trip to Europe in '09, and enjoying some of the best coffee ever (and it's hard to beat fresh-brewed over a campfire at 9500 feet in Wyoming!) I discovered that the coffee was being brewed one cup at a time, and with pump espresso machines, although not quite at espresso strength, as per my wishes.
So, returning to the states, I knew what I had to do----but then, which machine?
Nope, can't drop $400+, so started doing my research in cyber-land. Long story short, this machine is the only 15 bar pump available for under $100, and 2 years ago it was about $70 on Amazon.
I have one of these, ditto my brother, we both drink a fair amount of coffee, and we are both equally happy with our machines. I can't comment on anything other than straight-ahead coffee, since that's all I use it for.
I read about the supposedly leaky machines, and instantly wonder if the user is emptying the bottom tray regularly, which is necessary. Mr. Coffee figured out a way to make an exemplary machine for not a lot of money, but I believe the end user must become at least a little educated in its use---I think this is the trade-off here, but a terrific bargain, IMO.
I have used this machine for over 2 years now without any sort of issue---coffee is consistently good, and the machine operates flawlessly---all it asks of me is to keep water in the reservoir, empty the bottom tray often, and use some sort of cleaner from time to time if your water has deposits of one sort or another.
The only time my machine ever acted up was one time in the mountains at over 9200 feet, and I think for 2 reasons---water boils at a lower temp, and perhaps the coffee must be ground a smidgeon coarser---we'll find out next year!
All I can say is that if this machine quit today, I'd instantly be ordering another 'right here where I got the first one.'
title: Great Machine!!
bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Automatic Dual Shot

review_content:
I love my espresso maker, it makes great espresso. The only downside to this product is the built in milk frother is useless as a frother, but that's not its fault. Frothing milk properly for a latte or cappuccino requires more than just blowing a little compressed hot air into the milk. The good news is that the frother setting isn't useless, it makes an important pressure release valve so you can safely turn it off and unscrew the lid after you've unplugged it and used the frother to expel all the excess pressure, avoiding steam burns.

Over all, I gave this espresso maker a 5 because for its price, it's hard to find a comparable espresso maker. It makes good espresso, and that's all it does. The fact that it only makes espresso is actually a plus in my book, complicated latte and cappuccino makers with internal milk bags and creamer are a huge pain to clean and always get clogged. This espresso maker has simple cleaning instructions, and only requires a full cleaning about every other month, and it's fairly simple to do. It's a good simple, durable, easy to clean espresso maker and I love it!
