However, at this price point, I think small gripes like that are acceptable - it's a great little machine for trying your hand at home-made cappuccino.

review_content:
I was initially only researching Italian-made espresso machines, despite my adventures in owning two Fiats in my youth. However, after stumbling on this model with its 15 bar pump, reading the mostly positive reviews, and doing a double take over the reasonable price, I decided to go with it. It was shipped promptly by Dealyard, an Amazon partner. I've only tried it to make certain it works, and that was with a rather coarse ground espresso intended for brewing in a mocha pot (stovetop), but it brewed a nice espresso with a reasonable crema. I would suspect it could only do better with the proper grind and a better coffee (I'd recommend Pilon. Along with Bustelo, the two most popular espresso products in South Florida used for cafe cubano, most Italians recommend Pilon).

Without beating the science of espresso to death, I'd just say so far I'm pleased. Also, since espresso machines, regardless of brand or origin, seem to eventually break down I purchased a two year replacement plan through another Amazon company (NEW Replacement Coverage) which goes into effect after the one-year factory warranty expires, and I receive an additional year of coverage from Amex after all others expire through their extended warranty benefit, four years of coverage in all.

review_content:
Having been raised on South Indian filter coffee, I always have coffee with milk, and prefer it 'strong'. Coffee from standard coffee makers (with cream) is just too light and bland for my liking. Even cappuccino at most coffee shops tastes like lightly flavored milk foam. I usually make do with Nescafe Instant in hot milk, but I wanted a little variety. That's when I decided to get this. Keep in mind that this is my first Espresso maker, so many of my pros and cons might apply to Espresso makers in general and not just this unit.

This is my modus operandi:
1. Empty water reservoir. Fill with fresh water (since I usually make only a cup a day; more on weekends)
2. Dig out coffee from filter pod using a fork, wash, fill with fresh ground coffee (2-3 mins)
2. Turn on coffee maker. Wait for green light (1 min)
3. Poke the steam nozzle with a safety pin to ensure its not clogged
4. Fill half of coffee mug with milk. Steam using coffee maker till frothing (2-3 mins)
5. Add sugar
6. Place mug on coffee maker tray, switch to espresso, turn off when mug nearly full and remove mug quickly (1 min)
7. Run some steam into a cup with water and clean the steam nozzle with a paper towel (1-2 mins)

Totally takes about 10-12 mins. Nescafe instant coffee (just microwave milk, mix in instant coffee and sugar) takes just 2-3 mins total.

Pros:
1. It works
2. I can adjust the proportion of milk and espresso to get just the right strength and taste; coffee from standard coffee makers is too light no matter what I do
3. I'm experimenting with various types of coffee; can't do that with instant
4. Cheap (comparing with other pressure-based Espresso makers)
5. Steam maker great for frothing milk
6. Coffee mug platform has a decent-sized reservoir for overflow
7. Large water reservoir when making several cups a day
8. Option to fill 2 cups at once - I don't do this often since that makes each cup too dilute for my liking

Cons:
1. Very noisy! I can't use it early in the morning when we have guests over for fear of waking them up (our guest bedroom is close to our kitchen).
2. Steam nozzle had dried up the second time I used it and nothing came out, and after a minute I heard a loud pop and had steam coming out the top of the unit! Pricking the nozzle with a safety pin fixed this; I do this before each use now.
3. Even the larger filter pod doesn't give a strong/large enough shot of espresso - this is just based on my personal preference. I've reduced the volume of milk to compensate, but that gives a smaller cup of coffee than I'd like ideally.
4. Too little clearance between the espresso spouts and the coffee tray for most coffee cups.
5. The whole thing just takes a tad too long for my liking, with too many things to be done, for such a small cup of coffee in the end. I'm still resorting to instant more than half the time.

To summarize, if you're sure about getting an Espresso maker, getting this one is an easy choice - it works well and comes cheap. If you're not sure what it takes to use an Espresso maker, consider the time and effort you need to spend to get a relatively small cup of coffee, before you take the plunge.

review_content:
Once you get the drill down, you can make some pretty good espresso like coffee with this little beast (no, it isn't real espresso, but pretty decent). Reasonably easy to run (do read the instructions though). It can't compete with the $5000.00 outfits in your local coffee shop but it'll save you enough money to pay for itself in short order.

I've had mine for about three months, so here's some pros and cons:

Pros
- Good coffee (if you use good coffee and a decent grind) done fairly quick (say, 5 minutes from start to finish?)
- Not terribly noisy.
- Makes a good brew every time.
- Froths pretty decent too (I'm an Americano guy, but I have made a latte or two).
- Pretty good creama, every time.
- One scoop (1 tablespoon?) of coffee makes a great brew - don't dilute it with too much water though :(
Cons
- After I brew coffee, my machine drips for a few minutes.
- Messy cleanup. Emptying the coffee grounds can make a big mess since the "puck" is more like soup. My old (and base model Mr Coffee espresso maker) spoiled me with a good, dry puck at the end of its brew cycle. Be careful when you empty (and clean) the brew basket or the coffee "soup" can fly everywhere).
- Doesn't come with a carafe so you need to use a coffee cup, or??? when you brew the coffee.
- Don't bother tamping coffee in the brew basket - you'll risk blowing the seal on the brew head (result? dead machine...)

At $3-4 bucks for an Americano at my favorite coffee joint, vs maybe $1 for good homemade; guess which one wins?

review_content:
I have been using modestly priced espresso makes for 20 years and, so, have had quite a few machines. This one makes very good espresso drinks. I use Starbucks coffee and it is one machine where you can tell what kind of coffee you're using. This is good. Since I mostly make lattes, the ease of using the milk container is important to me. I am used to having to hold a container while the nozzle steams the milk. Not with this machine. You pour the milk in a milk container, affix the container on to the machine, aim the nozzle into the cup and push the button. No holding the cup. After the steamed milk goes into the cup, the espresso is automatically added. Neat. Unfortunately, you won't get a full portion of steamed milk unless you have almost completely filled the milk container because the suction apparatus doesn't work if the milk level is less than (almost) an inch. So, after you make your drink, you have left-over milk in the container to store or throw away. Also, it's more time consuming to clean that milk container than it is to wipe a nozzle. After a month's worth of use, I find myself using Q-tips to get the milk gunk out of the interior of the steaming tub. I find this annoying, but can live with it. It is really nice not to have to stand there and hold a container while the steamed milk is prepared.

I read a number of the reviews before I purchased this machine. Much to my surprise I did not find the milk container "flimsy" and I did not have to put vinegar through the machine in order to get it to heat properly.
title: More automatic than most espresso machines, but not without flaws

review_content:
UPDATE: My cup seemed to be filling up less and less over time, until I followed the tips for cleaning with vinegar. After completing the process, I am happy to report that my drinks are coming out better than ever. Also, you should be cleaning the milk dispenser lid and tube after every use. If you don't, the steamed milk will dry and gunk up the dispenser. I just take the lid off, flush out the tubes with hot water, and it's good to go for next time!

This is one of the best $100 I've ever spent. This machine does it all, and is extremely easy to use. It paid for itself in a little under 3 weeks. I used to spend $5 a day on my morning latte, now I can make one myself that actually tastes a heck of a lot better, for about 40 cents. Probably less than that if you use a cheap brand espresso, but I recommend Lavazza! The best part is the customization controls; I love being able to add more frothed milk at the touch of a button. Getting a second one for my office as well!!

I bought this at Targ√©t for $29, and it is freaking awesome. To the two reviewers above... if you actually read the manual you would know that the cord underneath the base can be unraveled to the desired length. This is to eliminate excess cord on your countertop.

Anyway, I discovered I was spending almost $200 at Starbucks... a near crack habit. My previous espresso machine broke over the summer--a $300 Gaggia. Prior to the gaggia I had a krups.

So I plunked down a few bucks for this one knowing I was taking a wee gamble. Usually you get what you pay for.

Let me tell ya, this little machine is great. First, it is super super quiet. My previous machines were deafening especially when frothing. Secondly, it takes up little space. Third, it's fairly nice looking and matches our coffee maker. And of course last, it makes great latt√©s.

So, don't waste your money on some huge hulking espresso machine that will only last a few years. This one does the job and won't cause ear trauma.

review_content:
We love this coffee machine. Had to replace a well-loved, 8-yr KRUPS and decided to give this a try. Very happy!

Lots of options with simple controls. Able to do large or small servings, add a little more espresso or a little more milk as needed. Skim milk froths really well. (We use coconut milk a lot. Not a frothy, but very good.) Cleaning setting is so nice!

It took a few days to get the hang of it. (Couple times I forgot to position the milk spout properly and ended up with milk all over the counter. Or I forgot to set the milk dial properly after cleaning and didn't get milk in my cup.) But now, it's an easy routine.

Only two minor complaints: very loud when steaming/frothing milk; takes a couple minutes to warm up.

I understand there are really crazy expensive machines that will do something like the coffeehouse. But if your looking for something economical and flexible, you should give this a try. We are very happy with it.

This economical machine will last about 1 year, before the frothing either quits getting up to the appropriate temperature, or the frothing takes forever to reach the appropriate temperature.  We make 1 to 2 drinks with it everyday & it lasts about 1 year before we need to replace it.  Which is very economical if you would otherwise go out & purchase one drink per morning at $3.50-$5.00/drink.

review_content: I have had this coffee maker for over a year now.  First, it seemed like it came without a piece, so the frother wasn't working at all.  I called Mr. Coffee and customer service had no idea what I meant, but I explained that unless the milk could defy gravity, there was definitely a piece missing.  Since they didn't know how the coffee maker worked any better than I did, they couldn't send me the part.  I ended up using a plastic straw to insert in the frother to ultimately make it work.  The machine takes a long time to heat up, so by the time you remember that you were going to make a cup of coffee, it has auto-shut off again.  The double espresso latte makes such a huge cup of coffee that no mug that could actually fit inside the machine would actually be able to hold all that coffee and milk.  Although I like that it automatically froths your milk, it is still such a hassle that I rarely use this machine and wish I had returned it the second I realized a part was missing.  I'm sure I'll be switching to a different latte maker pretty soon.
title: Do not buy this machine!

review_content: Pros - Good price. It doesn't take up a whole lot of space. Brews quickly. Cons - Water reservoir and the On-Off-Steam knobs are difficult to use especially when the machine is still hot/warm. That makes them difficult to turn if your making multiple cups.  Older people (like me) will have this problem. The seal between the cup holding the coffee grounds and the machine is very poor. Before the coffee is completely brewed steam is pouring out and I mean pouring, from this seal and also the reservoir seal. Be careful you don't get burned. Within two weeks the handle broke off from the carafe ring. I had this problem twice with a Krups machine. I finally repaired them both (like they should have been constructed n the first place) and I have no further problem.

review_content:
I decided to try this model after using Mr. Coffee's small (non-pump) model for many years, and loving it, frankly. I am blown away daily by the quality of espresso this machine produces. I use a dark-roasted bean from Ethiopia that I absolutely love, the best coffee I have ever tasted. This machine pulls flavors out of my beans that I never knew were there!
Earlier reviewers have said that the new user should read the manual. They are correct. 10 minutes spent on the front end reading all the instructions will make all the difference in the world. Also be forewarned; you will need to empty the drip tray after each use. A small inconvenience for truly outstanding espresso.
I am serious: the crema, temperature, and bouquet of flavors that this machine produces even exceed many of the shots I have had at really excellent shops in Europe and here in the nearby Major Metropolis. That I can get espresso this good for under $75, that blows away shots made by $1500 machines, is amazing to me.
title: Holy CRAP! This thing is wonderful!
bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Automatic Dual Shot

review_content: I have had my machine since June 2016.  Not quite 2 years.  I have used it every day until last Monday when I switched it on and it wouldn't work. My husband determined that it was a fuse.  After replacing the fuse, the circuit board shorted out.  It was good while I had it but now I have to replace it after less than 2 years.  We called and they offered us 15% off of a new one.  I can get a better deal at Kroger.
title: Affordable
bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Automatic Dual Shot

review_content:
Everything about this product seemed great until it came down to actually tasting the espresso. There is an extremely distinguishable plastic/metallic taste that carries into the taste of the espresso.
I don't know how nobody else has mentioned this because I actually had the product replaced via Mr.Coffee warranty and the replacement had the same issue
When you open the Reservoir, the smell is immediately evident. I followed instructions to clean the machine with water. I did so twice. The drinks were still coming out with the plastic/metallic taste. So I used a vinegar/water combination to clean the machine and ran through at least 3 additional times.
Still tasted metallic.
Even the steamed milk had a very slight hint of this taste because it is obviously being picked up during the steaming process while the water is in the reservoir.

I had difficulty using milk alternatives such as soy milk and could only froth about 1/4-1/3 cup of milk at a time because the steaming is too powerful and bubbles become too big.

I also had to purchase a tamp and frothing mug seperately
title: Everything about this product seemed great until it came down to actually tasting the espresso

review_content: I was looking for an espresso machine that wouldn't break the bank, but would also produce "true" espresso (15 bar pressure). This one caught my eye as it is a semi-automatic 3-in-1 espresso, cappuccino and latte maker. To make a latte, for example, simply fill the milk reservoir and it will add the proper amount of milk and froth to your cup before adding the espresso. I've been using the machine since Christmas 2017 and it produces delicious, creamy espresso every time.
title: Awesome, budget friendly, semi-automatic, 15-bar espresso machine

review_content: What a huge disappointment. In service just since Christmas of 2015, this machine seemed to be managing a highly competent job of preparing both latte and espresso beverages. Then, two days ago, the machine seemed to be slowing down... a goodly amount of froth, with dribbles of coffee into a cup which then overflowed on the two size serving. Yesterday, the Cafe Barista went bonkers... all was fine through the milk preparation and, then, when time for the coffee, there was a mini-pressure explosion that spewed hot coffee and tons of coffee grounds all around the handle of the coffee insert and into the coffee, around the machine, onto the floor. To make certain the preparation was properly instituted, we then tried twice more, with the last attempt proving to be rather dangers, with hot coffee rocketing from the coffee holder insert toward the preparers, striking hands and arms with steaming beverage. Needless to say, Mr. Coffee is no longer a resident in our kitchen and we shall find another grand with which to enjoy our latte breaks mid-morning.

The machine is rather easy to use... not too noisy and seems to make a great espresso when it's working. Other than that...be prepared to have it work 1 in 3 to 4 times you use it! It became rather annoying and I got to the point that I was tired of wasting espresso and throwing so much of it in the trash. I've since parked the machine on the counter and now use a Keurig!

review_content:
Very convenient, easy to use and clean.

I like a lot more milk than the machine adds --- the easiest way to do this is to make an espresso and then long press the cappachino button, which will cause the machine to start dispensing frothed milk until you press the button again.

review_content:
If you are a serious espresso drinker, this one is not for you.

The most obvious observation is that it does not produce enough heat to extract the coffee flavor. It is cold almost as soon as you pour the coffee into a mug. Seems to me this is fatal to the enthusiasts.

Then there a few more quirks. The power chord is just too short, less than a foot. Not sure if the designers were environmentally conscious. Doesn't make sense. The knobs are slippery, hard to grip.

Then why did I buy it?

Well, I am not as serious espresso drinker. When I bought it, it was on a big sale. So I guess I couldn't lose that much. Since I drink about a cup a day, I just use it as a regular coffee maker. I was aware of the unfavorable reviews. But that was an informed decision.

If you want another way to make very strong, D-minus drip-coffee alternative, buy this machine. If you in any remote way whatsoever want to enjoy a coffee beverage, DO NOT BUY THIS PRODUCT. review_content:
Short review: buy it, you won't be sorry.

Long review: I'm so glad my Keurig died so I could move on to something better. It's like dumping the disgusting pig and picking up a super babe. Hell, Keurig even sent me a free replacement brewer because they are so desperate to keep their client base. I'm selling it.

My in-laws have a $2000+ dollar machine that basically produces the same product. Yes, theirs does cool stuff like automatically grinds the beans and cleans itself. Sure, it will probably outlast the Mr. Coffee due to quality of components... But this machine, at $200 dollars makes an awesome cup of coffee (or espresso/cappuccino/latte for all you fancy folks). My wife also uses the frothing device for hot chocolate and loves it.

So far this machine is awesome. AWESOME. I look forward to having a cup everyday after work as a reward for another day in the books.

I'll update if something goes south. If no update is seen, this means the awesomeness is continuing.

Enjoy!!
title: Great Machine!!

review_content:
Have been using it for almost a year. Admittedly, it made great espresso, I liked it a lot.

However, this is not a safe product! I think I have to write it here to warn others who also bought this product.

This morning when I was brewing coffee as usual, the portafilter suddenly blew up and broke the glass decanter beneath. The coffee ground was everywhere on the wall and carpet! Fortunately I was not hurt, but the broken glasses are definitely something you don't want to see on your floor.

I uploaded a picture showing the accident scene.

The accident happened near the end of the brewing. Seems to me it's a malfunctioning portafilter lock, but I'm not sure. This part is supposed to be working under high pressure, I can't believe it failed so easily. Guess you got what you paid for.
title: This product is not safe!

I shouldn't have had such high expectations given the price tag, but less than a month of owning this thing and: the portafilter plastic handle broke inside so it slides off of the ground basket, it leaks water through the the dispenser when not in use, and half the time it does not dispense milk and I just get a lot of steam when making a latte. review_content:
We have had this machine for a year and a half. It is just starting to have that tired feel to it, and I'm about to get another one. My husband drinks a double shot every morning, and then the machine rests until next morning. We have noticed, as other reviews have said, that if you are making two espressos in a row, the second one isn't as good. I've never tried the steamed milk part, but I get plenty of crema on the espresso. You have to figure out the best grind and how hard to tamp the grinds. Making espresso is not an exact science, and that is the fun of it! I use a spice bottle for tamping, which works perfectly. I cannot see spending more money for a machine when this one meets our needs so well.

UPDATE - Here is how you make the best espresso with this newer model of the ECM160 espresso machine. First, have your beans ground to Turkish grind, the finest grind on commercial grinders. Or just grind your own beans super fine. For one shot, loosely fill the basket about 3/4 full. Tamp very gently to about 1/2 full. Do all your prep, turn machine on. The espresso will come out fairly steadily, and you'll think its done. Wait. Some crema will bubble out. Wait some more. Finally a solid stream of crema emerges. Leave the machine on for awhile until you are sure all moisture is out of the machine. Otherwise, it ends up in your next expresso, making the coffee watery. It took me awhile to figure all this out, but the espresso is excellent with about 1/2 of it crema.

If this sounds complicated, it really isn't. I just wanted to be very specific in my explanation.
title: update to great for single espresso
bought_model: Color: CappuccinoStyle Name: 4-Cup Steam

review_content: The knob which is turned to select the steam/espresso function is connected to the valve by a cheap plastic connection and will break easily. Unfortunately the valve is stiff when moving from one function to the other and this places additional stress on the plastic connection. This weakness is hidden from view.  My unit only lasted about a year before breaking; it makes good espresso and steam but don't expect much overall life of the appliance. When it breaks, there is no fixing - just toss it.
title: This appliance has a bad weakness
bought_model: Color: CappuccinoStyle Name: 4-Cup Steam

review_content:
This is the first espresso machine I've owned. I purchased because of the 15 bar pump, price, and double shot/frothing wand capabilities. The unit is easy to use (3 clearly defined steps), produces nice crema, contains steam well, is quick, and easy to clean. After using it a handful of times, I'd say it's a solid 4 stars. Sub 5-star because I'd prefer the frothing wand to be a little longer and without the rubber cap. The shortness of the frothing wand makes for a somewhat awkward frothing process. because of the shortness, you need to use a decent amount of milk for the wand to reach below the surface of the milk. Also, the portafilter requires a good amount of torque to get it to the lock position, although I know its a safety function to prevent steam from escaping while brewing. Other users have said that it loosens a little with use, so we'll see. You need to be sure that you use a cup/mug that is pretty short (3" or so). A standard size mug wont fit. And you have to manually stop the brewing process (turn knob from brew to stop) which is actually not a bad thing if you want to be able to adjust the strength. I spoon the grounds into the 14g filter and level it off before tamping. That gives a pretty consistent amount of grounds. The included scoop/tamp is nice but I'll probably purchase a stainless/heavy duty tamp because the plastic one included is just kind of cheap and I can't use the grip that I'd like to use because the spoon is in the way. Whew, all that said, I'm happy with the purchase and this will serve as a nice treat for weekend mornings.
*UPDATE You can remove the black rubber steam wand cover! Now the steam tube works great because I can clearly see and adjust the tip of the tube. Makes a great espresso shot and steams milk wonderfully. Highly recommended
title: The unit is easy to use (3 clearly defined steps)
bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Automatic Dual Shot

review_content:
I was married to my second wife for almost twenty years. I've had my car for about twenty one years now. But my longest relationship in this life was with my Cappucino Machine - over twenty five years. So you can appreciate that I was upset when my Riviera finally broke for good.

Actually that's not completely true. I could possibly have gotten it fixed yet again. But the machine is out of production. Some parts are still available but not all. One of the parts no longer available is one of the seals. The result of that missing seal has been that for about a year now when I try to make my daily cappucino it would spray boiling water in my face.

Not a good feature.

I would drape a paper towel over it so as to intercept the spray. It leaked elsewhere too. It still looked cool of course. Solid crome over solid brass with a pressure dial and an eagle on top. The last time I saw one on sale they were well over a thousand dollars. But in fact it was the maintenance that cost a lot not just the initial purchase price. I had sent it into the shop every two years for new seals. Each trip was about $150.

So a week or so ago when it wouldn't turn on - probably a switch again - I called it quits. I resolved to get a new machine. I expected to spend about $800 (the cost of a new Pavoni). To my delight it looked as though I could get a "starter" automatic machine for only about $400. But as it happens my twenty year old car needed a new transmission and that cost $4,000. So I decided to get some sort of interim machine for now until my finances recovered.

I knew as soon as I openned the box that I wouldn't send it back. That was because I immediately dropped the glass carafe on the kitchen floor, shattering it into a million shards. The other problem was that the directions require you to measure the water in that carafe. So I had to improvise my brewing procedure. Fortunately this is a truly simple machine. I have devised a procedure that makes a wonderful cappucino. I am no longer in the market for a more expensive machine. Like the song says "Ich habe genug".

Considering what I have been accustomed to spending on my morning coffee, this machine is really cheap. I could just throw it away every year and buy a new one and still come out ahead. It is almost a disposable cappucino maker. My former machine, the Riviera, was all metal. This machine is all plastic. You could sneak it through a metal detector. It is very lightly built. But I think nevertheless that it will last. My sold brass Riviera had a big boiler that took a while to come up to temperature. I would turn it on first thing in the morning and leave it on all day. That meant that the rubber seals inside cooked all day. That's why I had to have them replaced nearly every year. This little machine has a little boiler that heats up fast. I fill it with water and turn it on. Then I quickly find a cup, get out the milk, grind the beans and tamp. These actions take about five minutes at which time the coffee starts coming out. When there's enough (but not too much) I switch it to steam and froth the milk. Then - and this is the important point - I turn it off.

It takes me about six minutes to make a cappucino. The Mr. Coffee is only on for those six minutes.

It makes a great cup of Joe. It has only one flaw. Chicks are not impressed with it the way they always were with my gleaming chrome Riviera.
title: No longer in the market
bought_model: Color: CappuccinoStyle Name: 4-Cup Steam

review_content: I have had 3 of these. The first lasted 4 years; the 2nd is still going in another state.  This one, #3, I purchased thru Amazon from Warehouse Deals, with the description stating it was new but the packaging may be damaged. It arrived with all original packing and only a small ding on the outside box. Big mistake- it has given out.  It's leaking, and worse it would not pull the espresso through the grinds, even though I tried many different size of grind.  It had worked fine up til about 2 months ago.  I tried de-scaling, and have flushed the machine 20 times with plain water after the vinegar, and though it's now pulling weakly , there is a bad funky smell I can't get rid of.  Lesson learned: don't buy anything unless it's brand new.

I love Starbucks White Chocolate Mocha latte...and now I can enjoy one (...or two) at home anytime I desire. I actually purchase the white chocolate mocha syrup from Starbuck's online store---that, combined with the Lavazza Cafe espresso [that i use] and the crema that this little baby creates will surely put one in a very happy mood. Operating this little gem is very easy and I can't see anyone being disappointed in the finish product. I can honestly say that every time a friend stops by, they inevitably ask for me to prepare a latte for them. The dimensions are 12" in height, 9 1/2" is the depth and 9" in width. Oh---and here's more good news: the price I paid was $125.00 (they range from $175-$200, brand new at Target, Wal-Mart etc.)  I hope this review helps those who are are hesitant about purchasing a "used, like new" item from Amazon as well as the espresso maker itself.

review_content:
I used to own a coffee shop, so the idea of having a personal espresso machine excited me. (But I didn‚Äôt become rich off it, so buying a personal sized version of our La Marzocco machine wasn‚Äôt in the budget.) This wallet-friendly machine is great alternative.

I like the idea of grinding, tamping, and pulling my own shots. Using ‚Äúespresso pods‚Äù never appealed to me after, learning all I did about coffee. I submitted a video showing what happens when I made a mocha latte. The cocoa and sugar are in the bottom of my mug.

This is my first week using the machine. A few things I wished were different are as follows:
‚Ä¢ It‚Äôs loud, as you can hear in video
‚Ä¢ The scooper and tamper should be separate, not on reverse ends of the same tool. Also, I wish the tamper was stainless steel. (I can see myself bending it over time with daily use. You‚Äôre supposed to use 15lb of pressure when tamping espresso.)
‚Ä¢ There‚Äôs a little plastic flap piece on the espresso filter handle that doesn‚Äôt need to be there. I assume it flaps up to hold the steel filter in the handle?? But I‚Äôm not sure... If you twist the filter once it‚Äôs in place it will stay, so that flap just gets in the way.

All in all it‚Äôs a great little machine. I‚Äôll probably buy a separate tamper to use, because I don‚Äôt like the one it came with. The only big annoyance is the noise it makes. No sneaking lattes in the middle of the night, lol.

Any-who I contacted the seller and Just today I receive a brand new one with everything at no cost. "Of course I emailed them back asking if they wanted me to box up the original machine to send back. As I was not expecting to get a whole new one. Shocked me at how wonderful the customer service and response is with this company."

Tried the machine out, eh a little noisy but nothing that I wouldn't expect from a small "home" espresso machine. Heck even the machines at the "coffee" shops do have a bit of noise to them when in use.

title: I think I am in love...
bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Automatic Dual Shot

review_content:
My wife likes her coffee dark and strong. And when I say "dark and strong," I mean that she finds the darkest roast she can - the closer to pitting soil the better - and then uses 7 scoops (not the normal 5) for a 10-cup pot.

Even at these settings, though, sometimes her coffee just wasn't strong enough for her. It was really only that first cup that did it for her. Teh rest of the pot was just a tad weak. We tried going to 8 scoops, but that was too much for our coffee maker. It often spilled put of the basket while brewing, getting grounds in her coffee. I suggested making two pots each morning, but she didn't want to do all that before going to work. She just wanted to turn the machine on and pour.

We tried a Keurig, filling the reusable K-Cup with our own coffee. That still didn't do the trick. So, I decided that we needed to try an espresso maker. Of course, I wasn't going to spend $150 or $300 on an experiment. So, I got her this one for Christmas.

It's been wonderful. She gets exactly what she needs from her coffee now.

I was worried at first. Some of the reviews mentioned problems with brewing, and it doesn't come with a tamper. We've had no brewing problems. As for a tamper, a bottled of Mrs. Dash's seasoning works just fine.

The two other issues that kept coming up in reviews were the fact that the wand was immobile and that the machine wouldn't steam.

Yes, the wand is stuck in place. That can be a problem if you're too energetic in your frothing. If that's an issue for you or your mugs are too big, you probably shouldn't get this machine. For us, we figured out how to move our pitcher in smaller circles, and it's been just fine.

As for not steaming/frothing, I think I figured out the problem that most people complaining about this are having. This machine holds enough water for 4 "cups" of espresso. If you pour in 4 and make 4 shots of espresso, THERE WON'T BE ANY MORE WATER TO STEAM/FROTH YOUR MILK! So, you'll need to do one of two things. First, you can pour in 4 "cups" of water while only making 2 shots of espresso. This has been fine for us. Second, you could make four shots of espresso, refill the water, and then steam your milk. This is where the real drawback comes in, though. You obviously don't want to do this too quickly because you might burn yourself releasing the little bit of leftover steam. On the other hand, if you wait too long, your espresso is cold. This is probably what you want to think about most before buying this: "Do I usually make 4 or more shots of espresso that need steamed/frothed milk?" If you do, I'd say this machine won't be for you. However, if you can get by with making 2 or 3 shots, you should enjoy this.

And, most of all, if what you want is a very good, very inexpensive espresso maker, this is for you.
title: Very Much Worth the Money
bought_model: Color: CappuccinoStyle Name: 4-Cup Steam

review_content: I love my Barista! I used to drink coffee sporadically but now i have my latte or cappucino or expresso or even make nice hot chocolate using the froth option. Love it!!! I would caution however that the amountof coffee it makes is small so have to press the 2 cup portion twice to make 1 cup of coffee
title: I love my Barista

review_content:
I previously had a Gaggia Carezza. Its pump died (although this was after fair number of years of good use). When I started looking for a replacement, I saw this machine from Mr. Coffee. I was very skeptical at first; my impression of the Mr. Coffee brand was a discount entry level cheap product. But this machine had great reviews.

After about a year's use, I can say that I am more than satisfied. The make on the machine is very solid. The automatic frother works far better than I would have expected. Warm-up time is short and--most importantly--the coffee tastes great.

I usually just use the default settings, but if you want more (or less) steamed milk or froth, it is easy to set it to custom and control the output.

In short, a very good machine.

review_content:
We bought a Delonghi pump machine about six years ago. Like this machine, it was made in China and that seems to mean quality/function is hit or miss. If you get one that works properly it's five stars, but almost as likely it will fail horribly and earn one star. Thank goodness for warranties, or I would not take another chance on a Chinese made anything. Fast forward to this past weekend, our old machine needed repairs again and I decided it was time for a new machine. I shopped all espresso makers from $50 to $200 and was torn between the Gaggia Evolution that I could find factory refurbished for $125, and this machine that I found locally for $79. Incidentally, right now you can get this direct from the Mr. Coffee site for $49.99, and if you sign up for e-letters get an extra 10% off (also free shipping). I didn't find that deal until after I bought, though.

The initial impression is that they have hit the line between function and cost- that is, nothing feels more than adequate. The portafilter holder is lightweight, but good enough. The warming tray is thin metal, but will do the job. The buttons are small and cheap feeling, but they work. I guess this is reassuring in a way- I was wondering how they can sell a decent working machine for this price, it's because of low material cost and cheap labor. If this unit doesn't last more than two years, I think it would be cheaper in the long run to buy a more substantial machine- time will tell. What I like about the new machine compared to our old (and many others): there is a generous amount of room between the bottom of the portafilter and the tray, I can fit a small mug under there. There is a good amount of space under the frothing arm, also the arm has a good range of swivel. The water reservoir is fairly generous. It heats up quickly. It's ready to steam quickly. It's easy to clean.
What I don't like: the portafilter is double layer metal and sealed- no way to open it up to clean residue. Portafilter holder feels like you need to be careful how you handle it or it will break. Coffee temperature not very hot. Electrical cord is very short.

I have only used this twice, so I'm still learning the machine: this machine seems to have more going on automatically inside, amazing and wonderful to behold, if it doesn't quit. I mean things like you cannot use a function until the machine says it's ready, it does an automatic pre-infusion, after steaming it performs a cool down operation with shots of water that expel into the drip tray, it makes seemingly random sounds at inappropriate times . . . our old unit was very basic compared to this. The coffee it makes- well, I made a throwaway espresso last night just to see it operate (I'm still smelling oil and plastic, so I didn't feel like drinking one yet), and just finished the first cappuccino; this drink is not up to what I was making in the old machine in three areas- espresso is not as rich, not as hot, and milk did not froth as well. I attribute two of those to lack of experience; I need to dial in the grind of the coffee and perhaps ditch the rubber frothing cover. I had allowed the machine to preheat about ten minutes, and ran water through everything to warm it- maybe that isn't long enough, but as a practical matter that's all the time I'm likely to give it.
Bottom line- right now I think this may be a very good machine for (relatively speaking) a small amount of money. I'll add a follow up once I've had more time with it.

I found this review on CoffeeGeek.com that has some good information if you want to get into the nuts and bolts of it: http://coffeegeek.com/reviews/consumer/mrcoffeeespresso/Tonu/6038

1/06/15: I adjusted the grind on the coffee to be finer, and used a fairly light tamp pressure. I took the frothing tube cover off. The expresso was dark and rich, the milk had a chance to heat before it foamed, all together a much better drink than my first try- I think I'll be happy with this if the machine doesn't fail. Tomorrow the wife gets back and I begin making two drinks at a time, we'll see how that goes.

1/13/15: Still playing with the grind, I backed off the fineness and that is working well, but we need to get a darker roast bean. Milk is frothing well now with practice (hold the tip at the surface to let air get sucked into the milk and create foam, then drop the tip down to heat the liquid). I've ordered another filter basket, it is so much easier to have a second one filled and ready, swap it out with the first one that is full of soupy grounds. I'm still having to microwave the cappuccino to get it hot enough.
title: Nicely Designed, Great Value
bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Automatic Dual Shot

review_content:
I owned this product for a long time. first the espresso quality is high and is comparable or better than more expensive machines. The machine has design problems though:

The rubber bushing seal between the plastic water tank and the base unit erodes and water leaks heavily for some time when the tank is filled, in both cases when tank is removed, filled and replaced OR when water is filled with the tank in place.¬†

The second problem is that there is an inner plastic tube that carries water to the top of unit for delivery to the pump. The plastic tube becomes loose after some usage and water leaks from there as well. I was able to check this out being an engineer.¬†

Not a manufacturing problem but the selector knob on the right is flimsy and does not turn as easily.

The coffee basket is very tight and can only be closed to a bit left of center point. I tried with various fill levels and coarseness of coffee grounds. Even with partially closed, however, coffee comes out good.

After brewing is done, we find that there is water in the coffee basket and spent grinds fall into the coffee cup below.

Machine can accommodate medium size cups. Taller cups cannot be used.

¬†I wished water can be hotter as the brew is not hot enough.

In spite of the above, I still find this machine does fantastic job in brewing in comparison. Hope the company improves manufacturing quality. Barista model also has the same setup as above and perhaps has the same problems.
title: Great brew with defective and poor workmanship of the unit and materials.
bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Automatic Dual Shot

review_content: Give this 5 stars not because it's the best machine ever anywhere... but a really good machine for home use. Got mine on clearance at a local place and WISH i had grabbed all they had to use as gifts. After a couple trys it becomes real easy to use. Love all the settings and each one does what it says. Just keep the directions around for reference when your learning the settings because you WILL forget. At first glance seems a pain to clean but it really is a snap once you get it all figured out. DO do the cleaning feature before you use the FIRST time because it actually does get you to hotter results for some reason. LOVE MINE!

review_content:
Not sure why everyone's machine is breaking...yes, it's cheap and plastic but what do you expect for $30? Got mine on sale at local grocery store for $29.99, works great out of the box. I think for those having issues they're doing it wrong. I can only imagine how they man handle the machine for it to break in the ways I've read. You do need a tamper because the scoop they give you and suggest tamping with won't create an even surface- it still works though. Educate yourself on how to prep and pull a proper shot- this thing brews great espresso. As for the steam wand, as many others suggest I removed the plastic cover so it's just bear metal- steams faster than a DeLonghi I used to have. Overall I'm satisfied with the price paid. If I get 9mo to a year out of this I'll be happy.

Side note, worth investing in a steaming pitcher, liquid thermometer, and 49mm tamper so you can craft drinks up without juggling espresso between the glass carafe they provide.

title: Mixed Feelings About This One.
bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Espresso/Cappuccino Maker

review_content: Bottom line I bought this to save money from going to Dunkin or Starbucks. I have to admit with the right brewing time and the right type of beans the coffee is right on par with the aforementioned coffee stores. If you treat this machine as your regular type of coffee maker or a kruieg for that matter your not going to get the best results. This espresso maker actually takes some technique to get down in just a couple of brews. I'm used to the stove top expresso makers which in my opinion has a slight edge on this machine but I like this machine because it prepares my latte quicker and I don't have to warm up my milk in the microwave or in a pot on the stove. I must admit my first cup of latte was terrible!! But I know right off the back the expresso was water downed. So instead of using a coffee mug that I normally use for my stove top expresso I used my expresso shot glass so I knew when to stop brewing. I should mention that with this machine there is no timed brewing you do it manually your self, thats why I use the expresso shot glass to get a consistent measurement every time. I would recommend getting a stainless steel frothing pitcher for the milk and a thermometer to warm up the milk up to 155 F. As for the coffee brand I use Pilon or Cafe Bustelo which I have drank since the 4th grade.
title: If you treat this machine as your regular type of coffee maker or a kruieg for that matter your not going to get the best result
bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Automatic Dual Shot

review_content: I'm a 58 year old retired engineer and understand the limitations of these cheap little machines as this is my 3rd small type but first Mr. Coffee brand. I must say they have improved. Anyway if you follow the directions to a tee your going to get disappointing water logged coffee. But if you have a basic understanding of pressure and steam you'll lean to modify your operation of this little machine. What I do is fill the coffee filter holder to max shot coffee level line because your going to want to stop the excess water rush when the thick black coffee and cream stops pouring and that doesn't leave much coffee IMO but that's OK. I use only purified water unless you want your machine to last only 1 year from mineral deposits, and I fill glass carafe to the top of the metal band past the highest mark to ensure more than enough water and steam to do the job. With everything in place i.e. power off, coffee filter holder full locked in, steam cap screwed down tight, frothing arm extended and ready with cup and milk standing by...  I then turn the machine to knob to steam first to allow the machine to build pressure and steam without prematurely diluting the coffee filter holder, as soon as the frothing arm starts to sputter a hint of water I quickly switch the control knob to brew coffee position which brings in only hot steam and water trickling out only dark thick coffee and this is where you have to be rehearsed to act fast and operate the machine effectively! With the thick black coffee trickling, get your milk cup ready sitting under the frothing arm ready to be lifted up as soon as you see the brewing coffee go from slow tricking thick dark coffee to cream foam. Now GET READY to turn the control knob back to steam the INSTANT you see that the slow dark cream foam trickling out slowly starts to speed up. The moment before you see the slow dark cream foam trickling out start to speed up to water, I Instantly raise my milk cup submersing the frothing arm under the milk to avoid splatter while simultaneously switching the control knob to steam, which instantly stops the brewing process to the coffee filter holder preventing water dilution. Once your milk is frothed to my liking I switch the control knob to off. That's it, perfect Espresso IMO. When not in use to prevent premature compression damage to the sealing gaskets, I only slightly keep both the steam cap and the filter holder screwed in place. If you lock them down to full tight position when not in use, I find that it will prematurely compress the sealing gaskets and they will start to leak early making brewing ineffective.  Having said all of this, as a protective disclaimer I must say that this is what ‚ÄúI DO‚Äù and I'm not recommending any of these operating actions to anyone.  You should use the instruction book to a tee for OK strong watery coffee.
title: FIVE STARS FOR RATIO BETWEEN PRICE AND BREWING QUALITY
bought_model: Color: CappuccinoStyle Name: 4-Cup Steam

review_content:
Works just fine.
Works on the principle of a pump, rather than a pressurized water/steam reservoir, so it does make some noise.
A few tips, as some of the comments are a bit off the mark.
* Use good dark coffee. If you are a newcomer, start with Starbucks espresso blend and experiment.
* Warm the beans in a microwave until they are warm, shiny and fragrant (30 to 60 sec) before grinding.
* Don't remove the rubber tip from the frother arm: it operates on the Venturi principle to mix air bubbles with the steam.
* Yes, a very large mug of appropriate aspect ratio will easily fit under the brew head.
* If you are using a large mug for caf√© au lait, etc., microwave the empty mug for a minute so that it is warm.before using.
* No need to stand and hold the milk receptacle for frothing, Just place it on a pedestal of appropriate dimensions, An inverted ash tray fits perfectly for me.
* No reason at all that the frothing receptacle be made of stainless steel, so long as the milk is cold.
xxx
title: Also makes good caf√© au lait in a large mug
bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Automatic Dual Shot

review_content: I purchased this through another retailer in November and received is Dec. 7, 2017. We absolutely loved it at first. My husband was ridiculously spending $7 on a cup of coffee a day!!! Sometimes that crazy man would go through the coffee shop twice a day!!! Anyway, we opened this the day we got it and immediately primed it and started brewing. I think we brewed 3 different drinks that day. For the next few months, we were making at least 2 drinks/5 days a week and then a few on the weekend. It did great. I loved that it was automatic...push a button and continue getting ready for the day while the coffee brewed. It was amazing. Well fast forward to May/June 2018 and the automatic features have stopped. The frother no longer works unless you specifically turn the frother on. It doesn't work with any of the drinks selected. The drinks run longer than they should so you get water like coffee brewed at the end and you manually have to turn it off. The amount of coffee brewed is not what it should be which means we have to do two fills on the portafilter and run it twice while standing there watching it. I'm so glad I got this on sale for $99 and didn't pay the current price of $199. When I bought it, I had read reviews that it doesn't last but thought I would take a chance. It still saved me a bunch of money in the beginning, but now I have to look for another espresso machine.
title: Great while it lasts - but don't expect long life
bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Espresso/Cappuccino Maker

review_content: Love love love this machine! I was very Leary in purchasing this as I'm a coffee snob (worked at a coffee shop) who likes her coffee quite strong. I always had a hand held frother and used my stove top Italian espresso maker for lattes. When my hand held broke and my now 5 month old was born I needed something hands free. This actually was better than I expected. The espresso shots are strong, and the froth is great! Just like any froth low fat milk froths a lot better than any other milk or milk type product. My one recommendation is that you read all the instructions first. Was a great laugh trying to make my first few lattes. Also keep an eye on the water reservoir it will literally run out mid espresso shot and make a loud noise. There is supposed to be a warning but mine doesn't seem to do that. My brother has the same machine and his does not froth the exact amount of milk each time. I don't have an issue with that. Only use espresso unless you like a weak tasting latte. Has an excellent amount of crema and I make at least 1 double hot latte every morning and 4 espresso shots over ice for my husband. The espresso shots are quite strong! I also don't use the clean function but after every latte do a manual froth with just water to clean the tube. Works just like the cleaning button but takes less time. wish I could give this 5 stars but to have 5 stars it needs to be perfect and running out of water mid espresso shot without warning is quite frustrating at times.
title: Great machine! Excellent crema! Strong espresso shots! Great for a family with little ones!
bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Espresso/Cappuccino Maker

review_content:
I really wanted this as I wanted something that would let you make coffee both automatically and manually. It took 3 tries to get one that worked, and I am happy with the third one, overall. The first one had defective frother and leaked and the second one had both defective coffee dispenser and frother. Very frustrating, but again the third one is so far a good machine and makes a good cup of coffee that look and taste as good as anything I can get at Starbucks (mind you, I am NOT a coffee officiando!)

You can adjust the froth and milk you want dispensed which is great. You don't have to manually froth (but you can if you want to) so you can press the button and walk away while your coffee is being made.

Negatives--it is hard to get the coffee portafilter inserted--I always have issues. It is a bit slow to warm up. It is extremely loud--I keep waiting for apartment neighbors to complain! If you have roommates or family that is sleeping when you use this, you will wake them up for sure!

But makes good capps, lattes and espressos! Just hope it lasts!
title: Third time's a charm
bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Espresso/Cappuccino Maker

review_content:
So, I will write this review as what the machine is, not what it is not. What I mean, its not a $500 - $1000 espresso machine. Just isn't. And, I didn't expect that. I think some reviews believe it should perform on a par with the bigger, fancier machines.

I am a latte drinker. So I don't consider myself a total espresso/coffee aficionado. With the amount of milk, I can't really taste minor differences in the coffee flavor. Really bad is really bad, that I can tell. But, the minor differences noticeable in "neat" coffee probably isn't as noticeable to me.

When I first started using the machine, I measured the water temp coming out and followed other reviews advice and did a cleaning on the unit, using a good bit of vinegar. That did seem to raise the temp a bit. I also always first run one or two empty espresso pulls to make sure i'm getting hot water. Both of these seemed to help.

So, positives: Easy to use. Easy to get froth or froth/steamed milk (Mrs. likes that for hot chocolate). I like that I can put the milk container in the fridge for another day. There are two levels for the cup base, and that is convenient. It holds a fair amount of water, which is helpful.

Negative: You HAVE TO remember to put the metal spout in your coffee cup when make latte/cappuccino. Yep, made that mess twice. That's not the machine's fault, but there isn't really a lip around the unit that would contain the milk overflow.... it ran down onto the counter and into a drawer. This isn't the machine's fault, and I'm not taking a star away, but it would have been a great tweak to the design. Kinda idiot insurance.

I would suggest not removing the water reservoir too often as that could be a leak point. I haven't, but will be to do a cleaning on it soon. But, when its reinstalled, I will double check it.

So, given it is what it is, and isn't what it isn't.... its a good machine, that makes good lattes and didn't cost an arm and a leg.
title: Really bad is really bad
bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Espresso/Cappuccino Maker

review_content:
This was a great investment for me at $60. It produces better espresso than what Starbucks puts out most of the time. I use it for iced drinks only so I cant speak for steamed milk and whatnot. I read several reviews before ordering and some people complained of water tank leaks, I read another review that said to circumvent the issue you should only remove the water tank for cleaning, and I have not had any issues with it yet. The only issue I have had is if you grind the coffee too fine or tamp it too tight coffee will leak out around the gasket that seals the portafilter basket. I love this machine and I have had it for 6 months so far I will update my review if the machine dies within the next 12 months, if it serves its purpose for 18 months total I will consider it money well spent.

Just for reference I brew about 10 shots a week average.
title: This maching is awesome
bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Automatic Dual Shot

His birthday was coming up two days after returning home from Spain, so I knew this product was a must need! He is so happy with it and even said this was the best present I have ever gotten him. title: A Must Buy for Coffee Lovers

review_content:
Little did I know how quickly I‚Äôd love this cappuccino maker! Especially because assembling and learning how to use it did not come easy. I still hesitate when I begin pressing buttons. But the outcome‚Äîand prep and cleaning‚Äîis easy. And my cappuccinos are as tasty as any I buy when I go out. In fact mine are often better because I choose great coffee and whole milk.

First though the instructions for assembly were complicated by a missing part and a skipped step regarding the milk container. That intimidated me and stalled my initial use. Then too reviews suggested that packing the coffee would be difficult. But watching seasoned baristas and taking into account the instructions that say leave 1/8th of an inch clearance I have done fine since my first cap. Only pressing buttons and waiting for the process to signal it has started still confuses me.

Still if you‚Äôre likely to make yourself an espresso drink most afternoons, this is great. Again just buy excellent coffee ground right. No, I don‚Äôt grind it myself. Why? The fresh roast I buy and grind right then has been great. And not as expensive as going out for a cappuccino most afternoons.
title: After a couple of false starts, great cappuccinos!
bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Espresso/Cappuccino Maker

review_content:
I am so sorry to have to tell you I have lost faith in my coffee machine.. I first complained about the black plastic piece chjpping and would not link to the steel nozzle. You wanted to help me but since I live overseas, it just didn't seem important. When I first got it, it was very very difficult to swist the knob on the left to "broth" I knew it would more than likely get looser with age.. it did not.. Then this morning the complete glass cup fell apart..the metal band the plastic handle and the handle dropped a chip of plastic from the center connection..I am beginning to believe this is just one of those "duds"..that is never going to work correctly..However, I know what a good machine this is..however, not this particular one. I will do whatever you advise..but please don't ask me to return it..That would be another whole problem...
Just advise me as to what my choices are, and I will make it easy on you.. I know this is not your fault, it is just one of those that did not "gel" correctly in the making..
Sincerely Sue

bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Espresso/Cappuccino Maker

review_content:
Overall, I'd say this is a College student espresso machines.

This machine produces coffee that's just a slight smidge over "average".
It does not produce super fancy coffee.

Does the machine work? Yes... And no.
The espresso part works pretty well, and it makes... Some pretty good espresso! I personally use Caf√© Bustello. I tried Starbucks at espresso but Starbucks espresso isn't as finely ground as it should be... Therefore it produced pretty weak coffee.. Like coffee pot coffee, not strong espresso. Caf√© Bustello works amazing with this machine and it's pretty cheap.
The milk frother isn't the best, in all honesty. It works pretty okay with producing a thinner froth like a latte but it does terrible with producing a thick cappuccino. (This could be due to the milk I use though.. I'm not sure. I use coconut and soy milk. It might work better with cow's milk. No idea, though.)
It also seems like the frother waters down the milk just a little bit.. I'm not sure why. I've noticed it but it's not so bad that it destroys your beverage.
Luckily I only really use the espresso from this machine to make iced latte, I don't usually froth milk, too.

What's the overall quality of this machine?
I'd rate it a 6 on a scale from 1-10 (10 being best quality) it could definitely be a lot better.
The area where that holds the little (bed?) for your espresso grounds is stained with coffee.. It doesn't look pretty. This happened about a month after using is at least once a day. I'm not sure if they make replacements or not. If they do, I probably won't get a new one because I expect it to be stained again in about a month.
The machine is a little finicky. Removing and placing the water reservoir is a bit of a task (It's not that bad though.. Really. It's just not smooth)
Sometimes it has to go in at a certain angle... sometimes you have to remove it and place it back on again for the machine to accept it.. It's a bit of a pain but you'll place it on in about 30 seconds maximum.

This is a perfect machine for college students (Expect the fact that it's loud... But. Everything is loud in college.) I do recommend you clean your machine after every milk froth use, you do this by holding down the third button for about 3 seconds... Then it'll get a bit loud while it cleans itself.. This only takes about 10 seconds.
If you do not, you will have milk inside of your machine that will get moldy and your machine will be destroyed.
If you just use it for espresso then you just need to clean the espresso handle (I recommend doing this about 10 minutes after you've made espresso because it will be VERY hot. However, you can also do this right after. Just run it under cold water and avoid being burnt.). I don't suggest you use soap. A quick rinse under some water does the trick.
I do believe that keeping it clean will extend the life of the machine by quite a while. So far I've had mine for two-three months and it's doing pretty well.

If you aren't a college kid and you want something a bit more permanent for your home then I recommend you look at other machines. I don't expect my machine to last more than 2 years with proper maintenance. For the price, I'm okay with that. You may be better off buying two separate machines for espresso and milk frothing if you're trying to keep it cheap.

Tips! :
For better, thick, creamy, strong espresso... I recommend turning your machine on at least 5 minutes before you actually brew the espresso.
This ensures the machine will be hot and at a more even temperature. This helps a lot, trust me. The machine does turn off after about 10-15 minutes.. So don't leave it on too long! Five-Seven minutes works amazing.

There is no button for JUST brewing milk... but you can do it! All you have to do is press on either the latte or cappuccino button and froth the milk.. After the machine froths the milk it'll usually brew the espresso next. All you have to do is click the button again (Whichever one you clicked before, Latte or Cappuccino.) right after the milk stops brewing. This will cancel the task and so it won't go on to brew some espresso.
Ta-Da! Frothy milk!
title: Perfect for college students!
bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Espresso/Cappuccino Maker

title: Makes the house smell amazing when it's brewing
bought_model: Color: CappuccinoStyle Name: 4-Cup Steam

review_content:
Don't buy this machine if you want to make cappuccino......or anything else.

Things I like: The compact size.
Things I dislike:
The cheap quality of materials used in building the machine
The water reservoir cap that is narrower at the top than at the bottom, making it difficult to grip
The ridiculously SHORT steam arm that will not even reach the bottom of a coffee cup, let alone a steam pitcher.
The machine's inability to build up enough pressure to make foam.

Since I moved back to the states after living in Italy over 20 years ago, I have made myself espresso and cappuccino everyday at home. So I do know what I'm talking about when I assess this machine, as I have used several different espresso makers over the years, and used them regularly. Other than my beloved CMA Genius Commercial 2 group, my next favorite machine is a simple steam driven machine similar to this one. Only not like THIS one! Steam machines do require a bit of knowledge and practice to get good results, but they work, they're simple, and they are inexpensive.

I purchased this after my old Krups steam machine finally broke (it lasted 10+ years.....and did I say I used it EVERYDAY!?). The Mr. Coffee has overall cheapness to it. The filter basket is thin aluminun and can be dented on the bottom from tapping your coffee grinds out. The plastic parts are not durable thick plastic, but cheap.

The lid is a tapered cone, thicker at the bottom and narrow at the top, with smooth sides. This doesn't make the machine inoperable, it just requires a really firm finger grip (not great if you have carpal tunnel syndrome - or weaker hands - or are just sleepy or lazy). My 6' tall muscle-y husband even said it was a pain.

My biggest complaint is the frothing arm. Seriously. The arm itself is 2 INCHES!! (I measured) If you are using a thimble to warm your milk in, this will work. But if you are using even a small froth pitcher, this is totally inadequate. Even the silly plastic thing that goes over the top of the frothing arm (I guess it's supposed to be some type of froth enhancer, but I have never seen a need or found a use for one of these) only extends the total length to 2.75 inches.

As bad as the inept frothing arm, is the machine's ability to produce enough steam to make frothed milk. If you brew espresso first, when you switch the knob to "steam" a weak stream of warm air starts to emit from the froth arm. I tested to see if more water was needed - filled up the tank to full, brewed espresso, and turned the knob. The same thing happened. I tested several different possible causes of the problem and there is just no fix. If you leave the knob on "steam" and keep waiting, (and waiting) eventually the pressure builds up a little bit, but never to the point of making good foamed milk .... I could hold my fingers directly under the stream of warm air and I wasn't in the least concerned that it might burn me. Hello - isn't steam supposed to be hot? It should be called a "warm air for milk" arm on this machine.

If all you do is make espresso and do not want to froth milk, this machine can get you by; but better to buy a stove top espresso maker for half the price. I wouldn't recommend this espresso maker to anyone.

Last words: Don't waste your money!!! Keep looking!!!
title: Poorly built, poor performance, cheap quality Machine
bought_model: Color: CappuccinoStyle Name: 4-Cup Steam

review_content: Granted, I just received this machine yesterday and have already made five double cappuccinos for myself and family. With a little bit of  Torani Vanilla syrup it tastes very similar to the new vanilla cappuccinos from McD's, which are my new favorite. The unit is a little loud and you have to make sure it's heating up before you expect it to start your drink, but other than that I really like it. I can see it saving me a lot of money and hassle of getting my cappuccino and latte fix at drive-thru.
title: Love it so far! Use some flavored syrup and you've got a pretty good big-brand substitute!
bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Espresso/Cappuccino Maker

review_content:
My Kyrups 963A finally died after 21 years of daily, sometimes twice daily use. While I took good care of it and had to improvise when parts broke, the steam cap finally gave out. The plastic just crumbled.
I lived in Italy for a year and know good espresso. The 963A was not a true espresso machine, however, I wasn't and probably never will be ready to drop big bucks (i.e., hundreds) just so that I can get espresso froth. I can get good espresso with good beans. That's the key. I need strong coffee and caffeine! :-)
So, I turned to the Mr. Coffee ECM160 4-Cup Steam Espresso Machine. It's a backward engineered version of my former Kyrups 963A. I can use the 963A's carafes and lids. After running a few carafes of water through to clean it, the first batch was good. I like this machine... but I would not bother with black frother attachment which is suppose to help. On both the 963A and the ECM160, you'll have better control of frothing cream/milk without the attachments. Use the metal tip alone like I have for the last 21 years and you'll find it flexible, easy to control and fun at times improvising.
I might rate this a 5 star in 3-5 years... if it makes it that long. Some parts are as robust as the 963A. However for 40 dollars, you get what you pay for... and I got something that's worth that amount of money.
Time will tell on this one... My 963A was a 5star+, rest its dear soul.
title: Cheaper remake of the Kyrups 963/A
bought_model: Color: CappuccinoStyle Name: 4-Cup Steam

review_content:
We got one of these a year an a half ago and it just recently broke. The power light would just flash, and nothing would happen. :( We looked into getting a better one, but it seams to me that unless you want to spend a couple hundred dollars, this makes just as good espresso as the next one. I don't actually know that, just what I observed from some research.

Anyways, this seems to be a good espresso maker for the price. I figure if you spend twice as much it might not last twice as long, which makes this a good deal. The new one that we got wasn't put together quite right and the filter seal ... well doesn't seal very well at all. If the coffee is ground as fine as I like it, the seal pops and espresso and grinds go every where. I fixed the problem by just bending a paper clip in a circle the same size as the filter and used it as a shim to make the filter seal better. This is working just fine and it is making great espresso again!

Also, I saved the filters from the old maker so we now have two double filters! This is really nice for making espresso for two because I can pack the filters the night before and it makes it a lot faster in the morning!

title: This is great if you already know how to make lattes and ...

review_content: For the price this is an excellent product.  I love that you can fill the water resevoir and make lots of latte's before you have to refill.  This pump driven machine is so much nicer to use than the steam driven machine that I previously owned.  Operating the machine can seem a little complicated at first, but once you get the hang of it, it is very easy.  It warms up quickly and the whole process, start to finish,(including cleanup) takes about 10 minutes.  You can make 1 to 4 drinks at a time depending on how big your drinks are and how much espresso you like. I also like that you can imediatly turn around and make more (not possible with steam driven machines).  This is one of the least expensive pump driven machines I could find and I am very happy with it. It doesn't take up too much room on the counter.  The only reason I gave it a 4 instead of a 5 is it seems to have a little quirk with the frother.  You have to turn the machine completly off when your done frothing or the machines lights all start flashing (indicating an error).  This is not a big deal. You just have to turn it back on to continue using the machine.

title: Broke after 5 months
bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Espresso/Cappuccino Maker

review_content:
****2/18/16- Mon - Fri, 3 espressos made a day, this thing is still going strong, not one problem. Nice to have a reliable machine.

*********7/21/2014 - Adding to my review**************************************************************************************************
I just wanted to add to this review. I bought a super expensive machine since I bought this machine. It grinds the beans, tamps it, when done puts the puck in a bin. Very nice.. but it doesn't brew a shot with crema like this unit. It is 1/4 as reliable as this unit, and it costs 10 times more. Since I brought this to work we brew 4 cups a day on it with coworkers, I haven't de-calcified it once, it just pumps and pumps. This thing is awesome. I'm thinking about chucking my super fancy one and just get this one again for home.
*******************************************************************************************************************************************

I tried cheaper models, they are crap. You need 15 bars of pressure, this one has it!

When I brought it home, my wife looked at me kind of strange, I tried making espresso on our steam activated machine and it sucked.. no pressure.

So I excitedly unboxed it and made a shot.. delicious. Made one for my wife... her eyes opened wide. We were back in Florence Italy, eating cookies and having cappuccino again.

Since then.. we make it as much as we can during the week, but since it does take time, we usually make 4 cups a day on the weekends. 2 a piece :)

The things works great. I wish the steam heated up the milk faster but its an entry level machine. I don't like you have to wait to go from brewing to steaming but.. its an entry level machine.

Though it makes good cappuccinos. Take the plastic thing off of the wand, is sucks and is hard to clean, plus taking it off and putting it on puts a lot of stress on the wand. Just use the wand.

We have used it A LOT. No problems. Just be sure to empty the tray, a little water gets purged after every steam cycle and it fills up fast. No big deal though.

Make sure you clean the rim of the contraption you put your grounds in though (portafilter?). I make sure there are no grounds on it ever, because it can damage the seal ring on the unit, and then the pressure from the steam has a chance to spill out the sides.

I only use filtered water also, I think it tastes better.

Get a kit. I have a thermometer, shot glasses (otherwise you are guessing when to shut it off) and something to steam your milk in. This thing rocks, it pays itself off really quickly, and tastes way better than the crap you get at starbucks.

My one gripe and why it doesn't get 5 stars is the grounds. No matter how hard I tamp them, I think some water drips into them so when you pull out the container to dump the grounds, they are soupy, so I end up banging them against the garbage can and then I have to rinse out the unit. I wish I could just bang it once, it dumps out as a puck, and I'm off to my next brew.
title: Great way to see if you like to make your own espresso
bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Automatic Dual Shot

review_content:
I love my cappuccino maker. Sure, it only makes one cup at a time, but so do all other cappuccino makers. It is a bit confusing at first with the blinking lights, solid lights, and when exactly I can twist the knob to froth or begin brewing, but I learned within 2 or 3 days.

The cappuccinos it makes are delicious. This is a pump driven espresso machine, so the lower temperature doesn't torch the oils making for a delicious crema.

I took the rubber frothing tube cap off since I had to take it off all the time anyways and it just seemed gross to leave it on. If you leave it on, you have to take it off anyways in order to clean underneath and clean the rubber tube on the inside of it. I kept it off since it was a pain to keep taking it off as it isn't very easy.

After about 2 months of regular use, the frothing tube tip began to slip around and wouldn't screw in properly. I eventually figured out that the threads which attach the tip to the tube were stripped. One which end, I don't know, but all this meant to me was that I couldn't have frothed milk anymore without the tip just rocketing off.

I'm figuring out how I can either get replacement parts or get it sent in for repairs. I love this machine too much to just try another one. I'd give the product 5 stars if it weren't for the faulty frothing tube tip.

Edit:
After contacting the warranty company servicing the espresso machine and getting sent the wrong replacement part, they just sent me a new machine. A $2 piece would have sufficed, but I guess that's how they do business.

Edit:1/17/16
Nearly 5 years later and the machine still works perfectly. I don't use it every day anymore, maybe more like once a week to once a month lately. I keep telling myself I'm going to upgrading when this thing finally dies, but I think it heard me and now it refuses to die. This is a fantastic machine for a first time user and I would have no hesitations about recommending it to someone who craves the occasional cappuccino. Keep in mind you need to pair it with a decent grinder. I've been using a Capresso Infinity, and, more recently, a Baratza Encore.
title: Great product, Frothing tube stripped.
