title: Five Stars
bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Espresso/Cappuccino Maker

review_content:
I brought the combo: Barista machine & Automatic Burr Mill (I'm using beans from the "Real Good Coffee Company, Seattle, WA" which are excellent.)
The Barista took some practice but I love it now. There's a lot more parts to clean by hand but it's easy and well worth the results.
It makes a great double Cappuccino, which I sometimes add a single or double shot of espresso (it's versatile machine, with many possibilities.)
The Milk steamer/frother works as advertised. I like that the milk reservoir can be easily transferred to a refrigerator.
title: Awesome Machine!
bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Espresso/Cappuccino Maker

review_content: Step aside Starbucks! Outstanding espresso/latte/cappuccino machine for under $100! Mr. Coffee Dual Shot makes a terrific espresso and delicious cappuccino in record breaking time of under 1 1/2 minutes! Clean up is also a snap! Tip: clean frothing wand and brew basket right after making your drinks while the machine is still primed. Has automatic self cleaning feature after making your espresso or cappuccino! Best cappuccino machine for price and you could pay triple the price for comparable brands. Affordable and a must have for any espresso/cappuccino lover! Ignore negative reviews. A definite strong buy!
title: Step aside Starbucks!
bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Automatic Dual Shot

review_content: I've been using this every day, I LOVE it! I read up on how to pull the perfect shot and if I ever have a bad shot it's definitely user error; ran the shot too long, too fine/coarse of grind. It's a little cumbersome compared to a drip coffee machine but nothing worth having comes easy right? Works SO WELL for the price. I hope it continues to. I read on some reviews that their machine just stopped working one day. I have had that happen with a Mr. Coffee coffee maker, but I called and they sent me a brand new one.
title: Perfection
bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Automatic Dual Shot

review_content:
Pros:
There are a lot of push button options. Self cleaning, and even though its automatic, there are manual modes for basically everything to customize your drink.
Coming from a cheaper unit, I like the milk container and self cleaning.
My old one had a frothing nozzle. I don't have to sit there and froth my milk.
Large capacity water pitcher. I've made several drinks. Probably more than a dozen and I've refilled it once.

Cons:
It doesn't really make any of the drinks. It's more like... it puts cooked sugar, flower, eggs, and bits of Chocolate on a plate and says here you go Chocolate chip cookie! The drink is poorly ... it's not even close to mixed. I feel like it does things in the wrong order. Maybe I can fix that, but manual mode is your friend.
It is ridiculously frothy. Even the lowest setting. Seriously half the cup minimum everytime.
I wasn't looking for a huge expensive unit, so for me this isn't a deal breaker, But the area for a cup is pretty small. It could benefit by Including some kind of decanter. About the only thing that fits is a regular size coffee cup. A taller coffee cup kinda fits if you remove the removable cup holder thing, but it narrows. So a medium wide cup doesn't work. Basically if it has a lid, it probably won't fit. And with how much froth this thing gives, I don't see how anyone can do a double shot cappuccino. Unless your cup is a tartus.

Overall its decent. I feel like the espresso it makes is better than my less expensive one which was a mr coffee ECM160. I wasn't expecting to be amazed, but overall it's really not an improvement over the ECM160. Some improvements In convince in some areas. If I were to do this again, I would have looked at other options. But I think it's a decent starter if you've never had one.
title: Super frothy meh kind of latte maker
bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Espresso/Cappuccino Maker

review_content: I know you're thinking it's just an espresso machine, but it's not. I got one of these years ago, then when I broke up with my fianc√© he took it with him. My mother has one, my brother then bought one and I had to buy another because no other machine produce that little foam that you get at the top of the espresso. It comes out hot and well downright perfect. This is coming from a Cuban American if that means anything, ha, ha, ha. Buy it you won't regret it.
title: I know you're thinking it's just an espresso machine, but it's not.
bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Automatic Dual Shot

review_content:
I‚Äôve had this machine for 2 years now and it‚Äôs done an excellent job! Mainly used to make lattes and cappuccinos. Espresso shots are a bit harsh to drink neat but I can‚Äôt complain considering the cost.

Tips:

Make sure to only use filtered water to avoid scale build.

Run hot water through an empty portafilter before each use. This clears any leftover grinds and warms your mug.

Use a burr grinder or buy espresso grind if you want to pull shots with nice crema.

End your shot pull when it starts looking pale. In my mug it‚Äôs like 1/4 way full.

Remove plastic piece around the steamer, this makes it easier to clean up.

Discard spent grinds the following day and it will come out as a solid puck. If not it will be a hot slushy mess.

Have fun, be patient, and remember practice makes perfect.
title: Makes great lattes & cappuccinos!
bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Automatic Dual Shot

review_content: I have had several major expresso machines. This one is really easy and makes a good coffee. Obviously quality of coffee used is a big factor to desired flavor. The water and milk vessels form factor and usability works great for us. I like the cleaning function for the milk frothed and that the milk frothed unit is dishwasher safe. Once we got dialed in to the different functions, I use the custom functions to make it how I like it, like on Saturday morning, and hit the one step functions when I am running out the door to work and just need a cup to get me down the road.
title: One touch or custom coffee is easy
bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Espresso/Cappuccino Maker

review_content: I purchased this item 8 months ago, it worked fine up until now. The double cup dispenser does not allow water to flow thru it. I cleaned it and made sure there was nothing obstructing the openings. This still did not allow coffee to come thru. It just pools in the coffee grounds section building up pressure. I contacted the manufacturer for some trouble shooting or possible replacement that I can purchase and they said that is not possible because I bought it thru Amazon. I am not happy that this item only lasted 8 months and further more it is now  $60 less on Amazon. Not worth it even at that reduced price. Perhaps that is why its reduced. I do not recommend this product or this manufacturer.
title: it worked fine up until now
bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Espresso/Cappuccino Maker

review_content: This is a great machine if you are just starting to experiment with espresso. The instructions were very clear on how to use it and how to clean it. The hardest part of using the machine was figuring out what kind of coffee to buy. After using the machine for a couple of weeks I was having issues with the frother not working properly. After reading the manual I found that I had not been cleaning the steaming arm well enough. This would be my only complaint, it is very difficult to get the steaming arm completely clean each time. You would need to essentially do a deep cleaning of the arm immediately after each use to keep it perfectly clean. This would mean risking a burn (as the steaming arm is incredibly hot at this point) and by the time you would be done cleaning your drink would be cold. Overall, this machine does do the trick. It make good espresso shots for the price of the machine. I would recommend purchasing a tamper for the espresso grounds and a pitcher of you plan on steaming milk.
title: Overall, Nice Machine
bought_model: Color: CappuccinoStyle Name: 4-Cup Steam

review_content: It took a few days of adjusting the espresso to milk ratio, but well worth it!  It's really easy to use and to clean.  The espresso drinks from this are far superior to the last machine I had.  For an espresso machine, this is very affordable, very well made, and I anticipate having this machine for years to come.  I buy WAY too much on Amazon, but very rarely feel the need to review products.  This one, however, is just an outstanding value.

review_content: Can be a little messy, but not bad. I use this thing every day
title: but not bad. I use this thing every
bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Espresso/Cappuccino Maker

review_content:
I like the machine, deep coffee pod!!! for strong SHOTS. I would like these machines to be taller to be able to fit bigger cups, but other than that, good. I used to worked as a barista in a restaurant, the bad part of this machine is the Frothing pipe, doesn't let you control the air mixing, to fix that I removed the rubber pipe covering the stainless one, I can now have the bubble miniaturized enough to make them longer lasting until the end of your cup.

Here are my tips (echoing other reviews).
-Read the directions first! It'll last longer if you do.
-Make sure you use the correct roast and ground size and don't overpack.
-Play with the brewer until you figure out how long you want to brew (I count to ten).
-Ditch the single filter. You'll never use it.
-Get some demitasse cups.
-Get a frothing pitcher and use 1% milk.
-Ditch the rubber tip [ not existent in pro machines]on the frothing wand. It's useless unless you want to easily grow bacteria. Plus don't let you do a professional frothing
-After frothing, blow a little steam out the wand so no milk dries and clogs it. Wipe the wand with a damp towel shortly after steaming (it's easier to clean when it's hot).

Sad
title: I so wanted to like this BUT
bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Espresso/Cappuccino Maker

review_content:
Well... it makes espresso. The frother is absolute crap though. It just spits and hisses at you, and doesn't heat the milk. So far the frother has worked once out of about 8 attempts, and we've gone over the instructions repeatedly, following them exactingly every time.

*** 3 weeks of use later***
It's mean if out the bottom. Not from the water container. Not from there the container plugs into the machine. But from somewhere on the bottom that I have yet to find. And it's not a little dribble either! It's a full on, losing 1/4th cup every 30 seconds or so (that's being generous on the timing ). Besides that I'm not sure I can get the bottom plastic off to try and repair it, so THANKS Mr. Coffee, for making this crummy machine >:(
title: NOPE! Dont buy this! Just dont do it!
bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Automatic Dual Shot

review_content:
I've been drinking and making expresso for years, I've owned many machines, in the more recent years, I owned a Gaggia and a Rancilio. I spent a lot of money on these high end machines, and they both broke. After investing time and energy trying to replace parts, watching youtube videos, I gave up and decided to buy a new one and less expensive one, as neither machine had made it past the three year mark, and $500 for only three years was way pretty expensive IMO.
Any way, Mr. Coffee made a great little machine, the foam is even better than it was with my prior machines, and easier to work. One drawback, worthy of a star, the shots are significantly smaller, I would say a double expresso is about 2/3 the size of my prior double expressos. I actually just make two double shots in the morning instead now and I'm good to go. Also cleaning the coffee grinds tends to be messy as the grinds come out watery, as opposed to a hard cake like texture of other machines. All in all, I would say for the money, this is a great buy for your money.
title: Great Machine for a reasonable price, highly recommend!
bought_model: Color: WhiteStyle Name: Espresso/Cappuccino Maker

review_content:
Over the years I have bought 4 machines that ranged from $100-$500. This is without a doubt the best of the bunch which actually shocked me. Better then a $500 Silvia. How can a cheap Mr. Coffee be better then a $500 Italian machine? It is incredible easy to make a perfect cup of coffee. You push a button and 1 minute later have a perfect latte or espresso. It's very easy to tweak it as well, you want more coffee less milk, or more milk less coffee, or just frothed milk for cocoa or just a shot of coffee...it's as easy as the push of a button. I have used this machine 2-3 times a day for 2 months and have had NO issues. Not one. Great great product.

Update: A year after purchasing this machine it stopped producing coffee. It still frothed milk but wouldn't build up enough pressure for coffee. They sent me a new one. That was wonderful except that here I am another year later and the exact same thing has happened. I only only use distilled water and make 2 cups/day. This is a wonderful machine if you can afford to buy a new one each year.
title: My review updated 2 years into ownership.
bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Espresso/Cappuccino Maker

review_content:
This machine is my new best friend.

I bought it because I don't really like the quality of the coffee my K-Cup machine produced (and I've tried many different brands). This machine only takes up slightly more space on my counter, and even though I haven't tried fresh grounds yet, I'm really impressed with the output. I find that as long as I remove my mug right when the brew finishes, I don't end up with any unfiltered grounds in the cup.

A few negatives: this machine is a bit on the loud side (moreso than the average coffee maker), and there isn't much margin for error on your mug size. If you brew a double-shot, the average mug will nearly overflow, and there isn't enough room for most thermoses. But the former isn't an issue for me, and all the latter means is that I need to shop for new mugs.

Overall, I'm very pleased so far. I just ordered whole beans and some syrup flavorings to try. I can't comment at this point how well the machine holds up over time, as I've only had it a week.
title: I'm in love.
bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Espresso/Cappuccino Maker

review_content:
Update: I wish you could control the milk temp. Ive qlso found that I can only leave milk in the milk container for two days if I make one coffee a day, otherwise it spoils! Make sure you clean milk container pieces well!!
love my cafe barista!! The only two changes I would recommed would be a sturdier handle for the espresso/ coffee portion along with coffee tamper. The machine could be a little more stylish as well. Honestly after reading tons of reviews for $200-$500 espresso machines I can‚Äôt say enough good about it! Its already lessened my coffee trips on the run to virtually none!! Great flavored coffee, good warranty. The only think latte lovers may not like is hoq much froth it makes in your latte but you can always skim that off- doesnt bother me!
I love that you can customize the amount of milk/ froth and cuatolize the shot pull. This was a great buy!!

Mark this review a helpful if you find it to be

review_content: This product is not safe to use! Operation knob broke in 3 days(they use silicon for knob check out my photos), but I've never drunk an espresso from this machine because small metal pieces were coming from the water boiler every time I started the machine. I thought this is temporary, but I run the machine at least 15 times, but mini pieces kept coming check out my photos. Low quality machine, I don't recommend to buy this. Don't risk your health.
title: Health Hazard
bought_model: Color: CappuccinoStyle Name: 4-Cup Steam

review_content:
been using it twice daily for the last month since I bought this. Makes terrific foam that you can vary from latte to Cappucino and anyplace in between with the little adjustment knob.

The first time I used it, I forgot to raise the little milk froth pipe to shoot into the cup and it shot foamy milk all over the counter and floor. (So I am careful to remember that step now).

Love that you can just hit the latte or cappucino button and sit down while it makes the magic happen.
I have a couple of older manual type foaming machines and when my back is hurting, don't like to stand there that long messing with the foam. This machine is a dream. Once you get the little routine down pat, it is simple and fast to enjoy a latte in just a couple minutes.

Just pop the milk dispenser back in the fridge after using. And clean everything once a week. They also have the self cleaning feature button that gets used once a week.

I hope it lasts a long time. So far it is perfect. And it looks rather nice on the counter. And the price was pretty good for such a machine.

I went out and bought a bunch of coffee cups that fit the machine better than what I had in the cupboard.

I did snug up the little screw on the filter that someone mentioned came loose on theirs.

Just adding my 2 cents worth. Enjoy.
title: Amazing machine
bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Espresso/Cappuccino Maker

review_content: Have you been wondering which espresso machine to buy to offset massive Starbucks debt? This is the one for you. Like you, we read all the reviews and fretted over whether we could froth our own milk (no) or cared about real espresso vs. pods (yes). Just buy this one. We've had it for 2 weeks and have made at least one latte or shots for iced lattes a day. It's easy. Also, we just use the plastic tamper that came with it. So, really, just buy this machine, some espresso beans (ground or get a grinder), milk and drink a latte about 30 min. after UPS drops this at your door.
title: Get this one. Really.
bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Espresso/Cappuccino Maker

review_content:
I've been addicted to espresso for well over 20 years. Living out in the boonies usually meant making it at home or dropping by a local shop on the way to work. When making at home we used the steam espresso makers for many years. The espresso was OK, but the crema was thready and short lived.

My first ECMP50 lasted about two years. I always had to worry about over packing the grounds or getting them too fine and at times would have to start over because the machine was unable to pump the water through the grounds. I always wondered why it couldn't get the water through the grounds as most machines are the 15 bar variety.

I bought my current machine 3 years and 1 month ago. This machine works much better (the other was weak in the pressure category) and I can tamp the grounds and not worry about the fineness of the grind. I use a Capresso burr grinder on the large end of the Extra Fine setting.

My wife and I each pull a double espresso shot every day. She prefers no-froth latte and I like my cappuccino. When friends are over they usually like a cappuccino. I have an out-of-town friend who spends every week day morning at his local Starbucks with his cronies and says the caps I make are as good or better than theirs and he usually has two.

I do very little maintenance on this. Just an occasional cleaning of the drip area of the machine where the grounds come in contact with it.

I fill my coffee cup a hair under half with milk and use the frothing tube without the rubber tip. Just keep the surface of the milk half way up the bulb at the end of the tube and you'll end up with a cup of micro-bubble froth to dump your espresso in.

You really can't find a better espresso maker for the money, and I'm begging to think for any amount of money.
title: Great espresso maker and an even better bargain.
bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Automatic Dual Shot

review_content: Unfortunately I would not recommend this machine to anyone primarily looking for a "Latte" maker. I bought it for the sole purposes of making my lattes' and it ultimately performed horribly. Specifically the issue is with the milk frothing mechanism. Everything worked fine for the first couple of weeks but after that, the machine stopped distributing the milk the way it is supposed to. It would barely distribute any milk at all OR it would distribute WAY too much milk to the point of constantly overflowing. I did clean and trouble shoot all the possible scenarios with the customer support and even they recommended I send it back. To make matters worse, this is the THIRD time I have had to replace this machine for the exact same issue. I wanted this machine to continue to work because when it was working correctly, it was absolutely the best. Unfortunately, there must be some inherent problem with the frothing mechanism because I do not believe that it is just bad luck 3 times in a row. I can't speak to the other types of drinks on the machine because I only used it for Lattes.

One thing to note is that the cord to the unit is pretty short -- and this is by design. The cord length is about 6 inches, and it can only be plugged in one way. There are specific instructions on how to use the espresso machine and a lot of warnings, but don't be fearful, the unit is pretty easy to work with only three settings: off, make espresso and steam - so its pretty easy to operate, and surprisingly quiet. Bravo to Mr.Coffee for making an espresso machine for under $40 that holds up well.

review_content:
Man, I love this machine. I'm a cappuccino connoisseur of sorts, always in search of a great cup anywhere, and I think I've found one in Mr. Coffee's ECMP50. It's so inexpensive, yet it makes a brilliant cappuccino. Some very good and thorough reviews have already been written, but I want to express how excited I am about Mr. Coffee, right now.

The espresso maker produces an excellent crema. You gotta watch the brew, so you can manually shut it off when the drip starts to look weak. The measuring scoop has a tamper that works great, so you don't really need to buy one.

Being a first time frother, it took me three times to get the frothing right (using soy milk,) and boy is it glorious once you get it going. I just use a plastic, refrigerated cup for my "milk pitcher", and it works perfectly. One thing the instructions don't specify, for some reason, is that the water reservoir must be filled before testing the steamer. Also, I don't use the rubber tip on the steamer at all.

Overall, this cappuccino maker is real easy to use and cleaning up is a cinch. AWEsome. I highly recommend it!!

review_content:
I'm a big cappuccino drinker. I also used to work at a couple of coffee shops. Of course, my dream machine costs well over 1k, so I've been looking for a nice pump machine that doesn't cost a fortune. I got this one for my office, because I got tired of running out to starbucks in the middle of the day and wasting money. I have a Cuisinart EM 200 at home which I also like very much, but I wanted something a little easier and more automate for work, because I don't have time to stand and steam milk for a couple of minutes.
I JUST LOVE THIS machine. It's so easy and quick to use. You push one button and it does everything for you, and you still use whatever coffee you want and the milk you want. I did a lot of research, and was tempted to buy a capsule machine, but after trying out pretty much everything out there I was not a fan, because then you either have to get a separate milk frother, or use the dry milk capsules, and you don't get the coffee you like because you're typically stuck with a limited selection of capsules and certain brands only accept certain ones. I love to be able to use my own espresso, whether it's starbucks, illy, lavazza, etc. and my own organic milk. It's just great - you can customize the amount of espresso, and You can adjust the froth while it frothes to get either more foam or more milk. Or just push a button and it does premeasured amounts, which I found out are just right for me. And you can use pods if you don't want to make a mess pouring coffee.

I do recommend running the machine through a couple of times with water, otherwise you'll get a little bit of plastic taste - being brand new - it is to be expected.
I'm also pleasantly surprised that it is not loud at all. My cuisinart makes way more noise.
title: I'm impressed

review_content:
Hello Everyone,

This being my first espresso machine ever, I can honestly say I absolutely love it! Say goodbye to Starbucks and all those other name brand coffee's. Once you start making your own at home, nothing else will taste the same. A few tips that I've learned with this machine:

1. Get rid of that useless rubber tube. It is much easier to use and clean with out it
2. Have your beans ground fresh and fairly fine and keep them stored in a sealed container. Make sure to use the proper serving, but pack it really tight...trust me this works!
3. Froth your milk first before running the espresso. The steam may take a bit longer to get going than the hot water. I usually pack in my beans, then froth the milk to about 165-170 degrees (make sure the milk is cold before starting to froth), then run the espresso.

4. Frothing milk takes practice, so don't be discouraged if you don't get it right the first time
5. Buy a small stainless steal canter with a thermostat to froth your milk. I picked mine up at Target

Also, keep a clean wet rag or paper towel near by to clean the steam nozzle after frothing, it'll get baked on very quickly!

I've worked in fine dinning for a long time , so I've gotten pretty good at making espresso.

For those of you thinking of getting a starter or a mid range espresso machine....this is a winner!!!

review_content:
I had to return a pump driven espresso maker that stopped working after 5 brews, and the question came up again: do I really need a pump driven system (in general a more complex system, and more expensive system, and more failure prone system), or will a steam driven system work for me? The main reason for a pump as I understand, is the keep the brew temperature somewhat below the boiling point so as to get the best tasting coffee, quoted as 92-96 degrees C (197.6-204.8 F). Now, how important that is, or how discerning a taste you have to have to be able to tell the difference, or how important the temperature variable is compared to the type of coffee bean your are using, e.t.c. I do not know. (But I am certain it's discussed in some blog out there.) At sea level under normal condition the water boiling point is about 212 degree F. At the elevation my coffee is being brewed (5500ft) the boiling point is 202 F. As a steam coffee maker builds up pressure the steam temperature has to rise. But how much pressure is needed (and how much will the temperature rise?) The pump driven espresso maker specifications mention 15 bar or 217.5 psi! That certainly is a very high value, a nonsense value used by marketing (your car tires run on 25 to 50 psi). I would think that 5 to 10 psi would do the trick. (To test this wild guess one could mount a 12 ft -generating about 5 psi- pvc tube filled with water over the coffee basket and time a shot). To generate 5 psi at my altitude of 5500ft a steam machine would have to raise brewing water temperature by about 15 degree F above boiling temperature. (from tables published on the Web I figured a (Delta F/delta psi)=3). Boiling temperature here is 202, add the 15 and get 217 degree F, which is 12 F above the supposed ideal brewing range of 198 to 205. And ist somewhat more than a drip coffee maker uses at seal level. So, no clear answer and some guess work. But a placement of a steam machine at high altitude goes in the right direction.
Now to my Mr. Coffee steam espresso maker, especially what I like about it (other than the very modest price): A coffee basket large enough to brew up to four shot/cups worth of espresso, just right for us two. Due to this amount no heating-up-run of the machine is required. Generates enough pressure to use rather fine grind with slight tamping. You can measure the amount of water into the boiler and thus need not attend the process to stop the flow. The coffe basket seal does not accumulate coffe ground and/or is easy to clean. Negatives? I figured to remove the plastic tube covering the steam wand as it really inhibits proper steam jet action and only causes a nasty sounding bubbling action. And be very careful when you open the lid of the water reservoir when the machine is hot. In the instructions it says "release the pressure first" but I cannot figure out how to do that. When I open the steam wand to release pressure the boiler turns on at the same time. So you would have to unplug the machine first (what a nuisance). So I protect my hand with a potholder. It helps to be somewhat ambidextrous so that you can operate the steam/brew selector on the left and the pressure vessel lid on the top, both requiring a bit of strength. Those knobs have an interesting shape, almost ergonomic.
title: Steam or pump driven espresso maker?

First thing that happened - I primed it like it said butt..sometimes when you fill the water reservoir it still leaked all over the place and I couldn't get it to stop. Prime it again It may take a couple times. I also filled it when it was pumping and had suction and lightly pressed down on tank to secure seal..that seemed to really work it hasn't leaked in weeks. Months later something else just developed. I cleaned it with waterfall the time like directions said but it still clogged and wouldn't suck the water up this morning. ugh. like me you love your coffee and it wasn't happening. I didn't give up. Place white vinegar in milk container and run on manual froth 2x or until it starts to flow. This worked for me. Remember to run clear water thru until vinegar smell no longer present.BTW my clean cycle no longer works thats why froth cycle worked. I am writing this with excellent cup of coffee in hand. title: ... an expresso machine for Christmas and this one is terrible. It smells and taste like chemicals despite several ...

review_content:
This is a great unit for the price and it produces great espresso!
I have read on several sites that reviewers report a leak on the counter shortly after the unit is done being used.

Here is what I have discovered and how this issue seems to be be resolved.

Keep in mind your espresso has a pressurized pump inside. Generally most pumps will retain water depending on the type of pump it will retain a lot of water or a little water in the pump base.. What appears to happen as the pressure is released this water drains out to the drip tray and then over flows depending on the amount present. and it may leak out on the bottom holes of the unit as well.

The fix
Like any good pump care, one should drain the pump when finished.
To do this remove the water holder from the back of the unit, and pour the remaining water out. so the holder is empty.
Press the Steam button on the front of the unit. Wait for the green steam light to become solid
Turn the function knob to steam, you will have quite a bit of water left in the pump that will steam off
Turn the control knob back to the center position once the steamer quits steameaning.
Turn off the power switch so the pump doesn't run empty.
This will empty the pump totally of water.

Keep in mind doing this will mean you will have to prime the pump each first use of the machine again. by pressing the steam button and turning the control knob to steam and letting the pump pull in fresh water from your filled holder.

But this should get rid of the water issue if you totally empty the pump and holder after each use.

P.S make sure you have a cup under the steamer!

When priming the pump let it steam for about 30 to 60 seconds.
title: Solved Leak issue some people report

review_content:
The fact that this little machine was just short of $40 (at Walmart) overrides all of the cons, for me.
I'm not a connoisseur, but I do enjoy a quality mug of coffee, and I think this will satisfy most people with my mindset.

Pros:
- Relatively stylish, doesn't look too bad sitting on my counter.
- Milk steamer's powerful and froths my milk (some reviews say it doesn't, and is slow; mine frothed my milk easily, even 1%, and heated it to a good temperature in under 30 seconds).
- Makes a top notch cappuccino, better than Starbucks, at least.
- With the right batch of coffee, you can achieve a nice crema (contrary to other reviews, I did this rather easily).
- Really, really easy to use.
- Pays for itself, really.

Cons:
- Doesn't pull the absolute best espresso, if you solely drink espresso, perhaps this isn't the best machine for you. But, I like a shot of espresso every now and then and it satisfies me and my budget, but I wouldn't rely on it if that's all I drank and had money to throw around.
- The milk steamer's a little awkward, it's not long enough and doesn't extend that far away from the machine, but, it's not a deal breaker.
- Doesn't come with a tamper. Buy one. It'll make a world of difference.
- It took me absolutely ages to get the plastic smell/taste out of my coffee. A minor annoyance. I got best results with running lemon juice and diluted vinegar solutions through the machine a few times.

Bottom line, I love this machine, for the price you really can't go wrong. I'd recommend it to anyone.
title: Can't go wrong for the price
bought_model: Color: CappuccinoStyle Name: 4-Cup Steam

review_content:
I have been using the Mr. Coffee Espresso maker to make lattes for my wife for two years now. I have earned serious marriage points and the family coffee funds are not in the red!

I bought the unit at Target for $25 - on sale. The first unit soon failed to heat and was returned. The replacement has worked without a problem if cleaned properly (see below). Mr. Coffee makes a more modern looking unit that might use the same internals - if you want a different look for about the same $40 price. It lacks the top surface to store parts.

What follows are some functional characteristics I have discovered during continued use, Then I detail the procedure I have developed.
- The steamer will work after the espresso is made without needing additional water. I presume that the outlet from the tank going to the espresso plate is above the level of the bottom of the tank. This leaves you with pressure and water to steam milk for the latte. Don't open the top of the machine while it is hot and pressurized.

- Get a tamper that fits the cup and compress the grounds. I started with using the spoon, then a spice jar and then got an aluminum tamper and milled the circumference until it fit deep enough.

- The foaming arm will clog unless cared for. If the steamed milk is not rinsed from the arm and plastic cover it will get suctioned up into the arm as the steam/air cools. Once dried, you are in for a serious clog.

My Procedure for a one cup (10-11 fl oz) latte:
- I measure carbon filtered cold water from the fridge with the included carafe. Halfway between the "2" and the "4" lines. Don't overfill the tank.
- Very Fine (Turkish or espresso) ground espresso blend or other dark roasted coffee is required. I fill the filter basket with a bit over one scoop and use my tamp to firmly compact the grounds. I have started to add a few drops of water to moisten the grounds to improve the proportion of crema the unit produces. Unlike typical units - the heating element does not heat unless the valve is opened to the basket or the steaming arm. It empties when enough pressure builds up to make it flow. ***If the grounds are too porous, then pressure doesn't build up enough to create much crema at all.*** I turn the unit off when the carafe fills to the '2' mark - if the tank started with the right amount of water then steam is what is coming out of the espresso side. But there is still water available for steaming below the water outlet. Do not open the tank because it is pressurized with steam.
- Start foaming milk/soy/cream etc. The plastic cover recirculates the milk outside the nozzle helping to create more froth. While I am doing this with my right hand I empty a coffee cup of hot water used to prewarm it and empty the espresso into the cup. There is still time to empty and rinse the basket and fill the carafe with water to rinse the foaming head. I stop foaming milk when it gets too hot to touch/hold the stainless foaming pitcher towards the botttom. The milk should be starting to foam nicely at this temperature.
-Immediately steam the water in the carafe to rinse the nozzle so it doesn't clog with dried cooked milk. I pull the black cover off and use a brush and the carafe together to clean the scalded milk from the nozzle before it becomes rock hard - saves time to do it immediately.
-Pour the foamed milk into the cup with the espresso and dash the foam on top. Deliver to your wife as she is shuting off her alarm clock.
title: Great for the cost!

review_content:
This is a mixed review. The five stars are deserved by the Mr. Coffee franchise for their prompt replacement of a cappuccino maker that failed after approximately 2 months of service. In fact, I may have been at fault by not turning off/unplugging the machine after use, as stated in the user guide. The replacement works fine and I have found no need to buy or grind coffee beans to make a great cup of coffee. In fact, I use regular grind arabica beans, right out of the can and they make an aromatic, delicious, strong cup of coffee every time. I have only used the steamer side of the machine one time and it seemed to work just fine. Lattes are not my particular preference. Now, to the balance of my review. I originally bought this machine several months before I actually put it to use. When it failed, I frankly expected to have to "eat" the machine (kudos to Mr. Coffee), so I ordered a second one. It arrived and was put into service right away and it continues to work just fine.
What is troubling, tho, is the fact that I am certain both machines I received from Amazon had previously been rejected and returned by other customers. The first machine arrived, packaged with a stainless steel 1-cup measure that makes brewing easier. However, according to the product carton and the printed instructions, no such cup was included in the packaging.?? The second machine arrived with no stainless cup and also no coffee measure, which I am certain the Chinese would not have failed to include.
When buying products from a mass marketeer, such as Amazon, you should expect to be on the receiving end of previously returned merchandise, once in a while. However, it should be made a point to include all originally furnished parts, accessories and instructions as was originally packaged. So Boo to Amazon on this issue. No actual problem, tho. Since I still had the broken machine, I secured the coffee measure from that one.
title: The replacement works fine and I have found no need to buy or ...

First I would say take the little black plastic piece of the frothing wand off. All it did was make a mess. Otherwise this machine makes a great latte. I use rice milk for mine and it makes foam just fine. I would ad a tip if anyone has a problem with the steam wand not working as usually; You have to take it off and clean it with some vinegar once in awhile. Mine didn't seem to steam very well last week so I had to stop in the middle of making my coffee and clean the tip out. I think milk can get stuck in there since the hole is a little bigger than a needle. The coffee scoop that comes with the machine is a wrench on the handle end for that purpose.

If you want to save money get your own machine and have fun.

title: I have purchased two of these machines and will NEVER ...
bought_model: Color: CappuccinoStyle Name: 4-Cup Steam

review_content:
Bought this after all the raving reviews i read, and i'm glad to report that everyone was right. Thank you. What a fabulous product! Great espesso, yes, with creamy top when using the right blend for your brew. The milk frother is flawless, thick-n-creamy and you can fill a 450ml cup in just seconds. Easy to clean, excellent design, and although its plastic, its feels and looks like quality.

Like some other reviewers stated, i did not notice a plastic scent; at least nothing out of the ordinary (it is plastic after all). I had some trouble with the start-up since i didnt read the manual (dumb) .. it seems you have to blow it through with water the first time you use it. So, fill everything up and let it steam for a while on all three modes. Do this please, otherwise it wont work and you'll be like, what? no. I dont know if anyone else is hearing this little bleeeeep when electricity goes to the pump, but i asked around and that seems to be normal. Its building up pressure.

Highly recommended, even more so considering the mixed reviews of other (more expensive) machines. This is my first one, and i'm very happy with the results. Again, thanks to all the previous reviewers. Go for it, if you're on the look-out for a budget performer.

*** UPDATE 10 SEPTEMBER, REPLACEMENT

Sadly i had to return my machine. The whistle got worse, it leaked water by just turning it on (at the brew head) and the portafilter broke. The machine was on full force for about three months, rinsed it with vinegar once to keep it going, no problems and no complaints other than the whistle. After the leaking and broke portafilter i returned it and just got my replacement in. No whistle, no leaking and new portafilter. Lets see how far this one goes. Keep your invoice, just in case.
title: Easy does it! (update; i had it replaced)

review_content:
I bought this to replace my Melitta MEX1B.
This Mr. Coffee unit has some decent features like a small footprint and pleasing looks, but after two weeks of daily use I find I do not get the same espresso results each time. Sometimes the espresso tastes stronger and more burnt than other times.
I only use a separate Capresso milk frothing machine.
My big complaint is with the knobs on this Mr. Coffee maker. The top knob is almost impossible for me to remove by hand.
I now use a rubber cap remover to do this job with.
The knob is tapered and very smooth, with almost nothing to grasp onto, especially with my big hand.
So, after two weeks of use, I am now shopping again for a base model pump espresso maker and returning this steam model for a refund.
Or, I may just get another replacement caraf for my MEX1B.

review_content:
I bought this espresso maker for my wife as a gift. I chose this product because it seems to offer the most bang for your buck in terms of features.

As I was researching espresso machines, I started to notice that a lot of the machines seemed time consuming. I have also heard many stories about families that have dumped big $$$ into an espresso machine, then stopped using it because it was too time consuming to actually make yourself a beverage. (I remember the first home espresso machine I ever saw in person. It took the owner 20+ minutes to make me a drink. I remember thinking that seemed ridiculous. I also remember that espresso machine sitting unused for years after the novelty wore off.) Knowing how busy my family is, I did not want to fall into this same boat.

The Mr. Coffee Cafe Barista is great for a busy family. I can turn it on, press a few buttons, then return a few minutes later to a fresh brewed delicious espresso beverage. Not only is it convenient, but the beverage tastes great too. After you have finished brewing the beverage, cleanup is a breeze. Again, push a button, then the machine is cleaned. Also, the milk container easily separates from the machine and can be placed in the fridge to keep your milk fresh. I'm sure other espresso machines are great (and they better be for the price) but this one won out, hands down, in the convenience department.

Another feature that was important to me was I DID NOT want a pod based machine. I have a pod based coffee maker, and the truth is we don't use it because the pods are really expensive. Yes it is convenient, but the cost will eat through the average checking account just about as quickly as a daily run to your favorite coffee spot. Also, many of the pod based espresso makers require two pods (coffee and dairy) to make your beverage (see MORE $$$)! It is not a big deal to get coffee beans ground for an espresso machine, then tamp your grounds into the machine.

A few other thoughts. The machine comes with a recipe book. I've tried a few, they are delicious (Nutella Latte!). You can brew a single or double shot! The machine feels quality built and very durable. The machine is loud, but I would imagine anything including a milk steamer would be (just imagine how loud they are at Starbucks, now imagine that in your kitchen). If you can't stand noisy appliances, I would avoid this machine. Tamping your own espresso can be messy until you get used to it. Be prepared to spill some grounds and such as you learn.

The bottom line is, I believe this machine will put an end to our ritualistic weekend Starbucks runs. I did the math. This machine will pay for itself within a couple months.
title: Great Espresso Machine for a great value!
bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Espresso/Cappuccino Maker

I ordered this item by mistake due to that I did not read several 1-star reviews saying that this machine exploded after a few use. I just do not want to take the risk; therefore, I simply return it immediately without opening the box. If you only want to make a couple of good espresso or moka cups of coffee at home, try the stove top espresso maker, which costs between $17 to $25. IMHO, those are the most simple and efficient way to make you personal size espresso or moka cups of coffee. I ordered a "Bialetti Moka Express Made in Italy" and I am really happy with it. I may even write a 5-star review for this item. Since I did some research about coffee lately, I just realized that coffee making can be as complicated as you want it to be, but don't forget the KISS principle. Good luck to all of you and your coffee enthusiasm.

We've owned it since July and make no less than two cups per day (sometimes more). We have been extremely happy with it. The taste is excellent. The ease of use and time required is perfect.

In the past couple of weeks, I have noticed it is starting to make some strange sounds, but as of now (5 months later) it is still working perfectly. All the other reviews stated the machine usually breaks around 10 months but it comes with a 12 month warranty.

If you are looking to try an espresso machine for the first time, this is definitely the machine for you! If you want a good machine that you may have to replace on an annual basis, I would recommend this one as well!

It worked great for the short time it works. Steamed milk is perfect and the expresso good. Very easy to use and clean. The expresso function stopped working after 5 months, but the company replaced it with no difficulty. Will see how long the replacement lasts.
Update:
The replacement lasted 8 months before the espresso pump stopped working (just as the first one had). I contacted the company a few months later and they would not replace (it had been 13 months).
So if you want a coffee maker that lasts less than a year you will get nice coffee for the short time it lasts. Better in the long run to buy one that lasts longer.

review_content: I purchased this machine on November 17, 2012 as a gift after doing a TON of research.  I read all the negative reviews and purchased the 2 year warranty because I expected it to break in some way, regardless the price was still very low in comparison to other machines.  It's now over 2 years later and I've never had an issue with the machine.  Not only has nothing broke after over 2 years of daily use, but it doesn't leak either like many have reported.  At the end of the machines cycle, some water is ejected into the bottom tray but the tray is perfect at collecting it and I never find puddles on the counter.  I feel this machine makes a quick, good cup of espresso and you can easily control how much you want to fill into your cup.  It's easy to load, comes with a scoop and stamper and the metal cup that holds the espresso with locking mechanism fell very sturdy.  We've already got our moneys worth out of this machine and I have hopes that it will last a couple more years.
title: Awesome machine going strong for years!
bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Automatic Dual Shot

review_content:
I bought this because my dunkin donuts mocha latte habit was really beginning to add up. What a great purchase! I can now make hot mocha latte's comparable to the dunkin donuts ones (almost as good as paneras). I did buy a tamper to pack down the coffee grinds. At first it's a little confusing (directions are bad) - on how to use the frother. Here's what I do...fill the water up to the 2cup mark and then a little more water (this is what you'll use to steam). Turn to brew, when once espresso hits the 2cup mark on pot, switch it to off. Then get your milk cup ready to froth and turn the dial to steam. Problem is you never know how much extra water to add to get the right amount of steam. I also think it's a pain to clean up the frother.

So here's what I do to make a delicious hot mocha latte:
1. fill pot up to 2cup mark with water, pour in water reservoir
2. use tamper to pack down ground espresso beans (lavazza is good, 6.99/can at grocery store)
3. turn to brew
4. meanwhile, heat my milk in coffee mug (2/3 full in 16oz cup) - in microwave about 1:45/2min.
5. add a teaspoon of davinci chocolate sugar free syrup (or similar, like torani) to my hot milk cup
6. then pour in espresso and stir
YUM!

Whole thing takes about 4 min and clean up is a breeze. Much better than spending 2.64 a day at dunkin donuts.
I highly recommend this affordable espresso maker!

review_content: I worked at S-Bucks back in the day of a hand pulled shot. Their new electronic machines just don't cut it. This machine replicates that hand-pulled taste I've longed for. I owned an expensive S-Bucks machine and hated it. This machine pulls perfect shots with beautiful and tasty crema!! It froths milk easily, only room for improvement is if the steam wand could pull out in other positions but I'll live with it. Make sure to buy a PUMP driven machine if you want AUTHENTIC espresso, the others won't cut it! I'd recommended this as the perfect gift or addition to your home. You will be pleased. (Make sure to follow the step by step guide until you have it down and MAKE SURE to prime the pump!!)
title: Best Affordable Espresso Machine yet!
bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Automatic Dual Shot

review_content:
Do not let the 3-, 4-, and 5-star reviews fool you: this machine really is a plastic piece of junk. It's a cheap piece of junk to be sure, yes, but it's junk nonetheless.

To reiterate what other reviews have touched upon, the machine doesn't actually produce 'espresso', but rather a stronger cup of regular coffee--that is, the coffee's as thick and viscous as you'd expect instant coffee, tea, or water to be. The steamer works, but don't expect to get a lot out of it. The coffee machine also doesn't come with a tamper, so if you don't already have one, you can expect a good portion of your coffee grounds to be neglected / wasted every time you brew.

During the first 4 weeks of having the machine, all of that was fine. The coffee wasn't spectacular by any measure, but it was passable. More importantly, the machine actually worked.

1 month + 1 day after delivery, however, the machine stopped working completely. The espresso dispenser no longer functions; the steamer no longer steams; the heating element no longer heats. The whole thing simply died. And all this happened exactly 1 day past the return / exchange date.

In short, buyer beware. I'll be recommending that my own friends and family avoid the Mr. Coffee brand in the future.
title: Machine Died Exactly 1 Month + 1 Day After Delivery...

review_content:
After my own issues with reading the instructions to get past the "learning curve" I am absolutely impressed with how well this machine makes espresso, cappuccino (my favorite) and cafe latte.

While I don't use Mr. Coffee products for making my "Cafe Americano" because, for whatever reason, they refuse to use a "conical #4" coffee filter in any of their designs, the design engineers of this espresso/cappuccino/latte machine deserve compliments.

The machine not only works amazingly well, but it was well thought out for "ease of cleaning" as all of the parts that might ordinarily be "difficult to clean" are completely able to be thoroughly disassembled for thorough and complete cleaning.

Most of the wetted components are full stainless-steel.

It is also very nice how the separate milk-storage container is easily removable for storage in the refrigerator until its next use.

I highly recommend this product.

review_content:
There's a reason this item is a fraction of the price of other coffee makers: it's cheap garbage. The gaskets are inadequate to hold the steam pressure during brewing, steam frequently leaks out the top, and on one occasion the filter assembly started to loosen itself. It would not surprise me in the least if this thing blew up in my face. As for the quality of the coffee it brews: it just ain't espresso. Espresso should have crema, a frothy 'head' like in a glass of beer. Espresso should be viscous and bittersweet, with a distinct texture different from pour over coffee. This machine does not make proper espresso, just very strong drip coffee.
Also the milk steamer is poorly designed, it has a sort of vented sleeve that goes over the actual wand; milk builds up in the space between, and turns into a gross brown scum after just a couple of uses.
Save some money and buy a proper espresso maker; I wish I had.

About a year ago I purchased this machine at Target for $30. I loved it, worked great, frothed milk was perfect, quick, simple, and kept me happy throughout my busy schedule. I was able to save a lot of money because I stopped going to Starbucks for my lattes.

review_content: Just chiming in to write my first product review. I didn't buy this on Amazon, but like many others went the Bed,Bath and Beyond route and snagged it for about $160.00. I love this product! It is as close as you will get to an automatic espresso maker without spending hundreds or thousands more. All you do is fill the filter and push your desired button. The milk frothes excellent and the espresso extracts perfectly. I tend to use pre-ground espresso such as Illy and Lavazza (I look for sales), or a lesser known brand named Dalmeyer (sp?) from Germany. It fits a full size mug for my double latte or cappuccino and I don't have to mess with the milk anymore. After I finish my cup, I put it back under the machine, turn the milk valve to "clean", run the clean cycle and put the milk container back in the fridge. I was in Macy's and I saw a Nespresso machine (which uses pods) with an almost identical milk frothing unit, but the cost was $599! This thing is a bargain, and if you are one of those people who does still get their latte from a Starbucks or Barneys, I would think this unit will pay for itself in 4 to 6 weeks. Enjoy!

review_content:
At my house we have gone through quite a few espresso makers. My husband is a daily user - using it up to 2-3 times daily and I occasionally make a chai-tea latte.

This Mr. Coffee machine far-exceeded our expectations. It makes a great shot of espresso - with varying degrees of strength, based on our chosen setting. The temperature is nice and hot and the water tank holds the water without spilling or leaking.

My husband never uses the frothier on espresso machines because it makes a mess and is not worth the effort to clean up for the output received. However, with this machine and the easy removable milk tank - he uses the frothier. For me, it is one of the key components to a chai-tea latte, so it is nice that this one is so efficient.

For the price and the capacity to which this machine performs, I highly recommend!

bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Espresso/Cappuccino Maker

review_content:
I loved this machine when I first got it. Eventually the piece of on the end of the steamer wand broke off after a year- making the steamer useless. So I used it for just espresso for the following year. One day, while trying to make a coffee all of the lights lit up, and just kept blinking. So I called the Mr. Coffee, they gave me a repair shop phone number- I called, they said the unit was not designed to be repaired, and that I should by a better machine.

Works good for 2 years- then it just died, and there are no repair options.

Highly recommend it. P.S. Make sure you push the button and wait for the (green lights to light up when changing from steam to brew)
title: Highly recommend this Mr. coffee
bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Automatic Dual Shot

review_content:
I've owned one of these machines for almost three years now. It makes great espresso with wonderful crema and is very easy to use. Although others have experienced leaking problems, I have not. I've never had a problem with it that could not be solved by a good cleaning with vinegar. So, why only two stars?

There is no way to buy a replacement filter basket. The bottom of the metal perma filter is two seperate but attached layers - a top layer with many small perforations that allow water through, but keep coffee grounds in, and a bottom layer with one slightly larger hole in the center to allow the espresso out. The top layer has separated after three years of use, and the perma filter is impossible to use now because it gets clogged almost immediately, causing the seal to break and water to pour out around the sides when I try to make an espresso. I would completely understand that this small part has a limited lifespan, happily buy a replacement and give this product full stars - except that it is absolutely impossible to replace this simple part. Mr. Coffee does not have replacements available. The only replacement espresso filter they make will not fit this model, and I can find no others that will work with it. I even personally contacted the company, only to be told yep, I'm right, this part isn't available for separate purchase. So, because a $7 part is broken, I will have to pay for a completely new espresso machine. How does this make sense at all? At least I got 3 years out of it, but since the filter basket is small, it would also be an easy part to lose. Since there's no convenient place to store the basket on this model, if you keep the filter basket in a kitchen drawer, this is a distinct possibility. Imagine that you spent $80 on this thing, lost the filter basket after a couple of weeks, and then what?

I would happily buy another one of these based on performance and size (ability to put a mug underneath the spout, ability to make more than one shot of quality espresso at a time). But, I just can't give Mr. Coffee my money again in good conscience. The machine still WORKS, why should I have to buy another one just to get this one part? It's the most ridiculous thing I've ever heard of, and it really deserves only one star because of this huge marketing flaw, but I've loved this machine for so long that I just can't do it. So, two stars it is. Buy it if you're willing to keep the filter basket sitting on top of the machine where it won't get lost, and don't mind shelling out another chunk of money just for a tiny part after 3 years or so.
title: Great machine, if you don't mind buying a new one when you need a $6 part

title: Worked perfectly almost 5 years!
bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Automatic Dual Shot

review_content:
In a very confusing world of espresso/cappuccino makers, this is a solid buy. I read tons of reviews, and based on those, I chose this machine for these reasons:

1. Powerful steam feature. Most reviews pointed toward this as an important feature, and this machine has a pump to create powerful steam.
2. Short "warm-up" period. Many machines that are powerful take a long time to warm up. I turn this on, and by the time I've gathered my ingredients, it's ready to go.
3. A standard-size coffee cup fits under the drip spout.

Those were the reasons I purchased it. I discovered several other nice features after buying it.

1. It's very easy to use. The manual itself is helpful, and the instructions are easy to do. My 9-year-old son regularly makes me lattes with this machine.
2. Even though it's tall enough to fit a standard mug, it's not bulky or oversized.
3. Everything except the frothing wand is easy to clean.
4. It's very economical.

I'm really trying to think of any "cons," and the only ones I can come up with are:
1. You don't get any accessories with it (except the tamper), but then, most of the machines don't come with those anyway.
2. Although a standard coffee mug will fit under the spout, novelty mugs that are just a little taller won't.

Other reviews say that they've had problems with leaks. I haven't.

A hint if you purchase this machine: the manual says that, to clean the frothing wand, hold a cup of water under it and steam the water. I've found this isn't really sufficient. But we keep a clean toothbrush near the machine, and if you scrub the frother a little WHILE steaming the water, it comes clean quite well. Allthe other parts remove easily to be washed.

I definitely recommend this machine.
title: Lots of Pros; few cons
bought_model: Color: SilverStyle Name: Automatic Dual Shot

review_content: You get exactly what you pay for with this espresso machine. The housing and all components are made of low-grade plastic which will not stand the test of time. The pressure and temperature generated inside the handle compartment produce mediocre-tasting espresso. The unit does, however, make a cup of black stuff known as coffee. I would recommend this machine if you are desparate to save money and/or in an environment where people will mistreat the device.
